DOC.HEADLINE: Penghu residents may soon decide fate of casinos on islands
DOC.DATELINE: Penghu, July 31 (CNA) 07/31/09 23:13:38 (By Kao Mau-hsiung and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Penghu County residents may soon have the chance to decide whether the outlying island group will allow casinos to be built there, as the initiators of a referendum on the issue have collected a sufficient number of signatures to put it to a vote.

Lang Chun-yi, president of the Penghu County Business Council and concurrently acting speaker of the county assembly, said Friday that the initiators have collected a total of 3,853 signatures and sent the petition to the county election commission for verification.
He said the county government must hold a referendum within two months if the signatures are validated.

Expecting that a referendum will be held in mid-September, Lang said the county government has budgeted NT$8 million (about US$242,000) for the vote, and the special budget plan will pass the county assembly next week.
Gambling has long been banned in Taiwan, but the Legislative Yuan passed legislation on Jan. 12 to legalize casino gambling on outlying islands.
Since then, Penghu's business community has been keen to introduce the casino business to the relatively resource-deficient islands.
Many Penghu residents, however, have a different outlook on their home islands' economic development, fearing that gambling may instigate criminal activity.

Because receiving popular approval in a direct vote is a prerequisite for the county government to issue operating licenses, businessmen initiated the drive to collect signatures in February so that a referendum could be held at the earliest possible date.

According to the Referendum Law, a referendum in a county is possible when no less than 5 percent of the voters who cast ballots in the most recent county magistrate election have signed the petition.
A total of 70,427 votes were cast in the 2005 magistrate election, meaning at least 3,522 signatures were needed.

Consisting of some 90 small isles, the Penghu archipelago is seated off the western coast of Taiwan in the Taiwan Strait. Tourism has been an important source of revenue for the county of 93,000 residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ruling on ex-first daughter's travel ban to be issued Aug. 3

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court is scheduled to hand down a ruling Monday on whether to lift an overseas travel ban on former President Chen Shui-bian's daughter, judicial sources said Friday.

In the course of investigating perjury charges against Chen Hsing-yu in connection with a case against the former president, prosecutors imposed an overseas travel ban on the former first daughter in June.

Chen Hsing-yu later appealed the ruling. A panel of three judges at the district court is scheduled to hold a hearing Aug. 3 to decide whether to remove or uphold the travel ban, a court official said.
Prosecutors indicted Chen Hsing-yu on perjury charges July 17. Also indicted in the case were her husband Chao Chien-ming and her younger brother Chen Chih- chung.
Her mother, former first lady Wu Shu-jen, was also charged with coercing her children to give false testimony in the corruption case against the former president.

Prosecutors of the Special Investigation Division of the Supreme Prosecutors Office found inconsistencies in the testimony given in May by Chen Chih-chung, Chen Hsing-yu and Chao Chien-ming in their probe into the former president's alleged misuse of public funds during his term in office from 2000 through May 2008.

The indictment said the three lied to prosecutors when they claimed that the receipts they provided to Wu to claim reimbursement from the president's special state affairs fund were for gifts they bought for their parents.

Despite the indictment, prosecutors from the Taipei District Prosecutors Office have asked the court to treat them leniently because they admitted their offenses during the probe in connection with perjury.
Wu also confessed that she urged her children to give false testimony to cover up her offenses.
Wu was indicted on bribery and embezzlement charges in November 2006 in a separate case, but prosecutors have not sought to detain the wheelchiar-bound former first lady.

Chen Shui-bian has been detained since last December on charges of corruption, money laundering and embezzlement -- crimes he is accused of committing during his presidency. The former presdient has insisted on his innocence, arguing history will clear his name.
The court is scheduled to hand down a ruling on his case Sept. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 1, or the 11th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: British chemist Sir Joseph Priestley announces that he has discovered oxygen.
1834: Robert Morrison, the first English missionary to go to China and translator of the Bible into Chinese, dies.
1894: War between China and Japan over the question of Korea breaks out. The Treaty of Shimonoseki was signed the next year, compelling the Ching court to pay a huge indemnity, open its seaports, recognize the independence of Korea, and cede the Liaotung Peninsula, Taiwan, and the Pescadores to Japan.
1915: The Peking government mints its silver coin, known as "Yuantatou," bearing the likeness of Yuan Shih-kai.
1926: Kwangtung University changes its name to National Sun Yat-sen University.
1927: The Chinese communists stage the Nanchang Uprising against the Nationalist government.
1928: The Central Broadcasting System is set up in Nanking by the Kuomintang.
1941: American volunteer aviators form the "Flying Tigers," with Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault as commander. They help China combat Japanese air superiority in the early stages of World War II.
1943: Lin Sen, chairman of the Nationalist government, dies at the age of 76.
1949: The Office of Tsungtsai (director general) of the Kuomintang is established in Taipei.
1958: An insurance program providing 180,000 government employees with coverage for maternity leave, illness, injury, disability and death is put into effect.
1966: The Chinese Communist Party opens a plenum meeting that declares the start of the 10-year Cultural Revolution.
1971: The Tainan Giants of the Republic of China win the Little League Asian and Pacific play-offs.
1973: The Economic Planning Council (EPC) of the Executive Yuan is inaugurated. The EPC replaces the Council for International Economic Cooperation and Development.
1973: Gen. Kao Kuei-yuan takes over from Gen. Cheng Ta-ching as the Republic of China's minister of national defense.
1976: The National Reconstruction Seminar opens in Taipei with 130 local and overseas Chinese scholars participating.
1984: ROC athlete Tsai Wen-yee wins a bronze medal in weightlifting at the 1984 Olympic Games.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves a slight increase in the premium rate of laborers' occupational injury insurance. The rates for thirty-two occupations are raised.
1987: The Council of Labor Affairs is formally established under the Executive Yuan.
1989: A foreign currency call loan market designed to make the metropolis an international financial center is established in Taipei.
1992: The National Unification Council defines "one China" as "one country and two areas each ruled separately by a different political entity."
1992: The Taiwan Garrison General Headquarters, the ROC's highest security institution, is disbanded, and the Coastal Patrol General Headquarters is established under the Ministry of National Defense.
1999: The U.S. Defense Department announces the sale of two E-2T Hawkeye 2000E airborne early warning aircraft and related equipment and services to Taiwan.
2000: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh pays a visit to New Party leader Hau Lung-bin, a move Hsieh said is aimed at showing respect to the opposition.
2000: Taiwan resident Huang You-fu becomes the 10 millionth traveler to pass through Macau International Airport.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By attending to the cleanliness and purity of his person and the propriety and dignity of his dress, and in every word and act permitting nothing which is contrary to good taste and decency, that is how the ruler puts in order his personal conduct."

DOC.HEADLINE: Locally produced H1N1 vaccine being tested on animals (roundup)

TEXT.P: Locally produced swine flu vaccines are being tested on animals and are expected to be ready for human inoculation in November at the earliest if all goes smoothly, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said Friday.

"Research on the swine flu or influenza A (H1N1) vaccine is proceeding smoothly and the producer -- Adimmune Corp. -- promises to deliver the product at the end of September. As the vaccine has to undergo clinical trials, it will not be ready for distribution until November at the earliest," Yeh explained.
The DOH has already ordered 5 million doses of the vaccine from the company, in which the government has a stake.

Yeh said the DOH has formed a special task force to monitor progress in vaccine research and development for the H1N1 flu strain, and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan has also directed the DOH to seek foreign supplies.
According to Yeh, the DOH plans to purchase up to 10 million doses of swine flu vaccine to meet domestic demand.

"As Adimmune can only provide 5 million doses, we still have to seek foreign supplies to make up for the deficiency and we hope potential foreign suppliers will be able to deliver the vaccines ahead of Adimmune," Yeh said.

Meanwhile, an Adimmune spokesman said it is scheduled to start human trials of its swine flu vaccine in October, with Huang Li-ming, a professor at National Taiwan University Medical College, presiding over the trial project.

"Those who receive the first injection will have to receive a second inouculation three weeks later as foreign medical data show that humans need two doses of vaccines to produce antibodies, " the spokesman said.

With the confirmation of Taiwan's first swine flu fatality the previous day and the incidence of cluster and community infections growing, the DOH has stepped up efforts to contain the spread of the virus.
Yeh himself visited the central Taiwan branch of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Friday to review its epidemic-fighting operations.

At the moment, three severe swine flu patients are still receiving hospital treatment and 10 cluster infections have been confirmed around Taiwan involving students who are attending summer study programs, military servicemen on outlying islands, and migrant workers at local factories.

As part of the campaign against the spread of the virus, the minister said that from this weekend, 300 local hospitals will be allowed to conduct testing and offer anti-viral drugs to patients displaying swine flu symptoms.
From Aug. 15, grassroots doctors contracted by the Bureau of National Health Insurance will also begin offering testing and medication, Yeh added.

Five schools in four counties and cities have closed at different times since the beginning of summer vacation over swine flu concerns, Ministry of Education officials said. While some schools have re-opened, others remain closed.
Former DOH Minister Chen Chien-jen, an epidemiologist, warned Friday that Taiwan is approaching a stage where the swine flu will spread quickly.
"If we fail to intensify prevention efforts, a major outbreak could hit in late September or October, the traditional flu peak season," Chen said.
Taiwan has so far confirmed six severe swine flu cases, including one death. Based on this figure, he said, Taiwan should have at least 10,000 swine flu cases.
He suggested that the government speed up purchases of anti-viral drugs and vaccines to cope with any possible outbreak of the disease.
Earlier in the day, the Ministry of Education announced that any local school with a confirmed case should be closed for seven days to contain the possible spread of the disease.
If the situation is very severe, the ministry said, the school's closing can be extended to 10 days.

At the same time, should two schools in the same city or county each have a confirmed swine flu case or cluster infections, local governments can order all schools in the district or nearby region to be shut down for a week or so, ministry officials said.
Wang Chun-chuang, director of the ministry's Physical Education Department, urged local students not to go to school if they develop flu symptoms.
Wang said the ministry will hold a meeting Aug. 4 to map out a comprehensive package of working guidelines to prevent the spread of swine flu after schools reopen in September.
The general guiding principle, he said, will be that any nationwide school closure plan over swine flu concerns should be announced by the Central Epidemics Command Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen to use horseshoe crab breeding season to educate residents

TEXT.P: The Kinmen County government will begin to send experts to horseshoe crab breeding grounds on Sunday to give lectures on the "living fossil" and ways to protect the species, a county official said Friday.

County Bureau of Cultural Affairs Director Lee Hsi-lung said the program, to be held every weekend and holiday until Sept. 30, was conceived to promote horseshoe crab conservation and preserve the breeding grounds of the ancient creature.

The horseshoe crab's breeding territory in the island county, which lies just off the coast of southeastern China, has been eroded in recent years by wharf construction and expansion to accommodate increasing marine traffic between Kinmen and southern Chinese ports.

As part of its efforts to preserve the marine species, the local government has listed the sea area surrounding the small Jiankong islet off the western coast of Greater Kinmen as a conservation area.
Lee said the local government has invited the public to participate in the free lecture and tour on Jiankong islet, hoping local residents will then join in efforts to preserve the unique species.

Kinmen is one of only a few breeding areas in Taiwan for the horseshoe crab, a hard-shelled invertebrate that lives in coastal waters on the sea floor but breeds on shore. Its breeding season falls between June and October.
According to Kinmen County Fisheries Research Institute data, the horseshoe crab is known as a "living fossil" because it has been around for 400 million years.

Despite their common name, they are not crabs but rather related to spiders, scorpions, ticks and mites. Kinmen residents have nicknamed the horseshoe crab the "helmet fish" because it is shaped like a military helmet.

DOC.HEADLINE: People urged to save water as dry spell continues

TEXT.P: Taiwan's residents should minimize water consumption as the country's reservoirs are drying out, water resources officials warned Saturday.

Because of less-than-usual rainfall this summer, water levels at major reservoirs around Taiwan have fallen to alarmingly low levels, said Chen Shen- hsien, director-general of the Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
The situation at Shihmen Reservoir in northern Taiwan is the most serious, with its water level standing at 224.3 meters Friday evening, close to the "shortage level" of 220 meters, Chen said.

Shihmen Reservoir is a major source of potable water in the northern county of Taoyuan. At present, water supply for household use has been cut by 10 percent and that for agricultural use by 25 percent.
If the situation continues to worsen, supply for agricultural use may be cut further, Chen said.
He further said his agency will make every possible effort to refrain from any further cut into water supply for household use before October.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIG decides to sell Taiwanese unit
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 1 (CNA) 08/01/09 15:12:06 (By Tien Yu-ping and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The American International Group (AIG) Inc. has decided to sell its Taiwanese unit, Nan Shan Life, and some international private equity funds are reportedly going to team up with financial holding companies in Taiwan to bid for the life insurance company, which has total assets exceeding NT$1.5 trillion (about US$45.5 billion).
While Taiwanese regulators have expressed concern over the stability of whoever takes over Nan Shan, private equity funds attending the bid are looking for domestic partners.

According to local media reports, Bain Capital LLC and Morgan Stanley are teaming up with Chinatrust Financial Holding Company, while the Carlyle Group is interested in an alliance with the Fubon Financial Holding Company.
Nan Shan was established in July 1963. Nearly 50 years of operation in Taiwan has earned the company 10 percent to 12 percent of Taiwan's insurance market.
The company's extensive network of 35,000 agents serve 4 million policy holders in Taiwan.
When a crisis in AIG was exposed last October, reports regarding the company's plan to auction its overseas operations in order to raise money caused turbulence in Asia.

Sources in the insurance sector said the Nan Shan bid is a severe case for Taiwan's financial sector. While leading insurance companies are among the bidders, the changing hands of Nan Shan will change the landscape of Taiwan's insurance business tremendously.
Statistics released by Nan Shan indicate that as of May 2009, the company's total assets amounted to NT$1.5 trillion. Total policies in force reached 7.94 million, with 4 million policy holders.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's new tax reform a misstep: U.S. trade group

TEXT.P: A recommendation made by the Tax Reform Committee (TRC) to tax earnings from investment-linked life insurance policies is a "misstep," the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei said in its latest monthly publication Topics, expressing concern that it will undermine the interests of the insurance industry and disadvantage consumers by discouraging a useful option for funding their insurance needs.

"AmCham Taipei believes the TRC came to the wrong conclusion this month (July) when it decided that earnings from investment-linked life insurance policies should be subjected to income tax, " the editorial says.
"The biggest issue with the TRC's finding is that it misconstrues the purpose of the investment link," according to the editorial.

Rather than serving as a tax loophole for the very wealthy, the purpose of investment-linked insurance is to provide policy holders from all backgrounds with an alternative means of paying for their insurance coverage, it notes.

The TRC has proposed treating earnings from unit-linked insurance products as taxable income. Gains of up to NT$270,000 (US$8,241) would be tax-exempt under the existing exemption for interest income, but amounts beyond that would be subject to taxation.
At present, policy holders do not pay tax on income from investment-linked life insurance products.
The committee also suggested that proceeds from policies where the policy holder and beneficiary are not the same person be subject to a 10 percent gift tax on benefits of over NT$2.2 million.

The decision, which still requires final approval by the Executive Yuan, is aimed at creating a fairer tax environment, and the committee said it could take effect later this year but will not be applied retroactively.

The AmCham editorial says that Taiwan will be out of step with most advanced economies if it denies the status of investment-linked products as insurance. Although Taiwan should not necessarily be obliged to always take its cues from other jurisdictions, being the odd man out should at least set off warning bells that extra caution is needed and that international business may be heavily burdened by having to follow a separate standard in this market, it adds.
Another problem with the TRC's decision is procedural, as responsibility for determining what is or is not insurance should rest with the Financial Supervisory Commission, according to AmCham.

AmCham also disputed the TRC's judgment that implementing its decision could be done simply by administrative order without legislative approval, saying that investment-linked policies have been consistently accorded tax-exempt treatment under the law and if that status is to be revised, it should be through formal action by the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Employment outlook expected to remain bleak in coming year

TEXT.P: Taiwan's employment outlook is likely to remain bleak over the coming year, despite recent signs of improvement in the economic situation, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) officials said Saturday.
This is typical of a "jobless recovery" -- recovery from a recession in the absence of strong employment growth -- the officials said.
According to the latest data released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, the unemployment rate hit a new high of 5.94 percent in June, with 647,000 people out of work.

The number of employed people increased by 0.03 percent month-on-month to 10.24 million in June -- the third consecutive month in which growth was recorded. However, compared with the same month of last year, the number was down by 170,000, or 1.63 percent.

The results of a recent CEPD study reveal that the employment market tends to take longer to recover than the economy itself, as was the case during the economic downturn following the bursting of the dot-com bubble in 2001.

While it took six quarters for Taiwan's economy to recover from the recession, the unemployment rate still did not return to the low level before the bubble burst, despite 30 quarters of consolidation, the report shows.
CEPD officials noted that employers usually wait until an economic recovery is established or the economy begins to thrive before they increase hiring.

Under these circumstances, the number of employed people is unlikely to post a year-on-year growth at least until the second quarter of 2010, the officials said. A return to the level of before the global financial crisis hit will probably take until late 2010 or 2011, they added.
A strong recovery momentum will be essential to drive the unemployment rate down to below 4 percent -- the level before the start of the financial crisis, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Delay on high-speed railway affects passengers

TEXT.P: A serious delay of a northbound train on the high-speed railway Saturday led to some of its passengers missing flights at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, triggering a wave of complaints.

The train, which began its journey from Taichung, stopped suddenly for an unknown reason after passing Miaoli Station and remained there for 38 minutes before taking off in reverse direction back toward Taichung Station.
The train was scheduled to arrive at Taoyuan Station at 7:05 a.m., but failed to arrive until 8:38 a.m.
As of press time, the Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. had not commented on the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Games athletes from Kaohsiung City awarded NT$4.1 million

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu Friday awarded a total of NT$4.1 million (US$125,000) to 11 of the city's athletes who won medals in the just-concluded World Games 2009 Kaohsiung.

They include seven who garnered a total of five golds, five silvers and one bronze in the formal competitions for roller sports, karate, powerlifting and billiards. The other four bagged two silvers and two bronzes in the invitational dragon boat regatta and women's softball.
Chen said the games marked the first time Taiwan has held any global sports event and were also the biggest challenge she has encountered during her term in office.

Despite the many difficulties involved, the city government worked as hard as the athletes to ensure the event's success, proving Taiwan has the ability to host large-scale international sports competitions, Chen said.

Stressing that athletes are the soul of any such competition, she promised that the city government will continue to support efforts to nurture top athletes to help further improve Taiwan's sporting performance.

To encourage its residents to take part in athletic activities, Kaohsiung City currently awards NT$200,000 to each gold medalist, NT$150,000 to each silver medalist and NT$100,000 to each bronze medalist in formal international sports competitions. The prize money for medalists in invitational games is half the amount received by those in formal competitions.
The city government, however, has doubled the prize money for the medalists in formal competitions in the World Games, while maintaining the original level for those in invitational games.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to reward top Chinese travel agents

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau is planning to launch an incentive program to encourage Chinese travel agents to organize creative tours to Taiwan, as well as tours of specific regions of the country, as part of efforts to enhance tourist satisfaction, a bureau official said Saturday.

Under the program, top-performing salespeople will be offered free trips to Taiwan and the travel agencies that show the best performance in each Chinese province will also receive prizes in Taiwan, said Liu Hsi-lin, chief of the bureau's international affairs division.
The bureau will also provide training sessions for Chinese travel agents between late November and early December to increase their understanding of Taiwan's travel products, Liu added.
Since the first half of this year, various Chinese provinces have launched a "10,000 people traveling to Taiwan" campaign to promote tours to the country.
During this period, the number of tourists from Zhejiang Province has totaled 70,000, while those from Jiangsu and Shandong each reached 10,000, according to Tourism Bureau statistics.

Although tourists from these three provinces are less numerous than those from Fujian and Guangdong provinces, they tend to spend more on both their package tours and their consumption in Taiwan, bureau officials said.
Meanwhile, the results of a survey conducted by the bureau among Chinese tourists show that as many as 85 percent are satisfied with their visits here.
Among those who expressed dissatisfaction, the most common complaints were the long travel time for a round-the-island tour and hurried itineraries.

During her most recent visit to China in July, Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai first raised the proposal of encouraging Chinese travel agencies to organize more regional tours and to place less emphasis on round-the-island tours.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2010 Taiwan Lantern Festival to be held in Chiayi City

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan announced Saturday that the Taiwan Lantern Festival -- one of the most significant annual events on the country's calendar -- will be held in southern Taiwan's Chiayi City next year.

Liu made the announcement in a meeting with Chiayi Mayor Huang Ming-hui and other city officials during a visit to the city to attend the 49th National Primary and High School Science Fair held at National Chiayi University, a two- day event.
Applauding the decision, Huang described having the chance to host the annual festival as a "big gift" to the southern city from the Executive Yuan.

The festival is held each year in a different county or city on the 15th of the first month on the lunar calendar. As an event with prominent cultural and local folk features, the event always draws participation by both local and foreign visitors and is an important tourist draw.

Liu told Huang that he was impressed by the city's achievements in carrying out the central government's construction projects designed to expand domestic demand, as well as its success in organizing a magnificent fireworks display for the official celebration of last year's Oct. 10 National Day.
These achievements, he said, are why the central government decided to entrust Chiayi City with the task of organizing the Lantern Festival.

After the meeting, Liu went on to visit the science fair, at which award- winning projects were displayed, including a "sophisticated architect -- the silk worm" project by fifth graders Huang Yi-ning and Ting Jung of Long An Elementary School in Taipei City, who said it took them two years to study how the worm builds its cocoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan should position itself as technology hub: U.S. trade group

TEXT.P: A U.S. trade group has suggested that Taiwan should leverage its strengths in high-tech manufacturing to position itself as a technology regional hub, as more businesses will be willing to consider Taiwan an Asia-Pacific center when there are regular direct flights across the Taiwan Strait to major cities in China.

"Numerous analysts say, Taiwan's best bet would be to leverage its existing strengths in high-tech manufacturing to position itself as a regional hub for technology-intensive industries such as ICT and biotech, though they caution that Taiwan has a window of about 10 years to accomplish this before cities in China start catching up, " the Taipei-based American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) said in the cover story of its latest business publication, Topics.

Many Taiwan-based ICT companies are already playing important regional and even global roles, the report analyzes, noting that Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), for instance, is the world's largest contract chip maker and that companies with head offices in Taiwan account for 80 percent of the world's notebook computer production.

"In Taiwan, you have ready access to the electronic manufacturing chain and also access to distribution channels in China," Peter Kurz, head of Taiwan country research for Citi Investment Research, is quoted as saying.
"It'll be the tech companies that draw foreign companies here, whether Japanese or Western," he added.
Tristan Liu, an economist with the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER), reached the same conclusion about Taiwan's prospects for serving as a regional center.

He views such a hub as encompassing tech-related downstream activity, such as chip packaging, venture capital firms and other financial services aimed specifically at technology companies, and other services such as recruiting and training.

Wang Jiann-chyuan, an economist with the Chung-Hwa Institution for Economic Research (CIER), estimates that 5 percent to 10 percent of Taiwanese companies based overseas intend to relocate more operations here because of the improvements in cross-strait ties and new, more stringent labor regulations that have been adopted in China.

Lim Tay Her, an analyst with Asias leading brokage house CLSA Asia Pacific Markets, notes that if 30 percent of the more-than 1 million Taiwanese working in China should return, the added consumption of those 300,000 people would have a dramatic impact on the economy, since most of them are relatively highly paid professionals.

Besides technology expertise, Taiwan is also more attractive than Chinese locations in terms of living conditions, IPR protection and employee loyalty -- and surprisingly, even for many costs. But it still needs to reduce government red tape in order to be competitive.

"We've found that the cost of running a business in Taiwan is actually slightly better than running the same business in other (Asian) locations -- including things like cost of living, the cost of expatriate rent, office costs and manufacturing costs, " said Alan T. Eusden, chairman of AmCham and president of Corning Display Technologies, a leading maker of glass substrate for liquid crystal display panels.

However, the report warns that inadequate infrastructure and the proliferation of bureaucratic red tape might be the two most daunting obstacles standing in the way of Taiwan becoming a regional operations hub.

Overall, Eusden noted, as long as regulations are clear, their implementation efficient, and improvements made in the infrastructure, "combined with all the benefits that already exist in Taiwan, I think you end up with a location that can operate as a regional operations hub quite effectively."

DOC.HEADLINE: Signal malfunction causes delays for 20 high-speed railway trains

TEXT.P: Five trains on the high-speed railway were canceled and other 20 were delayed Saturday due to a signal malfunction on a track switch on the Miaoli-Yuanli section of the line, according to a statement released later that day by the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC).
The malfunction occurred at 6: 37 a.m. and was not fixed until 8: 50 a.m.

While technicians raced to fix the problem, all trains had to be switched to run on the unaffected southbound rail, a change that forced the company to cancel three scheduled southbound trains and two northbound ones, the statement said.

It added that 13 other trains were delayed to degrees that the company had to give passengers full refunds or half refunds of the ticket fares, while minor delays of less than 30 minutes hit a further seven trains.

The first delay occurred when a northbound train, which began its journey from Taichung at 6: 30 a.m., stopped suddenly after passing Miaoli Station and remained there for 30 minutes before taking off in reverse direction back toward Taichung Station.
The train was scheduled to arrive at Taoyuan Station at 7:05 a.m. but failed to get there until 8:38 a.m.

The company apologized for the cancellations and delays that triggered waves of complaints from inconvenienced passengers, with one TV station reporting that the cancellations and delays led to over 10,000 people having their travel plans disrupted.
One irate passenger said he was booked on a direct chartered flight to Nanjing from the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and that the delay caused him to miss his flight.

In addition to the businessman, five participants in a national examination for medical personnel at Taipei County's Chiang-Tsui Junior High School did not arrive at the test venue in time, and were forced to sit the first one-hour section of the test with only 20 minutes left on the clock.

The Bureau of High Speed Rail was cited by a local evening newspaper in its Saturday edition as saying that it is scheduled to conduct its annual check on THSRC's operations, maintenance and repairs, as well as passenger services, some time between the end of August and early September.
The bureau also said there have been 21 incidents on the high speed railway involving signal malfunctions related to track switching since the system began operation in January 2007.
The frequency has been so high that the company must strengthen its regular maintenance and repair operations, said Hu Hsiang-ling, deputy director general of the bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC expresses condolences over death of former Philippines president

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed condolences to the Philippines Saturday on the passing of former President Corazon Cojuangco Aquino.
Aquino, whose People's Power made her an icon of democracy in the Philippines, died of colon cancer earlier in the day at the age of 76.
"The Foreign Ministry will send a telegram to offer condolences on the passing of President Aquino, who made great contributions to democracy in the Philippines," said MOFA spokesman Henry Chen.
Aquino, who was diagnosed with cancer in March last year, passed away at 3: 18 a.m., her son Benigno Aquino III told reporters in Manila.

Aquino was elected in 1986 as the first female president of the Philippines, making her the first woman in Asia to reach such high office, after her husband Senator Benigno Aquino Jr. was assassinated in 1983.
Known as Cory to the people of the country, Aquino led the nonviolent People Power revolution in 1986, ending the repressive 20-year regime of then-President Ferdinand Marcos.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese Taipei beats South Korea at Asian Baseball Championship

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei beat South Korea 5-4 Saturday in the 25th Asian Baseball Championships that opened that day in the Hokkaido prefectural capital of Sapporo, in northern Japan.

Chinese Taipei opened the scoring with a point in the first half of the second inning. South Korea, however, tied the score later in the inning thanks to several defensive mistakes by the Taiwanese players, including a wild pitch.

South Korea took a 2-1 lead in the third inning, but by the fourth had lost it again 2-4 after Chinese Taipei batter Wu Chung-chun hit a homerun, sending himself and his teammate Lin Ken-wei who was at first base back to the home plate.
Not until the seventh inning did South Korea begin to claw its way back, getting one point by taking advantage of Chinese Taipei pitcher Huang Chih-lung's poor performance.
Huang was then replaced by Wang Yi-cheng in the same inning, who also made a wild pitch, allowing South Korea to tie the score.
Chinese Taipei struggled to overcome the Koreans in the ninth inning and took the winning point by striking out four safe hits in a row.
Chinese Taipei will take on defending champion Japan Sunday.
Four teams, including China, are in the semi-final round of the regional baseball championships, which are held every two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health official confirms two more A(H1N1) cluster infections

TEXT.P: A health official confirmed Saturday two more influenza A(H1N1) cluster infections, bringing to 12 the number of cluster infections, with a report on a possible third pending confirmation.
Lin Ting, deputy director of the Centers for Disease Control under the Department of Health, said that among the two newly confirmed cases, one occurred at a senior high school in northern Taiwan.

Twenty-two students from a single class of a summer camp at the school had developed flu symptoms since July 29. Out of five affected students tested, four were confirmed to be suffering from A(H1N1) infection, Lin said.
The school was ordered closed Friday and will not open until Aug. 5, according to Lin.

The second cluster infections took place in a junior high school in southern Taiwan, with 17 students from one class showing flu symptoms and four of eight children from whom samples were taken and examined confirmed as being infected.
That school was also ordered to be closed until Aug. 5.
Health officials were also taking samples from students from a third senior high school in southern Taiwan after being informed that 34 students there had developed flu symptoms.

Lin urged the public to be watchful for flu symptoms among the people around them and to alert health officials if they know anyone showing flu-like symptoms, as cases of A(H1N1) are increasing in Taiwan.
Health officials are concerned that the flu could spiral out of control when students return at the start of the regular semester in September after the summer vacation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 2, or the 12th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1100: William II, known as "William Rufus," king of England from 1087, is slain by an arrow while hunting in New Forest. He was succeeded by his younger brother, who became Henry I.
1798: A 14-vessel naval squadron commanded by Rear Adm. Horatio Nelson scores a brilliant tactical victory over a French fleet of 17 vessels in the Mediterranean.
1918: British, French, and U.S. troops try to smash Lenin's communist revolution by supporting the White Russian forces and seizing Archangel.
1921: Enrico Caruso, the Neapolitan with the golden voice known as the world's greatest tenor of his time, dies at the Hotel Vesuvio in Naples at the age of 48.
1922: Alexander Graham Bell, Scottish inventor of the telephone in 1876, dies at the age of 76.
1923: Warren G. Harding, the 29th president of the United States, dies in office at the age of 58. He made several misguided appointments that led to a corrupt administration.
1924: The Kwangchow government sets up the Central Bank of China with T.V. Soong (Soong Tzu-wen) as governor.
1934: Paul von Hindenburg, German general, politician, and president of the Weimar Republic, dies at the age of 86. He was succeeded by Adolf Hitler who declared himself "Der Fuhrer."
1938: Chinese troops blow up a bank along a section of the upper Yangtze River in an attempt to slow a Japanese advance.
1939: Albert Einstein, German-born American theoretical physicist, writes to U.S. President Roosevelt urging him to start an atomic project.
1944: Joseph P. Kennedy Jr., U.S. Navy pilot and elder brother of John F. Kennedy, is killed when his plane explodes over the Belgian coast.
1945: The Potsdam Conference, the final Allied summit of World War II, comes to an end.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Dahomey, Niger and Upper Volta.
1961: President John F. Kennedy and visiting ROC Vice President Chen Cheng issue a joint statement in Washington, D.C., opposing the admission of mainland China into the United Nations.
1964: President Lyndon B. Johnson orders a retaliatory strike after a torpedo attack on the U.S. Navy ship Maddox in the Gulf of Tonkin.
1980: The International Telecommunications Administration inaugurates direct dialing station-to-station telephone service between Taipei and major cities in Britain, France and West Germany.
1985: Kuo Yu-hsin, former member of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, dies of illness in Washington, D.C., at the age of 77.
1986: The ROC delegation to the Aug. 4 ROC-U.S. trade talks, headed by Board of Foreign Trade Director-General Vincent C. Siew, leaves for Washington, D.C.
1990: Saddam Hussein makes good on Iraq's claim to the oil-rich state of Kuwait by invading it. Thousands of heavily armed Iraqi troops quickly cut through the defenses of their tiny Gulf neighbor and gain firm control of the capital city of Kuwait City.
1996: Michel Debre, former French prime minister, dies at the age of 84. He was Charles de Gaulle's trusted aide and the architect of the Fifth Republic.
1996: Typhoon Herb roars across northern Taiwan, leaving nearly 60 people dead or missing.
1999: The ROC representative to Japan, Chuang Ming-yao, expresses his grave concern to his Japanese counterpart about a plan by a group of Japanese lawmakers to land on the Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea.
2000: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan leads a delegation of senior KMT officials to pay a courtesy call on ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh at the DPP headquarters in Taipei.
2000: The Asian Witness Center of the Guinness Book of World Records announces two of Taiwan's record-setting fathers as part of celebrations for Father's Day, which falls on Aug. 8. One of the record-breakers is Lo Tseng-wen, who has five children serving as police officers, and the other is Chang A-piao, a centenarian who is living with four generations of offspring under the same roof.
2001: The final section of the 11.307-kilometer New Kuanyin Tunnel of the North Link Railway is blasted through, making it the longest two-way railway tunnel in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By banishing all flatterers and keeping away from the society of women; holding in low estimation possession of worldly goods, but valuing moral qualities in men: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to worthy men."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
New low pressure system may strengthen into typhoon: CWB

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Sunday that it was watching a tropical depression system near Luzon Province in the Philippines that might develop into a tropical storm or typhoon.
The depression was moving in a west-northwesterly direction toward Taiwan at a speed of 20 kilometers per hour as of 8 a.m. Sunday, the CWB reported.
The system later slowed a bit, CWB meteorologists said, adding that it remained to be seen whether the system will alter in structure after passing across Luzon Island.
Meanwhile, hot weather in Taiwan persisted, with temperatures expected to reach 35-36 degrees Celsius in northern Taiwan and 33-34 degrees for the rest of the island for that day.
Sporadic afternoon showers were forecast for the eastern part of Taiwan under the influence of the outer bands of the depression system, the weather bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan housing prices to rise up to 30% in three years: analyst

TEXT.P: Taiwan's housing prices are expected to rise about 20 percent-30 percent in the next two to three years because the local housing market hit bottom in the first quarter of this year and is now showing signs of recovery, an analyst with Union Bank of Switzerland (UBS) said Sunday.

The housing trade volume rose by 47 percent in the second quarter compared with the first, while the average price of second-hand houses posted a 10 percent quarterly growth and a 3 percent growth over the same quarter of last year, said Chung Chao-an, a UBS analyst focused on mid- and small-cap companies.
Despite a 1.6 precent quarterly drop in new house prices, 70 percent-80 percent of houses traded in the first quarter were second-hand houses, according to Chung.
Judging from the surging housing prices and the increasing trade volume, housing prices must have hit their lowest in the first quarter, Chung added.

He further predicted that the unemployment rate will probably reach a peak in the fourth quarter of this year or the first of next year and that there will be room for house prices to rise further in the next two to three years following an anticipated increase in economic and trade relations between Taiwan and China, an overall recovery of Taiwan's economy, a boost in consumer confidence, and a low interest rate environment.
Chung also suggested that investors buy shares in Taiwan Fertilizer and Far Eastern Textile because they hold a high number of assets and have high potential for development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Far Eastern Air expects to resume flights by October

TEXT.P: The Far Eastern Air Transport Corp. (FEAT), which is under reconstruction after suspending all its flights since May 2008 due to financial troubles, expects to resume flights by October, although approval from the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) is still pending, a CAA spokesman said Sunday.
The airline has been conducting aircraft inspection and maintenance at Sungshan Airport in Taipei since early July.
The spokesman said FEAT is renting facilities at the airport from the administration's Taipei Aviation Station at a cost of NT$1.6 million (US$48,837) per month.
Eager to resume the flights, FEAT in mid-June asked more than 80 of its staff to report for work, paying them 80 percent of their salaries until such time as flights are resumed.

FEAT was the first privately owned airline in Taiwan and had its heyday as the major carrier on Taiwan's domestic routes before the Taiwan High Speed Railway started its north-south services in March 2007.
Ever-dwindling business and rising fuel prices took a heavy toll on the airline and it was forced to submit a bankruptcy protection early last year.

Court approval of bankruptcy protection failed to save the airline because it failed to obtain the necessary funds and it suspended all its flights after the last service between South Korea's Jeju and the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport May 16, 2008.

Many of its staff remained on duty for several months, holding on to every chance to save the company. Meanwhile, the airline received a court order three months ago, allowing it to initiate a restructuring plan.

The CAA spokesman said that while the administration has rescinded its certification for FEAT's international services, the airline can resume its regular domestic flights as well as flying cross-Taiwan Strait routes when it obtains final approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourism Bureau plans 10 new ecotourism packages

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau is planning 10 new ecotourism packages to capitalize on Taiwan's rich ecological resources and promote development of the tourism industry, an official said Sunday.

"The bureau has commissioned the Taiwan Ecotourism Association to help design ecotourism themes and tour packages to be implemented from next year, " said Chen Yu-chuan, a section chief at the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).

The initiative stems from findings that the number of foreign ecotourists who travel to Taiwan to see indigenous or migratory bird species and diverse geological spectacles has been increasing significantly in recent years, Chen said.
"The phenomenon indicates that our plentiful natural and ecological marvels can be most precious assets to upgrade the local tourism industry," Chen noted.
Major local tour operators echoed Chen, saying that domestic travel styles are changing as local people are no longer focusing their interest on simply visiting major sightseeing spots.

"Tour packages that feature whale- and dolphin-watching, hiking in Fushan Botanical Park and walks along historic trails in mountainous regions have become ever-more popular, " said a Taipei-based travel agent who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Chiang Kun-ta, a local birdwatching tourism promoter who led a group of British and Dutch tour operators on an islandwide tour in mid-July to appreciate the myriad bird species seen in Taiwan, said that nearly 150 bird species can be sighted in 24 hours from coastal areas of Tainan County to Yushan, or Jade Mountain, in neighboring Chiayi and Nantou counties.

Chen said the planned ecotour packages could feature a variety of themes, such as geological wonders, lagoons and coastal wetlands, rare bird species and water birds, as well as insects and indigenous plants.
The ecotourism association is also expected to come up with recommended lists of spots for appreciation of various ecological marvels or natural spectacles, Chen said.

The bureau will invite local travel industry executives to a meeting in October to map out detailed ecotour packages, Chen said, adding that the Tourism Bureau will offer incentives or subsidies for travel agencies that help promote ecotourism.

The association has also been commissioned to help organize training courses for volunteer ecotour guides, Chen went on, adding that special ecotour guiding courses will also be launched between Aug. 18 and Sept. 11 for local professional group tour leaders and guides.

According to Chen, Taiwan has become increasingly known as one of the world's major whale- and dolphin-watching meccas, with the success rate of sighting whales and dolphins on a voyage from Shihti port in eastern Taiwan's Hualien County reaching 95 percent, a ratio widely believed to be the world's highest.

Moreover, Taiwan's fame as a mountain climbing mecca is also growing, with an ever-increasing number of foreign climbers traveling to Taiwan to scale local peaks, particularly from Austria, Japan and South Korea.
"The fact that Taiwan has about 290 mountains rising above 3,000 meters has contributed to the maturing of the local mountain climbing tour business," Chen explained.
"Most of our high mountains are located not far from major highways and it is not difficult for foreigners to reach and scale even our highest summits," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health minister intends to run for Hualien magistrate post

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yeh Ching-chuan spelled out Sunday his intention to run for the magisterial seat in the eastern county of Hualien.

Yeh, who had been rumored over the past month to be running on a ruling Kuomintang (KMT) ticket in the Hualien magistrate election but had never spoken publicly about it, said he will report his intention to Premier Liu Chao-shiuan at the earliest possible date.
Declining to disclose whether he has submitted a resignation request to the premier, Yeh said he will take heed of Liu's instruction on the matter.
One of Yeh's aides told CNA that day that "it's up to the KMT leadership to decide whether and when Yeh should resign the ministership for the election."

KMT Vice Chairman Wu Den-yih said the day before that a primary for the KMT's candidate in the election will be held in the following month and that the candidate is expected to be determined before Sept. 12.
"Yeh will made his decision shortly on whether he will remain health minister or take part in the KMT primary," Wu said.

Meanwhile, Yaung Chih-liang, a professor at Asia University, Taiwan and a former DOH vice minister, confirmed that he is on a shortlist of candidates to be appointed Yeh's successor, but stressed that if possible he would rather not be appointed.

"I hope Minister Yeh will stay in his current post and make more contributions to the country's epidemic prevention efforts, particularly since cluster infections of swine flu, or influenza A(H1N1), have begun in Taiwan, with one fatality, " Yaung said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU ranks 26th in Webometrics Ranking of World Universities

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) was listed 26th in the 2009 Webometrics Ranking of World Universities released in July by the Spanish National Research Council, making it the only local university to be included in the top 100 of the rankings, a university official said Sunday.

The rankings, along with the 2009 Performance Ranking of Scientific Papers for World Universities released last week by the Higher Education Evaluation and Accreditation, Council of Taiwan, are among a great number of ranking surveys of world universities that are conducted based on objective figures, said Chiang Been-huang, dean of academic affairs at NTU.

NTU is normally ranked high in these types of ranking surveys, but is at a disadvantage relative to some other universities in the world when rankings are made using overall impression scores, such as the one conducted by The Times newspaper, Chiang added.
With concerted efforts of NTU faculty and teachers, however, the school has greatly improved its rankings in the Webometrics ranking survey, according to Chiang.

However, NTU's development is constrained to a great extent by inadequate resources, Chiang went on, expressing concern over a loss of talent at the school as the pay it offers to its faculty is lower than top-ranking universities in Singapore, Hong Kong and even China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese media delegation wraps up fruitful Taiwan visit

TEXT.P: A high-profile Chinese media delegation wrapped up a week-long visit Sunday with commitments to further promote cross-Taiwan Strait journalistic exchanges and cooperation in a pragmatic manner.
Yang Yi, director of the information department of China's Taiwan Affairs Office who headed the 16-member delegation, said at a pre-departure news conference that the visit had been very fruitful.
During the visit, Yang said, journalism scholars, journalists and media executives from the two sides discussed issues regarding the promotion of bilateral journalistic exchanges.

"Even though Taiwanese and Chinese media organizations operate in different environments and their management philosophies and operational principles are not identical, there should still be ample room for them to share their experiences and learn from each other, " Yang said.
Through candid and exhaustive discussion, Yang went on, both sides agreed to increase exchanges to lay a solid foundation for normalization of cross-strait journalistic exchanges and cooperation.
Some media organizations from both sides also tentatively agreed to cooperate or give mutual support in news coverage in the future, Yang said.

One of the group's purposes was to push for the establishment of reciprocal media company offices in Taiwan and China, and Yang said he hopes the two sides can reach an agreement on this issue as soon as possible to facilitate cross- strait news coverage and contribute to the peaceful development of bilateral ties.
"There have been mounting calls for each side to allow media organizations from the other side to set up permanent offices to facilitate continued and in-depth news coverage," Yang continued.

As basic differences exist between the two sides in terms of basic journalistic concepts and media functions, Taiwan is still reluctant to strike a deal with China on reciprocal media company office establishment, however.

Yang said he believes any problems or glitches in bilateral engagements can be overcome through goodwill exchanges. "We can do whatever is easy first to achieve concrete progress, leaving the more thorny issues to be tackled at a later stage," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Breakthrough in precursor studies key to earthquake prediction

TEXT.P: CNA staff writer
People are scared of earthquakes mostly because of their unpredictability.

For decades, seismologists have dreamed of being able to divine the time and place of the next disastrous shock. But the behavior of quake-prone faults has proved so complex that the experts have been forced to conclude that large tremors are isolated, random and unpredictable.

Industrially advanced countries have made commendable progress over the past several decades in earth sciences, but the prediction of the time, epicenter and magnitude of major earthquakes is a problem that has not been solved.

"We're still finding the ways to predict earthquakes, like a blind man feeling an elephant, " said Shin Tsai-chin, deputy director of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) , who oversees the bureau's Seismic Network.

Taiwan is located in a strongly oblique convergent zone between the Eurasian Plate and the Philippine Sea Plate, an area commonly referred to as the Pacific Ring of Fire. According to the CWB Seismic Network, the Taiwan area has about 16,000 to 18,000 detectable earthquakes each year, about 250 of which are of magnitude 4.0 and about 30 of which are magnitude 5.0 or larger.

Yilan in the northeast and Hualien in the east are the most earthquake-prone counties in Taiwan. However, a deadly 7.3 magnitude earthquake unexpectedly struck Taiwan Sept. 21, 1999, with its epicenter located near the town of Chi- Chi in central Taiwan -- not close to the more active seismic zones of Yilan and Hualien.

The earthquake -- the most serious disaster since World War II in Taiwan -- left some 2,500 people dead and 100,000 houses destroyed, and seriously disrupted the local economy as it occurred near the island's densely populated western plain.

Shin said seismologists may have gained some knowledge from labs and theoretical studies about earthquake precursors, but when it comes to reality, they have a hard time telling whether the phenomena they have detected can be coded as earthquake precursors.

Taking the CWB's experience as an example, he said, prominent short-term anomalies or dynamic tendencies of underground water levels are often detected in its seismological observation station in Hualien prior to certain major earthquakes, but there have been incidents in which underground water levels have had no changes at all before some quakes of similar magnitude have struck.

Shin said one of the things that make earthquake predictions impossible is that the prediction theory or method that proves to be effective at one location does not necessarily prove to be applicable to other localities, because all locations vary in terms of geological structure.

For example, he said, some historical accounts show that there have been apparent foreshocks before some major earthquakes have occurred, but many devastating quakes have struck without any foreshocks.
Japan, the United States and China have spent money and manpower in earthquake prediction research over the past 30-odd years, while Russia, Italy, Greece and Taiwan have started to catch up.

There have been cases that have proved to be successful in earthquake predictions in China, such as one made in 1975 that pre-warned an incoming disastrous jolt for Haicheng City in Liaoning Province, helping reduce damage to lives and property.

Nevertheless, the same theory and technology applied in an area of northeastern China failed to divine in advance a killer earthquake that battered Tangshan the following year that left more than 250,000 people dead.

Earth scientists have worked from various angles -- crustal deformation, plate behavior and alteration of underground water levels -- to try to divine when, where and how disastrous earthquakes occur, in the hope that someday, seismologists will be able to forecast major quakes the same way they forecast typhoons, Shin said.

Meanwhile, he went on, the CWB's earthquake prediction research has mainly focused on observation and analysis of mass transfer and rock dilation of the Earth's crust, as well as the short-term anomalies or dynamic tendencies of underground water levels before major earthquakes.

Since the devastating 921 Chi-Chi earthquake, the CWB has installed global positioning systems (GPS) at 150 earthquake observation spots nationwide, aimed at detecting crustal activities before and after major quakes.
The weather bureau has also dug a deep well in Hualien, hoping that variations in the underground water levels in the 300-meter well will tell when and how earthquakes occur.

So far, however, they have failed to obtain effective evidence provided by the well to prove that variations in underground water levels have direct or definite relationships to earthquakes, Shin noted.

Meanwhile, he continued, the CWB has received many phone calls from enthusiastic members of the public who claim to have an instinct for forecasting earthquakes. In one case, he said, a man said he develops tinnitus prior to a major earthquake. After quantitative verification, however, most of the predictions have proved wrong.
