Many people have also shown great interest in animal precursors, Shin went on, but pointed out that animal behavior can be altered by too many factors and so far, no government in the world has made serious research on the relationship between animal behavior and earthquakes.
Besides the CWB, other research institutes have also been doing research on earthquake precursors.

According to Shin, the Institute of Earth Sciences under Academia Sinica has established eight earthquake monitoring stations around the country since 1988 aimed at discerning the relationship between major earthquakes and geomagnetic fluctuations.
So far, they have not been able to determine the reasons behind geomagnetic fluctuations and their physical mechanism, Shin said.

Several leading local universities, including National Taiwan Central University and National Taiwan University, have also set up task forces to research the possibility of short-term earthquake prediction on the basis of electromagnetic field variations under, on, or over the Earth's surface and near space.
"Despite being an uphill battle, earthquake prediction research must go on," Shin concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan medical mission serves Tibetans in northwestern India
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, Aug. 2 (CNA) 08/02/09 19:02:34 (By Paul Kuo and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese medical delegation returned to the Indian capital of New Delhi Saturday after concluding a week-long medical mission providing services to Tibetans living in the mountainous northwestern region of India.

The 36-member mission of the Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps (TRMPC), composed of six doctors in various fields, five dentists and three nurses, as well as medical technicians and volunteers, left Dharamsala Friday and took a 12-hour bus ride to New Delhi before heading home later that day.
Liu Chi-chun, a dentist who served as head of the mission, said the group managed to see 2,690 patients in Dharamsala over its seven-day mission.
"The figure was far lower than that of the past years, " he said, however, speculating that rainy weather might have put prospective patients off traveling to seek medical attention.
But he also noted that the lower patient turnout "could also mean that the health of the Tibetans in the area has improved to a large degree."
Liu said his mission arrived in Dharamsala, seat of the Tibetan government-in- exile just as the Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama was about to leave on a trip to Europe.

When his holiness heard of the arrival of the mission, however, he arranged a meeting with them at his office and shook hands with each of the member to express his appreciation for their work, Liu said.

The TRMPC first visited Dharamsala in 2000, marking the beginning of the group's annual visits to India ever since. As the Tibetans living in the northern region suffer from a general lack of medical resources and health information, the group has made its visits to the area a priority.
In addition to Dharamsala, the group also visited Sikkim in northern India and Darjeeling in northeastern India.
The TRMPC, founded by Liu in 1995, is a private non-profit organization dedicated to improving quality of life through provision of medical services and health education.

It believes that medical service should transcend national borders and exceed the limitations of politics, race, and religion. It holds as its end goal a united international community working in cooperation to bring about equitable access of healthcare to all populations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hypermarket helps promote local produce

TEXT.P: Unlike some of its rivals, which regularly host gala-like sales to promote imported produce, one local hypermarket franchise has been cooperating with the Council of Agriculture (COA) to push sales of local produce on a seasonal basis.

The Far Eastern Ai Mai Group, which has since 2007 been cooperating with the COA to push domestically produced agricultural products, has launched a series of sales drives since July 21 this year to boost sales of freshly picked fruit and vegetables.

In one single week of promotion, the company's 15 branches islandwide sold 300,000 kg of fresh pears, guavas and lemons, mostly from southern Taiwan, generating record high sales to the tune of NT$5 million (US$15,244), said the franchise's marketing chief Chuang Chin-lung.
"The sales drive marked a four-way victory for the government, the consumers and the farmers, as well as for Far Eastern Ai Mai, " Chuang said.

The drive was particularly welcomed because it helped alleviate the price pressure that farmers have suffered due to abnormal weather in the first half of this year, when too much sunshine and too little rain caused some crops to ripen ahead of schedule or resulted in a glut of others.

Touting "produce directly from the farms," the Far Eastern Ai Mai stores have helped fruit growers in southern Pingtung and Kaohsiung counties by selling lemons at NT$1 per fruit and guavas at NT$5, greatly easing the glut of these fruits, Chuang said.

From July 29-Aug. 8, a second sales drive was launched at the stores, promoting signature agricultural products from the central county of Nantou, including pork sausages made with shaohsing wine, as well as various kinds of mushrooms cultivated in the area, he added.
He said that by the end of the year, the chain will have promoted agricultural products from 12 cities and counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: World's 1st botanical product industry cluster shaping in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The world's first botanical product industry cluster is taking shape in southern Taiwan's Pingtung Agricultural Biotechnology Park, which is now home to more than 20 companies in the field, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Sunday.

With the global botanical products market growing rapidly, the official said, the Cabinet-level council has made strenuous efforts to promote the development of the industry in Taiwan over the past few years.

"The role of botanical products is becoming increasingly important in the global mainstream medical market and the industry is growing at an average annual rate of more than 10 percent, " said the official.

Noting that annual global sales of botanical products have already exceeded US$60 billion, the official said Taiwan stands a good chance of excelling in this domain, given its outstanding research achievements and plentiful research capacity.

The Pingtung agricultural park -- the COA's botanical product industry development arm -- has for the last three years prioritized attracting companies that use herbs and medicinal plants as their major raw materials to set up production facilities there, the official said.

"Thanks to our strenuous efforts, we have managed to persuade 22 such companies to set up factories in the Pingtung park, " he went on, adding that the companies manufacture a variety of products, including health supplements, skin care products and animal feed additives.

As local botanical product manufacturers tend to operate alone, they can have difficulty upgrading their operational efficiency, a situation that prompted the park administration to lobby those companies to pool their resources and form a cooperative platform to enhance their operational efficiency and sharpen their competitive edge.

The official noted that the Taiwan Botanical Product Industry Union was established in April this year to help union members cooperate in raw material procurement, technology development, product examination and certification, as well as marketing and distribution.

"Through the integration of resources and cooperation in research, development and marketing, the Pingtung park is set to become the world's first and probably only botanical product industry cluster, " the official said.
He addd that the park administration has also set up various divisions to help those companies with raw material supply, technology development, product certification and marketing cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Financial crisis hurts job market more than dotcom bubble: CEPD

TEXT.P: The impact of the financial crisis on the local job market is even worse than that caused by the dotcom bubble of 2000 and will take at least two years to recover, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Sunday.

Taiwan's average unemployment rate in the first six months of this year reached 5.73 percent, up 1.86 percent from the same period of last year and exceeding the 1.15-percent increase between the first half of 2001 and 2002 after the dotcom bubble burst. The figures signal the even stronger impact of the financial debacle on the job market, according to the CEPD.

Men bore the brunt of the global financial turmoil because between January and June, the average employment among male workers was down by 134,000, compared with a decrease of 14,000 among females, the CEPD said.

The unemployment rate is expected to continue rising in July and August when new graduates enter the job market and will then begin to show signs of improvement after September, when a global economic recovery is expected, according to the CEPD.

However, the CEPD predicted that the employment situation will not improve greatly until the second quarter of 2010 at the earliest and said a booster shot is needed to help with economic recovery if Taiwan aims to bring the unemployment rate down to the average of 3.19 percent recorded in 2006 and 2007.

The economy recorded a negative 2.17 percent growth in 2000 and the nation's business cycle indicators flashed blue for the eighth straight time during the period, as it suffered badly from the collapse of the dotcom bubble. It took three quarters before the economy recovered from the recession and two years before the employment market was restored to its previous level, according to the CEPD.

Reeling from the global financial crunch that began in the last half of 2008, Taiwan's economy and gross domestic product (GDP) had both stayed in negative territory for four quarters as of the second quarter of this year.

As part of efforts to tackle unemployment, especially among middle-aged and elderly people, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) has urged job seekers in those groups to find a new job before quitting their old one.

Huang Meng-ju, head of a CLA-affiliated employment service center in central Taiwan, attributed the relatively high unemployment rate among middle-aged and elderly people to their general unwillingness to lower their expectations about their jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Windless weather gives Hsinchu record summer heat

TEXT.P: Persistent summer heat pushed the mercury up to a record 39.4 degrees Celsius in Hsinchu at around noon Sunday, while temperatures at Tamsui on the northern coast and in Taipei City were also stiflingly high at around 37 degrees Celsius, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported later that day.
The weathermen reported that the nearly 40-degree heat in Hsinchu was the hottest registered anywhere around Taiwan this year.

They noted that while Hsinchu, which lies on the western coast, usually benefits from the cooling influence of sea breezes during the summer, unusually windless weather over the past week has allowed the heat to build to an inferno in the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE gives go-ahead for summer camps despite flu concerns

TEXT.P: Summer camp activities for local students will proceed as scheduled despite confirmation of several influenza A(H1N1) cluster infections involving students taking part in such programs, a Ministry of Education (MOE) official said Sunday.

"Influenza A(H1N1) is a category-four statutory communicable disease, just like other forms of flu. Since no stricter regulations have been imposed on its prevention, summer camp activities can go ahead as usual," said Wang Chun-chuan, director of the MOE's Physical Education Department.
Nevertheless, Wang went on, the ministry will ask students attending camp activities to strengthen their health self-management.

The ministry has been scheduled to organize up to 110 summer camp programs for school students at various levels during this year's summer vacation, some of which have already been going on for more than a month. Some participating students have been involved in A(H1N1) cluster infections.

Addressing rising concerns as to whether the summer camps should be suspended because of fear of further infections, Wang said the ministry sees no need for such a course of action, as long as the camping site environments are kept clean and students maintain rigorous personal hygiene.
He also reminded local parents that their children should not attend camp activities if they develop flu symptoms, such as fever and sore throat.

As to whether schools that offer summer courses for students should be closed down if an A(H1N1) case is confirmed, Wang said the ministry has authorized school authorities to decide on their own because summer courses are not formal school days.
When local schools reopen in September at the end of summer vacation, Wang said that if there are still cluster infections arising, the ministry may announce clear guidelines for school closure.
As of Saturday, 12 A(H1N1) cluster infections have been confirmed in Taiwan.

Former Department of Helath Minister Chen Chien-jen, an epidemiologist, warned in an interview with a local newspaper Friday that Taiwan is approaching a stage where the A(H1N1) flu will spread quickly.
"If we fail to intensify prevention efforts, a major outbreak could hit in late September or October, the traditional flu peak season," Chen said.
Taiwan has so far confirmed six severe A(H1N1) cases, including one death. Based on this figure, he said, Taiwan should have at least 10,000 such cases.
He suggested that the government speed up purchases of anti-viral drugs and vaccines to cope with any possible outbreak of the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health minister to visit Hong Kong over A(H1N1) prevention

TEXT.P: Department of Health Minister Yeh Chin-chuan will travel to Hong Kong next week for a two-day visit during which he will attend a forum on the prevention of A(H1N1) infection and exchange views with members of the medical establishment there, a DOH source said Sunday.
The source made the remarks amid reports that Yeh will soon resign from his post to run on a ruling Kuomintang ticket in the Hualien magistrate election.
"Yeh's visit to Hong Kong was arranged a month ago and we have received no instructions that the trip has been canceled, " the source continued.

Yeh will depart for Hong Kong Tuesday and return the following day. During his visit, he will speak on the outlook of medical and health cooperation between Taiwan and Hong Kong, and will visit Princess Margaret Hospital and call on Anthony Wu, chairman of Hospital Authority.

Accompanying Yeh for his visit will be Huang Kun-chang, chief executive officer of the Hospital Administration Commission under the DOH; Chen Wen-chung, superintendent of Taoyuan General Hospital; and Chang Shen-chwen, vice superintendent of National Taiwan University Hospital.
Huang said that both Taiwan and Hong Kong have experienced A(H1N1) community and cluster infections, and both also have reported one fatality from the new flu strain.

Princess Margaret Hospital and the Taoyuan General Hospital are both charged with admitting potential sufferers of A(H1N1) that are detected at the international airports on both sides, and both could share each other's experiences of treating patients and preventing them from infecting others in the hospital.

Kuo Hsu-sung, director of the Centers of Disease Control, also under the DOH, said the DOH is planning to sponsor an international symposium on A(H1N1) when the flu situation stabilizes, and will invite experts from Hong Kong and the United States to attend.
However, if the situation continues to worsen, the DOH might not have time to spare to sponsor such a gathering, Kuo added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug. 3 , 2009

TEXT.P: Reform Committee under the Cabinet Date and Time: 9:30 a.m., Monday, Aug. 3,
2009 Place: conference room. Ministry of Finance
Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health minister intends to run for Hualien magistrate post

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yeh Ching-chuan spelled out Sunday his intention to run for the magisterial seat in the eastern county of Hualien.

Yeh, who had been rumored over the past month to be running on a ruling Kuomintang (KMT) ticket in the Hualien magistrate election but had never spoken publicly about it, said he will report his intention to Premier Liu Chao-shiuan at the earliest possible date.
Declining to disclose whether he has submitted a resignation request to the premier, Yeh said he will take heed of Liu's instruction on the matter.
One of Yeh's aides told CNA that day that "it's up to the KMT leadership to decide whether and when Yeh should resign the ministership for the election."

KMT Vice Chairman Wu Den-yih said the day before that a primary for the KMT's candidate in the election will be held in the following month and that the candidate is expected to be determined before Sept. 12.
"Yeh will made his decision shortly on whether he will remain health minister or take part in the KMT primary," Wu said.

Meanwhile, Yaung Chih-liang, a professor at Asia University, Taiwan and a former DOH vice minister, confirmed that he is on a shortlist of candidates to be appointed Yeh's successor, but stressed that if possible he would rather not be appointed.

"I hope Minister Yeh will stay in his current post and make more contributions to the country's epidemic prevention efforts, particularly since cluster infections of swine flu, or influenza A(H1N1), have begun in Taiwan, with one fatality, " Yaung said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU ranks 26th in Webometrics Ranking of World Universities

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) was listed 26th in the 2009 Webometrics Ranking of World Universities released in July by the Spanish National Research Council, making it the only local university to be included in the top 100 of the rankings, a university official said Sunday.

The rankings, along with the 2009 Performance Ranking of Scientific Papers for World Universities released last week by the Higher Education Evaluation and Accreditation, Council of Taiwan, are among a great number of ranking surveys of world universities that are conducted based on objective figures, said Chiang Been-huang, dean of academic affairs at NTU.

NTU is normally ranked high in these types of ranking surveys, but is at a disadvantage relative to some other universities in the world when rankings are made using overall impression scores, such as the one conducted by The Times newspaper, Chiang added.
With concerted efforts of NTU faculty and teachers, however, the school has greatly improved its rankings in the Webometrics ranking survey, according to Chiang.

However, NTU's development is constrained to a great extent by inadequate resources, Chiang went on, expressing concern over a loss of talent at the school as the pay it offers to its faculty is lower than top-ranking universities in Singapore, Hong Kong and even China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese media delegation wraps up fruitful Taiwan visit

TEXT.P: A high-profile Chinese media delegation wrapped up a week-long visit Sunday with commitments to further promote cross-Taiwan Strait journalistic exchanges and cooperation in a pragmatic manner.
Yang Yi, director of the information department of China's Taiwan Affairs Office who headed the 16-member delegation, said at a pre-departure news conference that the visit had been very fruitful.
During the visit, Yang said, journalism scholars, journalists and media executives from the two sides discussed issues regarding the promotion of bilateral journalistic exchanges.

"Even though Taiwanese and Chinese media organizations operate in different environments and their management philosophies and operational principles are not identical, there should still be ample room for them to share their experiences and learn from each other, " Yang said.
Through candid and exhaustive discussion, Yang went on, both sides agreed to increase exchanges to lay a solid foundation for normalization of cross-strait journalistic exchanges and cooperation.
Some media organizations from both sides also tentatively agreed to cooperate or give mutual support in news coverage in the future, Yang said.

One of the group's purposes was to push for the establishment of reciprocal media company offices in Taiwan and China, and Yang said he hopes the two sides can reach an agreement on this issue as soon as possible to facilitate cross- strait news coverage and contribute to the peaceful development of bilateral ties.
"There have been mounting calls for each side to allow media organizations from the other side to set up permanent offices to facilitate continued and in-depth news coverage," Yang continued.

As basic differences exist between the two sides in terms of basic journalistic concepts and media functions, Taiwan is still reluctant to strike a deal with China on reciprocal media company office establishment, however.

Yang said he believes any problems or glitches in bilateral engagements can be overcome through goodwill exchanges. "We can do whatever is easy first to achieve concrete progress, leaving the more thorny issues to be tackled at a later stage," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Breakthrough in precursor studies key to earthquake prediction

TEXT.P: CNA staff writer
People are scared of earthquakes mostly because of their unpredictability.

For decades, seismologists have dreamed of being able to divine the time and place of the next disastrous shock. But the behavior of quake-prone faults has proved so complex that the experts have been forced to conclude that large tremors are isolated, random and unpredictable.

Industrially advanced countries have made commendable progress over the past several decades in earth sciences, but the prediction of the time, epicenter and magnitude of major earthquakes is a problem that has not been solved.

"We're still finding the ways to predict earthquakes, like a blind man feeling an elephant, " said Shin Tsai-chin, deputy director of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) , who oversees the bureau's Seismic Network.

Taiwan is located in a strongly oblique convergent zone between the Eurasian Plate and the Philippine Sea Plate, an area commonly referred to as the Pacific Ring of Fire. According to the CWB Seismic Network, the Taiwan area has about 16,000 to 18,000 detectable earthquakes each year, about 250 of which are of magnitude 4.0 and about 30 of which are magnitude 5.0 or larger.

Yilan in the northeast and Hualien in the east are the most earthquake-prone counties in Taiwan. However, a deadly 7.3 magnitude earthquake unexpectedly struck Taiwan Sept. 21, 1999, with its epicenter located near the town of Chi- Chi in central Taiwan -- not close to the more active seismic zones of Yilan and Hualien.

The earthquake -- the most serious disaster since World War II in Taiwan -- left some 2,500 people dead and 100,000 houses destroyed, and seriously disrupted the local economy as it occurred near the island's densely populated western plain.

Shin said seismologists may have gained some knowledge from labs and theoretical studies about earthquake precursors, but when it comes to reality, they have a hard time telling whether the phenomena they have detected can be coded as earthquake precursors.

Taking the CWB's experience as an example, he said, prominent short-term anomalies or dynamic tendencies of underground water levels are often detected in its seismological observation station in Hualien prior to certain major earthquakes, but there have been incidents in which underground water levels have had no changes at all before some quakes of similar magnitude have struck.

Shin said one of the things that make earthquake predictions impossible is that the prediction theory or method that proves to be effective at one location does not necessarily prove to be applicable to other localities, because all locations vary in terms of geological structure.

For example, he said, some historical accounts show that there have been apparent foreshocks before some major earthquakes have occurred, but many devastating quakes have struck without any foreshocks.
Japan, the United States and China have spent money and manpower in earthquake prediction research over the past 30-odd years, while Russia, Italy, Greece and Taiwan have started to catch up.

There have been cases that have proved to be successful in earthquake predictions in China, such as one made in 1975 that pre-warned an incoming disastrous jolt for Haicheng City in Liaoning Province, helping reduce damage to lives and property.

Nevertheless, the same theory and technology applied in an area of northeastern China failed to divine in advance a killer earthquake that battered Tangshan the following year that left more than 250,000 people dead.

Earth scientists have worked from various angles -- crustal deformation, plate behavior and alteration of underground water levels -- to try to divine when, where and how disastrous earthquakes occur, in the hope that someday, seismologists will be able to forecast major quakes the same way they forecast typhoons, Shin said.

Meanwhile, he went on, the CWB's earthquake prediction research has mainly focused on observation and analysis of mass transfer and rock dilation of the Earth's crust, as well as the short-term anomalies or dynamic tendencies of underground water levels before major earthquakes.

Since the devastating 921 Chi-Chi earthquake, the CWB has installed global positioning systems (GPS) at 150 earthquake observation spots nationwide, aimed at detecting crustal activities before and after major quakes.
The weather bureau has also dug a deep well in Hualien, hoping that variations in the underground water levels in the 300-meter well will tell when and how earthquakes occur.

So far, however, they have failed to obtain effective evidence provided by the well to prove that variations in underground water levels have direct or definite relationships to earthquakes, Shin noted.

Meanwhile, he continued, the CWB has received many phone calls from enthusiastic members of the public who claim to have an instinct for forecasting earthquakes. In one case, he said, a man said he develops tinnitus prior to a major earthquake. After quantitative verification, however, most of the predictions have proved wrong.

Aware that improper forecasting of a major earthquake based only on superstition could trigger social anxiety or even instability, the CWB never makes any temblor forecasts based on the "precognition" of an individual, Shin stressed.

Many people have also shown great interest in animal precursors, Shin went on, but pointed out that animal behavior can be altered by too many factors and so far, no government in the world has made serious research on the relationship between animal behavior and earthquakes.
Besides the CWB, other research institutes have also been doing research on earthquake precursors.

According to Shin, the Institute of Earth Sciences under Academia Sinica has established eight earthquake monitoring stations around the country since 1988 aimed at discerning the relationship between major earthquakes and geomagnetic fluctuations.
So far, they have not been able to determine the reasons behind geomagnetic fluctuations and their physical mechanism, Shin said.

Several leading local universities, including National Taiwan Central University and National Taiwan University, have also set up task forces to research the possibility of short-term earthquake prediction on the basis of electromagnetic field variations under, on, or over the Earth's surface and near space.
"Despite being an uphill battle, earthquake prediction research must go on," Shin concluded.

The weathermen reported that the nearly 40-degree heat in Hsinchu was the hottest registered anywhere around Taiwan this year.

They noted that while Hsinchu, which lies on the western coast, usually benefits from the cooling influence of sea breezes during the summer, unusually windless weather over the past week has allowed the heat to build to an inferno in the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE gives go-ahead for summer camps despite flu concerns

TEXT.P: Summer camp activities for local students will proceed as scheduled despite confirmation of several influenza A(H1N1) cluster infections involving students taking part in such programs, a Ministry of Education (MOE) official said Sunday.

"Influenza A(H1N1) is a category-four statutory communicable disease, just like other forms of flu. Since no stricter regulations have been imposed on its prevention, summer camp activities can go ahead as usual," said Wang Chun-chuan, director of the MOE's Physical Education Department.
Nevertheless, Wang went on, the ministry will ask students attending camp activities to strengthen their health self-management.

The ministry has been scheduled to organize up to 110 summer camp programs for school students at various levels during this year's summer vacation, some of which have already been going on for more than a month. Some participating students have been involved in A(H1N1) cluster infections.

Addressing rising concerns as to whether the summer camps should be suspended because of fear of further infections, Wang said the ministry sees no need for such a course of action, as long as the camping site environments are kept clean and students maintain rigorous personal hygiene.
He also reminded local parents that their children should not attend camp activities if they develop flu symptoms, such as fever and sore throat.

As to whether schools that offer summer courses for students should be closed down if an A(H1N1) case is confirmed, Wang said the ministry has authorized school authorities to decide on their own because summer courses are not formal school days.
When local schools reopen in September at the end of summer vacation, Wang said that if there are still cluster infections arising, the ministry may announce clear guidelines for school closure.
As of Saturday, 12 A(H1N1) cluster infections have been confirmed in Taiwan.

Former Department of Helath Minister Chen Chien-jen, an epidemiologist, warned in an interview with a local newspaper Friday that Taiwan is approaching a stage where the A(H1N1) flu will spread quickly.
"If we fail to intensify prevention efforts, a major outbreak could hit in late September or October, the traditional flu peak season," Chen said.
Taiwan has so far confirmed six severe A(H1N1) cases, including one death. Based on this figure, he said, Taiwan should have at least 10,000 such cases.
He suggested that the government speed up purchases of anti-viral drugs and vaccines to cope with any possible outbreak of the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health minister to visit Hong Kong over A(H1N1) prevention

TEXT.P: Department of Health Minister Yeh Chin-chuan will travel to Hong Kong next week for a two-day visit during which he will attend a forum on the prevention of A(H1N1) infection and exchange views with members of the medical establishment there, a DOH source said Sunday.
The source made the remarks amid reports that Yeh will soon resign from his post to run on a ruling Kuomintang ticket in the Hualien magistrate election.
"Yeh's visit to Hong Kong was arranged a month ago and we have received no instructions that the trip has been canceled, " the source continued.

Yeh will depart for Hong Kong Tuesday and return the following day. During his visit, he will speak on the outlook of medical and health cooperation between Taiwan and Hong Kong, and will visit Princess Margaret Hospital and call on Anthony Wu, chairman of Hospital Authority.

Accompanying Yeh for his visit will be Huang Kun-chang, chief executive officer of the Hospital Administration Commission under the DOH; Chen Wen-chung, superintendent of Taoyuan General Hospital; and Chang Shen-chwen, vice superintendent of National Taiwan University Hospital.
Huang said that both Taiwan and Hong Kong have experienced A(H1N1) community and cluster infections, and both also have reported one fatality from the new flu strain.

Princess Margaret Hospital and the Taoyuan General Hospital are both charged with admitting potential sufferers of A(H1N1) that are detected at the international airports on both sides, and both could share each other's experiences of treating patients and preventing them from infecting others in the hospital.

Kuo Hsu-sung, director of the Centers of Disease Control, also under the DOH, said the DOH is planning to sponsor an international symposium on A(H1N1) when the flu situation stabilizes, and will invite experts from Hong Kong and the United States to attend.
However, if the situation continues to worsen, the DOH might not have time to spare to sponsor such a gathering, Kuo added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 3, or the 13th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
216: An army led by Carthaginian General Hannibal defeats a huge Roman army, seizing its supply depot in the Battle of Cannae and killing some fifty thousand Roman soldiers.
1460: Scottish King James II is killed by the English during the siege of Roxburgh Castle.
1492: A flotilla of three ships, led by Christopher Columbus, sets sail from the Spanish port of Palos de la Frontera in search of a land called India.
1867: Stanley Baldwin, British Conservative prime minister three times between 1923 and 1937, is born.
1872: Haakon VII, Norwegian monarch who refused to surrender to the Germans in World War II, is born in Denmark.
1881: William George Fargo, American pioneer of long-distance express service, dies at his home in Buffalo, New York, at the age of 65.
1904: The Dalai Lama flees Lhasa as British troops invade Tibet. The Ching court on Aug. 26 orders the Pachen Lama to take over Tibetan affairs from the Dalai Lama.
1916: German troops launch a surprise attack on British forces in the Sinai in Egypt. Some 5,000 German soldiers are killed, while British loses amount to 1,100 men.
1929: Emile Berliner, German-born American inventor, dies in Washington D.C. at the age of 78. He greatly improved the telephone and invented the gramophone in 1887.
1940: Lithuania is formally incorporated into the Soviet Union as the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic.
1958: Nautilus, the U.S. atomic submarine, becomes the first vessel to reach the North Pole under the ice.
1959: Japan Airlines formally inaugurates its Tokyo-Taipei route.
1967: The ROC Executive Yuan decides to extend the period of compulsory education from six to nine years beginning in 1968.
1969: Minister of Economic Affairs K.T. Li (Li Kuo-ting) receives the 1968 Ramon Magsaysay Award for government service.
1972: Sheng Chin-lai is appointed dean of the Engineering College at Chiaotung University.
1972: Brig. Gen. William C. Buttows, new chief of staff of the U.S. Taiwan Defense Command, arrives in Taipei.
1973: The Flying Tiger Line inaugurates air freight services between Kaohsiung and New York.
1974: Economics Minister Y.S. Sun and Paraguayan Minister of Industry and Commerce D. Ugarte Centurionuan sign an agreement in Taipei to boost economic cooperation between the Republic of China and Paraguay.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives eight members of the U.S. 14th Air Force Association, including Mrs. Anna Chennault, widow of the 14th Air Force's commander, Maj. Gen. Claire Lee Chennault.
1977: A US$100 million loan agreement is signed in Taipei between the Taiwan Power Company and 17 banks from five foreign nations.
1981: President Ronald Reagan orders the firing of 12,000 striking air traffic control workers.
1986: Construction of the Synchronous Radiation Research Center under the Executive Yuan is started at the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park. It is scheduled for completion within five to six years.
1988: Mathias Rust, a West German youth who landed his light air plane near Moscow's Red Square in 1987, is released from prison and expelled from the Soviet Union.
1999: Nine renowned scientists and former intelligence and military officials send a letter to all 100 U.S. senators calling for the prompt ratification of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty to prevent the weaponization of stolen nuclear secrets by Communist China.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian directs the ROC Air Force to draw up a forward- looking blueprint for developing a new generation of warplanes to ensure supremacy in the skies over the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By extending the powers of their functions and allowing them discretion in the employment of their subordinates: that is how a ruler gives encouragement to the high ministers of state."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan takes part in World Police, Fire Games under its own name

TEXT.P: Taiwan took part in the 2009 World Police and Fire Games in the Canadian city of Vancouver under the name of Taiwan rather than Chinese Taipei which is normally used at most international sports events.

The National Police Agency under the Ministry of the Interior said in a press release Monday that the 49-member team organized by the National Police Agency and the National Fire Agency was led into the venue under the name of Taiwan, while the flag of the Republic of China was flown at the opening ceremony July 31.

It was the first time that the nation succeeded in breaking the tradition of using the name Chinese Taipei as stipulated in an agreement it entered with the International Olympic Committee in 1981, according to the press release.

That terms of agreement, which also prevented Taiwan from displaying its flag at the Olympics in return for China's approval of its participation, have since become a pattern for Taiwan's participation in international sports events.

The press release said the appearance of Taiwan's name plaque and flag at the World Police and Fire Games caught the attention of the spectators, who gave the Taiwan team a big round of applause at the opening ceremony.

According to the National Police Agency, its persistent requests and those of Taiwan's representative office in Vancouver, as well as the goodwill of the host country, helped to achieve the use of the name Taiwan at the games.
The biennial games, which started in 1985, has drawn more than 10,000 athletes from 60 countries for competition in 65 events and will run until Aug. 9.
Taiwan has so far taken part in 10 events at the games including judo, karate, taekwondo, shooting, tug-of-war, tennis, golf, badminton, field and track and swimming.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan, China should sign investment guarantee pact: SEF

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should sign an investment guarantee agreement as soon as possible to resolve the many pending cross-strait investment disputes, according to a Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) official.

SEF Deputy Secretary-General Ma Shao-chang made the appeal at a seminar on promoting cooperation between Taiwanese and Chinese small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which took place in Taipei Sunday.

Noting that cross-strait investment is now a two-way flow since Taiwan has opened its doors to Chinese capital, Ma said the two sides should negotiate and sign an investment guarantee agreement soon to provide better protection for investors from both sides.

By providing a legal framework that clearly sets out investment norms and protections on each side, a cross-strait investment guarantee accord will be help to encourage greater bilateral investment flows, Ma said.

Such an agreement usually includes principles of equitable treatment and non- discrimination, compensation in the event of expropriation, free transfer of funds, and mechanisms for settling disputes between investors and the state.
In his keynote speech, Ma also mentioned barriers and bottlenecks faced by Taiwanese companies operating in China.

"One of the obstacles is the difficulty for Taiwanese companies to obtain working capital," said the official from the SEF -- a quasi-official intermediary body authorized to handle cross-strait negotiations in the absence of formal ties.

Small and medium-sized enterprises form the backbone of the Taiwan economy, accounting for 98 percent of all companies. Taiwanese SMEs in China tend to be denied access to bank loans because Chinese banks have a hard time verifying their credit status, Ma said.
"We hope this problem can be resolved after a bilateral memorandum of understanding (MOU) on financial supervisory cooperation is signed," Ma said.

Another problem Taiwanese companies face is the myriad kinds of taxes levied on them by Chinese governments at various levels, Ma noted, adding that China should offer more tax incentives to Taiwan companies through cross-strait negotiations.
The seminar brought together officials and business executives from the two sides to discuss measures to promote cross-strait cooperation in SME development and joint marketing efforts.

Among the participants were Lai Shan-kuei, director of the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Small and Medium Enterprise Administration and He Zuoxien, director of the SME Bureau of China's Guangdong Province.

DOC.HEADLINE: Traffic accidents rise 5.3% in first half of year: ministry

TEXT.P: A total of 86,268 traffic accidents that resulted in injuries or death were recorded in the first six months of this year, a 5.3 percent rise from the same period last year, according to a report released Monday by the Ministry of the Interior.
The figures translated into a year-on-year increase in the accident rate, from 39.4 to 40.9 cases per 10,000 vehicles, the ministry said.

The ministry said that the increase reflected a 5.5 percent rise in the number of accidents that involved the injury of passengers or motorists and deaths that occurred more than 24 hours after the accident.

However, the number of road users who died within 24 hours of an accident declined by 10 percent, the ministry said. In that category, 19.7 percent of the fatalities were caused by drunk-driving, 17.7 percent as result of drivers not paying attention, and 12.5 percent because of drivers' failure to yield right of way as stipulated in traffic regulations, the report stated.

According to the report, two-wheeled vehicles are the most dangerous types of transport, as 43.6 percent of road fatalities involved riders of bicycles, motorcycles or scooters. The road fatality rate involving cars was 27.3 percent and trucks 17.6 percent, the report showed.

The statistics showed that most fatal accidents -- 11.36 percent -- occurred between 6: 00 p.m. and 8: 00 p.m., while 9.61 percent occurred between 6: 00 a.m. and 8: 00 a.m., and 9.09 percent between 12 noon and 2:00 p.m.

In terms of the areas where most fatal traffic accidents occur, Pingtung County was at the top of the list with 78 deaths in 77 accidents, followed by Tainan County with 76 deaths in 75 accidents, and Taichung County, with 72 deaths in 70 accidents, the report stated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't agency proposes introduction of 'green tax'

TEXT.P: The Taxation Agency under the Ministry of Finance convened a meeting Monday to discuss a proposal to introduce a "green tax" in Taiwan.

Once a green taxation policy is crafted by the administration and passed by the legislature, the government will be able to levy on high energy use and environmental pollution as part of its efforts to cut greenhouse gas emissions, a Taxation Agency official said.
It is hoped that the meeting will yield preliminary consensus on the direction, parameters and details of the proposed green tax, the official said.
The meeting was attending by officials from the Ministry of Finance, including Finance Minister Lee Sush-der, academics from research think tanks and representatives from the industrial sector.

According to a Taxation Agency plan, the energy tax will be tied to the production and consumption of fossil and nuclear energy, while the environment tax will target the production of greenhouse gas emissions and pollution of the air, surface and underground water, land, and the ocean.

Daigee Shaw, president of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, said that the green tax should be based on a "users and polluters pay" principle and designed to encourage energy conservation while granting incentives to those who meet the specified targets.

Shaw said the green taxation system that his think tank is proposing is not meant to increase taxes on the public, but rather is a two-pronged strategy for improving environmental protection and simplifying the taxation system.

Under a "financially independent" model, added revenues that the government collects via the green taxation system would be used to finance the overhaul of outdated taxation systems, the operations of mass rapid transport systems and research on energy conservation and emission reduction, he added.
He estimated that the green tax will help cut carbon dioxide emissions by 19.67 million tons within one year and by 78 million tons within 10 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese delegation to join international youth program in Israel

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese youth delegation will leave for Israel soon to attend an international ecology and leadership summer program for young people, the Israel Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei (ISECO) said Monday.

At the invitation of the Taipei-based Israeli office, five young people with volunteering background in animal or environmental protection will participate in the international youth exchange program, which is being organized by Israel's National Council for Youth Exchange.

The ISECO said in a press release that the program will focus on the themes of ecology and youth leadership, and will feature workshops, adventure, ecological and cultural activities, and trips to Israel's museums and popular tourist attractions.
The program is scheduled to be held Aug. 9-16 in Hakefar-Hayarok (Green Village) and will serve as a platform for cultural exchanges among the participants, the office said.
The five members of the Taiwanese delegation were recommended by Taiwan's National Youth Commission (NYC).

They are Chang Hsin-yu from National Chengchi University's Department of Arabic Language and Literature; Cheng Yu-shun from National Taiwan University's Department of Geography; Lin Yun from Taipei Municipal First GirlsSenior High School; Chen Wan-shiuan, a volunteer with the Taiwan Environmental Information Center; and Hsieh Feng-ho, a volunteer with the Society of Wilderness.
The youth group will be led by Professor Kuo Shou-wang from Shih Chien University's Department of Applied Foreign Languages.
All accommodation costs will be covered by the Israeli Youth Council, the ISECO said.
In a meeting with the delegation last week, Israel's Representative to Taiwan Raphael Gamzou gave a short introduction of Israel and the program.
He also shared with the students his and his wife's experience in joining some of the volunteer activities of Taiwan's Buddhist Tzu-Chi Foundation.
"I hope that the success of this trip will help to promote the signing of a mutual youth exchange memorandum of understanding (MOU) between Taiwan and Israel," said Gamzou.

The ISECO and Taiwan's representative office in Tel Aviv are working with the Taiwan NYC and its Israeli counterpart to ink an MOU later this year on exchanges between young people of the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health minister resigns (update-1)

TEXT.P: Department of Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan, who is making a bid to run in the year-end magisterial elections on the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) ticket in Hualien County, resigned Monday.
Yeh tendered his resignation during a meeting with Premier Liu Chao-shiuan Monday morning, Government Information Office Minister Su Jun-pin said.
Su said Liu approved Yeh's resignation with effect from Aug. 6.

Yeh, who is thought to be an ace up the KMT's sleeve in its bid to maintain control of Hualien County, will first have to compete in party primaries for the KMT candidacy in the Hualien magisterial election.
His resignation, which comes at a time when the country is gripped by swine flue, has drawn criticism from lawmakers of both the ruling and opposition parties.

Legislator Tu Shiing-jer of the Democratic Progressive Party said Yeh, who helped President Ma Ying-jeou during his term as Taipei mayor to deal with the SARS crisis in 2003, is trying to help Ma again by working with the KMT to retain its control of Hualien County.
"This suggests that in the eyes of President Ma, politics comes before the health of the people," Tu said.

Legislator Chou Yi of the KMT echoed Tu's views, saying that Yeh's resignation is a bad decision made at the worst possible time and it sends a message that the KMT's reelection in Hualien is more important than the country's struggle with swine flu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourism bureau holds seminars in foreign offices to market Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau said Monday that seminars were held last week in 10 of Taiwan's foreign offices, as part of the bureau's efforts to seek creative ways of promoting the country's tourism.

According to the Tourism Bureau, the three-day seminars took place July 29 in the Foreign Ministry's representative offices in Tokyo, Osaka, Seoul, Hong Kong, Singapore, Kuala Lumpur, New York, San Francisco, Los Angeles and Frankfurt.

"The seminars were geared toward finding creative ways to promote tourism products in Taiwan through brainstorming, analyzing market information, and taking into consideration the specific needs of each of the overseas areas," the bureau said in a press release.
The Tourism Bureau invited the heads of the 10 offices to analyze the preferences of each of the foreign cities and come up with better promotion ideas.
The meeting discussed topics such as how to attract tourists from emerging markets and how to develop the Taiwan market for bicycle and leisure tours.

"The participants at the seminars all expressed confidence in the revival of the tourism market in the later half of the year, anticipating that the economic situation will improve and more people will start traveling again as the global outbreak of H1N1 influenza becomes milder," according to the bureau.

The Tokyo office noted that from January to June, the number of Japanese traveling abroad was down by 37.1 percent compared to the same period last year, and the number of Japanese tourists to Taiwan was down by 4 percent in that period.

Many new programs, such as the "good luck tours" and packages with culinary themes, targeting Japanese tourists will be launched in 2010, which has been designated as Taiwan-Japan tourism exchange year, the office said.
The Los Angeles office said that it will develop "stop over" tour packages and cooperate with other Asian countries to encourage tourists to China to include Taiwan on their itinerary.

The Executive Yuan launched a NT$30 billion program in April in an effort to turn Taiwan into a regional tourism hub that could generate NT$550 billion (US$16.5 billion) in tourism revenue in four years and help create 400,000 jobs in the tourism industry by 2012.
The government has set a goal of 4.1 million foreign tourist arrivals in 2009, 4.5 million in 2010, 5 million in 2011 and 5.5 million in 2012.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese Taipei slaughters China in Asian baseball championships

TEXT.P: Taiwan slaughtered China 13-1 Monday in the 25th Asian Baseball Championship in Sapporo, Japan, wiping out agrievance resulting from humiliating defeats to China in the 2008 Beijing Olympics and World Baseball Classic in March.
The Taiwanese brought into full play their ability against the Chinese, making three homeruns and 14 hits.
Chinese Taipei opened the scoring with two points in the first inning, thanks to a wild pitch by China's starter Lu Jiangang and a second-base hit by Taiwan's Lin Hung-yu.
They scored another point in the second inning thanks to several defensive mistakes by the Chinese players.
In the third inning, Chinese Taipei began a powerful offensive, scoring another six points by the end of that inning.
By the fourth inning, Taiwan had a seemingly unassailable 9: 0 lead over China, made even stronger when Liu Chien-chung scored with a hit in the fifth.
By the sixth inning, the Taiwanese lions of the field had secured a decisive lead of 11-1 against China before finishing in the seventh inning 13-1 after Wu Tsung-chun struck a two-point homerun.
The Taiwanese baseballers had been striving to even the score after unexpected losses in recent years to Chinese teams, which are regarded as having much less experience than the Taiwanese.
Chinese Taipei beat South Korea 5-4 Saturday in the championships that opened that day in Hokkaido, capital of Sapporo Prefecture in northern Japan.
It was defeated 6-5 by defending champion Japan the following day.
Four teams -- South Korea, Japan, Chinese Taipei and China -- are in the semi- final round of the regional baseball championships, which are held every two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Monday:
Liberty Times: Booming real estate and stock markets not a sign of economic recovery.
Taiwan's booming stock and real estate markets do not signal the country's economic recovery.
Actually, we are worried that President Ma Ying-jeou's increasing dependence on China for help with the country's economic woes will do more harm than good to Taiwan.
Our worries are well grounded, as the Asian Development Bank has forecast Taiwan's economic growth at 2.4 percent for 2010, which is the second-lowest in Asia.
China's economic development is more the result of a currency glut than an increase in production.
Apple Daily: Coast Guard Administration is fawning over president.
The Coast Guard Administration is currying favor with President Ma Ying-jeou by asking its staff to follow Ma's "blue revolution and strengthening the country by exploring the oceans."
China Times: Deaflympics in Taipei should be as successful as World Games in Kaohsiung.
The success of the Kaohsiung World Games undoubtedly has brought pressure to bear on Taipei City, which will host the Deaflympics Sept. 5-15.
Since the The World Games was opened by President Ma Ying-jeou in his capacity of the country's head, people are sure to expect the organizing committee of the Taipei Deaflympics to follow suit.

We are not certain that Taipei can do this, as the Deaflympics organizing committee has claimed that it follows the rules of the International Olympic Committee, in which Taiwan uses the name Chinese Taipei rather than the Republic of China.
It suggested that Ma probably will not be able to preside over the opening of the Deaflympics as he did at the World Games.
But we do not see why Taipei cannot do what Kaohsiung could, and the public will brook no excuse if Taipei fails to do this.
United Daily News: Ex-president's ill-gotten wealth should be confiscated.
Ex-President Chen Shui-bian's ill-gotten wealth is estimated at about NT$2 billion, most of which is salted away in banks overseas.
Whether justice is done in the case involving Chen and his family will be judged not only by what punishments the court hands down but also by whether their ill- gotten gains are confiscated.
We urge the court of appeal to take this into consideration when it considers whether to release Chen Shui-bian on bail.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan picture book selected as notable children's book in U.S.

TEXT.P: Artie and Julie, a picture book written and illustrated by Taiwanese author Chen Chih-yuan, has been selected as one of 10 notable children's books of 2009 by a U.S. teachers organization, a publishing source said Monday.

The English-language book about two friends -- Artie the lion and Julie the rabbit -- has been selected one of the top notable children's books by the prestigious Children's Literature Assembly under the U.S. National Council of Teachers of English (NCTE) for its Notables Award, according to Heryin Publishing Co., which published the Chinese edition of Artie and Julie in 2006.

Artie and Julie will be featured, along with 29 other notable children's books, at the NCTE Convention slated for November this year and at the International Reading Association (IRA) Convention in 2010, as well as in the Autumn 2009 edition of the Journal of Children's Literature, said Chou Yih-fen, editor-in- chief of Heryin Books Inc.

The 30 titles, which include works of fiction, non-fiction, poetry and picture books written for children, demonstrate uniqueness in the use of language or style, involve word play, word origins, or the history of language, and invite child response or participation, according to the NCTE assembly.

Having received glowing reviews from the U.S.-based Kirkus Reviews, the English edition of Artie and Julie, published in the United States last year, was introduced as "a good book worthy of having," according to Chou.
So far, Chen, 34, has six illustrated children's books to his name, including Guji Guji, On My Way to Buy Eggs, The Featherless Chicken and The Best Christmas Ever.

He is also the only Chinese writer and illustrator to have repeatedly won international recognition for his work, including a best children's book award presented by the U.S. Publishers Weekly in 2003 and a best children's book award presented by the Japan Library Association in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president's daughter still banned from leaving country

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court upheld a ruling Monday in which it refused to lift an overseas travel ban on former President Chen Shui-bian's daughter, Chen Hsing- yu.
The ruling, however, said that Chen Hsing-yu could file for permission to go abroad in the event of an absolute necessity.
The Taipei District Court will hold another pre-trial court hearing on her travel ban Aug. 13, according to the ruling.

In the course of investigating perjury charges against Chen Hsing-yu in connection with a case against the former president, prosecutors imposed an overseas travel ban on the former first daughter June 23.
She later appealed the ruling, so a panel of three judges at the district court decided to hold a pre-trial court hearing to decide whether to remove or uphold the travel ban.
Prosecutors indicted Chen Hsing-yu on perjury charges July 17. Also indicted in the case were her husband Chao Chien-ming and her younger brother Chen Chih- chung.
Her mother, former first lady Wu Shu-jen, was also charged with coercing her children to give false testimony in the corruption case against the former president.

Prosecutors of the Special Investigation Division of the Supreme Prosecutors Office found inconsistencies in the testimony given in May by Chen Chih-chung, Chen Hsing-yu and Chao Chien-ming during their probe into the former president's alleged misuse of public funds during his term in office from 2000 through May 2008.

The indictment said the three lied to prosecutors when they claimed that receipts they provided to Wu to claim reimbursement from the president's special state affairs fund were for gifts they had bought for their parents.
Despite the indictment, prosecutors from the Taipei District Prosecutors Office have asked the court to treat them leniently because they admitted to perjury.
Wu also confessed that she urged her children to give false testimony to cover up her offenses.
Wu was indicted on corruption charges in November 2006 in a separate case, but prosecutors have not sought to detain the wheelchair-bound former first lady.

Chen Shui-bian has been detained since last December on charges of corruption, money laundering and embezzlement -- crimes he is accused of committing during his presidency. The former president has insisted on his innocence, claiming that "history will clear his name."
The court is scheduled to hand down a ruling on his case Sept. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: Govt to promote ecology tours on two outlying islands

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) has decided to promote ecological tours on two offshore islands, the Tourism Bureau said Monday.

One of them, Green Island, is a small volcanic island located 33 kilometers off the coast of eastern Taiwan's Taitung County. The other, Hsiao Liuchiu, is a tiny coral islet off the coast of southern Pingtung County.

Both islands hold some of the most beautiful scenery in Taiwan, but development, including tourism development, in recent years has led to some environmental damages. For example, snorkelers have damaged some of the coral reef on Green Island by stepping on them. Overfishing and local restaurants' ability to sell coral reef fish, have also led to a reduction in that type of fish, which live in coral reefs and make the reefs more beautiful. Divers have reported there are far less fish than in the past.
Local environmental protection groups have been urging the government to do something about these problems.
By turning the islands into ecology-focused tourism destinations, the government hopes to reduce harm to the islands.

"The Tourism Bureau has mapped out strategies to promote ecological tours, such as promotion of the use of low-CO2 emission transportation tools and energy- saving equipment, as well as public education," the bureau said in a press statement.

It is unclear, however, whether such measures will work. On Green Island, the local office of the Tourism Bureau has said it has tried to encourage tourists to ride bicycles instead of hiring cars and scooters, but few tourists do so and there is little promotion of eco-friendly ways of sightseeing on the island or on the boats taking tourists to the island.
Sometimes, thousands of tourists rent scooters and zip through Green Island's roads in packs, changing the quiet, rustic atmosphere of the island.
Hsiao Liuchiu is less developed than Green Island.
The Tourism Bureau's plans for the two islands are part of a larger plan to boost tourism in Taiwan in the next few years.

The Executive Yuan launched a NT$30 billion-budget program in April in an effort to turn Taiwan into a tourism hub in East Asia that could generate NT$550 billion (US$16.8 billion) in tourism revenue in four years and help create 400,000 jobs in the tourism industry by 2012.
The government hopes to achieve at least 4.1 million foreign tourist arrivals in 2009, 4.5 million in 2010, 5 million in 2011 and 5.5 million in 2012.
As part of its efforts, the Tourism Bureau plans to divide the country into four major regions featuring different themes to cater to the different tastes of tourists from around the world.

To promote northern Taiwan, the bureau will feature lifestyle aspects such as the arts, pop music and fashion. Tea and flower gardens will be the main focus of the bureau when it introduces central Taiwan to potential tourists, while historic monuments will be the major attraction in its efforts to promote southern Taiwan.

The slow pace of life in eastern Taiwan will be capitalized on with an emphasis on bicycle riding tours and the cultures of indigenous tribes in the area, while the offshore counties of Penghu and Kinmen will be promoted as international resort islands and as the location of Cold War military relics, respectively.
