DOC.HEADLINE: Safety of H1N1 vaccine guaranteed as production set to begin

TEXT.P: The sole Taiwanese producer of a vaccine for the swine flu guaranteed Monday that its product will be safe and effective as it was gearing up to begin mass production of the yet untested formula.

"Mass production of the vaccine against influenza A (H1N1) for local use will get underway Tuesday with procedures precisely following international standards," said Ignatius Wei, deputy CEO and president of Adimmune Corp., Taiwan's only human vaccine manufacturer.
Taiwan will be the world's 12th country to produce a swine flu vaccine, Wei said.
Although this will be the first time that Adimmune has manufactured flu vaccines, Wei said the company has plenty of experience in producing vaccines for humans.
It is currently one of the major suppliers of vaccines for Japanese encephalitis and tetanus for use in Taiwan.
The partially state-owned company has chosen the seed virus provided by a World Health Organization (WHO) -authorized lab in New York for mass production of the vaccine, Wei said.
The company began animal trials of the vaccine in mid-July, and the Adimmune president said initial test results have been good.
"Animal trials have proven the safety and effectiveness of our products, with no lab animal showing any apparent side effects," Wei said.
Human trials will begin in October, with National Taiwan University Hospital taking charge of the project.

Only 200 volunteers will have to undergo tests, Wei said. The WHO has agreed to the unusually small sampling size for all swine flu vaccine producers, in part because it is simply a flu vaccine and not a new drug.
As to the company's production capacity, Wei said Adimmune will be able to produce more than 200,000 doses per day.
The company on Monday attempted to dispel misgivings about its ability to produce safe and effective flu vaccines for human use under time pressure.

Ho Mei-hsiang, an Academia Sinica biomedical research fellow who concurrently heads Adimmune's R&D department, said using chicken egg embryos to produce flu vaccines is not new and instead a mature technology that has been in use for more than half a century.
"Like vaccines against seasonal flu, those against swine flu are also being produced with chicken egg embryos and using the same technology, " Ho said.
She stressed that the company will strictly follow international norms and procedures in the production process.
"Any doses that fail to meet the standards will not be marketed," she insisted.
Before they get to market, the vaccines first have to undergo 24 kinds of tests within six weeks before they are presented to the Department of Health for approval to start human trials.
If the vaccine passes human trials without problems, it still needs to be certified by the DOH's Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs before being used on patients, Ho explained.
Taiwan has so far reported six severe A (H1N1) cases, including one death from the flu strain. As of Saturday, 12 H1N1 cluster infections, involving about 600 people, had also been confirmed.
Former DOH Minister Chen Chien-jen, an epidemiologist, warned in an interview with a local newspaper last Friday that Taiwan is approaching a stage where the A(H1N1) flu will spread quickly.
"If we fail to intensify prevention efforts, a major outbreak could hit in late September or October, the traditional flu peak season," Chen said.
He suggested that the government speed up purchases of anti-viral drugs and vaccines to cope with any possible outbreak of the disease.
DOH officials said the department plans to purchase up to 10 million doses of swine flu vaccine to meet domestic demand.
The DOH has ordered 5 million doses of the vaccine from Adimmune Corp. and has formed a special task force to monitor progress in vaccine research and development for the H1N1 flu strain.
If necessary, the officials said, the DOH will seek foreign supplies to make up for deficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature suggests making IPR protection an ECFA issue

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan has recently suggested listing intellectual property rights (IPR) protection in a planned cross-Taiwan Strait Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) , as IPR disputes involving Taiwanese businessmen operating in China are often reported.
The Legislature's Organic Laws and Statutes Bureau brought up the proposal in its latest report on China's existing IPR laws and their effect on Taiwanese businessmen with operations there.

The report attributed the occurrence of most legal disputes in the Chinese market to be related to patents, trademarks and copyrights held by Taiwanese businesses, as the value of IPR has never been treated as an asset in China and Taiwanese businessmen there have never been able to map out IPR protection strategies.
The report also said "protectionism" is the greatest hurdle facing Taiwanese investors doing business in China.

Moreover, it pointed out that while the two sides have different patent laws, China has a lack of experience and technique in handling patent disputes. The Chinese authorities therefore are often seen as inefficient in protecting Taiwanese businesses' IPR interests, the report said.

The report, therefore, suggested building an "IPR forum Web site" for Taiwanese businessmen operating in China that can serve as a platform for information and opinion exchanges on IPR issues, as well as a place where people can have their questions on IPR answered.

The report also suggested placing the issue of opening offices in charge of cross-strait IPR disputes on the agenda of the planned fourth round of talks between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), which is slated for later this year.

Another option would be to include in the proposed ECFA the issue of having regular cross-strait exchanges of personnel responsible for patent and trademark review affairs and cross-strait cooperation in fighting counterfeiting, forgery and pirating, the report said.
The SEF and ARATS are the two intermediary bodies founded to handle issues concerning cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei bus drivers learning sign language for Deaflympics

TEXT.P: More than 800 bus drivers employed by the Capital Bus Company are learning sign language for the deaf in order to offer better services to athletes competing in the upcoming 21st Summer Deaflympics to be held Sept. 5-15 in Taipei City, a spokesman for the private company said Monday.
General Manager Lee Chien-wen said the company broadcasts a lecture film at every bus marshaling center on the hour every day to give drivers the chance to learn the language on their own.

The company has also hired several dactylology teachers from the city's Department of Labor to give drivers training in the use of simple hand signals so that they can communicate with Deaflympics participants, Lee said.

Capital Bus has been awarded every year since 2000 by the city government for offering excellent public bus services and sparing no efforts to improve its facilities, such as adding new low-floor vehicles last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Star Cruises liner arrives in Tainan

TEXT.P: The Star Cruises liner Aquarius arrived Monday in Tainan City's Anping Port in southern Taiwan, bringing about 1,500 passengers from Hong Kong.

About 50 percent of the 1,500 tourists are Chinese, with the other half from more than 10 countries making what will be a three-day visit to Taiwan. Reporters from Hong Kong and China are also traveling aboard the ship to cover the story.

It is the first big group of tourists from China to sightsee in Tainan City since an incident in October last year in which Chang Mingqing, vice president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, was chased and pushed to the ground by a group of pro-independence supporters while he was touring the city's Confucius temple on his own.

Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair and city government officials gave a warm welcome to the visitors at Anping, while quarantine and immigration officials boarded the ship to take care of their responsibilities.
The visitors headed in three groups to different tourist destinations in the Tainan area, which ranged from sites of historic interest to ecology and shopping tours.
The cruise ship is slated to take the visitors to Taichung in central Taiwan Tuesday and to Keelung in the north of the country Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health minister's run for Hualien magistrate stirs controversy

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yeh Ching-chuan announced Monday that he will run for the magisterial seat in the eastern county of Hualien after his resignation request was approved by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan earlier that day.
His resignation, which comes at a time when the country is facing mounting fears over a potential swine flu epidemic, has drawn
criticism from lawmakers of both the ruling and opposition parties.

Yeh was scheduled to hold a press conference later in the day to respond to the criticism, and will stick with his plan to visit Hong Kong later in the week to attend a forum on the prevention of A(H1N1) infection and exchange views with members of the medical establishment there.

In order to secure the KMT's nomination, he will have to compete in party primaries with other party members including Legislator Fu Kun-chi, Hualien County Council Speaker Yang Wen-chi, Hualien Mayor Tsai Chi-ta and former Hualien County Agricultural Development Office Director Tu Li-hua, who have also registered with the party to participate in the primary.

Yeh, the country's first health minister to take part in the World Health Assembly (WHA) , said he hopes the KMT will retain its control of Hualien County and that he will support the winner of the primary if he does not get the nomination.
Yeh, once an adjunct professor at Hualien's Tzu Chi University, has lived in the eastern county for 10 years.
His decision scotched rumors that the KMT leadership was hoping Yeh would run for the post of mayor of the recently approved special municipality of New Taipei City.
A hero of the SARS crisis of 2003 when he was deputy mayor of Taipei, Yeh announced his participation in the Taipei mayoral primary three years ago but later withdrew from the race.

He was appointed to the top DOH position last September when former Health Minister Lin Fang-yue was forced to resign to take responsibility for the panic caused by melamine-tainted milk from China entering the Taiwan market.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-speed railway hit by another signal malfunction

TEXT.P: A signal from a track switch on Taiwan's high-speed railway malfunctioned Monday between Yunlin and Chiayi, resulting in the cancellation of seven trains in order to accommodate two-way traffic on a single track.
The glitch occurred at 4: 40 p.m. and was repaired two hours later, Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. said.

It was the railway's second mechanical failure in three days. On Saturday, five trains were canceled and 20 others delayed due to a similar problem that hit the railway between Miaoli and Yuanli in northern Taiwan.

Even before the cause of Saturday's malfunction was determined, the track switch on the railway's Huwei section in Yunlin County failed to send a signal to the traffic control center at nearby Chiayi Station as usual Monday evening.
When such a glitch occurs, the control center has to bar any train from passing that section, a spokesman for Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp.'s Chiayi Station said
"As a result, the Chiayi-Yunlin section was only able to maintain a 'single- track, two-way' service mode," the spokesman said.
Monday's signal malfunction led to the cancellation of seven trains and more than 30-minute delays to many others, the company said.
Including Monday's malfunction, 22 signal malfunctions have hit the railway since its inauguration two and a half years ago.

Chu Hsu, director-general of the Bureau of Taiwan High Speed Rail under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications which oversees THSRC operations, said Monday that the high frequency of switch malfunctions is unacceptable.

Chu has directed the company to intensify its maintenance routine and conduct an overall review of its design and installation procedures to get to the root cause of the problem and make the necessary improvements.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan workers on unpaid leave sharply down in July

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwanese workers remaining on unpaid leave dropped by late July, the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) reported Monday about a practice taken by some local firms to cope with the economic downturn.
A total of 74,468 workers remained on unpaid leave as of the end of July, down by 5,499 people compared to the figure recorded as of July 15, the CLA said.
Early March was the time when the number of Taiwanese workers put on mandatory unpaid leave peaked -- at 238,975, which is more than triple the current figure, according to the CLA.
Since March, the monthly figure had started to steadily decreased. The number of workers on unpaid leave at the end of June was 126,175.

While not commenting on whether the reduced number of workers on unpaid leave was an indication that the worst was over for Taiwan's economy, CLA officials did say that a steadfast rebound in orders placed by foreign buyers for local companies was a factor.
As of the end of last month, 655 enterprises still had employees on unpaid leave, but that was a fall from 704 for the first half of the same month.

After the global financial crisis broke out late last year, the CLA has since January required local enterprises to report the number of workers they have asked to take unpaid leave, to better monitor the impact of the sagging economy and falling exports on Taiwan's labor market.

About 202,000 Taiwanese workers have been put by their company on mandatory furlough since December 2008, due to their companies' bad business performance, with those in the high-tech sector making up the bulk of the companies using this practice.

The practice stirred debate. While employers say it gives them the flexibility of having staff readily available when business improved, labor rights groups have criticized the move because it spares the companies from paying the workers severance pay if they were to layoff the employees, and the employees lost a chunk of their income.
Some employees were put on unpaid leave for at least a couple of days a month, while others had to take several days off a month. Many employees, however, were grateful to keep their jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung MRT revenue increases to record high thanks to World Games

TEXT.P: Benefiting from higher passenger traffic during the 2009 World Games, the Kaohsiung mass rapid transport system took in more than NT$100 million (US$3.05 million) in revenue in July, the most it has collected in any single month in its history.

The system also set a monthly record by transporting 4.4 million passengers in July, up from 3.8 million in May and 3.1 million in June, said Huang I-chung, the director of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp.'s (KRTC's) Public Affairs Department.
During the 11-day World Games, which ran from July 16-26, an average of 150,000 passengers rode Kaohsiung's MRT lines on weekdays and 190,000 took the trains on weekends, Huang added.
The record revenue in July was calculated based on the assumption that each passenger paid an average fare of NT$24 per ride.
Since beginning commercial runs in April 2008 after a month-long free trial run, the MRT has totaled revenues of between NT$80 million and NT$90 million a month, Huang said.
Monthly revenue had never previously surpassed NT$100 million, even when KRTC offered incentives to push up ridership numbers, he said.

Despite July's encouraging numbers, however, the company does not expect they will substantially ease its financial woes. KRTC posted an estimated loss of NT$1.2 billion in the first half of the year and it expects to lose NT$2.5 billion for the year, Huang said.
The spokesman said interest on loans to construct the line and depreciation on equipment are the company's biggest burdens, costing a total of about NT$2.2 billion annually.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumption vouchers will definitely raise GDP by 0.66%: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumption voucher program will definitely help boost the country's annual gross domestic product (GDP) by at least 0.66 percent, the government's top economic planner reaffirmed Monday.

Chen Tain-jy, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), made the assertion in response to a recent report by the Ministry of Audit under the watchdog Control Yuan, which questioned the voucher program's effectiveness in stimulating the sluggish economy.

"It remains to be seen whether the NT$85.7 billion consumption voucher program can live up to its goal of stimulating economic growth given its high substitution rate and issuance cost, " the ministry said in its report.
Chen said the CEPD has commissioned Academia Sinica -- Taiwan's foremost research institute -- to evaluate the effects of the consumption vouchers program.
Citing an initial report by the Academia Sinica's research team, Chen said the consumption voucher "substitution rate" was between 60 percent and 70 percent.
That means that 60 percent to 70 percent of the vouchers used by consumers replaced purchases they would have made anyway, with the rest additional spending.
"Such a ratio reflects normal consumption activities and by no means implies that the program had a poor effect," Chen explained.

Judging from consumption patterns during the Lunar New Year holiday and retail sales volume for the period, Chen said he was 100 percent sure that the consumption voucher program will boost GDP growth by an estimated 0.66 percent.
Chen, however, acknowledged another of the report's criticisms -- that the program was too rushed, possibly diminishing its effectiveness.
He attributed the haste in issuing the vouchers to the government's desire to take advantage of the Chinese New Year shopping spree.

The government issued the consumption vouchers with a face value of NT$3,600 per set before the Lunar New Year holiday in January in an attempt to boost slumping domestic economy amid a global financial crisis.

To date, most of the consumption vouchers have been distributed and cashed in, CEPD officials said, adding that the council is scheduled to present a comprehensive assessment report to the Legislative Yuan in October.
All consumption vouchers must be used by the end of September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese procurement group to arrive in Taiwan later this month

TEXT.P: A delegation organized by the Association of Economy and Trade Across Taiwan Straits (AETATS) under China's Ministry of Commerce is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Aug. 19 for a week-long procurement visit, a semi-official trade group announced Monday.

The AETATS procurement group, the third of its kind, will comprise representatives from 55 Chinese companies, including Chongqing Hybest Air Tools Co, Ltd. and Kingfa Science & Technology Development Co, Ltd., according to officials at the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).

The Chinese procurement group will target some of Taiwan's most competitive items, including machinery, electronics, petrochemical goods, garments, footwear, and car accessories and parts, TAITRA officials said.
The total value of the group's purchases is expected to exceed US$1.2 billion.
The first AETATS-organized delegation came to Taiwan in May to purchase information technology and consumer electronics products.
The second AETATS group visited Taiwan from July 12-17 to buy specialty foods, giftware, daily necessities and handicrafts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water supply in Taoyuan area may be further rationed

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) could further cut or suspend water supply to selected sectors in the northern county of Taoyuan if the current dry spell continues, an official said Monday.

Because of lower-than-usual rainfall this summer, the water level in the Shihmen Reservoir -- the major source of potable water in the Taoyuan area -- has been falling rapidly and is approaching an alarmingly low level.
Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Huang Chung-chiou said the water supply has been cut during off-peak hours in the area.

"If the drought gets worse, we will not rule out the possibility of rationing the supply of water to certain heavy water-consuming services, such as car washes, spas, swimming pools and tall-building cleaning services, " Huang said, adding that the new restrictions may be announced Aug. 11.

To encourage water conservation, Huang said, the MOEA's Water Resources Agency (WRA) plans to offer subsidies for those who buy water-efficient appliances or equipment, just as the government has done in the past to encourage the purchase of energy-efficient home appliances.
According to Huang, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan will visit the Shihmen Reservoir Tuesday to decide if any measures need to be taken immediately to cope with the continuing dry spell.

Meanwhile, WRA Deputy Director-General Wu Yueh-hsi said that if no rain falls in the Taoyuan area in the coming days. the agency may further restrict water supply for agricultural use from late August.

Water supply for irrigation in the Taoyuan area has been cut by 30 percent since July, Wu said, adding that if necessary, irrigation water supply may be suspended from late August in order to ensure that water supply for household and industrial use will not be rationed until late October.
Similar water shortage problems are also troubling southern Taiwan, with major reservoirs in the region drying out due to limited precipitation.

Wu said his agency will immediately impose a rationing system in Tainan and Penghu counties where water supply for household use at night will be cut and water for irrigation purposes will be provided based on a "10 days on, five days off" supply model.
He also urged local residents to minimize water consumption in the face of Taiwan's prolonged drought.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmaker to lead an aboriginal delegation to visit China

TEXT.P: An aboriginal delegation will visit China later this month in a bid to help boost the economic prospects of Taiwan's indigenous peoples.
Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei of the Nonpartisan Solidarity Union will lead the delegation to visit Beijing and Yunnan province in southwestern China Aug. 19-27, her office director said Monday.
Chang Chun-chieh said this will be the first aboriginal delegation to visit China since the two sides of the Taiwan Strait began exchanges more than two decades ago.
Kao Chin's delegation will exchange views with related Chinese government agencies on issues that have long concerned indigenous peoples.

China is expected to announce measures to help the visitors, such as donation for the construction of "hope" elementary schools, an idea first initiated by Taiwanese in China, as well as a program to help aboriginal dropouts.

The delegation will also ask China to include indigenous communities in the itineraries of Chinese tourists and help sell agricultural produce grown by Taiwan's indigenous peoples to help them improve their incomes, Chang added.
He said it as "quite a pity" that when Chinese tourists visit Sun Moon Lake and Alishan, they do not have the chance to visit indigenous villages near these scenic spots.
He said aboriginal culture forms a major part of local culture, and if Chinese tourists could observe indigenous communities, they would understand the real Taiwan.
He noted that the Taiwan External Trade Development Council recently discussed the purchase of handicrafts made by local indigenous peoples while meeting with Chinese procurement groups in Taiwan.

The delegation hopes to further discuss the issue with China's Ministry of Commerce on the overall purchase proposal and amount, hoping that China can systematically introduce handicrafts from Taiwan's indigenous peoples and establish a marketing network there.
A traditional eight-part Bunun chorus will travel with the delegation, and it is expected to meet with the Dai and Na Xi tribes in Yunnan province in southwestern China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug. 4 , 2009

TEXT.P: of Rotary International Date and Time: 9:30 a.m., Tuesday, Aug. 4, 2009 Place: Presidential Office
Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

Yeh, the country's first health minister to take part in the World Health Assembly (WHA) , said he hopes the KMT will retain its control of Hualien County and that he will support the winner of the primary if he does not get the nomination.
Yeh, once an adjunct professor at Hualien's Tzu Chi University, has lived in the eastern county for 10 years.
His decision scotched rumors that the KMT leadership was hoping Yeh would run for the post of mayor of the recently approved special municipality of New Taipei City.
A hero of the SARS crisis of 2003 when he was deputy mayor of Taipei, Yeh announced his participation in the Taipei mayoral primary three years ago but later withdrew from the race.

He was appointed to the top DOH position last September when former Health Minister Lin Fang-yue was forced to resign to take responsibility for the panic caused by melamine-tainted milk from China entering the Taiwan market.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-speed railway hit by another signal malfunction

TEXT.P: A signal from a track switch on Taiwan's high-speed railway malfunctioned Monday between Yunlin and Chiayi, resulting in the cancellation of seven trains in order to accommodate two-way traffic on a single track.
The glitch occurred at 4: 40 p.m. and was repaired two hours later, Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. said.

It was the railway's second mechanical failure in three days. On Saturday, five trains were canceled and 20 others delayed due to a similar problem that hit the railway between Miaoli and Yuanli in northern Taiwan.

Even before the cause of Saturday's malfunction was determined, the track switch on the railway's Huwei section in Yunlin County failed to send a signal to the traffic control center at nearby Chiayi Station as usual Monday evening.
When such a glitch occurs, the control center has to bar any train from passing that section, a spokesman for Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp.'s Chiayi Station said
"As a result, the Chiayi-Yunlin section was only able to maintain a 'single- track, two-way' service mode," the spokesman said.
Monday's signal malfunction led to the cancellation of seven trains and more than 30-minute delays to many others, the company said.
Including Monday's malfunction, 22 signal malfunctions have hit the railway since its inauguration two and a half years ago.

Chu Hsu, director-general of the Bureau of Taiwan High Speed Rail under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications which oversees THSRC operations, said Monday that the high frequency of switch malfunctions is unacceptable.

Chu has directed the company to intensify its maintenance routine and conduct an overall review of its design and installation procedures to get to the root cause of the problem and make the necessary improvements.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan workers on unpaid leave sharply down in July

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwanese workers remaining on unpaid leave dropped by late July, the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) reported Monday about a practice taken by some local firms to cope with the economic downturn.
A total of 74,468 workers remained on unpaid leave as of the end of July, down by 5,499 people compared to the figure recorded as of July 15, the CLA said.
Early March was the time when the number of Taiwanese workers put on mandatory unpaid leave peaked -- at 238,975, which is more than triple the current figure, according to the CLA.
Since March, the monthly figure had started to steadily decreased. The number of workers on unpaid leave at the end of June was 126,175.

While not commenting on whether the reduced number of workers on unpaid leave was an indication that the worst was over for Taiwan's economy, CLA officials did say that a steadfast rebound in orders placed by foreign buyers for local companies was a factor.
As of the end of last month, 655 enterprises still had employees on unpaid leave, but that was a fall from 704 for the first half of the same month.

After the global financial crisis broke out late last year, the CLA has since January required local enterprises to report the number of workers they have asked to take unpaid leave, to better monitor the impact of the sagging economy and falling exports on Taiwan's labor market.

About 202,000 Taiwanese workers have been put by their company on mandatory furlough since December 2008, due to their companies' bad business performance, with those in the high-tech sector making up the bulk of the companies using this practice.

The practice stirred debate. While employers say it gives them the flexibility of having staff readily available when business improved, labor rights groups have criticized the move because it spares the companies from paying the workers severance pay if they were to layoff the employees, and the employees lost a chunk of their income.
Some employees were put on unpaid leave for at least a couple of days a month, while others had to take several days off a month. Many employees, however, were grateful to keep their jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung MRT revenue increases to record high thanks to World Games

TEXT.P: Benefiting from higher passenger traffic during the 2009 World Games, the Kaohsiung mass rapid transport system took in more than NT$100 million (US$3.05 million) in revenue in July, the most it has collected in any single month in its history.

The system also set a monthly record by transporting 4.4 million passengers in July, up from 3.8 million in May and 3.1 million in June, said Huang I-chung, the director of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp.'s (KRTC's) Public Affairs Department.
During the 11-day World Games, which ran from July 16-26, an average of 150,000 passengers rode Kaohsiung's MRT lines on weekdays and 190,000 took the trains on weekends, Huang added.
The record revenue in July was calculated based on the assumption that each passenger paid an average fare of NT$24 per ride.
Since beginning commercial runs in April 2008 after a month-long free trial run, the MRT has totaled revenues of between NT$80 million and NT$90 million a month, Huang said.
Monthly revenue had never previously surpassed NT$100 million, even when KRTC offered incentives to push up ridership numbers, he said.

Despite July's encouraging numbers, however, the company does not expect they will substantially ease its financial woes. KRTC posted an estimated loss of NT$1.2 billion in the first half of the year and it expects to lose NT$2.5 billion for the year, Huang said.
The spokesman said interest on loans to construct the line and depreciation on equipment are the company's biggest burdens, costing a total of about NT$2.2 billion annually.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumption vouchers will definitely raise GDP by 0.66%: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumption voucher program will definitely help boost the country's annual gross domestic product (GDP) by at least 0.66 percent, the government's top economic planner reaffirmed Monday.

Chen Tain-jy, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), made the assertion in response to a recent report by the Ministry of Audit under the watchdog Control Yuan, which questioned the voucher program's effectiveness in stimulating the sluggish economy.

"It remains to be seen whether the NT$85.7 billion consumption voucher program can live up to its goal of stimulating economic growth given its high substitution rate and issuance cost, " the ministry said in its report.
Chen said the CEPD has commissioned Academia Sinica -- Taiwan's foremost research institute -- to evaluate the effects of the consumption vouchers program.
Citing an initial report by the Academia Sinica's research team, Chen said the consumption voucher "substitution rate" was between 60 percent and 70 percent.
That means that 60 percent to 70 percent of the vouchers used by consumers replaced purchases they would have made anyway, with the rest additional spending.
"Such a ratio reflects normal consumption activities and by no means implies that the program had a poor effect," Chen explained.

Judging from consumption patterns during the Lunar New Year holiday and retail sales volume for the period, Chen said he was 100 percent sure that the consumption voucher program will boost GDP growth by an estimated 0.66 percent.
Chen, however, acknowledged another of the report's criticisms -- that the program was too rushed, possibly diminishing its effectiveness.
He attributed the haste in issuing the vouchers to the government's desire to take advantage of the Chinese New Year shopping spree.

The government issued the consumption vouchers with a face value of NT$3,600 per set before the Lunar New Year holiday in January in an attempt to boost slumping domestic economy amid a global financial crisis.

To date, most of the consumption vouchers have been distributed and cashed in, CEPD officials said, adding that the council is scheduled to present a comprehensive assessment report to the Legislative Yuan in October.
All consumption vouchers must be used by the end of September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese procurement group to arrive in Taiwan later this month

TEXT.P: A delegation organized by the Association of Economy and Trade Across Taiwan Straits (AETATS) under China's Ministry of Commerce is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Aug. 19 for a week-long procurement visit, a semi-official trade group announced Monday.

The AETATS procurement group, the third of its kind, will comprise representatives from 55 Chinese companies, including Chongqing Hybest Air Tools Co, Ltd. and Kingfa Science & Technology Development Co, Ltd., according to officials at the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).

The Chinese procurement group will target some of Taiwan's most competitive items, including machinery, electronics, petrochemical goods, garments, footwear, and car accessories and parts, TAITRA officials said.
The total value of the group's purchases is expected to exceed US$1.2 billion.
The first AETATS-organized delegation came to Taiwan in May to purchase information technology and consumer electronics products.
The second AETATS group visited Taiwan from July 12-17 to buy specialty foods, giftware, daily necessities and handicrafts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water supply in Taoyuan area may be further rationed

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) could further cut or suspend water supply to selected sectors in the northern county of Taoyuan if the current dry spell continues, an official said Monday.

Because of lower-than-usual rainfall this summer, the water level in the Shihmen Reservoir -- the major source of potable water in the Taoyuan area -- has been falling rapidly and is approaching an alarmingly low level.
Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Huang Chung-chiou said the water supply has been cut during off-peak hours in the area.

"If the drought gets worse, we will not rule out the possibility of rationing the supply of water to certain heavy water-consuming services, such as car washes, spas, swimming pools and tall-building cleaning services, " Huang said, adding that the new restrictions may be announced Aug. 11.

To encourage water conservation, Huang said, the MOEA's Water Resources Agency (WRA) plans to offer subsidies for those who buy water-efficient appliances or equipment, just as the government has done in the past to encourage the purchase of energy-efficient home appliances.
According to Huang, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan will visit the Shihmen Reservoir Tuesday to decide if any measures need to be taken immediately to cope with the continuing dry spell.

Meanwhile, WRA Deputy Director-General Wu Yueh-hsi said that if no rain falls in the Taoyuan area in the coming days. the agency may further restrict water supply for agricultural use from late August.

Water supply for irrigation in the Taoyuan area has been cut by 30 percent since July, Wu said, adding that if necessary, irrigation water supply may be suspended from late August in order to ensure that water supply for household and industrial use will not be rationed until late October.
Similar water shortage problems are also troubling southern Taiwan, with major reservoirs in the region drying out due to limited precipitation.

Wu said his agency will immediately impose a rationing system in Tainan and Penghu counties where water supply for household use at night will be cut and water for irrigation purposes will be provided based on a "10 days on, five days off" supply model.
He also urged local residents to minimize water consumption in the face of Taiwan's prolonged drought.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmaker to lead an aboriginal delegation to visit China

TEXT.P: An aboriginal delegation will visit China later this month in a bid to help boost the economic prospects of Taiwan's indigenous peoples.
Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei of the Nonpartisan Solidarity Union will lead the delegation to visit Beijing and Yunnan province in southwestern China Aug. 19-27, her office director said Monday.
Chang Chun-chieh said this will be the first aboriginal delegation to visit China since the two sides of the Taiwan Strait began exchanges more than two decades ago.
Kao Chin's delegation will exchange views with related Chinese government agencies on issues that have long concerned indigenous peoples.

China is expected to announce measures to help the visitors, such as donation for the construction of "hope" elementary schools, an idea first initiated by Taiwanese in China, as well as a program to help aboriginal dropouts.

The delegation will also ask China to include indigenous communities in the itineraries of Chinese tourists and help sell agricultural produce grown by Taiwan's indigenous peoples to help them improve their incomes, Chang added.
He said it as "quite a pity" that when Chinese tourists visit Sun Moon Lake and Alishan, they do not have the chance to visit indigenous villages near these scenic spots.
He said aboriginal culture forms a major part of local culture, and if Chinese tourists could observe indigenous communities, they would understand the real Taiwan.
He noted that the Taiwan External Trade Development Council recently discussed the purchase of handicrafts made by local indigenous peoples while meeting with Chinese procurement groups in Taiwan.

The delegation hopes to further discuss the issue with China's Ministry of Commerce on the overall purchase proposal and amount, hoping that China can systematically introduce handicrafts from Taiwan's indigenous peoples and establish a marketing network there.
A traditional eight-part Bunun chorus will travel with the delegation, and it is expected to meet with the Dai and Na Xi tribes in Yunnan province in southwestern China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 4, or the 14th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1578: The Portuguese King Sebastian and his court are killed in a failed crusade to Morocco.
1875: Hans Christian Anderson, Danish writer famous the world over for his fairy tales and stories, including "The Princess and the Pea" and "The Ugly Duckling," dies in Copenhagen at the age of 70.
1906: The Education Ministry of the Ching court promulgates a set of "regulations on education for women" governing the establishment of schools for women.
1914: World War I breaks out when German troops invade Belgium. Britain declares war on Germany as the United States declares its neutrality.
1916: Denmark sells the Danish Virgin Islands to the United States for US$25 million.
1922: Fighting breaks out in Italy between the fascists and the socialists.
1938: The Nationalist government moves its offices from Wuchang and Hankow to Chungking in order to cope with the lengthy War of Resistance Against Japan.
1940: Italian troops invade the country of British Somaliland in East Africa.
1942: David Russel Lange, New Zealand Labor politician, is born. He served as prime minister from 1984 to 1989 and was controversial for his refusal to allow nuclear-armed ships to dock in New Zealand.
1944: Anne Frank, a 14-year-old German Jewish diarist, and seven other Jews in hiding in Amsterdam, are captured by the Gestapo and sent to concentration camps.
1950: Gen. Douglas MacArthur dispatches a high-ranking aide to Taipei as a liaison officer as the United States begins providing military aid to Taiwan.
1954: The P-1 English Electronic Lightning, Britain's first supersonic fighter plane, makes its maiden flight.
1960: Chung Li-ho, a noted Taiwanese folk tale author, dies at the age of 45.
1963: The Foreign Ministry declares that the Republic of China will not recognize the border treaty signed between the Peking regime and Afghanistan.
1967: Malawian President Dr. H. Kamuzu Banda arrives in Taipei for an eight-day state visit.
1972: Ugandan President Idi Amin declares that his country will expel 50,000 Asians with British passports within three months.
1976: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang extends its "deepest sympathy" to victims of the earthquake that struck northern China.
1979: Ho Yen-sheng, former Saigon correspondent for the China Times of Taipei who had been stranded in Vietnam since 1975, arrives in Taipei from an isolated island in the South China Sea where he spent 70 days as a refugee.
1986: ROC-U.S. trade talks begin in Washington. During the five-day talks, the ROC agreed to abandon its use of duty tables as of Oct. 1, 1986.
1990: Iraq installs a nine-man puppet government in Kuwait and sets up a new "People's Army" to control the regime while 12 European Community nations ban oil imports from Iraq, impose an arms embargo on the country and suspend most trade with Iraq.
1993: Japan formally apologizes for the first time to women forced to serve as sex slaves for Japanese soldiers during World War II.
1993: The Japanese Cabinet resigns, ending 38 years of rule by the Liberal Democratic Party.
1999: British Defence Secretary George Robertson becomes the new secretary- general of NATO, succeeding Javier Solana.
1999: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Mayor Tarmile Ishoda of Majuro sign a pact of alliance in Taipei, making Majuro, capital of the Marshall Islands, the 44th sister city of Taiwan's capital.
2000: Government Information Office Director General Chung Chin says that the GIO is mapping out procedures for setting up exchanges across the Taiwan Strait of journalists for long-term postings.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By dealing loyally and punctually with them in all engagements which he makes with them and allowing a liberal scale of pay: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to men in the public service."

DOC.HEADLINE: Tropical storm may be headed toward Taiwan

TEXT.P: A tropical depression that has turned into a tropical storm over the West Pacific early Tuesday morning is expected to approach Taiwan, but it is not clear if it will deliver the heavy rainfall Taiwan desperately needs.
"It remains to be seen whether and how the tropical storm, dubbed Morakot, will directly affect Taiwan, " a Central Weather Bureau (CWB) meteorologist said.
According to the CWB, Morakot was located 1,500-plus kilometers east of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Eluanbi, moving in a northwesterly direction toward Taiwan at a speed of 9 kilometers per hour.

Morakot, the eighth storm system reported in the West Pacific region this year, is expected to maintain its course and speed until noon Tuesday and then shift to a west-northwest direction toward Taiwan in the following 24 hours, the CWB said.
Based on current projections, the tropical storm will begin affecting Taiwan Aug. 7 or 8.
Taiwan has received far less rainfall than normal so far this year, and water authorities have warned of possible rationing measures if drought conditions persist.
Another tropical storm, Goni, which formed Monday and was the West Pacific's seventh storm of the year, has swept through the South China Sea toward Hong Kong, CWB meteorologists said.
Its outer rim has brought sporadic showers to central, southern and eastern Taiwan, but not enough to ease the country's water shortage.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Tuesday:
APPLE DAILY:
Yeh Ching-chuan has fallen to new low
Amid mounting fears of a swine flu epidemic, Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan tendered his resignation to run for Hualien County magistrate Monday.

We question the timing of his departure and we also regret the rudeness of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) in handling the matter. The party has been saying that the SARS fighter would resign for days, leaving the Premier Liu Chao-shiuan in the cold.
Can the KMT call itself a democratic party? The party previously suspended the magistrate primary in Hualien, but decided to reinstate the system after Yeh's latest decision.
CHINA TIMES:
Maintain deficit for time being

As the central government begins to map out its general budget for next year, some have begun to debate whether the government should focus on cutting the deficit to balance spending or continue to prop up the sagging economy.
We have noted that nearly one year after the economic crisis, various economic indicators have shown that the economy is slowly bottoming out.
But looking back at history, economic recovery is never a straight line. A too hasty retraction of economic stimulus measures could cause the weak economy to take another plunge.

For this reason, we think the government should continue to adopt a budget with a potentially growing deficit, which will be necessary to prop up the weak recovery, especially because the jobless rate will continue to rise unabated in the year ahead.
UNITED DAILY NEWS:
Is President Ma going to act against Mayor Ma?
The Ministry of Justice has begun to review the lands in Taipei City that were seized during the time when the city failed to make health insurance payments it owed to the central government.
If the central government does sell the land to get the money back, then we can see the farcical effect of the Ma administration acting against Mayor Ma.

The issue began when the previous DPP administration maliciously cut the funding allocated to Taipei City. As a result, then Taipei mayor Ma refused to shoulder the health insurance payments, citing the city's dire financial straits.

The mayor argued that only 1.4 million workers were registered in Taipei City, and it was unfair for the central government to ask the city to pay for the 3.6 million employees of companies registered in Taipei City.
Mayor Ma then filed an administrative lawsuit, but the High Administrative Court ruled late last year that the city should pay its debt by auctioning its land.
Whether it is reasonable for Taipei to contribute to premiums for more than double the number of workers registered in the city is open to discussion.
But the point is that both the central government and Taipei City are headed by the same party, and they should show the ability to solve the problem instead of letting it fester.
LIBERTY TIMES:
Can premier stay on after Yeh's resignation?
Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan resigned from his post Monday to run for Hualien County magistrate.
At a time when the number of H1N1 cases continues to rise, President Ma Ying- jeou has said he was happy to see Yeh's decision, and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan approved the resignation swiftly.
A lot of people have begun to ask if Ma's administration thinks winning an election is more important than winning a battle against the new flu?
Doesn't the premier feel humiliated for having no say in whether a Cabinet member stays or leaves?

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Influenza A (H1N1) twist unexpected': outgoing health minister

TEXT.P: The outbreak of new swine flu, or influenza A (H1N1), has unfolded in an unpredictable way and not as originally expected, outgoing Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said Tuesday.

Unlike seasonal flu, which usually strikes mostly vulnerable targets such as the elderly and children during winter months, the H1N1 strain has affected people around the globe much earlier, with the majority of patients young people or individuals in their prime, Yeh said.

Yeh made the comments at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, before boarding a flight to Hong Kong to take part in the 5th Taiwan-Hong Kong Forum at the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Center Wednesday.

He said he and three other Taiwanese specialists will meet with top health authorities in Hong Kong at the forum to exchange views on preparedness in the face of the regional spread of the H1N1 flu virus strain.
Because Taiwan's H1N1 cluster infections only recently emerged, and there have been few cases of the H3N2 strain, Yeh said Taiwan can learn from Hong Kong's experience.
"We will take this opportunity to better understand how Hong Kong is treating and testing for the flu to have as a reference for future prevention efforts in Taiwan," he said.

Yeh and the three specialists -- Huang Kun-chang, CEO of the DOH Hospital Administration Commission, Chen Wen-chung, superintendent of Taoyuan General Hospital and Chang Shang-chun, deputy superintendent of National Taiwan University Hospital -- will meet with York Chow, Hong Kong's food and health secretary, and other ranking Hong Kong health officials during their stay in the former British territory.
The meeting will mark the first time that Taiwan and Hong Kong officials will openly discuss cooperation in epidemic prevention.

Yeh, who is making a bid to run in the year-end magisterial elections on the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) ticket in Hualien County, resigned Monday. Premier Liu Chao-shiuan approved his resignation, which will take effect from Aug. 6.
His resignation, which comes at a time when the country is gripped by mounting fears over a possible swine flu epidemic, has drawn criticism from lawmakers of both the ruling and opposition parties.
On the question of his successor, Yeh said at the airport that it would be the right and responsibility of the premier to make the decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's mango exports to Japan increase sharply

TEXT.P: Taiwan exported 999 tons of mangoes to Japan in 2009, up 19 percent from last year because of the adoption of enhanced safety and quality controls, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Tuesday.

Hsu Han-ching, the chief-secretary of the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency, said Taiwan's overall mango harvest was down from last year, and the export season, which usually continues into August, ended July 27 when the last batch of mangoes was shipped to Japan.
Yet despite the shorter growing season, this year's exports to Japan were well above the 838 tons shipped in 2008, but it was not immediately known how much the shipments were worth.
Japan was the No. 1 overseas market of Taiwan's mangoes by value in 2008, importing US$5.2 million worth of the fruit, followed by South Korea (US$2.97 million) and Hong Kong (US$590,000).
The agency attributed the increase in export volume to Japan primarily to enhanced quality control and a rise in orders for high-end mangoes.

By maintaining a high standard of quality, Taiwan's mangoes and especially Irwin mangoes grown in Tainan have been a hit in the Japanese market, helping prop up the price of local mangoes, the agency noted.
Though shipments were up to Japan, Hsu was not yet sure if the overall volume of mango exports surpassed that of 2008.
"The total export volume of the fruit is estimated at over 3,000 tons. Hopefully, this year's volume will exceed the 3,307 tons shipped last year," Hsu said.
Other big export markets for the fruit are Singapore and China, although as with Hong Kong, they generally purchase cheaper varieties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign Ministry mum on U.N. bid approach

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) remained tight-lipped Tuesday on how it will approach Taiwan's bid for representation in the United Nations as the bid deadline approaches, suggesting only that it will decide on the strategy in mid- August.

"We will make a sound decision based on an overall assessment of Taiwan's needs and the atmosphere in the international community and in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, one that will help us achieve concrete results in participating in international organizations in the future,Paul Chang, director-general of the MOFA's Department of International Organizations, said at a regular press briefing.

Noting that the MOFA has yet to come up with a final decision on this year's bid, Chang said it should make one around mid-August, but he refused to give any details on progress in the government's deliberations on the issue.

Pressed on whether Taiwan will even make a U.N. bid this year, Chang did not give a direct answer, saying only that the agency is engaging in a careful evaluation and will not exclude any possibility.
"There are many other options. We will make a public announcement when the issue is settled, " Chang said.
Taiwan has not been represented in the U.N. since 1971 when the Republic of China's seat was given to the People's Republic of China.
Its annual efforts to rejoin the body since 1993 have failed, as have its attempts to be part of U.N.-affiliated organizations, mainly because of China's obstruction.

But with relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait thawing since President Ma Ying-jeou's administration took office last year, Taiwan was invited to attend the World Health Assembly -- the decision-making arm of the U.N.-affiliated World Health Organization -- in May as an observer.

Last year, in a departure from the high-profile push in 2007 for full membership in the United Nations under the name Taiwan, the country proposed that it be allowed to "participate meaningfully in the activities of U.N. specialized agencies."
That approach was in line with President Ma's "modus vivendi" or flexible diplomatic strategy, which favors a moderate and pragmatic approach to expanding Taiwan's international space.

Although the request failed to make the agenda of the 63rd session of the U.N. General Assembly last year, it was well received by major countries such as the United States, Japan, and some European Union countries, which issued statements in support of the effort.

The 64th U.N. General Assembly session is scheduled to open Sept. 15 at U.N. headquarters in New York, and Taiwan must submit a bid proposal to the U.N. Secretariat through a diplomatic ally 30 days before then for it to be considered for the General Assembly agenda.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alishan welcomes one millionth visitor this year

TEXT.P: Alishan, a popular mountain resort in southern Taiwan's Chiayi County, welcomed its millionth visitor for the first time in 33 years, the Alishan National Scenic Area reported Tuesday.

Tsai Wei-shuan, who is from Keelung in northern Taiwan but now works in Kaohsiung City in the south, became the millionth visitor to Alishan this year when he made his first ever trip to the alpine resort with his friends.

Since it opened in 1976, the Alishan National Scenic Area had previously never drawn one million visitors a year. The number reached about 990,000 in 2006, and 950,000 in 1983, but has averaged between 600,000 and 800,000 per year.

Tsai, who was elated to be the millionth visitor for the year, was showered with gifts by the Chiayi Forest District Office. He was given an MP3 player, a video camera, a digital camera, a bicycle and one night free accommodation at Alishan House. Local tourism-related businesses also offered him speciality food worth more than NT$10,000 (US$300) and free guided tours of the area.
According to Chiayi Forest District Office Director Yang Chih-hung, Tsai was selected Tuesday by the scenic area's computerized ticket selling system as the year's millionth visitor.

Yang predicted that the number of visitors to the Alishan National Scenic Area for the whole of this year will reach a new high, despite the fact that some segments of the Alishan alpine train system need to be repaired.
Local forest district officials attributed the record number of visitors to Taiwan's broader opening to Chinese tourists in July last year.
Alishan and Sun Moon Lake in central Taiwan's Nantou County are the two most popular destinations in Taiwan among Chinese visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three local researchers elected fellows of Royal Society of Chemistry

TEXT.P: Three Taiwan chemists were elected in June as fellows of the Royal Society of Chemistry in the United Kingdom, which indicates that Taiwan's research achievements in the field of chemistry are being recognized worldwide, a dean at National Taiwan University said Tuesday.

The three -- Peng Shie-ming and Chou Pi-tai, professors at National Taiwan University's Department of Chemistry, and Cheng Chien-hong, a professor at National Tsing Hua University's Department of Chemistry -- are now fellows of the largest organization in Europe for the advancement of chemical sciences.

Every year, the Royal Society in the United Kingdom selects as fellows some 10 chemists from around the world who work at chemistry research institutes and have made significant contributions in the field of chemistry and applied chemistry, said Lo Ching-hua, dean of the College of Science at NTU.
Therefore, the selection of the three local academics reflects Taiwan's outstanding performance in the field, Lo said.
Peng, who is also a research fellow at Academia Sinica, specializes in inorganic chemistry and crystallography.
With stable financial support from the government, Taiwan's scientific research standards are close to international standards, he said in an interview with CNA.
Chou, who is also chairman of NTU's Department of Chemistry, specializes in optoelectronic materials and physical and biophysical chemistry.
Cheng's research areas mainly focus on organometallics and electroluminescent materials. In addition, he is involved in the synthesis of organic optoelectronic materials and their related properties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Budget approved for construction of Kaohsiung ocean and music center

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung government welcomed Tuesday the central administration's decision the day before to approve the budget for the construction of an ocean culture and pop music center in the southern port city, which has just successfully hosted the 2009 World Games.

The Cabinet-level Council of Economic Planning and Development approved a budget of NT$5.45 billion (US$166.67 million) for the building of the complex on a sprawling 12.5 hectares at Kaohsiung Harbor's Piers 11-15 near the mouth of the Love River.
The project is scheduled to be completed in 2015, said Chung Wan-shun, a department chief at the Kaohsiung Public Works Bureau.
"Renowned international architects are welcome to contact the bureau about the open design bid, which is scheduled to be finalized next May at the latest," Chung said.

The complex, which the planners envision will be on par with the Sydney Opera House, will feature facilities for outdoor performances, several concert halls, and exhibition areas for ocean culture. It will also include a center for the promotion of the pop music industry, and an area to showcase cultural and innovative designs and products, according to the Kaohsiung Bureau of Cultural Affairs.
The complex will be built at a prime location where the Kaohsiung Harbor meets the Love River and will afford magnificent ocean and river vistas, said a bureau official.
It is envisioned that the complex will become a nerve center of
cultural, media and innovative industries in southern Taiwan,
the official said.
While building the central infrastructure, he said, the Kaohsiung government will also strive to develop the surrounding environment and industries related to the project, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's stock prices tumble on water rationing concerns

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened high but closed 1.42 percent lower Tuesday, a day after the government said that water rationing measures may be introduced as early as Aug. 11.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, fell 100.84 points Tuesday to close at 6,955.87.

The local bourse opened at 7,129.43 and reached the day's high of 7,138.94 after the Nasdaq composite index closed at its highest level in 10 months and the Dow Jones Industrial Average and the S&P 500 index finished at 9-month highs Tuesday.

The local market later retreated to the day's low of 6,921.04 as selling pressure emerged following the government's statement that it may announce measures Aug. 11 for restrictions on the use of water for car washes, spas, fountains and the cleaning of buildings.
A total of 6.55 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$159.96 billion (US$4.90 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks and plastics and chemicals issues advancing the most at 0.9 percent. Paper and pulp issues rose 0.3 percent and foodstuff shares added 0.1 percent.

The other four major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 2.6 percent. Machinery and electronics shares fell 2.4 percent, textile issues dropped 0.6 percent, and banking and financial issues shed 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,667 to 805, with 135 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$2.09 billion in shares.

Although the weighted index previously broke the 7,000 mark, it pulled back because the turnover was not enough to sustain the market, according to an analyst. The local bourse would maintain momentum only if the market's volume rises above NT$180 billion, the analyst added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, falling NT$0.094 to close at the day's low of NT$32.674.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.768 and moved down to close at NT$32.674.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Memory Co. files business plan for DRAM restructuring

TEXT.P: Newly-established Taiwan Memory Co. (TMC) has officially filed its business plan with the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to participate in a government project to restructure the DRAM industry, Vice Minister Hwang Jung-chiou said Tuesday.

The MOEA first put forth in March the idea of setting up the TMC as part of its efforts to consolidate Taiwan's ailing dynamic random access memory, or DRAM, industry. The company has recently completed its establishment, with registered capital of NT$500,000 (US$15,244).

Under a project unveiled in July, the government will allocate a maximum of NT$30 billion to support one or two local DRAM companies to compete with their foreign counterparts, particularly those in South Korea.
Companies interested in obtaining the government funding should apply with the MOEA within three months, after which the ministry will review their qualifications.
"TMC is a bellwether, and we hope it will pass the screening, " Huang said.
Huang, however, would not disclose the amount of investment requested by TMC.

To qualify for the funding, the applicants should have the ability to efficiently acquire overseas intellectual property and technology usage rights, as well as fair and balanced research and development records from both domestic firms and overseas partners, according to requirements set by the MOEA.

The MOEA also demands that the international collaboration must provide adequate training of local talent and that the re-structuring plan must aim to improve existing corporate structures and broker possible mergers and acquisitions.
TMC, which aims to develop its own technologies in collaboration with Japan- based Elpida Memory Inc., is so far the only company that has filed its business plan to bid for the funding.
MOEA officials said they believe the Formosa Plastics Group will also file an application.
Two of Formosa's affiliates -- Nanya Technology Corp. and Inotera Memories Inc. -- have maintained a partnership with U.S.-based Micron Technology Inc., a leading DRAM technology provider.
TMC originally hoped to cooperate with both Elpida and Micron, but Micron turned down the proposal in April and decided instead to further reinforce its long- term cooperation with Nanya and Inotera.
Nanya and Inotera executives have urged the government to give the Micro-Nanya- Inotera alliance the same level of support it would have given to a Micron-TMC venture.

Taiwan's DRAM industry has been ailing due to an oversupply of local makers here, which are relatively small compared to their South Korean counterparts. The government thus proposed consolidating all the DRAM makers into one company -- TMC.

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidents visit to the South Pacific still slated for Oct.: MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 4 (CNA) 08/04/09 18:14:52 (By Rachel Chan and Deborah Ku)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Tuesday that it is still planning for President Ma Ying-jeou to travel to the South Pacific in October to attend the Taiwan-South Pacific leaders summit in the Solomon Islands, but details remain to be confirmed.

Everything is still in the planning stage within the foreign ministry. An announcement on the presidents visit will be made by the presidential office when it is confirmed,said MOFA spokesman Henry Chen.
Details to be confirmed include the exact date of the summit, Chen said.

Diplomatic sources, however, revealed that the president and his wife will visit the South Pacific region in the later half of October and will stop in several of the Republic of Chinas other diplomatic allies there.

Ma and his entourage are tentatively scheduled to depart from Taiwan on Oct. 17 and return to the country Oct. 22. During the trip, Ma may also visit Palau and another ally nation yet to be determined, an official who requested anonymity said.
Taiwan has six diplomatic allies in the South Pacific region, including the Solomon Islands, the Marshall Islands, Palau, Kiribati, Nauru and Tuvalu.

At the summit, Ma will join his counterparts from Palau, the Marshall Islands, Nauru, the Solomon Islands, Kiribati and Tuvalu, said the official, adding that the summit is currently scheduled to be held on Oct. 20 in the Solomon Islands.
The leadership summit will be the third of its kind since Sept. 4, 2006, when it was first held in Palau, and Taiwan was represented by then President Chen Shui- bian.

Relevant agencies in Taiwan have begun contacting Taiwan's six South Pacific allies to work out the topics to be discussed at the summit, the official said. The agenda may include the recent global financial crisis, climate change, fishery resources, alternative energy, and cooperation in the fields of medicine, agriculture and fisheries, the official added.
The upcoming trip will be President Ma's first visit to the South Pacific since he took office in May 2008, and Ma's third diplomatic tour this year.

Ma conducted a visit to Central America from May 26-June 4 that took him to Belize, Guatemala and El Salvador, and visited the region again from June 29-July 6 to attend the inauguration of then Panamanian President-elect Ricardo Martinelli and to pay official visits to Nicaragua and Honduras.

Since Ma took office, he and the Foreign Ministry have said the administration will seek to establish a long-term cooperation mechanism with the allies based on the main objective stated in its foreign aid white paper, which is to provide more effective and meaningful assistance to Taiwan's ally nations.
Ma previously visited the Solomon Islands in 1997 in his capacity as a professor.

DOC.HEADLINE: Improved techniques help Taiwan's red date farmers increase output

TEXT.P: Revenue generated by red dates in northern Taiwan's Gongguan township, Miaoli County, has increased by 10 to 15 percent, thanks to improved cultivation techniques a government research station has taught local farmers, officials said Tuesday.

The revenue generated from red date production reached NT$60 million (US$1.8 million) a year after the new techniques were adopted, said Liu Yu-tsung, an assistant researcher at the Miaoli District Agricultural Research and Extension Station under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture.

Liu attributed the success of improved red date output to the station's guiding local farmers to increase the concentration of the plants in the orchards, prune tree branches to help them grow in a way that allows the fruits to bath in sunlight more completely, and grade their fruits before selling them in the market.
Liu said the techniques passed on to farmers by the station have helped raise both the quantity and quality of the harvests.
The efforts have, for example, raised the fruit's sweetness by 25 percent, he added.
Gongguan is the only place in Taiwan where red dates, a fruit often seen sun- dried and commonly used in local and Chinese cuisine, are grown.
Dried red dates are also often used in traditional Chinese medicine to strengthen the functions of the heart and lungs, as well as to nourish the stomach and spleen.

The period between July and August is the only season for growing fresh red dates in Taiwan, making the fruit all the more precious, Hsieh Fu-yuan, head of the Gongguan Township Office's agricultural division, told the CNA.

Hsieh encouraged the public to consume the fruit that is rich in Vitamin C. Citing a study by the Miaoli agricultural research station, he said the Vitamin C content of red dates is at 270 mg per 100 grams and other nutrition contained in dates is much higher than that of apples.
There are currently more than 50 hectares of red date farms in Gongguan, whose total annual output amounts to between 6,000 kg and 12,000 kg, according to Hsieh.
The price of fresh red dates currently stands at between NT$100 (US$3) and NT$120 per 600 grams in Taiwan, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Hong Kong officials discuss cooperation in health field

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Department of Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan held talks with Hong Kong's Food and Health Secretary York Chow Tuesday on cooperation in the field of health, in what was the first meeting between top health officials of the two sides.
Yeh, who arrived in Hong Kong Tuesday morning for a two-day visit, met Chow over lunch. The chairman of Hong Kong's Hospital Authority, Anthony Wu, also attended the meeting.

Yeh told the Central News Agency before the meeting that his discussion with Chow would touch on cooperation not only in the prevention and control of the influenza A(H1N1) outbreak, but also in other areas of health.
The possibility of setting up a mechanism to facilitate such cooperation would also be raised, Yeh said.

The minister will take part in the 5th Taiwan-Hong Kong Forum, which will be held Wednesday at the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Center. He will deliver a keynote speech on the outlook for cooperation between Taiwan and Hong Kong in the area of health. 3By Stanley Cheung, Mandy Wong and Y.F. Low)

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourists spend freely in Taiwan: Visa poll

TEXT.P: Chinese tourists in Taiwan spend an average of NT$52,640 (11,000 Chinese yuan) each during their stays in Taiwan, nearly double the NT$27,850 (6,600 HK dollars) spent by each Hong Kong tourist, a survey has found.

According to the results of a survey commissioned by Visa Inc. and conducted by Research International, 90 percent of Chinese tourists and 87 percent of Hong Kong visitors have a positive impression of travel in Taiwan.
In addition, 63 percent of tourists from China and 75 percent from Hong Kong were impressed by the Taiwan people's hospitality, according to the poll.

Sun Moon Lake in central Taiwan's Nantou County and Alishan in Chiayi County in the south are the two most popular destinations among Chinese tourists, while Hong Kong visitors find Kenting, Alishan, Yangmingshan and Sun Moon Lake the most attractive places in Taiwan, the survey indicated.
The Taiwanese respondents in the poll named Alishan, Taroko National Park and Kenting as the top leisure spots.
Over 70 percent of Chinese and Hong Kong tourists listed Taiwan's night markets and hot springs as must-see attractions.
Meanwhile, oyster omelets were voted as the most popular snack sold in Taiwan's night markets, while pineapple cake was selected as the best speciality food in Taiwan, followed by tea and sun cakes.
About 60 percent of the Hong Kong respondents and 67 percent of Taiwanese said steamed dumplings are the number one delicacy in the country, but less than 50 percent of Chinese tourists agreed.
More than a half of the Chinese respondents said they prefer Taiwanese-style cuisine, dantsu noodle, beef noodle soup and ginger duck.
The survey interviewed 654 people over the age of 20 from Taiwan, Hong Kong and China, during the period April 25- May 4.
