DOC.HEADLINE: Three more severe A(H1N1) cases reported

TEXT.P: Taiwan reported Tuesday three new severe cases of influenza A(H1N1) infection, as well as a severe infection of the seasonal type-A flu H3N2.

Lin Ding, deputy director-general of the Center for Disease Control (CDC), said at a press conference that the three A(H1N1) -infected patients include a 32 -year-old male chef living in the central Taiwan city of Taichung, who was being treated in an isolation ward.

The other patients are two kindergarten boys -- one aged five and the other three. None of the three, although all were suffering from the complication of pneumonia, were in critical condition, Lin said.
CDC Director-General Steve Kuo attributed their non-critical status to the strategy of giving them anti-viral drugs soon after they were diagnosed.

The new cases brought the number of severe A(H1N1) cases in the country to nine, including one fatality. So far, only two of the patients have been discharged from hospital after recovering, according to CDC statistics.
The tallies also show that since July 1, Taiwan has reported 16 flu cluster infections involving over 600 people. One of the cluster infections was caused by the A virus subtype H3N2.
The only H3N2 cluster infection was reported in a dance troupe at an elementary school in Taipei that had recently returned from a tour of Shenzhen in southern China.

Lin said that some of the troupe fell sick July 22 during their stay in Shenzhen. After they came back to Taiwan, one member's brother, who has never traveled abroad, also came down with a fever, Lin added.
A total of 11 people were sickened in the cluster infection, six of whom were infected with H3N2, Lin said.

He noted that it is still unknown whether the infections were related to current H3N2 outbreaks in Hong Kong. "It is possible the patients contracted the virus in Taiwan, or in Shenzhen or Hong Kong" judging from the outbreak, Lin said.

H3N2 is a subtype of the flu virus that can infect birds and mammals. In humans, birds and pigs, the virus has mutated into many strains and the recent local outbreaks have caught the attention of the authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Allianz to recruit 1,000 more employees in Taiwan this year

TEXT.P: Allianz, one of the largest financial services providers in the world, will recruit 1,000 new employees this year in an effort to expand its presence in the Taiwan market, the CEO of the company's Taiwan subsidiary said Tuesday.

Chris James made the announcement at an event to celebrate the opening of a client service center at Allianz Taiwan Life Insurance Co. amid rumors that the German insurance giant is reeling from the global financial crunch and therefore considering withdrawing from the Taiwan market.
He said that the new client service center was set up to meet customer demand.

Meanwhile, James, who is also chairman of the Insurance Committee of the European Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (ECCT), reiterated his opposition to a government plan to tax earnings from investment-linked life insurance products.

He said that it is unfair to deny the long-standing socially recognized system that offers customers transparent, flexible, cost-effective life insurance and savings as an alternative to less flexible and more opaque traditional products.
He criticized the government's decision on the issue as a misstep, saying that it will erode public confidence in investment.
The subsidiary company suggested that the government should first amend the relevant laws before implementing the tax reform plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Plea bargain requests by ex-president's relatives rejected

TEXT.P: Prosecutors rejected Tuesday requests for plea bargains by several relatives of former President Chen Shui-bian involved in his corruption and money-laundering case.
They are the former president's son Chen Chih-chung, daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching, brother-in-law Wu Ching-mao and sister-in-law Chen Chun-ying.
Chen Chih-chung acted as a proxy for the former first family's controversial overseas bank accounts, while Huang, Wu and Chen Chun-ying were some of the nominal account holders.

Lin Che-hui, a prosecutor from the Special Investigation Division of the Supreme Prosecutors Office, told a Taipei District Court hearing that the prosecution decided not to consider the defendants' requests because they played a major part in the money-laundering case and are still under investigation in other related cases.
The fact that Chen Chih-chung and his wife Huang Jui-ching have so far not wired the overseas funds back to Taiwan is another reason why their requests were turned down, prosecutorial sources said.
Chen and his wife Wu Shu-jen are accused of siphoning off NT$104 million (US$3.15 million) from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during his term as president from 2000 to 2008.

They are also charged with accepting bribes totaling NT$300 million in connection with a land deal between the Hsinchu Science Park and Dayu Development Corp. and with receiving kickbacks totaling NT$90.93 million between 2002 and 2003 to help a contractor win the tender to build the Nangang Exhibition Hall.

In addition, the couple allegedly took bribes totaling NT$310 million from former Taipei Financial Center Corp. Chairwoman Diana Chen and former Chinatrust Financial Holdings Co. Vice Chairman Jeffrey Koo Jr.

The couple allegedly secretly stashed the funds overseas through various intermediaries, including members of their own family, all of whom have also been indicted for offenses relating to Chen and Wu.
The court is expected to announce its verdict on Sept. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua to host weekend festival for indigenous tribes

TEXT.P: A cultural festival and traditional sports competition for Taiwan's indigenous people will be staged Saturday in Yuanlin, Changhua County, with representatives of the Bunun tribe officiating at the opening ceremony, county officials announced Tuesday at a news conference.

According to officials of the local civil affairs bureau, the primary aim of the festival and competition is to allow the more than 4,700 indigenous people residing in the central Taiwan county to gain a fresh understanding of their traditional rituals, arts and culture and pass them on to the younger generations.

The event, sponsored annually by the Changhua County government, features on a rotating basis the culture of one of the 13 major aboriginal tribes in Taiwan, and the opening ceremony usually is chaired by a member of the featured tribe.
This year's festival will highlight the Bunun tribe.
Leaders, revered elders and representatives of all the tribes living in Changhua will gather Saturday for the annual activity in a bid to revive and preserve their traditions.

The public will see traditional aboriginal dances and an exhibition of craftsmanship and will also have an opportunity to sample a wide variety of speciality dishes prepared by indigenous people, county officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign language classes available for children of foreign spouses

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) gave a green light Tuesday to measures allowing elementary schools to give extra classes in Chinese and foreign languages to children of foreign spouses, a ministry official said that day.

Lu Hung-lin, director of the MOE's Department of Elementary Education, said the measures are aimed at helping these school children sharpen their language abilities and more quickly adapt to school life, and are part of the government's efforts to foster bilingual talent in its pursuit of an international competitive edge.

Apart from offering extra Chinese language classes on campuses, elementary schools are permitted to employ experts to give extra-curricular classes in the mother tongues of the students of foreign spouses of Taiwanese citizens.
It has been estimated that more than 30,000 children born into such families in Taiwan will enroll in first grade classes in September at primary schools around the country, Lu added.

The government has since 2004 adopted a series of measures to assist elementary school students of the so-called "new immigrants" to improve their learning at school and their family relationships at home, in view of the rising number of foreign wives from China and Southeast Asian countries.

At present, children born to foreign husbands and wives of local people account for about 10 percent of Taiwan's newborns each year, he noted. The ratio peaked at 13 percent in 2003 and gradually dropped to 9.6 percent in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., European insurers to openly voice opposition to new tax plan

TEXT.P: At least seven U.S. and European insurers are expected to attend a news conference to be held by the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei to express their opposition to a proposal by Taiwan to tax income from investment- linked insurance products, an AmCham official said Tuesday.

The prospective participants are Allianz, MetLife, HSBC Insurance, Manulife, New York Life Insurance, Cardif Assurance Vie and Prudential Life, all of which are members of either AmCham or the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT), said Lee Wood, chairman of AmCham's Insurance Committee.
They will also clarify misunderstanding among some members of the public about investment-linked insurance products, Wood said.

He said it is important that customers have the option of investment-linked products because they provide an additional and transparent layer of financial security for customers who could otherwise lose their savings to other general creditors if an insurer were to fail.

On July 24, the Tax Reform Committee under the Executive Yuan adopted a resolution to treat earnings from unit-linked insurance products as taxable income. Gains of up to NT$270,000 would be tax-exempt under the existing exemption for interest income, but amounts beyond that would be subject to taxation.
The committee also suggested that proceeds from policies where the policyholder and beneficiary are not the same person be subject to a 10 percent gift tax on benefits of over NT$2.2 million.
The proposal met immediate objections from AmCham and the ECCT, both of which warned that it would discourage consumer saving and damage Taiwan's insurance industry.

Commenting on the issue, officials from the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) said Tuesday that the resolution adopted by the Tax Reform Committee is not final and that the FSC will continue to communicate with the Ministry of Finance's Taxation Agency on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei receives highest rating in healthcare governance

TEXT.P: Taipei City was rated the best among 20 cities and counties in Taiwan proper, as well as the two special municipalities of Taipei and Kaohsiung, in terms of healthcare governance, according to rating results released Tuesday by the Taiwan Healthcare Reform Foundation (THRF).

In the 2009 healthcare governance rating, Taipei City scored in each of five rating categories -- medical resources, charges for medical treatment services, safety of medicines, services for the less-privileged, and settlement of medical disputes.
In each category, either "one point" or "zero" is given as a score, which denotes "good" or "in need of improvement" performance of local governments in healthcare administration.
Under the THRF rating, Taipei City received a total score of five points, meaning that the city was seen as doing a good job in every rating category.
Taipei County ranked behind the capital city with a score of four points, as its efforts in promoting the safety of medicines failed to receive a point from THRF.

Taoyuan County, Kaohsiung City and Hualien County all received scores of three points, while Keelung City, Hsinchu County, Taichung City, Taichung County, Changhua County, Yunlin County, Tainan City, Tainan County, Taitung County and Yilan County scored two points, according to the rating.
Hsinchu City, Chiayi County, Chiayi City, Kaohsiung County, Pingtung County, Nantou County and Miaoli County all got only one point.

The foundation found that Kaohsiung City performed the best in the management of medical service charges, while Taipei City, Hsinchu City and Chiayi County offered the best services in providing medical treatment subsidies.
In the category of the settlement of medical disputes, Taoyuan County was found to be doing the best job, the THRF said.
The THRF is an independent non-government organization that aims to improve healthcare quality and patient's rights in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to study local government restructuring

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourists spend freely in Taiwan: Visa poll

TEXT.P: Chinese tourists in Taiwan spend an average of NT$52,640 (11,000 Chinese yuan) each during their stays in Taiwan, nearly double the NT$27,850 (6,600 HK dollars) spent by each Hong Kong tourist, a survey has found.

According to the results of a survey commissioned by Visa Inc. and conducted by Research International, 90 percent of Chinese tourists and 87 percent of Hong Kong visitors have a positive impression of travel in Taiwan.
In addition, 63 percent of tourists from China and 75 percent from Hong Kong were impressed by the Taiwan people's hospitality, according to the poll.

Sun Moon Lake in central Taiwan's Nantou County and Alishan in Chiayi County in the south are the two most popular destinations among Chinese tourists, while Hong Kong visitors find Kenting, Alishan, Yangmingshan and Sun Moon Lake the most attractive places in Taiwan, the survey indicated.
The Taiwanese respondents in the poll named Alishan, Taroko National Park and Kenting as the top leisure spots.
Over 70 percent of Chinese and Hong Kong tourists listed Taiwan's night markets and hot springs as must-see attractions.
Meanwhile, oyster omelets were voted as the most popular snack sold in Taiwan's night markets, while pineapple cake was selected as the best speciality food in Taiwan, followed by tea and sun cakes.
About 60 percent of the Hong Kong respondents and 67 percent of Taiwanese said steamed dumplings are the number one delicacy in the country, but less than 50 percent of Chinese tourists agreed.
More than a half of the Chinese respondents said they prefer Taiwanese-style cuisine, dantsu noodle, beef noodle soup and ginger duck.
The survey interviewed 654 people over the age of 20 from Taiwan, Hong Kong and China, during the period April 25- May 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three more severe A(H1N1) cases reported

TEXT.P: Taiwan reported Tuesday three new severe cases of influenza A(H1N1) infection, as well as a severe infection of the seasonal type-A flu H3N2.

Lin Ding, deputy director-general of the Center for Disease Control (CDC), said at a press conference that the three A(H1N1) -infected patients include a 32 -year-old male chef living in the central Taiwan city of Taichung, who was being treated in an isolation ward.

The other patients are two kindergarten boys -- one aged five and the other three. None of the three, although all were suffering from the complication of pneumonia, were in critical condition, Lin said.
CDC Director-General Steve Kuo attributed their non-critical status to the strategy of giving them anti-viral drugs soon after they were diagnosed.

The new cases brought the number of severe A(H1N1) cases in the country to nine, including one fatality. So far, only two of the patients have been discharged from hospital after recovering, according to CDC statistics.
The tallies also show that since July 1, Taiwan has reported 16 flu cluster infections involving over 600 people. One of the cluster infections was caused by the A virus subtype H3N2.
The only H3N2 cluster infection was reported in a dance troupe at an elementary school in Taipei that had recently returned from a tour of Shenzhen in southern China.

Lin said that some of the troupe fell sick July 22 during their stay in Shenzhen. After they came back to Taiwan, one member's brother, who has never traveled abroad, also came down with a fever, Lin added.
A total of 11 people were sickened in the cluster infection, six of whom were infected with H3N2, Lin said.

He noted that it is still unknown whether the infections were related to current H3N2 outbreaks in Hong Kong. "It is possible the patients contracted the virus in Taiwan, or in Shenzhen or Hong Kong" judging from the outbreak, Lin said.

H3N2 is a subtype of the flu virus that can infect birds and mammals. In humans, birds and pigs, the virus has mutated into many strains and the recent local outbreaks have caught the attention of the authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Allianz to recruit 1,000 more employees in Taiwan this year

TEXT.P: Allianz, one of the largest financial services providers in the world, will recruit 1,000 new employees this year in an effort to expand its presence in the Taiwan market, the CEO of the company's Taiwan subsidiary said Tuesday.

Chris James made the announcement at an event to celebrate the opening of a client service center at Allianz Taiwan Life Insurance Co. amid rumors that the German insurance giant is reeling from the global financial crunch and therefore considering withdrawing from the Taiwan market.
He said that the new client service center was set up to meet customer demand.

Meanwhile, James, who is also chairman of the Insurance Committee of the European Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (ECCT), reiterated his opposition to a government plan to tax earnings from investment-linked life insurance products.

He said that it is unfair to deny the long-standing socially recognized system that offers customers transparent, flexible, cost-effective life insurance and savings as an alternative to less flexible and more opaque traditional products.
He criticized the government's decision on the issue as a misstep, saying that it will erode public confidence in investment.
The subsidiary company suggested that the government should first amend the relevant laws before implementing the tax reform plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Plea bargain requests by ex-president's relatives rejected

TEXT.P: Prosecutors rejected Tuesday requests for plea bargains by several relatives of former President Chen Shui-bian involved in his corruption and money-laundering case.
They are the former president's son Chen Chih-chung, daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching, brother-in-law Wu Ching-mao and sister-in-law Chen Chun-ying.
Chen Chih-chung acted as a proxy for the former first family's controversial overseas bank accounts, while Huang, Wu and Chen Chun-ying were some of the nominal account holders.

Lin Che-hui, a prosecutor from the Special Investigation Division of the Supreme Prosecutors Office, told a Taipei District Court hearing that the prosecution decided not to consider the defendants' requests because they played a major part in the money-laundering case and are still under investigation in other related cases.
The fact that Chen Chih-chung and his wife Huang Jui-ching have so far not wired the overseas funds back to Taiwan is another reason why their requests were turned down, prosecutorial sources said.
Chen and his wife Wu Shu-jen are accused of siphoning off NT$104 million (US$3.15 million) from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during his term as president from 2000 to 2008.

They are also charged with accepting bribes totaling NT$300 million in connection with a land deal between the Hsinchu Science Park and Dayu Development Corp. and with receiving kickbacks totaling NT$90.93 million between 2002 and 2003 to help a contractor win the tender to build the Nangang Exhibition Hall.

In addition, the couple allegedly took bribes totaling NT$310 million from former Taipei Financial Center Corp. Chairwoman Diana Chen and former Chinatrust Financial Holdings Co. Vice Chairman Jeffrey Koo Jr.

The couple allegedly secretly stashed the funds overseas through various intermediaries, including members of their own family, all of whom have also been indicted for offenses relating to Chen and Wu.
The court is expected to announce its verdict on Sept. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua to host weekend festival for indigenous tribes

TEXT.P: A cultural festival and traditional sports competition for Taiwan's indigenous people will be staged Saturday in Yuanlin, Changhua County, with representatives of the Bunun tribe officiating at the opening ceremony, county officials announced Tuesday at a news conference.

According to officials of the local civil affairs bureau, the primary aim of the festival and competition is to allow the more than 4,700 indigenous people residing in the central Taiwan county to gain a fresh understanding of their traditional rituals, arts and culture and pass them on to the younger generations.

The event, sponsored annually by the Changhua County government, features on a rotating basis the culture of one of the 13 major aboriginal tribes in Taiwan, and the opening ceremony usually is chaired by a member of the featured tribe.
This year's festival will highlight the Bunun tribe.
Leaders, revered elders and representatives of all the tribes living in Changhua will gather Saturday for the annual activity in a bid to revive and preserve their traditions.

The public will see traditional aboriginal dances and an exhibition of craftsmanship and will also have an opportunity to sample a wide variety of speciality dishes prepared by indigenous people, county officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign language classes available for children of foreign spouses

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) gave a green light Tuesday to measures allowing elementary schools to give extra classes in Chinese and foreign languages to children of foreign spouses, a ministry official said that day.

Lu Hung-lin, director of the MOE's Department of Elementary Education, said the measures are aimed at helping these school children sharpen their language abilities and more quickly adapt to school life, and are part of the government's efforts to foster bilingual talent in its pursuit of an international competitive edge.

Apart from offering extra Chinese language classes on campuses, elementary schools are permitted to employ experts to give extra-curricular classes in the mother tongues of the students of foreign spouses of Taiwanese citizens.
It has been estimated that more than 30,000 children born into such families in Taiwan will enroll in first grade classes in September at primary schools around the country, Lu added.

The government has since 2004 adopted a series of measures to assist elementary school students of the so-called "new immigrants" to improve their learning at school and their family relationships at home, in view of the rising number of foreign wives from China and Southeast Asian countries.

At present, children born to foreign husbands and wives of local people account for about 10 percent of Taiwan's newborns each year, he noted. The ratio peaked at 13 percent in 2003 and gradually dropped to 9.6 percent in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., European insurers to openly voice opposition to new tax plan

TEXT.P: At least seven U.S. and European insurers are expected to attend a news conference to be held by the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei to express their opposition to a proposal by Taiwan to tax income from investment- linked insurance products, an AmCham official said Tuesday.

The prospective participants are Allianz, MetLife, HSBC Insurance, Manulife, New York Life Insurance, Cardif Assurance Vie and Prudential Life, all of which are members of either AmCham or the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT), said Lee Wood, chairman of AmCham's Insurance Committee.
They will also clarify misunderstanding among some members of the public about investment-linked insurance products, Wood said.

He said it is important that customers have the option of investment-linked products because they provide an additional and transparent layer of financial security for customers who could otherwise lose their savings to other general creditors if an insurer were to fail.

On July 24, the Tax Reform Committee under the Executive Yuan adopted a resolution to treat earnings from unit-linked insurance products as taxable income. Gains of up to NT$270,000 would be tax-exempt under the existing exemption for interest income, but amounts beyond that would be subject to taxation.
The committee also suggested that proceeds from policies where the policyholder and beneficiary are not the same person be subject to a 10 percent gift tax on benefits of over NT$2.2 million.
The proposal met immediate objections from AmCham and the ECCT, both of which warned that it would discourage consumer saving and damage Taiwan's insurance industry.

Commenting on the issue, officials from the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) said Tuesday that the resolution adopted by the Tax Reform Committee is not final and that the FSC will continue to communicate with the Ministry of Finance's Taxation Agency on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei receives highest rating in healthcare governance

TEXT.P: Taipei City was rated the best among 20 cities and counties in Taiwan proper, as well as the two special municipalities of Taipei and Kaohsiung, in terms of healthcare governance, according to rating results released Tuesday by the Taiwan Healthcare Reform Foundation (THRF).

In the 2009 healthcare governance rating, Taipei City scored in each of five rating categories -- medical resources, charges for medical treatment services, safety of medicines, services for the less-privileged, and settlement of medical disputes.
In each category, either "one point" or "zero" is given as a score, which denotes "good" or "in need of improvement" performance of local governments in healthcare administration.
Under the THRF rating, Taipei City received a total score of five points, meaning that the city was seen as doing a good job in every rating category.
Taipei County ranked behind the capital city with a score of four points, as its efforts in promoting the safety of medicines failed to receive a point from THRF.

Taoyuan County, Kaohsiung City and Hualien County all received scores of three points, while Keelung City, Hsinchu County, Taichung City, Taichung County, Changhua County, Yunlin County, Tainan City, Tainan County, Taitung County and Yilan County scored two points, according to the rating.
Hsinchu City, Chiayi County, Chiayi City, Kaohsiung County, Pingtung County, Nantou County and Miaoli County all got only one point.

The foundation found that Kaohsiung City performed the best in the management of medical service charges, while Taipei City, Hsinchu City and Chiayi County offered the best services in providing medical treatment subsidies.
In the category of the settlement of medical disputes, Taoyuan County was found to be doing the best job, the THRF said.
The THRF is an independent non-government organization that aims to improve healthcare quality and patient's rights in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 5, or the 15th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1100: Henry I, the youngest son of William the Conqueror, is crowned king in Westminster Abbey, three days after his brother William Rufus was killed in a hunting accident in the New Forest.
1858: The laying of the world's first transatlantic telegraph cable between Ireland and Newfoundland is completed.
1792: Frederick North, British politician known as "Lord North," dies at the age of 60. He served as prime minister (1770-1782) under George III and instituted policies that led to the rebellion of the American colonies.
1861: A national income tax is introduced in the United States, initially to fund the Civil War.
1895: Friedrich Engels, German socialist theorist and writer, dies at the age of 75. He met Karl Marx in Paris in 1844 and collaborated with him on "The Communist Manifesto" in 1848.
1930: Neil Armstrong, American astronaut and the first man on the moon, is born.
1948: The Republic of China and the United States agree to organize the Joint Commission for Rural Reconstruction, with Chiang Meng-lin, James Yen and Shen Chung-han from the ROC, and Dr. Raymond T. Moyer and Dr. John Earl Baker from the United States as commissioners.
1949: The United States issues a "White Paper" on Sino-American relations, blaming the Nationalist government for the occupation of the Chinese mainland by the communists.
1950: A Kuomintang Central Reform Committee is set up in Taipei.
1950: The U.S. 13th Air Force is stationed in Taiwan to help the ROC guard against possible mainland Chinese air attacks.
1952: The first Japanese Embassy in Taiwan officially opens on Taipei's Chungshan North Road following the exchange of diplomatic notes ratifying the Sino-Japanese Peace Treaty.
1957: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Liberia.
1958: The nuclear-powered submarine Nautilus completes a historic 2,000-mile (3,200-km) underwater journey from Point Barrow in Alaska to the Greenland Sea, passing directly under the North Pole during its five-day voyage.
1958: Vice President Chen Cheng, who was appointed on July 1 to the concurrent post of Executive Yuan president, presides over a ceremony laying the foundation for the construction of the NT$3,200 million Shihmen Dam.
1971: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with the Republic of Turkey.
1973: The Hua Hsing Junior High School baseball team leaves for Gary, Indiana, to represent the Far East in the Senior League World Series.
1974: The Republic of China Amateur Big League baseball team leaves Taipei to participate in the 1974 Amateur Big League World Series in Ft. Lauderdale, Fla.
1976: The Executive Yuan approves the extension for two years of the Sino- Panamanian pact on technical fishery cooperation.
1984: Richard Burton, Welsh-born actor and twice husband of actress Elizabeth Taylor, dies of a stroke at his home in Switzerland.
1986: The Chinese Taipei women's basketball team leaves for Moscow to compete in the 10th Women's Basketball World Championships.
1991: President Lee Teng-hui receives Fijian Prime Minister Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara.
1999: The 18th International Baseball Association World Amateur Big League Baseball Championship opens in Kaohsiung County with 12 teams from Cuba, Japan, South Korea, Panama, the United States and Taiwan participating.
2000: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh announces the list of members for his inter-party task force on cross-strait relations, which he said will be an advisory body for the ROC president and not a policy-making unit.
2001: National Defense University President Gen. Hsia Ying-tsou says that Taiwan's first state-financed military think tank, the National Center for Strategic Studies, will be inaugurated on Sept. 1.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By strictly limiting the time of their service and making all imposts as light as possible: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to the mass of the people."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Younger fathers more willing to take child-rearing role: survey

TEXT.P: There are significant generational differences on how Taiwanese fathers see their role in raising children, with younger fathers more willing to be actively involved in the child-rearing process, a recently conducted survey has found.

The results of the survey, released Tuesday by Parenting magazine ahead of Father's Day, revealed that 50 percent of fathers born in the 1950s are willing to take parental leave, compared to 75 percent of younger fathers.

Asked if they would give up a promotion for their families' sake, 62 percent to 67 percent of fathers born in the 1970s and 1980s said they would, considerably higher than the 56 percent of respondents born in the 1950s who answered affirmatively.

The survey found that the most cited pressure or challenge of being a father was "maintaining stable finances." Others cited included lacking an understanding of what their children are thinking, differing with their wives on how to rear children, and lacking time to keep their children company.
Approximately 20 percent of fathers spend less than one hour per day with their children, and more than 40 percent think they are not spending enough time with their kids.
Although most Taiwanese fathers remain in their stereotypical role as their families' major income earners, many are showing shifts in their personal values.

The survey found that 46.92 percent of the respondents most valued family happiness while 42.52 percent cited health as their top priority, both far surpassing the 3.13 percent who listed wealth as their top priority and the 2.15 percent who paid most attention to career achievement.
The survey was conducted between late June and early July among 1,023 fathers aged between 19 and 58.
Also surveyed were 1,572 mothers in the same age group, 56 percent of whom described their husbands as willing to share the burden of household chores and bring their children to and from school.
Among the different types of husbands categorized according to their paternal roles, those who "do nothing" are the most disappointing to the women, according to the results.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Wednesday:
CHINA TIMES:
Yeh's decision has tied him to KMT Chairman Ma
Department of Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan's decision to step down to run for Hualien County magistrate has put him on a treacherous path.
He will now face a powerful local faction struggle and the notorious Kuomintang election culture.
President Ma Ying-jeou, even before taking over as KMT chairman, has used Yeh as a litmus test of the loyalty of KMT members and their desire for reform.
The KMT's "heavyweight" in Hualien has been convicted in court, and if the party nominates him, it will not be in keeping with public expectations of Ma's vision for integrity and reforms.
Moreover, if he is elected, his victory could be later invalidated, which would deal a heavy blow to the party and Ma.
But other KMT members cannot match the popularity of the "heavyweight, " and only if a candidate was "anointed" by Ma was there a chance of persuading the "heavyweight' to bow out voluntarily.
Ma had to take this risky step.
UNITED DAILY NEWS:
KMT choice in Hualien magistrate election

Yeh Ching-chuan's departure from the DOH amid mounting swine flu fears has been severely criticized. Yeh may not be the one and only choice, but from where the KMT stands, its first priority is to prevent KMT Legislator Fu Kun-chi from running.

Fu has demonstrated he is the most popular candidate by leading all other aspirants in polls, but because he was convicted of violating the Securities Transaction Law and sentenced to four years in jail, his joining the magistrate race will become a potential headache.

If Fu breaks away from the KMT and runs on his own, he still has the clout to beat rivals from either major camp. But what if he is elected, only to have his election victory later annulled? What if the scenario of "proxy" candidates becomes a reality in by-elections?
Since the legislative elections took place in January 2008, three legislators have had their victories revoked because of their involvement in various cases.
A by-election will be costly and will plunge local factions into a prolonged struggle, which is why the KMT will not allow it to happen in Hualien.
LIBERTY TIMES:
Ma administration's coolness toward allies killing nation's sovereignty.
Since the inauguration of Ma Ying-jeou's administration in May 2008, 17 U.S. congressmen and two U.S. governors have visited Taiwan, but no U.S. senators have done so.
Inviting influential U.S. senators to Taiwan is one of the major tasks of Ma's administration, but the government has fared poorly in this area.

This indicates that the U.S. government has misgivings about the Ma administration's tilt toward China. The other possibility is that the Ma administration has no intention of making efforts to deepen relations with Washington.
Ma's diplomatic truce policy toward China may have ended frosty cross-strait relations, but it has also sent Taiwan's sovereignty plunging into a paralyzed state of "diplomatic shock."

For over one year, the Ma administration has kept its distance from countries that are friendly toward Taiwan, but has seen China, which is doing everything possible to swallow Taiwan, as a good friend.
The so-called "cross-strait relations is paramount" outlook indicates that the Ma administration's overall policy has led Taiwan's sovereignty into crisis.
APPLE DAILY:
Two films and democratic collapse

The Hong Kong film "Miao Miao, " which was partially funded by Taiwan, was withdrawn from the Melbourne International Film Festival after the festival's organizer decided to air a documentary on exiled Uighur leader Rebiya Kadeer and invite her to Australia.
Meanwhile, opposition Legislator Chai Trong-rong revealed that a Chinese film called "Jianguo Daye, " or "The Great Cause of China's Foundation," will be aired in Taiwan Oct. 1.
Just looking at its title, the film appears to be a politically charged production without any artistic or entertainment value.

The retraction of "Miao Miao" could be a bad omen for the future, a sign that China's influence over Taiwan will penetrate more deeply into every corner of life, and that Taiwan will follow in China's footsteps to blast the Dalai Lama and the Uighur leader.
Whether Taiwan's democracy can be sustained or will collapse hinges on the government's attitude and policy toward these two films.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-intelligence chief to be posted to EU

TEXT.P: Former National Security Bureau (NSB) Director-General Shi Hwei-yow has been named the bureau's new representative to the European Union, the country's top intelligence agency announced Wednesday in a statement.
For years, the bureau has posted staff in selected countries or regions around the world to facilitate enforcement of its missions and government policy, the statement said.
Shi, a judge-turned-politician, who once studied in Germany and is well versed in European affairs, will take over a post that has been vacant since last November, the NSB statement said.
During his tenures as NSB deputy director and director, Shi visited various EU countries on multiple occasions and submitted many policy proposals for government reference, the statement said.

"With his educational and professional background, Shi is a great fit for the post, " the statement said, adding that Shi will be able to effectively carry out various cooperative projects with the EU after assuming his post.

A legal expert, Shi started his political career by heading the legal service department at the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), a quasi-official organization authorized to handle exchanges and negotiations with China in the absence of official ties.
He later served as SEF deputy secretary-general as well as its secretary-general and vice chairman. During those tenures, he represented Taiwan in many rounds of talks with China in the 1990s.
Shi, 57, has also been vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council and the head of the Coast Guard Administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kuo Hua Life Insurance taken over by government

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) , the country's top financial regulator, has taken control of debt-ridden Kuo Hua Life Insurance after the insurer failed to meet mandated financial targets.

In announcing the move Tuesday, FSC Chairman Sean Chen said Kuo Hua's failure to keep its capital adequacy ratio at the legally required level and increase its capital by the deadline set by the FSC were the main reasons behind the takeover.

The insurer will be managed by the Insurance Stability Fund for a tentative period of nine months, during which the company should complete a capital reduction and recapitalization as soon as possible, Chen said.
The FSC had required Kuo Hua to increase its capital by June.
At a shareholders meeting in July, the company resolved to increase its capital by NT$4 billion (US$122.32 million) after a reduction of NT$2 billion, but the target was never achieved.

Huang Tien-mu, director-general of the FSC's Insurance Bureau, said the government will set the target for capital reduction and recapitalization higher to strengthen the company's financial structure and better protect the interests of customers.
As of the end of June, Kuo Hua had a negative net worth of NT$57.9 billion, with assets valued at NT$246 billion, and 2 million policyholders, FSC data showed.

Chen stressed that the company's problems were the result of a weak financial structure rather than day-to-day operations and that during the takeover period, customers' rights will be fully protected.
He promised that the company will continue to operate as usual, collecting premium payments, and handling insurance coverage, policy loans and contract alterations or termination.
With liquidity of NT$120 billion, the company will be capable of handling any normal business needs or abnormal situations, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan records first H1N1 cluster involving hospital staff

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) on Wednesday reported five more clusters of influenza A (H1N1) infections, including the first case affecting hospital staff.
The CDC has ruled out the possibility that the victims contracted the new swine flu strain within hospital premises, CDC Deputy Director-General Lin Ting said.
All of the victims in the case were workers in the hospital's research division, who could have been infected while taking part in a conference held outside the hospital, Lin said.
The other four clusters occurred in local schools, affecting a total of 80 to 90 students, he said.
The CDC estimated that the number of influenza A (H1N1) infections in local communities is increasing at a rate of 4,000 per week, four times faster than four to five weeks ago.
The rapid spread of the virus is reflected in the frequent occurrence of infection clusters in local schools, CDC officials said.

Also Wednesday, Mingtao High School in Wurih Township, Taichung County decided to suspend classes for seven days, after five students in a class were confirmed to have been infected with the H1N1 strain of the influenza A virus.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese bank cards usable in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Chinese visitors will be able to make purchases in Taiwan with bank cards issued by the China-based China UnionPay Co. from Aug. 7, a move that will facilitate spending by Chinese tourists and help boost business for local companies, the Taipei-based National Credit Card Center (NCCC) announced Wednesday.

The decision will allow Chinese visitors to make purchases in Taiwan using their China UnionPay bank cards instead of cash, NCCC General Manager Wong Kuang-hui said. At present, Chinese tourists are permitted to bring with them a maximum of 20,000 Chinese yuan (US$2,928) in cash per visit.

The two sides are slated to make a joint announcement of the decision Aug. 7 at the National Palace Museum in suburban Taipei -- one year after Taiwan relaxed restrictions on visits by tourists from China, he added.

China UnionPay is China's only national electronic payment network, an umbrella network that covers more than 80 banking institutions. As the dominant player in China's bank card industry, it currently has more than 1.8 billion cards in circulation, which are accepted in 61 countries and regions outside China.
Earlier in the day, a China UnionPay delegation led by the company's president, Xu Luode, arrived in Taipei to announce the decision, made possible by the acquiescence of the Taiwanese authorities.
Speaking on his second visit to Taiwan, Xu hailed the Taiwanese authorities' decision to accept the use of bank cards issued by China UnionPay.

"It will not only significantly help increase business volume on both sides but will also mark a milestone in two-way financial cooperation and facilitate Chinese visitors' spending in Taiwan, " he said.

His delegation members included executives from major Chinese banking institutions such as the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, the Agricultural Bank of China, Bank of China, China Construction Bank and Bank of Communications.

Officials from the Taiwan-based Chinatrust Commercial Bank, Taiwan's largest card issuer, have estimated that Chinese tourists' spending volume in Taiwan is likely to hit NT$100 billion (US$3.05 billion) , based on 2 million tourist arrivals from China per year with an average spending in Taiwan of 10,000 yuan.

Government statistics show that tourist arrivals from China have totaled 380,000 since Taiwan opened its doors wider to Chinese tourists in July 2008. Daily spending by Chinese tourists averaged US$295 during the first six months of the opening.

DOC.HEADLINE: AirAsia offers extra-low fare on new Taipei-Bangkok route

TEXT.P: Malaysian budget airline AirAsia announced Wednesday its latest promotional program targeting the Taiwanese market, offering an extra-low fare of just NT$690 (US$21) one-way on the inaugural flight on its Taipei-Bangkok route to be launched Sept. 25.
The fare is limited only to the inaugural flight, with reservations accepted online Aug. 6-11, the company said.
In April, the carrier offered a promotional fare of NT$888 one-way on its July 1 inaugural flight from Taipei to Kuala Lumpur. All available seats were snapped up within 12 hours of the announcement.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beauty a top priority for Taiwanese students during summer break

TEXT.P: What are Taiwanese students doing during summer vacation? Instead of taking classes for extra credits, earning pocket money, or traveling, many are using the time off to get beauty treatments and plastic surgery.

Cosmetology and plastic surgery clinics are reporting an increasing number of student clients since the summer break began, and the Plastic Surgical Association, Republic of China, and the Taiwan Society of Aesthetic Plastic Surgery, have confirmed the trend.

The two professional associations, which represent certified aesthetic doctors and plastic surgeons, respectively, say it is impossible to get an accurate estimate of how big the market is and how much it grows every year, mainly because such treatments are not covered by Taiwan's national health insurance program.

Individual beauty clinics, however, are reporting year-on-year increases in the number of young people undergoing cosmetic procedures, with the number even doubling in July compared to previous months.

"Business in cosmetic procedures has surged in July and August due to the increasing number of student customers, whether they are from Taiwan or abroad, " says Tseng Chung-ren, a dermatologist who owns a medical cosmetic center and clinic in downtown Taipei.

Tseng told the Central News Agency that Taiwanese students would normally constitute 20 percent of his clientele, but that has jumped to 40 percent this summer, while another 20-30 percent are students from abroad and the remaining customers are local women aged 25-45.

Chao Tzi-kang, the director of a beauty clinic in Taipei's Ximending, a popular shopping district and a gathering place for students, has seen a similar trend, saying that student customers generally increase during the summer.

The long break provides enough time for students or newly-graduated young adults to recover from the procedures before entering a new school or the workforce, as more and more people put greater emphasis on their appearance, both Tseng and Chao observed.

The increasingly competitive job market, especially in the current economic downturn, is prompting people to acquire what they consider more advantageous features or at least get rid of blemishes and imperfections, all to improve their chances of getting hired.
"Patients come to have cosmetic treatment for a better look and to boost their confidence. The patients are getting younger and younger," Tseng said.
Even the number of elementary school students being brought in by their parents for simple treatments, such as mole removal surgery, has increased recently, he added.

Young patients go for different treatments depending on their age. Mole and birthmark removals are common for elementary school students. Acne treatments, and scar and tattoo removals are popular among high school students.

And among university students, hair removal, blepharoplasty (double eyelid surgery), and micro-plastic surgery, such as botox or rhinoplasty using hyaluronic acid, are in big demand, according to Tseng.
Hair removal procedures, especially the removal of leg hair for girls, and armpit odor treatments, are particularly popular among the college crowd, Tseng said.

The cost for the former starts at NT$30,000 (US$916) and can go as high as NT$100,000, depending on the body part, while the latter ranges from NT$20,000 to NT$40,000. The popular surgery to have double eyelids, meanwhile, costs NT$30,000.

Taiwanese students studying abroad opt for cosmetic treatments during their summer break because of Taiwan's high-quality medical sector and relatively low costs. Local procedures sometimes cost one-tenth the amount charged for the same procedures in Western countries, Tseng said.

There is also an increasing number of young men coming to have cosmetic procedures, according to Chao. He noted that 40 percent of his patients under the age of 20 are male and most of them come for skin treatments.
I find that many young male patients are more open-minded than before and will even make more of an effort than before to look after their skin following the procedures,Chao said.
A senior in college surnamed Lin told CNA that he has undergone a series of laser acne scar removal treatments because the problem has bothered him for a long time.
"I decided I had had enough and that I had to get rid of it, " said Lin, who is in the final stage of the treatment with barely any marks visible on his face.

Noting that he used to feel ashamed and avoided talking to friends for fear that they would stare at his acne, Lin said the treatment helped boost his confidence in his appearance and self-esteem when facing people.
Now I can look directly into people's eyes when I talk to them," he said.
Lin's father, who is paying for the course of six treatments that cost a total of around NT$100,000, said he totally supports his son's decision.
"My son feels that the procedures will help him look better and be more confident, and I think it is OK to do so, as long as the procedures are safe, " Lin's father said.

Chao from the Ximending clinic says more parents now bring their children to cosmetic surgery clinics to have moles and birthmarks removed because some are paying greater attention to their children's looks while others know their children worry about their flaws but are unwilling to say so.

From a professional point of view, it is also good that many parents let their children have the procedures while they are still young, since most of the moles or birthmarks should be removed sooner rather than later,according to Chao.
Both Chao and Tseng suggested patients do some research in advance before deciding to undergo plastic surgery.

They also stressed the importance of patients having thorough discussions with doctors to help their doctor get a better feel for their needs and learn more about a treatment's effectiveness and risks.

Tseng said it is better for patients to undergo a treatment over an extended period of time rather than trying to compress procedures into a limited time frame because the risks and side-effects are lower.

Meanwhile, the doctors said many people incorrectly believe that it is better to have laser skin treatments in the winter rather than the summer because there is less of a chance of developing pigmentation disorders.

In fact, side-effects such as temporary pigmentation disorders are reactions to inflammation resulting from skin treatments rather than due to exposure to sunshine, and they are normal and inevitable.

Patients should therefore not overreact to or worry about such skin reactions because the problem will be resolved in one to three months if they follow their doctor's instructions and take good care of their skin, the experts said.
These cosmetic treatments, however, are not always safe or satisfactory, said Hung Chia-huei, an official of the Plastic Surgical Association, Republic of China.

She told CNA that among the complaints her group receives from cosmetic surgery patients, most are related to disappointment with a treatment's outcome or to disputes with the clinic over the cost of the procedure, especially in a market where prices charged vary widely among clinics.

The organization, however, has no power to govern beauty clinics or punish doctors guilty of malpractice who do not belong to the organization, Hung said, indicating that it can only refer patients to seek help from the Department of Health.

Lin Shih-li, a spokeswoman for the Teacher Chang Foundation, a civic counseling group for teenagers, warned that plastic surgery should not be encouraged among young people because they are not mature enough and are easily influenced by the mass media, pop culture and peer pressure.
She noted that parents, therefore, play an extremely important role in guiding their children.
Your self-value is not about the beauty of your appearance but rather determined by the confidence and self-esteem gained through interactions with others and being a responsible person,Lin said.
"As your external beauty fades over time, your overall character, which represents who you really are as a person, becomes the charisma that will last forever,she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local firm raises NT$4 million for school fees

TEXT.P: The local chapter of the Christian charity World Vision said Wednesday that Inventec Appliances Corp. (IAC) has raised more than NT$4 million (US$122,000) in a one-month drive to help 1,335 disadvantaged students attending primary and junior high schools around Taiwan.

From July 1-31, the Taiwan-based manufacturer of Smart Handheld and network appliances partnered with World Vision to raise money through a "Love Loaf" coin donation program, mobile phone sales, donations from the corporation and its employees, as well as a World Vision account designated specifically for the cause.

World Vision Taiwan said it has already identified 710 primary school students and 625 junior high school students who will receive tuition aid to help ease the financial burden on their families when it comes to paying fees for the upcoming school year.

According to World Vision Taiwan, IAC President Daniel Lee sent an internal message to encourage his employees to support the cause, given that many businesses have been forced to close factories or lay off employees in response to the impact of the financial crisis. As a result, many low-income families lost their only source of income and were pushed deeper into poverty.

"Although they may not go hungry immediately, their children risk dropping out of school. Let's do our small part to save children from losing the only opportunity they have to break out of the vicious cycle of poverty, " Lee was quoted as saying in a press statement released by World Vision Taiwan.

Financial contributions from the IAC appeal will be offered to students living in cities and countries that recorded the highest jobless rates in the first half of the year -- Taipei County, Taoyuan County, Taichung City, Taichung County, Nantou County, Tainan County, Kaohsiung City and Hualien County.
According to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics under the Executive Yuan, the unemployment rate climbed to 5.94 percent in June, representing 647,000 people out of work.
This year, World Vision Taiwan plans to help finance 45,000 children to stay in school.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan plays vital role in polio eradication effort: Rotary president

TEXT.P: Taiwanese Rotarians play an important role in the global effort to eradicate polio and have made great contributions to the cause, John Kenny, president of the civic service group Rotary International, said Wednesday in Taipei.

"I think the contributions made (here in Taiwan) are tremendous contributions, probably out of proportion to the size of the country compared to other countries in the world," Kenny told CNA in an interview.

A retired judge and a notary from Grangemouth, Scotland, Kenny is on his first foreign visit in his capacity as president of Rotary International. He took office July 1, becoming the first Scotsman to head the international humanitarian service organization in its 105-year history.

He noted that Taiwan, which was declared polio-free by the World Health Organization in 2000 and has had no polio cases since 1991, can serve as a good example and share its experience with other countries in fighting against the disease.

Kenny suggested that Taiwan's landmark skyscraper Taipei 101 consider doing a light projection promotion that reads "End Polio Now," which he said will give a boost to the global effort and will be good publicity for the country.

For more than 20 years, the eradication of polio has been Rotary's top priority, and Kenny said that a final push is needed to vanquish the crippling, potentially deadly disease once and for all, especially in countries like India, Pakistan, Afghanistan and Nigeria where polio is pandemic.

Kenny said that during his one-year term as president, it's important for him to visit as many countries as possible where there are Rotary clubs and that he particularly wanted to visit Taiwan early in his term to thank Rotary members in Taiwan for their outstanding service.
"You have done great humanitarian work internationally, " said Kenny, adding that he also expressed this view and his sincere appreciation to President Ma Ying-jeou in a meeting the day before.

He noted that Taiwanese Rotarians have donated water purifiers for 42 schools in north Thailand, provided medical supplies and other necessities for people in war-torn Cambodia villages and helped street children in the Philippines and Brazil.
Rotary is very strong in Taiwan compared to the total population and is one of the top donors to the Rotary charity, Rotary Foundation, Kenny said.
Rotary held its annual convention in Taiwan in 1994 and is looking forward to returning, as Taipei is perceived as a safe city and is therefore an attractive venue, he said.
After he concludes his three-day visit to Taiwan Aug. 6, Kenny will visit Hong Kong, Shanghai and Beijing.

He said he hopes that China will one day relax its regulations on non- governmental organizations like Rotary International, as only foreign expatriates in China are allowed to join the civic group at present.
However, China will most likely change its stance on that issue over the course of time, he added.
Kenny intimated that as long as he is president of Rotary, the organization will not initiate any changes in Taiwan on the basis of considerations for China's position.

"It's up to people in this country to decide what they want to do. Rotary International will not force them to do anything that they don't want to, as long as I'm the president, " Kenny said. "You don't abandon your friends."

DOC.HEADLINE: Aboriginal villages to have broadband service by 2010: NCC

TEXT.P: New Century InfoComm Tech., one of Taiwan's major telecom players, has begun to provide broadband access services to Dahu village in Chiayi County's Fanlu township, the National Communications Commission (NCC) said Wednesday.

With the first broadband network for remote areas completed this year, the commission is confident of achieving its policy goal of "broadband in every tribe and village, " which is part of Taiwan's telecommunication universal service program.
The launch ceremony of the Power Line Communication and Broadband Universal Service was held at the township's Dahu elementary school, the commission said.
Those officiating at the ceremony included Chiayi Magistrate Chen Ming-wen, NCC Chairwoman Bonnie Peng and NCC Commissioner Hsieh Chin-nan.

Under the Regulations on Telecommunication Universal Services, New Century InfoComm has completed its construction of broadband connection networks to offer high-speed Internet access service in Dahu.
The service allows students at the elementary school to benefit from opportunities provided by an "e-learning" program.
Meanwhile, the NCC pledged that day that broadband services will be available in every aboriginal village in Taiwan by 2010.

Of the country's 730 indigenous villages, 54 still do not have access to broadband Internet. The commission will meet its policy goal when broadband services are available to all tribal villages in Taiwan's remote areas in 2010, according to an NCC news release. This year, the project will cost NT$77 million (US$2.35 million), which will come from the general telecommunication fund, with 30 of the designated sites located in tribal villages, according to the commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices plunge on local bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices plunged Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 107.63 points, or 1.54 percent, to close at 6,848.24.
The local bourse opened at 6,979.73 and fluctuated between 7,013.6 and 6,827.16 during the day's trading session.
A total of 4.98 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$145.28 billion (US$4.44 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 4 percent. Banking and financial shares declined 3.3 percent, paper and pulp issues were down 2 percent, foodstuff issues dropped 1.5 percent, machinery and electronics shares decreased 1.3 percent, and textile stocks declined 0.9 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares were down 0.4 percent.
Only cement stocks gained ground, advancing 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,880 to 586, with 107 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$2.74 billion-worth of shares.

An analyst with Yuanta Investment Consulting said it had been forecast that Taiex could maintain its momentum to reach between 7,200 and 7,300 after Taiex crossed the 7,000-point threshold Aug. 3. However, he admitted that the forecast was wrong, as a rise in share prices on international markets could not reverse the fact that profit-taking had been on the rise on Taiex over that previous two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, increasing NT$0.046 to close at NT$32.720.
A total of US$754 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.684 and fluctuated between NT$32.620 and NT$32.738.

DOC.HEADLINE: Medical groups postpone protests due to administrative changes

TEXT.P: Local hospital operators and pharmaceutical manufacturers have decided to postpone indefinitely their street protest plans due to an imminent change at the top of the Department of Health (DOH), medical sources said Wednesday.

The International Research-based Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association (IRPMA) and the Taiwan Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association (TPMA) had planned to mobilize up to 1,000 of their members to take to the streets Friday in protest against the Bureau of National Health Insurance's (BNHI) decision to cut its payments for pharmaceuticals by NT$10 billion (US$303 million) with effect from Sept.1.
"We have decided to suspend the plan for the time being as the new DOH minister, Yang Chih-liang, will soon assume office, " said IRPMA Secretary-General Cheng Hsing.

According to Cheng, the two professional associations made a decision to stage demonstrations only after outgoing DOH Minister Yeh Ching-chuan refused to meet with representatives of the two groups to discuss issues related to the BNHI's payment for pharmaceutical products.

"It seems that his successor will be more willing to communicate with us on relevant issues, therefore, we will adopt a wait-and-see attitude and will decide later whether or not to go ahead with our protest plans," said Cheng.

She was referring to Yang's remarks a day earlier that he will do his utmost to communicate with local medical service providers and pharmaceutical manufacturers because both groups are patrons of the DOH.
Yeh resigned Monday in preparation to seek the ruling Kuomintang's candidacy for the year-end magistrate election in the eastern county of Hualien.

Yang, 62, will take over the DOH helm Thursday. He is a widely respected public health educator, promoter and administrator. He has a Ph.D. in public health from the University of Michigan and has served as DOH vice minister and Asia University president.

Meanwhile, Hsieh Wu-chi, president of the Taiwan Community Hospitals Association, said his group will also suspend its plan to besiege the BNHI Aug. 12 in protest against a new patient classification system, known as the diagnosis-related group (DRG) system.
The new DRG system will classify patients' illnesses into 967 categories and will be phased in over the next six years.

Under the new system, patients within each category will be expected to use the same level of hospital resources and the health insurance bureau will pay the hospital a fixed amount in accordance with the applicable rate within each category.
The first phase, which will take effect Sept.1, will cover 111 categories, including appendectomy, caesarean section, hemorrhoid removal, hernia repair and myomectomy.
Hsieh argued that the new system will benefit large medical centers and deal yet another blow to smaller community hospitals.

His view was shared by Wu De-lon, president of the Taiwan Hospitals Association, who argued that the new system could force smaller hospitals to refuse to admit patients suffering from severe diseases.

Wu said his association had originally planned to stage a demonstration at the Legislative Yuan Aug. 13 to enlist lawmakers' support for its call to scrap the new system in consideration of patients' rights.

"But we are now having second thoughts as the new health minister will soon take charge and we would not like to embarrass him soon after he assumes office. Our association will call a meeting to decide whether to suspend the protest plan for the time being, " Wu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese bondholders want repayment from Japanese government

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwanese citizens who hold bonds issued by the Japanese colonial government petitioned the Ministry of Finance (MOF) Wednesday to help them seek repayment from the Japanese side in a case has been unresolved for more than 60 years.

According to the bondholders, after Taiwan was handed over to the Kuomintang (KMT) government in 1945, the Japanese government notified Taiwan that between 1952 and 1967 it would accept redemption of bonds it had issued.
However, the Taiwanese government did not seek repayment from Japan on behalf of the bondholders within that period, so that holders have never received any repayment, they said.
In response to the petition, Deputy Minister of Finance Tseng Ming-Chung said his ministry will work with the bondholders to find a solution to the problem.

However, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Lee Chun-yee, who helped the bondholders negotiate the matter with the MOF, was unsatisfied with ministry's failure to provide the bondholders with any substantive commitment and said the DPP will continue to promote the enactment of a law to require the government to reimburse the bondholders before seeking compensation from the Japanese side.
Similar legislation has been introduced by the DPP in the past but has been blocked by KMT legislators.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese cruise passengers impressed by Taiwan

TEXT.P: More than 1,500 tourists who arrived in Taiwan from Hong Kong aboard the Star Cruises liner Aquarius were scheduled to end a three- day visit to Taiwan Wednesday after enjoying the beauty of the island from north to south.
The vessel sailed from Taichung in central Taiwan to Keelung in the north that day and was scheduled to embark for Hong Kong later in the day.

As the more than 1,500 travelers, including 800 from China, bid farewell to Taiwan, many of them said they had a very good impression of the island's landscape, delicious food and people's hospitality.
Some of them described Taiwan as a "home away from home" and some even wore dresses printed with the Republic of China national flag.

In three days of sightseeing, the tourists visited popular tourist spots such as the National Palace Museum and the 101 building in Taipei City, as well as aboriginal Wulai township in Taipei County and the night market in Keelung City.
The Aquarius arrived Monday in Tainan City's Anping Port in southern Taiwan. Reporters from Hong Kong and China were also traveling aboard the ship to cover the trip.

Around half of the tourists are Chinese and they were the first from China to tour Tainan since an incident in October last year in which Chang Mingqing, vice president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, was chased and pushed to the ground by a pro-independence mob while he was touring the city's Confucius temple on his own.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan steps up crackdown against cross-border fishing from China

TEXT.P: Six Taiwanese coast guard vessels embarked on a patrol of the Taiwan Strait Wednesday at the launch of a new campaign to crack down against Chinese fishing boats illegally straying into the Taiwan side of the strait to fish.

It was the beginning of a reinforced effort by the Coastal Patrol Directorate General (CPDG) to raid intruding Chinese fishing boats - a problem that arose after China lifted its 30-month ban against fishing in the strait on Aug. 1.

Freed from the ban, Chinese fishing vessels are expected to stray into Taiwan- controlled water, CPDG Deputy General Director Lin Hsing-heng said at a ceremony Wednesday in Makong City in the Penghu archipelago off southwestern Taiwan, to mark the launch of the patrols.
Already, Taiwanese coast guards discovered many Chinese boats illegally sailing in the waters close to the Penghu archipelago on Tuesday, fishing wantonly, according to Lin.

Lin said many Chinese fishing boats spotted in the past use lethal drift gill nets; trinal nets, which have three parts; and rolling-wheel nets for fishing. This way of fishing damages the marine ecology and depletes marine resources, Lin said.
