DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's forex reserves rise to new high

TEXT.P: Taiwan was holding US$321.09 billion in foreign exchange reserves as of the end of July, a record high amount that was US$3.53 billion more than the June figure, the Central Bank of the Republic of China reported Wednesday.
In late July, Taiwan was ranked as the world's fourth-largest holder of forex reserves, after China, Japan and Russia, and ahead of India.

Lin Sun-yuan, chief of the bank's Foreign Exchange Department, attributed the forex reserves growth to the strong appreciation of its major currencies,like the euro and Japanese yen,against the U.S. dollar, as well as returns from foreign exchange reserve management.
Statistics showed that the euro appreciated by 0.41 percent against the greenback for the whole of July, while the Japanese yen gained 0.78 percent in value against the U. S. currency.

As of the end of June, China was holding the world's largest forex reserves, worth US$2.13 trillion, ahead of Japan with US$988.5 billion, and Russia with US$365.4 billion. India's foreign exchange reserves were recorded at US$256.7 billion as of July 24.

Singapore was holding US$174.7 billion in forex reserves as of the end of June, up by US$4.7 billion month-on-month, while Hong Kong had US$205.7 billion, an increase of US$9.5 billion compared to May.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA referendum initiative superfluous: vice minister

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) push for a referendum on the government's proposal to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China is tantamount to "carrying coals to Newcastle," an official said Wednesday.

"The DPP's campaign for an ECFA referendum is pointless and superfluous because if the agreement is signed, it will be referred to the Legislative Yuan for screening, " said Vice Minister of Economic Affairs John C.C. Deng.

The pro-independence DPP filed an application with the Central Election Commission (CEC) July 20 for the government to put the proposed ECFA with China to a referendum. The DPP's appeal is now awaiting approval by a CEC screening committee before it could progress to the next stage of obtaining a required ratio of public signatures.

Addressing a weekly meeting of the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) decision-making Central Standing Committee on the ECFA proposal, Deng said the DPP's referendum initiative is a waste of time and social resources because it would only spur yet another round of referendums.

Acknowledging that some people are still wary about the possible negative impact of a Taiwan-China ECFA on the local economy, Deng said the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will strengthen communications with various social sectors to seek their support for the planned cross-strait trade pact.

"We will try even harder to help the public understand that a cross-strait ECFA will help improve local job market prospects and will be beneficial to Taiwan's overall international relations," Deng said.

If Taiwan fails to strike an ECFA deal with China, Taiwan would be further marginalized when the "ASEAN plus 1" trade bloc -- comprised of China and ASEAN member states -- becomes a reality Jan. 1, Deng warned.
According to Deng, Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) could drop by an estimated 0.176 percent if the two sides fail to sign an ECFA by then.
Such a grim scenario could also take a toll on Taiwan's annual exports, imports and trade surplus, driving them down by 0.421 percent, 0.601 percent and US$180 million, respectively, Deng said.
However, if the ECFA is signed, Taiwan's employed population could increase by 257,000 to 263,000, he added.

KMT spokesman Lee Chien-jung said after the meeting that the KMT will launch a publicity campaign to help local people better understand the gist and advantages of a cross-strait EFCA and to enlist their support for the initiative.

DOC.HEADLINE: July CPI registers biggest year-on-year contraction in 38 years

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) in July stood at 104.28 (base year 2006 =100), which was a 38-year record contraction of 2.33 percent year-on-year, while prices almost across-the-board were suppressed by the lingering recession, government statistics showed Wednesday.
The Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Wednesday that Taiwan's year-on-year CPI and its wholesale price index (WPI) had both dropped considerably.
Government statistics have shown negative CPI growth for five consecutive months since March. In the first seven months, the CPI was 0.71 percent lower than in the same period last year.
A spokesman for the DGBAS said that as negative growth of the CPI is expected to continue in the coming months, it raises the worry of deflation.
A consistent decline in commodity prices over the past months had pushed the July WPI down by 14.11 percent as compared with the same month last year.
The import price index dropped 15.98 percent year-on-year and the export price index fell 9.52 percent, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei int'l robot exhibition opens

TEXT.P: The 2009 Taipei International Robot Show (TIROS) opened at the World Trade Center's Nangang Exhibition Hall Wednesday to serve as a platform for Taiwan's robotics industry to expand in domestic and foreign markets.

The annual show, the second of its kind, was jointly organized by the Industrial Department Bureau (IDB) and the Department of Industrial Technology -- both agencies under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, as well as the non-profit Robotics Association Taiwan (ROBOAT).
As the only professional robots exhibition in Taiwan, the event gathered 91 local and foreign companies, academic and research institutes, and civil organizations devoted to robotics development.
A total of 321 booths have been set up at the exhibition hall to showcase their inventions and products.

The exhibits at TIROS have been divided into two categories -- industrial robots and service robots, with the category of industrial robots further divided into robot arms, robot equipment, automation equipment, controller, and the components of industrial robots.
Service robots include cleaning, security, educational, entertainment, and life assistance robots.

The showcase, however, is not the only activity of the four-day show, the organizers said, noting that they have also prepared robotics contests, seminars and conferences for industry leaders, experts and researchers so they can share their insights on the robotics industry, as well as the sector's current and future trends.

According to the IDB, the venue was divided into several sections, including the one that showcases the government's efforts to promote the intellectual robots manufacturing industry over the past four years.

The academic section exhibits 18 works by robotics laboratories of local universities, such as National Taiwan University and National Taipei University of Technology. It was hoped the laboratory projects will help increase the cooperation between enterprises and technical-vocational education, the IDB said.
The robots experiencing section is the only area opened to children in the show. In this section, kids can play with different robots and participate in DIY activities and educational courses.
The 2009 robots show will run through Aug. 8.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan media delegation to visit China in October: SEF

TEXT.P: As relations across the Taiwan Strait continue to warm up, more Taiwan delegations are scheduled to visit China later this year, an official of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Wednesday.

Among others, a media delegation will embark on an exchange visit to China in October following a trip to Taiwan last week by a high-profile group of Chinese journalists, SEF Deputy Secretary-General Ma Shao-chang said.
The SEF is a quasi-official intermediary body authorized to handle cross-strait exchanges and negotiations in the absence of official ties.
As Taiwan has nearly 1,000 media organizations, Ma said, the SEF is still working on the list of media groups that will be invited to form the delegation.
"Basically, we will focus on inviting those who can contribute to cross-strait journalistic exchanges and cooperation," said Ma.

He added that the Liberty Times and SANLIH Entertainment TV, both of which are seen as critics of the current Kuomintang administration's reconciliatory approach toward China, will be on the invitational list.

As to whether the Formosa Weekly, a publication launched recently by former Vice President Annette Lu, will be invited to join the delegation, Ma refrained from giving a direct reply. He said instead that members of the delegation will be composed of editors-in-chief or chief editorial writers of major news organizations.
"The name list is still in the works, " Ma said, adding that the media delegation may be headed by SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung.

Meanwhile, Ma said he himself will also lead a delegation of experts and business executives to China in October to discuss viable measures to better protect the safety of Taiwanese business people operating in China.

"The delegation will join with officials of the SEF's counterpart -- the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) -- to craft an effective emergency communications mechanism to deal with any emergency situations encountered by Taiwanese businessmen in China, " Ma said.

Such a mechanism is badly needed to avoid recurrence of a recent case in which the killing of two Taiwanese businessmen and serious injury of another in Dongguan in the southern province of Guangdong was not immediately reported, he said.

According to the SEF's plan, Ma went on, the foundation will organize two more Taiwanese delegations to visit China for cultural and judicial exchanges before the fourth round of high-level cross-strait talks between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and ARATS President Chen Yunlin takes place late this year.

The first group, to be headed by Liu Te-hsun, a vice chairman of the Cabinet- level Mainalnd Affairs Council (MAC) which oversees SEF operations, is tentatively set to depart late this month, with judicial topics high on its agenda.

The second delegation, to be headed by another MAC vice chairman, Chao Chien- ming, is scheduled to visit Beijing, Xian and Keifong in September, with cultural institutions and museums as main destinations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Reference book for foreign spouses available in 7 languages

TEXT.P: The National Immigration Agency (NIA) has published a reference book in seven languages to help foreign spouses of Taiwanese citizens adapt to local customs and lifestyles, an official said Wednesday.

"The book has been printed in Mandarin Chinese, Vietnamese, Indonesian, Philippine, Thai, Myanmar and Cambodian languages for distribution to foreign spouses of local citizens," said NIA Director-General Hsieh Li-kung.
"The book contains all sorts of practical information and useful tips for better living," Hsieh said, adding that it is expected to help new immigrants assimilate into life in Taiwan.

In order for their marriages to succeed, foreign spouses need the full support of their Taiwanese family members, Hsieh said, calling on extended family members to open-mindedly accept these spouses as new immigrants to Taiwan.
According to Hsieh, the NIG has set up a databank of 394 translators versed in Vietnamese, Indonesian, Philippine, Thai, Myanmar and Cambodian languages.
"This new group of translating and interpreting talent can easily and smoothly communicate with new immigrants and offer them various counseling services," Hsieh said.
In addition, Hsieh said the NIA has installed hotlines for foreign spouses and other foreign expats to offer them more useful counseling and guidelines for living in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sea warning issued for Typhoon Morakot

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a sea warning Wednesday for Typhoon Morakot, which was located some 1,000 kilometers east of Taiwan as of 8:00 p.m. and moving in a west northwesterly direction toward the island at 23 kilometers per hour.
Warning that Morakot will be the worst typhoon to affect Taiwan so far this year, the CWB advised that boats take precautions against the storm, which has a radius of about 200 kilometers.
The storm was gaining strength and was expected to be upgraded to a medium- strength typhoon, the weathermen said.
A land warning could be issued by Thursday as the typhoon is expected to bring powerful winds and heavy rains to Taiwan, the CWB added.
The weathermen said the typhoon will probably make landfall on Taiwan Friday, with the northern and northeastern regions bearing the brunt of it into Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shihmen Reservoir administration hopes typhoon will break dry spell

TEXT.P: While weathermen are alerting people to possible damage by the approaching Typhoon Morakot, the Shihmen Reservoir Agency is hoping that the storm will bring torrential rains that will help relieve the long dry spell at the 45-year- old dam.
Agency director Chiu Chung-chuan said Wednesday that the water level at the reservoir had fallen to a critical 222.64 meters, although 7.5 million tons was collected Tuesday during the heavy showers.
In recent years, the water levels at the Shihmen Reservoir have fallen to alarming lows in summer, according to Chien chao-chun, deputy director of the Northern Region Water Resources Office.
Originally designed mainly to supply water for irrigation in the Taoyuan region, the reservoir now supplies households, farms, and a fast growing industrial sector in the area.

The population in the Taoyuan area has grown three-fold, from 500,000 in the 1960s to 1.8 million recently, and daily household consumption of water has increased from 110,000 tons to 1.2 million tons, Chien said.

The water resources official said that as rainfall and other sources are not sufficient to maintain an adequate storage level, the ultimate solution is to develop new resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade volume at Taichung port free trade zone tops other harbors

TEXT.P: The free trade zone at Taichung Harbor, central Taiwan recorded the highest trade value and cargo volume among the four major harbors in the country in the first half of the year, the general director of the Taichung Harbor Bureau said Wednesday.

Wang Chun-yu said that the value of export and import trade at the free trade zone reached NT$10.37 billion (US$317.39 million) in the first half of the year. The volume of cargo handled at the harbor amounted to 459,000 tons in same period, he added.

The figures prove that the bureau has set a great record in its mission to promote business at the free trade zone, in comparison with the other major harbors at Kaohsiung, Keelung and Hualien, Wang said in his briefing to Yeh Kuang-shih, deputy minister of Transportation and Communications.
Yeh visited the Taichung Harbor Wednesday to inspect operations at its free trade zone and he commended the bureau's performance.

He directed the bureau to try to attract customers through advertisements and by offering customized services, in order to maximize the scope of the free trade zone. He also expressed the hope that the bureau will take advantage of the harbor's geographic location to attract Chinese investment now that there are direct transport links across the Taiwan Strait.

He added that even as industrial pollution has contaminated many underground water resources and farmers are relying heavily on the reservoir for irrigation, its capacity has dropped considerably because many parts of the old dam have silted up.
The reservoir's storage capacity nowadays is 25 percent less than the 680,000 cubic meters it was originally designed to hold, Chien estimated.
The water resources official said that as rainfall and other sources are not sufficient to maintain an adequate storage level, the ultimate solution is to develop new resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade volume at Taichung port free trade zone tops other harbors

TEXT.P: The free trade zone at Taichung Harbor, central Taiwan recorded the highest trade value and cargo volume among the four major harbors in the country in the first half of the year, the general director of the Taichung Harbor Bureau said Wednesday.

Wang Chun-yu said that the value of export and import trade at the free trade zone reached NT$10.37 billion (US$317.39 million) in the first half of the year. The volume of cargo handled at the harbor amounted to 459,000 tons in same period, he added.

The figures prove that the bureau has set a great record in its mission to promote business at the free trade zone, in comparison with the other major harbors at Kaohsiung, Keelung and Hualien, Wang said in his briefing to Yeh Kuang-shih, deputy minister of Transportation and Communications.
Yeh visited the Taichung Harbor Wednesday to inspect operations at its free trade zone and he commended the bureau's performance.

He directed the bureau to try to attract customers through advertisements and by offering customized services, in order to maximize the scope of the free trade zone. He also expressed the hope that the bureau will take advantage of the harbor's geographic location to attract Chinese investment now that there are direct transport links across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 6, or the 16th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1806: Holy Roman Emperor Francis II is forced to resign due to the third defeat in the war against Bonaparte Napoleon.
1825: Bolivia declares independence from Peru.
1890: A murderer named William Kemmler is the first prison executed by electric chair in the United States.
1914: Yuan Shih-kai declares China's neutrality in World War I.
1932: The first international film festival opens in Venice, Italy with 29 motion pictures from the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Soviet Union and Italy being shown.
1945: U.S. plane drops the first atomic bomb in Hiroshima, Japan, killing more than 90,000 and injuring over 9,000.
1949: At the invitation of Korean President Syngman Rhee, President Chiang Kai- shek flies to Chinhae, Korea to discuss the formation of a Pacific alliance.
1962: Jamaica declares independence from Britain.
1997: Nicaraguan President Arnoldo Aleman Lacayo arrives in Taipei for a five- day visit.
1997: A South Korean Boeing 747-300 jetliner crashes in Guam, killing 234 on board.
2001: After careful planning, prayer rooms are formally opened at CKS International Airport. The three adjacent prayer rooms have one room equipped with rush mats for kneeling, another fitted with rows of chairs and still another with mattresses and a mark to show the direction of Mecca.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Minister proposes mechanism for health communication with Hong Kong
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 6 (CNA) 08/06/09 11:19:20 (By Mandy Wong and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Department of Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan has proposed that a mechanism be set up to facilitate regular communication between top health officials of Taiwan and Hong Kong.

Yeh noted that while the two sides have no problem exchanging practical or technical information on health issues such as epidemics and food safety, communication at the policy level is currently lacking.

Therefore, establishing a high-level communication mechanism between the health authorities of the two sides will help to enhance the overall quality of their respective public health systems, Yeh said.
The minister expressed the hope that Taiwan and Hong Kong could engage in closer cooperation on epidemic prevention, pharmaceutical research and the industrialization of healthcare service.
Yeh raised the issue in Hong Kong Wednesday at the 5th Taiwan-Hong Kong Forum held at the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Center.
On Tuesday, Yeh held talks with Hong Kong's Food and Health Secretary York Chow on cooperation in the field of health, in what was the first meeting between top health officials of the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Northern Taiwan braces for Typhoon Morakot

TEXT.P: The National Disasters Prevention and Protection Commission activated a "level one" alert against Typhoon Morakot Thursday after the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a land warning for northern Taiwan at 8:30 in the morning.

The level one alert-- the highest on a three-point scale -- puts more than 110 key personnel from 25 agencies on standby to monitor the impact of the typhoon around the clock and oversee disaster preparedness throughout the country, according to the commission.
The commission also urged the public to take precautions against the storm.

According to the Central Weather Bureau, Morakot was centered 540 kilometers southeast of Taiwan as of 11 a.m. Thursday, moving in a west northwesterly direction toward the island at a speed of 20 kilometers per hour. The typhoon is packing maximum sustained winds of 137 kilometers per hour and has a radius of 250 kilometers, the CWB said.

If Morakot, the eighth storm system reported in the West Pacific region this year, maintains its course and continues to strengthen, the system will cover the entire Taiwan area early Saturday, CWB meteorologists said.
The weather bureau cautioned that the storm would bring strong winds and heavy rains to northern Taiwan Friday and into Saturday.
Residents in mountainous areas in northern and eastern Taiwan should be extra careful of landslides and people should keep away from the seaside, the CWB said.

The typhoon is expected to temporarily alleviate the water shortage in the country, as rainfall in Taiwan has been below normal levels so far this year. Water authorities had warned of possible rationing measures if the drought conditions persisted.
Premier Liu Chao-shiuan visited the national disaster prevention commission Thursday morning to inspect its state of readiness ahead of the typhoon.
Because of the approaching storm, he canceled an appointment with local movie director Chang Tsuo-chi that was set up to view Chang's latest film "How Are You, Dad?"

DOC.HEADLINE: Neihu MRT line in Taipei closed until further notice

TEXT.P: The Taipei Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) Neihu line was closed Thursday noon until further notice due to problems with the computer system.

Before the line was closed, the trains were brought into the stations at slow speeds and passengers were asked to disembark. The Taipei Rapid Transit Corporation immediately dispatched buses to the stations to pick up the passengers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Control Yuan proposes corrective measures to DOH, insurance bureau

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top watchdog body, the Control Yuan, proposed corrective measures to the Department of Health (DOH) and the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) Wednesday, saying they have mismanaged the issues of National Health Insurance payments and pharmaceutical prices.

According to the decision, which was announced by Control Yuan members Cheng Jen-hung, Chien Lin Hui-chun and Liu Yu-shan, negligence by the two government agencies has resulted in problems in eight areas.
"The bureau has been asked several times to correct the problems and it has been warned that if it fails to do so now, incoming DOH Minister Yang Chih-liang could be impeached," Cheng said.
Outgoing Health Minister Yeh Chin-chuan has been quoted as saying that the bureau had to pursue cost-saving measures in order to cope with its financial problems, according to Cheng.

The main issue is that there are too many kinds of drugs that are approved for BNHI coverage, so it is difficult to manage them effectively, the Control Yuan said. The problem has persisted even though the bureau for a long time has been paying the same amount for all drugs prescribed for a single ailment, though they may vary in cost, it added.
There was also no proper monitoring of new drugs, of drug prices, or the effectiveness and quality of treatment, according to the watchdog body.

The two agencies did not move to increase health insurance premiums at the opportune time, even though it was within their right under the National Health Insurance Act, the Control Yuan said. This has left the BNHI with a budget deficit of NT$33.1 billion (US$1 billion), it noted.
When asked about the possibility of former health ministers being impeached, Cheng said that he does not want to make any speculations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Thursday.
Liberty Times: Energy tax will drive industries out of Taiwan
The Tax Reform Committee decided last week to launch an energy tax and environmental protection tax.
The new taxes will be phrased in over ten years and will exact about NT$220 billion from industries per year after they are fully implemented.
It is estimated that when the taxes are passed on to consumers, households with an income of NT$30,000 will pay as much as NT$10,000 in taxes.
We predict that these taxes will force local industries to relocate to China, rather than result in the improvement of living standards and the environment in Taiwan.
Apple Daily: In memory of actress Wen Yin.
Wen Yin passed away yesterday. She was a true Taiwanese who displayed the qualities of diligence, honesty, kindness, and generosity that are typical of Taiwan people.
Her performance style is not popular today, but it was unique to her and was loved by her audiences.
China Times: Ma's public support will be eroded by his administration's tinkering with the tax system

The Tax Reform Committee under the Executive Yuan decided last week to introduce an energy tax and a pollution tax. We are worried that the administration's tinkering with the tax system will erode the broad public support that President Ma enjoys.
The energy tax is intended more as a means of cutting back on the consumption of fossil fuel rather than as a source of government revenue, because it could be transferred to the consumer.

Tax reform is not just an academic exercise, but is also a political strategy to woo voters. This is why politicians are usually keen to cut taxes. However, the government needs to find a formula to increase taxes in some categories so as to offset tax cuts in other areas.
The tax system should be reviewed comprehensively rather than in the current piecemeal fashion that gives interest groups the opportunity to lobby against certain kinds of tax.
United Daily News: Tackling the drought problem.
As Taiwan braces for a hit by Typhoon Morakot, it is hoping that the storm will break the dry spell that has plagued the island since the beginning of the year.
Taiwan recorded average precipitation of 700 mm for the first half of this year, which is about half of the usual volume.
The drought problem should be addressed by raising water rates to reduce consumption, improving the efficiency of water use and recycling waste water.
Taiwan's water rates are unreasonably low, which leads to water waste by consumers, and the old pipeline system leaks about one third of the country's tap water supply every year.
In addition, Taiwan's irritation systems, which consume about 13 billion tons of water, are not efficient.
Also, the government has not done well in recycling waste water, especially industrial waste water which is easier to recycle than domestic waste water.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public urged be more aware of mosquito-borne diseases

TEXT.P: The public was advised Thursday to pay more attention to any uncomfortable symptoms experienced after being bitten by mosquitoes, as the first case of indigenous dengue fever this year has emerged.

Lai Chung-chang, a physician at the Dalin Tzu Chi General Hospital in Chiayi County, noted that the hot and humid summer weather is the most favorable to mosquito infestations, which can result in the transmission of diseases such as dengue fever and Japanese encephalitis.
Therefore, people who come down with fever or experience drowsiness after being bitten by mosquitoes should seek medical treatment immediately, as these could be signs of serious illness, Lai said.

To prevent transmission of the disease, it is important for the public to eradicate mosquito breeding grounds by getting rid of standing water that could accumulate in uncovered containers and drains, he said.
Dengue fever and Japanese encephalitis are two of the most common mosquito-borne diseases in Taiwan.

Dengue fever is transmitted by the aedes aegypti mosquito. The disease's incubation period runs from two to 15 days, and symptoms include high fever, severe headaches, retro-orbital pain, severe joint pains, muscle aches, general weakness, nausea, vomiting and rash.
Japanese encephalitis, meanwhile, is transmissible to humans via mosquitoes that become infected by feeding on domestic pigs and wild birds infected with the Japnaese encephalitis virus (JEV).

The incubation period of the disease runs between five and 15 days. Mild infections usually occur without apparent symptoms other than fever and headaches. In more severe infections, patients may experience headaches, high fever, stiffness of the neck, stupor, disorientation, coma, tremors, occasional convulsions and spastic paralysis.

The Taiwan government has since 1968 provided JEV inoculation to children, with the first two shots given at 15 months, followed by a booster shot the next year and another during the first year of elementary school.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait peace helps improve U.S.-Taiwan security ties

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that peace across the Taiwan Strait marks a new dawn in cross-strait relations and helps improve security ties between Taiwan and the United States.

During a brief meeting at the Presidential Office with U.S. Congressman Phil Gingrey (R-GA) who co-chairs the U.S. Congressional Taiwan Caucus, Ma said that his administration's continuous efforts since last May to improve relations with Beijing has brought about a dawn of peace across the Taiwan Strait and has also made U.S.-Taiwan security ties "easier and simpler" to maintain.

He told Gingrey that all American friends and politicians who have visited Taiwan over the past year have reacted positively to Taiwan's efforts, which he said have not only helped defuse cross-strait tensions, but have also contributed to regional stability. This has allowed the U.S., the European Union, Japan and other nations in the region to better position themselves in terms of global strategy, the president said.
"In other words, Taiwan's ever-warming relations with China are beneficial to all parties concerned," Ma added.

Meanwhile, the president expressed his appreciation for Gingrey's speech in the U.S. Congress in April to reaffirm the U.S. House of Representatives' commitment to the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) in recognition of the 30th anniversary of the law's enactment.

Rep. Gingrey also saw to it that an English summary of an address that Ma gave at an international conference in Taipei to mark the 30th anniversary of the TRA was entered in the U.S. congressional record, the president noted.
The House of Representatives on March 14 adopted a resolution in recognition of the TRA's 30th anniversary.
The resolution acknowledged the TRA as "the cornerstone of U.S. relations with Taiwan" and reiterated Congress' support for Taiwan's democratic institutions.
The resolution also expressed support for "the strong and deepening relationship between the United States and Taiwan."

President Ma expressed his appreciation for the recent visits to Taiwan by Shelley Berkley (D-Nev.) and Lincoln Diaz-Balart (R-FL) -- both co-chairs of the Congressional Taiwan Caucus -- as part of the TRA 30th anniversary celebrations.
The Taiwan Caucus, set up in January 2007, is an informal congressional organization comprised of 147 lawmakers with an interest in boosting Taiwan-U.S. relations.
Gingrey, elected congressman for Georgia State's 11th District in 2002, currently also serves on the Energy and Commerce Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan expects at least 10 more Chinese purchase missions by end 2009

TEXT.P: At least 10 more purchase missions from China are expected to visit Taiwan by the end of this year, following the visits by four such delegations which have already agreed to buy billions of US dollars worth of merchandise there, Taiwan External Trade Development Council's (TAITRA) Chairman Wang Chih-kang said in Beijing Thursday.

According to Wang, the first delegation organized by China's Association of Economy and Trade Across the Taiwan Straits (AETATS) arrived in Taiwan in May and had agreed to buy consumer electronics worth more than US$2 billion, orders for US$700 million of which have been received.

Another AETATS-organized delegation composing of mostly Chinese department store representatives that arrived in July plans to buy processed food worth US$760 million, orders for US$160 million of which have been placed, Wang said.
On Aug. 19, yet another AETATS-organized delegation is expected to arrive and buy goods worth US$1.2 billion, he said.

Meanwhile, another mission comprised mainly of Chinese TV makers organized by China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology arrived in June and made plans to purchase flat panels worth US$5 billion. Orders for US$1.5 billion of the amount have been received, Wang said.
At least 10 more Chinese shopping delegations will arrive in Taiwan during the remainder of the year, Wang said.
Wang made the remarks in a news conference held in Beijing to promote the Taiwan Trade Fair in Nanjing, which is scheduled for Sept. 17-20 at the Nanjing International Expo Center.
The event will be the largest overseas exhibition ever organized by TAITRA since its establishment 40 years ago.
The show will gather 620 Taiwanese businesses and display more than 30,000 Taiwanese products, with the exhibition area to cover 38,000 square meters, TAITRA officials said.

While TAITRA originally intended to provide only 300 booths, the number has been increased to 1,860 because of the widespread interest among Taiwanese businesses to take part in the fair, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of H1N1 clusters rises to 24

TEXT.P: Four more clusters of A (H1N1) influenza infections were confirmed Thursday, bringing the number of clusters in Taiwan to 24, a health official confirmed the same day.
Lin Ting, deputy director of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health, said that the four confirmed clusters involved nearly 50 people, mainly children and juveniles.
This brings to 600 the number of affected patients in A (H1N1) cluster infections, Lin said.
Most of the 24 confirmed cluster infections occurred at schools at all levels, kindergartens and children's homes throughout the country, Lin indicated.
In addition, the CDC reported three more suspected cases of severe A (H1N1) influenza. If these cases are confirmed, the number of severe A (H1N1) infections will rise to 12.
With the number of A(H1N1) cases in the country increasing steadily, Lin reminded people to wash their hands frequently and to cover their mouths when they cough.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's premier thanks outgoing health department chief

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan on Thursday thanked departing Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yeh Ching-chuan for his efforts as the country's top health official, and stated the government will continue to seek his advice and assistance in fighting epidemics, government spokesman Su Jun-pin said.
Su made the remarks in the weekly Executive Yuan meeting presided over by Liu. Yeh also attended the meeting.
Yeh announced on Monday that he had tendered his resignation to Liu in a bid to run for the seat of Hualien County magistrate.

His request was approved by the premier the same day, but drew criticism from lawmakers of both the ruling and opposition parties at a time when the situation of A(H1N1) flu has worsened over the past week, with more than 600 people in Taiwan newly infected in 24 confirmed cluster cases.
"Although Yeh resigned to build a new stage of his career, the government still needs Yeh's experiences in future combat against epidemics," Su quoted the premier as saying.
Meanwhile, the Executive Yuan and the DOH agreed to set up an anti-epidemic counselling panel, and Liu in the meeting demanded the DOH pay greater heed to the safety of vaccinations, according to Su.

The premier said the government is confident that it can effectively handle epidemic outbreaks and minimize their impact on society, but the current swine flu outbreak was still serious and posed a great challenge for the government.
But thanks to the efforts made by Yeh and other experts to curb its spread, Liu said, Taiwan has built one of the world's most comprehensive anti-epidemic networks.
When Yeh assumed office as DOH minister last year, he made it clear that he would leave once his objective at the post has been completed, Liu explained.

In the Executive Yuan weekly meeting, Yeh reported about the DOH's preparations against the spread of influenza A (H1N1) , saying that Adimmune Corp., Taiwan's only producer of vaccine for swine flu, will produce 4 million doses in November.

To prevent a second outbreak of the epidemic, the DOH has reserved enough medicine doses for 4.183 million people and has purchased 5 million doses of the vaccine and will purchase another 5 million doses.

In response to grave public concern about the safety of the company's products, Yeh gave his assurances that DOH personnel will take part in the vaccine's entire manufacturing and quality control process.

DOC.HEADLINE: Making rich pay higher premium is top priority: new health minister

TEXT.P: Adjusting Taiwan's national health insurance premiums will be a top priority, incoming Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yang Chih-liang said Thursday.
"There is room for adjustment of health insurance premiums, with higher-paid individuals paying more premiums and the impoverished paying less," said Yang hours before assuming the top DOH post.

Yang, who is scheduled to take over the DOH helm from outgoing Minister Yeh Ching-chuan in a changeover ceremony scheduled for 5 p.m. Thursday, made the remarks after the watchdog Control Yuan censured the DOH and its Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) the previous day for their failure to promptly increase health insurance premiums when the conditions were appropriate for an adjustment.
The supreme supervisory body said that it would not rule out the possibility of impeaching the incoming health minister if the DOH fails to address the problem.
For years, the BNHI has been operating in the red with its accumulated budget deficit already exceeding NT$33.1 billion (US$1 billion).
Responding to the Control Yuan's reprimand, Yang said he will ask the health insurance bureau next week to come up with a premium adjustment proposal and complementary measures.
"We will prioritize premium adjustments and then consider an overall overhaul of the health insurance system in a later stage, " Yang said.
In his view, Yang said, the insurance premium should be based on individuals' overall income.

"The current problems lie in that fact that rich people pay too little while poor people are overloaded, " Yang said, adding that the future adjustment should be based on the principle of raising premiums for the higher-paid individuals while lowering that for lower-paid people.
"My observation is that there should be room for reducing premiums for poor people," Yang said.

Acknowledging that hikes in health insurance premiums could trigger a backlash, Yang said he will step up communications with the public to minimize objections and enlist their support for any new measures to be adopted.
Yang was quoted as having said previously that ordinary people should not oppose health premium adjustments because they tend to benefit from premium hikes.

"As far as premiums are concerned, the government and employers tend to assume a larger share of the payment than the insured themselves, " he explained. "Why not pay a bit more to get better medical and health care services?"

DOC.HEADLINE: Siao Liouciou offering free ferry rides to promote tourism

TEXT.P: In an effort to attract more tourists to Siao Liouciou, the township office is offering special free round-trip ferry rides to the island, a Pingtung County official said Thursday.
"The free offer is for matchmaking party guests and the first 30 newlywed couples who choose to have their wedding photos taken on the island," the official said.

For the third consecutive year, the township office is promoting Siao Liouciou, an isle off the west coast of Pingtung, as a 'love island' for newly wed couples, focusing on its advantages as a location for wedding photography.

Its online promotions have proved successful, as there has been a steady increase in the number of visitors to the island recently, the office said. The office's data shows record high tourism revenue on the island for the first seven months of 2009.

One of the promotional events, a matchmaking party, will be held Aug. 15, targeting tourists between the ages of 22 and 39. The township office is offering free personal photos as gifts to those who are "matched" during the event.
The free ferry service offer will end Sept. 12, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO protests Miao Miao's withdrawal from Melbourne film festival

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) expressed deep displeasure Thursday over a decision by the producer of the Mandarin-language film Miao Miao to withdraw it from the Melbourne film festival along with other Chinese films.

Taiwan office of the Hong Kong-based Jet Tone Films, owned by noted director Wong Kar-wai, withdrew the movie from the Melbourne International Film Festival in protest against the festival's screening of a documentary about an exiled Uighur leader who has been branded by Beijing as a terrorist.

GIO Minister Su Jun-pin said at a news briefing that he has lodged a strong protest with Jet Tone's Taiwan office over the decision to pull the film without notifying the GIO, which partially funded the movie's production.
"This action has tarnished Taiwan's international and human rights image," Su said.

According to Su, Jet Tone Films Taiwan had applied for and received a grant of NT$4 million (US$122,324) from the GIO for the production of Miao Miao, which meant that the film would be representative of Taiwan if it was entered in international film festivals.
Miao Miao, a 2008 production, is a romantic comedy directed by Taiwanese Cheng Hsiao-tse, starring Taiwanese Ko Chia-yan, Sandrine Pinna (Chang Jung-jung) and Wing Fan.

Su said the GIO has asked Jet Tone Films Taiwan to produce evidence to prove that it has stuck to the terms of its contract with the GIO regarding participation in international festivals, such as the Melbourne International Film Festival.

Chinese films were withdrawn from the Melbourne festival July 26 after Beijing became unhappy with the Australian sponsor's decision to screen the documentary, The 10 Conditions of Love, about exiled Uighur leader Rebiya Kadeer, who is accused of plotting Urumqi riots.
The Melbourne festival is being held July 24-Aug. 9.
Taiwan has two other short films, namely Joyce Agape and The Pursuit of What Was, which are on the list of films to be shown at the festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't expected to set inspection standards for garden clogs

TEXT.P: The government is expected to set the standards for inspecting potentially harmful substances in garden clogs within one month, in response to calls by various sectors for a crack down, a Consumers Foundation official said Thursday.

Overseas reports have revealed that the plastic shoes contain a high level of plasticizer and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH), both of which can cause cancer, according to Wu Chia-cheng, secretary-general of the foundation.
While PAH is linked to lung cancer and lymphoma, plasticizer is related to thoracic cancer and breast cancer and can also disrupt hormone function, Wu said.

The Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection (BSMI) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs has set the inspection criteria for such substances in toys, but has yet to provide a similar criteria for garden clogs, Wu noted.
Besides the Consumers Foundation, the Legislative Yuan and Control Yuan have also urged the BSMI to take immediate action to address the issue, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices on local bourse edge higher

TEXT.P: Ending a three-day losing streak, Taiwan's share prices closed slightly higher Thursday, on news that Taiwan will allow Chinese visitors to make purchases in Taiwan using their China UnionPay bank cards instead of cash from Aug. 7.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, advanced 20.41 points, or 0.29 percent, to close at 6,868.65.
The local bourse opened higher Thursday at 6,886.70 before reaching the day's highest of 6,888.09.

It then surrendered earlier gains and retreated to the day's lowest of 6,775.87 after a government report showed that Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) in July registered a 38-year record contraction of 2.33 percent year-on-year, raising concern the island may take longer to recover from a recession.
But driven by the news that Chinese bank cards will be usable in Taiwan, the local bourse retained most of its early gains by the end of trading.
A total of 5.08 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$121.43 billion (US$3.70 billion).

Led by banking and financial shares which rose 1 percent, three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares advancing 0.6 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares adding 0.1 percent.
Cement stocks remained unchanged.

The other four major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 2.7 percent. Foodstuff shares fell 1.8 percent, textile issues dropped 1.3 percent, and paper and pulp issues shed 1.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,364 to 980, with 163 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$4.05 billion worth of shares.

Chu Yiu-chi, a senior executive of Grand Cathay Securities Investment Trust. Co., said that the market would probably need at least a week to bottom out on weak market turnover and rebound to above 6,950.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, increasing NT$0.072 to close at NT$32.792.
A total of US$887 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.72 and fluctuated between NT$32.645 and NT$32.794.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign ministry drafting int'l cooperation and development law

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that it is drafting a law to govern its engagement in international cooperation and development projects.

"The law will provide a legal basis and serve as a guideline for our foreign aid activities. It will also help speed up our efforts to achieve a more systematic, professional, and productive approach," Weber Shih, director-general of the MOFA's Department of Economic and Trade Affairs, said at a regular press briefing.

The draft bill will be discussed in the Executive Yuan and then forwarded to the Legislative Yuan for review, Shih said, adding that he hopes it will be given priority when the new session of the legislature opens in September.
The ruling and opposition parties have reached an initial understanding on the issue, he said.

The bill, which draws on the Paris Declaration on Aid Effectiveness of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) , is aimed at standardizing the objectives, principles, scope, and means of Taiwan's international cooperation and development affairs, bringing them in line with international standards, Shih said.
According to Shih, the bill designates MOFA as the authority responsible for handling such affairs and for coordinating related efforts by other government agencies.
In addition, it may entrust foreign aid work to Taiwan's International Cooperation and Development Fund as well as to private organizations and professionals, Shih said.

The draft bill also stipulates that the MOFA must be notified if foreign aid projects exceed a specified amount, according to Shih. For such projects, the opinions and assessments of an objective third party, such as a professional institution, will be taken into consideration, he added.
In the past, Taiwan's foreign aid programs have come under criticism in the international community as tools in its diplomatic tug-of-war with China to gain recognition by other countries.

Since President Ma Ying-jeou took office last May, the government has been considering an overhaul of its foreign aid program based on a cross-Taiwan Strait "diplomatic truce" under which Taiwan and China would tacitly agree not to vie for each other's allies.

On May 7, the MOFA released a white paper on Taiwan's foreign aid policy, outlining the country's vision for a specialized and reliable model to provide more effective and meaningful overseas assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't agencies urged to accelerate handling of petitions

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan urged government agencies Thursday to speed up handling of petitions filed by ordinary citizens of the country seeking resolution or redress on various problems.

To better protect people's rights and improve government efficiency, Liu said, all Cabinet-level agencies must improve content of statutes governing the people's petitions, improve the quality of the public offices' handling of petitions, and move forward the deadlines for screening and deciding on petitions to as early a date as possible.

Topping the list of 3,170 petitions filed in 2008 were 506 from people complaining about their right to travel overseas being restricted due to tax evasion disputes, according to a report reviewing petition handling by the administration last year.

The second largest type of petition cases concerned mainland Chinese spouses' applications to gain the right to come to Taiwan for family reunion and permanent settlement. There were 353 such cases, according to the report.
Cases involving foreign workers' employment problems in Taiwan made the third largest group of petitions, totaling 203, the report showed.
So far this year, the Executive Yuan agencies have handled 3,976 petitions, including 806 old cases.
Of the total, decisions have been made on 2,726 cases. Over half, or 57 percent of these decisions were made within three months after receiving the petitions, according to the report.
Cases that took government agencies more than three months, but less than five months to resolve amounted to 42.5 percent of the total cases decided upon, or 1,158 cases.
Decisions were handed down after five months of screening on 14 petition cases, according to the report. Part of the reason was various departments transferring the petition to another department.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese dancer joins Israels noted Batsheva Dance Company

TEXT.P: A young and promising Taiwanese dancer has been selected to join Israels world- acclaimed Batsheva Dance Company, making her the first person from Taiwan to do so, the Israel Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei (ISECO) said Thursday.

Lee Chen-wei, a former member of the famous Lan Yang Dance Group who graduated last year from Taipei National University of the ArtsSchool of Dance, will leave in a few days for Israel to join the dance company, the ISECO said in a press release.

In a recent meeting with Lee, Raphael Gamzou, Israels representative to Taiwan, wished the young dancer the best in her journey to Israel and Lee also expressed her excitement for the opportunity to perform with Batsheva, according to the press release.
This is a golden opportunity for you and Im sure you will do a great job there,Gamzou was quoted as saying.
Having grown up in Taiwans northeastern Yilan County, Lee began learning to dance at the age of 5.

She was selected by Batshevas Artistic Director, Ohad Naharin, out of many young dancers who auditioned around the world. Lee will join, at the first stage, Batshevas Young Dancers Ensemble, and will participate in the groups performance during the 2009-2010 season.
Batsheva has scheduled a performance in Taipeis National Theater Hall in 2010, as part of their Asian tour, and the ISECO said that it hopes Lee will be able to join the troupe.
The world-renowned Israeli Dancing Company Batsheva was founded in 1964 by famous dancer Martha Graham and patron of dance Baroness Batsheva (aka Bethsabee) De Rothschild, who lived in Israel.

The style of Naharin, who has served as Batshevas artistic director for the last 15 years, was acclaimed on the New York Times asdistinguished by stunningly flexible limbs and spines, deeply grounded movement, explosive bursts and a vitality that grabs a viewer by the collar.
Jiri Kilian, a renowned choreographer and considered one of the giants of modern dance, defines Batsheva under Naharin as one of the best modern dance groups in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign Ministry to set up database of foreign aid projects

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is working on establishing a database that will hold records of the government's foreign aid programs, taking for reference the method used by the non-profit Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) to compile statistics, a MOFA official said Thursday.

Shih Wen-bin, director-general of MOFA's Department of Economic and Trade Affairs, said the statistics will be similar to those of the OECD's Development Assistance Committee (DAC) , which is made up of 23 OECD members, whose numbers include the most important foreign aid donors.
Through the DAC, the OECD deals with issues involving aid, development and poverty reduction in developing countries, Shih added.

Under the OECD's operational procedures for aid programs, members of the DAC are required to carry out aid projects under the supervision of the OECD and to provide statistics and reports on aid and other resources given to developing countries, which are to be published each year, according to Shih.
The DAC serves as a forum in which donor governments come together to increase the effectiveness and the transparency of their aid, and to coordinate their development efforts, Shih went on.
The planned MOFA database will be set up similar to the one established by the OECD, but the MOFA will make some revisions based on the needs of Taiwan's various government agencies, Shih noted.

Once the database is established, the MOFA will make it available to government agencies related to foreign aid affairs and the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) , a Taiwanese fund that supports development projects, said Shih.

The ministry will also work to integrate information from various organizations regarding the implementation of foreign aid programs to keep better track of the flow of aid resources and assess aid effectiveness, Shih added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Travel Web site reaffirms no management changes

TEXT.P: A senior official of Taiwan's top online travel Web site said Thursday that the company's name and management team will remain intact despite changes in its shareholding structure.

"EzTravel will remain Taiwan's best travel service brand and its management team will not change in the wake of China's leading online travel Web site, Ctrip, upping its stake in our company to more than 50 percent," said ezTravel President Yu Chin-chang.

Ctrip, a NASDAQ-listed company, revealed a day earlier in its second-quarter financial report the increase of its stake in ezTravel to the level requiring it to compile a consolidated financial statement with the latter, indirectly acknowledging that its stake in ezTravel has exceeded 50 percent, up from the original 20 percent.
According to U.S. accounting regulations, listed enterprises are required to produce consolidated financial statements with subsidiaries in which they own more than 50 percent of the shares.
Yu described Ctrip as a multinational company rather than a wholly Chinese-owned one. With the approval of the Taiwanese government, Ctrip began to invest in ezTravel in 2006.
As ezTravel once had its shares traded on Taiwan's GreTai Securities Market between 2007 and 2008, Yu went on, Ctrip is also known to have purchased a number of ezTravel shares during that period.

"From its financial statement, Ctrip increased its stake in ezTravel to more than 50 percent in Q2 for the first time, " Yu said, adding that he did not know the company's exact shareholding ratio because ezTravel's shares are owned by divergent groups and individuals.

"The most important thing is that Ctrip has traditionally respected our management team, " Yu continued. "Our brand name and management team will remain unchanged and Ctrip is not expected to post any of its staff in our company."
Moreover, Yu said, both companies will benefit from their ever-closer ties.

Bucking a general downward trend in the global travel market in the wake of the worldwide financial crisis, Yu said, both ezTravel and Ctrip posted enviable gains in business turnover and earnings in the first half of this year.

The 10-year-old Ctrip registered a 27 percent year-on-year growth in its business revenues in Q2 and a 33 percent growth in net profits during the same period, according to the company's Q2 financial statement.
In the case of ezTravel, Yu noted, the company posted its best-ever business performance in the first half of this year since its inauguration in 2000.

Yu said his company had turned down prospective European and American investors and picked Ctrip as its partner mainly because it looks forward to the emergence of a world-famous Taiwan-based travel agency.

"It is not easy for any single Taiwanese travel agency to establish itself as a global brand. Just one of the problems is tapping into the vast Chinese market -- a tall order for a Taiwanese tour operator. Therefore, we needed to choose a good partner to realize our ambitions," Yu explained.

Because of the lingering global economic downturn and the worldwide influenza A(H1N1) outbreak, many of Taiwan's 2,000-plus travel agencies have been reeling in the recession-hit travel market. Even several of the more noted brands have reported financial crises and many smaller ones have closed down or declared bankruptcy.
Analyzing Taiwanese travel service providers' woes, Yu said small scale and delay in offering online services are the most serious disadvantages troubling local operations.
As many Taiwanese travel agencies have traditionally focused on incentive tour groups funded by business corporations, they are most vulnerable to the economic downturn, Yu pointed out.
In contrast, Yu said, ezTravel's business strategies and selling styles have been helpful to its survival during the economic hard times.

"Vacationers like to seek cheaper tour packages online and tend to opt for individual tours and domestic tours. All of these trends fit our business model. We have been strong in these fields, " he said proudly.

Last but not least is the company's joint procurement with Ctrip to cut its costs and enhance its competitive edge, Yu said, adding that ezTravel and Ctrip have been making joint purchases since 2007 and that their markets have not been confined only to Taiwan, China, Hong Kong and Macau but have expanded to Northeast and Southeast Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Lottery earns NT$1.96 billion in June

TEXT.P: Taiwan Lottery, a subsidiary of Chinatrust Financial Holding Co, made a profit of NT$1.962 billion in June, bringing its total earnings to NT$46.417 billion as of that month since it took over as the nation's exclusive Public Welfare Lottery issuer in January 2007, a company spokesman said Thursday.

Of the total profits earned in June, NT$981 million will be allocated to the local governments to finance their social welfare programs and charity activities, while NT$883 million will be injected into the national pension program and NT$98.12 million will go to the national health insurance system, according to the spokesman.
Among the nation's cities and counties, Taipei County received the largest lottery allocation of NT$154 million in June, while Taipei City came second with NT$129 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Council stages exhibition on cultural assets conservation

TEXT.P: The Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) will stage an exhibition from Aug. 10 featuring the fruits of a four-year plan aimed at conserving and renewing regional cultural assets around Taiwan, CCA officials announced Thursday.

Speaking at an explanatory session held at the council, a spokesman for the CCA's Headquarters Administration of Cultural Heritage (HACH) , said the exhibition will display the program's achievements over the past four years through a series of activities such as seminars and workshops.

During the session, the Shengping Wuchou Hand Puppet Troupe staged a show to underscore the importance of reinvigorating the nation's cultural heritage. A tea master also showcased the elegant rituals of the tea ceremony to show the audience the elegance of Taiwan's tea culture.
The first stage of the exhibition will run Aug. 10- 12 at the HACH's Tainan City office, while the second stage will be held Aug. 13-23 at its Taichung City office.

During the exhibitions, representatives and officials from grass-roots communities, cities and townships, as well as national-level officials, will exchange views and experiences on how to preserve and present historical heritage on a sustainable growth model through cooperation between the public and private sectors.

The exhibition will also allow the public to gain an understanding of the essence and content of the program designed to conserve and revive regional cultural practices that take place around their neighborhoods, HACH officials said.

The CCA came up with the program in 2006, seeking to better preserve and make the best use of natural resources, historic settlements and national monuments around the country in a sustainable approach through joint participation and management by local residents.

The program revolves around the idea of "regional environments" as its key notion and integrates concepts relating to urban development, city and community renewal and cultural recuperation, HACH officials explained.

It is also aimed at deepening the identity of Taiwan's people with their local cultures through a diverse and open platform, in part to raise public awareness of the significance of conserving local culture and in part to help boost local economies and create job opportunities, the officials said.

As of the end of April, the HACH had approved subsidies for 51 plans submitted by local city and county governments, 64 plans put forward by private communities and groups and 39 central government-level projects.
Lukang township in central Taiwan's Changhua County, as well as historic monuments in southern Tainan City, have already been approved by the HACH as state-level relics.

Meanwhile, Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan unveiled a city renewal plan that same day -- a project to transform a segment of the century-old railway adjacent to Kaohsiung Port into a "railway park."
The city seeks to make the run-down zone into a business district to help bolster the local economy, and to stage activities there to attract more tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: New health minister assumes office, vows to raise premiums

TEXT.P: Yang Chih-liang, a veteran public health educator and administrator, assumed office Thursday as minister of the Department of Health (DOH) and vowed to make the wealthy pay more for health insurance.

"If I fail to follow the law in adjusting the health insurance premiums, the watchdog Control Yuan will impeach me, but any adjustment must follow the principle that higher-paid individuals should pay more premiums while the impoverished should pay less, " Yang said at a changeover ceremony.

Yang, a former DOH vice minister, took over the DOH helm from Yeh Chin-chuan, who resigned Monday in preparation for his bid for the ruling Kuomintang's candidacy in the year-end magistrate election in the eastern county of Hualien.

Yang's pledge to adjust health insurance premiums came a day after the Control Yuan censured the DOH and the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) for failing to promptly increase health insurance premiums when the conditions were appropriate for an adjustment.
The supreme supervisory body said it will also not rule out the possibility of impeaching the incoming health minister if the DOH continues to fail to address the problem.
For years, the BNHI has been operating in the red, with its accumulated budget deficit having already exceeded NT$33.1 billion (US$1 billion).
Yang said he will ask NHIB officials next week to come up with a premium adjustment proposal and related complementary measures.

"We will prioritize premium adjustments and then later consider an overall overhaul of the health insurance system, " Yang said, adding that he will strengthen communications with the public to minimize any possible backlash over the premium adjustments.
Yang further said that ordinary people should not oppose health premium adjustments because they tend to benefit from premium hikes.

"As far as premiums are concerned, the government and employers tend to assume a larger share of the payment than the insured themselves, " he explained. "Why not pay a bit more to get better medical and health care services?"

He also outlined two other priorities on his agenda -- pushing city and county governments to repay their debts to the BNHI and increasing the procurement of vaccines for influenza A(H1N1) or swine flu.
Many local governments owe the BNHI huge sums in unpaid health insurance premiums, with the Taipei city government listed as the top debtor.
"It would be a dereliction of duty if I fail to work with the BNHI to secure repayment from local governments," Yang noted.
With the number of confirmed A(H1N1) infections rising steadily, Yang said the DOH will increase vaccine procurement as a precautionary measure to prevent any possible massive-scale outbreak.

The DOH has already ordered 5 million doses of A(H1N1) vaccine from Adimmune Corp., Taiwan's only human vaccine manufacturer. The department is seeking to purchase up to 10 million doses and may seek foreign supplies if the local company fails to meet the DOH's demands.
If necessary, Yang said, the DOH might purchase even more than 10 million doses. "But the premise must be that the vaccine lives up to the safety requirements," he added.
Describing his new job as a great honor, Yang said he will do his utmost to fulfill his mission in order not to let down his superiors or his old friend Yeh.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Neihu MRT line resumes operations after 4-hour shutdown

TEXT.P: The incident-prone newly inaugurated Muzha-Neihu line of the Taipei mass rapid transit (MRT) system resumed operations at 4: 20 p.m. Thursday after shutting down yet again at noon due to a network switch malfunction.

The breakdown halted 26 trains on the line for four-and-a-half hours, including five trains that stopped between two stations. The five unmanned trains had to be driven manually to stations to allow passengers to disembark, according to Tan Kuo- kuang, the Taipei city government's deputy secretary-general who concurrently serves as head of the administration's emergency response task force.
The city then mobilized buses to transport the passengers to their destinations.

According to Tan, a preliminary investigation found that the failure was caused by the breakdown of a network switch at Donghu Station that caused the control center to fail to follow the movements of the trains, prompting it to decide to suspend services on the whole line.
The line has suffered repeated glitches, including sudden stops and doors failing to open, since it was opened to the public July 4.
The largest breakdown occurred July 10 when the line ground to a halt completely for more than eight hours because of a power failure.

A survey conducted by the city government last month found that some 62 percent of city residents polled were dissatisfied with the new line, with the top three complaints listed as too-small carriages, frequent and sudden stoppages and poorly designed stations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier on high alert against approaching typhoon

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan made an inspection Thursday of the Central Emergency Operation Center and demanded that all personnel stay on high alert against possible damage caused by approaching Typhoon Morakot.
Liu asked all center staff to remain vigilant over the coming 24 hours, when the typhoon is forecast to affect all regions of Taiwan.
Government offices and schools islandwide will be closed Friday in preparation for the arrival of the medium-strength typhoon, which was steadily gaining strength.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange also announced that day that the market would be closed the following day and all trading postponed until Monday.

The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) also announced that a ceremony scheduled for Sunday to mark the local acceptance of bank cards issued by the China-based China UnionPay Co. will be put off until Monday.

Morakot, the worst typhoon to affect Taiwan so far this year, is likely to bring large amounts of rainfall to the whole island, particularly the northern Taipei area, providing at least temporary relief to a parched Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Polaris Taiwan Top 50 approved for offering in Hong Kong

TEXT.P: The Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) of Hong Kong granted authorization for the first time Thursday to a Taiwan exchange-traded fund (ETF) , Polaris Taiwan Top 50 Tracker Fund, for cross-listing in Hong Kong.

A spokesman for the Polaris Fund Management Platform said the ETF will be listed Aug. 19. While participating dealers are allowed to bid at HK$10 (US$1.29) per share before the listing, the listed price might vary, he added.
The cross-listing of the Polaris Taiwan Top 50 Tracker Fund will be done via a feeder fund, Polaris Taiwan Top 50 Tracker Fund (H.K.)

The Financial Supervisory Commission under the Executive Yuan in late July approved three Hong Kong ETFs for cross-listing in Taiwan, of which WISE CSI 300 China Tracker has already raised NT$7.1 billion from Taiwan's capital market via the feeder fund WISE Polaris CSI 300.
In addition to WISE CSI 300 China Tracker, Hang Seng Index ETF and Hang Seng H-Share Index ETF have also been granted approval for offering in Taiwan.

SFC Deputy Chief Executive Officer Alexa Lam said upon granting approval to Polaris that SFC welcomes more Taiwan ETFs seeking to apply for cross-listing in Hong Kong, so that Hong Kong investors can have more investment choices.

DOC.HEADLINE: New tour `passport' to be launched to promote travel around Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau is collaborating with the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) to launch a new project to promote in-depth travel around Taiwan, the country's top tourism official said Thursday.

"The Taiwan Tourbus Railway Tour Passport program will offer convenient transport services and tour packages at budget prices, aimed in particular at the individual traveler, " said Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai at a news conference to unveil the new promotion.

Taking its cues from a similar promotional program in Japan, where individual tours are very popular, Lai said the Tourism Bureau has selected 10 out of the 32 existing Taiwan Tourbus lines to be integrated with various rail tickets to make major tourist destinations accessible for tours using the program.

The selected bus lines include a one-day tour of the northeastern coastline, including the picturesque villages of Jinguashih and Jiufen, a one-day tour of Sun Moon Lake, a one-day tour of Lugang and the sprawling gardens along the Tienwei highway, as well as a one-day tour of mountain and seashore tourist spots around the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

The "passport" package tour includes bus services plus two railway tickets and a Sun Moon Lake pleasure boat ticket, as well as discount tickets for 19 theme parks and 50 hotels around the island, Lai explained.
Sales of the "passport" were scheduled to begin online at noon Friday on the Tourism Bureau's tour bus Web site at http://www.taiwantourbus.com.tw.
The first 1,000 online shoppers will get a discounted price of NT$999 apiece, Lai said, adding that the "passport" will also be available at travel agencies that use Taiwan Tourbus.
The "passport" will remain valid until the end of this year, Lai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug. 7, 2009

TEXT.P: briefing
Date and time: 2:00 p.m., Friday, August 7,
Place: Centers for Disease Control Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices on local bourse edge higher

TEXT.P: Ending a three-day losing streak, Taiwan's share prices closed slightly higher Thursday, on news that Taiwan will allow Chinese visitors to make purchases in Taiwan using their China UnionPay bank cards instead of cash from Aug. 7.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, advanced 20.41 points, or 0.29 percent, to close at 6,868.65.
The local bourse opened higher Thursday at 6,886.70 before reaching the day's highest of 6,888.09.

It then surrendered earlier gains and retreated to the day's lowest of 6,775.87 after a government report showed that Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) in July registered a 38-year record contraction of 2.33 percent year-on-year, raising concern the island may take longer to recover from a recession.
But driven by the news that Chinese bank cards will be usable in Taiwan, the local bourse retained most of its early gains by the end of trading.
A total of 5.08 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$121.43 billion (US$3.70 billion).

Led by banking and financial shares which rose 1 percent, three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares advancing 0.6 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares adding 0.1 percent.
Cement stocks remained unchanged.

The other four major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 2.7 percent. Foodstuff shares fell 1.8 percent, textile issues dropped 1.3 percent, and paper and pulp issues shed 1.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,364 to 980, with 163 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$4.05 billion worth of shares.

Chu Yiu-chi, a senior executive of Grand Cathay Securities Investment Trust. Co., said that the market would probably need at least a week to bottom out on weak market turnover and rebound to above 6,950.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, increasing NT$0.072 to close at NT$32.792.
A total of US$887 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.72 and fluctuated between NT$32.645 and NT$32.794.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign ministry drafting int'l cooperation and development law

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that it is drafting a law to govern its engagement in international cooperation and development projects.

"The law will provide a legal basis and serve as a guideline for our foreign aid activities. It will also help speed up our efforts to achieve a more systematic, professional, and productive approach," Weber Shih, director-general of the MOFA's Department of Economic and Trade Affairs, said at a regular press briefing.

The draft bill will be discussed in the Executive Yuan and then forwarded to the Legislative Yuan for review, Shih said, adding that he hopes it will be given priority when the new session of the legislature opens in September.
The ruling and opposition parties have reached an initial understanding on the issue, he said.

The bill, which draws on the Paris Declaration on Aid Effectiveness of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) , is aimed at standardizing the objectives, principles, scope, and means of Taiwan's international cooperation and development affairs, bringing them in line with international standards, Shih said.
According to Shih, the bill designates MOFA as the authority responsible for handling such affairs and for coordinating related efforts by other government agencies.
In addition, it may entrust foreign aid work to Taiwan's International Cooperation and Development Fund as well as to private organizations and professionals, Shih said.

The draft bill also stipulates that the MOFA must be notified if foreign aid projects exceed a specified amount, according to Shih. For such projects, the opinions and assessments of an objective third party, such as a professional institution, will be taken into consideration, he added.
In the past, Taiwan's foreign aid programs have come under criticism in the international community as tools in its diplomatic tug-of-war with China to gain recognition by other countries.

Since President Ma Ying-jeou took office last May, the government has been considering an overhaul of its foreign aid program based on a cross-Taiwan Strait "diplomatic truce" under which Taiwan and China would tacitly agree not to vie for each other's allies.

On May 7, the MOFA released a white paper on Taiwan's foreign aid policy, outlining the country's vision for a specialized and reliable model to provide more effective and meaningful overseas assistance.
