The planned MOFA database will be set up similar to the one established by the OECD, but the MOFA will make some revisions based on the needs of Taiwan's various government agencies, Shih noted.

Once the database is established, the MOFA will make it available to government agencies related to foreign aid affairs and the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) , a Taiwanese fund that supports development projects, said Shih.

The ministry will also work to integrate information from various organizations regarding the implementation of foreign aid programs to keep better track of the flow of aid resources and assess aid effectiveness, Shih added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Travel Web site reaffirms no management changes

TEXT.P: A senior official of Taiwan's top online travel Web site said Thursday that the company's name and management team will remain intact despite changes in its shareholding structure.

"EzTravel will remain Taiwan's best travel service brand and its management team will not change in the wake of China's leading online travel Web site, Ctrip, upping its stake in our company to more than 50 percent," said ezTravel President Yu Chin-chang.

Ctrip, a NASDAQ-listed company, revealed a day earlier in its second-quarter financial report the increase of its stake in ezTravel to the level requiring it to compile a consolidated financial statement with the latter, indirectly acknowledging that its stake in ezTravel has exceeded 50 percent, up from the original 20 percent.
According to U.S. accounting regulations, listed enterprises are required to produce consolidated financial statements with subsidiaries in which they own more than 50 percent of the shares.
Yu described Ctrip as a multinational company rather than a wholly Chinese-owned one. With the approval of the Taiwanese government, Ctrip began to invest in ezTravel in 2006.
As ezTravel once had its shares traded on Taiwan's GreTai Securities Market between 2007 and 2008, Yu went on, Ctrip is also known to have purchased a number of ezTravel shares during that period.

"From its financial statement, Ctrip increased its stake in ezTravel to more than 50 percent in Q2 for the first time, " Yu said, adding that he did not know the company's exact shareholding ratio because ezTravel's shares are owned by divergent groups and individuals.

"The most important thing is that Ctrip has traditionally respected our management team, " Yu continued. "Our brand name and management team will remain unchanged and Ctrip is not expected to post any of its staff in our company."
Moreover, Yu said, both companies will benefit from their ever-closer ties.

Bucking a general downward trend in the global travel market in the wake of the worldwide financial crisis, Yu said, both ezTravel and Ctrip posted enviable gains in business turnover and earnings in the first half of this year.

The 10-year-old Ctrip registered a 27 percent year-on-year growth in its business revenues in Q2 and a 33 percent growth in net profits during the same period, according to the company's Q2 financial statement.
In the case of ezTravel, Yu noted, the company posted its best-ever business performance in the first half of this year since its inauguration in 2000.

Yu said his company had turned down prospective European and American investors and picked Ctrip as its partner mainly because it looks forward to the emergence of a world-famous Taiwan-based travel agency.

"It is not easy for any single Taiwanese travel agency to establish itself as a global brand. Just one of the problems is tapping into the vast Chinese market -- a tall order for a Taiwanese tour operator. Therefore, we needed to choose a good partner to realize our ambitions," Yu explained.

Because of the lingering global economic downturn and the worldwide influenza A(H1N1) outbreak, many of Taiwan's 2,000-plus travel agencies have been reeling in the recession-hit travel market. Even several of the more noted brands have reported financial crises and many smaller ones have closed down or declared bankruptcy.
Analyzing Taiwanese travel service providers' woes, Yu said small scale and delay in offering online services are the most serious disadvantages troubling local operations.
As many Taiwanese travel agencies have traditionally focused on incentive tour groups funded by business corporations, they are most vulnerable to the economic downturn, Yu pointed out.
In contrast, Yu said, ezTravel's business strategies and selling styles have been helpful to its survival during the economic hard times.

"Vacationers like to seek cheaper tour packages online and tend to opt for individual tours and domestic tours. All of these trends fit our business model. We have been strong in these fields, " he said proudly.

Last but not least is the company's joint procurement with Ctrip to cut its costs and enhance its competitive edge, Yu said, adding that ezTravel and Ctrip have been making joint purchases since 2007 and that their markets have not been confined only to Taiwan, China, Hong Kong and Macau but have expanded to Northeast and Southeast Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Lottery earns NT$1.96 billion in June

TEXT.P: Taiwan Lottery, a subsidiary of Chinatrust Financial Holding Co, made a profit of NT$1.962 billion in June, bringing its total earnings to NT$46.417 billion as of that month since it took over as the nation's exclusive Public Welfare Lottery issuer in January 2007, a company spokesman said Thursday.

Of the total profits earned in June, NT$981 million will be allocated to the local governments to finance their social welfare programs and charity activities, while NT$883 million will be injected into the national pension program and NT$98.12 million will go to the national health insurance system, according to the spokesman.
Among the nation's cities and counties, Taipei County received the largest lottery allocation of NT$154 million in June, while Taipei City came second with NT$129 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Council stages exhibition on cultural assets conservation

TEXT.P: The Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) will stage an exhibition from Aug. 10 featuring the fruits of a four-year plan aimed at conserving and renewing regional cultural assets around Taiwan, CCA officials announced Thursday.

Speaking at an explanatory session held at the council, a spokesman for the CCA's Headquarters Administration of Cultural Heritage (HACH) , said the exhibition will display the program's achievements over the past four years through a series of activities such as seminars and workshops.

During the session, the Shengping Wuchou Hand Puppet Troupe staged a show to underscore the importance of reinvigorating the nation's cultural heritage. A tea master also showcased the elegant rituals of the tea ceremony to show the audience the elegance of Taiwan's tea culture.
The first stage of the exhibition will run Aug. 10- 12 at the HACH's Tainan City office, while the second stage will be held Aug. 13-23 at its Taichung City office.

During the exhibitions, representatives and officials from grass-roots communities, cities and townships, as well as national-level officials, will exchange views and experiences on how to preserve and present historical heritage on a sustainable growth model through cooperation between the public and private sectors.

The exhibition will also allow the public to gain an understanding of the essence and content of the program designed to conserve and revive regional cultural practices that take place around their neighborhoods, HACH officials said.

The CCA came up with the program in 2006, seeking to better preserve and make the best use of natural resources, historic settlements and national monuments around the country in a sustainable approach through joint participation and management by local residents.

The program revolves around the idea of "regional environments" as its key notion and integrates concepts relating to urban development, city and community renewal and cultural recuperation, HACH officials explained.

It is also aimed at deepening the identity of Taiwan's people with their local cultures through a diverse and open platform, in part to raise public awareness of the significance of conserving local culture and in part to help boost local economies and create job opportunities, the officials said.

As of the end of April, the HACH had approved subsidies for 51 plans submitted by local city and county governments, 64 plans put forward by private communities and groups and 39 central government-level projects.
Lukang township in central Taiwan's Changhua County, as well as historic monuments in southern Tainan City, have already been approved by the HACH as state-level relics.

Meanwhile, Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan unveiled a city renewal plan that same day -- a project to transform a segment of the century-old railway adjacent to Kaohsiung Port into a "railway park."
The city seeks to make the run-down zone into a business district to help bolster the local economy, and to stage activities there to attract more tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: New health minister assumes office, vows to raise premiums

TEXT.P: Yang Chih-liang, a veteran public health educator and administrator, assumed office Thursday as minister of the Department of Health (DOH) and vowed to make the wealthy pay more for health insurance.

"If I fail to follow the law in adjusting the health insurance premiums, the watchdog Control Yuan will impeach me, but any adjustment must follow the principle that higher-paid individuals should pay more premiums while the impoverished should pay less, " Yang said at a changeover ceremony.

Yang, a former DOH vice minister, took over the DOH helm from Yeh Chin-chuan, who resigned Monday in preparation for his bid for the ruling Kuomintang's candidacy in the year-end magistrate election in the eastern county of Hualien.

Yang's pledge to adjust health insurance premiums came a day after the Control Yuan censured the DOH and the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) for failing to promptly increase health insurance premiums when the conditions were appropriate for an adjustment.
The supreme supervisory body said it will also not rule out the possibility of impeaching the incoming health minister if the DOH continues to fail to address the problem.
For years, the BNHI has been operating in the red, with its accumulated budget deficit having already exceeded NT$33.1 billion (US$1 billion).
Yang said he will ask NHIB officials next week to come up with a premium adjustment proposal and related complementary measures.

"We will prioritize premium adjustments and then later consider an overall overhaul of the health insurance system, " Yang said, adding that he will strengthen communications with the public to minimize any possible backlash over the premium adjustments.
Yang further said that ordinary people should not oppose health premium adjustments because they tend to benefit from premium hikes.

"As far as premiums are concerned, the government and employers tend to assume a larger share of the payment than the insured themselves, " he explained. "Why not pay a bit more to get better medical and health care services?"

He also outlined two other priorities on his agenda -- pushing city and county governments to repay their debts to the BNHI and increasing the procurement of vaccines for influenza A(H1N1) or swine flu.
Many local governments owe the BNHI huge sums in unpaid health insurance premiums, with the Taipei city government listed as the top debtor.
"It would be a dereliction of duty if I fail to work with the BNHI to secure repayment from local governments," Yang noted.
With the number of confirmed A(H1N1) infections rising steadily, Yang said the DOH will increase vaccine procurement as a precautionary measure to prevent any possible massive-scale outbreak.

The DOH has already ordered 5 million doses of A(H1N1) vaccine from Adimmune Corp., Taiwan's only human vaccine manufacturer. The department is seeking to purchase up to 10 million doses and may seek foreign supplies if the local company fails to meet the DOH's demands.
If necessary, Yang said, the DOH might purchase even more than 10 million doses. "But the premise must be that the vaccine lives up to the safety requirements," he added.
Describing his new job as a great honor, Yang said he will do his utmost to fulfill his mission in order not to let down his superiors or his old friend Yeh.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Neihu MRT line resumes operations after 4-hour shutdown

TEXT.P: The incident-prone newly inaugurated Muzha-Neihu line of the Taipei mass rapid transit (MRT) system resumed operations at 4: 20 p.m. Thursday after shutting down yet again at noon due to a network switch malfunction.

The breakdown halted 26 trains on the line for four-and-a-half hours, including five trains that stopped between two stations. The five unmanned trains had to be driven manually to stations to allow passengers to disembark, according to Tan Kuo- kuang, the Taipei city government's deputy secretary-general who concurrently serves as head of the administration's emergency response task force.
The city then mobilized buses to transport the passengers to their destinations.

According to Tan, a preliminary investigation found that the failure was caused by the breakdown of a network switch at Donghu Station that caused the control center to fail to follow the movements of the trains, prompting it to decide to suspend services on the whole line.
The line has suffered repeated glitches, including sudden stops and doors failing to open, since it was opened to the public July 4.
The largest breakdown occurred July 10 when the line ground to a halt completely for more than eight hours because of a power failure.

A survey conducted by the city government last month found that some 62 percent of city residents polled were dissatisfied with the new line, with the top three complaints listed as too-small carriages, frequent and sudden stoppages and poorly designed stations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier on high alert against approaching typhoon

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan made an inspection Thursday of the Central Emergency Operation Center and demanded that all personnel stay on high alert against possible damage caused by approaching Typhoon Morakot.
Liu asked all center staff to remain vigilant over the coming 24 hours, when the typhoon is forecast to affect all regions of Taiwan.
Government offices and schools islandwide will be closed Friday in preparation for the arrival of the medium-strength typhoon, which was steadily gaining strength.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange also announced that day that the market would be closed the following day and all trading postponed until Monday.

The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) also announced that a ceremony scheduled for Sunday to mark the local acceptance of bank cards issued by the China-based China UnionPay Co. will be put off until Monday.

Morakot, the worst typhoon to affect Taiwan so far this year, is likely to bring large amounts of rainfall to the whole island, particularly the northern Taipei area, providing at least temporary relief to a parched Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Polaris Taiwan Top 50 approved for offering in Hong Kong

TEXT.P: The Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) of Hong Kong granted authorization for the first time Thursday to a Taiwan exchange-traded fund (ETF) , Polaris Taiwan Top 50 Tracker Fund, for cross-listing in Hong Kong.

A spokesman for the Polaris Fund Management Platform said the ETF will be listed Aug. 19. While participating dealers are allowed to bid at HK$10 (US$1.29) per share before the listing, the listed price might vary, he added.
The cross-listing of the Polaris Taiwan Top 50 Tracker Fund will be done via a feeder fund, Polaris Taiwan Top 50 Tracker Fund (H.K.)

The Financial Supervisory Commission under the Executive Yuan in late July approved three Hong Kong ETFs for cross-listing in Taiwan, of which WISE CSI 300 China Tracker has already raised NT$7.1 billion from Taiwan's capital market via the feeder fund WISE Polaris CSI 300.
In addition to WISE CSI 300 China Tracker, Hang Seng Index ETF and Hang Seng H-Share Index ETF have also been granted approval for offering in Taiwan.

SFC Deputy Chief Executive Officer Alexa Lam said upon granting approval to Polaris that SFC welcomes more Taiwan ETFs seeking to apply for cross-listing in Hong Kong, so that Hong Kong investors can have more investment choices.

DOC.HEADLINE: New tour `passport' to be launched to promote travel around Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau is collaborating with the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) to launch a new project to promote in-depth travel around Taiwan, the country's top tourism official said Thursday.

"The Taiwan Tourbus Railway Tour Passport program will offer convenient transport services and tour packages at budget prices, aimed in particular at the individual traveler, " said Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai at a news conference to unveil the new promotion.

Taking its cues from a similar promotional program in Japan, where individual tours are very popular, Lai said the Tourism Bureau has selected 10 out of the 32 existing Taiwan Tourbus lines to be integrated with various rail tickets to make major tourist destinations accessible for tours using the program.

The selected bus lines include a one-day tour of the northeastern coastline, including the picturesque villages of Jinguashih and Jiufen, a one-day tour of Sun Moon Lake, a one-day tour of Lugang and the sprawling gardens along the Tienwei highway, as well as a one-day tour of mountain and seashore tourist spots around the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

The "passport" package tour includes bus services plus two railway tickets and a Sun Moon Lake pleasure boat ticket, as well as discount tickets for 19 theme parks and 50 hotels around the island, Lai explained.
Sales of the "passport" were scheduled to begin online at noon Friday on the Tourism Bureau's tour bus Web site at http://www.taiwantourbus.com.tw.
The first 1,000 online shoppers will get a discounted price of NT$999 apiece, Lai said, adding that the "passport" will also be available at travel agencies that use Taiwan Tourbus.
The "passport" will remain valid until the end of this year, Lai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug. 7, 2009

TEXT.P: briefing
Date and time: 2:00 p.m., Friday, August 7,
Place: Centers for Disease Control Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 7, or the 17th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1858: Queen Victoria chooses Ottawa as the capital of the Dominion of Canada.
1903: Louis Leakey, British anthropologist, is born. He uncovered crucial evidence of man's early evolution, including a 1,750,000-year-old skull.
1904: Ralph Johnson Bunche, American diplomat, is born. He helped found the United Nations and won the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating the 1949 Arab- Israeli truce.
1912: Japan and Russia sign an agreement determining their spheres of influence in Manchuria and Mongolia.
1913: Samuel Cody, American aviator, becomes Britain's first air fatality when his plane crashes at Famborough.
1942: U.S. marines land on Guadalcanal in the Pacific during World War II.
1945: The Soviet Union declares war on Japan seven days before the Japanese surrender in World War II.
1948: The Yangtze River overflows its banks, forcing three million people into homelessness.
1952: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves the designation of July 1, instead of January 1, as the beginning of the fiscal year.
1957: The ROC Navy sinks four Communist Chinese warships south of Kinmen.
1957: Oliver Hardy, the husky one in the Laurel and Hardy comic-duo who made more than 100 films from 1926 until 1950, dies of a stroke at the age of 65.
1959: The worst floods in more than 60 years hit central and southern Taiwan, killing 1,075 people, injuring 852, and causing more than NT$3.4 billion in property damage.
1974: Pingtung's Mei Ho Senior Little League baseball team leaves for Gary, Indiana, to participate in the 1974 Little League World Series.
1974: Paul Hogberg, president of the International Handball Federation, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: Vice Foreign Minister H.K. Yang meets with President Alfredo Stroessner in Paraguay.
1976: Kin Aziwa, newly-appointed deputy chief of the Japanese Interchange Association, Taipei Office, arrives to assume his post.
1983: Communist Chinese air force pilot Sun Tien-chin flies his MiG-21 jetfighter to South Korea to seek political asylum. He arrived in Taipei on Aug. 24.
1987: The leaders of Nicaragua, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Costa Rica sign a 14-page peace plan in Guatemala City aiming to settle a 10-year-old conflict in the region.
1990: President George Bush orders U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia to defend against Iraq.
1992: Beijing signs an agreement with Washington promising to probe any allegations that goods produced by prison labor are being shipped to U.S. markets.
1998: Bombs explode almost at the same time outside the American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, killing more than 80 people and injuring over one thousand others.
1999: The Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew ends a five-day visit to Macedonia after a meeting with his Macedonian counterpart Ljubco Georgievski.
2000: Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng says the KMT is happy that President Chen Shui-bian has decided to hold a multiparty roundtable meeting to discuss major national issues with the heads of the opposition parties.
2001: The third cross-strait symposium about sports terms opens in Taipei, with sports representatives from Taiwan and mainland China sitting down to discuss the "unification" of various sports terms between the two sides.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a man should beware of in the three stages of his life. In youth, when the constitution of his body is not yet formed, he should beware of lust. In manhood, when his physical powers are in full vigor, he should beware of strife. In old age, when the physical powers are in decay, he should beware of greed."

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon Morakot makes landfall

TEXT.P: The edge of Typhoon Morakot made landfall in eastern and northern Taiwan early Friday, with wind and rain expected to intensify around the island, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported later that day.
At 8 a.m., the storm was centered 200 km southeast of Yilan, packing maximum sustained winds of 144 kph and moving northwest toward Taiwan at 12 kph, according to CWB data.

The bureau predicted that the downpour to be brought about by the storm would reach the level of "extremely heavy" or "torrential" rain, with "extremely torrential" rain likely to occur in mountainous areas.

Extremely heavy rain refers to 24-hour accumulated rainfall exceeding 130 mm, torrential rain is defined as 24-hour rainfall exceeding 200 mm, and extremely torrential rain means rainfall exceeding 350 mm in 24 hours, according to the CWB.

From Thursday until 8 a.m. Friday, accumulated rainfall had reached up to 505 mm in Miaoli County, 384 mm in Chiayi County, 300 mm in Yunlin County, 288 mm in Pingtung County, 285 mm in Kaohsiung County, 261 mm in Taoyuan County, 246 mm in Yilan County, 240 mm in Taipei County, 238 mm in Taipei City, 215 mm in Tainan County, 106 mm in Taichung County, 205 mm in Nantou County, and 188 mm in Taichung City, the CWB said.
The bureau reminded the public to properly fasten any outdoor hanging objects, signboards and scaffolding. They should also avoid going to the mountains or the seaside, the bureau said.

In preparation for the storm, local shippers on the outlying Matsu island group announced that all inter-island ferry services and services between Matsu and the Chinese city of Fuzhou would be suspended Friday and Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Next mayoral, county chief terms to be extended to five years

TEXT.P: The terms of mayors and county chiefs to be elected at the end of this year will be extended by a year to five years, according to a consensus reached Thursday at a Ministry of the Interior (MOI) meeting.
The MOI convened the inter-division meeting to screen an amendment to the Law on Local Government Systems in advance of the next elections of local public office holders set for the end of this year.

It was decided at the meeting that the next mayoral and county chief terms will be extended to five years so that the next mayoral and county chief elections can be held in tandem with the election of special municipality chiefs in 2014.
"The term extension is aimed at simplifying election proceedings and saving money," said an MOI official.

An MOI ad hoc panel approved in June the upgrading of Taipei County and the merger of Taichung City and Taichung County, Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County, and Tainan City and Tainan County into special municipalities.

If the MOI amendment draft on the overhauled local elections clears the legislative floor, the next mayoral and county chief elections, as well as the elections of chiefs of five special municipalities -- Taipei, New Taipei, Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung cities -- will be held in 2014 simultaneously, the official said.

Meanwhile, it was also decided at the meeting that district administrative consultant committees will be established in the new special municipalities to allow local elected representatives -- who are poised to lose their jobs after the upgrade and mergers -- access to public office work.
Members of the new district administrative consultant committees will not be paid, the meeting resolved.

DOC.HEADLINE: Disabled painter to receive family values award on Father's Day

TEXT.P: Locally renowned artist Yang En-dian, who paints with her mouth and feet, and two other people will receive a special Family Values Award on Father's Day Aug. 8 to recognize their strong family values, the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter- day Saints -- better-known as the Mormons -- said in a press release Friday.
An award presentation ceremony and press conference will be held at the Mormon Church Taiwan Headquarters on Father's Day, according to the press release.

This is the sixth consecutive year in which the church has recognized outstanding Taiwanese citizens for their contributions to strengthening families throughout Taiwan as they face the challenges of life.
Yang was born with no arms, a deformed right leg and spine. She was abandoned by her parents and brought to an orphanage in Kaohsiung in March 1974.
Believing that the baby was "sent by the Lord, " Rev. Yang Hsu, who founded the orphanage, named the infant "En-dian," meaning "grace and benevolence from God."

Yang developed a legendary friendship with the late President Chiang Ching-kuo, who visited the orphanage six times despite its remote location, and she became a celebrity after a picture of her and Chiang was used on a postage stamp.
Growing up to earn her own living by selling her paintings, Yang was one of the winners of the 2007 Republic of China's Ten Outstanding Young Persons and is now married with a daughter of her own.

"Yang used her own experience and devoted herself to helping parents with physically challenged children, teaching them to develop the strength of mind to assist their children, " according to the church.

Huang Suei-ping, founder of the Taiwan Spinocerebellar Ataxia Association, has also been named as one of the recipients of the award for expanding her love for her sick siblings to others with similar problems.

Huang put great efforts in raising funds to help the patients and increase awareness of the progressive degenerative genetic disease, which is characterized by lack of coordination of gait and poor coordination of hands, speech and eye movements.

Huang Chih-ming, the chief advisor of Prudential Financial Inc. Taiwan, has also been chosen to receive the award for his contributions to promoting family values. Huang is working on restoring his genealogical chart to preserve his family history, something the Mormons value greatly.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan Financial Holdings to put stocks up for public offering

TEXT.P: The state-owned Taiwan Financial Holdings (TFH) Co. is expected to complete all the required procedures for public offering by the end of this year, paving the way for its listing in late 2010 at the earliest, TFH Chairwoman Susan Chang said Friday.
Chang said the company is awaiting approval from the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC), as its application for public offering has already cleared the Ministry of Finance.
Once FSC approval is obtained, the company will still need to receive guidance from brokerage firms for one year before being allowed to list its stock on the Taiwan Stock Exchange, Chang said.
The Legislative Yuan passed the TFH Company Organic Law in November 2008 to authorize the company's establishment.
Government capital in the company cannot register below 90 percent, and no more than two foreigners or dual citizens are allowed on the board, which comprises 13 to 15 members, according to the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to consider including Chinese yuan in Forex reserves
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 6 (CNA) 08/07/09 13:57:56 (By Jaw-pyng Hwang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said in an interview with Dow Jones Newswires Thursday that Taiwan can consider including the Chinese yuan in its foreign exchange (Forex) reserves, as cross-Taiwan Strait ties are expanding at an unprecedented pace.

As trade and investment ties between Taiwan and China are set to grow further in the coming years, Taiwan can investigate the feasibility of including the yuan in its Forex reserves, Liu said during the interview, which was conducted in Taipei.
"This can be considered, although we do not have a timeframe at the moment, " he said.
Taiwan's Forex reserves, which stood at US$321.09 billion at the end of July, are the world's fourth-largest.
Taipei and China expect to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement -- a prelude to a cross-strait free-trade agreement -- "as soon as possible," Liu said.
"Next year, that's the hope, as we do feel the urgency and pressure," he went on.
China will become part of a Southeast Asian free-trade bloc in 2010, which will pose greater challenges to Taiwan's exporters selling goods in China, he continued.
Liu also said the Ministry of Finance is expected to announce a midterm fiscal- stabilization program in about a month, aimed at keeping the budget deficit in check.

"From next year, we plan to reduce our regular budget each year," he said, adding that the Cabinet has forecast that its 2010 central government spending will fall 3.8 percent to NT$1.74 trillion (US$53.21 billion) , while income is expected to decline 7.3 percent to NT$1.55 trillion. "That would mean a budget deficit of NT$189.1 billion, " he noted.
The government has estimated a budget shortfall of NT$124.78 billion for this year, he said.
Liu also said the government will push for more nuclear power once construction of the country's fourth nuclear power plant is completed, part of a move toward low-carbon dioxide energy resources.

Although it has a high population density, Taiwan might not be suited to renewable energy projects on a large scale because of its geographic limitations, but it can become a major supplier of equipment for the solar and wind power industries, he went on.
He said Taiwan aims to complete by the end of 2010 its much-delayed fourth nuclear power plant at Lungmen in Taipei County and plans to replace or augment the three existing nuclear plants.

The Lungmen power plant project, at least five years behind schedule, has been plagued by construction delays, soaring raw material costs, and at one point a decision by the previous administration to halt construction because of its "nuclear-free homeland" policy.
"The previous administration had a no-nuclear policy, " said Liu. "But nuclear power has advantages of price and efficiency. We can't really say no to nuclear power."
The move toward more nuclear power and renewable energy is part of Taiwan's plan to lower emissions of greenhouse gases to 2008 levels at some point between 2016 and 2020, and to 2000 levels by 2025.
Addressing the issue of the possibility of building a fifth nuclear power plant, Liu said that "the biggest problem is finding a site, but we can add more units to the existing ones."

Responding to the premier's remarks about a mid-term fiscal stabilization program, Vice Finance Minister Chang Sheng-ho confirmed in Taipei that the program is in the pipeline and is aimed at accelerating a reduction of expenditure and broadening sources of income.

DOC.HEADLINE: New health minister proposes raising insurance premium rate

TEXT.P: New Department of Health Minister Yang Chih-liang has advocated raising health insurance premium rates to 5.13 percent, a change he said was necessary to close the persistent shortfall in the program's finances.
Taiwan's National Health Insurance system, created in 1998, has only raised the premium rate once in its history, from 4.25 percent to 4.55 percent in 2002.

That small increase was considered a stopgap measure at the time, but kept the system's finances roughly in balance through 2006. Political wrangling has prevented a further increase since large deficits re-emerged in 2007.
Speaking hours before assuming the top health post Thursday, Yang said adjusting Taiwan's premium rate will be one of his highest priorities.
He proposed increasing the rate from 4.55 percent to 5.13 percent but stressed that under the scheme, higher-income individuals would pay higher premiums while the poor would pay less.

At present, anybody earning over NT$126,301 per month has their premium calculated using an income basis of NT$131,700, but Yang said the ceiling would be raised in the new plan. At the same time, low-income individuals near the poverty line would have their premiums reduced by up to 50 percent.
"The current problems exist because rich people pay too little while poor people are overburdened, " said Yang, who took over the post from Yeh Ching-chuan.

If the premium rate is raised to 5.13 percent, office workers with a monthly salary of NT$40,000 (US$1,223) would pay an extra NT$70 per month in premiums, while their employers would contribute an additional NT$140 per month on their behalf.

On Wednesday, the Control Yuan censured the DOH and its Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) for their failure to promptly increase health insurance premium rates when the conditions were appropriate for such an adjustment.

The body, responsible for overseeing the integrity of government agencies and workers, said it would not rule out the possibility of impeaching the incoming health minister if the DOH fails to address its deficit, which has ballooned to NT$33.1 billion.
Responding to the Control Yuan's reprimand, Yang said he will ask the health insurance bureau come up with a premium adjustment proposal and complementary measures next week.
"We will prioritize premium adjustments and then consider an overhaul of the health insurance system at a later stage, " Yang said.

A spokesman for a private alliance of national health insurance monitoring groups questioned Yang's strategy Friday, arguing that premiums calculated based on individuals' income would not be effective in getting the wealthy to pay higher premiums.

Teng Hsi-hua said many wealthy people in Taiwan are not salaried workers but rather accumulate income through stock market or real estate transactions or rental income on their properties, which are not included in the income basis on which premiums are figured.
"Even if the income ceiling to calculate premiums is raised to NT200,000 per month, it will still not sufficiently reflect the assets of the wealthy," Teng said.
Teng suggested that the DOH directly promote a second-generation health insurance premium scheme, which would calculate premiums based on "overall household income" rather than "individual salaries."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan sponsors land mine survivors assistance program in Vietnam
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 7 (CNA) 08/07/09 16:00:35 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has officially provided assistance to the U.S.-based nongovernmental Humpty Dumpty Institute (HDI) in support of a program aimed at promoting land mine removal and assisting land mine and unexploded ordnance survivors in Vietnam.
A memorandum of understanding on cooperation was signed in New York Thursday by Kenneth Liao, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, and HDI President Ralph Cwerman.
Liao later handed a US$200,000 check to Cwerman on behalf of his government.

The amount is intended to support the HDI's ongoing efforts to remove land mines in Vietnam and to expand mushroom farming there to generate jobs and income for those who have been left disabled by land mines or unexploded ordnance.
Over the next two years, Taiwan will also send mushroom farming experts to Vietnam to take part in the program.

Building on a small mushroom growing project launched by the institute in Vietnam's Quang Tri province in 2000, the program is designed to take mushroom farming in the province to the next level by introducing modern production technology and developing a strong partnership between Quang Tri mushroom farmers and the U.S. mushroom industry.
Quang Tri is one of the Vietnamese provinces that have been most severely affected by land mines and unexploded ordnance.
Vietnam now reports 2,000 casualties from land mines and unexploded ordnance annually, rivaling Cambodia and Angola as countries with the world's highest proportion of amputees, according to the HDI.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Friday:
Liberty Times:
Getting local governments to pay premiums owed

New health minister Yang Chih-liang vowed to improve the financial health of the National Health Insurance program by raising the premium rate and collecting overdue premiums owed by local governments.
We have to applaud the new minister for daring to go after the overdue payments, totaling NT$60.3 billion, of which Taipei City accounts for NT$34.7 billion.
Taipei City's delinquent payments arose from the refusal of its former mayor, President Ma Ying-jeou, to pay the premium to boycott the then-Democratic Progressive Party administration.
Since Ma was elected president, it is time for the city to stop the boycott and pay what it owes.
But we urge Yang to reconsider raising premiums, which will force many people who can hardly find a job amid the financial crisis to drop out of the health insurance program.
There are other ways--- such closing wasteful loopholes -- to improve the financial health of the system.
Apple Daily:
Probe three sham projects in Taipei City.
Taipei City currently has three poorly executed public projects -- the Maokong Gondola, the MRT Neihu Line, and the Xinsheng Elevated Expressway.
All of them were caused not by corrupt officials but by incompetent officials, and we have to point out that corrupt officials who are able to get things done are better than incompetent officials.
We urge law enforcement authorities to probe the projects and end the flawed public tendering systems that led to the glitches that are plaguing these public works initiatives.
China Times:
Fat cats are raising their ugly heads again
As the global financial tsunami subsides, fat cats are again raising their heads around the world, with some high-profile multinational companies paying huge bonuses to their senior executives.

These fat cats, many of whom received lucrative compensation despite contributing to their companies' failures, caused an uproar around the world and were branded as shameless by U.S. President Barack Obama.
To the anger of the general public, many took their bonuses from government subsidies allocated to keep their cash-strapped companies afloat.

Taiwan has its own share of greedy fat cats, who skim off the lion's share of their companies' profits as bonuses. To the chagrin of investors, the Financial Supervisory Commission can do nothing but require that their names and the size of their bonuses be made public.
Investors should shun these companies.
United Daily News:
Is DPP ready for ex-president's sentence?
The court is set to hand down a ruling in the corruption case involving ex- President Chen Shui-bian and his family members.

The Democratic Progressive Party will then face a number of dilemmas, such as whether it should expel Chen or continue to support him and boycott his trials, and whether it should separate Chen and its cause for Taiwan independence.
All these questions are connected with each other.
DPP Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu's success in holding the World Games has proven that it is possible for DPP politicians to part with Chen Shui-bian and go their separate ways.
The DPP will not be able to free itself from the thorn in its side unless it expels Chen and condemns him.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP slams panel's planned hearing on ECFA referendum

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) voiced objections Friday to a plan by a Cabinet panel to hold a debate on whether a proposed Taiwan-China trade pact should be put to a nationwide referendum.

DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said the referendum screening panel under the Executive Yuan, in compliance with the Referendum Law, is authorized to determine whether a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China can be put to a popular vote, but the panel is not empowered to host a debate on the issue.

The 21-member screening panel announced a day earlier that it will sponsor a public hearing Aug. 18 to discuss the DPP's initiative asking voters to decide if a referendum should be held on the proposed ECFA.

The panel decided to invite officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , including Minister Yiin Chii-ming, DPP representatives, such as DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, and experts to debate the pros and cons of such a trade pact in a public hearing.
The panel also said it will decide Aug. 27 on whether the DPP's referendum drive meets the criteria laid out in the Referendum Law.
Cheng accused the referendum screening panel of "expanding its power" to examine the ECFA under the pretext of a public hearing.

He stressed that the Referendum Law only bars issues related to budgets, taxation, investment, salaries and government personnel from being decided in a referendum, but the potential framework agreement, which could affect Taiwan's job market and people's livelihoods, does not fall in those categories and can be put to a popular vote.

The pro-independence DPP filed an application with the Central Election Commission (CEC) July 20 to hold a referendum that would have voters decide if the government should hold a popular vote on a proposed ECFA with China.

The DPP's petition must be approved by the CEC screening panel before it can progress to the next stage, where it will need to obtain the signatures of at least 850,000 eligible voters for the referendum to be held.
The DPP has repeatedly voiced strong opposition to an ECFA between Taiwan and China over fears that it would compromise Taiwan's sovereignty and job market.

According to the MOEA, Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) could fall by an estimated 0.176 percent if the two sides fail to sign an ECFA by Jan. 1. 2010, when the "ASEAN plus one" trade bloc -- comprised of China and ASEAN member states -- is established.

The lack of an ECFA would also negatively affect Taiwan's annual exports, imports and trade surplus, driving them down by 0.421 percent, 0.601 percent and US$180 million, respectively, the MOEA estimated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Colleges recruited to offer services in the countryside

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level National Youth Commission (NYC) has launched a program that it hopes will inject some youthful vitality into Taiwan's aging rural townships with the help of local colleges, universities, and nonprofit organizations.

The commission will provide subsidies to academic institutions and civic groups to set up service centers manned by young volunteers in the townships and provide services needed by local communities, the commission said in a statement.

The NYC said it has selected 12 of 368 townships around Taiwan as targets for the program, including Fusing in Taoyuan County, Dongyin in Lienchiang County, Dali in Taichung County, Sihu in Changhua County and Jhushan in Nantou County.
The others are Daliao in Kaohsiung County, Pingtung City in Pingtung County, Huxi in Penghu County, Toucheng in Yilan County, Sioulin in Hualien County, and Luye in Taitung County.

Colleges, universities and nonprofit civic groups are all welcome to apply for the up to NT$800,000 (US$24,400) in subsidies that will go to paying for people to plan the center, travel expenses, administrative costs, volunteer training and publicity.
The centers will run for a period of 16 months, between September 2009 and December 2010.

The planners' tasks will include initiating volunteer service projects based on local need, developing links with local facilities manned by young volunteers, and outlining volunteer training programs.
NYC Minister Wang Yu-ting said she hopes the installation of the service centers will attract young blood to revitalize their hometowns and boost local development.
The NYC was established in 1966 to be responsible for "organizing and handling the guidance of youths in the country."

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign ministry looks into use of 'Taiwan (China)' on WHO Web site

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday that it is looking into the World Health Organization's use of the termTaiwan (China)to refer to the country.

Taiwan was referred to asTaiwan (China) in an article titled "Taiwan (China) urges event planners to take precautions against Pandemic (H1N1) 2009, which was posted online Aug. 4 by the WHO's Western Pacific Regional Office located in Manila, Philippines.

"The Foreign Ministrys representative in the Philippines is now looking into the matter and will lodge a protest and request a correction from the world health body, but the process could take some time,said MOFA spokesman Henry Chen.
We hope that Taiwan can be referred to as Chinese Taipei in WHO agencies and meetings. This is the goal that we are working toward, " he said.

Taiwan, which lost its Republic of China seat at the United Nations in 1971, has long been referred to as "Taiwan, China" or other designations that subjugate Taiwan to China by the U.N. and affiliated agencies, such as the WHO.
It was hoped that would change in the WHO after Taiwan was admitted as an observer to the World Health Assembly in May this year under the name "Chinese Taipei."
The WHO also used that designation in its early situation updates on the number of influenza A (H1N1) cases reported around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central Bank cool to idea of holding Chinese yuan in forex reserves

TEXT.P: Taiwan's central bank seemed to have little interest Friday in a suggestion by the country's premier that it should consider including Chinese yuan in its foreign exchange reserve portfolio.

In a statement released Friday, The Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan) (CBC) said that no central bank in the world has holdings of Chinese yuan among its foreign exchange reserves because the yuan is not a freely convertible currency, a strong hint that it would not want to hold the yuan anytime soon.

Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said in an interview with Dow Jones Newswires published Thursday that "Taiwan can consider including the Chinese yuan in its forex reserves, as cross-Taiwan Strait ties are expanding at an unprecedented pace."

As trade and investment ties between Taiwan and China are set to grow further in the coming years, Taiwan can investigate the feasibility of including the yuan in its forex reserves, Liu also said during the interview, which was conducted in Taipei.
"This can be considered, although we do not have a timeframe at the moment, " he said.
Taiwan's Forex reserves, which stood at US$321.09 billion at the end of July, are the world's fourth-largest, behind only those of China, Japan and Russia, in that order.

Also in the statement, the CBC dismissed a local print media report published Friday which claimed that roughly 60 percent of the CBC's foreign exchange reserve holdings are U.S. dollars and 35 percent are euros.
"The report was sheer fabrication and way off base, " the CBC said.
The CBC has never disclosed its asset allocation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police tracking down typhoon holiday prankster

TEXT.P: Police is tracking down the owner of a fake Central Personnel Administration (CPA) Web site that has posted unauthorized announcements on school and office closures for Typhoon Morakot, Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) officials said Friday.
At around 1 p.m. Thursday, the Web site at http: //tw886.tw announced that all schools and government offices in northern and central Taiwan would be closed Friday because of the storm.

As the site appeared similar to the CPA's official site, it convinced many Internet users that the announcement was truly made by the CPA. It was only after checking with their local governments that users realized they were fooled.
The CIB launched an investigation into the case after receiving a report from the CPA that evening and discovered that the Web site fell within the domain of Chunghwa Telecom.
The police are currently cooperating with the telecom company to check the site's IP address. It is likely to arrest the owner if the address is confirmed to be local, CIB officials said.
While the CPA has requested that the owner be charged with forgery, the officials said the suspect may not get convicted if the act was intended simply as a prank.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan team competing in Pony League World Series
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, D.C., Aug. 6 (CNA) 08/07/09 18:32:28 (By Zep Hu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A baseball team from Taitung County has arrived in the United States to compete in the 2009 Pony League Baseball World Series slated for Aug. 7-15.

The team from the eastern county, made up of 13- and 14-year-olds from three junior high schools, will play its first game at the World Series Aug. 8 U.S. time against the winner of the matchup between Levittown, Puerto Rico, and Saltillo, Mexico.
The Taiwanese team will need to win at least five games in the double- elimination tournament if it hopes to capture the World Series title.
Ten teams, including one each from Taiwan, Mexico and Puerto Rico and seven from five U.S. states, are competing at the tournament, being held at the Lew Hays Pony Field in Washington, Pennsylvania.

Unlike the Little League baseball organization, Pony League has a two-year age bracket system and uses different sized diamonds for different age groups. The Pony League World Series is for players in the 13-14 age bracket.

DOC.HEADLINE: Heavy rains brought by Morakot raise local reservoir levels

TEXT.P: Typhoon Morakot battered Taiwan Friday and caused isolated damage, but its heavy rains have also replenished the country's reservoirs, easing mounting fears of a looming drought and water rationing, the Water Resources Agency (WRA) reported Friday.

The center of the storm was located 90 kilometers off the coast of Hualian County as of 5 p.m. Friday, moving in a north-northwest direction at 11km/hr. The storm was packing maximum sustained winds of 144kph.

Taiwan's reservoirs have accumulated an additional 167 million cubic meters of water because of the storm, which the water agency said will bring an end to night time water rationing in Keelung City, Taoyuan County, Tainan City and Tainan County.

In the north, the storm had contributed 20 million cubic meters of water to Feitsui Reservoir, raising its level to 150.95 meters as of Friday noon, less than 20 meters short of its full supply level. The reservoir will consider releasing water if the water level goes above 163 meters.
Shihmen Reservoir has added approximately 80 million cubic meters of rainwater, raising its level to 230.8 meters as of 10 a.m. Friday. The reservoir's maximum level is 245 meters.
In the south, Tsengwen Reservoir had collected about 40 million cubic meters of water, while Wushantou and Paoshan reservoirs also received large volumes of rainfall.
The level of stored water at Nanhua Reservoir had risen to 175.34 meters by 1p.m. Friday, close to its full supply level of 180 meters.

Because Typhoon Morakot was slowing down, meteorologists forecast that Taiwan would be in for an extended period of heavy rain that could force reservoirs to actually release excess water in the coming hours.

From Thursday until Friday noon, accumulated rainfall had reached the level of "torrential" rain -- defined as 200mm of rainfall over a 24-hour period -- in mountain areas in Kaohsiung, Pingtung, Hsinchu, Miaoli and Yilan counties, the Central Weather Bureau said.
Meanwhile, accumulated rainfall had exceeded 400 mm in Sandimen Township in Pingtung County, and Fanlu in Chiayi County.
More than 73,469 households around the country have experienced power outages as a result of the typhoon, including 10,621 households in Taichung.
The typhoon also forced the evacuation of more than 1,000 people in mountainous areas in Hsinchu and Taoyuan County Friday as a safety precaution.
Financial markets, schools and banks around the country were also closed on Friday in anticipation of the storm, and around 20 flights to outlying islands were canceled Friday.
Meanwhile, some ferry operators announced that service from Taiwan to Makung, Matsu, Liouciou and Green Island would be suspended Friday and Saturday.

They warned of the potential for extensive damage caused by strong winds and torrential rains in northern Taiwan both Friday and Saturday and cautioned residents in mountainous areas to be aware of the possibility of landslides.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. help with Taiwan's arms procurement helps cross-strait ties

TEXT.P: The United States' continuing assistance in helping Taiwan acquire necessary defensive weapons is important to the efficient promotion and stable development of cross-Taiwan Strait ties, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) chairwoman said Friday.

The comment by Lai Shin-yuan, made at a meeting with visiting U.S. Congressman and co-chair of the Congressional Taiwan Caucus Phil Gingrey (R-GA) at the MAC Thursday, was released in a MAC statement issued Friday.
According to the statement, Lai described the gradual improvement in the relations between Taiwan and China, who were once stubborn rivals, as a rare historic moment.
Taiwan and China should continue to conduct talks, dialogue and negotiations to build mutual trust and to lay a stepping stone for future eternal peace in the strait, she said.
Lai also asserted that increasing interaction between peoples from across the strait will strengthen the Taiwan identity of the Taiwanese people.

Lai reiterated that the two sides should respect the fact that they co-exist in international society and therefore should pursue international cooperation by treating each other with equality and dignity.

Gingrey encouraged Taiwan to continue its bid to join influential international organizations, including the United Nations, and Lai responded that it was the right and expectation of Taiwan's people to participate in the international community without having their dignity harmed.
She hoped that China, which has suppressed Taiwan's international space, could understand how Taiwanese people feel on the matter.

Gingrey arrived in Taiwan Aug. 5 for a four-day visit. He is described by President Ma Ying-jeou as one of Taiwan's most faithful friends in the U.S. Congress. He endorsed a House of Representatives resolution that marked the 30th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act.
The resolution reiterates principles in the Taiwan Relations Act, including caring for Taiwan's security and providing Taiwan defensive weapons.

DOC.HEADLINE: Swine flu school closure criteria to be announced Aug. 15

TEXT.P: Criteria to close schools in Taiwan due to an outbreak of swine flu, or influenza A (H1N1) , will be announced Aug. 15, Taiwan's top health official said Friday.

New Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yang Chih-liang said the DOH and the Ministry of Education have reached a consensus on the school closure issue and have decided to make a joint announcement Aug. 15, more than two weeks before schools open Sept. 1.
The DOH said last week that it may propose a nationwide school closure if the current influenza A (H1N1) outbreak gets more serious after local schools reopen following the summer break.
Speaking at his first meeting on epidemic control since assuming his post Thursday, Yang said Taiwan will adopt a school closure measure that is stricter than that imposed in the United States.

"Our criteria will be more restrictive than those used in the United States, where health authorities suggest that affected students stay home but schools need not close in the event of an A (H1N1) outbreak," Yang said.
In principle, the DOH would ask affected students to stay home if they were to come down with the virus, said Lin Ting, deputy director-general of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control (CDC).
According to CDC Director-General Kuo Hsu-sung, the new swine flu virus is transmitted and mutates very rapidly. There have been several thousands of cases in Taiwan, but most were mild, he said.

"More than 85 percent of local flu patients over the past week were infected with the swine flu virus, " Kuo said, adding that the ratio may even surpass 95 percent in the future as has been seen in the United States, Britain, Japan and Australia.
Taking cues from those countries' experiences, Kuo said, the CDC has drawn up plans to cope with a possible further spread of the disease, particularly after local schools reopen in the fall.
"Campus flu infections are most likely to trigger community cluster infections, so we may advise the Education Ministry to close all schools to contain a further spread of the virus," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: July exports hit nine-month high

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports in July were valued at US$17.27 billion, the highest level recorded over the past nine months, according to statistics released Friday by the Ministry of Finance (MOF).
Although the amount was 24.4 percent lower than the same month last year, the decrease was the mildest over the past eight months, the MOF said.
Imports in July totaled US$15.24 billion, a decline of 34.1 percent year-on- year, the ministry said.
A trade surplus of US$2.03 billion was recorded for the month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's universities see record high vacancies

TEXT.P: Taiwan's colleges and universities will suffer their lowest enrollment and highest vacancies when the new school semester begins in September, according to enrollment statistics released Friday.

A total of 76,434 students landed a spot in a Taiwanese university, resulting in a record high of 6,802 vacancies on the campuses and another record high college admission rate of 97.14 percent, according to the Joint Board of the College Recruitment Commission.
That was up from 4,788 vacancies and a college admission rate of 97.10 percent for last school year, commission statistics showed.
Admission rates and vacancies at higher learning institutions have been steadily rising in Taiwan in recent years.
Taiwan's falling birth rate and the rapid increase in the number of colleges and universities opened in Taiwan over the past 15 years are the main reasons behind this trend.

In 1986, there were only 28 four-year colleges and universities across Taiwan, but the number surged to 147 in 2008 -- the result of a government policy to reduce pressure and make it easier for high school students trying to get into a university.
The Ministry of Education (MOE) on Friday urged colleges with low enrollment to nonetheless fully protect enrolled students' and teaching staff's interests despite their low enrollments.

Ho Cho-fei, director of the MOE's Department of Higher Education, asked low- enrollment colleges and universities to remain committed to giving their students sufficient training, no matter how small their student population is.
To cope with this problem, Ho said the ministry will work out a mechanism to require schools with low enrollment to transform themselves or withdraw from the market.
A total of 18 college and university departments in Taiwan failed to recruit any students for the coming semester, according to the commission's figures.

Hsing Kuo University of Management in Tainan City had the highest number of 1,465 vacancies, as five of its 13 departments were unable to attract a single applicant. Only 14 would-be freshmen were recruited by Hsing Kuo despite a total of 1,479 spaces available.
Four departments in Leader University in Tainan City also posted zero- enrollment, with the university recruiting only 49 potential freshmen.
One department each of Mingdao University in central Changhua County and NanHua University in southern Chiayi County also failed to attract a single student.

Meanwhile, an applicant aged 63 was the oldest freshman in Taiwan accepted by a university this year. He has been admitted to the English Literature Department at Aletheia University. The youngest college applicant is almost 16 years old. He was recruited by the Department of Plant Pathology and Microbiology of National Taiwan University.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait steel companies sign cooperative deal

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung-based China Steel Corp. (CSC) has signed an agreement with China's Sinosteel Corp. to purchase raw materials and equipment from China's second- biggest iron ore trader while selling it steel products from Taiwan.

CSC Executive Vice President L. M. Chung signed the cooperation agreement with his Sinosteel counterpart Li Yi at CSC headquarters Friday. If the deal works out, it can be renewed on a yearly basis in the future.
The two companies signed a strategic cooperation agreement in 2006 to boost mutual exchanges and cooperation, but Friday's deal is the first time they have pledged to buy each other's products.
The deal was struck as international steel prices are surging, forcing CSC to increase the domestic prices of its steel products by an average of 9.4 percent, beginning in September.

The higher prices are expected to improve CSC's results in the third and fourth quarters and more than offset the NT$15 billion (US$457.69 million) loss it sustained in the first half of the year, according to analysts.

Sinosteel is involved in developing and processing metallurgical mineral resources, and trading and logistics related to metallurgical raw materials and products. It owns more than 80 subsidiaries, over 20 of which are based outside China.
CSC is the largest integrated steel maker in Taiwan. In 2006, it was listed by the International Iron and Steel Institute (IISI) as the world's 25th largest steel producer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon Morakot sends vegetable prices soaring

TEXT.P: Prices of vegetables have risen by an average 20 percent to 30 percent since Wednesday in anticipation that supplies would fall with the arrival of Typhoon Morakot, market sources said Friday.

The average wholesale price of vegetables rose from NT$16.4 per kilo on Aug. 5 to NT$19.8 per kilo a day later at the Siluo fruit and vegetables market in central Taiwan, according to figures compiled by the Council of Agriculture. No data was yet available for Friday.
At the Taipei wholesale fruit and vegetable market, the average price of vegetables soared to NT$27.9 per kilo Friday, up 32.2 percent from the NT$21.1 per kilo average Wednesday.
The COA said the price hikes were almost entirely driven by expectations that the approaching storm would disrupt harvests, as supplies remained stable.

But the council indicated that it will distribute some 7,770 metric tons of frozen vegetables, including 5,683 tons of root vegetables, 2,014 tons of leafy vegetables, and 73 tons of other fruits and vegetables, around the country to meet possible shortages and help stabilize prices.

Wholesale prices of most vegetables rose dramatically Friday, with the average price of 10 out of 76 types of high grade vegetables exceeding NT$100 per kilo, according to Taipei Agricultural Products Transportation Co.

The price of asparagus was the highest at NT$200 per kilo, followed by coriander at NT$170, string beans at NT$125, sweet peppers at NT$123, green bamboo shoots at NT$115, garlic at NT$115, yellow chives at NT$105, peeled water bamboos at NT$100, chilies at NT$100 and baby corn at NT$100, the comapany said.

Three hypermarts took advantage of the high prices at traditional markets by offering discounts on vegetables to lure consumers, most of whom were at home as financial markets, schools and most offices around the country were closed because of the storm.
Geant, RT-Mart and Carrefour all launched a vegetable sales campaign by respectively offering 150,000, 5,000, and 60,000 bundles of vegetables for NT$3-NT$10 each, creating strong buying interest.

The COA reported that as of 1 p.m. Friday, Morakot has led to losses of NT$5.02 million (US$153,000) in crops in Kaohsiung County, Pingtung County and Chiayi City, with portions of 144 hectares of farmland affected.
Bananas and cauliflower were the most affected crops, according to the COA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Macau casino king's son visits Kinmen

TEXT.P: The son of Stanley Ho, Macau's casino king, visited the island county of Kinmen Friday to learn about its investment environment and specifically the feasibility of building a casino there.

Lawrence Ho, chairman and CEO of Melco International Development, arrived at Shanyi airport in Kinmen on his private jet at 10:30 a.m., the first flight to fly directly from Hong Kong to the Taiwan-held island just off China's southeastern coast.
Ho gathered with other Melco executives, who had arrived in Kinmen by ferry from Xiamen, before calling on Magistrate Lee Chu-feng.
Melco had already sent executives to visit Kinmen in May after Taiwan passed an amendment in January paving the way to open casinos in outlying islands.
Ho said he has confidence in Kinmen's investment environment and that he is especially interested in its entertainment sector.
Lee responded that he is happy that foreign capital may come to the county but reminded his guest that whether or not Kinmen will allow a casino to open hinges on public opinion.

Lee noted that opinion polls have consistently shown considerable opposition among local residents to such an idea and said he will wait until there are more concrete plans before putting the matter to a public referendum, as is required by law.
Ho returned to Hong Kong at 3:15 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shih Chien University group to perform in Edinburgh
DOC.DATELINE: London, Aug. 7 (CNA) 08/07/09 21:58:09 (By Jennifer Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A Song Jian Battle Array troupe from Shih Chien University's Kaohsiung Campus will make its debut at this year's Edinburgh Festival Fringe Aug. 13.

The theme of the group's performances at the 7th Edinburgh Festival Fringe will revolve around four elements of nature -- wind, fire, thunder and lightning -- in a story-like presentation that blends martial arts, opera, dance and percussion with Taiwan's religious and folkloric parades.
The Song Jian Battle Array performance is often seen at religious festivals held outside temples in Taiwan.

The group, which is composed of more than 40 members and has won the top honor in Taiwan's creative Song Jian Battle Array Competition for three consecutive years, will stage 16 performances in the city's Meadowbank Sport Center beginning Aug. 13.
It will be the first time that Shih Chien University sends a group to introduce and promote Taiwan's culture at the annual Edinburgh Festival Fringe, which will last three weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Oil tanker grounded amid strong winds

TEXT.P: A Marshall Islands-registered oil tanker ran aground in coastal areas off Pingtung County due to strong winds and choppy seas brought by Typhoon Morakot, the Coast Guard said Friday.
Coast Guard members said they worked with firefighters to rescue the crew. All 17 crew members aboard the 4,535-ton vessel were rescued by 10 p.m.
Two other ships ran aground amid blustery winds in the afternoon. They were thought to be Cambodia-registered working ships on their way from Indonesia to South Korea.
The one that had problems near Fangshan Creek was closer to shore, and all 10 crew members were rescued by 4:30 p.m.
All 10 people aboard the other vessel near Checheng were also rescued as of 11 p.m.
