DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 8, or the 18th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1549: France declares war on England.
1588: The Spanish Armada is defeated by the British.
1900: The first Davis Cup tennis tournament, named after Dwight Filley Davis, begins in Brookline, Massachusetts.
1901: Ernest Lawrence, the American physicist who won the Nobel Prize for physics in 1939, is born. He invented the first subatomic particle accelerator and the color television tube.
1918: The Battle of Amiens begins when Allied forces advance against 20 German divisions and take 16,000 prisoners in two hours.
1919: A peace conference between India and Afghanistan results in the signing of the Treaty of Rawalpindi.
1923: Esther Williams, the American actress and former champion swimmer, is born. She became best-known for her appearance in "Bathing Beauty."
1944: Adolf Hitler has four of his top men hanged with piano wire for attempting to assassinate him.
1945: The United States drops its second atomic bomb, "Fat Man," on the Japanese city of Nagasaki, days after devastating Hiroshima with "Little Boy," the first such device ever used.
1957: General Chow Chih-jou is appointed governor of Taiwan, succeeding C.K. Yen.
1957: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Jordan.
1961: Mei Lan-fang, noted Beijing opera actor, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 67.
1963: In one of the most audacious holdups of all time, robbers involved in "The Great Train Robbery" net an estimated 2.5 million pounds (US$4.6 million) in unused bank notes from a night mail train traveling between Glasgow and London.
1963: The United States, Britain and the USSR sign the nuclear Test Ban Treaty in the Kremlin.
1967: The "Bangkok Declaration" is signed by the foreign ministers of Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand. The declaration led to the formation of the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN).
1974: Richard Nixon makes history as the first U.S. president to resign from office.
1977: The Interior Ministry reports that at the end of June, the population of Taiwan reached 16,655,140 and that of Taipei hit 2,113,030.
1983: A military coup led by Defense Minister General Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores overthrows President Efrain Rios Montt of Guatemala.
1988: ROC swimmer Wang Han and a six-man team swim across the English Channel in relays in 14 hours and 31 minutes.
1988: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa announces the decision to build a new highway linking Ilan and Nankang in Taipei County.
1990: National Defense Minister Chen Li-an announces that the Red Cross Society of the ROC will handle the repatriation of illegal mainland entrants in the future.
1994: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and mainland China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait sign and make public a joint announcement confirming the results of the second round of talks between Chiao Jen-ho and Tang Shubei.
1999: The Fifth Asia Children's Literature Convention opens in Taipei with 300 authors of children's literature from Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, the Philippines, Malaysia and the ROC attending.
2000: The Asian Witness Center of the Guinness Book of World Records names 109 -year-old Hu Chin-yao as Taiwan's oldest father.
2001: Officials from Taiwan and Australia gathers in Taipei to participate in a two-day conference on mineral and energy resources.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If those in authority have not the confidence of those under them, government of the people is an impossibility."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
A-moms struggling to keep colorful dreams alive

TEXT.P: Visitors to the central country of Nantou who become familiar with Chungliao township after the devastating 921 earthquake will have no trouble finding the building that houses A-mom's Dyeing Workshop, as it stands in the town as it did 10 years ago.
The difference now is that very few customers are calling at the shop on Yungping Road, even on holidays or weekends.
The flood of people that poured into the area after the 7.3 magnitude earthquake struck on Sept. 21, 1999 has trickled off and so has business at the hand dyeing shop.
Established by a loosely formed group of local women after the earthquake, the shop sells items that are colored with dyes made from natural plants that grow in the nearby mountains.

It also offers do-it-yourself classes for visitors to learn the basic techniques used by the over 10 mothers and housewives -- known as A-moms -- to dye the colorful pillows, cellphone pouches, sheets, notebooks and other items on sale at the shop.

The women learned their craft from professionals provided by the Taipei-based ROC Community Resources Exchange Association, and the shop got off to brisk start after it officially opened in 2003 with financial assistance from the Council of Labor Affairs.
However, the colorful dreams of the A-moms are being crushed by the bitter reality of fewer and fewer visitors over the years.
"We will not give up, because we don't want it to be just a flash in the pan, " said Wu Mei-chen, manager of the workshop.
In their efforts to revive the business, the women refurbished the run-down workshop and set up the classroom where visitors can learn and practice the basics of dyeing.

"At one point, we even hired fashion experts to teach us how to pose and model and this helped to attract some visitors and boost our revenues for a while," said Wu. "However, in the last two or three years, very few tourists have been calling at the workshop, and we'd be lucky if 10 people a day come by on weekends."

This is mainly because large crowds of people are no longer visiting the Chungliao area as they did after 921 earthquake, she said, adding that another factor is the township's relatively remote location.

The variety of colorfully dyed products on display in the workshop are also not moving off the shelves because the women lack knowledge of the marketing process and government assistance has dried up, Wu said.
The other women also expressed concern over the future of the business to which they have given so much time and effort and which now earns them only a few thousand New Taiwan dollars a month.
One of the women, Chien Chien-mei, called for the government to assist them in exploring markets and setting up a system to certify their products.
But the women are not sitting back and waiting. They are trying on their own to think of new ways to put the workshop back on its feet.

"We are mulling a transformation plan to achieve sustainable growth for the workshop, which we established from scratch, and we will continue to strive for its success despite the tremendous difficulties we are experiencing," said Wu.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC postpones astronomy exhibition opening to Aug. 10

TEXT.P: The National Science Council postponed Saturday the opening of an astronomy exhibition, which was planned to celebrate the 400th anniversary of Galileo's first observation of space and International Year of Astronomy 2009.
"The opening ceremony has been put off to next Monday due to Typhoon Morakot," according to Delicacy Integrated Marketing Company, one of the organizers.

At 9 a.m., Typhoon Morakot was centered 40 km south of Taipei City, packing maximum sustained winds of 119 kph and moving northwest out of Taiwan at 11 kph, according to Central Weather Bureau data. The storm has brought strong winds and heavy rains across Taiwan and caused at least two deaths. As of Saturday noon, four people were reported missing in the storm.

The NSC exhibit, titled "400 Years of Sky Gazing, " is aimed at explaining astronomy, showing how it is related to history, literature, religion, science and technology, and detailing how it has impacted on human exploration of the universe.
The exhibition is being organized by the NSC, Ministry of Education, Astronomical Society of the Republic of China, Taipei City Government, and National Taiwan University's Institute of Astrophysics.
The presentation will be theatrical, featuring 3D projections, digital audio and video displays and multi-touch interaction installations to showcase scientific knowledge, according to the NSC.

It will be composed of several theme areas, such as the "galaxy passage," "solar system corridor," "astronomy history hall," "physics room, " "astronomical observation center, " "stories of the sky" and "creative DIY area, " the council said.
Seminars given by noted scientists from abroad will also provide a lively experience for visitors, it added.

The exhibition is scheduled to run though Sept. 13 at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall's Second and Third Display Rooms and Art Gallery. Admission to the exhibit is free and more information is available at http://www.astronomy2009.tw/scisea.

DOC.HEADLINE: BTCO to hold a series of activities on climate change

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) said in its latest e-newsletter that it will hold a series of activities on climate change as part of a U.K. government program that is geared toward a global pact on the issue.

This year is a landmark one for climate change, as the nations of the world will gather in Copenhagen in December to work out a new international agreement to tackle climate change because the Kyoto Protocol will expire in 2012, according to the BTCO.

The British government has launched a Web site called "Act on Copenhagen, " which represents the official position of the U.K. on climate change negotiations, and it has also initiated "The Road to Copenhagen" program that sets out the U.K.'s case for an ambitious international agreement at Copenhagen.
The program focuses on urgent action to limit global temperature increases to no more than two degrees Celsius, beyond which the risks of dangerous climate change become much greater.
As part of the efforts, the BTCO is planning to work with the non-governmental Taiwan Environmental Actions Network to hold a workshop on climate change Aug. 25-26 at Youth Hub in downtown Taipei.

"The workshop is aimed at increasing awareness of climate change among college and university graduate students and helping them develop concrete plans for future campus or community actions on combating the issue," according to the BTCO.

The BTCO and Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs will together organize a forum on greenhouse gas management, which is scheduled to take place Sept. 29 at National Taiwan University's International Convention Center, the e-newsletter said.
Experts and representatives of governmental, industrial, academic and research sectors from home and abroad will participate in the event to discuss how to fight climate change.

At the workshop, five British experts will share their views on the policies and international cooperation mechanisms for the promotion of a low-carbon dioxide society, the trend of the European Union's "Carbon Labeling," and measures to lower corporate greenhouse gas emissions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon Morakot losing steam over Taiwan

TEXT.P: Typhoon Morakot covered the whole of Taiwan Saturday as it moved slowly on a north-northwesterly path after the eye made landfall in Hualien County late the previous night.

The typhoon, with a radius of 250 kilometers and packing maximum winds of 119 km per hour, had weakened considerably by the time the eye hit the coastline of Hualien at 11: 50 p.m. Friday, and was downgraded to a tropical storm Saturday noon, according to forecasters.
As of 11 a.m. Saturday, the storm was centered at 20 km south-southeast of Taipei and was moving at a speed of 11 km per hour.
According to forecasters, the storm's center will not leave the island until Saturday afternoon and its outer rim will not leave until Sunday.
They warned the public to guard against torrential rain which will continue islandwide for days after the storm has left.
As the storm drenched the island Friday, a weather station in Pingtung recorded 1003.5 mm of precipitation, the 7th highest ever recorded in a single day in Taiwan.
The Central Weather Bureau predicted that Morakot will bring about 2000 mm of accumulated rainfall to the island.

The rain will be welcomed in some areas, as Taiwan had experienced an unusually dry spell in the first seven months of the year, with accumulated precipitation recorded at 700 mm, or half of the normal volume.
Before the approach of Typhoon Morakot last week, at least four counties had begun rationing water.
But on Saturday morning, Shihmen Reservoir in Taoyuan County, which was almost half dry last week, had to open its floodgates as Morakot had filled it up in just one day.
However, the storm wreaked havoc on air and sea transportation, forcing airlines and shipping companies to cancel all outbound flights and marine services until Saturday noon.
By Saturday afternoon, about 80 percent of domestic and international flights had resumed.

At its peak strength Friday, the storm caused power outages in 896,833 households around the island and electricity grid workers had to brave the strong winds and heavy rain to fix the power system, according to Taiwan Power Company.
At Saturday noon, some 163,075 households were still without power, the company said.
Mudslides were reported in mountainous areas in the counties of Nantou, Pingdong and Taitung, forcing the closure of some bridges during the storm.
The torrential rain, coinciding with the monthly tide along the coastline of southern Taiwan, triggered flooding in the townships of Linbian, Jiadong, Donggang and Sinyuan, all in Pingdong County.
Flooding was also reported in Taimali, Taitung County when a river bank broke and a dozen residential buildings were half buried.

DOC.HEADLINE: Renowned illustrator, 14 artists hold joint exhibition

TEXT.P: A renowned Taiwanese illustrator, who uses the pen-name Jimmy, launched an exhibition in Taipei Saturday, featuring his latest drawings and the works of 14 artists from home and abroad.
The exhibition, titled "The Starry Starry Night" is based on Jimmy 's new book by the same name, according to the organizer Jimmy S.P.A. Co., Ltd.

The works on display by the other 14 artists were all inspired by the book and demonstrate the unique talent of each artist while at the same time showing aspects of their collaboration with each other, the company said.
"As an artist, I just try to do well what I am best at doing and leave the rest to the individual experts," Jimmy said at the opening ceremony.
"That kind of collaboration is the most appealing," he added.

Speaking of his newest picture book, Jimmy said The Starry Starry Night is a story about growing-up and it targets teenagers, which is something he has not done before as he never aims his work at any specific group.
Lee Yu-shan, general manager of Jimmy S.P.A. Co., Ltd., said that the exhibit serves as a dialogue between Jimmy and the 14 artists, whose works have been woven into a beautiful starry night.
The exhibition, which will run through Sept. 29 at Huashan Creative Park, presents Jimmy's work from a fresh perspective, using light installations, sculptures, horticulture, stage design, and music.

The artists involved in the project include stage and exhibition designer Huang I-ju, music composer and producer Liu Chi-ling, fashion designer Lai Wei-jion, puppet designer Yeh Man-ling, horticulturist Tim Chiu, astrophysicist Sun Wei- hsin, photographer Lin Sheng-fa, wax sculptor Lin Chien-cheng, industrial designer Yi Wei-shen, lighting designer Wang Tien-hung, and sculptor Zhang Xiao- ling.
The exhibition also features works from noted lyrist and writer Lin Xi, and toy designer Howard Lee, both of whom are from Hong Kong, as well as Japanese miniaturist Takuji Yamada.
Born in Taipei in 1958, Jimmy has become a prolific picture book author since 1998 when he released his first two books, Secrets in the Woods and A Fish that Smiled at Me.

He has since published 33 books and his work has been translated into nine languages worldwide. His illustrations have been used in theme music albums, stage plays and movies, such as The Sound of Colors and Turn Left Turn Right.

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential Office supervisor to be disciplined for flouting security

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office has referred one of its senior staff members to its performance evaluation committee for disciplinary action after he flouted security rules, a spokesman said Saturday.

Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi made the disclosure in response to media inquiries on a news report Saturday that a security loophole had opened up at the Presidential Office because of the arrogance of one of its division chiefs.

According to the local newspaper report, Shih Chao-hsien, who serves both as a Presidential Office consultant and a supervisor of the division in charge of liaison with the legislature, refused to submit to the military police's safety check as he drove into the office complex on July 22.
Shih reportedly drove through the security checkpoint, hitting and injuring a guard.
The report stated that Shih sees himself as a senior long-serving official at the Presidential Office who should have immunity from security checks.

However, the day before the incident, Presidential Office Secretary-General Chan Chun-po instructed that all officials and employees at the office, excluding the president and vice president, must submit to ID checks in the interest of security, the report said.
When Chan gave the order, Shih was at his side, the report claimed.

The reinforced security measures were reportedly instituted in the wake of a June 30 incident in which a 52-year-old local woman slipped past security guards and entered the Presidential Office building. She went to the fifth floor, which is off-limits to the public, and wandered around there for more than 10 minutes before the guards spotted her.
On Saturday, Wang confirmed that Shih had broken the new security rules and that Chan had decided to relieve Shih of his post at the liaison division.
In addition, Chan has referred Shih to the Presidential Office performance evaluation committee for disciplinary action, Wang added.

Wang said the committee will release its decision on the matter on Aug. 10. He stressed the office never intended to conceal the incident, as the newspaper report claimed. An investigation is in progress and the findings will be released along with the committee's decision, he added.
Wang also said that a task force, under Chan's supervision, will speed up its work of reviewing and making recommendations for improved internal management at the Presidential Office.
At President Ma Ying-jeou's request, the committee's report will be submitted by Aug. 24, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tropical Storm Morakot moving away from Taiwan

TEXT.P: Tropical Storm Morakot's eye moved off Taiwan Saturday afternoon after pounding the island with strong winds and downpours for two days.

The storm's eye moved out to sea from the coast of Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan at 2 p.m., although its outer rim, which extended 250 km outward from the eye, will covered most parts of the island until Sunday.
Forecasters warned however that the torrential rain brought by the storm will continue, especially in the central and southern parts of the island, until Aug. 10.
Typhoon Morakot made landfall on Taiwan at 11: 50 p.m. Friday, but weakened as it moved north-northwesterly, and was downgraded to a tropical storm Saturday noon, according to forecasters.

Although the eye of the storm moved over northern Taiwan, the capital Taipei was spared most of its fury, thanks to the fact that the city is located in basin shielded by mountains on the east, forecasters said.

The storm brought torrential showers to the island, drenching Pingdong with 1003.5 mm of rainfall, the 7th highest ever recorded in a single day in Taiwan, according to a weather station in that southern county.
The Central Weather Bureau predicted that Morakot would bring about 2000 mm of accumulated rainfall to the island.

The rain was welcomed in some areas, as Taiwan had experienced an unusually dry spell in the first seven months of the year, with accumulated precipitation recorded at 700 mm, or half of the normal volume.
Before the approach of Typhoon Morakot last week, at least four counties had begun rationing water.
But on Saturday morning, Shihmen Reservoir in Taoyuan County, which was almost half dry last week, had to open its floodgates as Morakot had filled it up in just one day.
However, the storm wreaked havoc on air and sea transportation, forcing airlines and shipping companies to cancel all outbound flights and marine services until Saturday noon.
By Saturday afternoon, about 80 percent of domestic and international flights had resumed.

At its peak strength Friday, the storm caused power outages in 896,833 households around the island and electricity grid workers had to brave the strong winds and heavy rain to fix the power system, according to Taiwan Power Company.
At Saturday noon, some 163,075 households were still without power, the company said.
Mudslides were reported in mountainous areas in the counties of Nantou, Pingdong and Taitung, forcing the closure of some bridges during the storm.
The torrential rain, coinciding with the monthly tide along the coastline of southern Taiwan, triggered flooding in the townships of Linbian, Jiadong, Donggang and Sinyuan, all in Pingdong County.

In some parts of Linbian, where the land had subsided because of overdrawing of underground water, the floodwaters were more than two meters deep and firefighters had to use inflatable rafts to rescue people.
Flooding was also reported in Taimali, Taitung County where a river bank broke and a dozen residential buildings were half submerged.
Meanwhile in Kaohsiung City, many streets were flooded by knee-deep water as the drainage system could not handle the rainfall.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor orders start of typhoon recovery work

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu ordered municipal agencies Saturday to deal with the damage caused by Typhoon Morakot, as many roads in the city have been closed due to severe flooding.

Heavy rainfall brought by Morakot, coupled with the monthly rising tide along the coastlines of southern Taiwan, caused flooding in many districts in the city, with the areas adjacent to Sizihwan, Love River and Chienchen River heavily affected. The water level rose knee-high in some streets in the Chienchen district.

Chen issued the recovery order at a disaster prevention meeting with city government officials Saturday morning, saying that although the typhoon caused only sporadic damage in Kaohsiung, the flooding in low-lying areas was serious and priority must be given to elderly citizens who live alone.
Chen particularly instructed the transportation department and public works bureau to remove fallen trees, signboards and monitor cameras from the roadways as soon as possible.
She also urged citizens to store water in case of an interruption of the supply, as the water collected in the reservoirs has been silted by mudslides.
Typhoon Morakot, the worst to affect Taiwan this year, began lashing Kaohsiung Friday evening with gusty winds and heavy rains.
According to the Central Weather Bureau, as of 11: 00 a.m. Saturday, Kaohsiung had recorded 342.5 millimeters of rainfall.

Although the typhoon weakened after it made landfall in Hualien, eastern Taiwan late Friday, weathermen said strong winds and heavy rains will continue to affect Kaohsiung City until Saturday evening.
Meanwhile, air, land and sea transportation in the city was seriously disrupted by the storm.

Domestic flights to and from Kaohsiung were canceled Friday and Saturday, while many international flights were canceled or delayed. Two Kaohsiung-bound flights from Tokyo were forced to land at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.
On the roads, the Yenchao township ramp to the No. 10 national freeway was closed and access to many townships was blocked due to floods or mudslides.
Segments of the South Link Line railway system and the High Speed Railway System also remained closed on Saturday.
Marine transportation was also affected, as the Kaohsiung Port Bureau closed the port to incoming vessels until the weather improves.
Meanwhile, rivers and streams in the adjoining Kaohsiung County all rose to alert levels and 21 bridges were closed as a result of rapidly rising water levels.
The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture on Saturday issued a red alert for 24 potentially dangerous streams in Kaohsiung County's 13 townships.
Agricultural damage in the southern Taiwan county has been initially estimated at NT$73.18 million (US$2.2 million).

On Saturday, fruit and vegetable supplies at the Fongshan wholesale market totaled 44.55 metric tons, down from Friday's 57.67 metric tons. Wholesales prices per kilogram averaged NT$11.43, an increase of NT$1.59 from the previous day.
Weathermen warned Saturday that the outer bands of the storm will continue to drench Taiwan over the next two days, particularly the central and southern regions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Residents of 37 villages advised to evacuate due to mudflow threat

TEXT.P: The residents of 37 villages in 11 counties across Taiwan were advised Saturday to evacuate, as those areas were under severe threat from mudflows, according to the Soil and Water Conservation Bureau under the Council of Agriculture.

With Typhoon Morakot bringing torrential rains at a rate of over 500 mm/day to many mountainous areas around the island, the 37 villages were put on red alert under a hazard warning system for landslides and debris flows.
In case of emergency, local governments can enforce village evacuation, the bureau said.

Another 32 villages in 12 counties that recorded rainfall close to the dangerous level of 350 mm/day were put on yellow alert and warned to be aware of and prepared for possible mudflows, as weathermen have forecast more rain in the coming days.
As of noon Saturday, 297 locations in the island's mountainous regions were threatened by heavy rain-induced mudflows, according to the bureau.
Reports from Nantou County in central Taiwan indicated that the aboriginal village of Hsinyi, with accumulated rainfall of 760 mm in some areas, was under the most serious threat.
In southern Taiwan, heavy rainfall in excess of 2000 mm over 24 hours in many locations caused flooding and the overflow of rivers.

The situation was exacerbated by high waves in Pingtung County, which recorded more than 1400 mm of rain over the past three days. Five major bridges in the county have been closed to traffic and roads leading to mountainous regions have also been closed due to landslides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Property damaged by typhoon tax deductible: finance ministry

TEXT.P: Tax payers can claim deductions for property damaged by Typhoon Morakot, once they have proper documentation, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said Saturday.

Property owners are eligible to file their tax deduction applications with local tax offices within 30 days and must attach detailed reports of the damage and legal verification of ownership, the MOF said.

Once the applications have been approved by the tax officials, who are required to conduct on-site inspections, property holders and business owners can list their damaged commodities or products for tax deductions when they file their income or business tax returns next year, the ministry said.

A wide range of personal property such as private cars, scooters, houses and land, damaged by Morakot Friday and Saturday, are included on the list of tax deductible items, according to MOF officials. Deduction rates vary in accordance with the law, the ministry added.
Meanwhile, Morakot, the strongest typhoon to affect Taiwan this year, has been moving off the island. The eye of the storm made landfall in Hualien, eastern Taiwan late Friday.
The central and southern regions of the country, including Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung, Pingtung and Taitung, have been inundated by torrential rains brought by the storm.

The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture reported Saturday that agricultural damage across the country was initially estimated at more than NT$50 million (US$1.52 million), with Nantou, Changhua and Tainan counties bearing the brunt.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense ministry urges U.S. to sell advanced fighter jets to Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) called on the United States Sunday to supply Taiwan with the advanced F-16C/D fighter jets, in the interest of military equilibrium in the Taiwan Strait.
The ministry stated in a press release that with China's military budget showing double-digit annual growth in recent years, an imbalance of military power is developing across the Taiwan Strait.

Quoting a recent research report by the Washington-based thinktank RAND Corp., the ministry said that "China's ability to suppress Taiwan and local U.S. air bases with ballistic and cruise missiles seriously threatens the defense's ability to maintain control of the air over the strait."
The research report released on Aug. 3 suggests that regaining the initiative in the air may require the U.S. and Taiwan to acquire new strike capabilities.
The MND maintains that the procurement of F-16C/Ds is vital and urgent to Taiwan's air defense, the release stated.
A military delegation from Taiwan visited Washington, D.C. in May to explore the possibility of procuring 60 F-16C/D fighter planes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police bust child-trafficking ring

TEXT.P: The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) has broken a crime ring that smuggled children from China to countries such as the United States, Mexico and France, according to a statement released by the bureau Saturday.

Police arrested two top members of the crime ring at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport Aug. 6 and seized items in their personal luggage that included counterfeit passports, lists of names, and fake National Immigration Agency entry and exit stamps, the CIB said.
The two men arrested were identified by their surnames Liao and Hsu.

According to the CIB, the police acted on a tip that Liao and Hsu were smuggling Chinese children to the U.S. with the use of passports that faked the identity of indigenous children from remote areas of Hualien County in eastern Taiwan.

The police said they found that the crime ring had paid the unaware parents of the indigenous children NT$5,000 to NT$10,000 (US$305) each for the IDs, which were then used to apply for passports and visas.

After acquiring Taiwan passports and the relevant travel permits to foreign countries, Liao and Hsu linked up in Hong Kong with their Chinese accomplices who had taken children away from homes in China, the police said. The children were then smuggled into the U.S. and other countries, they added.

The crime ring was forced to suspend its trafficking to the U.S. after the U.S. government amended its immigration regulations with effect from July 1 to require that Taiwanese children under the age of 14 must show up at the consulate when applying for non-immigrants visa to the U.S., the police said. However, the ring continued to smuggle children into France, they added.

According to CIB statistics, more than 45 aboriginal families in Hualien were found have sold IDs to the crime ring, and over 37 Chinese children were smuggled into foreign countries. The traffickers were paid US$70,000 for each child, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 20 houses in coastal Taitung County washed into Pacific
DOC.DATELINE: Taitung, Aug. 8 (CNA) 08/08/09 20:57:23 (By Lu Tai-cheng and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Twenty houses in Taitung were washed into the Pacific Ocean Saturday evening by the overflowing Taimali River, but the occupants had all been evacuated, the Taitung Emergency Management Center reported.

The disaster was caused by heavy rainfall brought by Typhoon Morakot, which damaged approximately 700 meters of roadbed and washed away bridges Friday in Taitung County along a coastal area that had no seawall.
Dozens of houses were swamped when the Taimali River burst its banks at around 5 p.m. Saturday. By that time the residents had been airlifted out the danger zone by helicopter.

However, as of 9: 00 p.m., a police patrol car carrying two officers was reported as still missing. The emergency management center was also still awaiting reports on other missing persons and property loss in the county.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait forum on technology, economy to be held in Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: The eighth cross-Taiwan Strait forum on technology and economy will open in Kaohsiung City Sunday, with 250 Chinese professionals from industrial, academic, governmental and research circles expected to attend.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng will attend the opening ceremony of the one-day forum, which is being held in Kaohsiung for the first time since it was launched in 2003 with the goal of promoting technology and economic exchanges between Taiwan and China.
It is being viewed as a significant achievement for the southern port city, as most major cross-strait activities to date have been held in the capital city of Taipei in the north.
The Chinese organizers have planned for the delegation from China to stay for three nights in Kaohsiung, which would allow for a tour of the southern Taiwan region.

The Chinese participants and local representatives will be divided into 11 groups that will discuss a range of topics, including cooperation between the electronic manufacturing sectors on both sides of the strait for mutual benefit and closer economic and trade ties through mutual investment.

At an evening party, over 600 attendees are expected to link up via video conferencing with 150 Taiwanese businessmen operating in Xiamen, southern China, and their local friends, according to the organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Colleges with low enrollment rates urged to mull future

TEXT.P: Colleges experiencing low enrollment rates should assess their future in light of their recruitment difficulties, a Ministry of Education (MOE) official urged Saturday.
Ho Cho-fei, director of the MOE's Department of Higher Education, advised such universities to thoroughly weigh their options and quickly chart a new course that could include mergers.
"A good restructuring plan could help these schools to attract more students," he said.

Ho made the comments after the Joint Board of the College Recruitment Commission on Friday published data on freshman recruitment this year by all four-year universities and colleges in the country, which showed that the number of admissions and vacant places were both at record highs.

The data showed that a total of 76,434 students were admitted to Taiwanese universities this year, but a record high 6,802 vacant places still remained. The admission rate was a record high of 97.14 percent, according to the commission.
Last year, there were 4,788 vacant places and the college admission rate was 97.10 percent, the statistics showed.

This year, Hsin Kuo University of Management in Tainan City, which had 1,470 places available, admitted only 14 students, while Leader University in the same city took in 49 new students, although it had 1,299 places available.
Mingdao University in central Changhua County recruited 330 students in its effort to fill its 1,148 places in 17 departments.

Fo Guang University in northern Ilan County, which had 575 vacant places, admitted 269 students, while NanHua University in southern Chiayi County attracted 509 students in its bid to fill 1,034 places.

All the above-mentioned colleges had a vacant place rate of more than 50 percent, with the figure at Leader University and Hsing Kuo University of Management being more than 95 percent, MOE statistics showed.
In the last school year, 24 out of the country's 147 colleges and universities had an enrollment rate of lower than 70 percent.

The MOE has stipulated that colleges with an enrollment rate of less than 70 percent must reduce their recruitment targets by 10 percent to 30 percent, starting from next year. The MOE's aim is to spur these schools to step up their pace of restructuring.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait forum on technology, economy postponed

The Chinese participants and local representatives will be divided into 11 groups that will discuss a range of topics, including cooperation between the electronic manufacturing sectors on both sides of the strait for mutual benefit and closer economic and trade ties through mutual investment.

At an evening party, over 600 attendees are expected to link up via video conferencing with 150 Taiwanese businessmen operating in Xiamen, southern China, and their local friends, according to the organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Morakot causes over NT$800 million in agricultural damage

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses caused by Typhoon Morakot were estimated at NT$832 million (US$25.36 million), with the southern and eastern regions suffering the heaviest damage, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) reported Saturday.

Presiding over a disaster prevention meeting, COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung instructed government personnel to begin the recovery work as soon as possible and he promised to grant subsidies and assistance to affected farmers and fishermen, in cooperation with local governments, to help them return to normal life.
Banana farms in Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties, on a total 1,612-hectares of land, suffered the biggest losses in the agricultural sector, according to the COA.
Meanwhile, losses in the fish farming sector in Pingtung County's Chiatong township was around NT$61.17 million, it said.
Chen also asked land and soil conservation authorities to continue monitoring the weather so as to prevent more damage from mudslides.
The typhoon brought torrential rains to the entire island, particularly the southern regions such as Pingtung, which recorded more than 2,000 mm of precipitation.
Weathermen have forecast that downpours will continue in central and southern Taiwan until Monday.

Kaohsiung and Pintung counties in southern Taiwan and Hualien County in the east were the hardest hit by Morakot, which made landfall in Hualien in late Friday and moved off Taiwan Saturday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 9, or the 19th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1794: General Napoleon Bonaparte is arrested in France on suspicions of Robespierrism.
1814: Under the terms of the Treaty of Fort Jackson signed between the U.S. government and the native Creek tribe, the Creeks lose 9.3 million hectares of land -- over half of Alabama and part of southern Georgia -- to the United States.
1842: The United States signs the Webster-Ashburton Treaty with Britain, establishing the boundary between the U.S. and Canada from Maine to the Great Lakes.
1867: John Harrison Surratt is arrested for being an alleged conspirator in the assassination of President Abraham Lincoln.
1902: Edward VII, 64, is crowned King of Great Britain and Ireland after a six- week delay due to an emergency appendectomy.
1903: Giuseppe Sarto becomes Pope Pius X following the death of Pope Leo XIII.
1919: India concludes a secret pact with Britain, recognizing Britain as India's protector after Britain promised India a major role in its own government.
1928: Italian divers find precious diamonds in the wreckage of "Elizabethville," a Belgian ship sunk during World War I.
1937: Japanese troops clash with Chinese forces at Hungchiao airport in Shanghai.
1938: Rod Laver, Australian tennis star, is born. He won the singles title at Wimbledon four times.
1942: Mohandas K. Gandhi, leader of the Indian National Congress, is arrested in Britain for his "Quit India" campaign, which demands that the British should withdraw from India.
1945: Soviet troops enter Manchuria after the Soviet Union declares war on Japan.
1946: Henry Pu Yi, who was enthroned as the "Emperor of Manchukuo" in Changchun by Japanese militarists on Mar. 1, 1934, arrives in Tokyo to testify before an international court against Japanese war crimes committed during the invasion of China.
1954: The Republic of China Navy sinks 12 Communist Chinese ships at Tungshan seaport, Dongshan Island, near Fukien province.
1965: Singapore is separated from Malaysia and becomes an independent state within the Commonwealth of Nations.
1973: Ku Cheng-kang, honorary chairman of the World Anti-Communist League, leaves for Washington to attend a WACL Executive Committee meeting.
1974: Gerald R. Ford is sworn in as the 38th president of the United States after the resignation of Richard Nixon.
1979: Councilors in the English seaside town of Brighton cause a furor by agreeing to allow naturalists to bare all on "Cliff Beach," one of the less popular beaches in the district.
1990: Communist China's first airship, with a length of 40 meters, makes its maiden flight over Hupei province.
1994: The U.S. government announces trade sanctions against the ROC under the Pelly Amendment, placing a ban on imports of Taiwan wildlife products effective from August 19, 1994.
1999: The China External Trade Development Council signs a memorandum of understanding on technological cooperation with the Agency for International Development of Technology and Trade under the Trade and Industry Ministry of France.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui says the main reason he voiced the "special state- to-state relations" statement regarding cross-Taiwan Strait ties the previous month was to elucidate the fact that the Republic of China exists in the world.
2000: The Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association is established to promote Taiwan's trade and cooperation with the international community.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to gain confidence for one's authority. If a man is not trusted by one's friends, he will not gain the confidence for his authority."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Landslide topples Taitung hotel

TEXT.P: A six-story hotel in Jhihben township in the eastern county of Taitung toppled into a river around noon Sunday in a landslide caused by Typhoon Morakot's torrential rains over the weekend.
Hotel Jinshuai tilted on its foundations at an angle of 20 degrees Sunday morning after flooding and a landslide washed away a 200-meter area near the building.
It collapsed around noon. All the guests and staff at the hotel had been evacuated to safety before it toppled.
Jinshuai was one of the scores of hotels in Jhihben township, which nestles at the foot of a mountain and is known for its hotsprings.
Some 400 tourists have been stranded in Jhihben, according to reports at noon Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Morakot rise to NT$1.14 billion

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Morakot had soared to NT$1.14 billion (US$34.98 million) as of Sunday morning, according to statistics released by the Cabinet- level Council of Agriculture (COA).

The COA said that Morakot, which pummeled Taiwan over the weekend, caused serious damage to the agricultural sector in 11 counties, with Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties in southern Taiwan and Hualien County in the east being the hardest hit.
The statistics show that damage to agricultural crops amounted to NT$894 million, as 23 percent of the crops on 14, 879 hectares of farmland were lost.
Banana crops suffered the heaviest damage, with 2,172 hectares ravaged by strong winds and flooding.

Some NT$44.29 million worth of poultry perished in floods caused by the storm, while losses in the aquaculture sector totaled NT$63.19 million, with 107 hectares of fish farms in Pingtung County's Jiadong and Gaoshu townships damaged.
Damage to agricultural facilities amounted to NT$85.53 million, and damage to forestry was estimated at NT$8.58 million.

Farmers in Kaohsiung, Pingtung and Hualien who suffered heavy losses can apply for cash relief or low-interest loans from the government, in accordance with the Agricultural Natural Disaster Relief Regulations, COA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Disabled population rising steadily: Interior Ministry

TEXT.P: Taiwan's disabled population is increasing steadily, with the number of physically or mentally challenged women growing faster than the number of males in this category, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) reported Sunday.
The number of people holding MOI-issued disability certificates had reached 1,054,457 as of the end of June this year, the ministry said in a press statement.
The figure marked a 2.67 percent year-on-year rise and accounted for 4.57 percent of Taiwan's total population, the statement said.

Males outnumbered females, 606,458 to 447,999, according to MOI statistics. But MOI officials said that over the past 12 years, the disabled female population has been growing faster than its male counterpart.
"This phenomenon mainly stems from the fact that more women have been falling victim to dementia or chronic mental disorders, " said an MOI official.

According to MOI statistics, people with limb deficiencies accounted for the largest percentage -- 37.6 percent -- of the disabled population, followed by those with dysfunctional vital organs at 10.8 percent and hearing-impaired persons at 10.7 percent.

By age, the mentally challenged formed the bulk of the under-18 disabled population, accounting for 37 percent of the total. In the over-18 category, people with limb deficiencies outnumbered those with other disabilities, making up 39 percent of the total.

In terms of areas, Taitung County in eastern Taiwan had the highest disabled population at 8.9 percent, followed by the southwestern county of Yulin at 7.9 percent and eastern Taiwan's Hualien County at 7.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Landslide 'red alerts' issued for 452 locations

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) issued "red alerts" Sunday for 452 locations in 11 counties around the country that are at high risk from rockslides or mudslides as a result of Typhoon Morakot's heavy rains.

A total of 452 riverside areas in 206 villages in the southern counties of Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung, the eastern county of Taitung, the central counties of Taichung, Nantou and Yunlin, the northern counties of Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli were put on "red alert" because of their vulnerability to soil saturation and landslides.
The council said that after a "red alert" is issued, the local government is responsible for warning local residents and implementing evacuation procedures if necessary.
Meanwhile, the council also issued "yellow alerts" for 328 areas in 129 villages in 12 counties around the country that are also at risk from rockslides and mudslides in the coming days.
COA officials said that all the 13 mudslide monitoring stations around the island have been activated since Friday.

According to the Central Weather Bureau, the accumulated rainfall in Sandimen township in the southernmost county of Pingtung reached 1403 mm Saturday, setting an all-time record as the highest volume of precipitation in a single day for that area.
Meanwhile, the weather bureau forecast that rainfall from Typhoon Morakot will reach 2900 mm in Chiayi County and 2700 mm in Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties, all record volumes in recorded history.
The storm, which swept through Taiwan Friday night, has left three persons dead, 19 injured and 31 unaccounted for as of 1 p.m. Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Asia-Pacific parliamentarians to meet in Taipei as scheduled

TEXT.P: The 40th annual conference of the Asia-Pacific Parliamentarians' Union (APPU) will take place in Taipei next week as scheduled, despite the disruptions to transportation services caused by Typhoon Morakot, organizers said Sunday.
"The APPU annual conference will open in Taipei Tuesday as scheduled, " said an official at the Secretariat of the Legislative Yuan, which is organizing this year's APPU meeting.
It will be the first time that Taiwan's Legislature is sponsoring an APPU annual conference.

Although Morakot affected the country's ground, air and maritime transportation services, many of the foreign parliamentarians invited to the APPU conference have arrived in Taipei over the past couple of days without any glitches, the official said.
APPU, which comprises 21 Asia-Pacific countries, is the only international parliamentary organization in which Taiwan has membership.
Other members of the organization include Japan, South Korea, Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines, Mongolia, Laos and the Solomon Islands.

About 100 lawmakers from 14 member countries are expected to take part in this year's APPU conference, the official said, adding that the meeting will focus on the theme of protection of human safety.
According to the work schedule, a welcome party will be held Monday evening ahead of the grand opening set for Tuesday morning. The curtain will come down on the event at noon Wednesday.
The Japan-based APPU grew out of the Asia Parliamentarians' Union which was created during the Cold War era with the aim of maintaining regional peace and stability.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said recently that the opportunity to host the APPU annual conference will allow Taiwan's legislators to strengthen their friendship and exchanges with their foreign counterparts.

In addition, the participation of Taiwan's legislators in international events will help to expand Taiwan's presence in the international arena, giving the country an opening to free itself from the diplomatic isolation imposed by China, Wang said.
"Parliamentary diplomacy is a path that can lead Taiwan back to the international community," Wang said.

At present, more than 50 countries and regions have set up Taiwan friendship groups within their parliaments, while there are 34 inter-parliamentary groups in the Legislative Yuan to promote friendship with their foreign counterparts, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan included in U.S visa-free program for Guam, Northern Mariana

TEXT.P: Taiwanese citizens have been included in a new U.S. visa-waiver program that will allow travelers visa-free entry to Guam and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands (CNMI) in the western Pacific, according to an announcement by Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
"The 'Guam-CNMI Visa Waiver Program,' which will take effect Nov. 28, is an international program that includes Taiwan passport holders," said MOFA deputy spokesman James Chang Saturday.

Guam is an island in the western Pacific and is an organized, unincorporated territory of the U.S. CNMI, which includes the islands of Saipan, Tinian and Rota, is a commonwealth in political union with the U.S. American immigration laws apply in both places.

At present, Taiwanese citizens can enter Guam without a visa for a maximum stay of 15 days. However, if they wish to enter CNMI, they are required to have a valid U.S. visa, or a letter of guarantee from a local resident or hotel if they wish to go via Guam.

The Guam-CNMI Visa Waiver Program, which was announced in January and is scheduled to take effect Nov. 28, will allow nonimmigrant visitors from certain countries to enter Guam or CNMI without a visa for stays up to 45 days.
The countries approved for the program are Australia, Brunei, Hong Kong, Japan, Malaysia, Nauru, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Republic of Korea, Singapore, Taiwan and the United Kingdom.

DOC.HEADLINE: Aug.8 downpours break one-day precipitation records

TEXT.P: Torrential downpours brought by Typhoon Morakot in the past couple of days have smashed one-day precipitation records in many parts of Taiwan, Central Weather Bureau (CWB) officials said Sunday.
"Morakot has brought amazing record-setting volumes of rainfall to Taiwan, " said Chen Yi-liang, a CWB section chief in charge of weather forecast.
Several southern Taiwan counties recorded accumulated rainfall of more than 2000 mm Friday and Saturday, which caused the worst flooding in those areas in half a century, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Father and daughter reunited thanks to persistence of volunteers

TEXT.P: An elderly father in Taichung, who gave up his infant daughter for adoption some 30 years ago because of poverty, was reunited with her recently, thanks to coincidence and the persistence of volunteers at a charity home.

DOC.HEADLINE: More rain forecast for the next two days

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau forecast Sunday that torrential rains will continue in central and southern Taiwan for another two days.
CWB meteorologists said that although Typhoon Morakot is expected to move away Sunday evening after wreaking havoc on Taiwan, its solid and vast skirt will still bring heavy rainfall.
Meanwhile, the Water Resources Agency (WRA) said that severe flooding in southern Taiwan had disrupted running water supply systems, leaving tens of thousands of households without potable water.
The agency is making every effort to the improve the water problem, WRA Deputy- Director Wu Yue-hsi said, adding that the supply of clean running water will resume gradually over the next seven days.

Meanwhile, he said, the agency is using some 346 pumping units to help pump flood waters out of low-lying areas in the southern counties of Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung, which were hardest hit by the storm.

DOC.HEADLINE: Abused dog taken to U.S. for treatment, adoption

TEXT.P: Despite the transportation disruptions caused by Typhoon Morakot, an abused dog was put aboard a U.S.-bound flight at the last minute to receive psychotherapy and find a new home there, animal rescue volunteers said Sunday.
"Mico is scheduled to arrive in San Francisco this evening," said Chang Ya-hui, a volunteer with the Animal Rescue Team Taiwan, a Kaohsiung-based animal protection group.
When he was spotted near an industrial park in Kangshan township in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County in April, Mico had a rubber cord around his neck that was strangling him, Chang said.
His trachea was broken, his neck was as thin as a chicken's and his head was swollen like a pig's, according to Chang.
Although his life was saved by emergency surgery after the cord was removed, he is still psychologically scarred, Chang said.

"It seemed that he could not overcome the mental trauma. Whether he was in the animal hospital or being taken by our volunteers from the shelter for a walk outdoors, all he would do is curl up in a corner and tremble incessantly," Chang recalled.
Although Mico's eyes were full of terror, he was not aggressive, Chang said, adding that after months of attentive care by the rescue team, it seemed that Mico has regained some trust in humans.
The Animal Rescue Team sought the help of an animal protection group in San Francisco to arrange for Mico to receive professional psychotherapy.
"Mico will stay at an American volunteer's home while he is having therapy, " Chang said, adding that the volunteer will later find a new home for the dog.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health teams to help with disinfection in flood-stricken regions

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) organized two emergency teams Sunday to help with disinfection and epidemic prevention in flood-stricken areas.
Several central and southern counties have been deluged by record rainfall from Typhoon Morakot in the past couple of days.

Fearing epidemic outbreaks in the flood disaster zones, the DOH directed two of its agencies -- the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) and the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) -- to assign teams to assist with the work of disinfection and epidemic prevention.

"BNHI and CDC staff members will first collaborate with health officials from Pingtung County, the hardest-hit region, to educate flood victims on the importance of maintaining proper personal hygiene and disinfecting their living environment, as part of the post-disaster work," said a DOH official.
As part of its emergency operations, the official said, the CDC has urgently allocated 20,000 cans of disinfectant for distribution in the county's most seriously battered townships.

Health officials will step up publicity campaigns to remind residents in flooded regions to clear standing water in order to prevent outbreaks of mosquito-borne diseases, such as dengue fever, the official added.
Local residents are also welcome to report to the CDC any cases of infectious diseases or problems with epidemic prevention, the official said.
Meanwhile, the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) launched a fund-raising campaign Sunday to help finance post-disaster relief projects in the flood-stricken regions.

Describing the Aug.8 flooding as the most devastating natural disaster to hit the southernmost county of Pingtung in 50 years, DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang urged the central government to follow the precedent set in the post-Sept.21, 1999 earthquake relief operations, to help the victims of the latest flooding.
He suggested that the counties of Pingtung, Kaohsiung, Tainan, Chiayi and Taitung be listed as disaster-affected regions that would be entitled to special central government aid for rehabilitation.
Southern Taiwan has long been a DPP stronghold. Cheng said DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, a Pingtung native, has donated NT$1 million to help with the relief work.
In addition to cash, various relief goods, such as mineral water, pharmaceuticals and lighting equipment, are also welcome, Cheng said.
Relief goods can either be sent to the auditorium of the Kaohsiung City Government for distribution or directly to flood-stricken counties, he said.
Meanwhile, ruling Kuomintang (KMT) officials also took lead in making donations to help with post-disaster relief projects.
The KMT also demanded its members intending to run for seats on the party's Central Committee suspend camapign activities and instead give priority to helping with post-flooding relief work.

Typhoon Morakot lashed Taiwan with powerful winds and torrential downpours over the weekend. It dumped a record 2500 mm or rain in the southernmost county of Pingtung alone by early Sunday, flooding at least three coastal townships.
As of 7 p.m. Sunday, the typhoon-induced flooding had left seven persons dead, 32 injured and 46 unaccounted for.

DOC.HEADLINE: President, premier pledge all-out rescue and relief efforts

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan on Sunday pledged full scale rescue and relief efforts, as they inspected areas in southern Taiwan that were devastated by floods during Typhoon Morakot.
President Ma said in Chiayi County that the phenomenal rainfall from Typhoon Morakot far exceeded the original forecasts, wreaking havoc in Kaohsiung, Pingtung, Chiayi and Tainan.
He said that he had a telephone discussion with Premier Liu Chao-shiuan on setting up a southern Taiwan command post that will be headed by a ministerial- level official in the morning.

The government will also mobilize all available equipment for the rescue efforts, the president said, adding that he has requested the use of Taipei City's rubber boats for the rescue work in southern Taiwan.
He noted that the rainfall broke 50-year records in southern Taiwan, causing widespread flooding.
"Rescue and relief efforts will be our top priority," Ma said.

The accumulated rainfall in the mountainous region of Fengchihu in Chiayi County had reached 2587 mm as of Sunday noon, causing the overflow of two rivers downstream -- the Pachang Creek and Niuchou Creek.

Ma originally wanted to visit Taitung in eastern Taiwan, but canceled the trip because the Taitung Airport was closed due to the effects of the typhoon. He also canceled two scheduled activities in Taipei.
Ma will visit Taimali and Jhihben in Taitung County Monday to inspect the damage there, according to the Presidential Office.

A six-story hotel in Jhihben township in Taitung County tumbled into a river around noon Sunday after it tilted on its foundations at an angle of 20 degrees Sunday morning. The building was destabilized by a landslide and floods that washed away a nearby 200-meter area.
Meanwhile, Premier Liu said on a tour of Pingtung County in southern Taiwan Sunday that a disaster prevention center headed by Interior Minister Liao Liou- yi would be set up.
Liu also said that he would stay in southern Taiwan overnight before returning to Taipei Monday.
The premier said that in addition to the efforts of the Eighth Army Corps stationed in southern Taiwan, other military units, including engineering and chemical experts, would also pitch in.

As of 8 p.m. Sunday, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said it had deployed 2,877 military servicemen and 85 armored and other vehicles to assist in the rescue and relief work. A total of 1,236 residents had been evacuated by the military, the MND added.

Liu went to the Pingtung County Reserve Command in the morning for a briefing on the damage in the county and to mobilize the military to assist with the relief work. He then visited Pingtung County's disaster emergency center for an update on what kind of support was needed.
In the afternoon, Liu rode on a rubber raft to Linbian township, which is submerged in flood waters half-a-story high.
Linbian has become a "water world," with rubber boats shuttling around, rescuing stranded residents and delivering food and other necessities.
Some of the township residents who have been unwilling to leave their homes waved to the premier from the second floors, and Liu waved back.
The raft that Liu was traveling on was towing a rubber boat filled with food and other necessities, and some residents lowered baskets or waded through the floodwaters to collect the supplies.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo went to Kaohsiung to inspect the collapsed Shuangyuan Bridge that connected Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties.
Initial estimates put the number of collapsed bridges at around 20, the worst infrastructure damage in a decade, National Central University said Sunday.
The university's Center for Bridge Engineering Research said that the damage to bridges was even worse than in September 1999 when Taiwan was struck by a magnitude-7.3 earthquake.
Meanwhile, the first group of rescue workers from Taipei City arrived in Pingtung County at 6 a.m Sunday, and went immediately to Linbian.
Taipei City has deployed 130 rescue workers and 38 motor boats and rubber dinghies to southern Taiwan, while Taipei County has sent more than 100 rescue personnel and large water pumps.
The weather bureau forecast that rainfall from Typhoon Morakot will reach 2900 mm in Chiayi County and 2700 mm in Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties, all record volumes in recorded history.
Central Weather Bureau meteorologists have predicted more rain for the next two days.
Agricultural losses had topped NT$2.1 billion as of 2 p.m. Sunday, the Council of Agriculture said.
The storm, which swept through Taiwan Friday night, has left seven persons dead, 32 injured and 46 unaccounted for as of 7 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Morakot rise to NT$1.14 billion

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Morakot had soared to NT$1.14 billion (US$34.98 million) as of Sunday morning, according to statistics released by the Cabinet- level Council of Agriculture (COA).

The COA said that Morakot, which pummeled Taiwan over the weekend, caused serious damage to the agricultural sector in 11 counties, with Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties in southern Taiwan and Hualien County in the east being the hardest hit.
The statistics show that damage to agricultural crops amounted to NT$894 million, as 23 percent of the crops on 14, 879 hectares of farmland were lost.
Banana crops suffered the heaviest damage, with 2,172 hectares ravaged by strong winds and flooding.

Some NT$44.29 million worth of poultry perished in floods caused by the storm, while losses in the aquaculture sector totaled NT$63.19 million, with 107 hectares of fish farms in Pingtung County's Jiadong and Gaoshu townships damaged.
Damage to agricultural facilities amounted to NT$85.53 million, and damage to forestry was estimated at NT$8.58 million.

Farmers in Kaohsiung, Pingtung and Hualien who suffered heavy losses can apply for cash relief or low-interest loans from the government, in accordance with the Agricultural Natural Disaster Relief Regulations, COA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Disabled population rising steadily: Interior Ministry

TEXT.P: Taiwan's disabled population is increasing steadily, with the number of physically or mentally challenged women growing faster than the number of males in this category, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) reported Sunday.
The number of people holding MOI-issued disability certificates had reached 1,054,457 as of the end of June this year, the ministry said in a press statement.
The figure marked a 2.67 percent year-on-year rise and accounted for 4.57 percent of Taiwan's total population, the statement said.

Males outnumbered females, 606,458 to 447,999, according to MOI statistics. But MOI officials said that over the past 12 years, the disabled female population has been growing faster than its male counterpart.
"This phenomenon mainly stems from the fact that more women have been falling victim to dementia or chronic mental disorders, " said an MOI official.

According to MOI statistics, people with limb deficiencies accounted for the largest percentage -- 37.6 percent -- of the disabled population, followed by those with dysfunctional vital organs at 10.8 percent and hearing-impaired persons at 10.7 percent.

By age, the mentally challenged formed the bulk of the under-18 disabled population, accounting for 37 percent of the total. In the over-18 category, people with limb deficiencies outnumbered those with other disabilities, making up 39 percent of the total.

In terms of areas, Taitung County in eastern Taiwan had the highest disabled population at 8.9 percent, followed by the southwestern county of Yulin at 7.9 percent and eastern Taiwan's Hualien County at 7.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Landslide 'red alerts' issued for 452 locations

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) issued "red alerts" Sunday for 452 locations in 11 counties around the country that are at high risk from rockslides or mudslides as a result of Typhoon Morakot's heavy rains.

A total of 452 riverside areas in 206 villages in the southern counties of Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung, the eastern county of Taitung, the central counties of Taichung, Nantou and Yunlin, the northern counties of Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli were put on "red alert" because of their vulnerability to soil saturation and landslides.
The council said that after a "red alert" is issued, the local government is responsible for warning local residents and implementing evacuation procedures if necessary.
Meanwhile, the council also issued "yellow alerts" for 328 areas in 129 villages in 12 counties around the country that are also at risk from rockslides and mudslides in the coming days.
COA officials said that all the 13 mudslide monitoring stations around the island have been activated since Friday.

According to the Central Weather Bureau, the accumulated rainfall in Sandimen township in the southernmost county of Pingtung reached 1403 mm Saturday, setting an all-time record as the highest volume of precipitation in a single day for that area.
Meanwhile, the weather bureau forecast that rainfall from Typhoon Morakot will reach 2900 mm in Chiayi County and 2700 mm in Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties, all record volumes in recorded history.
The storm, which swept through Taiwan Friday night, has left three persons dead, 19 injured and 31 unaccounted for as of 1 p.m. Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Asia-Pacific parliamentarians to meet in Taipei as scheduled

TEXT.P: The 40th annual conference of the Asia-Pacific Parliamentarians' Union (APPU) will take place in Taipei next week as scheduled, despite the disruptions to transportation services caused by Typhoon Morakot, organizers said Sunday.
"The APPU annual conference will open in Taipei Tuesday as scheduled, " said an official at the Secretariat of the Legislative Yuan, which is organizing this year's APPU meeting.
It will be the first time that Taiwan's Legislature is sponsoring an APPU annual conference.

Although Morakot affected the country's ground, air and maritime transportation services, many of the foreign parliamentarians invited to the APPU conference have arrived in Taipei over the past couple of days without any glitches, the official said.
APPU, which comprises 21 Asia-Pacific countries, is the only international parliamentary organization in which Taiwan has membership.
Other members of the organization include Japan, South Korea, Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines, Mongolia, Laos and the Solomon Islands.

About 100 lawmakers from 14 member countries are expected to take part in this year's APPU conference, the official said, adding that the meeting will focus on the theme of protection of human safety.
According to the work schedule, a welcome party will be held Monday evening ahead of the grand opening set for Tuesday morning. The curtain will come down on the event at noon Wednesday.
The Japan-based APPU grew out of the Asia Parliamentarians' Union which was created during the Cold War era with the aim of maintaining regional peace and stability.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said recently that the opportunity to host the APPU annual conference will allow Taiwan's legislators to strengthen their friendship and exchanges with their foreign counterparts.

In addition, the participation of Taiwan's legislators in international events will help to expand Taiwan's presence in the international arena, giving the country an opening to free itself from the diplomatic isolation imposed by China, Wang said.
"Parliamentary diplomacy is a path that can lead Taiwan back to the international community," Wang said.

At present, more than 50 countries and regions have set up Taiwan friendship groups within their parliaments, while there are 34 inter-parliamentary groups in the Legislative Yuan to promote friendship with their foreign counterparts, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan included in U.S visa-free program for Guam, Northern Mariana

TEXT.P: Taiwanese citizens have been included in a new U.S. visa-waiver program that will allow travelers visa-free entry to Guam and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands (CNMI) in the western Pacific, according to an announcement by Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
"The 'Guam-CNMI Visa Waiver Program,' which will take effect Nov. 28, is an international program that includes Taiwan passport holders," said MOFA deputy spokesman James Chang Saturday.

Guam is an island in the western Pacific and is an organized, unincorporated territory of the U.S. CNMI, which includes the islands of Saipan, Tinian and Rota, is a commonwealth in political union with the U.S. American immigration laws apply in both places.

At present, Taiwanese citizens can enter Guam without a visa for a maximum stay of 15 days. However, if they wish to enter CNMI, they are required to have a valid U.S. visa, or a letter of guarantee from a local resident or hotel if they wish to go via Guam.

The Guam-CNMI Visa Waiver Program, which was announced in January and is scheduled to take effect Nov. 28, will allow nonimmigrant visitors from certain countries to enter Guam or CNMI without a visa for stays up to 45 days.
The countries approved for the program are Australia, Brunei, Hong Kong, Japan, Malaysia, Nauru, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Republic of Korea, Singapore, Taiwan and the United Kingdom.
