Although Mico's eyes were full of terror, he was not aggressive, Chang said, adding that after months of attentive care by the rescue team, it seemed that Mico has regained some trust in humans.
The Animal Rescue Team sought the help of an animal protection group in San Francisco to arrange for Mico to receive professional psychotherapy.
"Mico will stay at an American volunteer's home while he is having therapy, " Chang said, adding that the volunteer will later find a new home for the dog.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health teams to help with disinfection in flood-stricken regions

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) organized two emergency teams Sunday to help with disinfection and epidemic prevention in flood-stricken areas.
Several central and southern counties have been deluged by record rainfall from Typhoon Morakot in the past couple of days.

Fearing epidemic outbreaks in the flood disaster zones, the DOH directed two of its agencies -- the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) and the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) -- to assign teams to assist with the work of disinfection and epidemic prevention.

"BNHI and CDC staff members will first collaborate with health officials from Pingtung County, the hardest-hit region, to educate flood victims on the importance of maintaining proper personal hygiene and disinfecting their living environment, as part of the post-disaster work," said a DOH official.
As part of its emergency operations, the official said, the CDC has urgently allocated 20,000 cans of disinfectant for distribution in the county's most seriously battered townships.

Health officials will step up publicity campaigns to remind residents in flooded regions to clear standing water in order to prevent outbreaks of mosquito-borne diseases, such as dengue fever, the official added.
Local residents are also welcome to report to the CDC any cases of infectious diseases or problems with epidemic prevention, the official said.
Meanwhile, the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) launched a fund-raising campaign Sunday to help finance post-disaster relief projects in the flood-stricken regions.

Describing the Aug.8 flooding as the most devastating natural disaster to hit the southernmost county of Pingtung in 50 years, DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang urged the central government to follow the precedent set in the post-Sept.21, 1999 earthquake relief operations, to help the victims of the latest flooding.
He suggested that the counties of Pingtung, Kaohsiung, Tainan, Chiayi and Taitung be listed as disaster-affected regions that would be entitled to special central government aid for rehabilitation.
Southern Taiwan has long been a DPP stronghold. Cheng said DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, a Pingtung native, has donated NT$1 million to help with the relief work.
In addition to cash, various relief goods, such as mineral water, pharmaceuticals and lighting equipment, are also welcome, Cheng said.
Relief goods can either be sent to the auditorium of the Kaohsiung City Government for distribution or directly to flood-stricken counties, he said.
Meanwhile, ruling Kuomintang (KMT) officials also took lead in making donations to help with post-disaster relief projects.
The KMT also demanded its members intending to run for seats on the party's Central Committee suspend camapign activities and instead give priority to helping with post-flooding relief work.

Typhoon Morakot lashed Taiwan with powerful winds and torrential downpours over the weekend. It dumped a record 2500 mm or rain in the southernmost county of Pingtung alone by early Sunday, flooding at least three coastal townships.
As of 7 p.m. Sunday, the typhoon-induced flooding had left seven persons dead, 32 injured and 46 unaccounted for.

DOC.HEADLINE: President, premier pledge all-out rescue and relief efforts

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan on Sunday pledged full scale rescue and relief efforts, as they inspected areas in southern Taiwan that were devastated by floods during Typhoon Morakot.
President Ma said in Chiayi County that the phenomenal rainfall from Typhoon Morakot far exceeded the original forecasts, wreaking havoc in Kaohsiung, Pingtung, Chiayi and Tainan.
He said that he had a telephone discussion with Premier Liu Chao-shiuan on setting up a southern Taiwan command post that will be headed by a ministerial- level official in the morning.

The government will also mobilize all available equipment for the rescue efforts, the president said, adding that he has requested the use of Taipei City's rubber boats for the rescue work in southern Taiwan.
He noted that the rainfall broke 50-year records in southern Taiwan, causing widespread flooding.
"Rescue and relief efforts will be our top priority," Ma said.

The accumulated rainfall in the mountainous region of Fengchihu in Chiayi County had reached 2587 mm as of Sunday noon, causing the overflow of two rivers downstream -- the Pachang Creek and Niuchou Creek.

Ma originally wanted to visit Taitung in eastern Taiwan, but canceled the trip because the Taitung Airport was closed due to the effects of the typhoon. He also canceled two scheduled activities in Taipei.
Ma will visit Taimali and Jhihben in Taitung County Monday to inspect the damage there, according to the Presidential Office.

A six-story hotel in Jhihben township in Taitung County tumbled into a river around noon Sunday after it tilted on its foundations at an angle of 20 degrees Sunday morning. The building was destabilized by a landslide and floods that washed away a nearby 200-meter area.
Meanwhile, Premier Liu said on a tour of Pingtung County in southern Taiwan Sunday that a disaster prevention center headed by Interior Minister Liao Liou- yi would be set up.
Liu also said that he would stay in southern Taiwan overnight before returning to Taipei Monday.
The premier said that in addition to the efforts of the Eighth Army Corps stationed in southern Taiwan, other military units, including engineering and chemical experts, would also pitch in.

As of 8 p.m. Sunday, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said it had deployed 2,877 military servicemen and 85 armored and other vehicles to assist in the rescue and relief work. A total of 1,236 residents had been evacuated by the military, the MND added.

Liu went to the Pingtung County Reserve Command in the morning for a briefing on the damage in the county and to mobilize the military to assist with the relief work. He then visited Pingtung County's disaster emergency center for an update on what kind of support was needed.
In the afternoon, Liu rode on a rubber raft to Linbian township, which is submerged in flood waters half-a-story high.
Linbian has become a "water world," with rubber boats shuttling around, rescuing stranded residents and delivering food and other necessities.
Some of the township residents who have been unwilling to leave their homes waved to the premier from the second floors, and Liu waved back.
The raft that Liu was traveling on was towing a rubber boat filled with food and other necessities, and some residents lowered baskets or waded through the floodwaters to collect the supplies.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo went to Kaohsiung to inspect the collapsed Shuangyuan Bridge that connected Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties.
Initial estimates put the number of collapsed bridges at around 20, the worst infrastructure damage in a decade, National Central University said Sunday.
The university's Center for Bridge Engineering Research said that the damage to bridges was even worse than in September 1999 when Taiwan was struck by a magnitude-7.3 earthquake.
Meanwhile, the first group of rescue workers from Taipei City arrived in Pingtung County at 6 a.m Sunday, and went immediately to Linbian.
Taipei City has deployed 130 rescue workers and 38 motor boats and rubber dinghies to southern Taiwan, while Taipei County has sent more than 100 rescue personnel and large water pumps.
The weather bureau forecast that rainfall from Typhoon Morakot will reach 2900 mm in Chiayi County and 2700 mm in Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties, all record volumes in recorded history.
Central Weather Bureau meteorologists have predicted more rain for the next two days.
Agricultural losses had topped NT$2.1 billion as of 2 p.m. Sunday, the Council of Agriculture said.
The storm, which swept through Taiwan Friday night, has left seven persons dead, 32 injured and 46 unaccounted for as of 7 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 10, or the 20th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1821: Missouri is admitted as the 24th state of the United States.
1846: The Smithsonian Institute is established in Washington as a center for scientific research with a bequest from English scientist James Smithson.
1874: Herbert Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, is born. His belief in individual freedom led him to reject federal relief for unemployment during the Depression and lost him the 1932 election to Franklin D. Roosevelt.
1894: Varahagiri Venkata Giri, president of India from 1969 to 1974, is born. He was prominent in India's labor movement.
1904: During the Russo-Japanese War, the Russian fleet suffers heavy loses when the Japanese fleet blocks it from escaping from Port Arthur in the Battle of the Yellow Sea.
1913: The Treaty of Bucharest is signed, ending the second Balkan War and partitioning Macedonia among Serbia, Greece, Romania and Bulgaria.
1926: Northwest Airlines is established in Chicago.
1944: Yicheng County in Hupei Province changes its name to Chihchung County in memory of the bravery of Gen. Chang Chih-chung who died in action during the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1944: American forces recapture Guam from the Japanese after three weeks of fighting in which only 500 of the 18,000 defending Japanese troops survived and surrendered.
1945: Robert H. Goddard, American pioneer of rocket science, dies at the age of 63. He conducted the first successful launch of a liquid-propellant rocket in 1926. The rocket climbed 184 feet (56 meters) into the air at a speed of about 60 miles (97 kilometers) per hour.
1946: Gen. George C. Marshall, a special envoy of U.S. President Harry Truman to China on a mission to mediate the civil war between the Nationalists and the Chinese communists, issues a statement declaring that his efforts have failed.
1950: U.S. State Department official Karl L. Rankin arrives in Taipei as charge d'affaires of the U.S. Embassy.
1961: Britain applies to join the European Economic Community.
1966: Orbiter I, the first American moon satellite, is launched from Cape Kennedy.
1975: Flight service between the Republic of China and Japan resumes after the ROC government announced on April 20, 1974 the termination of the Taiwan-Japan flights of China Airlines and Japan Airlines.
1979: The newly completed Keelung-Suao Highway is opened to traffic.
1981: The joint meeting of the Second Asian Conference of the International Association for Cross-Cultural Psychology and the First Asian Conference of the International Council of Psychologists opens in Taipei.
1990: The ROC government declares its support of a United Nations call for world sanctions against Iraq over its invasion of Kuwait.
1993: The New KMT Alliance breaks with the ruling Kuomintang and forms the New Party.
1993: Shih Yueh-po, a Chinese passenger, hijacks a mainland Chinese Boeing 767 passenger plane to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan.
1998: Some 2,000 people die in floods in China.
1998: Prince Al-Muhtadee Billah, eldest son of Sultan Hassan Bolkiah of Brunei, is proclaimed heir to the throne.
1999: The Republic of China inaugurates Asia's first flight recorder laboratory, allowing local personnel to analyze aircraft flight recorder (black box) data rather than having to send such data to a third country for analysis.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian accuses Beijing of hypocrisy in terms of its definition of "one China," and reiterates Taiwan's rejection of Beijing's demand that it embrace "one China" on Beijing's terms.
2001: After being on death row for almost 10 years, mainland Chinese hijackers Cho Chang-jen and Chiang Hung-chun are executed at the Taipei Prison for kidnap and murder.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to be trusted by one's friends. If a man does not command the obedience of the members of his family, he will not be trusted by his friends."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Morakot moves away, leaving a wet tail

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau reported Monday that tropical storm Morakot has left the island, moving west into eastern China, but torrential rain will continue in central and southern Taiwan for one more day.
The weather bureau urged people living in mountainous areas to be on the alert for possible landslides and mudslides in the next few days.
The storm, which was a typhoon when it hit Taiwan Friday, wreaked havoc on the island over the weekend with strong winds and extremely heavy rains.
Rainfall from Morakot reached 2777 mm on Alishan in Chiayi County, which was the highest volume in the island's recorded history, according to the weather bureau.

Meanwhile, the Council of Agriculture (COA) issued "red alerts" for 519 locations in 12 counties around the country that are at high risk from rockslides or mudslides as a result of the typhoon's heavy rains.
The council said that after a "red alert" is issued, the local government is responsible for warning local residents and implementing evacuation procedures if necessary.
The council also issued "yellow alerts" for 338 areas in 163 villages in 14 counties around the country that are also at risk from rockslides and mudslides in the next few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Astronomy exhibit provides good scientific education: deputy minister

TEXT.P: The National Science Council's (NSC's) astronomy exhibition provides a good opportunity for people to better understand the universe, Deputy Minister of Education Lin Tsong-ming, said Monday.

"The universe is so immense that human beings only know about a tiny part of it. Therefore, I encourage students to leave the classroom, explore the sky and treat nature as our best teacher," Lin said at the opening ceremony of the "400 Years of Heaven Gazing" exhibit.

The exhibition, which is the major activity in the NSC's 10th scientific season, is being held to celebrate the 400th anniversary of Galileo's first observation of space and International Year of Astronomy 2009.

Chen Tai-jen, vice president of National Taiwan University, said at the opening ceremony that astronomy is both an ancient and a modern science that is closely linked to literature, history and culture.
"This exhibition, which utilizes Taiwan's advanced projection technology, will educate the public by presenting scientific information in a form that is easily understandable," Chen said.
The exhibition has been organized by the NSC, Ministry of Education, Astronomical Society of the Republic of China, Taipei City Government, and National Taiwan University's Institute of Astrophysics.
The presentation is theatrical, featuring 3D projections, digital audio and video displays and multi-touch interaction installations to showcase scientific knowledge, according to the NSC.

It is composed of 10 theme areas, such as the "Starlight Gallery, " "Solar System Gallery, " "Conversations through Time and Space, " "Romantic Starlight, " "The Leaning Tower of Pisa, " "Giant Eyes of the Astronomers, " "The Heavenly Sound of Nature" and "Hands-On Activities -- Discovering the Universe, " the council said.
Seminars given by noted scientists from abroad will also provide a lively experience for visitors, it added.

The exhibition is scheduled to run though Sept. 13 at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall's Second and Third Display Rooms and Art Gallery. Admission to the exhibit is free and more information is available at http://www.astronomy2009.tw/scisea.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water Resources Agency chief to assume responsibility for flooding

TEXT.P: Water Resources Agency (WRA) Director-General Chen Shen-hsien pledged Monday to assume political responsibility for the severe flooding caused by Typhoon Morakot in southern Taiwan.
"I'm always prepared. When the rescue work is finished, I'll assume responsibility (for the disaster), " Chen told the Central News Agency.

Chen made the remarks one day after President Ma Ying-jeou demanded that the WRA critically examine whether the extensive flooding was the result of a natural catastrophe or ineffective flood prevention efforts.
Ma said the WRA should determine if the funds allocated for flood prevention projects had been used properly, and the agency should not pass the buck.
Chen promised that the WRA will definitely review the matter.

According to Chen, while the eight-year, NT$80 billion flood prevention project launched in 2006 targeted rivers within the jurisdiction of local governments, the heavy rainfall triggered by Typhoon Morakot caused the rapid overflow of larger rivers in areas that are under the central government.
Every flood prevention project has its limits, he said.

For example, he said, the flood prevention facilities built along rivers in local government areas were designed to withstand 50-year floods, and those constructed along rivers within central government areas were designed to withstand 100-year events.
"However, the rainfall brought by Typhoon Morakot exceeded the peak volume expected for a 200-year flood," he said.
The recurrence intervals refer to the average number of events over the specified period of time. For example, a 100-year flood is one that has a 1 percent chance of occurring in any given year.
To protect people from such disastrous flooding, it is important that rainfall volumes are forecast accurately so that residents in flood-prone areas can be evacuated early, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU shows outstanding performance in 2009 National Robotics Contest

TEXT.P: Teams from National Taiwan University (NTU) were the big winners in the 2009 National Robotics Contest, winning two of the three championships, a sponsor of the competition said Monday.

The contest was held at the Taipei International Robot Show, sponsored by the Industrial Development Bureau, the Taiwan Shin Kong Security (SKS security) and Hiwin Technologies Corp., held by the Precision Machinery Research Development Center and directed by the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Ministry of Education.

It was divided into three main themes: home service robots, intelligent robotic arms and security robots. The purpose of the contest was to incite student creativity, discover new talent and stimulate academic and industry cooperation, with the aim of spurring robot industry development in Taiwan.
The 102 teams were competing for prize money totaling NT$3.18 million (US$971,140).
The NTU teams won the Intelligent Security Robot Contest held by SKS securities and the Intelligent Robotic Arm Contest held by Hiwin Technologies Corp.

Team Rambo, which won the championship, explained that their security robot was tailor-made for the competition. It is a multi- sensor fusion-based wheeled robot equipped with remote control, motion planning, obstacle avoidance, image transmit and processing, automatic message sending, environment detection and voice detection. In addition, the robot can also detect unauthorized intruders.
Team Adam, the other winning NTU team, won the Intelligent Robotic Arm competition.

Taiwanese students have displayed ever-increasing expertise in robot technology. In 2007, seven top awards were won by Taiwanese students in the World Robot Olympiad, and the following year, 12 medals were won at an international mini- robot contest in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Modern-day 'Xu Xiakes' promote low-carbon travel

TEXT.P: A group of environmentally conscious scholars have formed an association to promote a travel style that would have little impact on the natural environment, academic sources said Monday.

"Travel should not just mean eating sumptuously and staying in luxury accommodations," said Tao Yi-huang, an associate professor at Tungnan University in Shenkeng, Taipei, who is also chief executive of the Taiwan Society of Xu Xiake.

Tao took issue with the way mountain resorts are promoted, saying he is always disgusted at TV commercials that feature a sport utility vehicle (SUV) driving to a lush mountain and disgorging a family that barbecues and plays on riverside rocks or lawns.
"That is not a way to enjoy ecotourism, but rather a way to destroy the natural ecology, " Tao said in a recent interview with a local paper.
The main purpose of his association is to study and promote eco-friendly travel styles, he said.
The group is named after Xu Xiake (1587-1641) , a famous travel enthusiast and geographer of ancient China's Ming Dynasty (1368-1644).

Xu Xiake, who began to travel when he was 22 years old, explored almost half of China. His travel diary, "Travel Notes of Xu Xiake, " is the earliest such record in China. It details geographical information on the regions he visited, and is the world's earliest record of Karst landscapes and writings on how they were formed.

Xu was an environmentalist and an ecotourism expert who slammed the rulers of his time for their slash-and-burn agricultural policies that decimated the mountains and forests and he identified the adverse impact of mining, husbandry and travel on the ecology and natural landscape, Tao said.
On his long journeys, Xu endured many hardships and often slept in the open.
"Our society needs to learn from Xu's spirit of overcoming hardships and turning them into low-carbon, eco-friendly travel and lifestyles," he suggested.
"When our group travels, our first choice is to walk or take public transport," Tao said.
"We invariably choose to eat locally grown farm produce, " he added, arguing that it is wrong for restaurants to always focus on offering delicacies from around the world.
Tao said his group would never stay at hotels or bed-and-breakfasts that are built on slopes.

"Such accommodations may offer beautiful mountain views, but their construction is greatly detrimental to water and soil conservation, " Tao said. "We like to stay at places that were built with locally available materials, which would have saved transportation resources."
Tao recalled that some of his students once asked his advice regarding a tour of Cingjing Farm in central Taiwan that they were planning.

"I told them to choose an affordable B&B that is located in a legally permitted area away from the main roads, properly equipped to treat garbage, and adheres to water and soil conservation practices," Tao recalled.
His students managed to find accommodation that met all those standards, but only after an extensive online search, he said.

"Travel planning should be part of students' education. Travel should not be just for fun -- they should be able to learn something in the process of arranging transportation and accommodation, " Tao added.

With environmental and health consciousness growing, Tao said, low-carbon travel is becoming increasingly popular in Taiwan, China and Hong Kong, and consequently, interest in Xu Xiake is also widening.
"Like-minded people in China and Hong Kong have also formed associations to study and promote Xu's legacy," Tao said.
According to Tao, his society maintains regular contact and has had academic exchanges with various Xu Xiake groups in China and Hong Kong.
Tao said his group usually organizes two to three local or overseas tours per year.

"Besides enjoying the natural scenery, we also evaluate whether the tourist facilities and promotional approaches in the various countries adhere to the spirit of low-carbon use and energy conservation," he said.
In his view, most of Taiwan's tourist spots are not sufficiently "low carbon" in their operations.
One of the exceptions is the Maoao community in Taipei County's Gongliao township on the northeastern coast, he said.

"Maoao's appeal lies in its low-profile development. It used to be a thriving fishing town, but it lost its steam with the migration of its young residents. It is re-emerging by developing ecotourism, " Tao said.

Instead of building new tourist facilities, the local residents have converted old houses into cafes and B&Bs. The lands are being used for eco-friendly farming and for the processing of locally produced seaweed into jellies and health foods, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Vision Taiwan raises funds for victims of Typhoon Morakot

TEXT.P: The local chapter of the Christian charity World Vision said Monday it has launched a fund raising program and is providing immediate relief items such as food and clean water for families in areas devastated by Typhoon Morakot.
World Vision Taiwan said it will request more help from its headquarters in its relief efforts.

Typhoon Morakot hovered over Taiwan Aug. 7-8, lashing the country with powerful winds and torrential downpours. By early Sunday, it had dumped a record 2500 mm of rain on the southernmost county of Pingtung, causing severe flooding in at least three coastal townships.
As of 8 a.m. Monday, flooding had left 12 persons dead, 32 injured and 52 unaccounted for islandwide.

World Vision Taiwan said in a press release Monday that it had been working in some of the affected areas for many years and already had resources in place to quickly start relief work in the wake of Typhoon Morakot.

In addition to food and cleaning supplies, emergency kits containing flashlights, radios, raincoats, gloves, toothbrushes, toothpaste and towels were also distributed, according to World Vision Taiwan.

As of Sunday evening, World Vision had distributed 400 kits at an emergency shelter in Taimali Township, Taitung, and 60 cases of mineral water and 284 packets of relief supplies at a shelter in Jiadung Township, Pingtung.

"Many of the affected people live in remote areas and the roads there are in bad condition. The roads and bridges are flooded or blocked by mudslides, fallen trees and other large debris, " stated Wesley Chen, manager of World Vision's Southern Area Office, in the press release.
"We are working to find a way to bring aid to those who can't reach the emergency shelters," he said.

The charity said that as the scope of the damage is vast, it is calling for more relief supplies, rescue vehicles and volunteers. It called on corporations and individuals to join the effort by donating funds or relief resources.
It has listed as priority items such as rice, instant noodles, canned food, oil, cooking utensils, mineral water, clothes, blankets, mosquito nets, sleeping bags, and cleaning materials.

In addition, World Vision Taiwan has opened an account through its 30-Hour Famine Campaign with the aim of raising NT$25 million (US$ 0.76 million) for emergency relief and rehabilitation of families affected by the storm.
Donations can be made to account number 15752467 (Account: World Vision Taiwan) or online at http: //www.30hf.org.tw/English/Default.aspx, the charity said.
People who wish to donate material goods can contact World Vision's Southern Regional Office at 07-7223608 ext. 66, or Hsu Yu-hua, supervisor of World Vision Taiwan's Taitung Center, at 0912151084.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Morakot rise to NT$4.2 billion

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Morakot had soared to NT$4.2 billion (US$127.9 million) as of Monday, according to statistics released that day by the Cabinet- level Council of Agriculture (COA).
The statistics show that damage to crops amounted to nearly NT$2 billion (US$60.9 million) , with 25 percent of the crops on 33,134 hectares of farmland lost.
Bananas suffered the heaviest damage, with 4,431 hectares ravaged by strong winds and flooding.
Some NT$48.84 million-worth of poultry perished in floods caused by the storm, while losses in the aquaculture sector totaled NT$1.53 billion, with 1,959 hectares of fish farms damaged.
Damage to agricultural facilities amounted to NT$138.42 million, and damage to forestry was estimated at NT$14.63 million.

Farmers in Kaohsiung, Pingtung and Hualien counties who suffered heavy losses can apply for cash relief or low-interest loans from the government, in accordance with the Agricultural Natural Disaster Relief Regulations, COA officials said.

Farmers in Taichung County who suffered losses can apply for low-interest loans from the government, while those in Yunlin, Tainan and Taitung counties can apply for cash relief, according to a COA announcement.

DOC.HEADLINE: Southeast coastline swamped with driftwood after Typhoon Morakot

TEXT.P: Flooding from Typhoon Morakot's record rainfall washed many uprooted trees and deadwood in the mountainous areas of Taitung County into the Pacific Ocean, some witnesses said Monday.
"Some beaches are covered with uprooted trees and driftwood, stretching 50 kilometers along the shoreline," according to one witness.
The mountainous regions in Taitung County recorded accumulated rainfall of more than 1000 mm from Friday to Sunday, according to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).
The heavy rains caused rivers in the county to overflow downstream.
"Driftwood is a common sight along the beaches in Taitung County after a typhoon," said Liu Chiung-hsi, a professor at the Life Science Department, National Taitung University.
"Taimali," the name of one of the driftwood covered beaches, means timber in Taiwanese, he noted.
One witness said that he spotted driftwood floating along a 100-kilometer stretch of coastline, from Taimali beach to Jinzun Fishery Harbor.
People were flocking to Fugang Fishery Harbor to view what one witness described as the most amazing sight in his experience.

DOC.HEADLINE: Disaster not necessarily in direct ratio with forecast: CWB

TEXT.P: The head of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Monday that the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot is not necessarily in line with or in direct ratio to CWB weather forecasts that failed to predict the disaster.

CWB Director Shin Tsai-chin said weather forecasting is a science, but the aftermath of a typhoon involves assorted factors. He noted that a typhoon forecast cannot be translated in a direct ratio to the scale of the disaster caused by a typhoon.
It is therefore unfair to lay the blame for the ballooning aftermath of Typhoon Morakot at the feet of the weather bureau, Shin said.
"The weather bureau does not take that kind of responsibility, " Shin pointed out.
He reiterated that the CWB makes its typhoon forecasts in accordance with weather charts showing the storm system's direction and strength.

The CWB's accuracy in forecasting a typhoon's strength and direction is about on a par with that of the United States and Japan, Shin said, adding that the bureau renews its typhoon forecasts every three hours and notifies every local government rescue command center in a timely manner.

He stressed that the CWB fulfilled its responsibilities in forecasting Morakot and has made accurate precipitation forecasts, noting, for example, that the CWB issued a sea warning for Morakot Aug. 5 and forecast that rainfall in mountainous areas of southern Taiwan would reach 800 mm.
On Aug. 7, he said, the weather bureau adjusted upward the rainfall forecast for mountainous areas in southern Taiwan to 1,100 mm.
Shin said weather forecasting is always plagued with uncertainty and added that there is room for the CWB to improve its forecasting ability.
"We will make greater efforts to forecast possible disasters, " Shin pledged.
Shin made the remarks after local media had reported that day that President Ma Ying-jeou had criticized the CWB for not having forecast Typhoon Morakot "precisely."

DOC.HEADLINE: Regular cross-strait flights scheduled to begin Aug. 31

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) confirmed Monday that regularly scheduled direct cross-Taiwan Strait flights will begin Aug. 31.
A CAA official said the arrangement was agreed upon between China and Taiwan during the third round of cross-strait talks held in the Chinese city of Nanjing April 26.

The agreement allows for 270 regular flights per week between China and Taiwan, a big increase compared to the existing 108 charter flights permitted each week. In addition, China has agreed to open up six more destinations to Taiwanese carriers, bringing to 27 the total number of Chinese destinations served by the flights.

Since the inauguration of daily chartered flights last December, they have enjoyed great popularity due to high demand, but have also received severe criticism for the high prices charged by the various carriers operating the routes. With the advent of regular direct flights, the government hopes airfares will become less expensive and already, carriers on both sides of the strait have begun cutting fares in anticipation of the imminent opening.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ministry opens accounts to take donations for typhoon victims

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) opened two special accounts Monday to accept donations from the public for the people who have been affected by flooding brought by Typhoon Morakot over the weekend.
"Members of the public are welcome to make donations to help the typhoon victims," Vice Interior Minister Lin Chung-sen said at a news conference to announce the opening of the accounts.

In response to Lin's call, the Buddha's Light International Association (BLIA) immediately donated NT$35 million (US$1.06 million) to the relief efforts, handed over by Kuomintang Legislator Wu Chih-yang, who concurrently serves as BLIA chief supervisor.
"BLIA President Master Hsin Yun took the initiative to make the donation in hopes of inspiring more people to support the fund-raising campaign to help flood victims," Wu said.
According to Wu, NT$25 million of the BLIA donation was contributed by the association's affiliates in China.
As of noon Monday, the storm had left 14 people dead, 32 injured and 51 unaccounted for, according to statistics released by the Central Emergency Operation Center.
On behalf of the government, Lin expressed gratitude to the Buddhist organization for its generous contribution.
"We hope more individuals and corporations will follow suit, " he added.

Donors can remit funds either to the Interior Ministry's special account at the Central Bank of the Republic of China (account number 269981) or the ministry's Post Office account (account number 19595889), Lin said.
In addition to donating instant noodles, mineral water and bread, Uni-President Group further donated NT$10 million in cash to help with post-disaster rehabilitation projects.
Meanwhile, Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor Inc. also donated NT$30 million to the MOI's post-disaster relief fund.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT postpones vote in view of typhoon damage

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) announced Monday that it has postponed its election of Central Committee members from Aug. 16 to Aug. 22, in light of the devastation caused by Typhoon Morakot in southern Taiwan over the weekend.
Lee Chien-jung, director of the KMT's cultural promotion department, made the announcement at a news conference following a weekly party meeting.
"Rescue efforts are our top concern now, and the KMT will work with local governments to launch rescue missions and help with the cleanup and recovery work," Lee said.

According to Lee, KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung has ordered that the vote be postponed for a week to Aug. 22, in view of the severe typhoon damage in the southern regions, which is the worst in 50 years.
During the one-week period, the 1,000-plus party delegates vying for the 315 posts will not be permitted to solicit votes or hold any other campaign activities, he said.
KMT Vice Chairman Wu Dun-yih said the party has opened a dedicated bank account for typhoon relief donations by party members and other people in the society.
Wu Poh-hsiung and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng have already donated NT$2 million (US$61,000) and NT$1 million, respectively, while Wu Dun-yih has given NT$200,000, Lee said.
Lee said the KMT, along with its overseas chapters, hopes to work with the public to help with the recovery work in southern Taiwan, and has informed its members of the donation drive.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC July sales hit 11-month high

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., Ltd. (TSMC) reported consolidated net sales of approximately NT$31.17 billion (US$949.75 million) in July, representing a month-on-month growth of 17.6 percent, the company said in a statement released Monday.
The figure represented an 11-month high, thanks to increasing demand for personal computers, mobile phones and other consumer electronics products.

The world's largest contract chipmaker garnered NT$144.89 billion in revenues on a consolidated basis in the first seven months of the year, a figure that represented, however, a drop of 30.2 percent compared to the same period of 2008, according to the statement.
TSMC anticipated that its sales would undergo drops in August and September based on an earlier assessment that put its net sales in Q3 at between NT$88 billion and NT$90 billion.
The company assessed that its Q3 products will generate a gross margin of between 46.5 percent and 48.5 percent, marking a growth of 0.3 percent points-2.3 percentage points compared with Q2.
Its operating margin is expected to stand at between 35 percent and 37 percent in Q3, also marking an increase from the 33.9 percent in Q2, the company said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Monday:
Liberty Times: The government should be responsible for failing to relieve flood victims effectively.

The government of President Ma Ying-jeou has been trying to shift the responsibility for the disastrous flooding caused by Typhoon Morakot to local governments, claiming that they did not inform the central government of the disaster in time.
Taiwan is a tiny island, with easy access to any part of it, so why should the disaster-relief work be divided between the local and central governments?
The relief work should be carried out by one unified agency, which would be more efficient.
Also, flood prevention is more important than rescue operations afterward, and the government's past flood-control efforts have concentrated on the dredging of rivers and the building of levees.

This has proved useless by the flooding caused by Morakot, and the government should take into account the development of land, industry and cities while addressing the flood problems in the long term.
China Times: Flooding a problem that cannot be addressed even by the Control Yuan.
Just after the Control Yuan corrected 14 agencies at once for negligence in their duties that led to last year's flooding, Typhoon Morakot triggered another flood in Taiwan.
Inaccurate weather forecasting has been blamed as one reason for the disaster because it failed to warn people of the approaching torrential rain brought by the typhoon.

The government's foot-dragging in managing the island's rivers properly is another reason for the flooding, which is proved by the many hotels that have sprouted in flood-prone areas around the country.
Some low-lying areas are also predisposed to flooding because of land subsidence caused by the overdrawing of underground water.
We urge the country's political parties to unite to solve this problem.
Apple Daily: A test of the quality of public projects
We should not blame the government for the flooding in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, as it was an act of God.
However, the catastrophe gives us the chance to examine the quality of the public infrastructure that collapsed or suffered damage during the storm.
Did the contractors collude with officials during the construction of these projects? We urge the government to take this chance to stamp out corrupt officials exposed by the disaster.
United Daily News: Working together to help flood victims get back on their feet

The flooding brought by Typhoon Morakot has proved that the country's past efforts at riverine management have not been sufficient, so more needs to be done to prevent future disasters from the point of view of land safety, environmental protection and land management.

The storm dumped more than 2,900 mm of rain on Taiwan in just three days -- the equivalent of eight months' of rain for the island under normal circumstances -- so no wonder the precipitation resulted in such unprecedented flooding.
The Central Weather Bureau failed to foresee the storm's power, forecasting it as a beneficial typhoon that would quench the drought-stricken island's thirst for rain.
The flooding also bore out the fact that Taiwan's land development has exceeded natural limits and should be brought into check immediately.
Man should learn from the disaster that he has to live with nature rather than compete against it.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign Ministry thanks Japan for typhoon condolences

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) thanked the Japanese government Monday for expressing condolences for the stricken families in areas devastated by Typhoon Morakot.

Peter Tsai, secretary-general of the MOFA's Association of East Asian Relations, told CNA that Naohiro Tsutsumi, director-general of the Taipei Office of the Interchange Association -- the de facto Japanese embassy in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic relations -- called him Aug. 8 on behalf of the Japanese government to express condolences over the situation, and offered help if necessary, which MOFA deputy spokesman James Chang said would be taken up if necessary.

Typhoon Morakot hovered over Taiwan Aug. 7-8, lashing parts of the country with powerful wind and torrential rain. By early Sunday, it had dumped a record 2,500 mm of rain on the southernmost county of Pingtung, causing severe flooding in at least three coastal townships.
As of 12 p.m. Monday, the flooding there and elsewhere had left 14 people dead, 32 injured and 51 unaccounted for islandwide.
The Foreign Ministry also received a letter from Japan's representative to Taiwan, Masaki Saito, who expressed concern about the serious flooding in southern Taiwan, Tsai said.

In addition, Tetsuya Hirose, secretary-general of the Japan-based Asia-Pacific Parliamentarians' Union, which will hold its 40th annual conference in Taipei Aug. 11, also expressed best wishes to the storm victims, according to Tsai.
"We sincerely appreciate their gestures in the wake of the devastation caused by Typhoon Morakot," Tsai added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU Hospital launches remote health care services for high-risks

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) launched a remote health care center Monday that will provide more timely care to high risk heart disease patients or those with secondary risk factors.
The center will enable case managers to monitor patients who have received cardiosurgeries or have suffered from heart disease via equipment installed at the patient's home.

Dr. Ho Yi-lun, director of the NTUH Heart Failure Center and one of the supporting doctors working at the Remote Health Care Center, said the patient only needs to be hooked up to the equipment for eight minutes to have his or her data transmitted to the center.
The data will give a clear picture of the patient's condition, including blood pressure, heart rate. blood oxygen, and blood sugar and also provide an electrocardiogram, Ho said.
Once they receive the data, case managers will in turn offer advice to the patient or alert presiding doctors if further medical attention is necessary.

Dr. Ke Wen-cheh, director of the NTUH Department of Trauma Medicine and another of the doctors participating in the new center's operations, said the service will be a big help to many recovering cardiosurgery patients who are afraid to leave the hospital even if they are physically able to do so.

"The equipment at home will allow such patients to have a clearer picture of their post-surgical situations, and the center will help them determine whether they should return to the hospital or just stay at home," Ke said.
Even before Monday's official opening, the center already had 14 patients under its care, including three in Shanghai, one in Xiamen and 10 in Taiwan.

A Mrs. Cheng, now living in Shanghai, has had her condition constantly monitored through NTUH equipment installed at her Shanghai home, and she receives regular advice from the center's case managers and doctors.

Miss Wu in Taiwan, another NTUH patient who is taking medication to control her coronary artery disease, said the remote health care service has allowed her to live a normal life since she signed up for it last year.

At a news conference Monday, Wu said that since being "connected" to the center's monitoring system, she has felt less stress and more at peace, calling the equipment at her home a"shepherd" through which doctors monitor her condition without her having to go to the hospital.

To get access to the monitoring system, a patient needs to pay a rental fee of NT$3,000-NT$4,000 per month for the equipment and another NT$2,000 per month in monthly management fees, according to a center spokeswoman.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.026 to close at NT$32.818.
A total of US$750 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.94 and dropped to the day's low of NT$32.72.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hundreds unaccounted for in mountainous village in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: An estimated 500 to 600 people remain unaccounted for Monday after mudslides triggered by Typhoon Morakot hit an isolated mountain village in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County, according to rescued villagers.

"Only 44 residents of Siaolin managed to avoid the mudslides, and the remaining 500 to 600 residents are unaccounted for, " said a family member of residents believed to be trapped in the village and possible buried alive.
The weeping family member urged the government to not waste even a second in launching an operation to rescue the trapped villagers.
Earlier in the day, two army helicopters managed to airlift 26 villagers from Siaolin and two more from neighboring Tajin to safety.

Army authorities originally planned to airlift all 44 of the Siaolin villagers who managed to flee from their mudslide-struck homes, but rescue efforts were suspended after four sorties due to bad weather and low visibility.
The National Airborne Service Corps (NASC) was also forced to cancel its plan to deliver relief supplies to two other mudslide-struck mountain villages -- Namasia and Taoyuan.

The staggering amount of rainfall delivered by Morakot over the weekend led to massive flooding and landslides that wreaked havoc in Kaohsiung County's mountainous Maolin, Taoyuan, Namasia, and Jiasian villages and part of Liouguei, cutting them off from the outside world.

Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing took an NASC flight Monday morning to see for himself the situation in the isolated villages, but the helicopter could not land when it flew to Siaolin because of poor weather.
Some rescued villagers criticized Yang for failing to take timely precautionary measures and procrastinating in organizing relief efforts, but Yang did not directly respond.

He simply said all-out rescue efforts could only begin after water levels in major rivers had retreated, as all bridges and roads linking the mountainous villages with the outside world have been severely damaged.
Meanwhile, Minister of the Interior Liao Liou-yi visited Kaoshiung County's Chishan Junior High School, a post-disaster operation base.

Some local officials complained that the central government was slow in responding to the region's worst flooding in half a century. Liao said that he has asked the military to enter the disaster zones, weather permitting, to rescue stranded villagers.

DOC.HEADLINE: President not planning to issue emergency decree after typhoon

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has no plans at present to issue an emergency decree to help clean up and rebuild parts of Taiwan that have been devastated by floods triggered by Typhoon Morakot, the president's spokesman said Monday.

The president believes existing government mechanisms are sufficient to deal with the situation and will put the Executive Yuan in charge of the operation rather than issuing an emergency decree, said Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chih.

Earlier in the day, ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislators urged Ma to issue such a decree to help facilitate rescue and recovery missions in dealing with the widespread destruction wreaked by Typhoon Marakot, which has left at least 15 people dead.

KMT legislators, including Hung Hsiu-chu, Yang Chiung-ying and Wu Ching-chih, suggested that the move would enable rescue operations to be conducted more efficiently, without legal barriers, based on the experience of the Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake and the Aug. 7 floods of 1959.
An emergency decree would permit government agencies at different levels to raise funds to assist, accommodate or evacuate victims in a more flexible way in case of an emergency, Hung said.
Under Taiwan's Constitution, the president is authorized, in line with a resolution by the Executive Yuan, to issue an emergency decree in case of major natural or economic disasters.
The president must obtain the Legislative Yuan's approval within 10 days of issuing the decree. It becomes invalid if the legislature fails to give its consent.
Yang also said the party's legislative caucus is thinking of holding an extra meeting to discuss a possible supplemental budget to support post-typhoon reconstruction work.
In addition, many KMT legislators also donated a day of pay in line with a donation drive launched by the party.

Morakot, the worst typhoon in 50 years to pass through Taiwan, has caused huge damage to southern Taiwan, particularly in Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties, as a result of massive mudslides triggered by the storm's staggering amount of precipitation.
Agricultural, farm and fisheries losses have so far amounted to NT$4.2 billion (US$128 million), according to figures compiled by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).
As of Monday noon, 15 people were killed, 32 were injured, and 52 were missing, but those numbers were likely to rise as some people in mountain villages still remain unaccounted for.
In one village in Kaohsiung County, called Siaolin, 400-600 hundred residents are feared to have been buried alive by mudslides that completely covered their houses Sunday night.
An estimated 200 had been rescued as of Monday late afternoon. Roads leading to the area have been cut off and continuing bad weather has prevented a bigger rescue operation to be launched.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's stock prices edge higher

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed slightly higher Monday, the first trading day after a typhoon hit the island.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, advanced 14.22 points to close at 6,882.87, but failed to move above its one-month moving average of 6,885.
Taiwan's stock market was closed on Friday due to Typhoon Morakot over the weekend.

The local bourse opened at 6,858.87 Monday and quickly fell to the day's low of 6,836.96 before recovering, paced by a strong showing from cement and construction shares in anticipation of the need for major reconstruction projects to repair damage from the storm.
The bourse later hit a high of 6,909.16 before retreating.
A total of 6.46 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$99.40 billion (US$3.03 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks advancing the most at 2.8 percent. Construction shares added 1.9 percent, machinery and electronics issues rose 0.3 percent, and plastics and chemicals stocks surged 0.2 percent.
The other four major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff stocks, textile shares, and paper and pulp issues each losing 0.8 percent. Banking and financial issues shed 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,208 to 1,061, with 154 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$1.47 billion in shares.

Tourism stocks underperformed relative to the overall market due to the impact of Typhoon Morakot, which delivered massive amounts of rainfill that triggered the worst flooding in 50 years in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Platform created to help dogs victimized by typhoon

TEXT.P: The Animal Rescue Team Taiwan (ARTT) appealed to the public Monday for relief supplies to save dogs kept in shelters that survived the flooding triggered by Typhoon Morakot.

The group has created a new Chinese-language Web page at www.savedogs.org to provide updated information on typhoon-affected privately-run shelters in Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties, volunteer Nee Ching-tai told the Central News Agency.
At present, Nee said, the group has received reports that at least 10 shelters were damaged, leaving over 1,000 dogs trapped by floods and more than 100 dogs drowned or missing.
"The survivors are mostly suffering from low temperatures after being rescued from the floods," he said.

Nee said other volunteers have visited the flooded shelters and taken pictures to document how they have been affected by Morakot's strong winds and heavy rains that pummeled southern Taiwan over the weekend.
They hope that through the Web page, animal lovers will know how badly the dogs and their caregivers need help, and what they need to survive, Nee said.
The shelters' primary needs at present are medical supplies, old sheets, drinking water, dog food and financial support, as well as volunteers who can help shelter keepers rebuild the dogs' homes.

ARTT volunteer Chen Tzai-han said humans have not been the only victims of the disaster. Stray dog shelters have been devastated and suffered great losses but the media and rescue personnel have ignored the dogs' plight, she complained.
Nee warned that more dogs will die if the shelters do not quickly receive relief supplies and help to restore and disinfect the shelters.

DOC.HEADLINE: 100-plus survivors said to be found in mudslide-battered village

TEXT.P: More than 100 survivors from mudslide-battered Siaolin Village in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County have been located, a rescued villager said Monday, but the fate of hundreds more said to be trapped there remained unknown.

"I received a phone call from my friend at the Ministry of the Interior saying a military special warfare task force entered Siaolin by helicopter earlier in the day and discovered 100-plus residents, including adults and children, taking shelter at a cottage on an elevated platform," the villager said.
In response, Kaohsiung County's disaster relief center said it will send a helicopter Tuesday to inspect the situation and rescue survivors.

Some 1,313 people have their household registration in the village, but only a fraction of them live there year round. Because August is bamboo shoot harvesting season, however, and many people returned for Father's Day on Saturday, more people were thought to be there than usual.
Rescued villagers estimated there are still 300 to 400 individuals who remain unaccounted for and are feared trapped in homes caught in mudslides.
Siaolin was just one of the villages ambushed by flooding and landslides in Kaohsiung County that were triggered by the staggering amount of rainfall delivered by Morakot over the weekend.
The natural disasters also affected the mountainous villages of Maolin, Taoyuan, Namasia, and Jiasian and part of Liouguei, cutting them off from the outside world.

Most of the towns, including Siaolin, are accessible only by single mountain roads that often cross or follow along rivers. The roads and connecting bridges were unable to withstand the pressure of rampaging waters and buckled under the pressure.
Earlier in the day, two army helicopters managed to airlift 26 villagers from Siaolin and two more from neighboring Tajin to safety.

Army authorities originally planned to airlift all 44 of the Siaolin villagers who managed to flee from their mudslide-struck homes, but rescue efforts were suspended after four sorties due to bad weather and low visibility.
Defense Vice Minister Huang Yi-ping said if weather permits, military servicemen will enter Namasia and other isolated villages in the county's mountainous region Tuesday.

Responding to criticism that the military reacted slowly in providing post- disaster relief, Huang said the criticism was not fair and that the military has so far mobilized 6,079 service members to join rescue and relief operations.

Meanwhile, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) said it has delivered 142,000 cans of disinfectant and nine disinfecting vehicles to flood-stricken central, southern and eastern Taiwan for epidemic prevention and environmental cleanup.
As of noon Monday, the typhoon had left 14 people dead, 32 injured and 51 unaccounted for, according to government statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA guarantees adequate vegetable supplies in wake of typhoon

TEXT.P: Domestic vegetable supplies will remain sufficient despite the severe damage caused by Typhoon Morakot to crops around Taiwan, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Monday.

"The council and major farmers associations around the country have a total of 7,600 tons of refrigerated vegetables in stock, which will be enough to meet domestic market demand, " said Cheng Shou-liang, director of the COA's Statistics Department.

The COA has 1,200 tons of cabbage and Chinese cabbage in inventory and will gradually release the stock based on the amount available and prices prevailing in the Taipei Fruit and Vegetable Market, Cheng said.
The remaining 6,400 tons are being stored by various farmers groups, and this supply will be released to meet demand through various distribution channels, he added.
According to official statistics, the Taipei Fruit and Vegetable Market received 1,347 tons of vegetables for sale Aug. 5 when Morakot had yet to hit Taiwan.
From Aug. 6-9, the daily supply was 1,333 tons, 1,573 tons, 1,036 tons and 1,168 tons, respectively. The market was closed Monday.
The quantity available for sale Tuesday is estimated at around 1,050 tons, roughly equivalent to the daily average of 1,200 tons.
"Local residents shouldn't worry about a shortage of vegetables in the wake of the typhoon disaster, " Cheng said.

Typhoon Morakot lashed Taiwan with strong winds and staggering amounts of rainfall over the weekend, causing severe damage to crops, with agricultural losses topping NT$5.06 billion (US$153.33 million) as of 2 p.m. Monday.
With more losses still expected, the NT$5.06 billion in losses already stands as the seventh worst agricultural disaster in 18 years, Cheng said.
The worst agricultural disaster was caused by Typhoon Herbert in August 1996 when NT$18.08 billion in agricultural losses were recorded.

DOC.HEADLINE: Acceptance of Chinese bank cards expected to boost business

TEXT.P: The acceptance of bank cards issued by the China-based China UnionPay Co. in Taiwan is expected to generate NT$10 billion (US$304 million) in spending in local shops, a National Credit Card Center (NCCC) official said Monday.

Yin Chieh-fang, the center's deputy president, made the forecast based on estimated yearly spending of about NT$35 billion by Chinese visitors in Taiwan -- which assumes 600,000 tourists per year will spend an average of US$290 per day on five- to six-day tours.
Should Chinese tourists make 30 percent of their purchases with their China UnionPay bank cards, that would equate to some NT$10 billion per year, Yin explained.
Chinese cardholders have used the cards to spend NT$15 million since Taiwan began allowing their use Aug. 7, she noted.

Yin made the comments following a ceremony marking the acceptance of the cards in Taiwan, which was also attended by Financial Supervisory Commission Chairman Sean Chen and representatives from China.

According to government statistics, 380,000 Chinese tourists have visited the country since Taiwan opened its doors wider to them in July 2008, and they spent an average of US$295 during the first six months of the opening.

Chiu Fong-kai, a senior vice president at Taishin International Bank, was even more optimistic than Yin, estimating Chinese tourists would make NT$30 billion in purchases in Taiwan with the card every year.
Xu Luode, president of China UnionPay, also suggested that Chinese tourist spending in Taiwan is likely to rapidly increase thanks to the acceptance of its bank cards in Taiwan's shops.
Because of the potential commercial opportunity, the center predicted that the number of merchants accepting China UnionPay bank cards will rise from some 500 now to 20,000 by the end of this year.

The bank cards are currently accepted mostly in popular tourist destinations, such as Alishan, Sun Moon Lake, night markets and duty free shops at airports as well as scenic spots in Hualien, Taitung and Pingtung counties.

At the head of a delegation composed of executives from major Chinese banking institutions, Xu arrived last week to jointly announce with the National Credit Card Center the acceptance of the Chinese bank cards in Taiwan.

China UnionPay is China's only national electronic payment network, an umbrella network that covers more than 80 banking institutions. As the dominant player in China's bank card industry, it currently has more than 1.9 billion cards in circulation, which are accepted in 62 countries and regions outside China.

DOC.HEADLINE: 16 Chinese tourists stranded on Alishan

TEXT.P: A group of 16 Chinese tourists have been stranded on Alishan in southern Taiwan because of blocked roads leading down the mountain, an official of the Tourism Bureau said Monday.

Bureau spokeswoman Chi Yi-lin said the group, which arrived in Taiwan Aug. 6 and is scheduled to leave Tuesday, was stranded in the scenic mountain resort because of the typhoon, which brought torrential rains that have caused many roads and bridges to collapse, especially in southern Taiwan.
The official said that as soon as the traffic situation improves, the tourists can leave the mountain.
She said that when Typhoon Morakot struck Taiwan over the weekend. there were 9,481 Chinese tourists from 405 groups in Taiwan.
All of them are safe, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's people mobilized to donate money for typhoon victims

TEXT.P: Charity organizations and private business groups have begun efforts to collect donations and ship relief supplies to areas in southern Taiwan that were devastated by Typhoon Morakot over the weekend.
As of noon Monday, the storm had left 14 people dead and caused agricultural losses of over NT$5 billion, according to statistics released by the Central Emergency Operation Center.

Chen Shih-kuei, secretary-general of the Red Cross Society of the R.O.C., said Monday that with money most needed in the affected areas, his organization has arranged for 2,350 retail outlets around Taiwan to accept donations until Sept. 10.
The Red Cross will collect the donations from the stores, using them on relief and recovery efforts, Chen noted.

Meanwhile, FamilyMart, the second largest convenience store chain in Taiwan, is cooperating with the Red Cross in the delivery of relief supplies to the typhoon-affected area, including bread from the chain stores, a company spokesman said.
On Monday, the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation delivered enough instant rice and noodles to feed 200,000 people in the affected areas of Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Tainan counties.

The food is expected to allow typhoon victims to have warm meals in the coming days while they are busy restoring their homes, which have been badly damaged or in some cases destroyed by flooding from the storm, according to Tzu Chi volunteers.
The Hualien County-based charity organization has also mobilized a large-scale volunteer force to assist flood-hit families in cleaning their homes, they added.

In addition to Tzu Chi, the Buddha's Light International Association has donated NT$35 million (US$1.1 million) to relief efforts in southern Taiwan, while the Hong Kong Buddhist Association donated 5 million Hong Kong dollars (some NT$20 million).
Other donors included the Far Eastern Group and its affiliates.

Group headquarters donated NT$60 million to buy urgently needed supplies for the affected areas, Far Eastern Memorial Hospital sent medical personnel and equipment, and retail subsidiaries Sogo and Geant were preparing to ship daily necessities.
Far Eastone Telecommunications Co., one of Taiwan's leading mobile phone service providers, opened an account at the number "55135" for its mobile phone users to make donations.
Justice Minister Wang Ching-feng initiated a donation campaign on Monday, encouraging officials and employees in the ministry to donate one day in pay to help typhoon victims.

As to rescue efforts by the Ministry of National Defense, the military has mobilized 8,235 servicemen for rescue missions over the past three days, and they have helped evacuate 2,858 persons out of the storm-battered areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Platform created to help dogs victimized by typhoon

TEXT.P: The Animal Rescue Team Taiwan (ARTT) appealed to the public Monday for relief supplies to save dogs kept in shelters that survived the flooding triggered by Typhoon Morakot.

The group has created a new Chinese-language Web page at www.savedogs.org to provide updated information on typhoon-affected privately-run shelters in Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties, volunteer Nee Ching-tai told the Central News Agency.
At present, Nee said, the group has received reports that at least 10 shelters were damaged, leaving over 1,000 dogs trapped by floods and more than 100 dogs drowned or missing.
"The survivors are mostly suffering from low temperatures after being rescued from the floods," he said.

Nee said other volunteers have visited the flooded shelters and taken pictures to document how they have been affected by Morakot's strong winds and heavy rains that pummeled southern Taiwan over the weekend.
They hope that through the Web page, animal lovers will know how badly the dogs and their caregivers need help, and what they need to survive, Nee said.
The shelters' primary needs at present are medical supplies, old sheets, drinking water, dog food and financial support, as well as volunteers who can help shelter keepers rebuild the dogs' homes.

ARTT volunteer Chen Tzai-han said humans have not been the only victims of the disaster. Stray dog shelters have been devastated and suffered great losses but the media and rescue personnel have ignored the dogs' plight, she complained.
Nee warned that more dogs will die if the shelters do not quickly receive relief supplies and help to restore and disinfect the shelters.

DOC.HEADLINE: 100-plus survivors said to be found in mudslide-battered village

TEXT.P: More than 100 survivors from mudslide-battered Siaolin Village in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County have been located, a rescued villager said Monday, but the fate of hundreds more said to be trapped there remained unknown.

"I received a phone call from my friend at the Ministry of the Interior saying a military special warfare task force entered Siaolin by helicopter earlier in the day and discovered 100-plus residents, including adults and children, taking shelter at a cottage on an elevated platform," the villager said.
In response, Kaohsiung County's disaster relief center said it will send a helicopter Tuesday to inspect the situation and rescue survivors.

Some 1,313 people have their household registration in the village, but only a fraction of them live there year round. Because August is bamboo shoot harvesting season, however, and many people returned for Father's Day on Saturday, more people were thought to be there than usual.
Rescued villagers estimated there are still 300 to 400 individuals who remain unaccounted for and are feared trapped in homes caught in mudslides.
Siaolin was just one of the villages ambushed by flooding and landslides in Kaohsiung County that were triggered by the staggering amount of rainfall delivered by Morakot over the weekend.
The natural disasters also affected the mountainous villages of Maolin, Taoyuan, Namasia, and Jiasian and part of Liouguei, cutting them off from the outside world.

Most of the towns, including Siaolin, are accessible only by single mountain roads that often cross or follow along rivers. The roads and connecting bridges were unable to withstand the pressure of rampaging waters and buckled under the pressure.
Earlier in the day, two army helicopters managed to airlift 26 villagers from Siaolin and two more from neighboring Tajin to safety.

Army authorities originally planned to airlift all 44 of the Siaolin villagers who managed to flee from their mudslide-struck homes, but rescue efforts were suspended after four sorties due to bad weather and low visibility.
Defense Vice Minister Huang Yi-ping said if weather permits, military servicemen will enter Namasia and other isolated villages in the county's mountainous region Tuesday.

Responding to criticism that the military reacted slowly in providing post- disaster relief, Huang said the criticism was not fair and that the military has so far mobilized 6,079 service members to join rescue and relief operations.

Meanwhile, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) said it has delivered 142,000 cans of disinfectant and nine disinfecting vehicles to flood-stricken central, southern and eastern Taiwan for epidemic prevention and environmental cleanup.
As of noon Monday, the typhoon had left 14 people dead, 32 injured and 51 unaccounted for, according to government statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA guarantees adequate vegetable supplies in wake of typhoon

TEXT.P: Domestic vegetable supplies will remain sufficient despite the severe damage caused by Typhoon Morakot to crops around Taiwan, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Monday.

"The council and major farmers associations around the country have a total of 7,600 tons of refrigerated vegetables in stock, which will be enough to meet domestic market demand, " said Cheng Shou-liang, director of the COA's Statistics Department.

The COA has 1,200 tons of cabbage and Chinese cabbage in inventory and will gradually release the stock based on the amount available and prices prevailing in the Taipei Fruit and Vegetable Market, Cheng said.
The remaining 6,400 tons are being stored by various farmers groups, and this supply will be released to meet demand through various distribution channels, he added.
According to official statistics, the Taipei Fruit and Vegetable Market received 1,347 tons of vegetables for sale Aug. 5 when Morakot had yet to hit Taiwan.
From Aug. 6-9, the daily supply was 1,333 tons, 1,573 tons, 1,036 tons and 1,168 tons, respectively. The market was closed Monday.
The quantity available for sale Tuesday is estimated at around 1,050 tons, roughly equivalent to the daily average of 1,200 tons.
"Local residents shouldn't worry about a shortage of vegetables in the wake of the typhoon disaster, " Cheng said.

Typhoon Morakot lashed Taiwan with strong winds and staggering amounts of rainfall over the weekend, causing severe damage to crops, with agricultural losses topping NT$5.06 billion (US$153.33 million) as of 2 p.m. Monday.
With more losses still expected, the NT$5.06 billion in losses already stands as the seventh worst agricultural disaster in 18 years, Cheng said.
The worst agricultural disaster was caused by Typhoon Herbert in August 1996 when NT$18.08 billion in agricultural losses were recorded.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 11, or the 21st day of the sixth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1858: Christiaan Eijkman, the Dutch physician who won the 1929 Nobel Prize for medicine for his discovery of Vitamin B, is born.
1863: The French, who occupy southern Vietnam, make Cambodia a protectorate.
1919: Scottish-born American industrialist and philanthropist Andrew Carnegie dies at the age of 84. He amassed a fortune in the steel industry and donated millions of dollars for the benefit of the public.
1921: Warren G. Harding, the 29th president of the United States, formally invites China, Japan, Britain, France and Italy to join a disarmament meeting in Washington, D.C. to cope with an increasingly dangerous international situation after World War I.
1930: Britain goes broke. The United States and France each lend it US$46 million, while American bankers extend another US$111 million.
1932: Herbert Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, says it is time to scrap Prohibition. He lost the presidency to Franklin D. Roosevelt later that same year.
1936: Nationalist Chinese forces of Chiang Kai-shek enter Canton after foiling a rebellion led by Chen Chi-tang in the city in southern China.
1945: The Allies inform Japan that its surrender offer is acceptable.
1945: Communist "Yenan General Headquarters" orders Chinese communist troops to start an all-out revolt against the Republic of China government.
1950: The U.N. Security Council rejects a Soviet proposal for the immediate expulsion of the ROC delegation. The Russian delegation walks out in protest.
1960: Chad gains independence from France.
1960: The ROC recognizes the Ivory Coast and Chad.
1966: A peace treaty is signed in Jakarta, ending three years of hostilities between Malaysia and Indonesia.
1972: President Richard M. Nixon completes his "Vietnamization" of the Vietnam War by pulling out the last 92 American soldiers from the Southeast Asian country.
1973: The Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League opens its three-day 19th Conference in Taipei.
1975: The first meeting of the Asian and Pacific Congress on Health, Physical Education and Recreation opens in Taipei with 250 experts from 17 nations and areas attending.
1976: The industrial and commercial panel of the National Reconstruction Seminar opens a three-day meeting to make recommendations to the government.
1986: Sixteen people are killed and 87 others injured in an accidental explosion aboard the tanker SS Canari which is waiting to be scrapped in a shipwrecking yard in Kaohsiung Harbor.
1992: The United States, Canada and Mexico reach an agreement to set up a North American free-trade zone that would rank as the world's largest single trading bloc.
1993: The ROC Cable Television Law goes into effect.
1997: An international meeting called to shore up the shaky Thai economy offers loans of US$16 billion to the financial crisis-hit country.
1999: Taiwan's China Airlines signs an agreement with Boeing Co. of the United States to buy 13 B747-400 cargo planes for an estimated US$2.5 billion.
2000: A "Tzu Chi Village" in South Africa built by Taiwan's Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, a charity organization, is formally inaugurated. Meanwhile, the Tzu Chi Medical Center announces the 99th and 100th overseas cases in which it has supplied bone marrow for transplant operations.
2001: The Bureau of Monetary Affairs under the Finance Ministry and the Central Deposits Insurance Corp. take the initiative to put 36 faltering local financial institutions under supervision, the first phase of a "Monetary Reconstruction Fund" action to consolidate the operations of local banks and farmers as well as fishermen's cooperatives.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to command the obedience of the members of one's family. If a man looking into his own heart is not true to himself, he will not command the obedience of the members of his family."
