DOC.HEADLINE: Government to provide cash relief to flood victims' families

TEXT.P: Families whose loved ones have died or gone missing because of Typhoon Morakot will receive NT$1 million (US$30,488) per casualty in condolence money, the Government Information Office (GIO) said Tuesday.

Of the NT$1 million, NT$200,000 will be paid for by the central government, NT$200,000 by local governments and NT$600,000 by the Cabinet-run nonprofit Relieve Disaster Foundation, according to a GIO statement.
Families whose members have suffered severe injuries as a result of the typhoon are entitled to receive NT$250,000 per victim.

Meanwhile, local governments will also provide relocation funding to families whose homes were destroyed or washed away by flood waters or mudslides. The grants will be NT$20,000 per person up to NT$100,000 per household, the GIO statement said.

The Relieve Disaster Foundation is also offering flood victims a choice of either NT$10,000 per person in relocation funds, up to five people per household; NT$3,000 per person to rent a place for up to six months, up to three people per household; or NT$20,000 per household in flood compensation, a foundation official said.
Victimized families could contact their local government offices to gain access to the funding, the official said.

As of Tuesday morning, the storm had left 41 people dead, 35 people injured, and 60 people still unaccounted for, and caused agricultural losses of over NT$5 billion, according to figures released by the Central Emergency Operation Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Hang Seng ETFs ready for investors in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Hang Seng Investment Management Ltd. will begin offering its two dual-listed exchange-traded funds (ETFs) on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TWSE) Aug. 14, the company's chief investment officer said Tuesday.

On July 29, Hang Seng Bank announced that two ETFs managed by fully owned subsidiary Hang Seng Investment Management -- Hang Seng Index ETF and Hang Seng H-Share Index ETF -- had been approved by Taiwan's Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) for listing applications with the TWSE.
The new cross-listing policy will allow Taiwanese investors to directly invest in Hong Kong ETFs.

Clement Ho, director and chief investment officer of Hang Seng Investment Management, was bullish on the ETFs near-term prospects, saying stock markets in both China and Hong Kong would retain their upward momentum into the second quarter of 2010.

Though some analysts fear credit risks and asset bubbles might compel the Chinese government to change its moderately loose monetary policy, Ho thinks China's monetary policy will remain unchanged, arguing that the timing is not right.
Unless China's exports increase dramatically and positive employment numbers are seen, the government is unlikely to initiate a large-scale retrenchment policy, Ho said.

Hang Seng Bank said on July 29 the two ETFs were the first Hong Kong ETFs to have obtained permission from the FSC to apply for dual-listing under a cross- listing regime recently established by Hong Kong and Taiwan.
HSBC Global Asset Management (Taiwan) Limited has been appointed the master agent of the ETFs in Taiwan, and Yuanta Securities was the first firm to be appointed as a participating dealer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese Red Cross Society offers help to Taiwan flood victims

TEXT.P: China's Red Cross Society has offered to send help and relief to Taiwan in the wake of the massive destruction wreaked by Typhoon Morakot in southern Taiwan, the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China said Tuesday.
"We will rush the help, whatever is needed, " the Chinese Red Cross Society said, according to its Taiwan counterpart.

Meanwhile, Chen Hua, president of the Fujian chapter of the Chinese Red Cross Society, who is currently in Taiwan, donated 1 million Chinese yuan to the relief effort during a visit to the headquarters of the ROC Red Cross Society in Taipei City Monday.

Zhang Xiaoling, head of a Chinese Red Cross Society chapter in Wuhan who is currently in Taiwan at the head of an educational delegation from the city, also donated 8,100 Chinese yuan that she collected from her delegation's members.
Meanwhile, the society said people in Taiwan have shown tremendous generosity in recent days, donating money and supplies to alleviate the hardships of typhoon victims in southern Taiwan.

Several hundred Red Cross volunteers have entered areas devastated by floods and mudslides with 6,000 sleeping bags, jackets, blankets and quilts, as well as 50,000 packs of ready-to-serve rations, said a Red Cross Society official.
In related news, the ruling Kuomintang said Tuesday that the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council sent its concern and condolences to Taiwan in a letter sent late Monday night.
Beijing said in the letter that China would provide assistance to Taiwan if necessary, according to Lee Chian-jung, director of the KMT Culture and Communications Committee.

The Beijing-based intermediary body Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) has also contacted its Taiwan counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), Tuesday morning to say that it would send help to Taiwan if needed.

DOC.HEADLINE: More downpours in the cards: forecasters

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Tuesday that Taiwan is still under the influence of air currents from the southwest and could still experience heavy rainfall after being battered by Typhoon Morakot over the weekend.

Although Morakot left Taiwan Sunday, it has joined with Typhoon Goni, which has lingered over China's Guangdong province, to form a low pressure system whose rain clouds are being pushed toward Taiwan by a high pressure system from the north, according to CWB meteorologists.
They said precipitation would be heavy in areas south of Miaoli County, and warned that mountainous areas in central and southern Taiwan could be hit by more torrential rains.

From Monday midnight to Tuesday morning at 8:10, Taoyuan village in Kaohsiung County had received 88mm of rainfall, the most anywhere in Taiwan, followed by Syueling in Taichung County with 71mm and Liouguei in Kaohsiung County and Weiliao in Pingtung County with 50 mm.

Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties were already battered by Typhoon Morakot over the weekend and the floods and landslides it precipitated. As of Tuesday morning, 41 people have been confirmed dead and dozens more are still missing.
Continuing heavy rains have hampered rescue operations in mountainous villages, where hundreds of people are still thought to be stranded.
CWB forecasters said the rains should ease Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Stranded Chinese tourists rescued

TEXT.P: A group of 16 Chinese tourists, who had been stranded on Alishan in southern Taiwan because of blocked roads leading down the mountain, were brought to safety around noon Tuesday, according to the Alishan National Scenic Area Administration.

The group, which arrived in Taiwan Aug. 6 and was scheduled to depart Tuesday, had been stranded in a resort on Alishan because of Typhoon Morakot, which brought torrential rains that caused many roads and bridges to collapse, especially in southern Taiwan.
The Chinese tourists were taken down the mountain in small groups by mountain bus around noon Tuesday, in time for them to catch their flight back to China, an administration official said.

According to the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, when Typhoon Morakot struck Taiwan between Aug. 7-9, there were 9,481 Chinese tourists in 405 groups in Taiwan. All of them are safe, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economy will be temporarily soaked by storm damage: think-tank

TEXT.P: Typhoon Morakot, which pummeled Taiwan Aug. 7-9, will drag down the domestic economy temporarily because of the the massive destruction it wreaked, a private economic think-tank forecast Tuesday.

The damage from the storm, which triggered the worst flooding in Taiwan in 50 years, will unavoidably impact adversely on the country's economy in the third quarter of this year, particularly in the agricultural and tourism sectors, said Liang Kuo-yuan, president of the Taipei-based Polaris Research Institute.

Liang quoted some companies as predicting that economic losses from the typhoon will reach NT$15 billion (US$457.32 million) , and that the domestic economy will fall by 0.53 percentage points in Q3 as a result.

However, the outlook for the GDP in the fourth quarter is not necessarily "pessimistic, " given that huge governmental funds and resources will be channeled into post-disaster reconstruction efforts, which might rev up economic growth, he said.
"The GDP might register positive growth in Q4 as rehabilitation work kicks off at home and the global economies possibly start rebounding," Liang forecast.

Citing the 2006 Hurricane Katrina in the United States and the 2008 killer earthquake in China's Sichuan Province as examples, Liang said that government- initiated reconstruction work in the wake of the natural disasters helped rev up the local economies and turned the growth from negative to positive.
The rehabilitation work will help generate new demand, investment and employment, he added.

He cautioned however, that apart from the physical damage caused by Typhoon Morakot, there could be mental trauma among disaster victims, a type of damage that would be hard to measure and would not be reflected in GDP figures.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rescue helicopter reported missing

TEXT.P: A helicopter operated by the National Airborne Service Corps under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) was reported missing Tuesday while carrying out a relief operation for Wutai township in Pingdong County, southern Taiwan.
The helicopter, reported missing by the MOI at 3: 30 p.m., was reported by the TVBS cable TV channel to be carrying five crew and one nurse.
Airborne Service Corps officials said a search had been launched for the missing aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rescue helicopter crashes (update-1)

TEXT.P: A helicopter operated by the National Airborne Service Corps under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) crashed Tuesday while carrying out a relief operation for Wutai township in Pingdong County, southern Taiwan.
The helicopter reportedly hit a mountainside and crashed into a valley near the aboriginal settlement of Sandimen at 3: 30 p.m., corps officials reported.
According to the TVBS cable TV channel, the aircraft was carrying three crew members.
There was no word about the fate of those aboard.

DOC.HEADLINE: Regional parliamentarians' conference opens in Taipei

TEXT.P: The 40th annual conference of the Asia-Pacific Parliamentarian's Union (APPU) opened in Taipei Tuesday, marking the first time that Taiwan is hosting an APPU event.
Before addressing the opening ceremony, President Ma Ying-jeou asked the participants to observe a moment of silence in memory of the victims of Typhoon Morakot.
Over the weekend, the storm triggered the worst flooding in 50 years, and the death toll of 41 continues to rise.
In his speech, which he delivered in English, Ma touted his government's achievement of improved relations between Taiwan and China and its adoption of a flexible diplomacy policy.
Ma also reiterated Taiwan's contribution to peace and democracy in the international community.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, the chairman of the conference, said that this year's APPU conference, which is being held under the theme of "human security, " will focus on economic security, food safety, health safety and environmental safety.
He reminded the participants that the Asia-Pacific region, one of the largest in the world, is home to more than half the world's population.

Wang said the region therefore has a responsibility to pay attention to human security issues, particularly as most people in the world have been under threat over the past year as a result of the global financial crunch, the outbreak of A(H1N1) influenza, and the occurrence of cross-boundary sandstorms.

The Legislative Yuan speaker also noted that many democratic countries attach great importance to parliamentary diplomacy as it not only helps governments address international issues, but also provides a platform for parliamentarians to better represent the opinions of the citizens in their respective countries.
Only by working together across national boundaries can the APPU members promote the wellbeing of the people in the region, he said.
The 40th APPU annual conference will conclude Wednesday with the signing of a joint communique by the 14 participating APPU members.
The APPU is comprised of 21 Asia-Pacific countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses from Morakot fourth-highest in 18 years

TEXT.P: Agricultural and fishery losses from Typhoon Morakot which swept Taiwan over the weekend were estimated at NT$6.85 billion (US$208 million) as of Tuesday, according to the newest government statistics.
Tallies compiled by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) showed that the storm damage figure is the fourth-highest in 18 years.
A total of 49,723 hectares of farmlands were devastated by Morakot, with banana plantations on some 5,356 hectares suffering the biggest blow, followed by papaya, guava, bamboo and vegetable farms.
Poultry and animal losses amounted to NT$737.59 million, with 2.7 million chickens and 709,000 ducks perishing in the storm. Pig farmers reportedly lost a total of 80,815 pigs.
Fisheries losses reached a new high of NT$2.91 billion, exceeding the NT$2.43 billion recorded when Typhoon Herbert hit in Aug. 1996, COA tallies showed.
A combined 5,832 hectares of fish farms in southern Taiwan's Tainan, Pingtung and Kaohsiung counties were badly damaged by Morakot -- the worst typhoon to hit the south in 50 years.

Losses in the forestry sector were estimated at NT$16.36 million, while agricultural facilities suffered damage amounting to NT$168.32 million, and 73 hectares of farmland were washed away, according to the COA.

Some 10 cities and counties -- Pingtung, Kaohsiung, Chiayi, Yulin, Tainan, Hualien, Taitung and Taichung counties as well as Tainan and Chiayi cities -- are eligible to apply for COA cash subsides in view of the severe damage caused by Morakot, the council said.

Fourteen cities and counties, including the 10 mentioned above, are also eligible to apply for low-interest loans, the COA said, adding that the other four are Taichung, Changhua and Miaoli counties and Taichung City.

As a result of the storm damage, vegetable supplies at the Taipei Vegetable and Fruit Market on Tuesday fell to 1,090 tons, a decrease of 78 tons compared to the last trading day on Sunday. The market was closed on Monday.
Strong demand drove vegetable wholesale prices up to NT$32.9 per kilogram Tuesday in the market -- an increase of 17.3 percent. Fruit supplies rose on Tuesday by 192 tons to 562 tons.

In view of the tight local supply of vegetables and the surging prices of staple commodities in the world market, COA officials are concerned that the prices of other food items, such as pork, chicken, eggs and fish, will soar in the coming three weeks.

The COA said it has been seeking to import vegetables from Southeast Asian countries and Australia to meet local demand. It predicted that pork and chicken prices will rise and remain at a relatively high level over the next six to nine months.

However, Cheng Shou-liang, director of the COA's Statistics Department, said Monday that the council and major farmers associations around the country have a total of 7,600 tons of refrigerated vegetables in stock, which will be enough to meet domestic market demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flood victims entitled to free medical attention: MOI

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Liao Liou-yi called for hospitals Tuesday to allow victims of Typhoon Morakot to receive medical attention on credit if they are unable to produce their health insurance cards.

Liao made the call after visiting an office of the Kaohsiung county government in Cishan township, where some flood and mudslide victims complained to him that when they were rushed to hospital for treatment, the hospital authorities refused to treat them unless they could produce health insurance cards and pay for registration.

The victims complained that in the wake of the flooding and devastation brought by Typhoon Morakot, they did not have enough time to bring with them health insurance cards or money when they were evacuated.

Liao later instructed that the victims should be given medical attention on credit and that their medical bills should be erased once local government offices issue documents proving that they are victims of the typhoon.

Meanwhile, the Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission said that Morakot victims, as well as other members of the public, should visit a Government Information Office (GIO) Web site set up to keep abreast of post-disaster rescue and relief work at http://info.gio.gov.tw/mp.asp?mp=1.
The site provides details about cash relief, subsidies, medical attention, taxation, education and employment assistance in the wake of the devastation, said the commission.
According to the GIO, families whose loved ones have died or gone missing because of the typhoon are eligible for condolence money of NT$1 million (US$30,488) per casualty.
Families whose members have suffered severe injury as a result of the typhoon are also entitled to receive NT$250,000 per victim, the GIO said.

Meanwhile, local governments will also provide relocation funding to families whose homes have been destroyed by flooding or mudslides. The grants will amount to NT$20,000 per person, to a maximum of NT$100,000 per household, the GIO said in a statement.

The Relief Disaster Foundation under the Ministry of the Interior is also offering flood victims a choice of either NT$10,000 per person in relocation funds for up to five people per household; NT$3,000 per person to rent a property for up to six months, up to three people per household; or NT$20,000 per household in flood compensation.
Those who believe themselves eligible should contact their local government offices to gain access to the funding, a foundation official said.

As of Tuesday morning, the storm had left 41 people dead, 35 people injured and 60 still unaccounted for, with agricultural losses estimated at over NT$5 billion, according to figures released by the Central Emergency Operation Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: 24 survivors rescued, hundreds found in isolated villages

TEXT.P: Twenty-four survivors in isolated villages in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County had been rescued as of early Tuesday, with hundreds more said to have been buried alive by mudslides, the Central Emergency Operation Center (CEOC) said that day.
Two army helicopters had landed at the mudslide-battered Siaolin, Taoyuan and Namasia villages and had airlifted 18 people to safety, according to the CEOC.

The staggering amount of rainfall delivered by Typhoon Morakot over the weekend led to massive flooding and landslides that wreaked havoc in Kaohsiung County's mountainous villages, cutting them off from the outside world.
Army servicemen sent to Siaolin found some 150 villagers and dropped some 1,300 kg of emergency food and water.

The army said it would continue to send helicopters to mountain villages to search for other survivors, the CEOC said, adding that some villagers upstream from Siaolin had refused to evacuate but had demanded airdrops of food and water.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices on local bourse edge above 6,900

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed slightly higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, advancing 26.15 points, or 0.37 percent, to close at 6,909.02.
The local bourse opened higher Tuesday at 6,904.45, but quickly fell to a low of 6,812.06, hit by sluggish performance by banking and financial shares and electronics stocks.
The market later rebounded to the day's high of 6,921.85, paced by a rebound from cement and construction shares in anticipation of major reconstruction projects in the wake of Typhoon Morakot.
The local bourse retained most of its early gains by the end of trading and finished above 6,900, surpassing the index's one-month moving average of 6,885.
A total of 3.69 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$107.61 billion (US$3.28 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 2 percent. Paper and pulp issues rose 1.3 percent, cement stocks added 1.2 percent, plastics and chemicals issues surged 1.1 percent, and machinery and electronics shares advanced 0.7 percent.
The other three major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff stocks moving down the most at 1.9 percent. Textile shares fell 1 percent, and banking and financial issues shed 0.9 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,202 to 1,124, with 180 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$3.19 billion worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.037 to close at NT$32.855.
A total of US$1.12 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.9 and fluctuated between NT$32.826 and NT$32.913.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA thanks international community for typhoon condolences

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) thanked the international community Tuesday for its condolences for the stricken families in areas devastated by Typhoon Morakot.

MOFA deputy spokesman James Chang said at a regular press briefing that both Japan and the United States have expressed deep condolences for the typhoon victims and their families and offered to help through all kinds of channels.

The Taipei-based American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) and the U.S. State Department contacted the foreign ministry and its representative office in Washington, respectively, to express concern over the situation, according to Chang.

In addition, the governments of France, Hungary and the Holy See, Taiwan's only diplomatic ally in Europe, and a German parliamentary group friendly to Taiwan also sent their condolences to the victims and their families, he added.

El Salvador Ambassador Francisco Ricardo Santana, who is the acting head of the diplomatic corps in Taiwan, also sent a letter on behalf of Taiwan's allies to Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou that same day to express condolences for the storm victims, Chang said.

The deputy spokesman said the Foreign Ministry appreciated the U.S. and Japan's offers to help but indicated that Taiwan would not request foreign assistance at present because there are sufficient recourses and the disaster relief mechanism is working well.

The MOFA will serve as a channel between the Central Disaster Emergency Operation Center and the international community to communicate and coordinate information and related relief needs, and will make an immediate request if foreign aid is needed,Chang said.

Typhoon Morakot hovered over Taiwan Aug. 7-8, lashing parts of the country with massive amounts of rain. It dumped a record 2,500mm of precipitation in Taiwan's southernmost county of Pingtung, causing severe flooding in at least three coastal townships.
As of 10: 30 a.m. Tuesday, the flooding there and elsewhere and widespread landslides had left 41 people dead, 35 injured and 60 unaccounted for islandwide.

Peter Tsai, secretary-general of the MOFA's Association of East Asian Relations, told the Central News Agency a day earlier that Naohiro Tsutsumi, director- general of the Taipei Office of the Interchange Association -- the de facto Japanese embassy in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic relations -- called him Aug. 8 on behalf of the Japanese government to express the country's condolences and offered help if necessary.
The Foreign Ministry also received a letter from Japan's representative to Taiwan, Masaki Saito, who expressed concerns about the serious flooding in southern part of Taiwan, Tsai said.

He added that Tetsuya Hirose, secretary-general of the Japan-based Asia- Pacific ParliamentariansUnion, which opened its 40th annual conference in Taipei Aug. 11, also expressed his best wishes to storm victims.
AIT Press Officer Christopher Kavanagh told CNA Tuesday that the U.S. is looking at what kind of assistance it could provide.

We are concerned about the situation. On behalf of the American people, we would like to convey our deepest sympathy for the victims and their families. The U.S. is ready to provide assistance, Kavanagh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan aborigines stage surprise protest at Japanese war shrine
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 11 (CNA) 08/11/09 17:53:10 (By Mike Chang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A group of indigenous people from Taiwan staged a surprise demonstration at the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo Tuesday in a fresh attempt to have the Japanese government remove the names of their ancestors from the controversial shrine that honors war dead.

The group, led by Legislator Kao Chin Shu-mei, walked straight toward the shrine's main hall as soon as it arrived there unexpectedly at 9: 30 a.m. The protestors chanted slogans and carried banners, demanding that the Japanese side "give us back our ancestors' spirits."
Despite attempts by the shrine's security guards to block the protesters and seize their banners, the group managed to reach the square in front of the main hall.

Using a megaphone, Kao Chin called for the removal of the names of Taiwanese aborigines who were forced to fight for the Japanese Imperial Army during World War II and demanded that the Japanese government critically examine, apologize and make reparation for Japan's war atrocities.
Unless Japan redresses its wrongdoings, the indigenous people will visit the shrine every year to demonstrate, she said.
The demonstrators sang a song to pay their respects to their ancestors, before ending their 30-minute protest and leaving the site.
While Kao Chin has organized similar demonstrations over the past several years, this was the first time that the protesters managed to enter the shrine.

According to the legislator, in the past the protesters were always barred by police from approaching the shrine, even though they had obtained permits in advance from the Japanese police to do so. The police at the shrine would deny the Taiwanese protestors access, on grounds that they could clash with Japanese right-wingers who usually gather there once they get wind of the planned demonstrations, she added.

The Yasukuni Shrine is dedicated to the 2.5 million soldiers who died fighting for Japan during World War II. More than 28,000 of them were from Taiwan, which was under Japan's colonial rule at that time.
The controversy stems from the fact that the shrine also honors executed Japanese war criminals who committed atrocities in China, Korea and many other countries in the Asia-Pacific region.
Kao Chin and the Taiwanese protesters, who arrived in Japan Aug. 7, departed Tuesday afternoon to return to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Vision to launch children's centers for typhoon victims

TEXT.P: The local chapter of the Christian charity World Vision said Tuesday that it is planning to set up seven centers to help rehabilitate children in areas devastated by Typhoon Morakot.

"These stricken children cannot continue to live chaotic lives, especially when a new school year is about to begin," Kuo Hsiu-ling, senior director of World Vision Taiwan's Marketing and Resources Development, told CNA in a telephone interview.
"World Vision has a network of children's centers around the world, which will serve as the base of the rehabilitation effort," she added.
According to Kuo, World Vision Taiwan is planning to set up seven daycare centers in areas devastated by the storm to take some of the burden off the families.
The children will receive psychological therapy through play and consultation, and World Vision Taiwan will also provide tuition aid and books to those in need, Kuo said.
The estimated budget for the program is around NT$130 million (US$4 million) and will be appropriated from the charity's typhoon fund and its 30-Hour Famine Campaign.
The first children's center will be opened in the southernmost county of Pingtung on Aug. 13 and first lady Chow Mei-ching will visit the children, Kuo said.
"With emergency relief stage coming to an end, the rehabilitation efforts should begin as soon as possible, " Kuo said.
According to World Vision Taiwan, in just two days, it has raised NT$62 million for emergency relief and the rehabilitation of families affected by the storm.
It urged the public to continue to donate money, rice, clean water, canned food and disposable underwear for the storm victims.

Typhoon Morakot hovered over Taiwan Aug. 7-8, lashing parts of the country with powerful winds and torrential rains. The storm dumped a record 2,500 mm of rain on Pingtung County, causing severe flooding in at least three coastal townships.
As of 11: 00 a.m. Tuesday, the flooding there and elsewhere had left 41 people dead, 35 injured and 62 missing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education Ministry to help schools resume operations

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) announced Tuesday that it will initially earmark NT$90 million (US$2.74 million) in emergency funds to help schools damaged by Typhoon Morakot resume operations by the end of this month.
"The central government will do its best to help local governments conduct cleanup and recovery operations after the flooding subsides," ministry officials said.
The MOE will also help schools return to normal as soon as possible and will also help destroyed schools find new sites for rebuilding, ministry officials said.

Meanwhile, Vice Minister of Education Lu Mu-lin, following an inspection of elementary and junior high schools and a briefing by Kaohsiung county officials earlier that same day about the damage sustained by local schools, decided to urgently allocate NT$20 million to Kaohsiung County to help classes open for the Aug. 31 start of the new semester.
Tainan and Chiayi counties will each also receive NT$20 million, while Pingtung County will get NT$30 million.
The four southern counties are the worst-hit regions by Typhoon Morakot that lashed Taiwan over the weekend.

MOE statistics show that schools around the country suffered combined losses amounting to over NT$500 million, with Pingtung schools sustaining the most serious damage of about NT$100 million, followed by Kaohsiung and Tainan counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Aquaculture losses from Typhoon Morakot worst in 18 years

TEXT.P: Financial losses suffered by Taiwan's aquaculture sector as a result of Typhoon Morakot had increased to NT$2.91 billion (US$88.72 million) as of Tuesday, the worst on record for a single typhoon over the past 18 years, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Council of Agriculture (COA).
Fish farms with a combined area of 5,832 hectares were affected by the storm, with those in Tainan, Pingtung and Kaohsiung counties, as well as Tainan City, among the hardest-hit, the COA said.

In Pingtung's Jiadong and Linbian areas, for example, many grouper ponds have been swamped by severe flooding triggered by the typhoon, allowing the expensive fish to be washed away by the overflowing water, leaving rotting fish all over the place when the floodwater began to subside later that day.
Lin Yi-wei, a local fish farmer, estimated that the typhoon has caused at least NT$20 million in losses to every fish farm in Jiadong and Linbian.
Besides aquaculture losses, Typhoon Morakot has also led to crop losses totaling more than NT$2.78 billion around Taiwan, the COA said.
The COA statistics show that 49,723 hectares of farmland lost an average 27 percent of expected harvests, with the hardest-hit crops listed as papayas, guavas, bamboo shoots and leafy vegetables.
Livestock losses were valued at NT$737.59 million, with 80,815 hogs, 2.7 million chickens and 709,000 ducks killed, the COA said, adding that forestry losses were estimated at NT$16.35 million.

Meanwhile, an estimated NT$168.32 million in damage to agricultural facilities was reported, with, NT$17.14 million for livestock facilities, NT$144.6 million for aquaculture facilities and NT$66.32 million for farmland, according to the COA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Tuesday: China Times:
Inaccurate weather forecast and bungled rescue attempts lead to disaster
Typhoon Morakot's dumping of nearly 2900 mm of rain on Taiwan in three days -- almost half a year's precipitation -- caught the island off guard.
The weathermen failed in their duty when they advised the public to be on the alert against torrential rains, without giving any details of what to expect.

In addition, inadequate communication between the central and local governments resulted in a quarrel between the minister of the interior and the magistrate of Pingdong County over who should be blamed for the government's slow response to the flood victims' calls for help.
United Daily News:
Why did southern Taiwan flood despite the billions spent by the government on flood prevention?

The administration of ex-President Chen Shui-bian had earmarked NT$80 billion to prevent flooding, and that budget was later increased to NT$160 billion. However, low-lying areas in southern Taiwan were swamped during Typhoon Morakot.

The first reason why the efforts failed is because the government was busy building new flood-prevention projects and ignored the maintenance of what was already in place. The collapse of the levees during the storm is one example.

The second reason is that the flood-prevention projects were executed by powerful officials who nonetheless had no relevant expertise, and the experts at the Water Resources Agency had little say in the drafting of the projects.
The third reason is that the work on the projects was shoddy, which points to corruption.
Liberty Times:
Rescue operation allows no excuses to pass the buck
The government will lose its raison d'etre if it fails to guarantee the security of its people and their property.

President Ma Ying-jeou is trying to shirk responsibility for the disaster caused by Typhoon Morakot by first blaming the Central Weather Bureau for failing to forecast the precipitation brought by the storm.
Then he told journalists that the rescue operation should be carried out by local governments with support from the central government.
Ma's tenure as mayor of Taipei City was marred by natural and man-made disasters and he is applying his failing Taipei experience to the nation.
The fact that local cable TV stations have been overwhelmed with calls for help from flood victims has demonstrated that the people have no faith in Ma's administration.
Apple Daily:
Government fails to do its duty
Government officials are ascribing blame for the disaster caused by Typhoon Morakot, as they always do in the event of disasters.
Taiwan is predisposed to earthquakes and storms owing to its location, and its government should be accustomed to dealing with such adversity.
But what we have seen is an administration as naive as a backward African state in its dealing with the flooding brought by Typhoon Morakot.

Its naivety is shown in the fact that the government sat on its hands for almost seven or eight hours when the scale of the disaster first became apparent, while the interior minister and the magistrate of Pingdong County blamed each other for the failure to address the catastrophe.

DOC.HEADLINE: President instructs centralized operation for relief distribution

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou instructed the mayors and magistrates of 11 cities and counties in central and northern Taiwan Tuesday that all local government relief resources for typhoon-devastated areas will be managed by the National Fire Agency under the Ministry of the Interior.

While most counties north of Taichung did not suffer as much as southern and eastern Taiwan from the onslaught of Typhoon Morakot, the governments of these cities and counties have been coordinating among themselves to provide resources for people in the south and on the east coast whose livelihoods have been left in jeopardy by calamitous floods and landslides.
Ma expects all manpower, relief resources and rescue equipment to be centralized and properly distributed, according to Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu- chi.

Meanwhile, referring to a proposal for the issuing of an emergency decree, Wang said the government has no plans to issue such a decree at present, since all necessary emergency measures have been brought into force in line with the Disaster Prevention and Rescue Law that was approved in 2000, one year after the Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake.

In reply to a suggestion by Legislator Huang Wei-che of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party that the government should adopt special provisions for reconstruction work in the wake of the flooding, Wang said the government will dedicate all its efforts toward relief work before addressing plans for reconstruction.

Meanwhile, Control Yuan President Wang Chien-hsuen directed four committees -- interior affairs, national defense and information, finance and economy, and transportation and procurement -- under the nation's highest watchdog body to investigate possible negligence by government agencies in relation to the disaster.

DOC.HEADLINE: More businesses chip in to help typhoon victims

TEXT.P: More enterprises from across Taiwan's business sector announced generous donations Tuesday for the relief of the victims of Typhoon Morakot, which devastated southern Taiwan with serious flooding over the weekend.

Delta Electronics Group donated a whopping NT$500 million (US$15.15 million), including NT$100 million from its founder, Bruce Cheng, NT$200 million from its subsidiaries and NT$200 million from an educational and cultural foundation run by the company.
Cheng said he was deeply saddened by the suffering in the devastated areas.
The business group will also launch a donation drive to encourage employees to donate one day of their salaries to the typhoon victims.
The Hon Hai Group and its staff also donated NT$400 million for the relief of flood-stricken areas.
The Formosa Plastics Group announced donations of NT$200 million for the relief of devastated areas.
Meanwhile, Quanta Group and its staff donated NT$100 million, with Quanta Chairman Barry Lam urging the public to help contribute to post-flood reconstruction.
The Chi Mei Group also announced that it would donate NT$100 million, while the Chi Mei Foundation Medical Center will also send a team to flood-stricken areas to provide medical services.

Other groups that announced donations Tuesday included the Chicony and Clevo Group (NT$70 million), MediaTek (NT$25 million), the TECO Group (NT$10 million and 1,000 electric motors), Altek Corp. (NT$10 million), Yageo (NT$10 million), Giant (NT$5 million) and Ve Wong Corp. (NT$3 million).
Taiwan businessmen operating in China announced on Tuesday the donations of NT$10 million for post-flood reconstruction.
The BenQ Group and Cathay Financial Holdings each announced donations of NT$100 million on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City seeks resumption of water supply in one week

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government urged the Taiwan Water Corp. (TWC) Tuesday to fix within a week the city's water supply problems resulting mainly from high turbidity levels in water from the Kaoping river diversion weir, which supplies around 60 percent of the city's water.

Some 200,000 households in the Kaohsiung area were without water that day, with the high turbidity caused by heavy rain brought by Typhoon Morakot making the water unfit for human consumption, prompting the company to cut supplies.

Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu directed the city's Police Bureau to convert police vehicles equipped with anti-riot water cannons into water-dispensing vehicles and asked the Kaohsiung branch of TWC and the Kaohisung Refinery of the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) to help set up 30 water supply stations in northern parts of the city.

The Chengching reservoir, which also supplies water to the Kaohsiung area, can at best provide about four days of water to the community if the turbidity problems cannot be resolved quickly, Chen said.
She made the remarks during an inspection of the Kaoping weir in neighboring Kaohsiung County in which she heard a briefing by the Kaohsiung branch of TWC.
Luang Tung-hsiung, an official of the TWC, said the company was working hard to repair 12 water pumps inundated by mud and silt, but was facing difficulties.

Meanwhile, the city government was collaborating with the water company to seek other water resources from wells in Shoujinliao in Kaohsiung County, said Liu Shin-zeng, chief of the city's Economic Development Bureau, who added that the water supply problems are expected to be resolved in three to seven days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Helicopter wreckage, bodies of three crew members found

TEXT.P: The wreckage of a helicopter that crashed Tuesday afternoon while on a rescue mission in Wutai township, Pingtung County, was found later in the day by an airborne rescue team that rushed to the site, according to the National Airborne Service Corps under the Ministry of the Interior.

The wreckage was located at about 4: 30 p.m., one hour after the crash, by another search and rescue helicopter on a steep mountainside some 500 kilometers west of an aboriginal settlement that is part of Wutai township.
The pilot of the rescue helicopter said it was impossible to land or to lift the wreckage or bodies because of the steepness of the slope.

"It appears that the three crew members were killed in the accident, " the pilot said after rescuers on board his chopper were lowered near the crash site and reported that the crash victims showed no signs of life.

According to the National Airborne Service Corp, more rescuers were making their way by land to the crash site Tuesday afternoon, determined to bring back the crew members, no matter how bad the weather.
The NA-501 helicopter hit a mountainside and crashed into a valley near the aboriginal settlement of Sandimen at 3: 30 p.m., officials of the corps reported.

According to the Central Emergency Operation Center, the corps had conducted 110 airborne relief missions, mainly focusing on the mountainous areas of Nantou, Tainan, Chiayi, Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties in central and southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon Morakot causes power outages for 1.59 million households

TEXT.P: The number of households that had experienced power outages as a result of Typhoon Morakot had accumulated to more than 1.59 million as of Tuesday, although electricity supplies for 97 percent of the affected households had already been restored, according to statistics released by the state-run Taiwan Power Company.

The 49,575 households still without power were mainly located in the southern counties of Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Chiayi, the company said, adding that efforts to restore electricity supplies were delayed mainly because floodwater in some areas of the affected counties had not subsided and roads in mountainous regions were still impassable.

Meanwhile, statistics compiled by the National Communications Commission (NCC) show that more than 3,000 mobile phone base stations were damaged by the typhoon, the highest number on record for a single typhoon over the past 10 years.
While 2,500 of the stations had been repaired, 700 were still out of service, including 400 that were shut down because of the power outages, the NCC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourism losses estimated at over NT$800 million: Tourism Bureau chief

TEXT.P: The tourism sector's losses in six national scenic areas run by the Tourism Bureau have initially been estimated in excess of NT$800 million (US$24.4 million) in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai reported Tuesday.

According to Lai, Morakot has led to losses worth some NT$670 million in the six national scenic areas in terms of income and facilities, not including damage worth some NT$137 million to 17 hotels, such as the 30-year-old Chinsuai Hotel in the Chihpen hot spring area of Taitung County, which collapsed early Sunday due to serious landslides.

Of the national scenic areas, the Maolin National Scenic Area in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County was the hardest hit, Lai went on, with a three-story building housing its administration headquarters washed away by floods, while a tourism information center run by the Tourism Bureau in nearby Liouguei township was also seriously damaged.
No damage to the country's prime recreational parks was reported, while no workers in tourist spots and no foreign or local tourists were injured during the typhoon, according to Lai.

Later that same day, Lai and Yao Ta-kuang, chairman of Taiwan's Travel Agent Association, jointly announced a donation of NT$10 million from the tourism sector to victims affected by Morakot -- the worst typhoon to hit southern Taiwan in 50 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan hopes to expand cooperation with Marshall Islands: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that Taiwan looks forward to expanding its cooperation with the Marshall Islands to further consolidate bilateral relations with its South Pacific diplomatic ally.

Ma made the remarks during a meeting held at the Presidential Office with Marshall Islands President Litokwa Tomeing, who was in Taiwan to attend the 40th annual conference of the Asia-Pacific Parliamentarian's Union.
Ma noted that Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco H.L. Ou was accorded a warm reception when he visited the Marshall Islands in May to take part in the country's 30th National Day celebration.

The visit also allowed Ou to see the Marshall Islands' beautiful scenery and experience the kindness of its people, as well as giving him a first-hand view of the country's rapid development, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipower, road authorities report on typhoon damage

TEXT.P: The state-run Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) and the Directorate General of Highways (DGOH) issued reports Tuesday on the progress of repairs to roads, bridges and electricity supplies destroyed by Typhoon Morakot.

A DGOH official announced that 76 roads and bridges had been repaired, with 111 yet to be attended to, mostly in Kaohsiung, Chiayi, Pingtung, Nantou, Hualien, Taitung, Taichung and Yunlin counties. He added that these facilities will not be repaired for some time.
The destruction has hampered rescue operations in mountainous villages, where hundreds of people are still thought to be stranded.
Meanwhile, a Taipower spokesman announced that electricity had been restored to over 1,527,172 homes, leaving only 58,142 without power.

At Morakot's peak strength last Friday, the storm caused power outages all around the island and electricity grid workers had to brave strong winds and heavy rain to fix the power system, according to the spokesman.
Homes still without power were mostly in Pingtung, Jiayi, Nantou, and Kaohsiung counties, with 20,160 homes in Pingtung County still without electricity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon death toll climbs to 62

TEXT.P: Typhoon Morakot, which swept through Taiwan over the weekend, had left 62 dead, 35 injured and 57 unaccounted for as of 8 p.m. Tuesday, according to a report from the Central Emergency Operation Center.

Three people aboard a helicopter that crashed that afternoon while on a rescue mission in Wutai township, Pingtung County, were not included on the casualty list but were instead listed on a list of ongoing rescue operations.

The wreckage of the helicopter was located on a steep mountainside some 500 meters west of an aboriginal settlement that is part of Wutai township later in the day by an airborne rescue team, which added that it was unable to reach the wreckage due to the steepness of the slope.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rescue teams locate 700 stranded villagers in Kaohsiung County

TEXT.P: Military rescue teams had found some 700 stranded villagers in isolated mountainous regions of Kaohsiung County as of late Tuesday, according to Chou Yen-chung, director of political affairs of the Army Command.

The rescue teams were reported to be delivering food and water to the villagers, who had managed to find shelter when their homes were buried in mudslides triggered by Typhoon Morakot, which battered southern Taiwan over the weekend, causing the worst flooding in 50 years.

Hundreds of the villagers were earlier believed to have been buried alive in the mudslides. Among the survivors located by the rescue teams are 200 from the village of Siaolin, who had become a focus of media attention over the previous two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Widespread outbreaks of A(H1N1) flu likely in late August: CDC

TEXT.P: The number of patients infected with the A(H1N1) flu virus in Taiwan might have surpassed the 10,000 mark after an estimated 6,000 new mild cases were reported last week, with an epidemic likely as soon as the end of August, Centers for Disease Control Director-General Kuo Hsu-sung said Tuesday.

Taiwan has seen a sharp increase in cases of flu-like illness over the past three weeks, with confirmed flu cases accounting for 21 percent of the total and cases of A(H1N1) flu accounting for 90 percent of those, according to Kuo.
The number of patients infected with the new flu virus is expected to register a further surge in the next two to three weeks, one month ahead of the seasonal flu peak season, he noted.
On June 11, the World Health Organization (WHO) upgraded its A(H1N1) alert level to phase six, which indicates that a global pandemic is underway.

Although it also said that "the pandemic is moderate in terms of severity with the majority of patients experiencing only mild symptoms and a full recovery, " the new strain spreads easily from one person to the next and there is no vaccine presently available that offers protection, Kuo went on.
Anyone experiencing flu-like symptoms should immediately seek medical treatment, Kuo warned.

The state-sponsored Adimmune Corp., the country's only producer of A(H1N1) flu vaccine, which won a bid last month to produce 5 million doses of A(H1N1) vaccine at NT$199 each, will begin mass production of the vaccine once clinical trials are complete, according to Chen Hui-fang, a CDC official who is part of the production project.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 12, or the 22nd day of the sixth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1099: The Crusaders defeat the Egyptians at Ascalon on the Palestine coast in the First Crusade.
1813: Austria declares war against Napoleon.
1848: George Stephenson, the British railway pioneer who built the first passenger railway in 1825, dies at the age of 67. He also developed the first practical steam locomotive, the "Rocket."
1877: A group of people witness a public demonstration of a new device, a phonograph that records the human voice, at Thomas Edison's "invention factory" at Menlo Park, New Jersey.
1881: Cecil B. De Mille, the American film director, is born. He is legendary for his large-scale Biblical and historical epics such as "The Ten Commandments," "Samson and Delilah" and "Cleopatra."
1898: The United States and Spain sign a protocol ending the Spanish-American War, with Spain relinquishing Cuba and ceding Puerto Rico to the United States. In addition, the Hawaiian Islands are formally annexed by the United States.
1908: The Ford Motor Co. introduces its Model T car, a sturdy, black, four- cylinder number that comes in two versions: tourer and roadster. Both retail at incredibly low prices: the roadster at US$825 and the tourer for just US$25 more.
1912: William Booth, a Methodist minister who founded the Salvation Army in London in 1865, dies of illness in London at the age of 83. The Salvation Army works to foster a love of God and to provide for the needy. It offers its services to people of any race, creed, sex or age.
1914: Britain declares war on Austria-Hungary.
1946: The stolen body of dictator Benito Mussolini is found in northern Italy.
1948: The United States recognizes South Korea.
1954: The last batch of United Nations forces in the Korean War pulls out of Korea.
1961: Chen Chia-keng, an overseas Chinese from Singapore and founder of Amoy University, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 88.
1970: The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and West Germany sign a non- aggression pact in Moscow.
1970: A China Airlines (CAL) passenger plane of the Republic of China crashes into a mountain on its way from Hualien in eastern Taiwan to Taipei, killing or injuring 31 people.
1978: Taiwan's fastest electrified train, the Tzu Chiang Express, makes a test run between Taipei and Taichung.
1978: Mainland China and Japan sign a treaty of peace and friendship in Beijing.
1985: A Japan Airlines Boeing 747 Jumbo jet crashes into Mount Osutaka on its way from Tokyo to Osaka, killing all but four of the 524 people aboard.
1990: Beijing's attempt to restore its tarnished image after the slaughter in Tiananmen Square receives a severe setback. Official documentation of the disturbances now reveals that more than 450 were killed, the majority by bullets, while 750 were injured and 3,000 were detained.
1991: Two mainland journalists arrive in Taipei, marking the first-ever visit to the ROC by the mainland Chinese press.
1995: The United States government decides to stop all nuclear testing.
1996: ROC Vice President and Premier Lien Chan departs for the Dominican Republic to attend the Aug. 16 inauguration of President Leonel Fernandez.
1999: CAL signs an agreement with Airbus Industrie of Europe for a US$1.8 billion order for seven A340-300 passenger jets, with an option for one more A340-300 and four A330-300s.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh urges mainland China to produce a president through popular elections so as to bridge the gap between the political systems and public opinion on either side of the Taiwan Strait.
2001: The Taiwan Solidarity Union, a political party formed by some of former President Lee Teng-hui's followers is formally inaugurated, with a written congratulatory message from President Chen Shui-bian read out at the ceremony.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way for a man to be true to himself. If he does not know what is good, a man cannot be true to himself."

DOC.HEADLINE: Huashan turns to its past to flourish after 921 earthquake

TEXT.P: When a magnitude 7.3 earthquake rocked central Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999, the village of Huashan in Yunlin County's Gukeng Township was initially spared, far enough away from the quake's epicenter to withstand the blow.

But in the hours and days that followed, Huashan was battered by a series of landslides. The earthquake had shaken loose soil and trees on nearby mountain slopes, and powerful typhoons sent them cascading down into the village and the surrounding area.
Roads crumbled and houses, buildings and bridges collapsed under the weight of the buckling mountains.

Despite the destruction, Huashan has since pulled itself out of its nightmare to become a prosperous community, fueled by a crop that had been the town's trademark decades and even centuries earlier: coffee beans.

The coffee trade has enabled Huashan to reposition itself as a tourist destination with its famous Taiwan Coffee Festival, splendid night views and mountain forest landscapes, beautiful walkways and Koji pottery art.

With the help of the Yunlin County government and NT$600 million from the Soil and Water Conservation Bureau, the township also built the country's first debris flow education garden in Huashan three years after successive disasters.

The garden, which features natural landscapes and new equipment, such as flood drainage facilities, is a model for the control and prevention of debris flow, according to Yunlin County Councilor Hsieh Su-ya, who played an important role in Huashan's rebirth as head of Gukeng Township between 1998 and 2006.
The unique showcase not only helps protect the safety of local residents but also gives provides a boost to the local economy, she said.

Many of the park's water conservation features, such as sabo dams, slit dams, and sediment control dams, were environmentally engineered and built with locally available mud and gravel to prevent flooding, Hsieh explained.
Though the garden is one of the area's landmarks and has had a positive economic effect, it's coffee that sparked Huashan's economic revival.
"The transformation of Gukeng to prosperity did not happen overnight, " Hsieh said, recalling how hard she tried to create a unique agricultural brand for the township even before the earthquake hit.

She considered oranges, bamboo shoots, and tea, but after a meeting in 1998 with Chang Lai-en, a local coffee farmer in Gukeng's Hebaoshan region and a pioneer in the coffee business, Hsieh embraced the crop's potential because it evoked memories of Gukeng as a coffee growing town.

"Suddenly the answer arrived as though a gift from the gods," she says. "I realized at that moment that coffee was the best fit for us to go from traditional farming to recreational agriculture, or agrotourism."
According to the 50-something Chang, Gukeng was already planting coffee when the Dutch occupied Taiwan in the 17th century, and because of its high quality, it was all shipped overseas.
Hebaoshan, nicknamed 'Coffee Hill,' and the surrounding area used to be covered by coffee plants, he said.

The golden age of Taiwan's coffee industry started in 1902, when the colonial Japanese government decided to develop this lucrative crop, mainly in Gukeng, which had suitable soil and a subtropical climate.
Though Hsieh had taken to the idea of coffee in 1998, little was done until the township was shaken by the earthquake and subsequent landslides.
Farmers were encouraged by the local government to plant coffee to protect the topsoil, according to coffee grower Chung Chiu, who previously grew bamboo shoots.
"So we switched to coffee growing, " Chung said. "Coffee was our best hope to pull us together after the disasters."
It wasn't until four years later, however, that the community really made a name for itself when Hsieh launched the "Taiwan Coffee Festival" at a cost of NT$3 million.

Aside from raising the visibility of the rural township and putting a spotlight on the coffee industry, the event also generated NT$200 million for the local economy. Revenue from the festival soared the next two years to about NT$400 million and NT$1 billion, respectively.

Building on the success of the festival, the Gukeng Farmers' Association inaugurated a recreational agricultural center in October 2003, designed to hold training sessions on making coffee and special exhibitions, Hsieh said.

Another draw, the Literature Walkway, a brainchild of writer Ku Meng-jen, was inaugurated in 2004 when Ku was chief of the Yunlin County Cultural Affairs Department. A year later, Ku launched the Huashan Poet Festival.
The walkway stretches a distance of more than 600 meters and matches works of famous writers set in Yunlin County with the beautiful surrounding landscape.

The combination of nature and literature, along with the lure of locally grown coffee, attracted an estimated 1 million tourists a year to the mountain village of 35,000 inhabitants for much of the decade -- and the commercial impact is clearly evident.

More than 100 coffee shops and homestays have been set up in the greater Huashan region, earning a good share of the hundreds of millions of Taiwan dollars from tourists that pour into the area annually.

"Our business is booming, with a good influx of visitors who come to Huashan just to enjoy a cup of coffee, " said Lai Song-chi, a coffee shop operator who settled down in Huashan after the 921 earthquake.
Huashan's economic prosperity, however, has not been immune to the country's economic slump, as tourist numbers have plummeted within the past year.

Hsieh says the region must find innovative ways to revitalize itself again, such as improving coffee growing and roasting techniques, integrating sightseeing resources, developing regional agricultural products and tour itineraries, and improving the quality of tourist attractions.
But is hard to believe that any of those measures will live up to the tremendous boost the humble coffee bean gave to Huashan in pulling it out of its nightmare after the earthquake in 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: Floods and landslides triggered by Morakot leave Taiwan in tears

TEXT.P: The calamitous floods and landslides precipitated by Typhoon Morakot have left at least 62 people dead and dozens missing and caused at least NT$7 billion in agricultural losses as of Tuesday evening.
As the casualties and losses pile up after again being struck by nature, Taiwan weeps and wonders what the future holds.

Mud flows that buried a whole village in southern Taiwan, and floods that washed away dozens of houses on the east coast were natural phenomena that people on an island of extreme rainfall intensity, steep river slopes and brittle shaley hills inevitably face.

In the wake of the calamity, Fan Liang-hsiu, vice chairman of the National Disaster Prevention and Protection Commission, suggested Tuesday that villagers whose homes were destroyed by the mudflows over the weekend should be relocated because mudslides in mountainous areas very often reoccurred in the same spots in torrential rains.
But most villagers, he said, refuse to leave the land they have lived on for years, or even generations.

In the past, the government has worked out plans for 26 mountain villages to be relocated, but only two -- one in Taichung County and the other in Pingtung County -- were moved to locations which are much safer in times of heavy rainfall.

The rest continue to brave areas that are most vulnerable to nature's powerful forces, and they may face even more destructive mud and debris flows in the future during typhoons as climate change renders the weather even more unpredictable -- and volatile.

Statistics compiled by the Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs indicate that average annual precipitation in Taiwan is 2,500 mm, but up to 80 percent of that comes between May and October, during the summer typhoon season in particular.

This uneven rainfall distribution was particularly evident last week, which started with Taiwan wrestling over how to ration water amid a worsening drought and ended with a year's volume of precipitation pelting southern areas in three days, triggering the worst flooding the country had seen in 50 years.
As Typhoon Morakot hovered near and over Taiwan, it brought more than 2,000 mm of rainfall to Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties between Aug. 6-8.

In the southeastern county of Taitung, over 1,600 mm in rainfall in the mountains triggered serious mudslides. Debris flows and rapids turned the rivers into rampaging forces that swept away anything in their path.

That led to a number of shocking scenes televised around the world, such as the dramatic collapse of the Chin Shuai Hotel in the hot spring resort of Jhihben on Aug. 9, after the floodwaters eroded the river bank on which it stood.

While there is sure to be plenty of finger-pointing during the post-disaster period, former Water Resources Agency director Huang Ching-san said that human efforts to control water flows could be in vain when facing the extreme amount of rainfall seen in recent days.

He suggested that while the government has invested heavily in regulating rivers and channeling water to prevent floods, equally important tasks will be to avoid reckless land development, especially in mountainous areas, and reinforce soil and water conservation efforts.
