The wreckage of the helicopter was located on a steep mountainside some 500 meters west of an aboriginal settlement that is part of Wutai township later in the day by an airborne rescue team, which added that it was unable to reach the wreckage due to the steepness of the slope.

DOC.HEADLINE: 350 evacuated in Pingtung as rain continues

TEXT.P: A total of 350 people in five isolated villages affected by Typhoon Morakot in Pingtung County will be evacuated on Wednesday, the county government said.
These villages include Jiamu, Dawu, Ali, and Yila in Wutai Township as well as Dewun Village in Sandimen Township.
All six villages in Wutai Township have been cut off because all bridges and roads linking the mountainous villages with the outside world have been severely damaged.

Most of the villages are accessible only by single mountain roads that often cross or follow riverbeds. The roads and connecting bridges have buckled under the pressure of floodwaters precipitated by Typhoon Morakot.
Wutai township has a total population of 600. More than half of them will be evacuated by helicopters by Wednesday, according to the county's government.
Meanwhile, The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) maintained its heavy rain warning for southern Taiwan Wednesday.
The bureau said that mountainous areas in central and northern Taiwan could also be hit by more torrential rains.
The CWB also warned that residents in mountain areas should be on the alert for falling rocks, mudslides and landslides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Satellite images show power of natural forces

TEXT.P: Satellite images released Tuesday demonstrated just how powerful the floods and mudslides unleashed by Typhoon Morakot were as they devastated much of southern Taiwan.
One of the most stunning images obtained by the Center for Space and Remote Sensing Research (CSRSR) under National Central University was the explosive expansion of the Taimali River in Taitung.

The images showed that the upper stream of the river, which originally was barely more than 10 meters wide, spread to more than 800 meters as large amounts of mud were washed down the mountain by heavy rainfall.
Chang Chung-pai, an associate professor at the center, said the mudslides observed in this typhoon have been the largest on record both in terms of length and scale.

"Mudflows that we observed in the past usually filled about 10 kilometers of the river. But the entire Taimali River was filled with mudflows in this typhoon, " he said of the 31-kilometer long river.

According to Chang, both the toppled Chinshuai Hotel in Taitung's Jhihben hotspring area and the collapsed Shuangyuan Bridge in Kaohsiung County were located on the outer edge of a river bend, where the water's momentum and erosive potential are the strongest.

Comparing the bridge's satellite images taken Jan. 14 and Aug. 11, the CSRSR found that the bridge broke up over the west side of Gaoping River, the point where the water was deeper and flow rate was faster.

Torrential rainfall from Typhoon Morakot, which battered Taiwan over the weekend, triggered the worst flooding in 50 years, leaving at least 62 dead, 35 injured and 57 unaccounted for, according to the Central Emergency Operation Center. Also, many became homeless when their homes were buried by mudslides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Medical staff enter hardest-hit disaster zones

TEXT.P: Medical workers have finally entered flood- and landslide-ravaged villages in remote mountainous areas of southern Taiwan to offer emergency medical services, medical sources said Wednesday.

Medical staff from Kaohsiung's Chang Gung Memorial Hospital and I-Shou University Hospital were airlifted to Kaohsiung County's Namasia Village Tuesday afternoon to man an emergency health care station, the sources said.

The station housed at the Presbyterian Church in the village has extended first- aid treatment for injured villagers rescued from homes buried by mudslides, the sources said, adding that some ailing villagers were also given emergency treatment before being transferred to referral hospitals.
An I-Shou spokesman said the hospital has also sent physicians and surgeons to the Department of Health-run Cishan Hospital in nearby Cishan township to provide care to newly rescued villagers.

A number of mountainous villages in Kaohsiung County, including Siaolin, Taoyuan, Maolin, Namasia, Jiasian and part of Liouguei were cut off from the oustide world after Typhoon Morakot delivered staggering amounts of rainfall to southern Taiwan Aug. 7-9.

Most of the towns are accessible only by single mountain roads that often cross or run parallel to rivers. Unable to withstand the pressure of rampaging waters, the roads and bridges buckled under the pressure, hampering rescue efforts.
Medical professionals managed to enter the devastated villages by helicopter only after continuing downpours subsided Tuesday.

Chang Gung Hospital said a team of its medical staff was airlifted to Jiasian from Cishan Junior High School in neighboring Cishan township Wednesday morning to set up an emergency medical station to serve rescued villagers. Hundreds of residents have been trapped in Jiasian since Aug. 7.
Meanwhile, a villager from Namasia Village urged health authorities to step up disinfection operations because a foul smell is permeating his hometown.
"I am afraid that if we delay disinfection efforts, epidemics may break out, a situation that would aggravate our current woes, " said Lin Nan-chi, who was resuced late Tuesday.

The Kaohsiung County-based Fo Guang Shan Monastery has also sent medical service vehicles to the stricken southern counties of Chiayi, Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Tainan to offer health care and mental counseling for traumatized flood victims, a spokesman for one of Taiwan's most famous Buddhist organizations said.
As of Tuesday, the typhoon had left 62 people dead, 35 injured and 57 unaccounted for, according to statistics released by the Central Emergency Operation Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Wednesday:
UNITED DAILY NEWS:
Is it preposterous to evacuate 50,000 residents?

After Typhoon Morakot brought unexpected precipitation last weekend, and several villages in southern Taiwan were "buried" by mudslides, a much-blamed county chief blurted out that to evacuate up to 50,000 residents is a daunting task.
The official even asked what official would dare to order an all-out evacuation when a forecast called for 1,000 mm of rainfall.
But as the death tolls continue to rise, would the magistrate still think it absurd to evacuate 50,000 villagers and mitigate the disaster?
As a local chief, the magistrate should know the vulnerability of the county's soil and water conservation and has more authority and responsibility for risk assessment.
The mindset of officials should change, especially at a time when climate change in recent years has become unpredictable and "extreme" phenomena can happen.
LIBERTY TIMES:
President Ma, please show more concern for this land
The devastation caused by Typhoon Morakot has exposed the fallacy of the Ma administration's guiding principle.
His principle, in a nutshell, is "cross-strait relations is paramount and supersedes all else."
President Ma has been keen on the so-called 1992 consensus, the resumption of cross-strait talks and has even hinged Taiwan's economic development to China, despite it being a sugar-coated toxin.
With his mind set on China, it is natural that he would ignore this land. Last year's Typhoon Kalmaegi already gave sufficient warning to Ma that the island's infrastructure is miserably inadequate.

But regrettably, Ma's only concern is China. He has no regard for his land and its people so that the tragedies of bridges collapsing, rivers overflowing, and foundations eroding have been repeated again and again.
APPLE DAILY:
North-South perception gap in government rescue operations
The slow or even obtuse response by the Ma administration to Typhoon Morakot is related to the administration being located in Taipei and its Taipei-oriented perception.
It had no empathy for the serious flooding in southern Taiwan as northern Taiwan only experienced relatively mild rains when the typhoon battered Taiwan over the weekend.
Taiwan is not diverse geographically, and the differences in northern and southern Taiwan lie mainly in other areas, such as fashion, language and their reactions to situations.
The consciousness gap has regrettably widened with each election's political maneuvering.
Taipei, as the capital of Taiwan, s the power center, which has given rise to its cultural supremacy and the phenomenon of slighting people in southern Taiwan.

But Taiwan is small, and whether people live in southern or northern Taiwan, they have identical memories. Their differences have been augmented by political factors, which are hidden at a subconscious level until exposed at critical moments.
Taiwan needs to think deeply about this hidden bias so as to forge a national consensus that we are all in the same boat.
CHINA TIMES:
Face China and you can get hold of the world
Want Daily, the first Taiwanese daily devoted to China news, was launched Tuesday.
The emergence of China is a fact that one can no longer ignore, and the birth of the daily reflects the new trend: know China and you can get hold of the world.

According to a Want Daily public opinion poll, 57 percent of local people think China is important to Taiwan's future development, but only 28 percent said they know China, and up to 72 percent said they have insufficient knowledge of it.

Cross-strait exchanges over the past two decades have not been enough to close the gap in cross-strait political, cultural and social aspects created by four decades of isolation between the two sides.

Taiwan needs to face China and learn about it again. We have to face what we may be unwilling to admit. China has really undergone change. Taiwan cannot be complacent about what it has achieved over the past six decades and continue to ignore it.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bodies of helicopter crash victims recovered

TEXT.P: Rescuers have recovered the bodies of three crew members who were killed a day earlier when their helicopter crashed in mountainous Wutai Township in Pingtung County, the Central Emergency Operation Center said Wednesday.

The bodies were first removed from a mountain slope, where they were found, to a valley before being airlifted to the National Nei-Pu Senior Agricultural- Industrial Vocational High School, according to National Fire Agency Director- General Huang Chi-min.

Huang said the victims showed no signs of life when they were discovered by an airborne rescue team Tuesday afternoon soon after the accident. The team did not airlift the bodies out of the area at that time because it was getting dark, he added.

The UH-1H helicopter belonging to the National Airborne Service Corps hit a mountainside and crashed into a valley near the aboriginal settlement of Sandimen at 3:30 p.m. Tuesday while carrying out a mission to help victims of natural disasters triggered by Typhoon Morakot.
Following the accident, the corps grounded all UH-1H helicopters for inspection.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA News Budget for Aug. 12

TEXT.P: landslides make Taiwan weep 2. Satellite images show power of natural forces 3. 350 evacuated in Pingtung as downpour in the cards 4. Religious groups begin cleaning in flood-stricken areas

5. Emergency medical station set up in disaster zone Villagers call for disinfection 6.PTT BBS users raise funds for victims of Typhoon Morakot 7. Bodies of helicopter crash victims recovered 8. Alliance formed to adopt mudslides-battered villages 9. President inspects Pingtung, 100 bridged blocked 10. Agricultural losses from Morakot second-highest in 18 years

DOC.HEADLINE: PTT BBS users launch donation drive for victims of Typhoon Morakot

TEXT.P: Users of PTT, a terminal-based bulletin board system (BBS) based in Taiwan, have launched a fund raising drive that has already provided relief supplies such as food and clean water for people living in areas hard-hit by Typhoon Morakot.

PTT, the largest BBS in the country with more than 1.5 million registered users, said it will request more help from its users and coordinate its relief efforts with local charity organizations such as World Vision and the Tzu Chi Foundation.
"We raised more than NT$100,000 (US$3,041) in one hour and purchased relief supplies online," said Liao Chi-cheng, the initiator of the "PTT users disaster relief team."
Liao added that relief supplies, including food, water, rain shoes, sleeping bags and bleach, have been delivered to Pingtung County by online suppliers and will be distributed by World Vision.
"When those online suppliers realized the orders were for typhoon victims, they also made donations immediately, " Liao said.
Some PTT users in Kaohsiung are cooperating with Tzu Chi and the Kaohsiung County government and joining their volunteer teams, Liao said.

He continues to appeal for more relief supplies and volunteers and said he welcomed anybody who wants to make a donation or become volunteers to visit the PTT donation station at Taipei's Liberty Square Wednesday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alliance formed to urge adoption of devastated mountain villages

TEXT.P: A group of northern Taiwan-based politicians and medical professionals formed an alliance Wednesday to pool resources to help flood- and mudslide-ravaged aboriginal villages in southern Taiwan get back on track.

"As many people in Taipei City are anxious to extend a helping hand, the alliance decided to take direct action and adopt hard-hit aboriginal villages in southern Taiwan, " said Lee Shin, a ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Taipei City councilor.

The "88 Taiwan Warmth Delivery Alliance" will enlist physicians, nurses, pharmacists and social workers to enter the most severely impacted villages in mountainous areas of southern Taiwan, most of which are home to indigenuous tribal people, Lee said at a news conference held at the Legislative Yuan.
"If all goes smoothly, our medical relief workers will set off before this coming Sunday to undertake post-disaster rehabilitation operations in affected zones," Lee said.
He also urged more like-minded people to join the alliance and make donations to sponsor rehabilitation projects in devastated aboriginal villages.

Speaking on the same occasion, Hou Chin-chu, head of Shihzih Township in the southernmost county of Pingtung, said floods and landslides triggered by Typhoon Morakot had hurt the county's aboriginal communities far more than has been reported in the media.

"Many villages, such as Wutai, Sandimen, Majia, Taiwu and Laiyi, have all been isolated after extremely heavy rainfall delivered by Morakot knocked out roads and bridges connecting them to the outside world, " Hou said.
He added that many village residents believed to be trapped were in desperate need of help.

Huang Sung-hsiung, a physician from the New Taiwanese Cultural Foundation who is also a member of the "88 Alliance, " said the alliance will organize teams of doctors, nurses, pharmacists and public health experts to visit disaster areas in southern Taiwan later this week.
They will offer survivors professional medical services and mental counseling as well as help with the environmental cleanup to prevent outbreaks of communicable diseases.
Another alliance member, KMT Legislator Lo Shu-lei, said the disaster zones now need not only instant noodles but also detergents and medical supplies, such as surgical masks.
"The alliance has sent 2,000 masks to Kaohsiung County to meet the demand, " said Lo, who also urged others to join the new alliance to assist in post- disaster rehabilitation operations.
A spokesman for Althea Medical Resources Integrated Service said the company has decided to join the alliance and help in getting medical aid to flood survivors.
"We will dispatch well-equipped medical vehicles to assist medical personnel sent to disaster zones by government authorities in providing medical attention to flood victims," said the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close marginally lower on local bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed marginally lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 10.12 points, or 0.14 percent, to close at 6,898.9.
The local bourse opened at 6,878.34 and fluctuated between 6,933.51 and 6,864.91 during the day's trading session.
A total of 3.63 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$103.26 billion (US$3.14 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 1.7 percent. Banking and financial shares declined 1.6 percent, while cement stocks dropped 0.2 percent.

The five other major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 2 percent. Foodstuff issues increased 1.6 percent, machinery and electronics shares were up 0.3 percent, textile stocks and plastics and chemicals shares both advanced 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,226 to 1,078, with 191 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$4.73 billion-worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT donates US$250,000 for Typhoon Morakot victims

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) donated US$250,000 Wednesday to the stricken families in areas devastated by Typhoon Morakot.

"The people of the United States of America have been moved by the humanitarian tragedy in Taiwan caused by Typhoon Morakot. On behalf of the American people, AIT would like to convey its deepest sympathy for the victims and their families," the AIT said in a press release.
"At the same time, we are struck by the courage, determination and unity of purpose of the Taiwan people in responding to this crisis," it added.

In support of the response to the disaster, the AIT donated the money to the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China. The money, provided by the U.S. Agency for International Development, will be used to provide immediate assistance to households affected by the typhoon, according to the AIT, which serves as the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations.
"We are confident the Red Cross will use our contribution in the most efficient and effective manner possible to alleviate the suffering and hardship of the typhoon victims," the AIT said.

The United States and the AIT have supported the humanitarian work of Taiwan's Red Cross in previous natural disasters, according to the U.S. agency, adding that it deeply appreciates the assistance Taiwan has provided for victims of natural disasters in the United States, including during Hurricane Katrina in 2005.

Typhoon Morakot hovered over Taiwan Aug. 7-8, lashing parts of the country with massive amounts of rain. It dumped a record 2,500mm of precipitation in Taiwan's southernmost county of Pingtung, causing severe flooding in at least three coastal townships.

As of 12: 00 p.m. Wednesday, the flooding there and elsewhere, along with widespread landslides, had left 67 people dead, 45 injured and 61 unaccounted for. The casualties included three rescuers who were killed a day earlier when their helicopter crashed in mountainous Wutai township in Pingtung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Charity foundations help clean up typhoon wreckage

TEXT.P: Charity organizations have begun to help clean up areas that suffered major damage from flooding and landslides triggered by Typhoon Morakot over the weekend.
Leading the way are the Dharma Drum Mountain Social Welfare and Charity Foundation (DDMSWCF) , the Tzu Chi Foundation and the Eden Social Welfare Foundation (ESWF).
On Tuesday they organized volunteer teams to help clean up typhoon stricken areas as floodwaters began to recede.

The DDMSWCF, a Buddhist charity foundation, has targeted its cleanup efforts at the coastal towns of Linbian and Jiadong in Pingtung County. Groups of eight volunteers were led at dawn by masters from Dharma Drum Monastery in cleaning debris and shattered houses in the areas.
In addition, volunteers, who made their way to disaster areas at their own expense, also formed investigation teams to survey the area and learn more about the needs of local residents.
The foundation said that by clearing the typhoon wreckage, it was also clearing the minds of the disaster victims and helping lift away their heavy spirits caused by the natural disaster.

The Tzu Chi Foundation, another Buddhist charity organization, appealed to volunteers to join their local Tzu Chi cleanup team and said residents in Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties can sign up at the foundation's meditation halls.
The Eden Social Welfare Foundation said it has been deploying professional volunteers to disaster areas since the typhoon hit to provide counseling and prepare the victims to rebuild their homes.
It will also organize groups to engage in cleanup operations.

The charity foundations have also engaged in other relief efforts. The DDMSWCF began sending drinking water, sleeping bags, lunch boxes and flashlights to shelters on Aug. 8, the day after the storm dropped much of its rain on Taiwan, benefiting 15,000 people.

The Tzu Chi Foundation recruited 15,000 volunteers who have passed out over 200,000 hot lunches through Tuesday to disaster victims. It also plans to dole out grants ranging from NT$5,000 to NT$10,000 to help 12,000 victimized households.

Typhoon Morakot hovered over Taiwan Aug. 7-8, lashing parts of the country with powerful winds and torrential rains. The storm dumped a record 2,500 mm of rain on Pingtung County, causing severe flooding in at least three coastal townships.
As of 11 a.m Wednesday, flooding and landslides triggered by the typhoon had left 67 people dead, 45 injured and 61 missing.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, increasing NT$0.095 to close at NT$32.950.
A total of US$1.01 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.885 and fluctuated between NT$32.800 and NT$32.950.

DOC.HEADLINE: President inspects typhoon damage in Pingtung, Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou inspected Jiadong and Linbian townships in Pingtung County Wednesday, both of which are in one of the hardest-hit regions after Typhoon Morakot swept southern Taiwan over the weekend.

Ma instructed officials accompanying him to do their utmost to help with the county's recovery work and promised that the government will help the victims rebuild their homes and allow them to get back to their normal lives.
He also instructed that sick and elderly people, as well as women and children, should be evacuated from danger areas first.

In Jiadong township, which relies heavily on grouper aquaculture, Ma and his entourage were intercepted by a group of local residents who appealed for help. The president listened to several villagers emotionally decrying their losses and gave his assurance that the government will assist all the typhoon victims.
He also ordered the military, local governments and central government agencies, including the Council of Agriculture, to fully cooperate in rescue and reconstruction tasks.

Pingtung Magistrate Chao Chi-hung and Vice Secretary-General to the President Lai Feng-wei accompanied Ma on his tour, braving the stench of the thousands of rotten fish that had been washed from the area's fishponds into the flooded streets.
Chao said the top priority was to clean up the dead fish to prevent disease and he called for heavy machinery to pump the floodwater out of local townships.
Later that same day, the president proceeded to neighboring Kaohsiung County, which was also severely damaged by mudslides caused by the extreme precipitation brought by Morakot.

Accompanied by military generals and Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing on a tour of Cishan Junior High School, which was being used as an emergency staging post for victims evacuated from nearby mountain townships, Ma said rescue helicopters would be mobilized to rescue other villagers still stranded in the mountains and added that the military will deliver relief materials to them in the meantime.
He added that the government will mandate forced evacuation if some of them are unwilling to leave their homes.

He also pledged that the government will take full responsibility for the victims' accommodation and medical treatment once they are transported to safety and that the government will provide subsidies for their property and agricultural losses.

According to the latest government statistics, 67 people had been killed, including three crew members of a helicopter that crashed while on a relief mission in Wutai township in Pingtung County, with 61 missing and 45 injured in the wake of Typhoon Morakot -- the worst to hit southern Taiwan in 50 years.

Nearly 100 bridges in central and southern Taiwan damaged by Morakot remained closed as of Wednesday noon, with no expectation that traffic would be resumed any time soon, the Directorate-General of Highways reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady keeps close track of typhoon aftermath

TEXT.P: The principal of a Pingtung County elementary school said Wednesday that first lady Chow Mei-ching has been keeping a low-profile eye on the school following Typhoon Morakot, e-mailing the school every day to show her concern.
Wu Li-hua, principal of the Taiwu Elementary School, told CNA that Chow always e-mails whenever a natural catastrophe occurs.
The school was severely damaged by Morakot, which drew Chow's attention, Wu said.

Wu said Chow e-mailed her every day even before the typhoon hit, and was very concerned about the school's graduates who attend junior high school in neighboring Laiyi township, which was also hit hard by the typhoon, offering to help obtain assistance for them, Wu said.

Chow first visited the school in 2008 when she made a trip to the remote indigenous Taiwu township with two university professors to inspect local education facilities. During the trip, Chow promised to help raise NT$160,000 to finance a summer lunch program for students there.

Meanwhile that day, the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, of which Chow is honorary chairwoman, said the organization was studying the possibility of having Chow participate in volunteer services in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses from Morakot second-highest in 18 years

TEXT.P: Agricultural and fishery losses from Typhoon Morakot, which hit Taiwan directly last weekend, had reached an estimated NT$7.8 billion (US$237 million) as of Wednesday, according to the latest government statistics.
Figures complied by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) showed that the storm damage estimate was the second-highest in the 18 years since the COA started to keep such records.
The worst agricultural disaster was caused by Typhoon Herbert in August 1996 when NT$18.08 billion in agricultural losses were recorded, according to the COA.
The statistics showed that damage to crops amounted to nearly NT$3.17 billion, with 27 percent of the crops on 55,050 hectares of farmland lost.
Bananas suffered the heaviest damage, with 5,605 hectares ravaged by strong winds and flooding, followed by papayas, guavas, sweetsops,rice, bamboo shoots and leafy vegetables.
Fisheries losses reached a new high of nearly NT$3.4 billion, exceeding the NT$2.43 billion recorded when Typhoon Herbert hit thirteen years ago, COA data showed.
A combined 6,074 hectares of fish farms in southern Taiwan were badly damaged by Morakot -- the worst typhoon to hit the south in 50 years.
Poultry and livestock losses amounted to NT$1.21 billion, with 5.32 million chickens, 922,000 ducks, and 101,802 pigs perishing in the storm.
Meanwhile, an estimated NT$174 million in damage to agricultural facilities was reported, and 647 hectares of farmland were washed away, according to the COA.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1,000 typhoon victims still awaiting evacuation in Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: Nearly 1,000 residents of flood- and mudslide-ravaged villages in mountainous areas of southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County were still awaiting evacuation Wednesday, according to military authorities.

"Army rescue teams who managed to reach isolated mountainous villages in Kaohsiung County had located nearly 1,000 villagers as of Wednesday morning," said Maj. Gen. Hu Jui-chou, the political warfare chief of the 8th Army Corps.

"I received a satellite phone call from one of our rescue teams Tuesday night saying that more than 500 residents from Namasia township's Minchuan and Mintsu villages, and 200 each from Taoyuan township's Chinho village and Jiasian township's Siaolin village had been found, " Hu said at a news conference held at an army base in neighboring Pingtung County.
"The following morning, 70 more residents were also located in Wulipu, near Siaolin," Hu went on.
"All of the rescued villagers are safe and do not face any life-threatening dangers," Hu continued, adding that military rescue teams had provided them with ready-to-serve rations and drinking water.
The military had also assigned 18 UH-1H choppers, two CH-47SD and five B-234 transport helicopters to evacuate the disaster victims from their mudslide- devastated hometowns, Hu said.
"So long as weather permits, the military aircraft will fly up to 136 sorties today to evacuate all stranded typhoon victims, " Hu added.

Wednesday's rescue efforts were centered around Kaohsiung County's Jiasian, Taoyuan, Maolin, Namasia and Liouguei townships, all of which were cut off by Typhoon Morakot-triggered devastation Aug. 7-9.

Speaking on the same occasion, Maj. Tsai Tsung-you, one of the leading officers in the previous day's mountain rescue operations, said the Chinho village chief was picking wild edible plants when he spotted the arriving military rescue party.
According to Tsai, the chief was surprised by the earlier-than-expected arrival of rescue personnel.
"Given the massive scale of the devastation, the village chief said he originally guessed that it would take at least a week or more for rescue teams to arrive," said Tsai.
The chief further said that he evacuated all of the Chinho residents to the village's activity center when Typhoon Morakot struck Aug. 8
"This timely evacuation helped save the lives of all the villagers," Tsai noted.

Maj. Tang Teng-kai, who led a rescue team into Siaolin, another typhoon-battered village, said more than 200 villagers there were evacuated to an elevated hut inhabited by nearby construction workers before the onslaught of the typhoon.

The Siaolin villagers had become a focus of media attention over the previous two days, as some survivors who left the village earlier told the media that they were afraid many of their neighbors might have been buried alive by mudslides triggered by Morakot-induced torrential rain.

The typhoon delivered staggering amounts of rainfall to southern Taiwan Aug. 7-9, taking out roads and bridges connecting many mountainous villages in the region with the outside world, leaving many villagers trapped and hampering rescue efforts.
The storm had left 67 people dead, 61 missing and 45 injured as of noon Wednesday, according to statistics released that day by the Central Emergency Operation Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. standing by to offer help for typhoon victims: AIT official

TEXT.P: The United States is standing by to offer assistance such as equipment and technology to help the stricken families in areas devastated by Typhoon Morakot over the weekend, the acting director of the Taipei-based American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) said Wednesday.

Robert Wang made the remarks at a donation ceremony in which the U.S. government offered US$250,000 dollars to Republic of China Red Cross Society Secretary- General Steven Chen in support of the response to the natural disaster.
The money, provided by the U.S. Agency for International Development, will be used to provide immediate assistance to households affected by the typhoon, according to Wang.

"We are so touched by the relief efforts by the public and the government and admire very much the courage of all the rescuers. Therefore, the United States decided to make a quick response to disaster relief efforts by making this small contribution in the hope that it will help the victims," Wang said.

The AIT, which serves as the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations, also contacted various government agencies in Taiwan, including the National Security Council and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), and expressed its willingness to provide more assistance if necessary, according to Wang.
"We will do our best to help if the Taiwanese authorities have any needs, which can be made to the AIT directly," Wang said.
Chen said the Red Cross appreciated the AIT donation and will make best use of the money to help the victims.

MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said earlier in the day that the Foreign Ministry appreciates the support and concern expressed by the international community but indicated that Taiwan will not request foreign assistance at present because so far, the country is capable of handling the disaster relief work on its own.

Typhoon Morakot hovered over Taiwan Aug. 7-8, lashing parts of the country with massive amounts of rain. It dumped a record 2,500mm of precipitation in Taiwan's southernmost county of Pingtung, causing severe flooding in at least three coastal townships.

As of 12: 00 p.m. Wednesday, the flooding there and elsewhere, along with widespread landslides, had left 67 people dead, 45 injured and 61 unaccounted for islandwide. The casualties included three rescuers who were killed a day earlier when their helicopter crashed in mountainous Wutai township in Pingtung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local governments ordered to come up with rehoming plans in two days

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan ordered local governments Wednesday to work with the central government and come up with plans within two days to temporarily rehome victims of the devastation brought by Typhoon Morakot to allow them to get their lives back to normal.

Liu issued the order while inspecting the Central Emergency Operation Center, which has been closely monitoring the situations in several central and southern counties hit hardest by Morakot -- the worst storm to lash the south in 50 years.
"Many people have been made homeless by the typhoon, and local governments should begin work to rehome them as soon as possible, " he said.

Meanwhile, Liu went on, a disaster area service task force set up under the Executive Yuan a day earlier has established a coordination and service network in various cities and counties to provide assistance to people affected by the typhoon.

According to the premier, the Executive Yuan established the ad hoc group composed of staff from various agencies who were tasked with swiftly heading for six typhoon-affected cities and counties to assist the victims.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tzu Chi planning to build prefab houses for typhoon victims

TEXT.P: The Tzu Chi Foundation, a Buddhist charity, said Wednesday it is planning to build 95 prefabricated housing units in Taitung, eastern Taiwan, for victims of Typhoon Morakot.
According to Tzu Chi, 95 residents in Taitung's Taimali and Jinfeng village have been rendered homeless by the typhoon, which scored a direct hit on Taiwan last weekend.
The charity promised to erect 95 prefab units, using a similar approach as after the 921 earthquake in 1999, to house the homeless families by the end of August.

Tzu Chi said it has already conferred with the Taitung County Government on the plan and has begun to scout for suitable sites. Other locations for the erection of more emergency prefab houses are still being considered, as landownership issues are involved, it said.
As the scope of the damage from Typhoon Morakot gradually emerged, the Tzu Chi Foundation outlined a three-phase emergency relief plan, with the building of prefab houses being phase one.
The next two stages will be rehabilitation of the disaster victims, and psychotherapy under a "Project Hope" plan, it said.
Tzu Chi has been actively involved in international disaster relief work since 1991.
In related news, Chunghwa Telecom reported Wednesday that it had restored 40,000 telephone lines knocked out by the storm and still had 69,000 more to go.
The damage to phone lines was mostly scattered across central and southern Taiwan, it said.
In Linbian township in Pingtung County, the most severely affected area, 21 free temporary telephones have been installed and the base stations there have been repaired, the company said.

Typhoon Morakot hovered over Taiwan Aug. 7-8, lashing parts of the country with powerful winds and torrential rains. The storm dumped a record 2,500 mm of rain on Pingtung County, causing severe flooding in at least three coastal townships.
As of noon Wednesday, the flooding there and elsewhere had left 67 people dead, 45 injured and 61 missing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien school closed over A(H1N1) cluster infection

TEXT.P: A private senior high school in eastern Taiwan's Hualien County announced a six- day closure Wednesday after seven of its students were confirmed to have come down with swine flu, officially known as influenza A(H1N1).
A spokesman for Stella Maris Ursuline High School in Sincheng township said 23 of its students had shown flu-like symptoms since the school began its summer study program Aug. 6
The school reported the situation to the county's health department out of concern that it might have fallen victim to a swine flu cluster infection, the spokesman said.

Follow-up laboratory tests confirmed that seven of the students had indeed contracted A(H1N1) , the spokesman said, adding that all the students had already been discharged from hospital after recovering.
"Nevertheless, we decided to suspend school from today through Aug. 17 for environmental disinfection and cleanup, " said the spokesman.
Lin Nan-yueh, director of the Hualien County Health Bureau, said all seven students were mild cases and did not need to be quarantined.

Taiwan has seen a sharp increase in cases of flu-like illness over the past three weeks, with confirmed flu cases accounting for 21 percent of the total and cases of A(H1N1) flu accounting for 90 percent of those, an official of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said Tuesday.

"The number of patients infected with the A(H1N1) virus in Taiwan might have surpassed the 10,000 mark after an estimated 6,000 new mild cases were reported last week, with an epidemic likely as soon as the end of August," said CDC Director-General Kuo Hsu-sung.
According to Kuo, the number of patients infected with the new flu virus might register a further surge in the next two to three weeks, one month ahead of the seasonal flu peak season.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foundation to help children orphaned by typhoon

TEXT.P: A child welfare group said Wednesday that it will immediately put into effect a plan to help children who lost their parents to Typhoon Morakot, which devastated southern Taiwan over the weekend.

Child Welfare League Foundation representatives visited a temple in Kaohsiung County serving as a makeshift shelter for flood victims, bringing with them stationery and toys to comfort the children there.
The plan will see the foundation providing long-term care and school sponsorship for the bereaved children until they reach the age of majority.

"Children who have encountered calamity suffer physiologically, " said Alice Wang, executive director of the league, adding that "due to the psychological impact, they will experience fear, anxiety and nightmares and will need the companionship of adults."

Under its plan, social workers and volunteers of the foundation will visit the children at temporary shelters to help them cope with their stress and grief, in addition to hosting day camps for other children affected by the typhoon to ease the burden on their parents.
They will also target children who need long-term care and will arrange for regular visits or calls to help them get their lives back on track.
The storm had left 71 people dead, 61 missing and 45 injured as of 6 p.m. Wednesday, according to statistics released that day by the Central Emergency Operation Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses from Morakot exceed NT$9 billion

TEXT.P: Financial losses suffered by Taiwan's agricultural sector as a result of Typhoon Morakot had exceeded NT$9 billion (US$272.7 million) as of 3 p.m. Wednesday, according to statistics released by the Council of Agriculture (COA).
The figure was the second highest since 1991 when the COA started to keep such records, officials of the Cabinet-level council said.
The worst agricultural disaster in Taiwan was caused by Typhoon Herbert in August 1996 when agricultural losses of NT$18.08 billion were recorded.
Morakot-triggered damage to crops and animal husbandry production alone accounted for NT$7.94 billion, the officials said.
Damage to crops amounted to NT$3.24 billion, with 27 percent of the crops on 57,071 hectares of farmland lost, according to COA estimates.
Bananas suffered the worst damage, with 5,605 hectares ravaged by strong winds and flooding; followed by papayas, guavas, sweetsops, rice, bamboo shoots and leafy vegetables.
Poultry and livestock losses amounted to NT$1.24 billion, with 106,370 hogs, 5.4 million chickens and 962,000 ducks perishing in the storm.
Meanwhile, 684 hectares of farmland, worth an estimated NT$665.7 million, were washed away, with the eastern county of Taitung suffering the most with 524 hectares buried under debris or eroded.
The agricultural losses also included an estimated NT$174 million in damage to farming facilities.
The COA statistics also showed that the aquaculture sector incurred an estimated NT$3.49 billion in financial losses, a new 18-year high for losses in a single storm.

A combined 6,094 hectares of fish farms in southern Taiwan were severely damaged by Morakot, the worst typhoon to hit the south in half a century. Of the damaged aquaculture farm areas, 1,231 hectares were coastal fish ponds.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei aerospace and defense show to open Thursday

TEXT.P: The biennial 2009 Taipei Aerospace & Defense Technology Exhibition (TADTE) will be staged at the Taipei World Trade Center from Aug. 13-14, with 680 booths showcasing top notch products for the benefit of professional and business visitors.

The event, sponsored by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Ministry of National Defense (MND) , and Ministry of Transportation and Communications, is one of the leading aerospace and defense shows in the Asia-Pacific region, said the organizer, the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).

Apart from the MND, TAITRA said, the show will also feature the products of private companies from home and abroad, including the Taichung City-based Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. and U.S.- based Lockheed Martin Corp.

The MND will erect its largest ever TADTE pavilion, which will showcase the MND's advanced equipment for the Army, Navy, Air Force, Combined Logistics, Chung-shan Institute of Science and Technology (CSIST), and its Material Production and Manufacturing Center.

The pavilion will unfold in six sections, which will highlight weapons and equipment, simulation systems, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) , space technology, defense technology R&D, and dual-purpose technology.

The defense technology section will feature the Hsiung-Feng (HF) III Anti-Ship Missile and Tien-Kung III Anti-Air Missile, while the dual-use technology section will introduce platforms for converting military technologies into business opportunities.
A series of conferences and seminars will also be held during the exhibition to give visitors and firms a better understanding of the latest developments in the defense industry.
The guest speakers will be Lou Kratz and Tom Goudreau from Lockheed Martin and Ian McDonald and Alfred Wu from Oracle Company.

The forum, organized by National Space Organization (NSPO), will highlight opportunities for cooperation between the government and civil enterprises in the area of manufacture and supply of satellites, sub systems and related components.
For the air show, Songshan Air Force Base will be opened free of cost to the general public Aug. 15-16.
The air show will include mid-air spirals by F-16s and IDF jet fighters, an S70C low-altitude performance, and paratrooper display.
There will be displays of 13 anti-air weapons and vehicles, including 35mm guns, Patriot II Missiles, Hawk Missiles, vehicle-mounted Sky Sword I Missiles and M109A2 self-propelled howitzers.
Also on show will be 9 models of aircraft, including AH-1W Attack Helicopters, C-130 transport planes, and E-2K early-warning aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nan Shan Life workers' union demands job security

TEXT.P: The workers' union of Nan Shan Life, the Taiwanese unit of the American International Group (AIG) which is facing auction, demanded Wednesday that the company guarantee job security for its nearly 40,000 employees in Taiwan.

Nan Shan Life is open to bidding until Aug. 28, when AIG will close the bid and announce the new owner of the life insurance company, which has an extensive network of 35,000 agents serving 4 million policy holders in Taiwan.

The Nan Shan workers' union adopted a series of resolutions in a meeting Wednesday, including one to seek assistance from the Council of Labor Affairs and the Financial Supervisory Commission to ensure the job security of Nan Shan employees and to secure their pension fund.
A union source said that the pension fund, amounting to NT$14 billion (US$437 million), should not be counted as part of the company's assets.

The union, which is planning to hold a public hearing to discuss employees' rights and welfare, said it is awaiting responses to its requests from the company and relevant government agencies, and it will not rule out the possibility of taking to the streets if it does not receive favorable responses.
Since AIG's financial crisis was exposed last October, reports regarding the company's plan to auction its overseas businesses have worried Nan Shan's employees as well as policy holders.
The company revealed the auction plan in July and several international private equity funds are reportedly teaming up with financial holding companies in Taiwan to make the bid.
As of May 2009, Nan Shan's total assets amounted to NT$1.5 trillion, and the policies in force totaled 7.94 million, according to company statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ministry recruiting 10,000 students to help in disaster areas

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) announced Wednesday that it is recruiting 10,000 college and university students to join a campaign to clean up and rebuild schools and babysit children in areas devastated by Typhoon Morakot.
Vice Minister of Education Lu Mu-lin made the announcement following an emergency ministry meeting.

The MOE plans to recruit 100 students from each college and university to help with the rehabilitation of typhoon-hit schools in central and southern Taiwan and the care of elementary school students prior to the start of the new semester in late August or early September, Lu said.
At the same time, the ministry also hopes that the experience will help to foster social responsibility among college students, he explained.
Lu urged the public to donate relief supplies such as water containers, cooking appliances and computers to schools in areas of south and central Taiwan devastated by Typhoon Morakot.

Citing statistics compiled by the MOE, Lu said that 1,211 schools, including 1,048 elementary and junior high schools, had reported damage estimated at NT$1.1 billion (US$33.54 million) as of Wednesday afternoon.
Lu said a day earlier that the MOE will urgently allocate NT$20 million to Kaohsiung County to help local schools that were destroyed to open classes on Aug. 31 at the start of the new semester.
Tainan and Chiayi counties will each also receive NT$20 million and Pingtung County NT$30 million, he said.
The four southern counties were the regions worst hit by Typhoon Morakot over the weekend.

DOC.HEADLINE: Donations continue to flow in for post-disaster rehabilitation

TEXT.P: Individual and corporate donors from home and abroad continued Wednesday to donate funds for rehabilitation work, in the wake of serious flooding wrought by Typhoon Morakot in southern Taiwan over the weekend.

Eighteen corporate board members of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) donated a total of about NT$530 million (US$16.06 million) to help with post-disaster relief work.
ARATS Vice President Zheng Lizhong said at a donation ceremony in Beijing that the funds convey the Chinese people's goodwill and concern for Taiwanese flood victims.
Zheng said the money will be handed over to Taiwanese authorities through the ARATAS' counterpart in Taiwan, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).
ARATS and SEF are intermediary bodies established by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges and negotiations in the absence of official ties.
SEF Deputy Secretary-General Ma Shao-chang, on behalf of the Taiwan people and flood victims in particular, expressed gratitude to the ARATS board members for their generous donations.
"We believe this humanitarian aid from China during our time of hardship will contribute to the future development of cross-strait ties," Ma added.
The SEF has also received cash donations from major China-based Taiwanese trade associations and individual businessmen operating there.

As mainstream Chinese news media have given prominent coverage to Morakot- triggered flooding and mudslides in mountainous regions in central and southern Taiwan, many Chinese Internet users have also launched online appeals for aid for typhoon victims in Taiwan.
Meanwhile, major expatriate groups in the Greater New York area have raised more than US$110,000 in relief funds for flood victims in Taiwan.
On Wednesday, Evergreen Group Chairman Chang Jung-fa and member companies in the group donated a total of NT$520 million for post-disaster rehabilitation.
The group said it will also encourage its local and overseas employees to donate to the relief efforts.
Typhoon victims in need of relief supplies are also welcome to contact the Chang Jung-fa Foundation, an Evergreen Group spokesman said.
Another blue-chip company, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., also announced its decision to donate NT$150 million for rehabilitation.
In addition, the world's largest computer chip foundry will allocate NT$50 million in relief funds for its employees affected by the Morakot-triggered flooding and mudslides.

Many other local companies and individuals have also opened their heart and wallets to help typhoon victims, as the bank accounts opened by the Ministry of the Interior have received donations worth over NT$700 million in the past two days, according to an official.

With the aim of helping typhoon victims return to normal life as soon as possible, the Central Personnel Administration said it has directed all government agencies to encourage their staff members to donate one day's pay to the post-disaster rehabilitation drive.
As of 6 p.m. Wednesday, the typhoon death toll had risen to 71, while 61 people remained missing and 45 were reported injured.

DOC.HEADLINE: Debris flows damage undersea cables off southeastern Taiwan

TEXT.P: Deepsea debris flows off southeastern Taiwan, which were triggered by Typhoon Morakot, seriously damaged undersea cables and disrupted Internet services between Taiwan, China and Southeast Asia, according to Taiwan's main telecommunications company.

A spokesman for Chunghwa Telecom Co. said Wednesday that the debris flows in the Bashi Channel damaged several undersea cables there, including the Streaming Media World 3(SMW3), Asia Pacific Cable Network (APCN), APCN2, and East Asia Crossing (EAC).
However, telecommunications in Taiwan had been restored to normal by Wednesday evening, through Chunghwa Telecom's quick work and its initiation of a backup system, according to the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon death toll climbs to 103

TEXT.P: Rescue workers found a total 32 bodies buried in two mudslides at a hot springs resort and a remote village in Kaohsiung County Wednesday, which brought the death toll from Typhoon Morakot to least 103.
The Central Emergency Operation Center reported Wednesday evening that in addition to the 103 deaths, 61 people were still missing, and 45 injured as of 9 p.m.
Mud and debris flows have cut off roads leading to some remote mountainous villages, and hundreds of isolated villagers in the central and southern counties are still waiting to be evacuated.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$40 billion available for post-disaster rehabilitation: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Wednesday that the government can redirect more than NT$40 billion (US$1.21 billion) from its annual budget toward rehabilitation projects, in the wake of Typhoon Morakot which wreaked havoc in southern Taiwan over the weekend.

"The Executive Yuan can take more than NT$40 billion from its 2009 budget for certain programs and use it to finance more urgent post-disaster reconstruction work," said Liu at a news conference held after he met with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and caucus whips of the ruling and opposition parties.
Liu said he briefed Wang and the legislative whips of various political parties on the progress of the post-typhoon rescue and relief operations.
"I told them that the executive branch will decide how much it should spend on rehabilitation, based on the scale of destruction caused by Morakot-triggered flooding and mudslides," Liu said.

A more detailed estimate of the damage will be available by Thursday afternoon, Liu said, adding that by then, the executive branch will have a basis on which to calculate how much money will be needed for rehabilitation projects.
If necessary, Liu said, the Executive Yuan will draft special legislation to pave the way for a budget bill specifically to finance relief and reconstruction efforts.
"If it comes to that, we believe the Legislature will pass the special budget bill," Liu said.
The ruling Kuomintang controls an absolute majority in the Legislature.

As to whether President Ma Ying-jeou should declare a state of emergency to facilitate rehabilitation in the wake of the worst flooding disaster in southern Taiwan in half a century, Liu said he sees no need for that.
"When the Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake occurred, we did not have a disaster relief act in place, therefore, then-President Lee Teng-hui had to declare a state of emergency to facilitate the relief work.
Today, we have a Disaster Prevention and Relief Act, therefore, such a decree is not necessary, " Liu said, adding that Wang and many other lawmakers shared his view on the issue.

Responding to a U.S. State Department offer to assist in the post-typhoon rescue and relief operations in Taiwan, Liu said that if Taiwan needs foreign help in this regard, it will not hesitate to accept the offer.

Noting that rescue efforts in the past few days had been hampered mainly by bad weather, Liu said Taiwan has sufficient manpower and equipment to rescue residents trapped in several villages in remote mountainous regions in southern Taiwan ravaged by floods and mudslides.
Lu said he and Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng will travel to the hardest-hit Kaohsiung County Thursday to assess the damage caused by Morakot and to boost the morale of rescue workers there.
Rebutting criticism that military personnel were slow to get off the mark in the relief and rescue work, Liu said such criticism is unfair and untrue.
"Our military service members are efficient in their rescue operations," Liu argued.
According to military authorities, 34,214 servicemen have been mobilized to help evacuate 4,136 people stranded by floods in the past five days.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of National Defense said it will deploy an additional 4,056 servicemen in order to complete the post-disaster rescue work in a week.

As of 6 p.m. Wednesday, the typhoon death toll had risen to 71, while 61 people remained missing and 45 were reported injured.

DOC.HEADLINE: Debris flows damage undersea cables off southeastern Taiwan

TEXT.P: Deepsea debris flows off southeastern Taiwan, which were triggered by Typhoon Morakot, seriously damaged undersea cables and disrupted Internet services between Taiwan, China and Southeast Asia, according to Taiwan's main telecommunications company.

A spokesman for Chunghwa Telecom Co. said Wednesday that the debris flows in the Bashi Channel damaged several undersea cables there, including the Streaming Media World 3(SMW3), Asia Pacific Cable Network (APCN), APCN2, and East Asia Crossing (EAC).
However, telecommunications in Taiwan had been restored to normal by Wednesday evening, through Chunghwa Telecom's quick work and its initiation of a backup system, according to the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon death toll climbs to 103

TEXT.P: Rescue workers found a total 32 bodies buried in two mudslides at a hot springs resort and a remote village in Kaohsiung County Wednesday, which brought the death toll from Typhoon Morakot to least 103.
The Central Emergency Operation Center reported Wednesday evening that in addition to the 103 deaths, 61 people were still missing, and 45 injured as of 9 p.m.
Mud and debris flows have cut off roads leading to some remote mountainous villages, and hundreds of isolated villagers in the central and southern counties are still waiting to be evacuated.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$40 billion available for post-disaster rehabilitation: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Wednesday that the government can redirect more than NT$40 billion (US$1.21 billion) from its annual budget toward rehabilitation projects, in the wake of Typhoon Morakot which wreaked havoc in southern Taiwan over the weekend.

"The Executive Yuan can take more than NT$40 billion from its 2009 budget for certain programs and use it to finance more urgent post-disaster reconstruction work," said Liu at a news conference held after he met with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and caucus whips of the ruling and opposition parties.
Liu said he briefed Wang and the legislative whips of various political parties on the progress of the post-typhoon rescue and relief operations.
"I told them that the executive branch will decide how much it should spend on rehabilitation, based on the scale of destruction caused by Morakot-triggered flooding and mudslides," Liu said.

A more detailed estimate of the damage will be available by Thursday afternoon, Liu said, adding that by then, the executive branch will have a basis on which to calculate how much money will be needed for rehabilitation projects.
If necessary, Liu said, the Executive Yuan will draft special legislation to pave the way for a budget bill specifically to finance relief and reconstruction efforts.
"If it comes to that, we believe the Legislature will pass the special budget bill," Liu said.
The ruling Kuomintang controls an absolute majority in the Legislature.

As to whether President Ma Ying-jeou should declare a state of emergency to facilitate rehabilitation in the wake of the worst flooding disaster in southern Taiwan in half a century, Liu said he sees no need for that.
"When the Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake occurred, we did not have a disaster relief act in place, therefore, then-President Lee Teng-hui had to declare a state of emergency to facilitate the relief work.
Today, we have a Disaster Prevention and Relief Act, therefore, such a decree is not necessary, " Liu said, adding that Wang and many other lawmakers shared his view on the issue.

Responding to a U.S. State Department offer to assist in the post-typhoon rescue and relief operations in Taiwan, Liu said that if Taiwan needs foreign help in this regard, it will not hesitate to accept the offer.

Noting that rescue efforts in the past few days had been hampered mainly by bad weather, Liu said Taiwan has sufficient manpower and equipment to rescue residents trapped in several villages in remote mountainous regions in southern Taiwan ravaged by floods and mudslides.
Lu said he and Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng will travel to the hardest-hit Kaohsiung County Thursday to assess the damage caused by Morakot and to boost the morale of rescue workers there.
Rebutting criticism that military personnel were slow to get off the mark in the relief and rescue work, Liu said such criticism is unfair and untrue.
"Our military service members are efficient in their rescue operations," Liu argued.
According to military authorities, 34,214 servicemen have been mobilized to help evacuate 4,136 people stranded by floods in the past five days.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of National Defense said it will deploy an additional 4,056 servicemen in order to complete the post-disaster rescue work in a week.

DOC.HEADLINE: Donations continue to flow in for post-disaster rehabilitation

TEXT.P: Individual and corporate donors from home and abroad continued Wednesday to donate funds for rehabilitation work, in the wake of serious flooding wrought by Typhoon Morakot in southern Taiwan over the weekend.

Eighteen corporate board members of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) donated a total of about NT$530 million (US$16.06 million) to help with post-disaster relief work.
ARATS Vice President Zheng Lizhong said at a donation ceremony in Beijing that the funds convey the Chinese people's goodwill and concern for Taiwanese flood victims.
Zheng said the money will be handed over to Taiwanese authorities through the ARATAS' counterpart in Taiwan, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).
ARATS and SEF are intermediary bodies established by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges and negotiations in the absence of official ties.
SEF Deputy Secretary-General Ma Shao-chang, on behalf of the Taiwan people and flood victims in particular, expressed gratitude to the ARATS board members for their generous donations.
"We believe this humanitarian aid from China during our time of hardship will contribute to the future development of cross-strait ties," Ma added.
The SEF has also received cash donations from major China-based Taiwanese trade associations and individual businessmen operating there.

As mainstream Chinese news media have given prominent coverage to Morakot- triggered flooding and mudslides in mountainous regions in central and southern Taiwan, many Chinese Internet users have also launched online appeals for aid for typhoon victims in Taiwan.
Meanwhile, major expatriate groups in the Greater New York area have raised more than US$110,000 in relief funds for flood victims in Taiwan.
On Wednesday, Evergreen Group Chairman Chang Jung-fa and member companies in the group donated a total of NT$520 million for post-disaster rehabilitation.
The group said it will also encourage its local and overseas employees to donate to the relief efforts.
Typhoon victims in need of relief supplies are also welcome to contact the Chang Jung-fa Foundation, an Evergreen Group spokesman said.
Another blue-chip company, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., also announced its decision to donate NT$150 million for rehabilitation.
In addition, the world's largest computer chip foundry will allocate NT$50 million in relief funds for its employees affected by the Morakot-triggered flooding and mudslides.

Many other local companies and individuals have also opened their heart and wallets to help typhoon victims, as the bank accounts opened by the Ministry of the Interior have received donations worth over NT$700 million in the past two days, according to an official.

With the aim of helping typhoon victims return to normal life as soon as possible, the Central Personnel Administration said it has directed all government agencies to encourage their staff members to donate one day's pay to the post-disaster rehabilitation drive.
As of 6 p.m. Wednesday, the typhoon death toll had risen to 71, while 61 people remained missing and 45 were reported injured.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 13, or the 23rd day of the sixth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1814: The British formally take over the colony at the Cape of Good Hope, located at the southernmost tip of the African continent, from the Dutch.
1860: Annie Oakley, the American sharpshooter who could hit the edge of a playing card at 30 paces, is born as Phoebe Anne Oakley Moses.
1898: American forces led by George Dewey capture Manila during the Spanish- American War.
1899: Hollywood film director Alfred Hitchcock is born in England. He directed such classics as "Psycho" and "The Birds."
1910: Florence Nightingale, the British nurse known as "the Lady with the Lamp," dies at the age of 90. She organized and directed a unit of field nurses during the Crimean War and is considered the founder of modern nursing.
1923: Mustafa Kemal Ataturk is elected president of Turkey.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, commander in chief of China's Nationalist Revolutionary Forces, resigns in order to bring about solidarity between the Nanking and Hankow factions of the Kuomintang.
1927: Japanese troops launch a major attack on Shanghai and are met with stiff resistance from Chinese defenders.
1942: The United States and Britain decide to carry out joint research on the atomic bomb.
1949: Mao Zedong names Beijing as Communist China's capital.
1960: The Central African Republic gains independence from France.
1961: Communist East Germany begins the erection of the Berlin Wall, drawing strong protests from Western nations.
1967: Fifteen grand justices nominated by President Chiang Kai-shek are approved by the Republic of China's Control Yuan.
1969: Communist China and the Soviet Union accuse each other of sending troops across their Central Asian border and inflicting heavy casualties.
1974: Mort Young, deputy editor-in-chief of Hearst Newspapers in the United States, arrives in Taipei for a two-week visit.
1975: An eight-member Taiwan dance troupe leaves for La Paz to perform at celebrations marking Bolivia's independence day.
1976: Over 140 youths from 20 nations join in the opening ceremony of the International Youth Recreation Tour to the Republic of China sponsored by the China Youth Corps.
1976: The ROC Cabinet approves extension of the Sino-Uruguayan Agreement on Agricultural Cooperation for two years.
1978: A building serving as the Beirut headquarters of the Palestine Liberation Front and containing the offices of their rivals, Al-Fatah, is ripped apart by a bomb, leaving some 150 people dead.
1984: Six mainland Chinese freedom seekers freed by the Korean government arrive in Taipei. The six hijacked a Communist Chinese Trident plane from Shenyang, Manchuria, to Seoul, South Korea, on May 5, 1983.
1989: Two hot air balloons collide in the worst-ever hot air balloon disaster in Australia, with one of the balloons plunging 182 meters to the ground, killing 12 people.
1993: A hotel collapses in Thailand, killing over 120 people.
1999: The Council for Economic Planning and Development under the Executive Yuan estimates that the ROC's economic growth rate will reach 5.5 percent for the year.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian and his 200-member entourage leave Taipei, beginning a 13-day visit to six states in the Caribbean, Central America and Africa.
2001: Academia Sinica member George C. Tiao becomes the first scholar and the first ethnic Chinese to receive both the prestigious Wilks Memorial Award and the Julius Shiskin Award in statistics in the same year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Trust is the law of God. Acquired truth is the law of man."

DOC.HEADLINE: Township reborn from ashes gains newfound prestige

TEXT.P: Longan was traditionally an unremarkable village in central Taiwan, lacking the scenic vistas or a distinct historical and cultural heritage to set it apart from other communities and make outsiders take note.

That all changed on Sept. 21, 1999. A destructive magnitude 7.3 earthquake shook the village to its very foundations in the middle of the night, with many local residents killed by their collapsing homes.

Also jarred forever was Longan's anonymity and nondescript past, as survivors united and refused to surrender to the blast's devastation, rebuilding their community with the help of a team of architects headed by Luo Shi-wei, director of Tunghai University's Department of Architecture.

Luo's contributions continue to this day, in Longan and throughout Jhongliao Township in which the village is located, and the new institutions built and sustained since the earthquake have given the area newfound visibility.

Recalling the aftermath of the second deadliest earthquake in Taiwan's recorded history, Luo said he rushed to the area three days after the quake hit with more than NT$2 million (US$61,000) in donations from students, teachers and alumni of the department.

He wanted to use the money to build prefabricated housing units to shelter those rendered homeless by the quake, and he and his team of architects scoured the area for land on which they could install the pre-fab units.

They searched most of the worst-hit areas -- Nantou County's Caotun, Guosing, Puli, Jiji and Jhongliao townships, and Taichung County's Sinshe, Shihgang and Dongshih townships -- but had little success, stymied by land ownership and building construction issues.
Finally, one township lent a helping hand.

"We needed land to accommodate the shelters, and during those chaotic days, only Jhongliao Township chief Wu Chao-feng was willing to help us. He eventually contacted a local landowner who was willing to offer us his land near the Pingxi River to build the shelters, " Luo said.

Jhongliao is an agricultural township set in the mountains that had 4,829 households and 17,925 residents prior to the earthquake in 1999. It was an aging community, with many young people leaving home for the city to find work and live a more modern life.
The earthquake, centered in the neighboring township of Jiji, hit it as hard as any township in Taiwan.

A total of 178 lives were lost in Jhongliao, the highest number in proportion to its population of any township in the country, as 2,528 homes crumbled and another 1,417 were severely damaged. Most of the damaged homes were old brick houses.
Luo's prefabricated houses, which differed from the many temporary shelters being erected in the area at the time, offered every homeless household an independent living space of 427 square feet.

The distinction was critical to earthquake victims, Luo said, because what they needed was not just a short-term shelter but a place where they could start making a living again. The homeless families refused to see themselves as "refugees."

In the first several years after the destructive earthquake, Luo spent most of his time in the northern part of Jhongliao. Under his guidance, Cingshuei Village was relocated and rebuilt over a four-year period on solid ground, its new structures sturdily constructed to resist future quakes.

While the relocation of Cingshuei earned him many accolades, Luo believes his most influential restoration project in the shattered township was the establishment of a community educational center and a public kitchen for the elderly in Longan.

Opened May 7, 2000, the Lungyenlin community educational center was housed in the office of a local forestry conservation association and a bamboo factory. It offered classes to help local victims of the earthquake learn professional skills that enabled them to rebuild their homes and their lives.
In the center's first semester, area residents could choose from courses on computers, photography, English, medicinal plants, woodworking, and construction materials, Luo says.

The formation of the educational center was part of a broader rebuilding process, encompassing spatial, social and industrial reconstruction, in which it was hoped people would learn not only how to appreciate the place where they lived but also how to use local resources to improve their living environment and livelihoods.
Luo's initiatives fulfilled these goals, triggering the re-engineering and transformation of the aging community.
With knowledge learned at the center, some local farmers evolved into successful operators of competitive leisure-oriented farms. Others launched new businesses by growing medicinal plants.
Luo and his team also built a unique kitchen for Longan village that turned into a communal gathering ground for senior citizens to eat and converse together.
Opened in May 2001, the kitchen offered fresh and cheap lunches and dinners on a daily basis to seniors who were unable to care for themselves following the earthquake.

It also delivered meals to elderly people living alone in remote mountain areas, a service that eventually became a way to keep tabs on the health of these older residents, says village chief Liao Chen-yi.

The kitchen for seniors -- the only one of its kind in Taiwan -- and the Longyenlin community educational center have not been closed for even a day since they opened nearly a decade ago and continue to serve local residents today.

They have even become tourist attractions, their stories becoming legends that have caught the attention of outsiders and put the small village on the map, along with the area's new recreational farms and hiking paths.

Luo insists that his role was of trifling importance, saying he was just one of many people including historians, cultural workers and the local residents themselves, who helped the village rise again from the ashes.

In fact, he is thankful for all that he has learned from the restoration process, in which he witnessed severly scarred individuals and communities go through some intense soul-searching before learning to care for their living environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB forecasts more torrential rain

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) has forecast that torrential rain will continue Thursday in southern Taiwan, where vast areas have been saturated by downpours from Typhoon Morakot since Aug. 7 in the worst flooding in half a century.
There is also a chance of afternoon thunder showers in northern and central Taiwan Thursday, CWB meteorologists forecast.

Meanwhile the hot weather in Taiwan will persist, with temperatures expected to reach 35 degrees Celsius in northern Taiwan, 34 degrees central Taiwan and 33 degrees in the rest of the island Thursday, the CWB said.

As of 9 p.m. Wednesday, Typhoon Morakot, which pummeled Taiwan Aug. 7-9, had left at least 103 people dead, 45 people injured and 61 still missing. Agricultural losses were estimated at over NT$9 billion, according to figures released by the Central Emergency Operation Center.
