DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan sets up bank account to accept overseas donations
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 12 (CNA) 08/13/09 11:49:31 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng, Jennifer Huang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The government of Taiwan has set up a dedicated bank account to accept overseas donations for disaster relief in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York said Wednesday.

Expatriates wishing to contribute to the fund can remit their donations to the "Ministry of the Interior Donation Account" at Mega International Commercial Bank. The account number is 007-09-087816, and the swift code is ICBCTWTP007, the office said.
Donors can also mail checks directly to the Ministry of the Interior in Taipei or take them to any of Taiwan's overseas missions, the office said.

Typhoon Morakot battered Taiwan last week with strong winds and heavy rains that led to severe flooding and mudslides in some areas in central and southern Taiwan. The death toll from the disaster had climbed to at least 103 as of Wednesday, with 45 injured and 61 still missing, according to the Central Emergency Operation Center.

With the situation drawing wide attention in the international community, Japan has donated 10 million yen to Taiwan, and the United States has indicated its intention to make donations to help in the aftermath of the storm.

Also, the United Kingdom, Germany, France, Hungary, Israel, South Korea and South Africa have expressed their concerns. Many of Taiwan's diplomatic allies have expressed sympathy through their U.N. missions in New York over the past three days.

Meanwhile, various fundraising campaigns have been launched by Taiwanese- American organizations in New York, including the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association, the Taiwan Center, the New York branch of the Tzu Chi Foundation, and the New York branch of the Buddha's Light International Association.

In the United Kingdom, the Global Federation of Chinese Business Women will hold a charity sale and set up donation boxes at Ming-Ai (London) Institute at 2 p.m. Aug. 15, when Taiwanese pipa player Luo Chao-yun is scheduled to stage a performance.

At 2 p.m. Aug. 18, Taiwanese-British organizations will jointly hold a street fundraising event at London Chinatown to coincide with a Song Jiang battle array performance there by students from Taiwan's Shih Chien University.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Even greens gathered in the wild have been consumed:' survivors

TEXT.P: A storm survivor who has been stranded for six days in a township in the eastern country of Taitung sent out an email appeal Thursday saying that some 1,000 survivors of a killer mudslide in the mountainous area were on the verge of starvation.
"Even greens and taros gathered in the wild have been consumed, " said Lin Feng- shu, an elementary school teacher in Taitung County's Jinfong township, in the email.
Lin got the email out Thursday after Taiwan Power Co. and Chunghwa Telecom managed to restore Internet services, which were disrupted by Typhoon Morakot after it hit last Friday.

"Please help us quickly, " the letter stated. According to Lin, vast areas of Jinfong township -- a mountainous area that is traditionally home to aborigines -- have been without drinking water or electricity for six days and roads have been blocked by landslides.
Relief supplies, including bottled water, canned foods, instant noodles, powdered milk and basic daily necessities, are urgently needed, the school teacher said.
There are about 1,000 people stranded in the Jinfong area, she said.

Meanwhile, as of Thursday morning, many residents in the tribal communities of Taitung County's southern Dawu township remained cut off from the outsie world and still had no access to basic supplies.
Electricity was restored in some places in Dawu, but roads were still blocked, which meant that food and other items could not be supplied to the villages.
Residents there have begun to clean up their homes with their bare hands and on empty stomachs, according to a staff member of a local government office.

In the mountainous Lidao township -- a stop on the Southern Cross-Island Highway -- residents were living in constant fear of rockfalls triggered by the record- high rainfull brought by Typhoon Morakot, according to Wang Hsi-chun, an elementary school teacher based in Lidao.
"The Lidao Reservoir could break at any minute as the landslides continue," Wang said in an email.

Typhoon Morakot deluged parts of the country with massive volumes of rainfall Aug. 7-9, causing the worst flooding in Taiwan in half a century. It dumped a record 2,500mm of precipitation on Taiwan's southernmost county of Pingtung, causing severe flooding in at least three coastal townships.

As of 9 p.m. Wednesday, the storm had left at least 103 people dead, 45 people injured and 61 still unaccounted for islandwide. The casualties included three rescuers who were killed Tuesday when their helicopter crashed in the mountainous Wutai township in Pingtung County.

CNA News Budget Aug. 13

TEXT.P: Gov't will come up with a detailed list

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan has not declined foreign relief aid: president

TEXT.P: Taiwan has not rejected offers of foreign assistance in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, and in fact the government has accepted relief aid from several countries, President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday during an inspection tour of Tainan County -- one of the four worst-hit regions in southern Taiwan.
Ma made the remarks in response to questions from reporters while in Madou township, where the pomelo harvest was almost totally wiped out by Morakot over the weekend.
According to the president, as of Wednesday evening, the United States, Japan, Singapore and China had offered money and other aid to Taiwan and the government had accepted.

Speaking after a Cabinet meeting later Thursday, Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung said the president gave him instructions by phone that morning to have the relevant agencies immediately compile a list of the relief items needed from abroad.
Citing Premier Liu Chao-shiuan's remarks in the meeting, Government Information Office Minister Su Jun-pin said the same day that Taiwan welcomes donations from other countries.
"The United States has donated US$250,000, Japan 10 million yen, China 111 million yuan and Singapore US$200,000 and 50,000 Singapore dollars' worth of medicines," Su noted.
According to Su, the government will publish a detailed list of the items that it needs and will ask for international assistance to improve its rescue and relief operations.
"The list might include personnel, aircraft and heavy machinery," he added.

As of Thursday 10: 30 p.m., the Ministry of Economic Affairs had requested 100,000 bottles of disinfectant and 200,000 chlorine pills, the Department of Health had called for 1,500 disinfection machines, and the national research center had requested six rescue helicopters, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma pays respects to deceased village administrator

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou paid his respects Thursday to a deceased village administrator who slipped to his death during a daring effort to save his village in Yunlin County on a night when Typhoon Morakot was raging.
Ma visited the home of Miu Jung-tang, head of the Chinghan Village Office in Yunlin County's Kouhu township, and offered his condolences to Miu's family.
Miu, 47, is survived by his wife, their four children and his 80-year-old father who has been confined to a sick bed for years.

Miu braved strong winds and heavy rains on the night of Aug. 9 to climb onto a drainage channel near the coastal area of Chinghan Village to close the water gate and thus prevent the village from being inundated by waves kicked up by the typhoon.
However, immediately after closing the water gate, he slipped and fell into the channel where he drowned.
Praising Miu's efforts as heroic, Ma said Miu showed great courage in the face of danger and was a national role model.
Ma said he will see to it that Miu's family receives good condolence compensation from the government.

Meanwhile, the Yunlin County government in southern Taiwan presented a special certificate of commendation for bravery to Miu's family Wednesday and renamed the water gate as the Jung Tang Water Gate in commemoration of the late administrator.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices surge on local bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices surged Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, gaining 136.06 points, or 1.97 percent, to close at 7,034.96.
The local bourse opened at 6,949.5 and fluctuated between 7,037.47 and 6,931.55 during the day's trading session.
A total of 4.41 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$120.43 billion (US$3.66 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 2.9 percent. Plastics and chemicals shares advanced 2.7 percent, construction issues gained 1.9 percent, machinery and electronics shares rose 1.8 percent, foodstuff issues were up 1.7 percent, textile stocks advanced 1.5 percent, and paper and pulp issues rose 0.5 percent.
Only one of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks decreasing 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,838 to 597, with 144 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$6.56 billion worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet mulls special typhoon recovery budget

TEXT.P: The Cabinet will study the possibility of drawing up a special budget to meet the huge disaster relief needs in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot, an official said Thursday.

With this in mind, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan has instructed concerned agencies under the Cabinet to complete their estimates of the typhoon damage by Thursday afternoon and send their reports to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, said spokesman Su Jun-pin after a Cabinet meeting.
An estimate by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications puts transportation damage alone at more than NT$22 billion, Su said.
During the meeting, Liu issued a directive for the repair work on the transportation networks to continue and for the efforts to rescue stranded typhoon victims to be speeded up.
The number of airborne missions should also be increased to quickly evacuate the victims and deliver supplies to isolated communities, Liu said.
Authorities should respond early to the possibility of more heavy rains and strikes by other typhoons and should find proper places to relocate victims, Liu said.
He also urged the Fair Trade Commission and the Consumer Protection Commission to monitor consumer prices to ensure that they are maintained at reasonable levels.
Data provided by the Cabinet showed that a total of 2,877 victims in the counties of Nantou, Chiayi, Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Taitung were still awaiting evacuation by air to safer places.
There were also 308 injured or sick residents who needed to be airlifted to hospitals, and 74,822 kilograms of supplies had yet to reach storm victims.

Typhoon Morakot battered Taiwan last week with strong winds and heavy rains that led to severe flooding and mudslides in some areas in central and southern Taiwan. The death toll from the disaster had climbed to at least 108 as of Thursday, with 45 injured and 58 reported missing, according to the Central Emergency Operation Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, falling NT$0.052 to close at the day's low of NT$32.898.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.950 and fluctuated between NT$32.866 and NT$32.980.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shipment of relief supplies from Singapore arrives in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Taiwan received its first batch of disaster relief supplies from abroad Thursday in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot which wreaked havoc on the island Aug. 7-9.
The shipment of food and medical supplies, valued at US$34,652, was donated by Singapore to help people in areas devastated by Morakot.
The relief goods were flown to Taiwan on a Republic of Singapore Air Force C-130 transport aircraft, according to the Singapore Trade Office in Taipei.

Before shipping the supplies to Taiwan, the Singaporean government pledged Thursday to donate, through the Singapore Red Cross Society, US$200,000 to the relief efforts, the trade office said in a statement.
"The Singapore government extends its condolences and sympathy to the victims of Typhoon Morakot and their families, " the statement read.
The donation will be handed over by Singapore Trade Representative in Taiwan Stanley Loh to Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs at a ceremony in Taipei Friday, according to the statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady visits typhoon victims in Pingtung

TEXT.P: First lady Chow Mei-ching visited the southern county of Pingtung Thursday to show her concern for local residents who were left homeless by Typhoon Morakot.
The county's Jiadong and Linbian townships are among the areas that were severely flooded by Morakot's torrential rains. In many places in the townships, the floods had not yet subsided Thursday.

Chow, a member of World Vision Taiwan, first went to Datong village in Jiadong township to see children who are sponsored by the Christian charity. She then headed to National Chiatung Agricultural Vocational Senior High School, where typhoon victims are being temporarily sheltered.
The victims told the first lady that the floods rose so suddenly that the water level had reached the second floor of their homes in less than 20 minutes, forcing them to flee in a hurry.

They said they lost all their belongings and have been in the temporary shelter for four to five days. They urged the government to speed up the rescue and relief efforts so that they could return home as soon as possible.
Chow assured the victims that the efforts are being expedited and that they have not been forgotten.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mechanism in place to request international aid: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan has a mechanism in place to make immediate requests for international aid for disaster relief efforts whenever such needs are made known by the Central Disaster Emergency Operation Center, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

"We welcome all international assistance and will request international aid through the existing mechanism as soon as the government ascertains the needs of stricken areas, " MOFA deputy spokesman James Chang said at a regular press briefing.
"We will make sure international aid reaches the devastated areas as soon as it arrives," he added.

Chang's response came after the ministry was lambasted by the media for declining offers of foreign assistance in the wake of Typhoon Morakot. Chang pointed out that the ministry was simply waiting for the central government to assess levels of need before approaching the international community.

The previous day, MOFA had said that while Taiwan appreciates the support and concern expressed by the international community, it had decided to hold off on requesting foreign assistance because the country is capable of handling the disaster relief work on its own.

According to Chang, the MOFA is maintaining close contact with the Central Disaster Emergency Operation Center and is communicating with the Taipei-based American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) to clarify the country's needs and what kinds of equipment and supplies the United States can offer.

The U.S. donated US$250,000 a day earlier to the Republic of China Red Cross Society in response to the disaster and expressed willingness to offer more assistance if necessary, such as providing machinery and technology.

Peter Tsai, secretary-general of the MOFA's Association for East Asian Relations, said at the briefing that in addition to a donation of 10 million Japanese yen, the Japanese government was reviewing whether to offer more help.
"If Japan decides to offer any additional help to our disaster relief efforts, we will most gladly accept," he added.

Typhoon Morakot lashed Taiwan Aug. 7-8, dumping massive amounts of rain over southern parts of the country, with the southernmost county of Pingtung receiving a record 2,500mm of precipitation, causing severe flooding in at least three coastal townships.

As of 3 p.m. Thursday, the flooding there and elsewhere around the country, along with widespread landslides, had left 108 people dead, 45 injured and 58 unaccounted for. The casualties included three rescuers who were killed Tuesday when their helicopter crashed in mountainous Wutai township in Pingtung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan desperately needs large helicopters, prefab housing

TEXT.P: What needs most at present in terms of disaster relief assistance is prefabricated housing and helicopters that can carry heavy-duty gravel trucks and excavators into disaster areas to help speed up post-disaster relief and rehabilitation operations, an official said Thursday.

"What we need is a way of getting 32-ton gravel trucks and excavators into mountainous villages ravaged by floods and mudslides triggered by Typhoon Morakot Aug. 7-9, " said Huang Chi-min, director-general of the National Fire Administration under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).

Huang made the remarks after the Executive Yuan directed all central government agencies to come up with lists of items that they need foreign countries to donate or supply to facilitate rescue and rehabilitation efforts in the hardest- hit villages in the mountains of southern Taiwan.
The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) was the first to come up with a report, saying that it urgently needs helicopters capable of handling extra-heavy payloads.
According to Huang, the largest chopper used by Taiwan's military is the CH-47, which can transport a maximum of 12 tons of cargo and has a maximum lift capacity of only about 6 tons.
As a result, Huang said, the MOTC was able to deliver only two light excavators to a mudslide-ruined village in the southern county of Kaohsiung the previous day.

Noting that the most efficient way to repair damaged mountain roads is to work simultaneously from both ends of the damaged sections, Huang said borrowing large helicopters to airlift heavy machinery into disaster zones is desperately needed to accelerate the reconstruction work.

However, a military flight instructor later pointed out that the maximum handling capacity of the biggest choppers in existence at the moment is only about 20-plus tons, adding that the U.S.-built CH-54 and the Russian MI-26 can accept such payloads.
"We can deliver medium-sized machinery if there are no helicopters capable of carrying heavy-duty equipment, " said an MOTC official.
Meanwhile, the MOI's Construction and Planning Agency came up with a report saying it hopes foreign countries can provide 1,000 prefabricated houses to help shelter displaced typhoon victims.

The Central Disaster Emergency Operation Center also said it welcomes foreign search and rescue teams willing to come to Taiwan to assist in locating people who remain unaccounted for after Morakot-triggered mudslides tore through several remote mountain villages in central, southern and eastern Taiwan.

As of 3 p.m. Thursday, the storm had left 108 people dead, 45 injured and 58 unaccounted for. The casualties included three rescuers who were killed Tuesday when their helicopter crashed in mountainous Wutai township in Pingtung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Thursday:
Apple Daily:
It's unreasonable for President Ma to refuse foreign aid.
President Ma's administration has rejected offers by foreign countries to assist in the disaster relief work, as China did after the Sichuan earthquake to heavy international criticism.

It is considered unwise for Ma to refuse foreign aid, as such assistance can accelerate the rescue operations and afford Taiwan an opportunity to share the disaster relief skills and experience of other countries.
It would also give the international community a chance to better understand the country, so why turn down the offers?.
Liberty Times: President Ma should abandon his 'three noes' ostrich policy and face reality

The flooding caused by typhoon Morakot has severely damaged the country. The disaster has received wide coverage in the international media. Some experts have called it "the worst disaster in Taiwan in 50 years." However, in this time of crisis, our president is not handling his responsibilities and meeting the challenges as a leader of Taiwan should. Instead, he has adopted a bizarre "three noes" ostrich policy.

His first "no" is to foreign aid. Taiwan has been struggling with the disaster rescue work because of limited resources. The country has very few helicopters and the ones it has are ancient models. Because of this problem, many disaster victims are still stranded on dangerous mountainsides and three crew members have died in a helicopter crash.

The U.S. has been showing deep concern over the conditions in Taiwan ever since the typhoon hit. U.S. Assistant Secretary of Public Affairs Philip J. Crowley has offered his country's formidable resources to help in the rescue and relief operations. However, President Ma has not accepted the offer. The U.S. State Department said that it has not received any requests for help from Taiwan.
Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Chen Ming-cheng said that "Taiwan can handle the disaster, and will ask for help only if international support is needed."

The second "no" is to declaring a state of emergency. Complaints of inefficiency in the rescue and relief work have been buzzing around the country since the disaster occurred. Rescue equipment was found lying idle and there have been reports of uneven distribution of resources and slow rescue teams. Many local government chiefs have proposed an emergency decree that would allow for greater efficiency in rescue operations, as there would be fewer legal hurdles. However, President Ma has rejected this proposal, saying that the existing government mechanisms are sufficient to deal with the situation.

The third "no" is to a special budget. It is obvious that the relief and reconstruction work after a disaster of this scale would require a huge budget. Thus it is baffling why President Ma could allocate NT$800 million for a questionable consumer voucher program, but denies the need for a special disaster budget, arguing that the current allocation of NT$40 billion would be enough.

Ma's decisions make it clear that he not yet faced the fact that Taiwan is in a serious crisis right now. If Ma wants to prevent further damage, he should immediately abandon his "three noes" policy, apologize to the pubic, and cooperate swiftly with the local governments and the international community to rebuild the country.
China Times:
Comparing governments' responses after Aug. 8 flooding and Pachang Creek incident.
Why did a medium-strength typhoon, against which there were warnings, wreak such havoc in Taiwan?

We would like to compare the Kuomintang government's performance in dealing with the Typhoon Morakot disaster and the Democratic Progressive Party administration's handling of the Pachang Creek incident in 2000.
In the Pachang Creek incident, four workers stranded in a surging river in Chiayi were washed away and drowned after waiting two hours for rescue while TV cameras rolled.
Two days later, then Vice Premier Yu Shi-kun resigned to take responsibility for the incident and many other officials were disciplined.
In this regard, the Ma administration lags far behind the DPP government, as no officials have so far taken responsibility for the disaster caused by Morakot.
United Daily News:
Mother Nature's warning to Taiwan
At the height of Typhoon Morakot's fury, Siaolin, a small village in the mountains of Kaohsiung County, was buried by mudslides caused by the swelling of a creek that runs through the village.

The Council of Agriculture claimed that it had put the village on a red alert against mudslides, but it seems that this was nothing more than a perfunctory warning designed to shield the council from criticism rather than alert the villagers to danger.
In addition to the torrential rain, over-development of mountain areas in surely one of the factors that made the island vulnerable to mudslides.

When people used hoes to farm the mountain slopes, the impact on the environment was much less than now when bulldozers being are used to develop land in the mountains. This kind of development tips the balance between economic development and nature.
We hope the disaster caused by Morakot will prompt people to think twice about development in the mountainous areas of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: President of Guatemala thanks Taiwan for scholarship offer
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 12 (CNA) 08/13/09 18:13:28 (By Huang Kwang-chun and Julia Chien)

TEXT.P: President Alvaro Colom Caballeros of Guatemala -- one of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies -- officiated at a scholarship award ceremony at Guatemala's National Palace of Culture Thursday and thanked Taiwan for offering the scholarships and helping his country nurture new talent.
This year, 19 Guatemalan students received the scholarships provided by Taiwan's International Cooperation and Development Fund.

The Republic of China government has provided scholarships for Guatemalan students for several years, giving them the chance to pursue further studies in Taiwan with the goal of developing Guatemala's human resources.
Colom expressed gratitude for Taiwan's efforts and said the scholarships are an ideal way to improve bilateral relations.
He also expressed sympathy over the devastation caused in Taiwan by Typhoon Morakot.

Republic of China Ambassador to Guatemala Adolfo Sun, who attended the ceremony, said that after the Guatemalan students return from their studies in Taiwan, they will be able to provide great support to Guatemala's development.
Also present at the ceremony were Secretary-General to the President of Guatemala Carlos Esteban Larios, Foreign Minister Haroldo Rodas and Vice Economic Minister David Cristiani.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses estimated at NT$9 billion: Council of Agriculture

TEXT.P: Financial losses suffered by Taiwan's agricultural sector as a result of Typhoon Morakot had exceeded NT$9.78 billion (US$272.7 million) as of Thursday, according to statistics released that day by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).

The figure is the second-highest since 1991, when the council started to keep such records, COA officials said, adding that the worst agricultural disaster was caused by Typhoon Herb in 1996, when agricultural losses of NT$18.08 billion were incurred.
Damage to crops amounted to NT$3.33 billion as a result of Morakot, with 26 percent of the crops on 62,574 hectares of farmland lost, according to COA estimates.
Bananas suffered the worst damage, with 5,649 hectares ravaged by strong winds and flooding, followed by papayas, guavas, custard apples, rice, bamboo shoots and leafy vegetables.
Poultry and livestock losses amounted to NT$1.32 billion, with 118,143 hogs, 5,714,000 chickens and 1,065,000 ducks perishing in the storm.

Meanwhile, 684 hectares of farmland worth an estimated NT$665.7 million were washed away, with the eastern county of Taitung suffering the most with 524 hectares buried under debris or carried away by floodwater.
The agricultural losses also included an estimated NT$174 million in damage to farming facilities.
The COA statistics also show that the aquaculture sector incurred an estimated NT$3.93 billion in financial losses, an 18- year high for losses resulting from a single storm.

A combined 8,381 hectares of fish farms in southern Taiwan were severely damaged by Morakot, the worst typhoon to hit the south in half a century. Of the damaged aquaculture farm areas, 1,231 hectares were coastal fish ponds.
According to the COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung, farmers in 13 cities and counties will be entitled to cash relief, with those in 14 cities and counties also eligible for low-interest disaster loans.

In addition, those with existing agricultural credit and low-interest disaster loans will be able to extend their principal and interest loan terms for one more year, while the Agricultural Trust Fund guarantees for 90 percent.
Chen also said that vegetable and rice production will resume production in three weeks, once the floodwater has receded.

Poultry, livestock and aquaculture, which suffered heavier damage, might take longer to recover, Chen said, adding that the COA estimates about five to six weeks for poultry farmers to resume production, while pig farmers and aquaculturists might not return to full speed for six months.

DOC.HEADLINE: List of relief needs forwarded to overseas

TEXT.P: Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Thursday that it had forwarded a checklist of items that Taiwan needs for international assistance to improve its rescue and relief operations in the wake of Typhoon Morakot.

The Government Information Office released the list later that day bearing the items the country most needs from the international community, especially heavy- lift helicopters capable of carrying gravel trucks and excavators.

"The list was forwarded to the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) and to Japan's Interchange Association by Deputy Foreign Minister Andrew Hsia as soon as it was released, " MOFA spokesman Henry Chen told CNA.
"In addition, the Foreign Ministry has requested all its overseas representative offices to pass on the list to their respective host governments to seek help," he added.
The AIT confirmed with CNA later in the day that it had received the list and said it would immediately make a report to the U.S. State Department.
"We are looking at it and will be working with Washington to see what we can provide," said AIT Press Officer Christopher Kavanagh.

The United States and Japan had already donated US$250,000 and 10 million Japanese yen, respectively, in response to the disaster, and both have expressed willingness to offer more assistance if necessary, such as providing machinery and technology.

The Foreign Ministry was lambasted by the media for declining offers of foreign assistance in the wake of Typhoon Morakot. The previous day, MOFA had said that while Taiwan appreciates the support and concern expressed by the international community, it had decided to hold off on requesting foreign assistance because the country is capable of handling the disaster relief work on its own.
The ministry said in its own defense Thursday that it was simply waiting for the central government to assess levels of need before approaching the international community.

Typhoon Morakot lashed Taiwan Aug. 7-8, dumping massive amounts of rain over southern parts of the country, with the southernmost county of Pingtung receiving a record 2,500mm of precipitation, causing severe flooding in at least three coastal townships.

As of 3 p.m. Thursday, the flooding there and elsewhere around the country, along with widespread landslides, had left 108 people dead, 45 injured and 58 unaccounted for. The casualties included three rescuers who were killed Tuesday when their helicopter crashed in mountainous Wutai township in Pingtung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon death toll climbs to 108

TEXT.P: The death toll from Typhoon Morakot had climbed to at least 108 as of 3 p.m. Thursday, with 58 people listed as missing and 45 injured, the Central Emergency Operation Center reported later that day.

While numerous bridges were severely damaged by mud and debris and many roads rendered impassable in mountainous regions, the Directorate-General of Highways reported that of the 132 damaged and blocked roads, 59 had been reopened to traffic as of that evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: Aborigines in Pingtung planning mass exodus

TEXT.P: Residents of Wutai and Sandimen townships in the southernmost country of Pingtung, one of the two hardest-hit regions when Typhoon Morakot pummeled Taiwan Aug. 7-9, are planning a mass exodus in the wake of the storm's devastation.

"We hope to see all 600 of Wutai's residents, most of whom belong to the Rukai Tribe, airlifted out of the mountains to safety, " said Tseng Chih-yung, head of the Aboriginal Affairs Department under the Pingtung county government.
Rescue helicopters authorized by the Central Emergency Operation Center made over 30 sorties to three villages in Wutai township Thursday, evacuating some 280 villagers to safety.

Of the three villages, 76 of the 80 residents of Ali village had been airlifted out as of Thursday, with only four young men left behind to clean up the area and release animals and livestock kept by the villagers.
Roads leading to neighboring Dawu village were all cut off by floods and landslides and were not expected to be fully reopened for two years, according to the Wutai township authorities.
Meanwhile, Dashe village in Sandimen township, also home to Rukai tribal people, was awaiting complete helicopter evacuation of its some 400 inhabitants over the following several days.

According to Lege-ai, a Sandimen township representative who navigated debris and broken roads on foot for seven hours to reach Dashe village the previous day, the entire village had subsided, with many houses inundated by mudslides.

During Thursday's evacuation, the Rukai tribal elders wore their traditional garb, while younger tribesmen took their ceremonial swords with them, anxious that they might never return to their homes again.

According to the latest government statistics, 108 people had been killed as of 3 p.m Thursday, including three crew members of a helicopter that crashed while on a relief mission in Wutai township, with 58 missing and 45 injured.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top museums in Taiwan, China strike 1st cooperation deal

TEXT.P: The two most prestigious museums on either side of the Taiwan Strait have finally struck a deal on co-hosting an exhibition in Taipei in October that will feature artworks from the Qing Dynasty's Yongzheng period, museum sources said Thursday.

The National Palace Museum (NPM) in suburban Taipei and the Palace Museum in Beijing struck the agreement via a third party -- the Taipei-based United Daily News Cultural Foundation -- the sources said, adding that the two museums will make a formal joint announcement in a teleconference to be held Friday.

Under the terms of the agreement, the Beijing Palace Museum will loan a collection artifacts and documents from the Yongzheng Emperor period for the exhibition at the NPM scheduled to open Oct. 7 and run through Jan. 10, 2010.

The exhibition will mark the first time that ancient Chinese art treasures held by the two museums have ever been displayed under the same roof since Taiwan and China split in 1949 following a civil war.

The intermediary third party was retained in an effort to avoid sensitive political issues, as the Beijing museum would not sign any agreement directly with the Taiwanese museum, which carries the word "national" as part of its name, according to NPM sources.

China claims sovereignty over Taiwan and despite significant improvements in cross-strait relations in the past year under President Ma Ying-jeou's conciliatory approach toward cross-strait ties, China still refuses to give any impression that it recognizes Taiwan as a sovereign state.

The two museums reached a nine-point consensus in March this year on promoting exchanges and cooperation in museum management, artworks preservation, academic study and arts exhibitions, including establishing a mechanism that would allow for co-hosting exhibitions.

"The upcoming exhibition of Yongzheng period artworks owned by both museums embodies the realization of the consensus we reached earlier this year, " said an NPM curator who spoke on condition of anonymity.
The NPM -- one of the world's most famous museums -- has the world's largest collection of Chinese historical artifacts, which total more than 700,000 pieces.

The October exhibition in Taipei will showcase aspects of the life of Yongzheng Emperor, who ruled China for 13 years from 1722 to 1735. He was a tough and hard-working emperor who opposed corruption and was bent on clean, effective government. During his reign, the Manchu Empire became a great power and a peaceful country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislators concerned about government's land restoration policy

TEXT.P: Legislators of both the ruling and opposition parties said Thursday that the government urgently needs to enact a law enforcing measures to restore the balance of Taiwan's natural environment.

With mountain villages buried in mud and debris triggered by torrential rain and houses along the east coast washed into the Pacific by flash flooding when Typhoon Morakot swept across Taiwan Aug. 7-9, the growing extent of the damage caused by the disaster has raised concern among legislators regarding the government' s land restoration policy.

Although the Cabinet approved a land restoration and conservation action plan in January 2005 and there has been discussions in the Legislative Yuan on drafting a law on land restoration, the issue was mostly neglected until the latest natural disaster wreaked its devastation.
In the wake of Morakot, Legislator Wu Yu-sheng of the ruling Kuomintang suggested a land restoration law, a proposal that was echoed by lawmakers of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

While scholars have warned time and again of the danger of unregulated building catering to the tourist trade in mountain areas, of draining underground water and of using coastline and riverbank areas for fish farms, the government tends to remain laissez-faire on the issue until a serious natural disaster strikes, according to the legislators.

KMT Legislator Lu hsueh-chang suggested that when discussing the restructuring of the government in the next legislative session, one important task will be to clarify the responsibilities of government agencies in land restoration and management.

DPP Legislator Wang Hsin-nan said that the DPP caucus will draft a new law based on the draft of land restoration and conservation provisions already on the shelf and will submit it in the coming legislative session.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chiao Tung University to cooperate with 3 South Korean schools

TEXT.P: National Chiao Tung University (NCTU) President Wu Chung-yu headed for South Korea Thursday to strike cooperation deals with three renowned universities in that country as part of the school's drive to upgrade its international profile.

During his visit, Wu will sign memorandums of understanding (MOUs) with National Seoul University (NSU), Hanyang University and Sungkyunkwan University on academic exchanges and cooperation, an NCTU spokesman said.

In the initial stage, NCTU and the three South Korean universities will offer mutual student exchange quotas, arrange for exchange visits between their faculty members and jointly organize academic forums, the spokesman said.

"The cooperation programs will enable NCTU to attract top-notch South Korean students to study on our campus, a development that will not only accelerate our globalization drive but will also help Taiwanese enterprises absorb South Korean talent to facilitate their global business expansion plans," the spokesman explained.

Noting that NSU is South Korea's top-ranking university, the spokesman said the school has made brilliant achievements in natural sciences and mathematics, as well as in engineering and computer science.
In addition, South Korea's Hyundai Motor Group has invested US$1.6 billion in setting up an advanced automobile research center there to cultivate engineering talent.
According to the spokesman, NCTU will also promote cooperation with NSU in biomedical engineering, energy and environmental research programs in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1,282 schools damaged by landslides, flooding

TEXT.P: A total of 1,282 schools in central and southern Taiwan were demolished or damaged by Typhoon Morakot-triggered landslides and flooding, with accumulated losses estimated to have reached NT$1.8 billion (US$56.2 million) , Vice Education Minister Wu Tsai-shun said Thursday.
After an inspection tour to Tainan County earlier in the day, Wu said most of the school damage in the south had been caused by floodwater.

Statistics compiled by the ministry's Department of Compulsory Education indicate that schools in Kaohsiung County suffered the most severe damage, with the losses estimated to have reached NT$520 million, followed by Tainan County with NT$510 million-worth of damage, and Pingtung County with NT$290 million- worth.

While several elementary schools in remote mountain villages were leveled or buried in mud and debris, the ministry needs to find ways to accommodate students of the 22 most seriously damaged schools before the end of August, in order to fulfill its pledge of enabling all schools to start the new semester according to schedule.
In a meeting of high school principals the previous day in Kaohsiung City, Wu had suggested that these schools could temporarily conduct classes in prefabricated housing units.
Meanwhile, universities and colleges around the island launched a campaign to mobilize at least 10,000 students to provide voluntary services at the damaged schools.

As of late Thursday, more than 10,000 students had volunteered. They will be assigned to 119 schools in two seven-day shifts over the coming two weeks to help clean classrooms and schoolyards and look after the children.

DOC.HEADLINE: Penghu to hold casino referendum Sept. 26

TEXT.P: Voters in Penghu County will go to the polls Sept. 26 to decide the fate of a controversial proposal that the outlying island county legalize the establishment of tourist casinos, a county official announced Thursday.

"Members of the county's Election Commission unanimously agreed at a meeting convened earlier in the day that a public referendum on the long-discussed tourist casino proposal should be held Sept. 26, " Chang Jui-tung, the commission's secretary-general, said at a news conference.
"The referendum will ask voters whether they either agree or disagree with setting up an international recreation area in which casinos will be allowed to operate, " Chang said.

A one-hour public hearing will take place Sept. 16 to allow proponents of and opponents to the plan to air their views, Chang went on, adding that the hearing will be televised live by a local cable TV station and broadcast several times in the runup to the vote.
As of July 31, the commission had received 3,853 signatures from local residents endorsing the referendum petition, exceeding the required minimum number of 3,522, Chang said.
In the 2008 presidential election, the county had 72,170 eligible voters.

According to the Referendum Act, more than half of the eligible voters will need to cast their ballots for the referendum to be counted valid and more than half of them will have to cast "yes" votes for the casino proposal to become reality.
Gambling has long been banned in Taiwan, but the Legislative Yuan passed legislation on Jan. 12 to legalize casino gambling on outlying islands.

While some local politicians and businessmen welcome the proposal, as they believe it will reinvigorate the county's sluggish economy, many others oppose the proposal out of concern about damage to the county's beautiful scenery, natural environment and social mores.

Consisting of some 90 small isles, the Penghu archipelago is seated off the western coast of Taiwan in the Taiwan Strait. Tourism has been an important source of revenue for the county of 93,000 residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug. 14, 2009

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: 34 A(H1N1) cluster infections confirmed in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Four more cluster infections of swine flu -- known formally as influenza A(H1N1) -- were confirmed Thursday, bringing to 34 the number of such cases recorded in Taiwan, a Department of Health (DOH) official reported Thursday.
"All of those involved in the latest cluster infections are mild cases, " said Wang Chung-hsi, director of the public affairs department of the DOH Centers for Disease Control (CDC).
Two of the new cluster infections involve schools in Taipei and in eastern Taiwan, while the other two involve military servicemen stationed in central and southern parts of the island, Wang said.

Among the 34 confirmed A(H1N1) cluster infections, 19 cases have been reported on school campuses, five in summer camps, five in military barracks, two among long-term caregivers, and one each involving migrant factory workers, hospital staff and incoming visitors.
A total of 1,630 people showed flu-like symptoms in the cluster infections, but only 207 of the 324 people who had samples taken for testing were confirmed to have contracted the A(H1N1) virus.
"All of them were mild cases," Wang added.

As of Thursday, only 21 severe A(H1N1) cases had been recorded in Taiwan, with one fatality. Nine of the patients were still hospitalized and the remaining 11 had already been discharged after recovering, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon fatalities surge to 116

TEXT.P: Human fatalities from Typhoon Morakot had climbed to at least 116 as of 10 p.m. Thursday, with 59 others listed missing and 45 injured, according to the latest statistics released by the Central Emergency Operation Center.
Financial losses incurred by the agricultural and aquaculture sectors had also surged to NT$10.07 billion.

Meanwhile, according to surveys by schools in the hardest-hit Siaolin village in Kaohsiung County, 18 junior high school students and more that 50 elementary school pupils there remained unaccounted for as of late Thursday.

While numerous bridges were seriously damaged by Morakot-triggered flood and mudflows and many roads rendered impassable in mountainous regions, the Directorate-General of Highways reported that of the 132 damaged and blocked roads, 59 had been reopened to traffic as of Thursday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: President of Guatemala thanks Taiwan for scholarship offer
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 12 (CNA) 08/13/09 18:13:28 (By Huang Kwang-chun and Julia Chien)

TEXT.P: President Alvaro Colom Caballeros of Guatemala -- one of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies -- officiated at a scholarship award ceremony at Guatemala's National Palace of Culture Thursday and thanked Taiwan for offering the scholarships and helping his country nurture new talent.
This year, 19 Guatemalan students received the scholarships provided by Taiwan's International Cooperation and Development Fund.

The Republic of China government has provided scholarships for Guatemalan students for several years, giving them the chance to pursue further studies in Taiwan with the goal of developing Guatemala's human resources.
Colom expressed gratitude for Taiwan's efforts and said the scholarships are an ideal way to improve bilateral relations.
He also expressed sympathy over the devastation caused in Taiwan by Typhoon Morakot.

Republic of China Ambassador to Guatemala Adolfo Sun, who attended the ceremony, said that after the Guatemalan students return from their studies in Taiwan, they will be able to provide great support to Guatemala's development.
Also present at the ceremony were Secretary-General to the President of Guatemala Carlos Esteban Larios, Foreign Minister Haroldo Rodas and Vice Economic Minister David Cristiani.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses estimated at NT$9 billion: Council of Agriculture

TEXT.P: Financial losses suffered by Taiwan's agricultural sector as a result of Typhoon Morakot had exceeded NT$9.78 billion (US$272.7 million) as of Thursday, according to statistics released that day by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).

The figure is the second-highest since 1991, when the council started to keep such records, COA officials said, adding that the worst agricultural disaster was caused by Typhoon Herb in 1996, when agricultural losses of NT$18.08 billion were incurred.
Damage to crops amounted to NT$3.33 billion as a result of Morakot, with 26 percent of the crops on 62,574 hectares of farmland lost, according to COA estimates.
Bananas suffered the worst damage, with 5,649 hectares ravaged by strong winds and flooding, followed by papayas, guavas, custard apples, rice, bamboo shoots and leafy vegetables.
Poultry and livestock losses amounted to NT$1.32 billion, with 118,143 hogs, 5,714,000 chickens and 1,065,000 ducks perishing in the storm.

Meanwhile, 684 hectares of farmland worth an estimated NT$665.7 million were washed away, with the eastern county of Taitung suffering the most with 524 hectares buried under debris or carried away by floodwater.
The agricultural losses also included an estimated NT$174 million in damage to farming facilities.
The COA statistics also show that the aquaculture sector incurred an estimated NT$3.93 billion in financial losses, an 18- year high for losses resulting from a single storm.

A combined 8,381 hectares of fish farms in southern Taiwan were severely damaged by Morakot, the worst typhoon to hit the south in half a century. Of the damaged aquaculture farm areas, 1,231 hectares were coastal fish ponds.
According to the COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung, farmers in 13 cities and counties will be entitled to cash relief, with those in 14 cities and counties also eligible for low-interest disaster loans.

In addition, those with existing agricultural credit and low-interest disaster loans will be able to extend their principal and interest loan terms for one more year, while the Agricultural Trust Fund guarantees for 90 percent.
Chen also said that vegetable and rice production will resume production in three weeks, once the floodwater has receded.

Poultry, livestock and aquaculture, which suffered heavier damage, might take longer to recover, Chen said, adding that the COA estimates about five to six weeks for poultry farmers to resume production, while pig farmers and aquaculturists might not return to full speed for six months.

DOC.HEADLINE: List of relief needs forwarded to overseas

TEXT.P: Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Thursday that it had forwarded a checklist of items that Taiwan needs for international assistance to improve its rescue and relief operations in the wake of Typhoon Morakot.

The Government Information Office released the list later that day bearing the items the country most needs from the international community, especially heavy- lift helicopters capable of carrying gravel trucks and excavators.

"The list was forwarded to the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) and to Japan's Interchange Association by Deputy Foreign Minister Andrew Hsia as soon as it was released, " MOFA spokesman Henry Chen told CNA.
"In addition, the Foreign Ministry has requested all its overseas representative offices to pass on the list to their respective host governments to seek help," he added.
The AIT confirmed with CNA later in the day that it had received the list and said it would immediately make a report to the U.S. State Department.
"We are looking at it and will be working with Washington to see what we can provide," said AIT Press Officer Christopher Kavanagh.

The United States and Japan had already donated US$250,000 and 10 million Japanese yen, respectively, in response to the disaster, and both have expressed willingness to offer more assistance if necessary, such as providing machinery and technology.

The Foreign Ministry was lambasted by the media for declining offers of foreign assistance in the wake of Typhoon Morakot. The previous day, MOFA had said that while Taiwan appreciates the support and concern expressed by the international community, it had decided to hold off on requesting foreign assistance because the country is capable of handling the disaster relief work on its own.
The ministry said in its own defense Thursday that it was simply waiting for the central government to assess levels of need before approaching the international community.

Typhoon Morakot lashed Taiwan Aug. 7-8, dumping massive amounts of rain over southern parts of the country, with the southernmost county of Pingtung receiving a record 2,500mm of precipitation, causing severe flooding in at least three coastal townships.

As of 3 p.m. Thursday, the flooding there and elsewhere around the country, along with widespread landslides, had left 108 people dead, 45 injured and 58 unaccounted for. The casualties included three rescuers who were killed Tuesday when their helicopter crashed in mountainous Wutai township in Pingtung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon death toll climbs to 108

TEXT.P: The death toll from Typhoon Morakot had climbed to at least 108 as of 3 p.m. Thursday, with 58 people listed as missing and 45 injured, the Central Emergency Operation Center reported later that day.

While numerous bridges were severely damaged by mud and debris and many roads rendered impassable in mountainous regions, the Directorate-General of Highways reported that of the 132 damaged and blocked roads, 59 had been reopened to traffic as of that evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: Aborigines in Pingtung planning mass exodus

TEXT.P: Residents of Wutai and Sandimen townships in the southernmost country of Pingtung, one of the two hardest-hit regions when Typhoon Morakot pummeled Taiwan Aug. 7-9, are planning a mass exodus in the wake of the storm's devastation.

"We hope to see all 600 of Wutai's residents, most of whom belong to the Rukai Tribe, airlifted out of the mountains to safety, " said Tseng Chih-yung, head of the Aboriginal Affairs Department under the Pingtung county government.
Rescue helicopters authorized by the Central Emergency Operation Center made over 30 sorties to three villages in Wutai township Thursday, evacuating some 280 villagers to safety.

Of the three villages, 76 of the 80 residents of Ali village had been airlifted out as of Thursday, with only four young men left behind to clean up the area and release animals and livestock kept by the villagers.
Roads leading to neighboring Dawu village were all cut off by floods and landslides and were not expected to be fully reopened for two years, according to the Wutai township authorities.
Meanwhile, Dashe village in Sandimen township, also home to Rukai tribal people, was awaiting complete helicopter evacuation of its some 400 inhabitants over the following several days.

According to Lege-ai, a Sandimen township representative who navigated debris and broken roads on foot for seven hours to reach Dashe village the previous day, the entire village had subsided, with many houses inundated by mudslides.

During Thursday's evacuation, the Rukai tribal elders wore their traditional garb, while younger tribesmen took their ceremonial swords with them, anxious that they might never return to their homes again.

According to the latest government statistics, 108 people had been killed as of 3 p.m Thursday, including three crew members of a helicopter that crashed while on a relief mission in Wutai township, with 58 missing and 45 injured.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top museums in Taiwan, China strike 1st cooperation deal

TEXT.P: The two most prestigious museums on either side of the Taiwan Strait have finally struck a deal on co-hosting an exhibition in Taipei in October that will feature artworks from the Qing Dynasty's Yongzheng period, museum sources said Thursday.

The National Palace Museum (NPM) in suburban Taipei and the Palace Museum in Beijing struck the agreement via a third party -- the Taipei-based United Daily News Cultural Foundation -- the sources said, adding that the two museums will make a formal joint announcement in a teleconference to be held Friday.

Under the terms of the agreement, the Beijing Palace Museum will loan a collection artifacts and documents from the Yongzheng Emperor period for the exhibition at the NPM scheduled to open Oct. 7 and run through Jan. 10, 2010.

The exhibition will mark the first time that ancient Chinese art treasures held by the two museums have ever been displayed under the same roof since Taiwan and China split in 1949 following a civil war.

The intermediary third party was retained in an effort to avoid sensitive political issues, as the Beijing museum would not sign any agreement directly with the Taiwanese museum, which carries the word "national" as part of its name, according to NPM sources.

China claims sovereignty over Taiwan and despite significant improvements in cross-strait relations in the past year under President Ma Ying-jeou's conciliatory approach toward cross-strait ties, China still refuses to give any impression that it recognizes Taiwan as a sovereign state.

The two museums reached a nine-point consensus in March this year on promoting exchanges and cooperation in museum management, artworks preservation, academic study and arts exhibitions, including establishing a mechanism that would allow for co-hosting exhibitions.

"The upcoming exhibition of Yongzheng period artworks owned by both museums embodies the realization of the consensus we reached earlier this year, " said an NPM curator who spoke on condition of anonymity.
The NPM -- one of the world's most famous museums -- has the world's largest collection of Chinese historical artifacts, which total more than 700,000 pieces.

The October exhibition in Taipei will showcase aspects of the life of Yongzheng Emperor, who ruled China for 13 years from 1722 to 1735. He was a tough and hard-working emperor who opposed corruption and was bent on clean, effective government. During his reign, the Manchu Empire became a great power and a peaceful country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislators concerned about government's land restoration policy

TEXT.P: Legislators of both the ruling and opposition parties said Thursday that the government urgently needs to enact a law enforcing measures to restore the balance of Taiwan's natural environment.

With mountain villages buried in mud and debris triggered by torrential rain and houses along the east coast washed into the Pacific by flash flooding when Typhoon Morakot swept across Taiwan Aug. 7-9, the growing extent of the damage caused by the disaster has raised concern among legislators regarding the government' s land restoration policy.

Although the Cabinet approved a land restoration and conservation action plan in January 2005 and there has been discussions in the Legislative Yuan on drafting a law on land restoration, the issue was mostly neglected until the latest natural disaster wreaked its devastation.
In the wake of Morakot, Legislator Wu Yu-sheng of the ruling Kuomintang suggested a land restoration law, a proposal that was echoed by lawmakers of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

While scholars have warned time and again of the danger of unregulated building catering to the tourist trade in mountain areas, of draining underground water and of using coastline and riverbank areas for fish farms, the government tends to remain laissez-faire on the issue until a serious natural disaster strikes, according to the legislators.

KMT Legislator Lu hsueh-chang suggested that when discussing the restructuring of the government in the next legislative session, one important task will be to clarify the responsibilities of government agencies in land restoration and management.

DPP Legislator Wang Hsin-nan said that the DPP caucus will draft a new law based on the draft of land restoration and conservation provisions already on the shelf and will submit it in the coming legislative session.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chiao Tung University to cooperate with 3 South Korean schools

TEXT.P: National Chiao Tung University (NCTU) President Wu Chung-yu headed for South Korea Thursday to strike cooperation deals with three renowned universities in that country as part of the school's drive to upgrade its international profile.

During his visit, Wu will sign memorandums of understanding (MOUs) with National Seoul University (NSU), Hanyang University and Sungkyunkwan University on academic exchanges and cooperation, an NCTU spokesman said.

In the initial stage, NCTU and the three South Korean universities will offer mutual student exchange quotas, arrange for exchange visits between their faculty members and jointly organize academic forums, the spokesman said.

"The cooperation programs will enable NCTU to attract top-notch South Korean students to study on our campus, a development that will not only accelerate our globalization drive but will also help Taiwanese enterprises absorb South Korean talent to facilitate their global business expansion plans," the spokesman explained.

Noting that NSU is South Korea's top-ranking university, the spokesman said the school has made brilliant achievements in natural sciences and mathematics, as well as in engineering and computer science.
In addition, South Korea's Hyundai Motor Group has invested US$1.6 billion in setting up an advanced automobile research center there to cultivate engineering talent.
According to the spokesman, NCTU will also promote cooperation with NSU in biomedical engineering, energy and environmental research programs in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1,282 schools damaged by landslides, flooding

TEXT.P: A total of 1,282 schools in central and southern Taiwan were demolished or damaged by Typhoon Morakot-triggered landslides and flooding, with accumulated losses estimated to have reached NT$1.8 billion (US$56.2 million) , Vice Education Minister Wu Tsai-shun said Thursday.
After an inspection tour to Tainan County earlier in the day, Wu said most of the school damage in the south had been caused by floodwater.

Statistics compiled by the ministry's Department of Compulsory Education indicate that schools in Kaohsiung County suffered the most severe damage, with the losses estimated to have reached NT$520 million, followed by Tainan County with NT$510 million-worth of damage, and Pingtung County with NT$290 million- worth.

While several elementary schools in remote mountain villages were leveled or buried in mud and debris, the ministry needs to find ways to accommodate students of the 22 most seriously damaged schools before the end of August, in order to fulfill its pledge of enabling all schools to start the new semester according to schedule.
In a meeting of high school principals the previous day in Kaohsiung City, Wu had suggested that these schools could temporarily conduct classes in prefabricated housing units.
Meanwhile, universities and colleges around the island launched a campaign to mobilize at least 10,000 students to provide voluntary services at the damaged schools.

As of late Thursday, more than 10,000 students had volunteered. They will be assigned to 119 schools in two seven-day shifts over the coming two weeks to help clean classrooms and schoolyards and look after the children.

DOC.HEADLINE: Penghu to hold casino referendum Sept. 26

TEXT.P: Voters in Penghu County will go to the polls Sept. 26 to decide the fate of a controversial proposal that the outlying island county legalize the establishment of tourist casinos, a county official announced Thursday.

"Members of the county's Election Commission unanimously agreed at a meeting convened earlier in the day that a public referendum on the long-discussed tourist casino proposal should be held Sept. 26, " Chang Jui-tung, the commission's secretary-general, said at a news conference.
"The referendum will ask voters whether they either agree or disagree with setting up an international recreation area in which casinos will be allowed to operate, " Chang said.

A one-hour public hearing will take place Sept. 16 to allow proponents of and opponents to the plan to air their views, Chang went on, adding that the hearing will be televised live by a local cable TV station and broadcast several times in the runup to the vote.
As of July 31, the commission had received 3,853 signatures from local residents endorsing the referendum petition, exceeding the required minimum number of 3,522, Chang said.
In the 2008 presidential election, the county had 72,170 eligible voters.

According to the Referendum Act, more than half of the eligible voters will need to cast their ballots for the referendum to be counted valid and more than half of them will have to cast "yes" votes for the casino proposal to become reality.
Gambling has long been banned in Taiwan, but the Legislative Yuan passed legislation on Jan. 12 to legalize casino gambling on outlying islands.

While some local politicians and businessmen welcome the proposal, as they believe it will reinvigorate the county's sluggish economy, many others oppose the proposal out of concern about damage to the county's beautiful scenery, natural environment and social mores.

Consisting of some 90 small isles, the Penghu archipelago is seated off the western coast of Taiwan in the Taiwan Strait. Tourism has been an important source of revenue for the county of 93,000 residents.

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.

DOC.HEADLINE: 34 A(H1N1) cluster infections confirmed in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Four more cluster infections of swine flu -- known formally as influenza A(H1N1) -- were confirmed Thursday, bringing to 34 the number of such cases recorded in Taiwan, a Department of Health (DOH) official reported Thursday.
"All of those involved in the latest cluster infections are mild cases, " said Wang Chung-hsi, director of the public affairs department of the DOH Centers for Disease Control (CDC).
Two of the new cluster infections involve schools in Taipei and in eastern Taiwan, while the other two involve military servicemen stationed in central and southern parts of the island, Wang said.

Among the 34 confirmed A(H1N1) cluster infections, 19 cases have been reported on school campuses, five in summer camps, five in military barracks, two among long-term caregivers, and one each involving migrant factory workers, hospital staff and incoming visitors.
A total of 1,630 people showed flu-like symptoms in the cluster infections, but only 207 of the 324 people who had samples taken for testing were confirmed to have contracted the A(H1N1) virus.
"All of them were mild cases," Wang added.

As of Thursday, only 21 severe A(H1N1) cases had been recorded in Taiwan, with one fatality. Nine of the patients were still hospitalized and the remaining 11 had already been discharged after recovering, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon fatalities surge to 116

TEXT.P: Human fatalities from Typhoon Morakot had climbed to at least 116 as of 10 p.m. Thursday, with 59 others listed missing and 45 injured, according to the latest statistics released by the Central Emergency Operation Center.
Financial losses incurred by the agricultural and aquaculture sectors had also surged to NT$10.07 billion.

Meanwhile, according to surveys by schools in the hardest-hit Siaolin village in Kaohsiung County, 18 junior high school students and more that 50 elementary school pupils there remained unaccounted for as of late Thursday.

While numerous bridges were seriously damaged by Morakot-triggered flood and mudflows and many roads rendered impassable in mountainous regions, the Directorate-General of Highways reported that of the 132 damaged and blocked roads, 59 had been reopened to traffic as of Thursday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 14, or the 24th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1811: The British occupy Java.
1811: Paraguay proclaims independence from Spain.
1900: Forces of eight powers -- Britain, Japan, the United States, Germany, Russia, France, Austria and Italy -- march from Tientsin and scale the walls of Beijing, relieving the foreign legation besieged there since the start of the Boxer Uprising two months earlier.
1917: The Beijing government declares war on Germany and Austro-Hungary.
1937: The Republic of China Air Force shoots down nine of 18 Japanese aircraft which are bombing Hangchow, capital of Chekiang Province in eastern China.
1945: Japan surrenders unconditionally, ending World War II.
1945: The Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance is signed in Moscow.
1945: Nationalist leader Chiang Kai-shek invites Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Zedong to come to Chungking for a conference.
1947: Pakistan gains independence from Britain.
1949: Konrad Adenauer becomes the first chancellor of West Germany.
1951: Randolph W. Hearst, the newspaper publisher known as the king of America's "yellow press," dies at the age of 88. Beginning with the San Francisco Examiner in 1887, he built the world's largest publishing empire comprising 28 major newspapers.
1951: Seamen aboard the Ta Han, a 2,000-ton mainland Chinese freighter, defect to Taiwan, sailing their ship to the port of Kaohsiung.
1958: The ROC Air Force shoots down three Communist Chinese MiG-17s over Matsu.
1958: The United States decides to maintain an embargo on trade with Communist China, North Korea and North Vietnam, despite NATO's announcement of a relaxation of trade restrictions with the Soviet bloc and Communist China.
1971: Ground for the construction of Taiwan's north-south freeway is broken near Linkou.
1973: Over 300 Chinese and foreign computer scientists meet at the Academia Sinica for the First International Symposium on Computers.
1974: The Taipei Century Symphony Orchestra leaves for the United States on a three-week goodwill tour.
1977: The ROC Air Force celebrates the 40th anniversary of its victory over the Japanese at Hangchow, with Gen. Szetu Fu presiding.
1979: Wang Yun-wu, senior advisor to the president of the Republic of China, dies of heart failure at Veterans General Hospital at the age of 92.
1980: More than 360 scholars from home and abroad take part in the International Conference on Sinology at the Academia Sinica.
1985: The ROC Executive Yuan issues a report on the investigation of official administrative responsibilities regarding the 10th Credit Cooperative scandal. Fifteen financial officials are reprimanded, given demerits or dismissed.
1988: Major racial conflict breaks out in the African country of Burundi, with more than 24,000 people being killed in the conflict.
1999: The United States defeats Chinese-Taipei 10-9 to win the 18th International Baseball Association Big League Championship in Kaohsiung.
2000: Premier Tang Fei instructs the Ministry of Justice to review and revise relevant laws and regulations so as to enable the government to effectively crack down on the types of crimes that are increasingly harming Taiwan society.
2001: Former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias Sanchez, a 1987 Nobel Peace Prize winner, says in Kinmen that Taiwan and mainland China should engage in dialogue to ease the tension across the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who intuitively apprehends truth is one who, without effort, hits what is right, and without thinking understands what he wants to know; whose life is easily and naturally in harmony with the moral law. Such a one is what we call a saint or a man of divine nature."

DOC.HEADLINE: President to call high-level meeting on storm aftermath

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will call a high-level meeting Friday on the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot and possible changes to relevant national policies.

The president is expected to meet with Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, ruling Kuomintang Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung and the heads of relevant Cabinet agencies to discuss contingency measures to cope with the situation in the aftermath of the typhoon, one of the worst natural disasters in Taiwan in half a century.
Ma will also discuss with the officials how to craft a new stimulus plan to boost the economy in the wake of the disaster.

As damage wreaked by the storm had exceeded NT$70 billion (US$2.13 billion), a figure that overruns the government's available budget, the Executive Yuan is drafting a bill allowing special budget to beef up post-disaster relief and rehabilitation efforts, said Government Information Office Minister Su Jun-pin.
"President Ma hopes that the Legislative Yuan will pass the special budget proposal as soon as possible," Su said.
