DOC.HEADLINE: People evacuated as barrier lake expected to burst

TEXT.P: Work began early Friday to evacuate residents living along the Laonong River in a mountainous area of northern Kaohsiung County out of fear that a big barrier lake created by mudslides and torrents over the past week could burst at any minute.

Rock- and mudslides as a result of the extreme torrential rain triggered by Typhoon Morakot have created choked-up lakes of various sizes in areas along the river, with the largest one covering some 6 hectares, according to the Kaohsiung County Emergency Operation Center.
Fearing that the lake could burst at any minute, rescue officials alerted residents of Taoyuan, Baolai and Liouguei townships, warning them to prepare for evacuation.

Meanwhile, helicopters had made 32 sorties as of 10 a.m. that day to airlift supplies to stranded villagers in these townships and ferry people to safety. Over 400 flood victims had been carried out of their mud-encased homes as of that morning.

Further south in Pingtung County, more than 200 villagers in Wutai township -- one of the hardest-hit of the county's townships -- had been airlifted to safety as of 11 a.m. that day, with some 100 more awaiting additional helicopter sorties.
However, some 250 residents of Wutai village, the most densely settled part of the township, refused to be evacuated as the weather had cleared and the rain had subsided.

At a senior high school in Neipu village, members of 10 volunteer or charity organizations who had been there for several days to console the evacuees, were continuing their efforts to cheer up the flood victims, playing with the children and offering career or medical consultations to the adults.
Meanwhile, Taitung county officials called a halt to a mass evacuation plan for villagers stranded in three villages on the banks of the Taimali River.

The evacuation plan, drawn up the night before, was called off after a group of specialists got a bird's-eye view from a helicopter of a giant barrier lake that had been created over the past several days in the Baosheng community, located about 24 km west of the coastal township of Taimali.
The specialists said that the "crisis had been defused" as the water level of the new lake was much lower than the previous day.
Taitung Deputy Magistrate Peng Teh-cheng said that evacuation plans would be halted temporarily while work to repair the South-Link Railway and the South- Link Highway should be resumed immediately.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan might approach U.N. bid issue differently: deputy FM

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday that Taiwan might resort to a different approach than last year in Taiwan's bid for representation in the United Nations.

The 64th U.N. General Assembly session is scheduled to open Sept. 15 at U.N. headquarters in New York, and Taiwan must submit a bid proposal to the U.N. Secretariat through a diplomatic ally 30 days before then for it to be considered for the General Assembly agenda.

Pressed by reporters on whether it means that Taiwan will not make any bid if it does not act before the Aug. 15 deadline, Deputy Foreign Minister Andrew Hsia said that was not necessarily the case, as there are many different ways to approach Taiwan's U.N. bid.
"If no proposal is made on that day (Aug. 15), then we might have a different bid than last year. We will have a new approach, said Hsia without elaborating what it would be.
I'm sure you will get an answer (next week),he added.
Taiwan has not been represented in the U.N. since 1971 when the Republic of China's seat was given to the People's Republic of China.
Its annual efforts to rejoin the body since 1993 have failed, as have its attempts to be part of U.N.-affiliated organizations, mainly because of China's obstruction.

But with relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait thawing since President Ma Ying-jeou's administration took office last year, Taiwan was invited to attend the World Health Assembly -- the decision-making arm of the U.N.-affiliated World Health Organization -- in May as an observer.

Last year, in a departure from the high-profile push in 2007 for full membership in the United Nations under the name Taiwan, the country proposed that it be allowed to "participate meaningfully in the activities of U.N. specialized agencies."
That approach was in line with President Ma's "modus vivendi" or flexible diplomatic strategy, which favors a moderate and pragmatic approach to expanding Taiwan's international space.

Although the request failed to make the agenda of the 63rd session of the U.N. General Assembly last year, it was well received by major countries such as the United States, Japan, and some European Union countries, which issued statements in support of the effort.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Friday:
China Times:
Salute to heroes who go all-out to rescue flood victims
Typhoon Morakot brought about the most serious flooding of last five decades in Taiwan.
Unprecedented heavy rain of course was the main culprit behind the disaster, while the government has drawn fire, with accusations of having bungled the relief operation.
However, many people plunged headfirst into the rescue operation without complaint, struggling to reach remote mountainous settlements accessible only on foot, carrying heavy relief supplies.
The disaster has also brought out the best in many people, who have silently donated services, money and materials to help with the rescue operation.
We know the country's economic development is based on the exploitation of nature and we should therefore be prepared to bear the disastrous results of our behavior.
We should understand that nature's backlash is non-partisan and is equally likely to fall on any administration, whatever its political persuasion.

We don't need politicians indulging themselves in political maneuvering, or TV commentators babbling inanities. We need people who are prepared to walk into the remote areas to help the stranded people.
Apple Daily:
Be ready for more fatalities if the government keeps allowing unlimited use of hillsides
The disaster caused by Typhoon Morakot was the result of extremely heavy rain coupled with the unrestricted use of hillside lands.
Global warming is responsible for the unpredictable torrential rains, but the unlimited use of mountain lands is dereliction of duty on the part of the government.
Unless the government tightens control on the development of mountain areas, more mudslides and heavier death tolls could be expected in the future.
United Daily News:
Should the president declare a state of emergency?
Lawmakers of both the ruling and opposition parties have urged President Ma Ying-jeou to declare a state of emergency to deal with the devastation caused by Typhoon Morakot.
They said that under a state of emergency, the president would be given carte blanche to carry out the post-disaster reconstruction work.
However, Ma and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan have rejected the proposal, claiming that they have enough leeway under the existing laws to do what needs to be done.
We have to say that this is more of a political than a a legal matter, and the president should have the political wisdom to accommodate the lawmakers' calls.

By declaring a state of emergency, the president would show that he is very much concerned about the crisis and this will reassure and encourage the public to rally behind him in his post-disaster efforts.

There are administrations in the world that have been undermined as a result of disasters, but there are also administrations that have emerged from crises more powerful than before. The difference lies is how the crisis is handled.
Liberty Times:
Confused command system contributes to disaster

The administration's bungled attempts to rescue flood victims in the wake of Typhoon Morakot have irritated scholars, retired generals, and people who took part in the rescue operation after the earthquake on Sept. 21, 1999.
The performance of the administration in the last few days has shown that President Ma Ying-jeou's administration didn't learn anything from the country's ordeal in 1999.

Ma's persistence to stick to a regular command system rather than declaring a state of emergency and take the leadership in coping with the disaster has demonstrated that he is only interested in following the letter of the law rather than considering the big picture.

DOC.HEADLINE: Israel donates water tanks, purification units to Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Israel Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei (ISECO) said Friday that the government of Israel has arranged a shipment of water tanks and purification devices, scheduled to arrive in Taiwan later in the day, for victims of Typhoon Morakot.

"When the scale of disaster caused by Typhoon Morakot began to unfold, ISECO took the initiative to approach the Executive Yuan with the idea of shipping water devices that might be useful in the situation," the Israeli office said in a press release.
According to ISECO, the Executive Yuan welcomed the idea and immediately directed ISECO to the Ministry of the Interior, and then to the Taiwan Water Corp. in Kaohsiung.
Among a variety of solutions suggested by the ISECO, products from WaterSheer, an Israeli company that specializes in water purification, were selected.

The shipment will include two SOS Tank Systems to transport water to remote disaster-hit areas and hundreds of SulisPPD, a personal and simple-to-use device to purify flood and murky water into drinking water, the Israeli office said. Each SulisPPD can produce 700 liters of drinking water, which would be enough for a large family or a group of people, he added.

The shipment left Ben Gurion International Airport in Tel Aviv Thursday night aboard an EL AL flight. The supplies were donated by the Israeli Foreign Ministry with additional support from Giza Venture Capital of Israel and Huang Lung Engineering Co., Ltd., a Taiwanese company that has Israeli business partners.

The shipment was scheduled to arrive in Taiwan later in the day and Israeli Representative to Taiwan Raphael Gamzou was slated to oversee the direct transfer to the Taiwan Water Corp. in Kaohsiung, the ISECO said.
Gamzou also intends to be in Kaohsiung Aug. 15 to observe the efficiency of the devices, it added.

Typhoon Morakot lashed Taiwan Aug. 7-9, dumping massive amounts of rain on the southern parts of the country. The southernmost county of Pingtung received a record 2500mm of rainfall, which caused severe flooding in at least three coastal townships.

As of 3 p.m. Friday, the flooding there and elsewhere around the country, along with widespread landslides, had left 117 people dead, 45 injured and 59 unaccounted for. The casualties included three rescuers who were killed Tuesday when their helicopter crashed in the mountainous township of Wutai in Pingtung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon death toll climbs to 117

TEXT.P: The official death toll from Typhoon Morakot had climbed to 117 as of 10 a.m. Friday, with 59 people listed as missing and 45 injured, the Central Emergency Operation Center has reported.

Kaohsiung County had the greatest number of fatalities, with 66, followed by Tainan County with 24, Pingtung County with 16, Chiayi County with five, Nantou County with four and one each in Changhua and Yunlin counties.
The death toll is likely to rise, however, as an undetermined number of people in remote villages, especially Siaolin in Kaohsiung County, are thought to have died in massive landslides.

In terms of water and electricity supplies, the center said over 363,000 households in the southern counties of Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung were still without running water as of 10 a.m. Friday and more than 19,000 households were still suffering from power outages.
Meanwhile, according to the center, 14,960 telephone lines remained to be recovered and 242 mobile phone base stations needed to be fixed.

Islandwide, coastal Dongshih township in Chiayi County was still inundated, with floodwaters 30-50 centimeters high, said a center official, adding that with 19 pumping systems continuously working around-the-clock for days, the flooding was expected to end by 10 a.m. Saturday.
Two villages in Pingtung County's Jiadong township remained encased in mud, with mudflows reaching as high as 100 centimeters.
A total of 48 pumping systems had been mobilized to Pingtung County's Linbian and Donggang townships to pump water out of low-lying areas, where floodwaters were still about 30 centimeters high.
Meanwhile, Typhoon Morakot's toll on Taiwan's agricultural sector reached NT$10.72 billion as of Friday morning, with Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Tainan counties suffering the most, in that order.
Only Typhoon Herb in 1996 has proved more destructive in the past 18 years, causing over NT$18 billion in agricultural losses.

Of the damage sustained in Typhoon Morakot, the aquaculture sector suffered NT$3.6 billion in losses, also with Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Tainan counties being the most battered areas, according to the center.

In related news, the National Police Agency said Friday that it has notified local government offices in Kaohsiung County that a total of 37 corpses or fragments of human remains had been gathered around the county to be identified.

The agency called for relatives of people who had lost contact with their families since Typhoon Morakot to have their DNA taken at police stations to facilitate the search for those who have died or gone missing.

In related news, the Presidential Office denied a media report that relevant officials had done nothing after President Ma Ying-jeou promised an excavator to a man from Taitung County's Taimali township who was searching for the body of his father.
Two days later, after failing to receive any response from officials, the man, Lee Yu-ying, was forced to rent his own equipment to dig out his father's mud- encased car, according to the report.
Discounting the report, the Presidential Office said the government has mobilized 200 people every day to search for bodies of those missing around areas along the Taimali River.
"The report was groundless and off base, " the Presidential Office said.

President Ma offers his deepest sympathy to Lee and families of other missing people, but is also grateful to rescuers for their selfless efforts in searching and rescuing people around-the-clock without rest, the Presidential Office said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses estimated at NT$10 billion

TEXT.P: Financial losses suffered by Taiwan's agricultural sector as a result of Typhoon Morakot had exceeded NT$10.66 billion (US$324.6 million) as of Friday, according to statistics released by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).

The figure is the second-highest since 1991, when the council started to keep such records, COA officials said, adding that the worst agricultural disaster was caused by Typhoon Herb in 1996, when agricultural losses of NT$18.08 billion were incurred.
Damage to crops amounted to NT$3.58 billion as a result of Morakot, with 26 percent of the crops on 65,566 hectares of farmland lost, according to COA estimates.
Bananas suffered the worst damage, with 5,800 hectares ravaged by strong winds and flooding, followed by papayas, guavas, custard apples, rice, bamboo shoots and leafy vegetables.
Poultry and livestock losses amounted to NT$1.34 billion, with 119,476 hogs, 5,738,000 chickens and 1,088,000 ducks perishing in the storm.

Meanwhile, 684 hectares of farmland worth an estimated NT$1.37 billion were washed away, with the eastern county of Taitung and Kaohsiung suffering the most. A total of 1,474 hectares of land in the two counties were buried under debris or carried away by floodwater.
The agricultural losses also included an estimated NT$192 million in damage to farming facilities.
The COA statistics also show that the aquaculture sector incurred an estimated NT$3.81 billion in financial losses, an 18-year high for losses resulting from a single storm.

A combined 6,470 hectares of fish farms in southern Taiwan were severely damaged by Morakot, the worst typhoon to hit Taiwan in half a century. Of the damaged aquaculture farm areas, 1,531 hectares were coastal fish ponds.

According to COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung, farmers in 13 cities and counties will be entitled to cash relief, while those in 15 cities and counties will also be eligible to obtain low-interest disaster loans.

The cash relief program will require roughly NT$100 billion, which will be taken from the Rural Development Foundation and other sources. The low-interest loans will be handled by the Bureau of Agricultural Finance.

In addition, farmers with existing agricultural credit and low- interest disaster loans will be able to extend their principal and interest loan terms for one year, with the Agricultural Trust Fund guaranteeing 90 percent.
Chen also said that vegetable and rice production will resume in three weeks, once the floodwater has receded.

Poultry, livestock and aquaculture, which suffered heavier damage, might take longer to recover, Chen said. The COA estimates that poultry farmers will be able to resume production in about five to six weeks, but pig farmers and aquaculturists might not get up to full speed for another six months, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President prepares for post-typhoon relief efforts

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou directed central and local governments Friday to set up post-disaster reconstruction committees to restore communications and transportation in affected areas in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot and deal with compensation issues.

Ma issued the directive -- one of a total of nine -- at the first high-level national security meeting he has convened since taking office in May 2008, according to Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi after the meeting.

The president also said that because of the severity of the impact of Typhoon Morakot, the government should set up a national mobilization mechanism for post-disaster relief, relocation and reconstruction efforts to help victims return to normality.
He requested the Cabinet to draw up relocation plans and complementary measures for villages ravaged by floods or mudslides with the help of geography and meteorology experts.

The typhoon triggered the country's worst flooding in half a century and had claimed an estimated 500 lives as of Friday noon, including an estimated 380 people buried by a landslide in the southern Taiwan village of Siaolin, according to Ma.
It has also caused an estimated NT$50 billion (US$1.52 billion) in property losses.

Saying that post-disaster relief and recovery operations are currently underway simultaneously, Ma noted that no matter how difficult the tasks, his administration was duty bound to carry out the mission, according to Wang.

He said Ma has asked the Ministry of Economic Affairs to allocate at least NT$3 billion in two years for flood prevention, and instructed the Department of Health to provide mental health consultation services for the health of the survivors.

Ma also instructed the Executive Yuan to inform the public on disaster relief operation procedures and methods, clearly divide the responsibility between central and local governments in relief efforts, and help enhance local-level disaster relief capabilities.

The president said the reconstruction committees at various levels should be set up to come up with compensation arrangements for disaster affected industries, and quickly restore communications and transportations in affected regions.
He also demanded that the disaster response center should release accurate and real-time information and make good use of donations.

Touching on an initiative by the Ministry of the Interior to draft a land restoration law to restore the balance of Taiwan's natural environment, the president said the ministry should first hold hearings to survey public opinion.

Ma also directed the National Police Agency to send police cadets to help with post-disaster reconstruction and demanded the Ministry of National Defense to dispatch 10,000 more servicemen to help in relief efforts.

Recognizing the rescue efforts already made by the military and the National Airborne Service Corps, Ma said they airlifted 2,200 stranded villagers to safety Thursday, the highest daily total since the typhoon hit Taiwan over the weekend.
In addition, President Ma thanked Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng for his support for a special budget proposal to fund disaster relief efforts in the aftermath of the typhoon.

Also attending the meeting to discuss contingency measures to cope with the aftermath of the typhoon were Vice President Vincent Siew, Presidential Office Secretary-General Chan Chuen-po, National Security Council Secretary-General Su Chi, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, ruling Kuomintang Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung and the heads of relevant Cabinet agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government plans to hire more hydraulic engineers

TEXT.P: The Examination Yuan confirmed Friday that it will hold examinations to help the Water Resources Agency (WRA) recruit an additional 104 hydraulic engineers over the next two years, after the WRA was censured by the Control Yuan for its lack of expertise.

The Control Yuan, the branch of Taiwan's government responsible for monitoring the behavior of government officials, censured the WRA and 13 other central and local government agencies on Aug. 5 for their poor performance and lack of expertise that led to disastrous consequences during Typhoon Kalmaegi in July 2008.
The storm caused flooding and landslides in the central and southern areas of the country, leaving 20 people dead and causing NT$1.05 billion (US$34.57 million) in agricultural losses.

Taiwan's flood control and water management problems -- and the need for more expertise -- were further exposed in the past week as torrential rains from Typhoon Morakot led to the flooding of over one-quarter of the country's land area and heavy losses of life and property.
Following the censure, the WRA requested the Examination Yuan to help it recruit hydraulic engineers.

The Examination Yuan, responsible for civil service recruitment and management, will organize special civil service examinations and will require qualified engineers to commit to the WRA for six years before they can work for anybody else.

At a press conference Thursday morning, Examination Yuan President Kuan Chung reflected that the government has been bombarded with criticism since Typhoon Morakot hit Taiwan for inaccurate weather forecasting, poor flood control, a lack of hydraulic engineers, and its slow response to disaster relief.

He hoped that the government would take these criticisms seriously, saying, "a civil service system should be sympathetic and responsive to the sorrows of the people. This must be the fundamental attitude of all civil servants."

Dung Bau-tscheng, the deputy chief of the Ministry of Examination under the Examination Yuan, said his agency will meet soon with the WRA, and after understanding its needs will immediately organize the exam.

He also announced that once disaster relief efforts are concluded, the Ministry of Examination will contact local governments in eastern and southern Taiwan to find out more about what types of people are needed to prevent future disasters.

Aside from hydraulic engineers, the government also lacks experts in land restoration and organization, disaster relief and soil and water conservation, and Tung said the Ministry of Examination will soon organize other examinations to meet this demand.

Meanwhile, the Examination Yuan has encouraged its staff to donate one day of pay to relief efforts, while Deputy Secretary-General Lee Jih-Shyan and his disaster relief squad arrived at the disaster relief center at Cishan Senior High School in Kaohsiung County.
They reported that people there were in urgent need of relief volunteers, daily commodities and trauma therapy. The second relief squad will bring medical assistance to the south on Friday.
Typhoon Morakot battered Taiwan last weekend, dumping a year's worth of rainfall on some areas in three days, triggering severe flooding and deadly landslides.
The death toll from the disaster had risen to at least 116 as of 10 p.m. Thursday, with 45 injured and 59 reported missing, according to the Central Emergency Operation Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: All S-70C helicopters deployed for rescue work: Air Force

TEXT.P: The Air Force Command Headquarters said Friday that all of its 11 S-70C helicopters have been deployed for rescue work in the aftermath of Typhoon Morokat, and have not been reserved for use by the president and government officials, as the media has reported.

The statement came in response to a report Friday in the China Times, which claimed that two of the S-70Cs had been pulled from the rescue operations and were being kept on standby to transport President Ma Ying-jeou and Minister of Defense Chen Chao-min.

One of the helicopters left from Songshan Air Force Base on Thursday night and the other on Friday morning for the Chiayi Air Force Base from where they both embarked on missions to rescue stranded typhoon victims, according to the command headquarters.
The China Times claimed that this action was taken in reaction to its attempts Thursday night to confirm with the command headquarters the information in its news report.

The command headquarters said that airspace and air traffic in the disaster areas have become congested and it had therefore issued air traffic rules for its helicopters to regulate landings and takeoffs.

Since Typhoon Morakot hit Taiwan on Aug. 8, the Air Force has sent out 363 flights, rescued 1,254 stranded victims, flown 103 patients to hospital, and transported 143 medical personnel and 60,785 kilos of relief supplies, the command headquarters said.
However, it only mentioned the number of flights, but not the actual number of aircraft flying the missions.

The Taiwan public has become quite sensitive to rescue aircraft issues since helicopter accident occurred three days ago. The UH-1H rescue helicopter from the National Airborne Service Corps hit a mountainside and crashed into a valley near the aboriginal settlement of Sandimen at 3:30 p.m., killing the three crew members aboard.
Following the accident, the corps grounded all of its UH-1H helicopters for inspection.

DOC.HEADLINE: Relief supplies sufficient, volunteers needed: county governments

TEXT.P: Government officials in southern counties ravaged by Typhoon Morakot have urged local residents to stop donating relief supplies as their warehouses are now full of goods.

"We stopped accepting relief supply donations today as our storage centers are filled with many kinds of daily necessities, such as bottled water, instant noodles and powdered milk, " said an official with the Pingtung County government's Social Affairs Department Friday.

The county has opened 26 temporary shelters to accommodate 1,700-plus displaced typhoon victims after Morakot-triggered flooding swamped its coastal towns and landslides overran its mountainous villages, the official said.

"Steady streams of donated relief supplies have continued flowing into our disaster response centers from around Taiwan after the news media gave prominent coverage to typhoon victims' woes," the official said. "Now we have sufficient supplies of relief goods and no longer need any donations."
The county government has also received NT$100 million in cash donations, the official said.

"To help those who were rendered homeless by the natural disaster to rebuild their homes, cash donations are still welcome, " said the official, who also appealed for more volunteers to clean up the environment.
"Some 300 volunteers have joined the cleanup and disinfection drive, but we need more, " the official said. He also asked for people to contribute cleaning equipment to speed up the recovery effort.
Neighboring Kaohsiung County, which was also hit hard by Morakot-triggered flooding and landslides, echoed Pingtung's call to halt donations of daily necessities.

"If we need any special disaster relief equipment, such as life-saving equipment and generators, we will post the information on our official Web site, " said Wu Li-hsueh, director of the county government's Social Affairs Department.

The Red Cross Society also said it has collected enough supplies for typhoon- affected people in major disaster zones, including the southern counties of Chiayi, Tainan, Pingtung and Kaohsiung as well as the eastern county of Taitung.
"We will deliver all relief goods to affected regions through our volunteers as soon as possible," said a spokesman for the charity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices surge on local bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices continued their winning streak Friday to close 0.49 percent higher, on hopes that the Cabinet's plan to allocate a special budget of NT$200 billion for disaster relief in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot would give a boost to the country's economy.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, gained 34.55 points to close at 7,069.51.

Although Morgan Stanley Capital International decreased its weight on the Taiex, the local bourse opened high at 7,091.82 in line with Wall Street's overnight gains and the rallies of regional stock markets.
The Taiex later reached the day's high of 7,132.33 but subsequently retreated to the day's low of 7,062.49 due to the emergence of selling pressure.
The local market has added 176 points in the week since southern Taiwan was hit by Typhoon Morakot, which triggered the most severe flooding in the country in 50 years.
A total of 4.55 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$124.04 billion (US$3.78 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile shares moving up the most at 3.2 percent. Cement stocks rose 1.8 percent, foodstuff issues and plastics and chemicals shares each advanced 1.7 percent, construction shares surged 1.6 percent, and machinery and electronics shares moved up 0.1 percent.
Paper and pulp issues remained unchanged.
Only one of the eight major stock categories, banking and financial shares, lost ground with a 0.4 percent drop.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,243 to 1,118, with 192 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$5.03 billion worth of shares.
One analyst said that although the index rebounded to above 7,000 and moved toward this year's high of 7,185, the market would advance further only if turnover rises above NT$160 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, falling NT$0.003 to close at NT$32.895.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.898 and dropped to the day's low of NT$32.825.

DOC.HEADLINE: Memorial park for Siaolin village to be considered

TEXT.P: Kaohisung Mayor Yang Chiu-hsing said Friday he will convene a meeting to discuss the possibility of establishing a memorial park at the site of the southern Taiwan village of Siaollin, which was completely buried by mudslides during Typhoon Morakot last week.

In response to a suggestion by survivors that the village should not be excavated, Yang said he hopes to establish a memorial park on the site and thus avoid destroying the bodies of the people buried under the mudslide.
Yang also said the county government will not give up its search for survivors and will help typhoon victims to rebuild their homes.
Some 380 people are feared buried under the mudslides that covered the village.

DOC.HEADLINE: Stranded flood victims raise smoke signals for help

TEXT.P: Villagers in Chiayi County's Meishan township, who have been stranded for seven days since Typhoon Morakot, raised smoke signals Friday in an attempt to attract attention and be evacuated.

Being cut off from the outside world for days and their supply of food and potable water exhausted, the villagers in the remote community of Chuantsaiser sent the smoke signals, which in the past were used only to issue warnings or war alarms, said a local resident surnamed Yeh via a civil band radio.

To their chagrin, their smoke signals did not draw any rescue helicopters to their location. They returned to their muddy homes and made plans for their next meal -- probably bamboo shoots that they planned to dig up, Yeh said.

Meanwhile, Wang Ching-hui, formerly a rescuer, said he has lived in Taihe Village in Meishan township for nearly half a century but had never seen any natural disaster as devastating as the flooding and landslides triggered by Typhoon Morakot.

Wang said as far as he knew, four residents in the tribal community of Youcheliao had been buried alive by mudslides and their bodies were still there, while some 80 tribal people in the Chengmikao community remained stranded without any supply of food or water.

He said some deep valleys were still completely cut off from rescue or relief efforts because massive landslides knocked out roads in the area. If villagers need to venture out, they will have to travel by foot from Meishan township via neighboring Yunlin or Nantou counties.

To reach Youcheliao and Chengmikao communities -- the hardest-hit areas in Meishan township -- rescuers would have to cross the Chingshui River first and then navigate through broken mountain roads for another two hours, Wang said.

As of 10 a.m. Friday, the storm had left 117 people dead, 45 people injured and 59 still unaccounted for islandwide. The casualties included three rescuers who were killed Tuesday when their helicopter crashed in mountainous Wutai township in Pingtung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Namasia evacuees vow to return, but many more refuse to leave

TEXT.P: Over 300 residents in Namasia, a remote mountainous township in southern Taiwan, were finally evacuated Friday after being trapped for several days in their Typhoon Morakot-devastated homeland, but many others refused to depart.
Many of the 362 Namasia evacuees broke down in tears as they bade farewell to their small town in Kaohsiung County.
They were airlifted by military helicopters to the county's Cishan township in several groups.
An emotional old man, surnamed Hsu, was dismayed at having to leave his hometown.

"I have grown up on this land. I am sad to leave. I will definitely return some day," he grumbled as the chopper he was aboard drifted away from the typhoon- battered town that faced another threat Friday -- the possible bursting of a big barrier lake in its vicinity.

Some 600 other people living in neighboring towns along the Laonong River in the county's mountainous region were also evacuated Friday out of concern that the barrier lake created by Morakot-triggered mudslides and torrents over the past week could rupture at any minute.
Although the aboriginal Namasia township was almost ruined by the recent storm, several hundreds of its residents still refused to be evacuated.
Most of them are residing in the township's Minsheng First and Minsheng Second villages.

"They do not know that only their two villages were left relatively unscathed by Morakot while all other villages were inundated by mudflows and debris, " said Chu Wen-hua, a Namasia villager who was evacuated earlier in the day. "If a new storm comes, I'm afraid the two villages won't be able to withstand it."
Therefore, Chu said, eight influential Namasia residents will return to their town Saturday to persuade other people living in the town to evacuate to safety as early as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet to come up with special budget bill for reconstruction

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Friday that the Executive Yuan will create an ad hoc committee next week to coordinate various reconstruction programs in southern and southeastern Taiwan, which have been devastated by Typhoon Morakot.

The executive branch will also draft a special budget bill to finance post- disaster rehabilitation and reconstruction projects as financial losses from the typhoon damage have topped an estimated NT$110 billion (US$3.33 billion), Liu said.

Because figure is far more than the Executive Yuan can draw on from its annual budget, the Cabinet will draft a budget bill in accordance with the existing Disaster Relief and Response Act to finance various rehabilitation and reconstruction projects, the premier said.
The draft budget bill will be ready for a review at the Executive Yuan's weekly meeting next Thursday and will then be referred to the Legislature for screening, Liu said.
According to the premier, Legislative Yuan Wang Jin-pyng has promised to push for lawmakers to screen the budget bill as soon as possible.
In response, Wang said the Legislature will decide whether to convene an extraordinary meeting to deliberate the special budget bill after receiving it from the executive branch.
Liu said Wednesday that the government can redirect more than NT$40 billion (US$1.21 billion) from its annual budget toward post-disaster rehabilitation projects.
But damage from the typhoon has far exceeded the original estimates, he said, necessitating the drafting of a special budget.
As of 3 p.m., the official death toll from Morakot had surged to 118, with 57 listed as missing and 45 injured, according to statistics released by the Central Emergency Operation Center.
Financial losses incurred by the agricultural sector had reached NT$11.1 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., Japan did not decline sending helicopters: deputy FM

TEXT.P: Deputy Foreign Minister Andrew Hsia on Friday rebutted an earlier statement by the defense minister that the U.S. and Japan had declined to provide Taiwan with helicopters to assist in disaster relief efforts, saying that the two countries were still assessing the possibility.

Defense Minister Chen Chao-min said earlier Friday that the U.S. and Japan would not offer Taiwan specialized helicopters capable of transporting heavy payloads because they did not have the range to fly to Taiwan from Guam, where the U.S. helicopters are stationed, or Japan.

But Hsia said the two countries have initially responded positively to Taiwan's requests for assistance to help with rescue and relief operations in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, and that the helicopters were still on the table.

From what I know, they are still assessing the possibilities. The U.S. and Japan did not say that such a requirement is not doable. Everything is still under negotiation, Hsia told reporters after attending a ceremony to celebrate Singapore's 44th National Day.

Asked how the international community is responding to Taiwans list of disaster relief needs, Hsia said that the Foreign Ministry has received a very positive response but will wait for individual governments to announce what they can provide.

Naohiro Tsutsumi, director-general of the Taipei Office of the Interchange Association -- the de facto Japanese embassy in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic relations -- told the Central News Agency that he would not comment on specific listed items but said Japan is weighing all the requirements.
Japan is now in the process of considering the possibility of our response to the requirements. We have to wait for Tokyo to reach a conclusion,Tsutsumi said.

Japan responded quickly to news of the devastation that Typhoon Morakot wrought in southern Taiwan by expressing condolences to the victims, making a donation of 10 million Japanese yen to disaster relief efforts and offering to provide additional assistance if necessary.

After being lambasted by the media over the past few days for declining offers of foreign assistance, Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) apologized Friday for telling its overseas representative offices to politely decline international assistance such as supplies and rescuers in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, describing it as a technical error made out of negligence.

Tsutsumi, however, dismissed media reports that Japan's offer of aid was rejected by Taiwan, saying that his country always understood that Taiwan would have to first clarify its needs before approaching the international community.

He noted that Junzo Yamamoto, the Japanese delegation leader of the Japan-based Asia-Pacific ParliamentariansUnion that opened its 40th annual conference in Taipei Aug. 11, told President Ma Ying-jeou earlier in the week that Japan had the intention to help, an offer that was well received by Ma, who thanked Tokyo for the offer.
"It's very strange to interpret Ma's response as a rejection, Tsutsumi said.We don't think so.
"Japan remains very willing and happy to help Taiwan, as it is one of the most important and friendly countries of Japan in the region,he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hardy survivor attributes his lucky escape to a raincoat

TEXT.P: A policeman in flood- and landslide- ravaged Liouguei township in Kaohsiung County, who was airlifted to safety after being stranded on the roof of his police station for four days, said Friday that he was able to cheat death with the help of his strong will, devout beliefs and a police raincoat.
Chang Hui-cheng, resting in a hospital after being rescued Aug. 11, said the ordeal started Aug. 7, when Typhoon Morakot began dumping heavy rain on his village of Nanshalu in Namasia township.
He persuaded tourists in the mountainous area to flee to plains areas as soon as possible, and they all followed his advice, Chang recalled.
But villagers were more reluctant to follow his instructions to evacuate, refusing initially to do so because they believed that Christ would bless them and they would be OK, Chang lamented.
But Chang's sense that a calamity that would destroy people's homes would soon occur unfortunately came to pass.

He said that when he tried to get some rest after helping with evacuation efforts, the torrential rain broke windows in the first floor of the police station, sending him rushing to grab his raincoat and run up to the roof of the three-story building.

Quickly realizing the roof did not provide any shelter against the storm, he simply sat there and relied on the raincoat for protection from the rain, while holding steel columns to prevent himself from being washed away by floodwaters.

During his four-day ordeal, he sometimes felt a desire to sleep, but he realized that if he succumbed to the temptation, he would die. "The waterproof raincoat saved my life, as it kept me warm, " Chang said.
After having a bowl of instant noodles Aug. 7 noon, Chang did not consume anything except rainwater until when he was rescued.
"Aside from God, there was nobody I could ask for help when I was trapped, " Chang stressed. He said he continuously prayed to God to protect the police station while he was on the roof.
His opportunity to end his ordeal came on Aug. 11, when he saw a helicopter flying by. He attracted its attention by waving a red cloth and was flown to safety.
Almost at the same time, Chang's wife, children and a number of villagers were also airlifted to safety, Chang added.
The policeman, who applied to retire in April, said the first thing he wants to do after retiring will be to rebuild his home.

DOC.HEADLINE: Palace museum to donate funds for typhoon victims

TEXT.P: The National Palace Museum (NPM) said Friday it will donate 15 percent of its daily giftware sales during an exhibition of artworks from the Qing Dynasty's Yongzheng period for post-Typhoon Morakot recovery projects.

NPM Director Chou Kung-shin unveiled the donation program at a news conference in which she joined with Zheng Xinmiao, director of the Palace Museum in Beijing, in announcing via a teleconference the two museums' first cooperation deal -- co-hosting the Yongzheng period arts exhibition at the NPM in suburban Taipei in October.

The Yongzheng exhibition, which is scheduled to open Oct. 7 and run through Jan. 10, 2010, will mark the first time that ancient Chinese art treasures held by the two museums have ever been displayed under the same roof since the People's Republic of China was established in 1949.
During the Yongzheng exhibition period, Chou said the NPM's giftware shop will donate 15 percent of its daily revenues for the post-typhoon reconstruction and rehabilitation projects.
"An estimated NT$25 million is expected to be raised from the program during the exhibition period for the relief cause, " Chou said.
The museum also donated Friday's income of its food and beverage sales department, worth about NT$1 million, for post-typhoon relief projects.

Meanwhile, a Red Cross Society box was installed at the museum's gift shop Friday to accept donations by visitors to the museum, which is one of Taiwan's most popular tourist attractions among visitors from other countries around the world.
"Many Chinese tourists contributed funds into the box this afternoon," said an NPM staff member.
The NPM -- one of the world's most famous museums -- has the world's largest collection of Chinese historical artifacts, which total more than 700,000 pieces.
The Beijing Palace Museum will loan a collection of artifacts and documents from the Yongzheng Emperor period for the October exhibition at the NPM.
The exhibition in Taipei will showcase aspects of the life of Yongzheng Emperor, who ruled China for 13 years from 1722 to 1735.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug. 15, 2009

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA thanks Singapore for typhoon-relief donations

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed its appreciation to Singapore on Friday for donating NT$1.14 million (US$34,550) worth of medical supplies to Taiwan in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, which devastated southern Taiwan.
Singapore, in an act of concern for typhoon victims, donated food and medical supplies worth 50,000 Singapore dollars and US$200,000 in cash to Taiwan, the MOFA said in a press release.

Meanwhile, the Kaohsiung Customs Office said the five-ton shipment of medical supplies from Singapore arrived at Kaohsiung International Airport Friday afternoon. It cleared customs speedily and was sent to Kaohsiung Veterans General Hospital to be used to treat disaster victims.

The Taipei Customs Office also said that to facilitate the shipment of foreign donations, it has set up a one-stop counter to handle customs clearance procedures so that the donations can reach the typhoon victims as soon as possible.
The one-stop counter will operate around the clock.

DOC.HEADLINE: USAID official visits Taipei to evaluate typhoon damage

TEXT.P: Ron Libby, a coordinator with the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) in charge of disaster response assistance and support, arrived in Taipei Friday to evaluate the devastation Typhoon Morakot had wrought on Taiwan.

During his stay, Libby will travel to regions hardest hit by Morakot-triggered flooding and landslides, including Pingtung and Kaohsiung counties in southern Taiwan, according to a statement issued by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

Libby is scheduled to stay for three to four days, during which he will assess the extent and scale of the destruction the storm brought to Taiwan and the resources, facilities or equipment that foreign countries can contribute to post-disaster relief and rehabilitation operations.
His assessment will serve as a basis for the U.S. government to determine how to help Taiwan, the MOFA statement added.

Meanwhile, the Embassy of the Holy See (Vatican) in Taipei announced that Pope Benedict XVI will donate US$50,000 to help with Taiwan's post-typhoon relief programs, in addition to praying for the well-being of Taiwanese flood victims.

As of Friday, the MOFA had received condolences extended by 59 countries as well as the European Union and nine other international organizations. Several countries, including the United States, Japan, South Korea and Singapore, have also donated money for post-disaster rehabilitation efforts.
