DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 15, or the 25th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1057: Macbeth, King of Scotland who ascended to the throne after killing his cousin King Duncan in battle in 1040, is killed by Duncan's son Malcolm at Lumphanan, near Aberdeen. The legend of his rise to power and his reign are the basis of Shakespeare's tragedy "Macbeth."
1769: Napoleon Bonaparte, military leader and the emperor of France from 1804 to 1815, is born in Ajaccio, Corsica.
1900: The Kuang Hsu Emperor and his aunt, the Empress Dowager Tzu-hsi, flee to northwestern China from Beijing as the capital is captured by the forces of eight foreign powers during the Boxer Uprising.
1914: The 82-km-long Panama Canal, connecting the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, is opened after 35 years of construction.
1945: The Republic of China Legislative Yuan unanimously approves the United Nations Charter.
1947: India gains independence from Britain with Jawaharlal Nehru as the first prime minister.
1948: President Syngman Rhee formally proclaims South Korea as the Republic of Korea.
1949: A Southeast China Governor's Office is established in Taipei with Gen. Chen Cheng as governor.
1959: The ROC Army receives Nike-Hercules surface-to-air missiles from the United States under a military aid program.
1960: The Council of Grand Justices of the Judicial Yuan rules that, according to Article 77 of the ROC Constitution, courts of all levels shall be placed under the jurisdiction of the Judicial Yuan.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes the Congo (Brazzaville) Republic.
1962: The Netherlands signs a treaty agreeing to Indonesian rule of Irian Jaya (Netherlands New Guinea).
1967: Kung Hsiang-hsi, former ROC premier and finance minister, dies in the United States at the age of 88.
1974: South Korean President Park Chung Hee's wife is shot dead by an assassin in an attempt on Park's life.
1976: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo urges college students to contribute their wisdom and energy to the country as he presides over the closing ceremony of the summer vacation military training program of college students at the Cheng-kung base in Taichung.
1979: Direct dialing service to the United States, Hong Kong and Singapore is initiated by the Taiwan Telecommunications Administration.
1980: The wreckage of the Titanic, the British luxury liner which sank after hitting an iceberg during its maiden voyage to New York on April 14, 1912, is found laying on the ocean floor 3,657 meters below the surface of the Atlantic Ocean.
1981: The First ROC-Indian Cultural and Economic Seminar on India's 34th Independence Day is held in Taipei.
1981: The Republic of China and Saint Vincent establish formal diplomatic relations.
1985: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa accepts the resignation of Finance Minister Loh Jen- kong.
1986: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa, in an interview with Saudi Arabian journalists from the Okaz Daily and Al-Bilad Daily, points out that the achievements of the ROC over the past thirty-odd years has won the nation international recognition and made it an indispensable force against communist expansion in the Asia-Pacific region.
1990: President Mikhail Gorbachev restores Soviet citizenship to Nobel Prize- winning author Alexander Solshenitsyn, who was exiled to the West in 1974 for his novels attacking Stalinism.
1995: The Chinese mainland begins eleven days of tactical guided missile exercises by firing live artillery shells into the sea 136 kilometers north of Taiwan.
1999: Chiao Jen-ho, chairman of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Commission, donates US$100,000 and 20 computers to the Chinese Benevolent Federation in San Francisco.
2000: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture announces that beef imports from Argentina and Paraguay will be temporarily banned due to an outbreak of foot- and-mouth disease in the two South American countries.
2001: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party formally establishes the Taiwan-Japan Goodwill Association to further bolster bilateral ties between the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who acquires truth is one who finds out what is good and holds fast to it."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Emergency operation chief replaced

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo assumed the concurrent post of chief of the Central Emergency Operation Center Friday, taking over from Public Construction Commission Chairman Fan Liang-shiow.

Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Mao's rich experience in post-disaster reconstruction is the main reason why he was selected for the position, which makes him responsible for coordinating rescue and relief efforts in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot.

Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Su Jun-pin, meanwhile, rejected speculation that Fan was replaced because he differed with the GIO over the release of news about the disaster wrought by the typhoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: Death toll from Typhoon Morakot rises to 121

TEXT.P: The fatalities from Typhoon Morakot had increased to 121 as of 8 a.m. Saturday, with 53 reported missing and 45 injured, the Central Emergency Operation Center said that day.
The dead include 66 in Kaohsiung County, 24 in Tainan County, 17 in Pingtung County, six in Chiayi County, six in Nantou County, one in Changhua County and one in Yunlin County.
A total of 21,199 people had been evacuated as of that day, 4,888 of whom were being given temporary shelter at 44 locations, while the rest were staying with friends and relatives.
Water supplies remained cut off to 315,540 households, while 18,140 households were still affected by power outages.
Also awaiting repair were telephone services for 8,642 households, as well as 207 mobile phone base stations.
In Pingtung County, Yenwen and Wenfeng villages remained inundated by up to 60 centimeters of floodwater.

DOC.HEADLINE: Naval vessels ferry supplies to typhoon-hit townships in Taitung

TEXT.P: Two naval landing craft were loaded with supplies and vehicles to help isolated townships in the eastern counties of Taitung Saturday, as roads remained impassable one week after the onslaught of Typhoon Morakot.
With the help of some 400 soldiers, 100 tons of supplies and six loaders for transport and clean-up work were loaded aboard the vessels beached at Jhihben early that morning.

The vessels were expected to arrive at Dawu township later in the day, after which the items were to be unloaded and sent to local communities in Dawu and Daren townships, where more than 20,000 residents were reportedly still stranded without food or potable water.

DOC.HEADLINE: More than 1,300 people still trapped in typhoon devastation

TEXT.P: The Central Emergency Operation Center (CEOC) said Saturday that 1,373 people were still trapped in isolated mountain villages in southern Taiwan as of that day, after Typhoon Morakot devastated the region the previous weekend, bringing torrential rain that triggered massive flooding and landslides.
The center said it would dispatch 75 helicopters later in the day to the villages in the counties of Kaohsiung, Pingtung, Taitung and Chiayi to conduct rescue missions and drop relief supplies.

According to CEOC data, the number of trapped people still cut off in Chiayi County was listed as 57 in Jhuci township, 582 in Alishan township and 56 in Meishan township, while the figure for Kaohsiung County stood at 107 in Namaxia township, 63 in Jiaxian township, 173 in Taoyuan township, 258 in Liouguei township and 16 in Maolin township.
The number in Pingtung County was listed as 47 in Sandimen township and 12 in Wutai township, while 12 were still stranded in Taitung County's Haiduan township.

DOC.HEADLINE: Living in mudslide-prone areas should be prohibited: scholars

TEXT.P: Experts urged the government Saturday to prohibit people from living in areas at risk of mudslides.

The experts told CNA that as the typhoon season is not yet over, people who have been evacuated from their settlements in mountainous areas in the wake of Typhoon Morakot should be banned from returning to their homes because of the danger that remains of further mudslides.

Morakot, which battered the island Aug. 7-9, dumped about 2,500mm of precipitation -- the equivalent of a whole year's rainfall -- on southern Taiwan, triggering the most serious flooding and mudslides in five decades.

In terms of the government's efforts to seek foreign help with its search and rescue operation, Hung Hung-chih, a professor in the Department of Real Estate and Built Environment of National Taipei University, said the efforts have come too late.
"The best window of opportunity to find survivors is within 72 hours of a disaster," he pointed out.
The government has come under increasing fire for rejecting foreign aid in the immediate aftermath of the disaster and for waiting several days before flip- flopping on its decision.

Taiwan has amassed a lot of experience in relief operations since the earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999, Hung went on, adding that unfortunately, this experience has not been translated into standard operating procedures that could help the country enrich its experience and drive performance improvements.
"As a result, the government has failed to deal with the present tragedy effectively," he said.
The top priority now is to accommodate those people whose settlements have been destroyed by mudslides.

Meanwhile, Hsu Shi-jung, a professor in the Department of Land Economics at National Chengchi University in Taipei, alerted the government to the many barrier lakes formed in valleys by the mudslides.
"They could burst under the weight of the water they are holding back, leading to more flooding," he noted.

Both Hung and Hsu warned the administration against letting the evacuees return to their mudslide-destroyed settlements, at least during the next three months, when the island is still vulnerable to typhoons.
It will take five years for the terrain in the devastated areas to firm up and only after then should reconstruction even be considered, the experts said.

They suggested that the government relocate residents of these areas to safe places and help them resettle by finding them jobs so that they do not have to move back into their dangerous mountain settlements.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ takes charge of forensic tests on typhoon victims

TEXT.P: The Institute of Forensic Medicine under the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) has been conducting DNA tests on people killed during typhoon-triggered flooding and landslides over the past week, with each positive identification expected to be completed within five days, the MOJ said in a statement Saturday.

The MOJ issued the explanation in response to complaints by the families of some of the victims in the most serious flooding in southern Taiwan in 50 years about what they see as administrative inefficiency in the methods used to do the DNA testing on the remains of people drowned or killed by landslides.

The MOJ said the district prosecutors offices in the Kaohsiung, Tainan and Pingtung areas have been cooperating with the institute to provide DNA testing services and help the families of those unaccounted for to find their loved ones.
A dedicated forensic medical service center has also been opened at the Department of Health-operated Chi-Shan Hospital in Kaohsiung County to offer the testing services, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. considering Taiwan's request for relief aid
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 14 (CNA) 08/15/09 16:08:43 (By Zep Hu, Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States has received Taiwan's request for additional relief assistance in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot and is evaluating how to best to provide help as quickly as possible, a U.S. State Department official said Friday.
"We are currently considering how best to assist Taiwan with its urgent humanitarian needs," State Department spokesman Philip Crowley said during a daily press briefing.
"We'll compare what we are able to provide with what might be flowing from other countries in the region," he added.

According to a list released by Taiwan's Foreign Ministry, items most needed include specialized helicopters and pilots capable of transporting very heavy payloads such as excavators and heavy gravel trucks, as well as 1,000 prefabricated houses to provide temporary refuge for homeless flood victims.

In addition, the country is requesting 100,000 bottles of phenolic disinfectant or Benzyl-p-chloropherno, 200,000 Aquatab water purification tablets, 100,000 liters of sterilizing agent for sanitation, 1,000 portable sterilizers and 500 automatic sterilizers.
Jason Yuan, Taiwan's representative to the United States, told a news conference held in the U.S. capital that he was deeply touched that Washington is taking Taiwan's request very seriously.

According to Yuan, the U.S. government called an inter-agency meeting to discuss the matter immediately after receiving Taiwan's request for assistance, in the hope that a feasible resolution could be reached by the end of the week.

Although the U.S. side indicated that it does not have the kind of helicopters requested by Taiwan, it is studying the possibility of dismantling excavators and airlifting them in pieces to the disaster areas, Yuan said.

Yuan said Washington was impressed by Taiwan's generous donations in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina that battered the United States in 2005 and is very concerned about the disaster brought about by Morakot in Taiwan last week.
Besides donating US$250,000 to the Republic of China Red Cross Society, Washington has also sent an official in charge of disaster response assistance and support to Taiwan, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon agricultural losses close to NT$11.8 billion

TEXT.P: Financial losses suffered by Taiwan's agricultural sector as a result of Typhoon Morakot had reached nearly NT$11.8 billion (US$358.8 million) as of Saturday, according to statistics released that day by the Council of Agriculture (COA).
The figure came close to that of the NT$18.8 billion lost in 1996 when Typhoon Herb devastated Taiwan, bringing the worst agricultural disaster in the country's history.
Morakot-triggered damage to crops and animal husbandry production alone had accounted for nearly NT$5.1 billion, according to the latest COA statistics.
Meanwhile, the aquaculture sector incurred an estimated NT$4.1 billion in financial losses, a new 18-year high for losses due to a single storm.

The statistics show that 6,925 hectares of fish farms in southern Taiwan were severely damaged by Morakot, the worst typhoon to hit the south in 50 years. Of this area, 1,231 hectares comprised coastal fishponds, the COA said.
The COA estimated that damage to crops had amounted to NT$3.74 billion, with 27 percent of the crops on 68,202 hectares of farmland lost.
Bananas suffered the worst damage, with 5,849 hectares ravaged by strong winds and flooding; followed by papayas, guavas, rice, sweetsops, jujubes, bamboo shoots and leafy vegetables.
Poultry and livestock losses amounted to NT$1.36 billion, with 120,633 hogs, 5.9 million chickens and 1.17 million ducks perishing in the storm.
Meanwhile, 2,106 hectares of farmland, worth an estimated NT$1.9 billion, were washed away, with the eastern county of Taitung suffering the most with 646 hectares buried under debris or washed away.
The volume of washed-away farmland had reached 628 hectares in Pingtung County and 451 hectares in Kaohsiung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sponsorship from Taiwan changes lives: African beneficiaries

TEXT.P: Three African beneficiaries under World Vision Taiwan's sponsorship program have traveled to Taiwan to express their appreciation and share how Taiwanese people have helped them change their lives.

World Vision Taiwan, the local chapter of the international Christian charity group, invited the three special guests from Ethiopia, Rwanda and Sierra Leone to attend its 20th 30-Hour Famine 2009, a two-day event that opened Saturday at the National Taiwan Sport University.

Two of the visitors told CNA in a recent interview that the assistance they received from Taiwan not only brought hope to their devastated lives but also helped them get back on their feet and out of danger and poverty.

"It is very difficult for me to tell my story. I owe so much to the Taiwanese people who helped me and every day I pray for God's blessings for them," said Alex Gahigi, a survivor of the 1994 Rwanda genocide.
Gahigi, who was only eight when the genocide happened, was forced to shoulder the responsibility of taking care of his nine-month-old brother and two-year-old sister after his parents were killed.

Hunger was a common occurrence for Gahigi, who said that a single meal a day for him and his siblings would be considered a luxury. The only thing they could do was beg for food or do simple chores in exchange for food, he added.

"I could not see what my future held after losing my parents, but God was so merciful that I and my brother and sister survived the humanitarian disaster by fleeting to Congo, " said Gahigi, whose expressionless face bears testament to his harsh and difficult past.

After joining the Orphan and Vulnerable Children project under World Vision's Buliza Area Development Program six years ago, Gahigi trained to become a carpenter and could finally make a decent living making furniture. He is now married with two children of his own.

Mohamed Tamba Kambo, a 19-year-old from Sierra Leone, has a difference experience to that of most people. Instead of being included in the program as an underprivileged child, Kambo ran into a delegation from World Vision Taiwan in May while he was looking for diamonds to scrape a living.

Because of poverty, he was forced to drop out of school and spend 10 hours a day in a deserted diamond mine looking for something valuable. However, he found only one tiny rock worth just US$3 in two weeks.
Kambo told CNA that World Vision Taiwan not only helped him go back to school but also set his life back on the right track.
"Education is very important because it brings hope to people for a better future, " said Kambo, who majors in English and who aspires to become a teacher or doctor.

Asked what messages they would like to tell the participants in the 30-Hour Famine, Kambo said that without experiencing hunger, one just takes abundant food for granted, while Gahigi noted that "when you are hungry, you are vulnerable to everything."

DOC.HEADLINE: World Vision Taiwan 30-hour famine rally kicks off

TEXT.P: World Vision Taiwan, the local chapter of the international Christian charity, kicked off Saturday its 20th 30-Hour Famine 2009, which was attended by some 15,000 people seeking to promote public awareness of the need to combat the global food crisis.

This year's rally is of special meaning in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, which brought devastation to southern areas of Taiwan the previous week, and the participants will be praying for the typhoon survivors and appealing for more funds for relief and rehabilitation efforts.

"Over the years, whenever disaster has struck, World Vision has responded swiftly, bringing urgently needed food and supplies to children and families faced with crisis," World Vision Taiwan said in a press release.
"The number of 30 Hour Famine participants has increased annually and the campaign has touched countless lives," it added.
Now in its 20th year, the rally this year is taking place at gymnasium of National Taiwan Sport University and will run a full 30 hours.

Artists from major record labels have also geared up to support the event, which is part of the group's global movement to involve people, especially youngsters, who fast for 30 hours to raise money for people suffering from famine in poor countries, according to World Vision Taiwan.

Various celebrities and spokespeople, including 30 Hour Famine "ambassador" Wang Lee-hom and several news anchors were taking part to cheer on the fasters and share their experiences, as well as to encourage the participants to continue their support for people affected by humanitarian crises in Taiwan and around the world, according to World Vision Taiwan.

The program is one of World Vision Taiwan's three principal fund-raising activities, the other two being a child sponsorship program that helps poor children in Taiwan and abroad and a program that assists local and overseas development projects.
The Taiwan chapter of World Vision was established 43 years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. to dispatch helicopters, materials for typhoon relief

TEXT.P: The United States will send heavy-lift helicopters along with other relief supplies to Taiwan in the coming days in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, the Taipei-based American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) said Saturday.
"The U.S. has agreed to provide U.S. personnel-operated heavy-lift helicopters and other materials to support the relief operation," AIT Press Officer Christopher Kavanagh told CNA.
Details such as the number of choppers and when and from where they will be dispatched were still being worked out, he added.

In addition to a donation of US$250,000 made by the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) Aug. 12, Ron Libby, a coordinator with USAID in charge of disaster response assistance and support, arrived in Taiwan Friday and was scheduled to travel to regions hardest hit by Morakot, including Pingtung and Kaohsiung counties in southern Taiwan.

Libby is tasked with assessing the extent and scale of the destruction and the resources, facilities and equipment that foreign countries can contribute to post-disaster relief and rehabilitation operations.

Taiwan has been receiving all various humanitarian care from friendly countries worldwide in the wake of the typhoon, with assistance and resources from the international community continuing to pour into the country.

The Australian government announced that day that it will donate US$168,600-worth of emergency supplies to assist the storm victims and pledged to provide sanitation supplies to combat water-borne diseases caused by flooding.

According to a press statement released by the Australian Agency for International Development, the donation will include 200,000 water purification tablets, 5,000 large buckets for treating water and for general household use, 100 sanitizer spray packs that hold disinfectant and repellent for spraying around buildings to stop disease, insects and rodents.
China Airlines will transport the shipment, which is scheduled to arrive in the country Aug. 16, free of charge.

As of that day, the MOFA had received condolences extended by 59 countries as well as the European Union and 19 international organizations. Several countries, including the United States, Japan, South Korea and Singapore, have also donated money for post-disaster rehabilitation efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Schooling, aid measures announced for typhoon-affected students

TEXT.P: The government announced Saturday schooling and aid measures for students affected by Typhoon Morakot to ensure their education is not interrupted.

Information provided by the Central Emergency Operation Center shows that due to damage wrought by the typhoon, 20 elementary and junior high schools will not be able to reopen in time for the start of the new school year in September.

Under these circumstances, students from these schools will be allowed to attend schools in areas in which where their relatives live, in other counties or cities, or near their temporary shelters, without being subject to normal school district restrictions, said Deputy Minister of Education Wu Tsai-shung.
If none of these three options fit the students' needs, the Ministry of Education (MOE) will open temporary classrooms at the various shelters, Wu said.
In addition, the MOE will provide a variety of subsidies for the affected students.

Elementary and junior high school students will each receive NT$1,500 (US$45.73) to NT$1,600 per semester for up to three years in general subsidies and NT$1,500 per month in lunch subsidies, according to the MOE.
Senior high school, college and university students will be able to postpone their enrollment and will be granted full tuition and miscellaneous fee waivers for up to three years.

While senior high school students will each receive NT$23,600 per semester in living cost subsidies for up to three years, college and university students will get full dormitory fee waivers for one year.

For all levels of students, the relief allowance will range from NT$5,000 to NT$10,000, while subsidies ranging from NT$10,000 to NT$60,000 will be provided on the death or injury of students or their parents, the MOE said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Survivors of destroyed village mourn dead

TEXT.P: Villagers who survived the destruction of Siaolin village in Kaohsiung County went back to the site of the destroyed village Saturday to pay tribute to the hundreds of villagers buried under mud and debris.

Five days after last Friday's disaster, Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing had said that some 300 villagers were still missing and that rescue teams reckoned there was no hope of finding anyone else alive.

Following the folk custom in which the spirits of the deceased should be comforted on the seventh day of their departure, families of the victims prepared slippers and food for the dead on their journey to the other world.

While the heartbroken villagers prayed that the bodies dead will not be disturbed, Yang agreed to investigate the possibility of establishing a memorial park on the site of Siaolin, a river valley scenic spot.

Siaolin was not the only village in the county to be devastated as a result of Typhoon Morakot. Hundreds of residents of Liukuei village were also still missing, and rescuers have turned from rescuing survivors to unearthing corpses.

Although there were still hundreds of villagers in remote mountain regions facing the threat of further mudslides, the presence of the police and military had somewhat alleviated their fear of being cut off again.
Meanwhile, President Ma Ying-jeou, who visited the damaged village of Shuili in Nantou County Saturday, apologized for the government's failure to do a quicker and better job.
He said that there were limitations and difficulties, while the rainy weather had delayed the evacuation of isolated villagers.

He elaborated that in the first four days following the disaster, only 1,500 villagers were rescued because bad weather restricted the operations of the helicopters. As the weather improved, however, 4,700 villagers were evacuated over the following two days.

To help residents in the devastated areas clean up and resettle the homeless, cadets from military schools and the police academy had also been mobilized, in addition to volunteers from religious and social welfare groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: Donations from countries, organizations flow into Taiwan

TEXT.P: Fifty-nine countries around the world, as well as 19 international organizations and foreign civic groups have made donations for the relief of flood-stricken families in southern Taiwan, the Central Emergency Operation Center (CEOC) said Saturday.
The accumulated donations had reached NT$54.72 million (US$1.66 million) as of 3 a.m. Saturday, the CEOC said, citing statistics from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Twenty-two countries that maintain diplomatic ties with the Republic of China had offered their condolences for those who died in the worst flooding in 50 years in southern Taiwan over the past week, while 37 countries with no diplomatic links with Taiwan, such as the United States, Japan, Canada and Britain had also expressed condolences, the CEOC said.

According to the CEOC, the international organizations that had expressed concern about the flooding included the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, the Asian-Pacific Parliamentarians' Union, Feed the Children and Food for the Poor.

At the same time, Singapore had donated NT$1.14 million-worth of supplies for medical treatment, while Israel had donated water-cleaners and water transport equipment, the CEOC said, noting that the U.S. Agency for International Development had sent a representative to Taiwan to assess the damage and the kinds of assistance it can offer.
The European Union will send representatives to Taiwan Aug. 18 to conduct a similar evaluation, the CEOC said.
Meanwhile, Pope Benedict XVI donated US$50,000 that day for the typhoon victims.

The donation was handed over by Monsignor Paul Russell, charge d'affaires of the Holy See Embassy, to Vice Minister of the Interior Tzeng Chung-ming. The Holy See is the only country in Europe that has diplomatic links with Taiwan.

The Roman Catholic Metropolitan Archdiocese of Taipei also held a ceremony at the Holy Family Catholic Church in Taipei City earlier in the day to pray for the flood victims, which was attended by Russell and Tzeng.
Citing the pope, Russell said that "Taiwan has many friends. It is not a lonely island."
The prayers were initiated by Cardinal Shan Kuo-hsi, who also urged all believers in Taiwan to make donations at the more-than 1,000 Catholic churches around the island for the relief efforts.

Archbishop of Taipei Hung Shan-chuan suggested that everyone in the country should donate NT$1 each day and continue the donations for 64 days in a row to remind themselves that their fellow countrymen were still suffering.

In addition to the donation campaign, all Catholic medical institutes and social welfare groups have dispatched volunteer teams to the affected areas to help the rescue and relief efforts, according to Hung.

Fatalities from Morakot had increased to 121 as of 8 a.m. Saturday, with 53 reported missing and 45 injured, according to official CEOC tallies, which did not include those who might have been killed by landslides in Siaolin village in Kaohsiung County.

According to the CEOC, there were estimated 169 households in Siaolin, with 398 people believed to remain unaccounted for after the whole village was buried in mud and debris. No efforts to begin digging the village out had begun as of Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Reconstruction advancement committee to have first meeting

TEXT.P: A post-Typhoon Morakot reconstruction advancement committee under the Executive Yuan will be formed and will hold its first meeting Sunday, a Cabinet official said Saturday.

In response to President Ma Ying-jeou's instruction at a national security meeting Friday to set up such committees at central government as well as local government level, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan decided to form the committees at the earliest possible date.

With the forming of the committee, experts with experience in the post-921 earthquake reconstruction, knowledge of mud flows as well as water and soil conservation, in addition to officials from related government agencies, will evaluate the disaster situation and work out relief measures.

Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo, in his capacity as chief of the Central Emergency Operation Center, will give a briefing on the damage and rescue action to date at the meeting.
In the wake of the 921 earthquake, a similar reconstruction advancement committee was formed Sept. 27, 1999.

Based on the Disaster Prevention and Protection Act promulgated and put into force July 19, 2000, the emergency committees responsible for recovery and reconstruction are disbanded upon the completion of their missions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alishan tourism sector sustains severe typhoon damage

TEXT.P: Massive flooding caused by Typhoon Morakot in southern Taiwan since Aug. 8 has badly damaged the scenic Alishan area -- one of the most popular tourist attractions in Taiwan -- after flood and landslides smashed roads and buried various sightseeing spots.

The Alishan Highway, which is the main road to the Alishan forest recreation area, suffered massive cave-ins and losses of the road bed, and the Directorate General of Highways (DGH) estimated that part of the road could be fixed by Sept. 5, although the road is not expected to reopen completely until the end of September.

Kuo Ching-shuei, a DGH official in charge of construction and repair of roads in the area, was cited by a local newspaper that it would take at least six months to one year before big tourist buses will be able to use the road.

Damage to the Alishan forest railway was even worse, with Yen Mao-sheng, the official in charge of railway construction affairs at the Chiayi Forest District Office, assessing that it would take a year to restore the popular scenic railway.

Four townships in the Alishan scenic area, including Jhuci, Fanlu, Alishan and Meishan, received nearly 3,000 mm of rain during the typhoon devastation last week, the highest precipitation recorded anywhere in the country.
Restoration of the townships is expected to take many years, as will recovery of the agriculture and tourism sectors in the area, Fanlu township chief Lou Yin- chang said.

The number of tourists visiting the Alishan forest recreation area this year alone reached 1 million Aug. 4, the highest figure since its inauguration in 1980, thanks to Taiwan's opening to visits by Chinese tourists.
Meanwhile, Tourism Bureau officials noted, however, that most of the country's other tourism destinations had escaped relatively unscathed from the devastation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan reports second death related to H1N1

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) reported Saturday evening that a six-year- old girl became the second fatality case related to the A(H1N1) swine influenza in Taiwan.

A CDC release indicated that the girl fell ill with symptons of flu and was checked into hospital on July 25. She was under intensive care since July 30 when the symptons exacerbated and she was diagnozed with the H1N1 virus.
As of Saturday, 25 severe cases have been hospitalized. Among them, 16 have already been released from hospital. Only three patients are under intensive care.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug. 16, 2009

TEXT.P: international press conference Date and Time: 6 p.m., Sunday, Aug. 16, 2009 Place: 200 Peihsin Road, Hsintien, Taipei
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alishan tourism sector sustains severe typhoon damage

TEXT.P: Massive flooding caused by Typhoon Morakot in southern Taiwan since Aug. 8 has badly damaged the scenic Alishan area -- one of the most popular tourist attractions in Taiwan -- after flood and landslides smashed roads and buried various sightseeing spots.

The Alishan Highway, which is the main road to the Alishan forest recreation area, suffered massive cave-ins and losses of the road bed, and the Directorate General of Highways (DGH) estimated that part of the road could be fixed by Sept. 5, although the road is not expected to reopen completely until the end of September.

Kuo Ching-shuei, a DGH official in charge of construction and repair of roads in the area, was cited by a local newspaper that it would take at least six months to one year before big tourist buses will be able to use the road.

Damage to the Alishan forest railway was even worse, with Yen Mao-sheng, the official in charge of railway construction affairs at the Chiayi Forest District Office, assessing that it would take a year to restore the popular scenic railway.

Four townships in the Alishan scenic area, including Jhuci, Fanlu, Alishan and Meishan, received nearly 3,000 mm of rain during the typhoon devastation last week, the highest precipitation recorded anywhere in the country.
Restoration of the townships is expected to take many years, as will recovery of the agriculture and tourism sectors in the area, Fanlu township chief Lou Yin- chang said.

The number of tourists visiting the Alishan forest recreation area this year alone reached 1 million Aug. 4, the highest figure since its inauguration in 1980, thanks to Taiwan's opening to visits by Chinese tourists.
Meanwhile, Tourism Bureau officials noted, however, that most of the country's other tourism destinations had escaped relatively unscathed from the devastation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 16, or the 26th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1777: Americans led by Gen. John Stark defeat the British at the Battle of Bennington during the American Revolution.
1825: Bolivia declares its independence from Spain.
1909: Japanese Chutaro Kido discovers an iron mine in Anshan, Liaoning Province, located in Manchuria, where Japan has extensive economic privileges. The Southern Manchuria Railway later sets up a steel plant in Anshan.
1913: Menachem Begin, Israeli prime minister from 1977 to 1983, is born in Russia. He shared the 1978 Nobel Peace Prize with Anwar Sadat of Egypt.
1913: Lo Fu-hsing, who had participated in Dr. Sun Yat-sen's overthrow of the Ching dynasty, organizes a revolt in Tahu, Hsinchu County, against Japanese rule of Taiwan in the so-called Miaoli Incident. He was executed after the uprising failed.
1923: Lee Kuan Yew, prime minister of Singapore from 1959 to 1990, is born.
1923: Shimon Peres, Israeli prime minister from 1984 to 1986, is born in Poland.
1937: The Supreme National Defense Council decides at a meeting that the Nationalist government should authorize Chiang Kai-shek as generalisimo to lead the Republic of China armed forces in the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1948: George Herman Ruth, known as "Babe" Ruth, the most famous baseball player of all time, dies in New York City at the age of 53. He broke the Major League home run record in three consecutive seasons (1919-21), and then again in 1927 with a staggering 60 home runs.
1949: Margaret Mitchell, the author of "Gone with the Wind," dies after being hit by a car two days earlier. She was 49.
1950: Taiwan, formerly comprising eight counties and nine cities, is re-divided into 16 counties and five cities.
1960: The new republic of Cyprus comes into being, with Archbishop Makarios as its first president.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Gabon.
1968: The first Poseidon missile is launched.
1974: Wu Kuan-hsiung, secretary-general of the China External Trade Development Council, and Ahmad Sowaidi, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of Qatar, sign a trade cooperation memorandum.
1975: The Republic of China and Nauru sign a civil aviation agreement.
1977: Elvis Presley, the king of rock and roll, dies of heart failure at the age of 42 after collapsing in his mansion in Memphis, Tenn.
1978: Cardinal Yu Pin dies of a heart attack in Rome at the age of 77.
1979: John G. Diefenbaker, Canadian politician who served as prime minister from 1957 to 1963, dies at the age of 84. The Progressive Conservative government he headed lost the 1963 general elections because of opposition to his proposals to build nuclear weapons in Canada.
1990: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq warns U.S. President George Bush that thousands of the troops he has sent to the Gulf will return home in coffins.
1996: Leonel Fernandez becomes the 100th president of the Dominican Republic.
1999: Two Republic of China warships, the Hui Yang and the Han Yang, are decommissioned after almost 30 years of service, bringing to 10 the total number of naval vessels decommissioned by the ROC.
2000: Visiting ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his delegation take part in the inauguration of Dominican Republic President Hipolito Mejia held at the Parliament Building.
2000: ROC Premier Tang Fei unveils a proposal to transform Taiwan into a knowledge-based economy that is on par with those of the world's most advanced nations within ten years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In order to acquire truth, it is necessary to obtain a wide and extensive knowledge of what has been said and done in the world; to critically inquire into it; to carefully ponder over it; to clearly sift it; and to earnestly carry it out."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Relief supplies from foreign donors continue flowing into Taiwan

TEXT.P: Post-disaster relief supplies donated by foreign countries continued flowing into Taiwan Sunday as the country digs itself out of the devastation wrought by Typhoon Morakot.

An Emirates Airlines flight arrived in Taipei early in the morning with a batch of shelter boxes donated by Britain's Shelter Box Trust, which is administered by the Helston-Lizard Rotary Club in Cornwall, disaster response officials said.

The shelter boxes, which will soon be delivered to the hardest-hit disaster zones, contain a 10-person tunnel tent, 10 sleeping bags, and accessories such as a multifuel cooker, water purifier, a spade and rope.
China Airlines, Taiwan's largest carrier, also airlifted a shipment of emergency supplies donated by Australia to Taipei early Sunday free of charge.

Richard Mathews, Australia's deputy representative in Taiwan, handed over the supplies to Lee Shih-ming, director-general of the East Asian and Pacific Affairs Department under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, in a donation ceremony held at Taoyuan International Airport in northern Taiwan.

The supplies include 200,000 water purification tablets, 5,040 large buckets for treating water and for general household use, 100 sanitizer spray packs that hold disinfectant, and repellent to spray around buildings for disease prevention.

Australian Representative to Taiwan Alice Cawte formally presented the US$168,600 worth of water purification and disinfectant supplies at the Central Emergency Operation Center in Taipei around noon Sunday to Minister of Transportation of Communications Mao Chih-kuo.
Mao, who concurrently serves as the post-disaster response commander, said Taiwan's government and people are grateful for Australia's donation.
Taiwan's Red Cross Society will help deliver the sanitation supplies to disaster zones for distribution to affected families, Mao said.

Cawte said the Australian government hopes its emergency supplies can allow local typhoon victims to enjoy clean drinking water and help combat water-borne diseases caused by Morakot-triggered flooding.

Typhoon Morakot dumped more than 2500 mm of precipitation -- the equivalent of a whole year's rainfall -- in southern Taiwan Aug. 7-9, swelling rivers that washed away bridges and spurring landslides that buried entire villages.

The storm, one of the worst natural disasters to batter Taiwan in half a century, had officially killed at least 124 people across Taiwan and left 45 injured and 56 otehrs unaccounted for as of 10 p.m. Saturday.

Those numbers do not include the potentially hundreds of people believed to have been buried in landslides in remote mountainous areas of southern Taiwan, especially in Siaolin village in Kaohsiung County.
Agricultural losses from Morakot has exceeded NT$12.24 billion (US$370.91 million) as of 9 a.m. Sunday, the second highest caused by asingle typhoon in nearly 19 years.
The amount was only second to NT$18.08 billion in agricultural losses caused by Typhoon Herb, which rattled Taiwan in August 1996.
Aquaculture losses as a result of flooding spurred by Morakot had broken all previous records to top NT$4.13 billion as of Sunday morning.

Meanwhile, 59 countries from around the world, as well as 19 international organizations and foreign civic groups have made donations to help disaster- stricken families in southern Taiwan, disaster response officials said.
As of 3 a.m. Saturday, foreign entities had donated NT$54.72 million (US$1.66 million) to the cause, according to tallies released by the Central Emergency Operation Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan team wins Pony League World Series title
DOC.DATELINE: New York-Pennsylvania, Aug. 15 (CNA) 08/16/09 16:52:55 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A team from Taitung County won the Pony League World Series championship Saturday in Washington County, Pennsylvania, the sixth Taiwanese team to win the title in the past sixteen years.
The Taitung team defeated Riverside, California, 12-1 in the title game to become the first team since 2001 to win the double elimination tournament after losing its opening game.

In the final against Riverside, Taiwan trailed 1-0 before erupting for four runs in the bottom of the third inning. Catcher Ispalidev Lanihu's bases-loaded single drove in the tying run, and Su Chih-chieh drove in two more with a single to right. Lanihu scored the fourth run on a groundout.
Taiwan put the game away in the fourth inning as Chang Yu-cheng's three-run blast and Su Chih-chieh's two-run homer keyed an eight-run rally, putting the team ahead 12-1.
Lai Ta-kuan, who relieved starter Lan Chen-wei to start the fourth inning, retired Riverside in order in the fifth, and the game was called because of the 10-run rule.
About 200 Taiwanese expatriates from Pennsylvania and Maryland were there to root for the Taitung team, composed of students from junior high schools in rural areas of the southeastern county.
Manager Wang Kuo-ching could barely hide his excitement over his team's triumph and praised his team's will and indomitable spirit to come back after losing its first game of the tournament.
Taiwan fell to Toa Baja of Puerto Rico 3-1 on Aug. 8, but then beat Bay County, Michigan, 13-9, and Johnstown, Pennsylvania, 7-3, to set up a showdown with Toa Baja.
Having to beat the Puerto Rican team twice in a row to reach the final, Taiwan defeated Toa Baja 8-3 on Aug. 13, and then 4-2 a day later on a dramatic home run by Chang Cheng-nan in extra innings.
The Pony League tournament was for players 13 and 14 years old. Unlike Little League, the Pony League is composed of two-year age brackets and different sized diamonds for different age groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. heavy-lift chopper to arrive Monday

TEXT.P: At least one U.S. heavy-lift CH-53E helicopter will arrive in Taiwan Monday to assist in relief operations in the southern part of the country, which was devastated by flooding and landslides from Typhoon Morakot, defense officials said Sunday.

"The U.S. military is now working to have its CH-53E helicopter take part in humanitarian post-disaster relief efforts in Taiwan, " said an official with the Ministry of National Defense (MND) , who spoke on condition of anonymity.

According to the official, at least one CH-53E helicopter will be delivered by an amphibious transport dock ship, also known as a landing platform dock, to waters near Taiwan from where the chopper will fly to the Tainan air base in southern Taiwan.
If all goes well, the official said, at least one CH-53E chopper will arrive in Tainan Monday at the earliest.
The official would not confirm, however, if the United States will provide one or two such heavy-lift helicopters.
"Our two sides are still in close contact to work out relevant details, " the official said, adding that the Defense Ministry will inform the public once all technical details are settled.

As the CH-53E chopper can transport a 16-ton payload, its arrival is expected to help with relief and rehabilitation work in mountainous areas that were cut off from the outside world in the storm, the official added.

Typhoon Morakot, which dumped more than 2500 mm of precipitation -- the equivalent of a whole year's rainfall -- in some parts of Taiwan Aug. 7-9, proved lethal in several remote villages that dot mountains in the southern counties of Kaohsiung and Pingtung.

A National Fire Administration official said earlier this week that Taiwan urgently needs helicopters that can carry cranes and other heavy-duty machinery into flood- and landslide-ravaged mountainous villages to help rescue those who might still be stranded.

The storm, one of the worst natural disasters to batter Taiwan in half a century, had officially killed at least 124 people across Taiwan and left 45 injured and 56 others unaccounted for as of 10 p.m. Saturday.

Those numbers do not include the potentially hundreds of people believed to have been buried in landslides in remote mountainous areas of southern Taiwan, especially in Siaolin village in Kaohsiung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. C-130 brings plastic sheeting for typhoon relief

TEXT.P: A United States military C-130 transport plane arrived Sunday at Tainan Air Force Base with a cargo of plastic sheeting to help with reconstruction efforts in the wake of Typhoon Morakot.

It marked the first time that a U.S. military transport aircraft had landed in Taiwan in the name of humanitarian aid since the United States switched political recognition from the Republic of China to the People's Republic of China in 1979.
The aircraft arrived in Tainan at 2: 50 p.m. local time and flew back to Okinawa immediately after discharging its cargo.

Christopher Kavanagh, press officer of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , told the Central News Agency that the C-130 aircraft took off from the U.S. military base in Okinawa, Japan, at noon, carrying 120 rolls, or 15,200 pounds, of plastic sheeting that can be used for temporary shelter during the reconstruction process.
We have been looking at what materials are available and what kind of services we have to commute the items Taiwan needs,Kavanagh said.
Asked when the heavy-lift helicopters that Washington has decided to send will arrive, Kavanagh said that the mission is in progress but details have yet to be confirmed.

Taiwan has been receiving humanitarian aid from countries around the world in recent days to help with disaster relief efforts after Typhoon Morakot battered Taiwan Aug. 7-9, triggering massive flooding and deadly landslides throughout southern Taiwan.

Although the official death toll from the storm stood at 124 as of 10 p.m. Saturday, hundreds more are feared to have been buried in landslides in remote mountainous villages, especially in Siaolin in Kaohsiung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: First serious swine flu case involving pregnant woman reported

TEXT.P: Pingtung County health officials reported Sunday two serious cases of swine flu, including the first such case involving a pregnant woman in Taiwan.
Health officials said that of the two patients seriously affected by the H1N1 strain of the flu, one has recovered while the other -- a 25-year-old pregnant woman -- is still in intensive care.
The officials said the woman, 24 weeks pregnant, began to cough Aug. 9. She developed a fever the following day and went to the hospital for emergency treatment.
She began to develop pneumonia Aug. 13, and was later confirmed to have been infected with the new influenza A flu strain.
Health officials said pregnant women are at the highest risk of contracting swine flu and are more likely to develop serious complications from the virus than the average patient.

They also indicated that the flu progresses faster in pregnant women and noted that the World Health Organization has suggested that pregnant women be the top priority group to be vaccinated against the flu strain.
The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) reported on Saturday that a six-year-old girl had died from the H1N1 strain, the second person in Taiwan to have died from the flu virus.

DOC.HEADLINE: More funds sought for reconstruction in typhoon-ravaged areas: MOF

TEXT.P: The government is looking to raise more funds to rebuild and rehabilitate areas in southern Taiwan that were devastated by Typhoon Morakot, a Ministry of Finance (MOF) official said Sunday.

Funding provisions for flood control, disaster prevention and reconstruction in the central government general budget and special budgets will be allocated on a priority basis to the reconstruction of typhoon-affected areas, but more is needed for a variety of uses.

Among them: a disaster-related budget; emergency loans for post-disaster rehabilitation; the Natural Disaster Aid Fund for Agriculture; subsidies for city and county governments; the secondary reserve fund; and funding for disaster preparation, the official said.
One of the possibilities being considered to raise funds, the official noted, was to sell shares in state-run enterprises at an appropriate time.

The ministry is also considering creating resources through land management strategies, such as urban land rezoning and land expropriation, and will make timely use of the general revenue sharing program to help meet the needs of local governments, the official added.

During a tour of flood-affected areas in Tainan County, Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi also said the government is planning to earmark an extraordinary budget to subsidize households that suffered flood damage to lessen the financial burden on local governments.
Under the initial plan, each household will be given NT$5,000-NT$20,000 in subsidies, with the criteria for qualification still under deliberation.
Liao said his ministry is also considering raising funds to help flood-hit households.
In a related development, the Council of Agriculture said Sunday that rice prices will remain stable in the short term thanks to a good harvest of this year's first rice crop.
According to Chen Wen-teh, the director-general of the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency, Taiwan harvested over 830,000 tons of rice in the first harvest of the season, up 7 percent year-on-year.
Along with 300,000 tons in inventory and access to imported rice, the country will have an adequate supply of rice in the short term in the wake of Typhoon Morakot.

The storm may have an impact in the longer term, however. The typhoon's onslaught coincided with the country's second rice seedling transplanting period, and the COA said it is closely monitoring any damage to the seedlings caused by the storm.

DOC.HEADLINE: President wants to establish guidelines for compulsory evacuation

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday the Ministry of the Interior should establish a compulsory evacuation system with clear guidelines that would better protect residents of areas in imminent danger of a natural disaster.
At present, there is no legal basis in Taiwan to force people to evacuate from a potential danger area. Local governments can only urge residents to abandon their homes if a disaster is foreseen.

Ma said the existing Disaster Prevention and Response Act should be updated to establish criteria that would trigger a compulsory evacuation to prevent a repeat of the loss of human life and suffering caused by Typhoon Morakot Aug. 7-9.

The president made the remarks while inspecting an ad hoc southern Taiwan disaster response command center set up in Pingtung County, one of the regions hardest-hit by Morakot-triggered flooding and landslides.

Morakot, which dumped more than 2500 mm of rainfall -- the equivalent of a whole year's precipitation -- in some parts of Taiwan, had its deadliest impact on dozens of remote villages that dot mountains in Pingtung and neighboring Kaohsiung counties.
One such village, Siaolin, was obliterated when Morakot's torrential rains sent the faces of two nearby mountains tumbling down on the village's 200 or so houses.
Hundreds of residents are feared to have been buried alive in the killer landslides, but their number may never be known because the village may not be excavated.

While many survivors in nearby villages along the Laonung River have been evacuated to safety by military rescue helicopters, a combined total of 1,000 residents in those isolated villages still refuse to be evacuated.

On mounting criticism that his administration has been slow and inefficient in post-disaster rescue and relief operations, Ma said that as the country's head of state, he is obligated to assume full responsibility.
"I will fulfill my duty to do a good job, " he pledged.

Arguing that disaster prevention should take precedence over disaster relief, Ma said county and city governments should always prioritize precaution before the onslaught of typhoons to minimize possible casualties and regularly conduct disaster response training drills to enhance operational efficiency.

Earlier in the day, Ma inspected dikes in Pingtung County's Sinyuan township, which almost burst when floodwaters swamped the Gaoping and Donggang River. Fortunately, some young residents repaired the ruptures in time.
Nevertheless, the low-lying township was still inundated by flash flooding, with floodwaters reaching 60 centimeters in most of the district.

Pingtung County Magistrate Tsao Chi-hung, who accompanied Ma on the visit, suggested that all flood prevention projects should be based on being able to last 150 years or 200 years instead of the current 100 years in order to reinforce criteria for relevant infrastructure construction.
Ma agreed that standards should be upgraded in densely populated areas or industrial zones.
The president also inspected a temporary shelter for evacuated typhoon victims set in the county's Neipu township.
Many of the 200-plus aboriginal people evacuated from the partly ruined mountainous Wutai village told Ma that they need the government's help to rebuild their hometown.

The president pledged that the central government would fully support county governments in resettling displaced typhoon victims and helping them find jobs and assisting in their children's schooling.

According to the county's magistrate, all evacuees will be resettled in two weeks, suggesting that Radio Taiwan International's houses in Pingtung County can be used to accommodate them. In the longer term, he said, prefabricated housing will be built to house all displaced victims.
Moreover, he said, the county government will hire evacuees to help with environmental cleanup tasks and other rehabilitation operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1st shipment of China-donated prefab houses to arrive Tuesday

TEXT.P: The first batch of 100 prefabricated houses donated by China is scheduled to arrive at Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan early next week to help house displaced typhoon victims, an official said Sunday.

"The prefab housing will be loaded onto a vessel at Shenzhen in southern China's Guangdong province Monday evening, and it is scheduled to arrive at Kaohsiung Harbor around noon Tuesday," said Ma Shao-chang, deputy secretary-general of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

China offered to assist in Taiwan's rehabilitation operation last week after Typhoon Morakot wreaked havoc in certain parts of the island Aug. 7-9, particularly the southern counties of Pingtung and Kaohsiung.
After an evaluation, Taiwan's government said it hoped China could provide 1,000 prefab houses to facilitate resettlement of typhoon victims.

Technical details involved in the donation are being handled by the SEF and its Chinese counterpart -- the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- both of them quasi-official intermediary bodies founded by their respective governments to handle negotiations in the absence of official ties.

Noting that assembling the prefab housing is a professional job, Ma said the Ministry of the Interior's Construction and Planning Agency (CPA) will send officials to take delivery of the cargo when the shipment arrives Tuesday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Liu Te-hsun said the CPA already informed Chinese authorities the specifications of prefab housing suitable for Taiwan. The Cabinet-level MAC oversees SEF operations.
"All the prefab hosuses will be distributed to typhoon victims in terms of their demand," said Liu.
Delivery of other relief supplies that China has offered Taiwan, including 10,000 blankets, 10,000 sleeping bags and 500 automated disinfecting machines, will come later, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12,000 servicemen help clean up flood-affected areas in Pingtung

TEXT.P: The Marine Corps mobilized 12,000 servicemen to help with post-typhoon cleanup efforts in Pingtung County Sunday in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot, which caused the most serious flooding in southern Taiwan in 50 years.

The marines provided assistance in 14 townships in the southern Taiwan county, focusing on cleaning mud and sludge from the streets and decomposing fish from fish ponds in Linbian and Jiadong townships.
The two low-lying coastal towns were seriously inundated when the typhoon passed through Taiwan Aug. 7-9. Floodwaters were about two-stories high at their peak.
An old woman from Jiadong said "thanks, young men" when she saw a group of servicemen busily cleaning out fish ponds and picking up debris from the streets.

The air was filled with the pungent smell of rotting fish, but the marines braved the foul odor to shovel out the ponds with urgency under southern Taiwan's sweltering heat. Chemical specialists followed by spraying disinfectants in the area.
The 66th Marine Brigade is in charge of the rescue and rehabilitation operation in the two townships.
Brigadier Chen Tze-fong said the military is proud to be able to pitch in to help the typhoon affected areas.

The Environmental Protection Administration is also mobilizing 3,000 people, including cleaning workers and volunteers, to help with the cleanup effort in Linbian township under the military's direction.

EPA official Chang Huan-chang said 10 villages in the township were inundated during the typhoon, and water levels had receded slowly, most likely because of blocked drainage systems, but he estimated the cleanup would be completed within three to five days.
As of Sunday, two villages -- Linbian and Chunglin -- were still submerged in water.

National Defense Minister Chen Chao-min instructed the military to clear the mud on streets in areas where floodwaters had receded within two days, according to vice chief of general staff Wu Da-peng,
who was speaking at a news conference Sunday on the military's disaster relief efforts.

The military should complete the cleaning of areas where floodwaters have receded in central Taiwan, Kaoshu in Pingtung County and Cishan in Kaohsiung County by Aug. 18; Tainan City and County by Aug. 19; and Linbian in Pingtung County by Aug. 20, Wu said.
If rescue efforts are completed in the next two days, the military will then move on to help with the next stages of resettlement and reconstruction.
Chen also requested aerial monitoring of barrier lakes in Cishan, the Laonong River area in Kaohsiung County and Taimali in Taitung County to prevent any unexpected disasters, according to Wu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 37,000 typhoon victims rescued: interior minister

TEXT.P: More than 37,000 victims stranded by floods and landslides unleashed by Typhoon Morakot have been rescued and 103 roads and bridges have been reopened since the typhoon devastated Taiwan a week ago, Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi said Sunday.
The next phase of disaster relief efforts will focus on resettling victims and reconstructing disaster ravaged areas, said Liao, who is in charge of the Southern Taiwan Disaster Relief Center.

Briefing President Ma Ying-jeou at the center in hard-hit Pingtung County, Liao said 37,366 people trapped in southern Taiwan villages have been evacuated to safety and about 45,000 cartons of relief supplies, including milk powder, instant noodles and bottled water, have been delivered to affected areas.

Liao also reported that water service had resumed to 670,287 out of 730,972 households in the counties of Pingtung, Kaohsiung, Tainan, Chiayi and Taitung that had been without water because of the typhoon, while electricity had been restored in 823,884 out of 846,784 households.
In addition, 103 of 127 damaged roads and bridges in the above mentioned counties have been repaired and opened to traffic.
Places still inaccessible by vehicles include Wutai township in Pingtung County, Namasia, Taoyuan and Maolin townships in Kaohsiung County and Alishan township in Chiayi County, Liao said.

All related agencies in the central government, in coordination with local governments, will do their utmost to expedite relief efforts and help the lives of victims return to normal as soon as possible, Liao added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government questioned over delays in typhoon relief efforts

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government was peppered with questions from the foreign media Sunday on the administration's failure to act quickly enough in organizing rescue and disaster relief operations in the wake of Typhoon Morakot.

At a news conference with Mao Chi-kuo, the commander of the Central Emergency Operation Center (CEOC), Western media and major Japanese news outlets all focused on why Taiwanese authorities seemed to respond slowly to the disaster while at the same time giving conflicting information on the death toll.

Responding to the questions on and criticism of the government's performance and its slow deployment of the military to help people stranded by the typhoon, Transportation Minister Mao said the situation was different than that faced following earthquakes and other disasters.

Heavy rainfall, along with landslides, continued in the days after the typhoon first began to affect Taiwan and resulted in damaged roads and bridges, which impeded rescue operations by the armed forces, Mao said.
Full-scale rescue operations could not begin until Aug. 10 when the weather cleared up, at which point the military dispatched personnel by land and air to affected areas, he added.

Asked whether he agrees with public criticism that the government isincompetentbased on its handling of the disaster, Mao said, "many of the criticisms were actually a chain of mixed-information and that judging from the information he received in the initial stages when the relief efforts began, the government was well informed and in control of the situation."

In terms of disaster relief, we can always do better and we understand that the typhoon victims wished we did more and much quicker. We can only humbly accept their criticism and work harder, Mao said.

The foreign media were also very concerned about the exact number of deaths in Siaolin village in the southern county of Kaohsiung, where some 380 people are feared buried under the mudslides that destroyed the village during Typhoon Morakot last week.
"The government should be responsible and very careful when it comes to death toll numbers. There is a certain procedure that we need to go through before making any announcement," Mao said.

Mao said the government is in the process of verifying the exact number of dead and will consult with the families of the villagers on whether to start digging the village out of the mud that buried it.

DOC.HEADLINE: Diversified measures to be used to resettle typhoon victims

TEXT.P: The government will adopt diversified measures to resettle people displaced by flooding and landslides spurred by Typhoon Morakot, Government Information Office Minister Su Jun-pin said Sunday.
Su was speaking after Premier Liu Chao-shiuan convened a meeting of an ad hoc post-disaster reconstruction committee to discuss feasible measures for resettling displaced typhoon victims.

Senior officials from the Ministry of the Interior, the Ministry of National Defense, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications as well as other relevant agencies took part in the brainstorming session, Su said.
"During the meeting, Liu directed the Ministry of the Interior to form an inter- agency task force to survey typhoon-affected people's preferences for resettlement within a week," Su said.

Noting that intermediate resettlement is an urgent task, Su said the government may either offer subsidies for typhoon victims to rent houses on their own or provide them with living expenses if they agree to live in the same selected communities.

Meanwhile, Minister-without-Portfolio Tsai Hsun-hsiuan said the intermediate settlement period may last for a couple of months, a half year or up to two years, depending on the extent and scale of destruction caused by the storm to their original homes.
"The amount of the proposed rental subsidy has yet to be decided, " Tsai said, adding that the amount may be set at NT$3,600 per month.
As to the living subsidy, the amount may be slightly higher than the figure presently offered for low-income families, Tsai said.

Reconstruction, Tsai said, would be more complicated because if residents insisted on rebuilding homes in their original hometowns, a comprehensive review would be needed to determine whether the areas were still safe.
If residents are willing to relocate to other areas to build their new homes, Tsai said it will take time to select a safe and suitable plot of land for reconstruction projects.

"Professional assessments and villagers' choices should be considered in addressing these problems, " Tsai said, adding that the inter-ministerial task force should come up with a report within a week.

As many civic groups have organized volunteers to help with post-disaster rehabilitation operation, Liu ordered the establishment of a platform to integrate volunteer forces to enhance operational efficiency.

The premier was also said to have directed the Ministry of National Defense to designate various units to take charge of post-disaster response assistance in specific districts in the future, a measure that is believed to facilitate gaining disaster relief experience.
"The premier also asked military authorities to organize a regular disaster response force," Tsai said.
In related developments, the Ministry of Education said 31 elementary and junio high schools will not be able to reopen in time for the start of the new school year in September.

According to the ministry, 1,305 local schools were damaged during the onslaught of the typhoon, with elementary and junior high schools taking the brunt of destruction. Financial losses from the school damage were estimated at NT$1.95 billion.
