DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Relief supplies from foreign donors continue flowing into Taiwan

TEXT.P: Post-disaster relief supplies donated by foreign countries continued flowing into Taiwan Sunday as the country digs itself out of the devastation wrought by Typhoon Morakot.

An Emirates Airlines flight arrived in Taipei early in the morning with a batch of shelter boxes donated by Britain's Shelter Box Trust, which is administered by the Helston-Lizard Rotary Club in Cornwall, disaster response officials said.

The shelter boxes, which will soon be delivered to the hardest-hit disaster zones, contain a 10-person tunnel tent, 10 sleeping bags, and accessories such as a multifuel cooker, water purifier, a spade and rope.
China Airlines, Taiwan's largest carrier, also airlifted a shipment of emergency supplies donated by Australia to Taipei early Sunday free of charge.

Richard Mathews, Australia's deputy representative in Taiwan, handed over the supplies to Lee Shih-ming, director-general of the East Asian and Pacific Affairs Department under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, in a donation ceremony held at Taoyuan International Airport in northern Taiwan.

The supplies include 200,000 water purification tablets, 5,040 large buckets for treating water and for general household use, 100 sanitizer spray packs that hold disinfectant, and repellent to spray around buildings for disease prevention.

Australian Representative to Taiwan Alice Cawte formally presented the US$168,600 worth of water purification and disinfectant supplies at the Central Emergency Operation Center in Taipei around noon Sunday to Minister of Transportation of Communications Mao Chih-kuo.
Mao, who concurrently serves as the post-disaster response commander, said Taiwan's government and people are grateful for Australia's donation.
Taiwan's Red Cross Society will help deliver the sanitation supplies to disaster zones for distribution to affected families, Mao said.

Cawte said the Australian government hopes its emergency supplies can allow local typhoon victims to enjoy clean drinking water and help combat water-borne diseases caused by Morakot-triggered flooding.

Typhoon Morakot dumped more than 2500 mm of precipitation -- the equivalent of a whole year's rainfall -- in southern Taiwan Aug. 7-9, swelling rivers that washed away bridges and spurring landslides that buried entire villages.

The storm, one of the worst natural disasters to batter Taiwan in half a century, had officially killed at least 124 people across Taiwan and left 45 injured and 56 otehrs unaccounted for as of 10 p.m. Saturday.

Those numbers do not include the potentially hundreds of people believed to have been buried in landslides in remote mountainous areas of southern Taiwan, especially in Siaolin village in Kaohsiung County.
Agricultural losses from Morakot has exceeded NT$12.24 billion (US$370.91 million) as of 9 a.m. Sunday, the second highest caused by asingle typhoon in nearly 19 years.
The amount was only second to NT$18.08 billion in agricultural losses caused by Typhoon Herb, which rattled Taiwan in August 1996.
Aquaculture losses as a result of flooding spurred by Morakot had broken all previous records to top NT$4.13 billion as of Sunday morning.

Meanwhile, 59 countries from around the world, as well as 19 international organizations and foreign civic groups have made donations to help disaster- stricken families in southern Taiwan, disaster response officials said.
As of 3 a.m. Saturday, foreign entities had donated NT$54.72 million (US$1.66 million) to the cause, according to tallies released by the Central Emergency Operation Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan team wins Pony League World Series title
DOC.DATELINE: New York-Pennsylvania, Aug. 15 (CNA) 08/16/09 16:52:55 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A team from Taitung County won the Pony League World Series championship Saturday in Washington County, Pennsylvania, the sixth Taiwanese team to win the title in the past sixteen years.
The Taitung team defeated Riverside, California, 12-1 in the title game to become the first team since 2001 to win the double elimination tournament after losing its opening game.

In the final against Riverside, Taiwan trailed 1-0 before erupting for four runs in the bottom of the third inning. Catcher Ispalidev Lanihu's bases-loaded single drove in the tying run, and Su Chih-chieh drove in two more with a single to right. Lanihu scored the fourth run on a groundout.
Taiwan put the game away in the fourth inning as Chang Yu-cheng's three-run blast and Su Chih-chieh's two-run homer keyed an eight-run rally, putting the team ahead 12-1.
Lai Ta-kuan, who relieved starter Lan Chen-wei to start the fourth inning, retired Riverside in order in the fifth, and the game was called because of the 10-run rule.
About 200 Taiwanese expatriates from Pennsylvania and Maryland were there to root for the Taitung team, composed of students from junior high schools in rural areas of the southeastern county.
Manager Wang Kuo-ching could barely hide his excitement over his team's triumph and praised his team's will and indomitable spirit to come back after losing its first game of the tournament.
Taiwan fell to Toa Baja of Puerto Rico 3-1 on Aug. 8, but then beat Bay County, Michigan, 13-9, and Johnstown, Pennsylvania, 7-3, to set up a showdown with Toa Baja.
Having to beat the Puerto Rican team twice in a row to reach the final, Taiwan defeated Toa Baja 8-3 on Aug. 13, and then 4-2 a day later on a dramatic home run by Chang Cheng-nan in extra innings.
The Pony League tournament was for players 13 and 14 years old. Unlike Little League, the Pony League is composed of two-year age brackets and different sized diamonds for different age groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. heavy-lift chopper to arrive Monday

TEXT.P: At least one U.S. heavy-lift CH-53E helicopter will arrive in Taiwan Monday to assist in relief operations in the southern part of the country, which was devastated by flooding and landslides from Typhoon Morakot, defense officials said Sunday.

"The U.S. military is now working to have its CH-53E helicopter take part in humanitarian post-disaster relief efforts in Taiwan, " said an official with the Ministry of National Defense (MND) , who spoke on condition of anonymity.

According to the official, at least one CH-53E helicopter will be delivered by an amphibious transport dock ship, also known as a landing platform dock, to waters near Taiwan from where the chopper will fly to the Tainan air base in southern Taiwan.
If all goes well, the official said, at least one CH-53E chopper will arrive in Tainan Monday at the earliest.
The official would not confirm, however, if the United States will provide one or two such heavy-lift helicopters.
"Our two sides are still in close contact to work out relevant details, " the official said, adding that the Defense Ministry will inform the public once all technical details are settled.

As the CH-53E chopper can transport a 16-ton payload, its arrival is expected to help with relief and rehabilitation work in mountainous areas that were cut off from the outside world in the storm, the official added.

Typhoon Morakot, which dumped more than 2500 mm of precipitation -- the equivalent of a whole year's rainfall -- in some parts of Taiwan Aug. 7-9, proved lethal in several remote villages that dot mountains in the southern counties of Kaohsiung and Pingtung.

A National Fire Administration official said earlier this week that Taiwan urgently needs helicopters that can carry cranes and other heavy-duty machinery into flood- and landslide-ravaged mountainous villages to help rescue those who might still be stranded.

The storm, one of the worst natural disasters to batter Taiwan in half a century, had officially killed at least 124 people across Taiwan and left 45 injured and 56 others unaccounted for as of 10 p.m. Saturday.

Those numbers do not include the potentially hundreds of people believed to have been buried in landslides in remote mountainous areas of southern Taiwan, especially in Siaolin village in Kaohsiung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. C-130 brings plastic sheeting for typhoon relief

TEXT.P: A United States military C-130 transport plane arrived Sunday at Tainan Air Force Base with a cargo of plastic sheeting to help with reconstruction efforts in the wake of Typhoon Morakot.

It marked the first time that a U.S. military transport aircraft had landed in Taiwan in the name of humanitarian aid since the United States switched political recognition from the Republic of China to the People's Republic of China in 1979.
The aircraft arrived in Tainan at 2: 50 p.m. local time and flew back to Okinawa immediately after discharging its cargo.

Christopher Kavanagh, press officer of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , told the Central News Agency that the C-130 aircraft took off from the U.S. military base in Okinawa, Japan, at noon, carrying 120 rolls, or 15,200 pounds, of plastic sheeting that can be used for temporary shelter during the reconstruction process.
We have been looking at what materials are available and what kind of services we have to commute the items Taiwan needs,Kavanagh said.
Asked when the heavy-lift helicopters that Washington has decided to send will arrive, Kavanagh said that the mission is in progress but details have yet to be confirmed.

Taiwan has been receiving humanitarian aid from countries around the world in recent days to help with disaster relief efforts after Typhoon Morakot battered Taiwan Aug. 7-9, triggering massive flooding and deadly landslides throughout southern Taiwan.

Although the official death toll from the storm stood at 124 as of 10 p.m. Saturday, hundreds more are feared to have been buried in landslides in remote mountainous villages, especially in Siaolin in Kaohsiung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: First serious swine flu case involving pregnant woman reported

TEXT.P: Pingtung County health officials reported Sunday two serious cases of swine flu, including the first such case involving a pregnant woman in Taiwan.
Health officials said that of the two patients seriously affected by the H1N1 strain of the flu, one has recovered while the other -- a 25-year-old pregnant woman -- is still in intensive care.
The officials said the woman, 24 weeks pregnant, began to cough Aug. 9. She developed a fever the following day and went to the hospital for emergency treatment.
She began to develop pneumonia Aug. 13, and was later confirmed to have been infected with the new influenza A flu strain.
Health officials said pregnant women are at the highest risk of contracting swine flu and are more likely to develop serious complications from the virus than the average patient.

They also indicated that the flu progresses faster in pregnant women and noted that the World Health Organization has suggested that pregnant women be the top priority group to be vaccinated against the flu strain.
The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) reported on Saturday that a six-year-old girl had died from the H1N1 strain, the second person in Taiwan to have died from the flu virus.

DOC.HEADLINE: More funds sought for reconstruction in typhoon-ravaged areas: MOF

TEXT.P: The government is looking to raise more funds to rebuild and rehabilitate areas in southern Taiwan that were devastated by Typhoon Morakot, a Ministry of Finance (MOF) official said Sunday.

Funding provisions for flood control, disaster prevention and reconstruction in the central government general budget and special budgets will be allocated on a priority basis to the reconstruction of typhoon-affected areas, but more is needed for a variety of uses.

Among them: a disaster-related budget; emergency loans for post-disaster rehabilitation; the Natural Disaster Aid Fund for Agriculture; subsidies for city and county governments; the secondary reserve fund; and funding for disaster preparation, the official said.
One of the possibilities being considered to raise funds, the official noted, was to sell shares in state-run enterprises at an appropriate time.

The ministry is also considering creating resources through land management strategies, such as urban land rezoning and land expropriation, and will make timely use of the general revenue sharing program to help meet the needs of local governments, the official added.

During a tour of flood-affected areas in Tainan County, Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi also said the government is planning to earmark an extraordinary budget to subsidize households that suffered flood damage to lessen the financial burden on local governments.
Under the initial plan, each household will be given NT$5,000-NT$20,000 in subsidies, with the criteria for qualification still under deliberation.
Liao said his ministry is also considering raising funds to help flood-hit households.
In a related development, the Council of Agriculture said Sunday that rice prices will remain stable in the short term thanks to a good harvest of this year's first rice crop.
According to Chen Wen-teh, the director-general of the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency, Taiwan harvested over 830,000 tons of rice in the first harvest of the season, up 7 percent year-on-year.
Along with 300,000 tons in inventory and access to imported rice, the country will have an adequate supply of rice in the short term in the wake of Typhoon Morakot.

The storm may have an impact in the longer term, however. The typhoon's onslaught coincided with the country's second rice seedling transplanting period, and the COA said it is closely monitoring any damage to the seedlings caused by the storm.

DOC.HEADLINE: President wants to establish guidelines for compulsory evacuation

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday the Ministry of the Interior should establish a compulsory evacuation system with clear guidelines that would better protect residents of areas in imminent danger of a natural disaster.
At present, there is no legal basis in Taiwan to force people to evacuate from a potential danger area. Local governments can only urge residents to abandon their homes if a disaster is foreseen.

Ma said the existing Disaster Prevention and Response Act should be updated to establish criteria that would trigger a compulsory evacuation to prevent a repeat of the loss of human life and suffering caused by Typhoon Morakot Aug. 7-9.

The president made the remarks while inspecting an ad hoc southern Taiwan disaster response command center set up in Pingtung County, one of the regions hardest-hit by Morakot-triggered flooding and landslides.

Morakot, which dumped more than 2500 mm of rainfall -- the equivalent of a whole year's precipitation -- in some parts of Taiwan, had its deadliest impact on dozens of remote villages that dot mountains in Pingtung and neighboring Kaohsiung counties.
One such village, Siaolin, was obliterated when Morakot's torrential rains sent the faces of two nearby mountains tumbling down on the village's 200 or so houses.
Hundreds of residents are feared to have been buried alive in the killer landslides, but their number may never be known because the village may not be excavated.

While many survivors in nearby villages along the Laonung River have been evacuated to safety by military rescue helicopters, a combined total of 1,000 residents in those isolated villages still refuse to be evacuated.

On mounting criticism that his administration has been slow and inefficient in post-disaster rescue and relief operations, Ma said that as the country's head of state, he is obligated to assume full responsibility.
"I will fulfill my duty to do a good job, " he pledged.

Arguing that disaster prevention should take precedence over disaster relief, Ma said county and city governments should always prioritize precaution before the onslaught of typhoons to minimize possible casualties and regularly conduct disaster response training drills to enhance operational efficiency.

Earlier in the day, Ma inspected dikes in Pingtung County's Sinyuan township, which almost burst when floodwaters swamped the Gaoping and Donggang River. Fortunately, some young residents repaired the ruptures in time.
Nevertheless, the low-lying township was still inundated by flash flooding, with floodwaters reaching 60 centimeters in most of the district.

Pingtung County Magistrate Tsao Chi-hung, who accompanied Ma on the visit, suggested that all flood prevention projects should be based on being able to last 150 years or 200 years instead of the current 100 years in order to reinforce criteria for relevant infrastructure construction.
Ma agreed that standards should be upgraded in densely populated areas or industrial zones.
The president also inspected a temporary shelter for evacuated typhoon victims set in the county's Neipu township.
Many of the 200-plus aboriginal people evacuated from the partly ruined mountainous Wutai village told Ma that they need the government's help to rebuild their hometown.

The president pledged that the central government would fully support county governments in resettling displaced typhoon victims and helping them find jobs and assisting in their children's schooling.

According to the county's magistrate, all evacuees will be resettled in two weeks, suggesting that Radio Taiwan International's houses in Pingtung County can be used to accommodate them. In the longer term, he said, prefabricated housing will be built to house all displaced victims.
Moreover, he said, the county government will hire evacuees to help with environmental cleanup tasks and other rehabilitation operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1st shipment of China-donated prefab houses to arrive Tuesday

TEXT.P: The first batch of 100 prefabricated houses donated by China is scheduled to arrive at Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan early next week to help house displaced typhoon victims, an official said Sunday.

"The prefab housing will be loaded onto a vessel at Shenzhen in southern China's Guangdong province Monday evening, and it is scheduled to arrive at Kaohsiung Harbor around noon Tuesday," said Ma Shao-chang, deputy secretary-general of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

China offered to assist in Taiwan's rehabilitation operation last week after Typhoon Morakot wreaked havoc in certain parts of the island Aug. 7-9, particularly the southern counties of Pingtung and Kaohsiung.
After an evaluation, Taiwan's government said it hoped China could provide 1,000 prefab houses to facilitate resettlement of typhoon victims.

Technical details involved in the donation are being handled by the SEF and its Chinese counterpart -- the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- both of them quasi-official intermediary bodies founded by their respective governments to handle negotiations in the absence of official ties.

Noting that assembling the prefab housing is a professional job, Ma said the Ministry of the Interior's Construction and Planning Agency (CPA) will send officials to take delivery of the cargo when the shipment arrives Tuesday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Liu Te-hsun said the CPA already informed Chinese authorities the specifications of prefab housing suitable for Taiwan. The Cabinet-level MAC oversees SEF operations.
"All the prefab hosuses will be distributed to typhoon victims in terms of their demand," said Liu.
Delivery of other relief supplies that China has offered Taiwan, including 10,000 blankets, 10,000 sleeping bags and 500 automated disinfecting machines, will come later, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12,000 servicemen help clean up flood-affected areas in Pingtung

TEXT.P: The Marine Corps mobilized 12,000 servicemen to help with post-typhoon cleanup efforts in Pingtung County Sunday in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot, which caused the most serious flooding in southern Taiwan in 50 years.

The marines provided assistance in 14 townships in the southern Taiwan county, focusing on cleaning mud and sludge from the streets and decomposing fish from fish ponds in Linbian and Jiadong townships.
The two low-lying coastal towns were seriously inundated when the typhoon passed through Taiwan Aug. 7-9. Floodwaters were about two-stories high at their peak.
An old woman from Jiadong said "thanks, young men" when she saw a group of servicemen busily cleaning out fish ponds and picking up debris from the streets.

The air was filled with the pungent smell of rotting fish, but the marines braved the foul odor to shovel out the ponds with urgency under southern Taiwan's sweltering heat. Chemical specialists followed by spraying disinfectants in the area.
The 66th Marine Brigade is in charge of the rescue and rehabilitation operation in the two townships.
Brigadier Chen Tze-fong said the military is proud to be able to pitch in to help the typhoon affected areas.

The Environmental Protection Administration is also mobilizing 3,000 people, including cleaning workers and volunteers, to help with the cleanup effort in Linbian township under the military's direction.

EPA official Chang Huan-chang said 10 villages in the township were inundated during the typhoon, and water levels had receded slowly, most likely because of blocked drainage systems, but he estimated the cleanup would be completed within three to five days.
As of Sunday, two villages -- Linbian and Chunglin -- were still submerged in water.

National Defense Minister Chen Chao-min instructed the military to clear the mud on streets in areas where floodwaters had receded within two days, according to vice chief of general staff Wu Da-peng,
who was speaking at a news conference Sunday on the military's disaster relief efforts.

The military should complete the cleaning of areas where floodwaters have receded in central Taiwan, Kaoshu in Pingtung County and Cishan in Kaohsiung County by Aug. 18; Tainan City and County by Aug. 19; and Linbian in Pingtung County by Aug. 20, Wu said.
If rescue efforts are completed in the next two days, the military will then move on to help with the next stages of resettlement and reconstruction.
Chen also requested aerial monitoring of barrier lakes in Cishan, the Laonong River area in Kaohsiung County and Taimali in Taitung County to prevent any unexpected disasters, according to Wu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 37,000 typhoon victims rescued: interior minister

TEXT.P: More than 37,000 victims stranded by floods and landslides unleashed by Typhoon Morakot have been rescued and 103 roads and bridges have been reopened since the typhoon devastated Taiwan a week ago, Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi said Sunday.
The next phase of disaster relief efforts will focus on resettling victims and reconstructing disaster ravaged areas, said Liao, who is in charge of the Southern Taiwan Disaster Relief Center.

Briefing President Ma Ying-jeou at the center in hard-hit Pingtung County, Liao said 37,366 people trapped in southern Taiwan villages have been evacuated to safety and about 45,000 cartons of relief supplies, including milk powder, instant noodles and bottled water, have been delivered to affected areas.

Liao also reported that water service had resumed to 670,287 out of 730,972 households in the counties of Pingtung, Kaohsiung, Tainan, Chiayi and Taitung that had been without water because of the typhoon, while electricity had been restored in 823,884 out of 846,784 households.
In addition, 103 of 127 damaged roads and bridges in the above mentioned counties have been repaired and opened to traffic.
Places still inaccessible by vehicles include Wutai township in Pingtung County, Namasia, Taoyuan and Maolin townships in Kaohsiung County and Alishan township in Chiayi County, Liao said.

All related agencies in the central government, in coordination with local governments, will do their utmost to expedite relief efforts and help the lives of victims return to normal as soon as possible, Liao added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government questioned over delays in typhoon relief efforts

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government was peppered with questions from the foreign media Sunday on the administration's failure to act quickly enough in organizing rescue and disaster relief operations in the wake of Typhoon Morakot.

At a news conference with Mao Chi-kuo, the commander of the Central Emergency Operation Center (CEOC), Western media and major Japanese news outlets all focused on why Taiwanese authorities seemed to respond slowly to the disaster while at the same time giving conflicting information on the death toll.

Responding to the questions on and criticism of the government's performance and its slow deployment of the military to help people stranded by the typhoon, Transportation Minister Mao said the situation was different than that faced following earthquakes and other disasters.

Heavy rainfall, along with landslides, continued in the days after the typhoon first began to affect Taiwan and resulted in damaged roads and bridges, which impeded rescue operations by the armed forces, Mao said.
Full-scale rescue operations could not begin until Aug. 10 when the weather cleared up, at which point the military dispatched personnel by land and air to affected areas, he added.

Asked whether he agrees with public criticism that the government isincompetentbased on its handling of the disaster, Mao said, "many of the criticisms were actually a chain of mixed-information and that judging from the information he received in the initial stages when the relief efforts began, the government was well informed and in control of the situation."

In terms of disaster relief, we can always do better and we understand that the typhoon victims wished we did more and much quicker. We can only humbly accept their criticism and work harder, Mao said.

The foreign media were also very concerned about the exact number of deaths in Siaolin village in the southern county of Kaohsiung, where some 380 people are feared buried under the mudslides that destroyed the village during Typhoon Morakot last week.
"The government should be responsible and very careful when it comes to death toll numbers. There is a certain procedure that we need to go through before making any announcement," Mao said.

Mao said the government is in the process of verifying the exact number of dead and will consult with the families of the villagers on whether to start digging the village out of the mud that buried it.

DOC.HEADLINE: 6.5 magnitude earthquake hits Taiwan

TEXT.P: A magnitude 6.5 earthquake struck Taiwan Monday morning as the island is still reeling from the attack of Typhoon Morakot.

The quake struck at 8:05 a.m. (0005 GMT), with an epicenter at the sea 187.7 km southeast to Hualien, 11 km underground, and was felt around the island, according to the Central Weather Bureau. No immediate reports of injuries and damage.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Monday, moving down 35.24 points at 7,034.27 on a turnover of NT$3.49 billion (US$106.29 million).
The weighted price index gained 34.55 points, or 0.49 percent, to close at 7,069.51 Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 17, or the 27th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1424: The English defeat the Scots and the French at the Battle of Verneuil during the Hundred Years' War.
1786: Davy Crockett, American frontiersman and politician, is born. He was a U.S. representative from Tennessee who joined with Texan revolutionaries fighting against Mexico. He died at the siege of the Alamo in 1836.
1892: Mae West, American comedy actress and international sex symbol known for her sultry stage persona during the 1930s, is born. She wrote most of her own stage productions and film scripts.
1896: A massive influx of prospectors to the Yukon Territory of Canada is expected after the discovery of a major gold field at Bonanza Creek on the Klondike River.
1896: The first pedestrian to be killed by a car is knocked down in Croydon, England, by a car traveling at just 6.4 kilometers per hour.
1908: The world's first animated cartoon premiers in Paris.
1943: U.S. forces under Gen. George S. Patton liberate Messina, Italy, arriving just hours ahead of Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's British Eighth Army.
1945: After the end of Japanese occupation, Indonesia declares itself a republic under the leadership of Dr. Sukarno.
1946: After ordering Chinese communist troops to start an all-out revolt against the government on Aug. 11, 1945, the communist Yenan General Headquarters issues a second mobilization order instructing all communist forces to launch a full- scale war against the Nationalists.
1960: Gabon gains independence from France.
1961: The polio vaccine developed by American researcher Albert B. Sarbin is approved for use in the United States.
1975: Europe's first particle accelerator is formally inaugurated in Geneva, Switzerland.
1976: A strong earthquake rocks Mindanao in the Philippines, killing some 8,000 people.
1982: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs issues a statement urging the United States to recognize Beijing's ambitious attempt to take over Taiwan, following the issue of the "Aug. 17 Joint Communique" by the United States and mainland China. The ministry also asks the United States to implement the Taiwan Relations Act.
1987: Rudolf Hess, Adolf Hitler's close friend and deputy leader of the Nazi party, commits suicide in his cell in Spandau Prison in West Berlin at the age of 93.
1988: Gen. Zia ul-Haq, Pakistan's iron-fisted ruler for the previous 11 years, dies at the age of 64 when his camouflaged C-130 Hercules plane crashes shortly after takeoff from Bahawalpur.
1989: An Australian airliner becomes the first commercial plane to fly nonstop from London to Sydney.
1993: The ROC and Australia sign two memoranda, one protecting industrial property rights and the second promoting investment and technical cooperation.
1995: A French supersonic jetliner completes a round-the-globe trip in 31 hours 27 minutes and 49 seconds, faster than the previous record by one hour and 20 minutes.
1995: ROC Control Yuan President Chen Li-an announces his candidacy for the 1996 presidential election, one day before renouncing his KMT membership, which he has held for 42 years.
2000: Chen Yi-song, leader of the Agriculture Technical Mission to the Republic of the Gambia, says that ROC agriculture technologists have transformed the Gambia River basin, which used to yield nothing but peanuts, into the "rice bowl of West Africa" over a period of five years.
2001: Taiwan's two major paper makers -- Yuen Foong Yu Paper and Chung Hwa Pulp -- sign a merger agreement and promise that there will be no layoffs in the new company.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you learn, but once learning a thing, you must never give it up until you have mastered it."

DOC.HEADLINE: 31 storm-damaged schools may not open for new semester: ministry

TEXT.P: Some 31 junior high and elementary schools damaged by landslides and flooding from Typhoon Morakot would probably not be able to reopen in time for the start of the new school year in September, a Ministry of Education (MOE) official said Monday.

Because of the serious damage to the schools -- located in in Nantou County in central Taiwan and in Chiayi, Kaohsiung and Pingtung in the south -- it is feared that they will not be able to resume classes in time, according to Yang Chang-yu, director of the MOE's Department of Elementary Education.
However, it is not clear exactly how many students would be affected, as many schools have lost contact with their students, Yang added.
The ministry suggested that the schools try to locate these students and that typhoon victims who have moved to other cities and counties inform the schools of their children's whereabouts.
Once home room teachers have certified such students as typhoon victims, the families would be eligible for subsidies to cover the children's tuition and lunch fees, Yang said.

A total of 1,305 schools in central and southern Taiwan were demolished or damaged by the typhoon, with accumulated losses estimated at NT$1.95 billion (US$59.45 million) . Junior high and elementary schools were hit the hardest, incurring losses in excess of NT$1.47 billion, according to MOE figures.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Strong earthquake rattles Taiwan

TEXT.P: An earthquake of magnitude 6.5 rattled Taiwan at 8:05 a.m. Monday, the strongest quake to strike the island this year, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported.
The epicenter of the quake was located 187.7 kilometers east-southeast of Hualien, at a depth of 11 kilometers below the Pacific Ocean floor, according to the CWB's Seismology Center.

The temblor was felt almost everywhere around the island. It registered an intensity of 4.0 in Orchid Island off Taitung County and an intensity of 3.0 in the eastern counties of Hualien and Yilan, as well as in the central counties of Taichung, Changhua, Nantou and Yunlin, the seismologists said.
Its intensity was measured at 2.0 in Taipei, Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Miaoli, Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung, Pingtung and Penghu counties.
No immediate injuries or damage had been reported as of 11 a.m. Monday.

Taiwan is located in a strongly oblique convergent zone between the Eurasian Plate and the Philippine Sea Plate. Underground tectonic activity in this area is responsible for 16,000 to 18,000 detectable earthquakes in Taiwan each year, about 250 of which are up to magnitude 4.0, about 30 of which measure up to 5.0 on the Reichter scale, and two to three of which are magnitude 6.0 or bigger, according to the Seismology Center.

A magnitude 6.3 quake centered off Hualien rocked the country at 2: 05 a.m. July 14, the strongest temblor to strike Taiwan in nearly two years. No major injuries or damage were reported as a result of that earthquake.
Yilan in the northeast and Hualien in the east are the most earthquake-prone counties in Taiwan.

Taiwan experienced its deadliest earthquake in five decades on Sept. 21, 1999, when a 7.3 magnitude temblor struck central Taiwan, killing some 2,400 people, leaving more than 10,000 injured, and causing immeasurable damage to property and infrastructure.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$32.97 at 10 a.m. Monday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.075 from Friday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Morakot rise to NT$12 billion

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Morakot had soared to NT$12.27 billion (US$373.27 million) as of Monday morning, according to statistics released by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).

The COA said that Morakot, which pummeled Taiwan Aug. 7-9, caused serious damage to the agricultural sector in 11 counties, with Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties in southern Taiwan and Hualien and Taitung counties in the east being the hardest hit.
The statistics show that damage to agricultural crops amounted to NT$3.99 billion, with 27 percent of the crops on 72,345 hectares of farmland wiped out.
Banana crops suffered the heaviest damage, with 5,945 hectares ravaged by strong winds and flooding.
Damage to the aquaculture sector amounted to NT$4.13 billion, the heaviest loss in 19 years, COA officials said. Stocks in some 8,845 hectares of ponds or beach farms were washed away, it said.

Some 138,000 pigs, nearly 600,000 chickens and more than 132,000 ducks perished in floods caused by the storm, bringing the total livestock losses in these three areas to NT$1.42 billion, the COA said.
Meanwhile, according to COA tallies, a total of 2,256 hectares of farmlands were either washed away or inundated, mostly in Taitung, Pingtung and Kaohsiung counties.
Farmers who suffered heavy losses can apply for cash relief or low-interest loans from the government, in accordance with the Agricultural Natural Disaster Relief Regulations, COA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. sends heavy-duty choppers to Taiwan for relief work

TEXT.P: A U.S. heavy-lift CH-53E helicopter and a U.S. military C-130 transport plane will give muscle to Taiwan's relief efforts in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot when they arrive in Taiwan Monday, defense sources said.

A U.S. heavy-lift CH-53E helicopter landed at Tainan Air Force Base in southern Taiwan at 2: 25 p.m. to join the relief operations in the southern part of the country, which was devastated by flooding and landslides from Typhoon Morakot, Hung said.
It is the first time that the U.S. military is joining humanitarian aid efforts in Taiwan since formal diplomatic relations between the two sides were severed in 1979.

The CH-53E chopper, which can transport a 16-ton payload, is expected to help with the relief and rehabilitation work in the mountainous areas that were cut off from the rest of the island in the storm.

According to Mao Chih-kuo, chief of the Central Emergency Operations Center, this helicopter is the first of four U.S. military aircraft transported by USS Denver -- an amphibious transport dock ship -- to waters near Taiwan. From there, the other three choppers will also fly to the Tainan Air Force Base to join Taiwan's relief and rehabilitation operations.

The three other U.S. military helicopters are another CH-53Es, more commonly known as the Super Stallions, and two SH-60s, which are commonly known as Seahawks, according to Christopher Kavanagh, press officer of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT).
"The four helicopters will return to USS Denver at night after their daily work on the island," said Kavanagh.

Meanwhile, A C-130 transport plane, the second in two days, landed at Tainan Air Force Base around noon Monday with a cargo of about a half ton of calcium hypochlorite tablets for water sanitization, said Hung Wen-cheng, a spokesman for the air force base.
The calcium hyphchlorite tablets will be transferred to the Centers for Disease Control under the Cabinet-level Department of Health, Hung said.
A U.S. military C-130 transport plane arrived at Tainan Air Force Base Sunday, delivering 120 rolls of plastic sheeting that can be used to build temporary shelters during the reconstruction process.
The aircraft arrived in Tainan at 2: 50 p.m. local time and flew back to Okinawa immediately after discharging its cargo.

Typhoon Morakot, which dumped more than 2500 mm of precipitation -- the equivalent of a whole year's rainfall -- on some parts of Taiwan Aug. 7-9, proved lethal in several remote villages that dot mountains in the southern counties of Kaohsiung and Pingtung.

The storm, one of the worst natural disasters to batter Taiwan in half a century, had officially killed at least 124 people across Taiwan and left 45 injured and 56 others unaccounted for as of 10 p.m. Saturday.

Those numbers do not include the potentially hundreds of people believed to have been buried in landslides in remote mountainous areas of southern Taiwan, especially in Siaolin village in Kaohsiung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Temporary job program launched to aid flood victims

TEXT.P: More than 600 people who became unemployed as a result of the flooding caused by Typhoon Morakot in southern Taiwan were offered temporary jobs Monday when the Executive Yuan launched a new employment program to aid victims in 40 townships.
Commander of the Central Emergency Operation Center Mao Chi-kuo announced that the program, originally designed to last 14 days, will be extended to Sept. 17.
Also, the number of job openings have been doubled to 220,000, he said.
According to the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) , the temporary employment program will provide 200 jobs in each of the flood-affected townships.
Each employee will be paid an hourly wage of NT$100, or NT$800 a day, to help clean up and restore flooded buildings and communities, the CLA said.
The budget for the program, estimated at NT$200 million, will be taken from the government's employment security fund, the CLA said in a statement released Monday.
Mao explained that the program was designed to help the flood victims by providing them with work opportunities, instead of just giving them money.
As soon as the initial one-month period expires, the workers will be given other employment opportunities by the CLA, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/09 16:48:23 (By Julia Chien and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Monday:
China Times:
Public donations for victims must be used for victims.
Public donations have been pouring in ever since Typhoon Morakot ravaged Taiwan Aug. 8 and 9.
This is proof of how compassionate Taiwan people are. They chip in with donations whenever there is a disaster in the world.
We urge the authorities as well as the many charities organizing fund-raising activities to ensure that every penny donated is used to help the typhoon victims.
United Daily News:
When will local bridges be able to withstand storms
Fourteen bridges on the island's major highways as well as 50 other bridges collapsed or were damaged during the onslaught of Typhoon Morakot.
It is the highest record of bridges damaged in a single storm. This high toll occurred because the designers of the bridges knew little about hydrology.
Bridge designers should not only take hydrology into consideration, but should also should bear in mind that water currents under a bridge will change during its life expectancy.
Some experts have suggested that cable-stayed bridges are better able to withstand storms, although they are more expensive to build.
Their suggestion should be considered seriously by the authorities.
Liberty Times:
A few words to Ma's incompetent administration
We would like to offer a few words of advice to President Ma Ying-jeou's administration in the hope that it will heed them and avoid other costly mistakes.
First, priority should be given to the rehabilitation of the flood victims, and this should be done quickly without any red tape.
Second, the cash donations pouring in from home and abroad should be used for the victims, and not siphoned off by shrewd politicians and officials.
Third, the rebuilding of some 70 bridges which were damaged or destroyed by Typhoon Morakot should be done quickly and properly.
Also, a scientific approach should be taken in the development of mountain areas. Apple Daily:
Taiwan' government efficiency requires further scrutiny

It is a warm and welcoming sight to see the foreign aid that is flowing into Taiwan in the aftermath of the flooding caused by Typhoon Morakot. It proves that Taiwan is not the orphan of the international society, as we tend to think.

However, the disaster has unveiled the seamy side of the Taiwan government. Its inefficiency caused a major delay of the disaster rescue and relief efforts and resulted in a massive death toll, injuries, and a shortage of relief supplies.
Above all, President Ma is the one to be blamed. His inertia after the storm was fully evident from the fact that a national security meeting was not convened until seven days later.

He also denied the need for declaring a state of emergency , not knowing that without it, the Ministry of Defense, which has the most rescue resources, could not take part in the local disaster relief efforts.

Premier Liu Chao-shiuan and Minister of Defense Chen Chao-min also share the blame. Why didn't Premier Liu contact Chen immediately after the disaster? And why didn't Minister Chen command his army to join the rescue and relief work immediately after the disaster?

Local military commanders have the authority to deploy their troops for disaster rescue and relief and notify their superiors later. However, in reality many soldiers were put on standby, being told that they had to "wait for orders."

Every year Taiwan is affected by typhoons and earthquakes, yet the government's reaction to these disasters remains sluggish and bureaucratic. It seems it is not only the disaster relief system that requires reevaluation, but also the government system.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan youth baseballers celebrate after winning Pony championship
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/17/09 17:00:46 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A team from Taiwan's eastern Taitung County that won the Pony League World Series championship Saturday celebrated their victory in New York Sunday before heading home later that day.

The players, all aged under 15 and from the Taiyuan Junior High School in Taitung, arrived in New York City Sunday from Washington County, Pennsylvania, where they competed in the 2009 Pony League Baseball World Series Aug. 7-15.

They toured several major tourist attractions around New York City before attending a dinner hosted by Liao Kang-min, Taiwan's top representative in New York. d The team defeated Riverside, California, 12-1 in the title game Saturday to become the first team since 2001 to win the double elimination tournament after losing its opening game.
Saturday's victory also marked the sixth Taiwanese team to win the title in the past 16 years.
At the dinner in honor of the young players, Liao said the Taitung students demonstrated strong will and indomitable spirit by coming back after losing their first game of the tournament.
Taiwan fell to Toa Baja of Puerto Rico 3-1 Aug. 8, but then beat Bay County, Michigan 13-9 and Johnstown, Pennsylvania 7-3, to set up a showdown with Toa Baja.
Having to beat the Puerto Rican team twice in a row to reach the final, Taiwan defeated Toa Baja 8-3 Aug. 13, and then 4-2 a day later on a dramatic home run by Chang Cheng-nan in extra innings.

Manager Wang Kuo-ching could barely contain his excitement over his team's triumph and praised his team's ability to come together after being defeated by Puerto Rico and going on to win all ensuing five games and finally the title.
The Pony League tournament is for players aged 13 and 14. Unlike Little League, the Pony League is composed of two-year age brackets and different sized diamonds for different age groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's stock prices drop below 7,000

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened low and closed even lower Monday, in line with Wall Street losses of Friday and declines in regional stock markets in Asia.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, fell 137.71 points, or 1.94 percent, to close at 6,931.80 Monday.
The local bourse opened at 7,034.27 and reached the day's high of 7,051.78. It later retreated to the day's low of 6931.80 as selling pressure emerged after the index rose above the 7,000 mark.
The market finished below 7,000 after failing to retain early gains by the end of trading.

A total of 3.54 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$95.67 billion (US$2.92 billion), which represented a more-than 20 percent decline in market volume compared with the previous trading day.

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks dropping the most at 2.8 percent. Cement shares fell 2.6 percent, banking and financial stocks dropped 2.3 percent, plastics and chemicals issues lost 2.1 percent, paper and pulp issues, as well as machinery and electronics stocks, each shed 1.9 percent, foodstuff shares dipped 1.7 percent, and construction shares dropped 1.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,786 to 523, with 121 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$6.34 billion-worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPA announces 9-day Lunar New Year break in 2010

TEXT.P: The Central Personnel Administration (CPA) has released the 2010 work calendar for government agencies, announcing a total of 112 holidays for that year, an official said Monday.
According to the calendar, the 112 days off that civil servants will be entitled to in 2010, includes a nine-day Lunar New Year vacation.

In two instances, the holidays will fall the day before or after the weekend, which means public servants will have a three-day vacation. The Republic of China Memorial Day holiday will run from Jan. 1-3, while the Tomb Sweeping Day holiday will extend from April 3-5.
The 9-day Lunar New Year holiday will begin on Feb.13 and end on Feb. 21, but public servants will be required to work one extra day on Feb. 6, according to the schedule.
Other holidays include the Dragon Boat Festival on June 16 and Moon Festival on Sept. 22.
The CPA stressed that its holiday calendar only applies to government agencies and that private enterprises should refer to the Labor Standards Act to plan their schedules.
The 2010 Governmental Agencies Holiday Overview has been posted on the CPA website at http://www.cpa.gov.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma to hold news conferences Tuesday on Typhoon Morokat

TEXT.P: President Ma will hold two press conferences, one in English and other in Chinese, Tuesday on the issue of disaster relief in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot, the Presidential Office said Monday.
The Ma administration has been bombarded with questions by the local and foreign media alike over its slow reaction and rejection of foreign aid after Typhoon Morakot hit Taiwan more than a week ago.
Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-ci said that during the news conferences Ma will explain the government's position on post-disaster rescue and relief work.

Vice President Vincent Siew, Secretary-General to the President Chan Chuen-po and two Deputy Secretary-Generals to the President Lai Feng-wei and Kao Lang will also be at the press conferences, Wang said.
The Mandarin-language press conference is scheduled to be held from 2: 30 p.m. to 3: 30 p.m., followed immediately by the English-language segment from 3:50 p.m. to 4:50 p.m., Wang said.
The president will make a short statement before taking questions from the media, and will answer every question candidly, no matter how critical they might be, Wang said.

Typhoon Morakot battered Taiwan last week with strong winds and torrential rains that led to severe flooding and mudslides in some areas of central and southern Taiwan. The death toll from the disaster had risen to at least 116 as of 10 p.m. Thursday, with 45 injured and 59 reported missing, according to the Central Emergency Operation.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU experts to arrive to help with Taiwan's disaster response

TEXT.P: The European Union is sending five disaster relief experts to help Taiwan as the country tries to dig itself out of the devastation wrought by Typhoon Morakot, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Monday.

"The team of five EU experts will arrive later in the day to assess what the 27-member organization can assist Taiwan in terms of post-disaster response operations, " said Chang Chi-ping, deputy director-general of the MOFA's Information and Cultural Department.

Chang said the EU relief specialists will visit the Central Emergency Operation Center to get an overview of the casualties and destruction caused by Morakot, one of the worst natural disasters to rattle Taiwan in half a century.
They will also travel to southern Taiwan, the hardest-hit disaster zone, to see for themselves the severity of the damage and evaluate what kind of help the EU can offer Taiwan, Chang said.

"The EU experts are expected to focus on assessing the need for assistance in water sanitizing, relief supply distribution and the selection of sites to accommodate prefabricated houses for displaced typhoon victims," Chang elaborated.

A batch of water purification tablets donated by the EU is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Aug. 21, according to Chang. He added that the goods will be delivered to the hardest-hit disaster zones upon their arrival.

Nearly 32,000 people are without clean water, according the National Fire Agency's disaster relief center. Water purification tablets are needed to ensure they do not fall ill drinking the local area's water.

Typhoon Morakot dumped nearly 3,000 mm of rain -- half a year's or two-thirds of a year's rainfall in many places in Taiwan -- in just four days from midnight Aug. 6 to 4 a.m. on Aug. 10. in certain parts of Taiwan, swelling rivers that washed away bridges and triggering landslides that buried entire villages.
The storm killed at least 126 people across Taiwan and left 45 injured and 60 others unaccounted for as of 5 p.m. Monday.

But the figure on the number of people killed does not include the nearly 400 people believed to have been buried in Siaolin Village, Kaohsiung County by a mudslide and those buried in other villages whose bodies have not yet been uncovered. The official number of missing also does not include around 100 people from Siaolin who still could not be contacted, including children who study in the cities.
President Ma Ying-jeou has said the total death toll could be more than 500.

DOC.HEADLINE: Only 15 fund-raising groups legally registered: Interior Ministry

TEXT.P: Nearly 100 groups around the country have launched fund-raising drives for relief efforts in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, but only 15 of them have been legally registered, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Monday.
Of the 15 groups, eight are officially registered with the MOI, with the other seven registered with city or county governments, according to the MOI Social Affairs Department.

The eight MOI-registered groups are World Vision Taiwan, the Child Welfare League Foundation, the United Way Taiwan, the Dharma Drum Mountain Social Welfare and Charity Foundation, the Fubon Charity Foundation, the Tzu Chi Foundation, the Ling Jiou Mountain Buddhist Foundation and the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families, the Social Affairs Department said.

The seven groups registered with local governments are the Formosa TV Foundation, the Lovely Taiwan Foundation, the Chang Yung-Fa Foundation, the Pacific Sogo Social Welfare Foundation, the TVBS Education and Welfare Foundation, the Lin Rung San Foundation of Culture and Social Welfare, and the Xiang-Shan-Xing Compassionate Foundation, according to the department.
"Fund-raising activities are considered illegal if they are conducted by organizations that are not legally registered, " a department official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Watchdog chief vows to open probe on typhoon failings

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan, Taiwan's highest watchdog body, is set to open a probe into the failings of government officials in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, one week after the initial emergency stages of the relief operation wrap up, Control Yuan President Wang Chien-shien said Monday.

"The Control Yuan will launch the investigation in one week and will come up with a report within one or two months, before it moves to correct and impeach the wrongdoings of the Executive Yuan and its ministries and subordinate agencies over any failings in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, which lashed Taiwan Aug. 6-10, " Wang told a news conference.
Wang said the Control Yuan investigation will not kick off immediately because aid and relief operations are the government's top concerns at the present stage.

Assuring the typhoon victims that "you are not alone, " Wang pledged that the Control Yuan will get to the bottom of the typhoon failings and will impeach any officials found guilty of dereliction of duty.
"An overall report on areas of Taiwan prone to the danger of flooding will also be worked out in six months," he said.

Pointing to a report on the state of national territory conducted by the Control Yuan in 2001, Wang said angrily that the government sector did not pay heed to the report, nor has it learned anything from its suggestions. "This negligence has led to today's disaster, " he added.
Control Yuan Vice President Chen Chin-li and Secretary-General Chen Feng-yi also attended the news conference.
According to Wang, Chen Chin-li has been appointed convener of an investigative ad hoc group composed of members from four Control Yuan committees.

Apart from probing dereliction of duty by government officials, the Control Yuan chief said the investigation will focus on the government's long-term land and soil conservation plans to explore why Taiwan is so prone to disaster every time a typhoon hits and delve into the question of whether mountain and slopeland areas are over-developed.
Typhoon Morakot brought torrential rain to southern Taiwan, especially Chiayi, Kaohsiung, Pingtung and Taitung counties.

Over 100 people had been reported killed and some 600 reported missing in the typhoon, including hundreds believed to have been buried under mudslides in Siaolin village in Kaohsiung County. Agricultural and farm losses totaling NT$12.27 billion (US$371.9 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: No disease outbreaks reported in flood-affected areas: official

TEXT.P: There have been no reports of epidemics in southern Taiwan areas devastated by the massive flooding from Typhoon Morakot, a senior official at the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said Monday.

CDC Deputy Director-General Lin Ting made the announcement after visiting flood- affected regions. He said most of the sick in the affected areas are suffering from either gastrointestinal diseases, common infections of the upper respiratory tract, or skin problems due to poor hygiene in the wake of the flooding.
There have been no reports from affected areas of group infections of influenza A(H1N1) or other communicable diseases, he added.
However, Lin noted an increase in the number of patients seeking treatment for chronic diseases at the provisional medical stations set up for the typhoon victims.
According to Lin, there are no shortages of drug supplies at the medical stations, as most of them are operated by regional medical centers.
Lin's assertion, however, was criticized by Lu Chung-chien, a physician at the National Taiwan University Hospital emergency treatment division.

Lu, stationed in the disaster-affected Tawu township in Taitung County where he is providing free treatment to flood victims under the auspices of the Taiwanroot Medical Peace Crops (TRMPC), told CNA that many chronic disease sufferers fled their homes without bringing their medicine with them.
Some of them, suffering in the shelters from lack of sleep and nutrition, have been unable to get proper treatment at the medical stations because they lack the drugs they require.

Meanwhile, TRMPC-affiliated pharmacist Wu Ming-huei complained that the southern rescue headquarters do not know about either what kinds of medicine for chronic disease sufferers are needed in the flood-battered areas, or where the medical supplies should be sent.
"TRMPC has packed enough medication for 2,000 chronic patients, but does not know where to ship the supplies to," Wu said.

She pointed out that despite a great quantity of donations of medical supplies from local drug manufacturers and foreign countries, the supplies are either stockpiled in warehouses because there are no pharmacists available who can sort them out, or shipped to places where they are not needed.
Wu expressed concern over wastage due to the short shelf life of many of the drugs.

Rebutting this complaint, officials of the Department of Health Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs said the National Cheng Kung University Hospital in Tainan City has been assisting in the distribution of supplies.
The officials urged those intending to donate drugs for flood victims to register with the bureau, which will distribute the supplies to the places most in need.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA news budget for Aug. 17

TEXT.P: subsidy of NT$2,000 per month 15. Canada and more other countries extend relief aid 16. U.S. heavy-duty choppers to start work Tuesday 17. Cluster infection of 400 new H1N1 flu patients

DOC.HEADLINE: Foundation to subsidize those who accommodate young typhoon victims

TEXT.P: With many young children affected by the devastation wrought by Typhoon Morakot in southern Taiwan, a children's welfare foundation said Monday that it will subsidize relatives and friends who provide short-term homestays for children who have lost their homes.

Miguel Wang, executive director of the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF), said that for each child under their care, the relatives or friends will receive a subsidy of NT$2,000 per month, for a period of up to six months.
He noted that at present, the typhoon victims are staying in makeshift shelters or are living with relatives or friends.
However, he went on, the makeshift shelters are not the most ideal of places for young children and moving in with relatives or friends is a better option for them.

Aware and concerned about the possible economic pressure on such host families as a result of having extra mouths to feed, the foundation decided to subsidize such relatives and friends willing to "care for and accommodate the young victims so that they can return to normal life soon," Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. heavy-lift choppers to go into service Tuesday

TEXT.P: Air force sources said Monday that four U.S. heavy-lift helicopters will begin to transport heavy-duty machinery into disaster zones Tuesday to help mountainous areas in southern Taiwan dig themselves out of the rubble left by Typhoon Morakot.

Two MH-53Es and two SH-60 Seahawks are scheduled to arrive at the Tainan air base early Tuesday, where they will prepare to airlift excavators and other equipment into disaster zones cut off by landslides and flooding, said Hung Wen- cheng, a spokesman for the air base.
An MH-53E and SH-60 will first embark on trial flights to scan the flight routes shortly after their arrival, Hung said.
The four helicopters were transported by the USS Denver, an amphibious transport dock ship, to waters near Taiwan from a U.S. naval base in Okinawa, Japan, Monday.

The long line extended more than two kilometers and crossed the riverbed of the Jhuokou River, where the Dajin Bridge once stood.

Maolin township became isolated after the bridge, which connected Maolin in Kaohsiung County and Kaoshu township in Pingtung County, was destroyed by flooding and mudslides brought about by Morakot Aug. 6-10.

The military deployed the troops on the labor-intensive food delivery mission after discovering it was difficult to install Bailey bridges in places on both sides of the mountain leading to Maolin where existing bridges collapsed.
The first batch of foodstuffs and other materials were transported by three big trucks to the main gate of the Maolin National Scenic Area at 11 a.m.
The troops immediately began delivering the supplies by hand and completed the task in just over an hour.

DOC.HEADLINE: Relief and rescue efforts continue in worst-hit areas by flood

DOC.HEADLINE: Military hit with single largest cluster infection in Taiwan

The cluster infection came to light Aug. 10 when a spate of servicemen began to develop fevers, coughs, sore throats and aches.
The barrack notified the health authority the following day and an epidemic investigation was conducted immediately.
The 1922 hot line provided by the CDC for reporting the epidemic has since been swamped with calls by family members of the servicemen, many of whom protested that they could not visit them.

The number of serious case increased to 25, and among them, three are still in intensive care.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign aid continues pouring into Taiwan

TEXT.P: Canada will donate 50,000 Canadian dollars (US$45,454.55) to help with Taiwan's post-typhoon relief efforts, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said in a statement Monday.
The Canadian representative to Taiwan, Ronald Macintosh, will deliver the money contributed by the Canadian government to Taiwan's Red Cross Society Tuesday, the statement said.

Staff members of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei have also chipped in to help those affected by Typhoon Morakot, donating a total of NT$67,300 (US$2,039.39), which will also be delivered to the Red Cross Society.
Meanwhile, the Canadian government will also donate 200,000 water purification tablets for use in disaster zones, which were battered by Morakot-triggered deluge and landslides, the statement said.

Nearly 32,000 people are without clean water, according to the National Fire Agency's disaster relief center. Water purification tablets are needed to ensure they do not fall ill drinking the local area's water.
Several other countries, including Australia, the United States and the European Union, have also donated such tablets to Taiwan.
On Monday, four EU disaster relief experts arrived in Taiwan to assess how Europe can assist Taiwan's post-disaster response operations.
The four EU experts, led by Roger Valberg of Sweden, will stay in Taiwan for 10 to 12 days to help with relief efforts, MOFA officials said.
A fifth member of the EU team will arrive in the next few days to join the relief operations, the officials said.
Meanwhile, a batch of disaster relief supplies, including 250 blankets, 42 sleeping bags and 32 tents, donated by Germany's civic group Aviation Without Borders will be delivered to Taiwan Tuesday.
The Aviation Without Borders is the German branch of the European family of aviation charities.
China Airlines, Taiwan's largest carrier, will airlift the goods to Taiwan from Germany free of charge, MOFA officials said.

At least 59 countries from around the world, as well as 19 international organizations and foreign civic groups have made donations to help disaster- stricken families in southern Taiwan, disaster response officials said.
As of 3 a.m. Saturday, foreign entities had donated NT$54.72 million (US$1.66 million) to the cause, according to tallies released by the Central Emergency Operation Center.

Typhoon Morakot dumped nearly 3,000 mm of rain in just four days from midnight Aug. 6 to 4 a.m. on Aug. 10. in certain parts of Taiwan, swelling rivers that washed away bridges and triggering landslides that buried entire villages.
The storm killed at least 126 people across Taiwan and left 45 injured and 60 others unaccounted for as of 5 p.m. Monday.

But the official death toll does not include the nearly 400 people believed to have been buried in Siaolin Village, Kaohsiung County, by a mudslide and those buried in other villages whose bodies have not yet been uncovered.
President Ma Ying-jeou has said the total death toll could be more than 500.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA announces new plan to offer more extensive aid to farmers

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Chen Wu-hsiung announced Monday that the council will unveil a NT$2 billion (US$60 million) plan Tuesday to help certain farmers and fishermen who sustained losses in Typhoon Morakot.
Speaking at a news conference, Chen said the new measures were devised mainly to assist farmers and fishermen who might otherwise not qualify for subsidies under existing regulations.

"The council will put forward the additional measures to help some farmers and fishermen who, due to land, property, or business ownership registration problems, might not be eligible to apply for existing government subsidies," Chen said.
The new plan could cover an estimated 25,000 farmers and fishermen and will be effective from Aug. 18- 31, he said.

Farmers will be subsidized NT$16,000 for each hectare of damaged rice paddies and NT$60,000 for each hectare of damaged orchards. Hog raisers will also be given NT$500 for each pig that they lost in the typhoon.

The new measures will be implemented in 14 cities and counties that have already been proclaimed by the COA as natural disaster areas qualifying for financial aid in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, which lashed Taiwan Aug. 6-10.
The 14 cities and counties are Kaohsiung, Hualien, Pingtung, Taitung, Tainan, Yunlin, Chiayi, Changhua, Taichung, Nantou, Miaoli and Penghu counties, as well as Tainan and Chiayi cities.

Farmers and fishermen who sustained serious losses but who do not live in the above mentioned localities are also entitled to the new measures as long as local governments and COA officials jointly verify their losses on the spot.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top brass mulling cancellation of National Day activities

TEXT.P: With Taiwan preoccupied with relief efforts in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakat, top government officials are considering whether to cancel all activities related to the National Day celebrations, government sources said Monday.

The sources said that at a regular Monday meeting of five officials, including President Ma Ying-jeou and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, the participants agreed that typhoon relief work should take precedence over everything else given the number of casualties and tremendous property losses suffered in the storm.

An organizing committee for the National Day celebrations will convene a provisional meeting Aug. 19.
The sources said that if there is a consensus that the National Day celebrations should be canceled, then it will still need the confirmation of the committee meeting Wednesday.
The storm killed at least 126 people across Taiwan and left 45 injured and 60 others unaccounted for as of 5 p.m. Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shifts U.N. bid strategy, targets specialized agencies
