According to the county government, the 17 cut-off villages include 11 in Alishan township, one in Dapu township, two in Jhuci township, two in Fanlu township and one in Meishan township.

The townships are all situated in the Alishan area, which received nearly 3,000 mm of rain during the typhoon. The massive amount of precipitation, more than usually falls in an entire year, created huge torrents of water that flooded riverbanks.

The rainfall also precipitated massive landslides, destroying the mountain roads and bridges that connect the villages with the outside world, and the military has began work to repair them, the Chiayi County government said.

Meanwhile, Hsinchu City Mayor Lin Junq-tzer said his administration will directly contact authorities of the typhoon-devastated townships in southern Taiwan, voluntarily offering its assistance in post-disaster restoration.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military hit with single largest cluster infection in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Nearly 400 alternative military servicemen in a military barrack in central Taiwan have shown influenza-like symptoms in the single largest cluster infection in Taiwan, the Department of Health (DOH) reported Monday.
Lin Ting, deputy director-general of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control (CDC) , said 374 out of 2,700 servicemen have developed influenza symptoms.
As of noon Monday, 81 had been tested positive for influenza A, and laboratory screening confirmed some to have the H1N1 flu strain and others the seasonal H3 strain.
"The patients are all mild cases and are being treated with Tamiflu," Lin said.
"The CDC cannot rule out the possibility that the trainees have been infected with the new flu, and we will also not rule out the possibility of more cases," he added.
Lin said that the men were participating in three weeks of basic training due to end Aug. 24.
Leaves and family visits have been suspended because of the cluster infection, Lin said, but it will not affect the dispatching of new trainees to the military.
The cluster infection came to light Aug. 10 when a spate of servicemen began to develop fevers, coughs, sore throats and aches.
The barrack notified the health authority the following day and an epidemic investigation was conducted immediately.
The 1922 hot line provided by the CDC for reporting the epidemic has since been swamped with calls by family members of the servicemen, many of whom protested that they could not visit them.
The CDC estimated that there were an additional 9,000 new flu cases through community infection over the past week.
The number of serious case increased to 25, and among them, three are still in intensive care.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign aid continues pouring into Taiwan

TEXT.P: Canada will donate 50,000 Canadian dollars (US$45,454.55) to help with Taiwan's post-typhoon relief efforts, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said in a statement Monday.
The Canadian representative to Taiwan, Ronald Macintosh, will deliver the money contributed by the Canadian government to Taiwan's Red Cross Society Tuesday, the statement said.

Staff members of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei have also chipped in to help those affected by Typhoon Morakot, donating a total of NT$67,300 (US$2,039.39), which will also be delivered to the Red Cross Society.
Meanwhile, the Canadian government will also donate 200,000 water purification tablets for use in disaster zones, which were battered by Morakot-triggered deluge and landslides, the statement said.

Nearly 32,000 people are without clean water, according to the National Fire Agency's disaster relief center. Water purification tablets are needed to ensure they do not fall ill drinking the local area's water.
Several other countries, including Australia, the United States and the European Union, have also donated such tablets to Taiwan.
On Monday, four EU disaster relief experts arrived in Taiwan to assess how Europe can assist Taiwan's post-disaster response operations.
The four EU experts, led by Roger Valberg of Sweden, will stay in Taiwan for 10 to 12 days to help with relief efforts, MOFA officials said.
A fifth member of the EU team will arrive in the next few days to join the relief operations, the officials said.
Meanwhile, a batch of disaster relief supplies, including 250 blankets, 42 sleeping bags and 32 tents, donated by Germany's civic group Aviation Without Borders will be delivered to Taiwan Tuesday.
The Aviation Without Borders is the German branch of the European family of aviation charities.
China Airlines, Taiwan's largest carrier, will airlift the goods to Taiwan from Germany free of charge, MOFA officials said.

At least 59 countries from around the world, as well as 19 international organizations and foreign civic groups have made donations to help disaster- stricken families in southern Taiwan, disaster response officials said.
As of 3 a.m. Saturday, foreign entities had donated NT$54.72 million (US$1.66 million) to the cause, according to tallies released by the Central Emergency Operation Center.

Typhoon Morakot dumped nearly 3,000 mm of rain in just four days from midnight Aug. 6 to 4 a.m. on Aug. 10. in certain parts of Taiwan, swelling rivers that washed away bridges and triggering landslides that buried entire villages.
The storm killed at least 126 people across Taiwan and left 45 injured and 60 others unaccounted for as of 5 p.m. Monday.

But the official death toll does not include the nearly 400 people believed to have been buried in Siaolin Village, Kaohsiung County, by a mudslide and those buried in other villages whose bodies have not yet been uncovered.
President Ma Ying-jeou has said the total death toll could be more than 500.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shifts U.N. bid strategy, targets specialized agencies

TEXT.P: A senior Taiwanese diplomatic official argued Monday that the government has not given up its bid for representation in the United Nations despite its inaction to launch a new campaign by the U.N. deadline this year.
"The inaction marks a significant change in our strategy to take part in U.N. activities," said the official who spoke on condition of anonymity.

"We will focus on securing seats in selected U.N. specialized organizations, " the official said, adding that the government will brief the public and international society on its ultimate goal and changing strategy later.
"The content of our new U.N. bid will be finalized and unveiled this week," he elaborated.

Since 1993, Taiwan had annually asked its diplomatic allies to come up with a proposal asking the U.N. Steering Committee to include Taiwan's membership bid on the agenda of the annual session of the U.N. General Assembly.
Although the annual bid never succeeded due to China's vocal opposition, it represented the government's determination to upgrade Taiwan's international profile.
According to U.N. regulations, Taiwan's membership bid should be filed with the U.N. Secretariat one month before the opening of the annual session of the General Assembly.

This year's General Assembly session is scheduled to open Sept. 15 in New York, but Taiwan's government did not ask any diplomatic ally to present the membership bid proposal to the U.N. Secretariat before Aug. 15 as it had in the past.
"The inaction indicates that the government had no intention to come up with such a proposal this time around," said the official.
He stressed, however, that the inaction should not be interpreted as abandoning the U.N. bid.
"We will never forgo our goal of seeking meaningful participation in U.N. activities in a pragmatic manner," the official said.

Since President Ma Ying-jeou assumed office, his administration has pursued a flexible diplomatic strategy to halt a diplomatic tug-of-war with China in luring diplomatic allies with lucrative financial aid.

"Although this strategy has been effective in helping us consolidate relations with our existing diplomatic allies, it doesn't mean we'll have a smooth ride in pursuing representation in major international organizations, " the official said.

With China's tacit agreement, Taiwan managed to attend this year's World Health Assembly -- the decision-making body of the World Health Organization -- in May as an observer under the designation of Chinese Taipei.

The official said the government will follow the similiar pragmatic strategy in seeking representation in selected U.N. specialized agencies that major foreign countries will support and will serve Taiwan's major national interests.
Thsoe organizations may include in the International Civil Aviation Organization and the International Maritime Organization, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 18, or the 28th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1227: The Mongol ruler Genghis Khan, who through conquest created a vast empire that extended from the Pacific to the Dnieper River, dies after falling from his horse. He was 65.
1503: Pope Alexander VI, originally Rodrigo Borgia, Spanish-born pontiff since 1492, dies in Rome at the age of 72 after succumbing to a fever. He was noted as a patron of the arts and for his corrupt papacy.
1759: The British led by Adm. Boscowen defeat a French fleet at Lagos, Portugal.
1825: Scottish explorer Alexander Gordon Laing becomes the first European to reach Timbuktu, located in present-day Mali.
1830: Franz-Joseph I, the Austro-Hungarian emperor who invaded Serbia and helped initiate World War 1, is born.
1917: Casper Weinberger, American statesman and secretary of defense for President Ronald Reagan, is born.
1932: Scottish aviator Jim Mollison makes the first westbound transatlantic solo flight, from Portmarnock, Ireland, to Pennfield, New Brunswick.
1945: Henry Pu Yi steps down as emperor of Manchukuo, a puppet regime installed in China by the Japanese in 1932. He was nabbed by Russian troops two days later.
1946: Albert Einstein, German-born American theoretical physicist, declares that he had written a memo to President Franklin D. Roosevelt asking the president not to use the atomic bomb against Japan.
1966: Some one million Red Guards hold a huge demonstration in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in celebration of the "great proletarian cultural revolution" launched by Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Zedong.
1974: Taiwan baseball teams for the first time win the Little League, Senior League and Big League world titles in the same year.
1984: South Africa is banned from taking part in the Olympic Games because of its policy of apartheid.
1985: A ship sinks near Harbin in northeastern China, leaving 171 people dead or missing.
1987: Terrorists throw grenades into the Congress of Sri Lanka, killing two people and injuring 16 others, including Prime Minister Ranasinghe Premadasa.
1988: The Mainland Affairs Task Force is established under the Republic of China Executive Yuan.
1989: Colombian presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan is assassinated. The Colombian government takes immediate action by launching a nationwide crackdown on drug dealers.
1991: Vice President Li Yuan-zu of the Republic of China leaves for a state visit to Costa Rica, Nicaragua and Honduras and to attend the 23rd Plenary Meeting of the World League for Freedom and Democracy in San Jose, Costa Rica.
1992: The Department of Anti-Corruption is established under the ROC Ministry of Justice.
1994: An earthquake rocks the Mascara region of western Algeria, killing more than 120 people.
1995: A referendum is held in Bermuda, with 73 percent of the voters in the British dependency voting against independence.
1997: Typhoon Winnie hits Taiwan, killing some 40 people and injuring 81 others.
2000: The Paraguayan embassy in Taipei requests that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs lift an import ban on beef from Paraguay, saying that there have been no cases of foot-and-mouth disease reported among the country's livestock.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you inquire into, but when you inquire into a thing, you must never give it up until you have thoroughly understood it."

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH closely monitors epidemic situations in flood-affected areas

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) is closely monitoring the potential spread of disease in southern Taiwan areas devastated by flooding from Typhoon Morakot, a senior official with the DOH's Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said Monday.

CDC Deputy Director-General Lin Ting said that although there have been no reports from affected areas of group infections of influenza A (H1N1) or other diseases, the CDC will still closely monitor the situation there, as 10,000 new cases of the H1N1 flu strain were reported in the past week around Taiwan.
Lin said the CDC has also prepared 23,000 doses of tetanus boosters to prevent wounded disaster victims and relief workers in flood-affected areas from getting lockjaw.

Lin made the remarks after visiting flood-affected regions Monday. He said most ailing people in the disaster areas are suffering from either gastrointestinal diseases, infections of the upper respiratory tract, or skin problems due to poor hygiene in the wake of the flooding.

Meanwhile, he said, the CDC will assess whether to include victims from the flood-affected areas on the priority list of people entitled to receive influenza A (H1N1) vaccines. The list currently includes pregnant women and medical personnel.

Concerns that the flu is becoming more widespread in Taiwan have mounted after 400 alternative military servicemen in a military barrack in central Taiwan showed flu-like symptoms recently in the single largest cluster infection in the country to date.
As of noon Monday, according to Lin, 81 had been tested positive for influenza A, and laboratory screening confirmed some to have the H1N1 flu strain and others the seasonal H3 strain.
"The patients are all mild cases and are being treated with Tamiflu," Lin said.

In related news, five junior high school students from Hsinchu were tested positive for the H1N1 flu strain Monday in South Korea. They have been put under observation by Korean health authorities until Aug. 23.

The five students were among 150 students and teachers from two Hsinchu junior high schools who were on a performance tour on Jeju Island. They were originally scheduled to conclude their trip Aug. 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: Deputy foreign minister offers to step down

TEXT.P: Deputy Foreign Minister Andrew Hsia has offered to step down to take responsibility for declining international assistance in the early days after Typhoon Morakot struck, Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou said Tuesday.
"Premier Liu Chao-shiuan has not yet made any decision on Hsia's resignation, " Ou said, noting that he referred a letter of resignation submitted by Hsia to the premier Monday.
According to Ou, the premier asked him to first decide whether to accept Hsia's resignation or not, a decision Ou said would be painful but one he would make soon.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs apologized Aug. 14 for telling its overseas representative offices to politely decline international assistance such as supplies and rescuers in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, describing it as a technical error made out of negligence.

The Foreign Ministry issued instructions Aug. 11 to all MOFA's foreign representative offices to politely decline offers by host governments to provide assistance in dealing with the massive flooding and landslides in southern Taiwan triggered by the typhoon Aug. 7-9.

"It was a technical error in that we did not make clear that it should have read 'temporarily' decline international assistance. If such negligence has caused any bad public perception, I solemnly apologize to the public on behalf of the ministry, " Hsia said that day.
"As the acting foreign minister, I will take full responsibility and accept any disciplinary action, " Hsia said. Ou was out of the country attending a meeting.
Hsia also noted that neither the Presidential Office nor the Executive Yuan were aware of the telegram.
The Foreign Ministry has been lambasted by the media over the past few days for declining offers of foreign assistance in the wake of Morakot.
The United States, Japan, Singapore and other countries have made donations and have expressed willingness to provide additional assistance.
The MOFA said in its own defense that it was waiting for the Central Disaster Emergency Operation Center to clarify the needs of victims and rescuers before approaching the international community.

The central government later released a list of items that Taiwan needs from the international community for its rescue and relief operations, including specialized helicopters capable of transporting very heavy payloads, and sanitation supplies.

DOC.HEADLINE: New storm forms over West Pacific, may not pose threat to Taiwan

TEXT.P: A tropical depression that has turned into a tropical storm over the West Pacific early Tuesday morning may not pose a direct threat to Taiwan, Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Tuesday.

According to the CWB, as of 8 a.m., tropical storm Vamco was located some 1,000 kilometers southwest of Wake Island or more than 4,000 kilometers east of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Eluanbi, moving in a north-northwesterly direction at a speed of 16 kilometers per hour.
Although it is unlikely the storm will hit Taiwan, CWB meteorologists said they will still closely monitor the storm, given that the system's course or strength could change in the following days.

Meanwhile the hot weather in Taiwan will persist Tuesday, with temperatures expected to reach 35 degrees Celsius in northern Taiwan, 34 degrees in central and southern Taiwan and 33 degrees in the eastern part of the island, the CWB said.

DOC.HEADLINE: More foreign aid flowing in for typhoon relief

TEXT.P: Thailand and the Philippines made contributions Tuesday to help with Taiwan's post-typhoon relief efforts, donating NT$1,165,000 (US$35,000) and NT$2 million, respectively, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

Arbhorn Manasvanich, the executive director of the Taipei-based Thailand Trade and Economic Office, presented the Thai government's donation of NT$1 million along with NT$165,000 contributed by Thai citizens to Matthew Lee, director- general of the MOFA's Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, at a press briefing.
Manasvanich said that the money shows Thailand's heartfelt condolences and sympathy for Taiwan's people, and she hoped it would help relieve their suffering.
We hope that the government and people of Taiwan will be successful in the reconstruction and rehabilitation process, " Manasvanich said.
Lee said countries in the Asia-Pacific region have all expressed deep concern for the scale of the destruction caused by Typhoon Morakot, which devastated southern Taiwan Aug. 7-9.
In addition to Australia, Singapore, South Korea, Thailand and other countries, the Philippines also donated NT$2 million the same day in the wake of the natural disaster, Lee said.

As of Tuesday, at least 72 countries from around the world, as well as 16 international organizations, have donated a total of NT$95 million to help disaster-stricken families in southern Taiwan, according to the latest rallies released by the foreign ministry.

A five-member team from the European Union, who arrived in the country the previous day, are scheduled to visit the Central Emergency Operations Center, Vice Foreign Minister David Lin and the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, to develop an understanding of current relief operations, according to the MOFA.
The EU team will leave for southern Taiwan Aug. 19 to join the relief operations and stay for 10-12 days to assess disaster relief needs.
Meanwhile, a batch of disaster relief supplies, including 250 blankets, 42 sleeping bags and 32 tents donated by Germany's civic group Aviation Without Borders, arrived in Taiwan earlier Tuesday.

Typhoon Morakot dumped nearly 3,000 mm of rain in just four days from midnight Aug. 6 to 4 a.m. on Aug. 10. in certain parts of Taiwan, swelling rivers that washed away bridges and triggering landslides that buried entire villages.
As of 8: 30 a.m. Tuesday, the storm has killed at least 127 people across Taiwan and left 45 injured and 307 others unaccounted for.

DOC.HEADLINE: Employers reveal what they're looking for in online survey

TEXT.P: Experience, educational background, and professional skills are the qualities employers are looking for in resumes, and 89 percent of them also expect a concise biography with the resume, according to a survey conducted by a local employment agency.

The employers responding to the 1111 Human Resources Bank survey said a resume must make it through an average of three different internal checks before an interview is scheduled and at least two interviews are needed for applicants to get jobs.
As for other parts of the job application process, the four main qualities expected to be reflected in a biography are experience, past achievements, ambition and character.
In an interview, employers are looking for an ability to get along with others, proper manners, verbal communication skills and interaction with the interviewer.
The survey also found that companies want people to be able to work alone, communicate well with others, and have quick reactions.
Sixty percent of respondents said they give written tests during interviews that mainly focus on professional knowledge, adaptive tests, and linguistic ability.
Wu Rui-ying, the deputy general manager of the online employment agency, cautioned job seekers that applying for jobs is not like winning a lottery.

Sending resumes out randomly will not increase the odds of getting an interview, much less a job. The only way to get hired is to fully understand how companies recruit and the positions they need to fill.

Although survey respondents said experience and professional achievements should be part of an applicant's biography, Wu said a biography should be concise and only address points that were not detailed in the applicant's resume, such as character or special talents or experience.
The biography should also include an analysis of the applicant's strengths and weaknesses and why the applicant is able to handle the job, revealing his or her desire to be hired.
The survey of human resource centers and managers of companies using the online hiring firm was conducted between July 31 and Aug. 13. A total of 540 valid responses were collected.

DOC.HEADLINE: Eight Taiwanese contract A(H1N1) flu in South Korea
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, South Korea, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/09 14:43:18 (By Chiang Yuan-chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Eight Taiwanese wind musicians who are attending an international music festival in Jeju Island, tested positive for the A(H1N1) flu virus Monday, South Korean health authorities said Tuesday.
Six other Taiwanese wind instrument players were put under observation Monday after they developed high fever, the authorities said.

Five Malaysians who were also attending the 2009 International Wind Instrument Festival in Jeju Island, were the first participants to test positive for the A(H1N1) flu strain Sunday, according to the South Korean health authorities.
Nearly 2,000 people from nine countries are attending the international wind instrument festival -- one of the major summer festivals in Jeju -- from Aug. 12-20.
According to the Korean health authorities, 47 new cases of the new swine flu were confirmed Monday, bringing the total number of A(H1N1) flu infections in South Korea to 2,212.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Japan offers more disaster relief aid to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/09 16:39:03 (By Yang Ming-chu & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Japan has decided to give more disaster relief aid to Taiwan following its donation of 10 million yen last week, its Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Monday.

The Japan government will offer Taiwan additional aid amounting to 100 million yen (NT$35 million or US$1.06 million) for urgent relief work, given that the death toll and damage from Typhoon Morakot have escalated, the ministry said.
Some 50 million yen will be donated in the form of cash, and the rest will be given for disaster relief supplies and other needs, according to the ministry.
It also said that the Japan International Cooperation Agency will sent a team to the typhoon-affected areas of Taiwan Tuesday to assess how best Japan can help the victims.
Based on the team's report, Tokyo will decide what kind of relief supplies it should send to Taiwan, according to the ministry.

Japan was the first country in the world to donate money to Taiwan in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot which struck on Aug. 7-9, triggering massive flooding and landslides, killing hundreds of people and destroying numerous homes and other structures.
The damage caused by the typhoon is estimated at nearly NT$100 billion, according to Taiwan President Ma Ying-jeou.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fire Dept. chief collapses at emergency operation center

TEXT.P: The head of the National Fire Administration (NFA) collapsed at the Central Emergency Operation Center around noon Tuesday, apparently because of fatigue and work pressure.

According to NFA officials, Huang Chi-min fainted at the emergency operation center immediately after being briefed on the latest developments in the post- disaster relief work in southern Taiwan, where Typhoon Morakot from Aug. 7-9 caused the worst flooding in half a century in Taiwan.
Medical personnel at the NFA tried to resuscitate Huang after he fell unconscious to the floor and began foaming at the mouth.
He was soon whisked away to West Garden Hospital in Taipei City's Wanhua District for treatment.

According to NFA officials, Huang had been working at the Central Emergency Operation Center almost around-the-clock since Aug. 5 when the Central Weather Bureau issued a land warning for Typhoon Morakot.
They said Huang had not gone home since Aug. 5 and had been sleeping at the center for about two to three hours day.
According to West Garden Hospital, Huang's condition is not life-threatening and he has regained consciousness.
Because Huang struck his head on the floor when he fell, further examination will be required to determine whether he collapsed because of fatigue or some other condition, the hospital said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's stock prices plunge below 6,800

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices plunged for the second consecutive day Tuesday, after major U.S. stock indices on Monday fell the steepest in six weeks amid uncertainty over the sustainability of the recent economic gains.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, fell 142.03 points, or 2.04 percent, to close Tuesday at 6,789.77, after shedding 137.71 points the previous day.
The local market added 176 points last week.

In line with weakness in regional markets, the local bourse opened low at 6,843.27 before reaching the day's high of 6,904.64. It later retreated to the day's low of 6746.30 following the emergence of selling pressure.
A total of 4.10 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$106.67 billion (US$3.24 billion), an increase of NT$11 billion compared with the previous trading day.

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp stocks dropping the most at 5 percent. Textile shares and construction issues each fell 3.1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares shed 2.7 percent, banking and financial stocks dropped 2.1 percent, cement issues as well as machinery and electronics stocks each shed 2 percent, and foodstuff shares dipped 0.8 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 2,105 to 350, with 96 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$4.08 billion worth of shares.
Due to the impact of Typhoon Morakot, tourism issues led the market decline, dropping 4.4 percent at one point during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, falling NT$0.021 to close at NT$32.964.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$33.020 and dropped to the day's low of NT$32.925.

DOC.HEADLINE: Charities get aid to disaster victims faster than government

TEXT.P: Ten days have passed since Typhoon Morakot unleashed massive floods and lethal landslides in southern Taiwan, but the government has made little progress in distributing cash subsidies to families who lost loved ones in the disaster.

Soon after the severe flooding, the government promised that families whose loved ones have died or gone missing due to the natural disaster would receive NT$1 million (US$30,488) per casualty in condolence money.
To date, however, only 35 families have received the money because of the complicated procedures applicants must follow in applying for the money.
Death certificates and the IDs of the deceased relatives of the are required as part of the application process, but many documents were flushed away by the flooding and are simply not available.

This bureaucratic approach to disaster relief has disappointed many flood victims and drawn criticism, but charitable organizations are temporarily filling the void by distributing aid to individuals left homeless.

Responding to the government's appeals for help, the Red Cross Foundation started to pass out subsidies of NT$5,000 per person Monday, according to lists from emergency placement centers, and planned to support 5,400 people in three days.
In the past, the Red Cross usually handed out subsidies to each household but this was the first time that subsidies were passed out to individuals.

The Buddhist Tzu Chi Foundation has also been effective in distributing financial aid, passing out subsidies of NT$5,000 to NT$10,000 beginning the day after the floods according to lists obtained from township offices.
Some 22,000 households have received the subsidy to date.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Tuesday:
China Times:
Golden 72 hours lost
President Ma Ying-jeou has recovered a little since his poor response to the storm flood caused an uproar in the early stages of the ongoing relief operations.
His initial inadequate response sprung from the following flaws in his character:
First, he lacks a sense of empathy. He cannot identify with the feelings of others, and he cannot hide this flaw.
Second, he doesn't have the backbone to make quick and firm decisions. This was demonstrated by his refusal to declare a state of emergency.
He convened a meeting of the National Security Council four days after the crisis, when things were getting out of control, and he came up with only some trivial decisions.
In the face of disaster, the head of state should be able to take extraordinary action to lead the country out of crisis rather than stick to the legal framework and system.
Being meticulous about procedural details is an appropriate approach for other officials, but not for a head of state.
After the disaster, Ma had 72 hours to show his leadership, but he squandered that time and there is no way to recover it now.
Liberty Times:
What are the responsibilities of a president?

President Ma told CNN that he will take full responsibility for the disaster caused by Typhoon Morakot, by examining the mistakes his administration made and disciplining the officials who failed in their duties.
Ma's answer has exposed his ignorance of his responsibilities.
No wonder, 82 percent of the people surveyed by CNN say Ma should step down.

As president of the state and the supreme commander of the armed forces, he should ask himself, did he order the armed forces to engage in the rescue operations, and has the National Security Council fulfilled its functions?
The Executive Yuan and the National Security Council are the two executive arms of the government, but both of them have failed to fulfill their duties.
In order to show his determination to take responsibility, the president should reshuffle his Cabinet and sack his national security chief.
Apple Daily:
Don't let down the people who donate cash generously to relief operations
It is reported that the disaster areas in southern Taiwan have been flooded with relief materials which pose a threat for another disaster.
We urged people to donate cash instead of materials as cash is preferred by most of the victims and would help them rebuild not only their lives but also their mental ability.
We also call the authorities to set up a transparent system to ensure that every penny donated for the victims will be used for them.
United Daily News:
All aid from China and United States is humanitarian aid
A U.S. military transport plane loaded with relief supplies landed in Taiwan Aug. 16 for the first time since the two countries severed ties in 1979.
A spokesman for China, which opposes any official contact between Washington and Taipei, said it was humanitarian aid delivered via a civic channel.

This comment contrasts sharply with Beijing's reaction in 1999 when an official of China's Red Cross Society said that countries wishing to render aid to Taiwan in the aftermath of a fatal earthquake should first seek Beijing's approval.
It shows what a long way China has come in its understanding of humanitarianism, and no explanation is required to identify which response is the wiser one.
We hope the authorities will accept whatever aid China offers to Taiwan, even it is not urgently needed, since it will help to improve the atmosphere across the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Identities of Typhoon Morakot victims to be confirmed quickly: MOJ

TEXT.P: Government offices will try to determine the identities of victims of Typhoon Morakot as quickly as possible so as to help bring closure to bereaved families, according to the head of Taiwan's Ministry of Justice Tuesday.

Vice Minister Huang Shih-min told a news conference that results of identity tests, such as DNA tests, can be obtained within five days after the test is conducted, denying local media reports that the process was moving at a snail's pace.

Death certificates can be issued three months after all the rescue work in the aftermath of the typhoon have been completed, Huang said. They will be issued for people who were either confirmed dead or listed as unaccounted for, but later proven dead by district prosecutors.
Huang denied reports that family members of people missing in the typhoon and feared dead will have to wait one year for an official declaration of death of their loved ones.
He said the ministry's Institute of Forensic Medicine and its Investigation Bureau have been working together in giving DNA tests.

Hundreds of people were buried in mud and debris washed down by landslides triggered by torrential rain from Morakot, including 380 residents of Siaolin village in Jiasian township, Kaohsiung County, who were believed to have been buried in the mudslide. Another 100 people in the village are unaccounted for, including people who could be studying or working in other cities.
The survivors of the village have decided to leave their buried loved ones untouched instead of excavating their bodies at the site where the village used to be.

As for the dead whose bodies cannot be found, Huang said prosecutors will launch an investigation based on relevant family members' testimony before acting to issue a death certificate -- an indispensable document for the victim's family members to apply for government compensation for typhoon victims.
According to the Executive Yuan, for each killed or missing from the typhoon, the government will compensate their family NT$1 million, while offering NT$250,000 for each severely-wounded survivor.
As of 4 p.m. Tuesday, the total number of confirmed fatalities had risen to 128, with 307 people missing and 45 injured, according to the National Fire Agency's disaster relief center.
The figures, however, do not include those believed buried in Siaolin Village and 32 people buried in the Xinkai tribe of Taoyuan township, Kaohsiung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Post-typhoon reconstruction to cost NT$110

TEXT.P: - President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that a special budget amounting to NT$110 billion will be needed for post-typhoon reconstruction work after Typhoon Morakot brought widespread destruction to the island.

Speaking at a news conference for foreign journalists, President Ma said that the administration already has NT$40 billion of the total reconstruction budget needed, but needs to ask the legislature to approve another NT$70 billion.

The source of the money will likely come from debt borrowing, Ma said, adding that Taiwan's amount of debt, currently at 32 percent of its gross domestic product is still under the maximum ceiling allowed of 40 percent.

While drafting special provisions and guidelines for the reconstruction work, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) under the Executive Yuan has initially set the special budget at NT$100 billion, according to CEPD Vice Chairman Hu Chung-ying.

He said that the draft provisions have been submitted to the Cabinet for screening. It is expected that the Cabinet will approve the provisions at its Thursday meeting and forward the bill to the Legislative Yuan to be enacted.

The draft provisions will allow local governments in hardest-hit counties to submit budget plans to subsidize businesses that were battered by Typhoon Morakot, particularly those in the tourism and agricultural sectors, Hu said.

In addition, Hu said, efforts to help displaced people from the flood-affected areas to find employment or receive vocational training will also be financed by the central government in accordance with the draft bill.
Much of the reconstruction budget will be used to rebuild damaged bridges, roads and houses as well as to resettle thousands of people displaced.

DOC.HEADLINE: President apologizes for shortcomings in typhoon rescue efforts

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou apologized Tuesday for the government's shortcomings in dealing with the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot and pledged to punish any liable officials by early September.
Ma made the remarks at a news conference held to address mounting public resentment and criticisms that the government's response to the disaster was slow and its rescue efforts inefficient.
Ma said that as the national leader, he will take responsibility for any deficiencies on the part of the government.
"I hereby offer my heartfelt apology to the entire nation, especially to those who lost their loved ones in the disaster," he said.

He said as the rescue operations are ending, the government will soon begin to investigate and identify the deficiencies in handling the disaster aftermath and will examine the administrative and political responsibilities of the officials involved.
Any punishments for those deemed liable and any Cabinet reshuffle decisions will be announced by early September, he said.
Ma stressed that the government has decided to hold off on the matter for a couple of weeks so as not to dampen the morale of rescuers.
"We are not trying to cover up our mistakes, but are only making a little postponement," he said.
Ruling out the possibility of stepping down over the matter, Ma said he must shoulder the upcoming post-disaster reconstruction effort and cannot leave office, as this would be an evasion of duty.

On the public's doubts over his decision not to declare a state of emergency in the aftermath of the storm, Ma explained that the Disaster Prevention and Protection Act enacted in 2000 already empowers the government to take the necessary steps to deal with emergency situations.
He said the mechanisms provided under the law should be allowed to function, although there may be room for improvement to these provisions.

Noting that the government set up a rescue command center in southern Taiwan immediately after the disaster, he said that communication problems probably contributed to the inefficiency of the rescue operations.

The president explained that he activated the national security mechanism Aug. 14 because the government needed to prepare for the huge outlay of financial and human resources that would be required in the post-disaster reconstruction period.

DOC.HEADLINE: President vows to correct failings in typhoon relief response

TEXT.P: Facing criticisms from home and abroad that his administration's rescue and relief efforts were slow and flawed, President Ma Ying-jeou vowed Tuesday to improve his performance and lead the country into recovery from the disaster caused last week by Typhoon Morakot.

Ma made the remarks at a news conference at the Presidential Office amid falling approval ratings driven by his government's response in the aftermath of massive flooding and landslides triggered by the storm, particularly in Tainan, Chiayi, Kaohsiung and Pingtung and Taitung counties in the south.

He said that a disaster prevention and rescue agency will be established to replace the National Fire Agency, which is in charge of rescue operations in the country, and that the government will spend US$300 million to purchase rescue helicopters.
According to the president, the money will come from the budget originally earmarked for the purchase of 60 Black Hawk helicopters from the United States.
"The government has now decided to buy 45 Black Hawks instead, and the US$300 million left over will be used to purchase rescue helicopters and equipment to better meet Taiwan's needs," he said.

Replying to a question on the possibility of a Cabinet reshuffle, Ma said that his administration will seek to identify the mistakes made and that, based on an agreement between him and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, any decisions pertaining to personnel will be made in two weeks.
As part of the government's plan to improve its rescue capability, disaster prevention will be included as one of the priority missions of the military, he added.

"In the future, the disaster prevention concept must be integrated into the nation's overall military strategy, military approach, military personnel deployment, as well as its budget allocation and equipment and machinery installation, " the president said.
In addition, disaster prevention units will be set up in all local governments, he said.

Asked whether the government will force an evacuation if a similar disaster should threaten, Ma replied in the affirmative and stressed that standard operation procedures must be established to deal with any similar situations.
"We will face up to and delve into the evacuation issue, despite predictable difficulties due to the fact that some villagers will never be willing to leave their homes in the mountains." he said.
"A homeland safety law is being crafted to serve that end. Villagers must be transported to safety early, in the event of similar flooding or disasters," the president said.

Aboriginal townships and settlements in Chiayi, Kaohsiung, Pintung and Taitung were the worst hit by Typhoon Morakot, with many of them cut off as mountain roads and bridges collapsed during the storm which battered the island Aug. 6-10.

Over 100 people have been killed and some 600 are reported missing in the typhoon, including close to 500 believed to have been buried under mudslides in Siaolin village. Most of the dead were indigenous people from mountain settlements.

Ma said that in view of the high death toll among aborigines and in an effort to honor his campaign promise to build a safe homeland for them, his government will allocate NT$50 billion over the next four years to mudslide prevention.
"The Council for Economic Planning and Development has already budgeted NT$12.6 billion for that purpose," he said.

Commenting on the government's plans for rehabilitation and reconstruction in the aftermath of the storm, Ma said it will need some NT$110 billion to fund such projects in the devastated areas of southern Taiwan.
The government has appropriated NT$40 billion from its special budgets and the remaining NT$70 billion will be obtained through public borrowing, Ma said.
Although agricultural and farm losses from Morakot have exceeded NT$12.2 billion, Ma said "Taiwan's economy would be only slightly affected, but its Q3 economic growth rate would become negative."

In light of the devastation wrought by the storm and the magnitude of the work ahead, the president said, he has canceled a planned trip to the South Pacific for a summit with leaders of Taiwan allies in that region in October.
He also announced a cancellation of National Day celebrations that are usually held annually on October 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: Evaluation of relief to be determined after reconstruction: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou declined Tuesday to judge the performance of himself and his government in the rescue and relief operations in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, saying that the success of the disaster relief efforts should be determined after the resettlement and reconstruction process is completed.

"We have entered a new face of disaster relief, that is re-settlement and recovery. We will try our best to do a better job. Certainly, we will do our job right this time," Ma said at an international press conference held by the Presidential Office, in which he apologized to the public for "the failure to act faster and in a more orderly way."

He pledged that the government will do whatever it can to correct its mistakes and become efficient in the process of resettlement and reconstruction, which the president said will determine the success of the entire post-typhoon operation.

Over the past week, Ma and his administration have come under fire for what is perceived by the public and foreign media as slow and insufficient response in the wake of the natural disaster, with several opinion polls, including a recent one conducted by CNN, showing strong public dissatisfaction with the government's performance.

The questions of whether Ma exercised strong and competent leadership and how his administration performed in the post-typhoon relief efforts, however, were strongly questioned by the foreign media, as reporters from Time Magazine, Japan's Kyodo News and other international media outlets all raised similar questions in the press conference.

"I think I have exercised strong leadership throughout the process by ordering the armed forces to increase their participation in the disaster rescue operation," Ma said, adding that the operation was "different from any other natural disaster" because bad weather impeded the rescue efforts.
"We are not blaming just the weather, but this is a fact, " he said.
Ma said any review and punishment of the government's performance should be carried out later, as it is more important for his government to focus on resettlement and the reconstruction process.

Pressed on whether he will make a Cabinet reshuffle and how he will take responsibility as president, Ma did not respond directly, saying only that his administration will review the performance of the government to identify the mistakes and negligence by officials.
The investigation and punishment process will take place no later than early September, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: No political influence in foreign aid: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou denied Tuesday that China played a role in his administration's decision to accept international assistance in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, saying that all international assistance is "purely humanitarian."
"We consider this assistance humanitarian and we don't politicize the assistance. Whatever the assistance is, we will take that attitude," Ma said at a news conference for foreign media outlets.
According to Ma, his government welcomed "all international assistance from the very beginning" and all humanitarian aid is treated the same.

"We accepted donations from the U.S., Japan, Singapore and China. We also accepted donations of materials from other countries. We don't have any political attitude, they are purely humanitarian," Ma said.

Ma and his administration have been lambasted over the past week by the media, both domestic and international, as well as typhoon victims and members of the public, for declining offers of foreign assistance in the wake of the natural disaster.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs was panned in particular for issuing instructions Aug. 11 to all MOFA's foreign representative offices to decline offers by their host governments of aid supplies or rescuers.
Media reports said that the rejection of foreign aid was for fear that it would upset China, which claims sovereignty over Taiwan.
Ma said that he and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan decided that Hsia should be responsible for the negligence.
"The resignation is now on the premier's desk and I believe he will approve it," the president said.

Ma added that an overall review of blame of his government and the punishment of relevant officials will be carried out in early September, as it is more important at present to focus on the resettlement of the typhoon victims and the start of the reconstruction process.

Noting that the scale of destruction brought by Typhoon Morakot is unprecedented and describing it as a result of global warming, Ma said Taiwan needs to take more effective measures in the face of similar situations.
According to Ma, the government is drafting a Homeland Planning Act that will divide the country into different regions and identify those areas that are unsuitable for human habitation.

In addition to making arrangements and providing incentives for those living in dangerous zones to leave, the government will also work on public education on the importance of evacuation in the face of mudslides.
"We believe that disasters cannot be prevented but can only be mitigated," Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung magistrate inspects spots for prefabricated homes

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing on Tuesday inspects several spots for setting up prefabricated homes for victims hit hard by Typhoon Morakot which lashed Taiwan from Aug. 6-10.
Leading a group of public works and construction officials, Yang visited six spots selected to serve that purpose and listened to the opinions and demands of people displaced by the typhoon.
"We hope to make a decision soon and start erecting prefabricated houses on appropriate sites as soon as possible," Yang said.

Huang I-hsiung, director of the Economic Development Department, said officials have selected four sites, including a nine-hectare plot of land belonging to Taiwan Sugar Company near Shanlin Junior High School, and a 0.6-hectare plot of land in Wulipu, close to Siaolin Village.
The village, the worst-affected in the typhoon, is covered in 20 to 30 meters of mud following a mudslide, with more than 400 people believed buried. Some 50 villagers managed to escape.

Huang said, two other places, one in Dashu township and another in Cishan, were being considered for location of new dormitories to be constructed for students who have to study at schools in other neighborhoods after Typhoon Morakot damaged their schools.

Although the six spots are being viewed as suitable to erect prefabricated houses to accommodate typhoon victims and affected students, county officials said the victims' needs and concerns must first be addressed.
Later Monday, the Executive Yuan announced that the government and private sector will cooperate to help victims build new homes and return to normal lives as soon as possible.

According to Executive Yuan officials, the National Property Administration under the Ministry of Finance, within one week, will offer suitable state-owned land plots for the Ministry of the Interior or local governments to select and use.

The Executive Yuan has asked charitable organizations to adopt disaster areas in line with the rehoming project, the officials said, adding that welfare organizations will be allowed to first erect prefabricated homes or houses for victims on these land plots before conducting legal procedures required by the government.
Typhoon victims will be eligible to rent these houses from the property administration, but the rentals will be decided by the Executive Yuan, an administration official said.

The Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, Fo Guang Shan Monastery, Dharma Drum Mountain, Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation and World Vision Taiwan have agreed to take part in the plan, Executive Yuan officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait celebrities raise over US$6 million in aid for Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/09 20:50:50 (By Mandy Wong & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Around 300 celebrities and entertainers from Hong Kong, China and Taiwan have raised HK$50 million (US$6.37 million) in Hong Kong for aid to the victims of Typhoon Morakot.
They include Jackie Chan and Hong Kong media mogul Sir Run Run Shaw, as well as popular Hong Kong actors and singers Andy Lau, Aaron Kwok and Jackey Cheung.

They led a fund-raising show organized by the Hong Kong Performing Artistes Guild at the AsiaWorld-Expo Monday at which each audience member was asked to donate at least HK$20 as an entrance fee to help relief work in the aftermath of the typhoon that struck southern Taiwan last week.
The entertainers, well-known in the Taiwan Strait region and other areas with large Chinese societies, not only sang for the typhoon victims, but also donated their own money.

The funds raised in the four-hour show increased donations from Hong Kong to over NT$560 million, including a contribution of NT$212 million by the Hong Kong government, NT$100 million from Sir Li Ka-shing -- the richest person in Hong Kong -- and NT$42.5 million from the Hong Kong Jockey Club.
Typhoon Morakot dumped nearly 3,000 mm of rain in just four days in parts of southern Taiwan, washing away bridges and triggering landslides that buried entire villages.

As of 4 p.m. Tuesday, the storm had killed 128 people across Taiwan and had left 45 injured and 307 others unaccounted for, according to official statistics. The death toll did not include the inhabitants of a mountain village entirely buried in mud and debris.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Morakot rise to NT$13 billion

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Morakot had surged to NT$13 billion (US$394.4 million) as of Tuesday, an increase of NT$750 million from a day earlier, according to statistics released by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).

The COA said that Morakot, which pummeled Taiwan Aug. 7-9, caused serious damage to the agricultural sector in 11 counties, with Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties in southern Taiwan and Hualien and Taitung counties in the east the hardest hit.
The statistics show that damage to crops had amounted to NT$4.13 billion, with 27 percent of the crops on 72,345 hectares of farmland wiped out.
Banana crops suffered the heaviest damage, with 5,947 hectares ravaged by strong winds and flooding.
Over 140,000 pigs, nearly 6 million chickens and around 1.4 million ducks perished in floods caused by the storm, bringing the total livestock losses to NT$1.42 billion, the COA said.

Damage to the aquaculture sector had amounted to NT$4.13 billion, the heaviest loss in 19 years, according to the statistics, with stock in some 8,845 hectares of fishponds or coastal areas washed away, it said.

Forestry losses had reached over NT$112 million, while damage to agricultural infrastructure had amounted to NT$221.7 million, mostly facilities for the cultivation of vegetables and papayas in the areas of Yunlin, Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung.
Damage to the fishery sector had surpassed NT$261 million, with the worst damage reported in Pingtung County.
The tallies also show that a total of 2,967 hectares of farmland had been either washed away or inundated, mostly in Chiayi, Taitung, Pingtung and Kaohsiung counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: First shipment of Chinese prefab houses arrive in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The first 100 of a donation of 1,000 prefabricated houses from China for the displaced victims of Typhoon Morakot arrived at Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan Tuesday.
The prefab houses cleared Kaohsiung customs rapidly and were sent directly to Jiadong township in Pingtung County, one of the areas hardest hit by Typhoon Morakot.
Taiwan-based Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp. transported the houses free of charge from Guangdong Providence in southeastern China.
Yang Ming will also help transport the remaining 900 units that China has pledged to donate, according to a spokesman from the company.

Addressing misgivings about possible excessive levels of formaldehyde in the houses, Chen Hung-yi, a section chief of the Construction and Planning Agency (CPA) under the Ministry of the Interior, said that "all plastic products contain formaldehyde," and said that as long as the products are put in well- ventilated places, the toxic fumes will dissipate.
He added, however, that officials will conduct inspections to ensure that the units meet government safety requirements for temporary shelters.
The Environmental Protection Administration will also monitor the water drainage systems and hygiene situations of the locations for the prefab houses.

China offered to assist in Taiwan's rehabilitation operation last week after Typhoon Morakot wreaked havoc in parts of the country Aug. 7-9, particularly the southern counties of Pingtung and Kaohsiung, prompting the government to request the housing units.
In a related development, the Executive Yuan is planning to cooperate with five private groups to resettle typhoon-affected victims.

Among them, the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China said Taiwan is capable of assembling 2,000 prefab houses and expressed the hope that hard-hit cities and counties will make requests for the housing.

Red Cross Society Secretary-General Chen Shih-kuei said all five groups, which also include the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, World Vision Taiwan, Dharma Drum Mountain and the Fuokuangshan Foundation, support the government's efforts to resettle the displaced victims.
"But except for Taitung County, which has requested 153 prefab houses, no other cities or counties have made any requests, " Chen said.
According to the Red Cross, 2,000 prefab houses built in Taiwan, combined with the 1,000 houses donated by China, will meet the needs for initial resettlement.

Chen urged the affected city and county governments to select locations fit for resettlement quickly to allow assembly work to get started, adding that the victims would be able to move in two weeks after assembly begins.

Tzu Chi spokesman Ho Jih-sheng said the foundation supports the government's decision to resettle the flood victims, but noted that the government had yet to come up with any proposals as to how this should be achieved.
"Tzu Chi will wait for more details from the government before assessing how to cooperate," Ho added.

He said that members of the foundation -- the largest charity group in Taiwan -- have gone to every flood-affected area to carry out relief work, and that its plan is to resettle the victims, taking into account the views of the victims as to whether the resettlement areas will be temporary or more permanent shelters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water shortages in Kaohsiung to be resolved soon: MOEA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is working to resolve water shortages in the Kaohsiung area in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot and is expected to have overcome the situation in two days, Economic Minister Yiin Chii-ming said Tuesday.
Yiin said that although water supplies to Kaohsiung have resumed, some residents might still experience shortages because demand is higher than usual.
He said the MOEA was trying to purify the turbid water flowing into to the Nanhua reservoir in Tainan -- one of Kaohsiung's main water suppliers -- in an effort to increase the water supply.

According to a report published that day by the Economic Daily News, the water shortages have affected hundreds of factories in the Gangshan, Yanchao, Lujhu, Renwu and Dashe areas of Kaohsiung County, as well as the Nanzih district of Kaohsiung City, with some factories having been forced to suspend operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady visits children's center in typhoon-affected area

TEXT.P: First Lady Chow Mei-ching visited children at a Child Friendly Space (CFS) set up by the local chapter of the international Christian charity World Vision to shelter children affected by Typhoon Morakot.

Chow, who visited the center in the eastern county of Taitung, sang songs with the children and joined a drawing activity in which they used art to share their dreams, according to a World Vision Taiwan press release.
Its great that you all have a dream. I hope you will pursue your dream with much joy, Chow was quoted as saying in the press release.
With dreams in your heart, even when you are faced with difficulties or frustrations, you will not give up,she added.

Some of the children had to flee from the typhoon's destruction and had lost their home. Even those who may have been less affected may suffer from the trauma of enduring these stressful situations, the center's officials said.

World Vision Taiwan said that providing children with psychological and social support is one of its top priorities in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, as children are often the most vulnerable among disaster survivors.
Two centers have been set up in Taitung county, two in Pingtung county, and three in Kaohsiung county -- to shelter 280 children.
At these centers, these children engage in fun games and other creative activities, under the guidance of trained volunteers, to help them express their emotions and begin the process of healing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Expert urges single agency for nation's land, water management

TEXT.P: A single government agency should be made responsible for land restoration and river management, a scholar said Tuesday in the wake of the devastation in southern Taiwan caused by Typhoon Morakot.

Yao Nai-jia, director of the Center for Bridge Engineering Research of National Central University, noted that over 90 bridges were damaged in the flooding and mudslides triggered by the typhoon that battered Taiwan Aug. 6-10.
"The large number of damaged bridges shows that the government has done a poor job in land restoration and river management, " Yao said.

He noted that at present, the planning, use and restoration of land, as well as river management, are managed by different government agencies such as the Council of Agriculture and the Ministry of Economic Affairs, and suggested that "one agency should take full responsibility."

He explained that Taiwan has a unique climate and terrain, and is divided roughly into two parts by the Central Mountain Range, which means that torrential rain in mountainous regions quickly flows down to the sea.
"The nation also has more than 27,000 bridges, a density that is also rather rare," he added.

These bridges are most vulnerable during flooding, he said, pointing out that central and southern Taiwan recorded the equivalent of a whole year's-worth of precipitation in just two days during the typhoon.
The damage sustained by the bridges, he went on, was most likely caused by torrential rain over a very short period of time that triggered rockslides and mudslides.
He also said that the large amount of driftwood seen in flood-devastated areas is evidence of the abusive development of mountain areas.

Yao, who assisted in a survey of bridges after the earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999, said many bridges were only tilted or knocked askew during the big temblor, while the destructive power of the landslides caused by the typhoon was immediate.
If serious flooding washes away a bridge pier, the bridge will collapse immediately, Yao noted.
Another scholar agreed with Yao and said that "it is not fair" to compare the relief work after Typhoon Morakot with that which followed the 921 earthquake.
Wang Ya-nan, a professor of National Taiwan University, said that while many houses collapsed after the earthquake and there were numerous aftershocks, roads remained open.
After the typhoon left Taiwan Aug. 9, however, downpours continued that further disrupted road and bridge traffic, he said.
"With the changing weather patterns nowadays, extreme weather might become a norm, " Wang predicted.
"We also have to reflect upon the land overdevelopment that has caused this backlash of nature," she said.
"To solve the problem at its root, the government and the private sector must work together to conserve energy and cut carbon dioxide emissions," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Culinary Exhibition to contribute to typhoon disaster relief

TEXT.P: The organizer of the 2009 Taiwan Culinary Exhibition announced Tuesday that 10 percent of the revenues from sales of full-price tickets will be donated to disaster relief in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot.
A fundraising campaign will also be held at the exhibition venue in which visitors who donate to the fund will be presented with a cookbook or a book on food, the organizer said.
In addition, charity sales of food and hotel accommodation vouchers will take place on each day of the exhibition, the organizer said.
Now in its 20th year, the exhibition is scheduled for Aug. 20-23 at the Taiwan World Trade Center.
Among the highlights of this year's exhibition will be a giant grouper pavilion provided by the Aquaculture Development Association.

The Chinese cuisine pavilion, meanwhile, will feature Suzhou cuisine, one of China's eight main culinary schools. Soong He Lou, a 200-year old restaurant in Suzhou, will prepare a "riverboat banquet" and 60 famous Suzhou dishes at the show.

DOC.HEADLINE: Township declines Chinese prefab houses due to toxin misgivings

TEXT.P: A township in southern Taiwan that was hit hard by Typhoon Morakot refused Tuesday to accept the first in a batch of 1,000 prefabricated houses that were donated by China, due to misgivings about levels of formaldehyde in the units.
The first 100 of the donation of 1,000 prefab houses from China arrived in Kaohsiung Harbor Tuesday and were immediately shipped to Jiadong township in Pingtung County.
However, the residents expressed concern after reports noted that the prefab houses might contain formaldehyde.

Jiadong township chief Lai Hsien-ho said he called the county government to convey the people's misgivings, upon which the county government decided to provide the township with 150 prefab houses donated by Rotary International.

The county government then called the Construction and Planning Agency (CPA) under the Ministry of the Interior and told the agency that there was no need to ship the Chinese houses to Jiadong. However, by that time, the prefabs were "already on the way, " Lai said.

CPA official Chen Hung-yi said Taitung County was the first to apply for the prefab houses, but as roads to Taitung were still not fully open after the serious flooding triggered by Morakot, Jiadong became the first stricken township to receive the temporary housing units from China.

Chen said that the Jiadong authorities should have made their objections known earlier. He pointed out that the houses had already arrived in the township, but added that if Jiadong is certain that it does not want them, they will be transferred elsewhere.

Addressing the misgivings about the possibility of formaldehyde in the houses, Chen had said earlier that a lot of plastic products contain formaldehyde and that as long as the products are situated in well-ventilated places, any toxic fumes will soon dissipate.
Another CPA official said that same day that the agency had not received any product certificate with the units and that certification was not included as part of the customs inspection.
But the official said that during the assembly process, the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection will dispatch staff to conduct tests on the materials.

The official said that each prefab house is about 15 pings (equivalent to around 50 square meters) , which is bigger than the 12-ping units provided for each homeless family after the magnitude 7.3 earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999 and also bigger than the 20-square-meter shelters used to house the victims of the major earthquake in China's Sichuan Province in 2008.
The larger size is because the Taiwanese authorities requested that each unit should include a kitchen and toilet, the official added.
