Ma said that as the national leader, he will take responsibility for any deficiencies on the part of the government.
"I hereby offer my heartfelt apology to the entire nation, especially to those who lost their loved ones in the disaster," he said.

He said as the rescue operations are ending, the government will soon begin to investigate and identify the deficiencies in handling the disaster aftermath and will examine the administrative and political responsibilities of the officials involved.
Any punishments for those deemed liable and any Cabinet reshuffle decisions will be announced by early September, he said.
Ma stressed that the government has decided to hold off on the matter for a couple of weeks so as not to dampen the morale of rescuers.
"We are not trying to cover up our mistakes, but are only making a little postponement," he said.
Ruling out the possibility of stepping down over the matter, Ma said he must shoulder the upcoming post-disaster reconstruction effort and cannot leave office, as this would be an evasion of duty.

On the public's doubts over his decision not to declare a state of emergency in the aftermath of the storm, Ma explained that the Disaster Prevention and Protection Act enacted in 2000 already empowers the government to take the necessary steps to deal with emergency situations.
He said the mechanisms provided under the law should be allowed to function, although there may be room for improvement to these provisions.

Noting that the government set up a rescue command center in southern Taiwan immediately after the disaster, he said that communication problems probably contributed to the inefficiency of the rescue operations.

The president explained that he activated the national security mechanism Aug. 14 because the government needed to prepare for the huge outlay of financial and human resources that would be required in the post-disaster reconstruction period.

DOC.HEADLINE: President vows to correct failings in typhoon relief response

TEXT.P: Facing criticisms from home and abroad that his administration's rescue and relief efforts were slow and flawed, President Ma Ying-jeou vowed Tuesday to improve his performance and lead the country into recovery from the disaster caused last week by Typhoon Morakot.

Ma made the remarks at a news conference at the Presidential Office amid falling approval ratings driven by his government's response in the aftermath of massive flooding and landslides triggered by the storm, particularly in Tainan, Chiayi, Kaohsiung and Pingtung and Taitung counties in the south.

He said that a disaster prevention and rescue agency will be established to replace the National Fire Agency, which is in charge of rescue operations in the country, and that the government will spend US$300 million to purchase rescue helicopters.
According to the president, the money will come from the budget originally earmarked for the purchase of 60 Black Hawk helicopters from the United States.
"The government has now decided to buy 45 Black Hawks instead, and the US$300 million left over will be used to purchase rescue helicopters and equipment to better meet Taiwan's needs," he said.

Replying to a question on the possibility of a Cabinet reshuffle, Ma said that his administration will seek to identify the mistakes made and that, based on an agreement between him and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, any decisions pertaining to personnel will be made in two weeks.
As part of the government's plan to improve its rescue capability, disaster prevention will be included as one of the priority missions of the military, he added.

"In the future, the disaster prevention concept must be integrated into the nation's overall military strategy, military approach, military personnel deployment, as well as its budget allocation and equipment and machinery installation, " the president said.
In addition, disaster prevention units will be set up in all local governments, he said.

Asked whether the government will force an evacuation if a similar disaster should threaten, Ma replied in the affirmative and stressed that standard operation procedures must be established to deal with any similar situations.
"We will face up to and delve into the evacuation issue, despite predictable difficulties due to the fact that some villagers will never be willing to leave their homes in the mountains." he said.
"A homeland safety law is being crafted to serve that end. Villagers must be transported to safety early, in the event of similar flooding or disasters," the president said.

Aboriginal townships and settlements in Chiayi, Kaohsiung, Pintung and Taitung were the worst hit by Typhoon Morakot, with many of them cut off as mountain roads and bridges collapsed during the storm which battered the island Aug. 6-10.

Over 100 people have been killed and some 600 are reported missing in the typhoon, including close to 500 believed to have been buried under mudslides in Siaolin village. Most of the dead were indigenous people from mountain settlements.

Ma said that in view of the high death toll among aborigines and in an effort to honor his campaign promise to build a safe homeland for them, his government will allocate NT$50 billion over the next four years to mudslide prevention.
"The Council for Economic Planning and Development has already budgeted NT$12.6 billion for that purpose," he said.

Commenting on the government's plans for rehabilitation and reconstruction in the aftermath of the storm, Ma said it will need some NT$110 billion to fund such projects in the devastated areas of southern Taiwan.
The government has appropriated NT$40 billion from its special budgets and the remaining NT$70 billion will be obtained through public borrowing, Ma said.
Although agricultural and farm losses from Morakot have exceeded NT$12.2 billion, Ma said "Taiwan's economy would be only slightly affected, but its Q3 economic growth rate would become negative."

In light of the devastation wrought by the storm and the magnitude of the work ahead, the president said, he has canceled a planned trip to the South Pacific for a summit with leaders of Taiwan allies in that region in October.
He also announced a cancellation of National Day celebrations that are usually held annually on October 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: Evaluation of relief to be determined after reconstruction: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou declined Tuesday to judge the performance of himself and his government in the rescue and relief operations in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, saying that the success of the disaster relief efforts should be determined after the resettlement and reconstruction process is completed.

"We have entered a new face of disaster relief, that is re-settlement and recovery. We will try our best to do a better job. Certainly, we will do our job right this time," Ma said at an international press conference held by the Presidential Office, in which he apologized to the public for "the failure to act faster and in a more orderly way."

He pledged that the government will do whatever it can to correct its mistakes and become efficient in the process of resettlement and reconstruction, which the president said will determine the success of the entire post-typhoon operation.

Over the past week, Ma and his administration have come under fire for what is perceived by the public and foreign media as slow and insufficient response in the wake of the natural disaster, with several opinion polls, including a recent one conducted by CNN, showing strong public dissatisfaction with the government's performance.

The questions of whether Ma exercised strong and competent leadership and how his administration performed in the post-typhoon relief efforts, however, were strongly questioned by the foreign media, as reporters from Time Magazine, Japan's Kyodo News and other international media outlets all raised similar questions in the press conference.

"I think I have exercised strong leadership throughout the process by ordering the armed forces to increase their participation in the disaster rescue operation," Ma said, adding that the operation was "different from any other natural disaster" because bad weather impeded the rescue efforts.
"We are not blaming just the weather, but this is a fact, " he said.
Ma said any review and punishment of the government's performance should be carried out later, as it is more important for his government to focus on resettlement and the reconstruction process.

Pressed on whether he will make a Cabinet reshuffle and how he will take responsibility as president, Ma did not respond directly, saying only that his administration will review the performance of the government to identify the mistakes and negligence by officials.
The investigation and punishment process will take place no later than early September, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: No political influence in foreign aid: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou denied Tuesday that China played a role in his administration's decision to accept international assistance in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, saying that all international assistance is "purely humanitarian."
"We consider this assistance humanitarian and we don't politicize the assistance. Whatever the assistance is, we will take that attitude," Ma said at a news conference for foreign media outlets.
According to Ma, his government welcomed "all international assistance from the very beginning" and all humanitarian aid is treated the same.

"We accepted donations from the U.S., Japan, Singapore and China. We also accepted donations of materials from other countries. We don't have any political attitude, they are purely humanitarian," Ma said.

Ma and his administration have been lambasted over the past week by the media, both domestic and international, as well as typhoon victims and members of the public, for declining offers of foreign assistance in the wake of the natural disaster.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs was panned in particular for issuing instructions Aug. 11 to all MOFA's foreign representative offices to decline offers by their host governments of aid supplies or rescuers.
Media reports said that the rejection of foreign aid was for fear that it would upset China, which claims sovereignty over Taiwan.
Ma said that he and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan decided that Hsia should be responsible for the negligence.
"The resignation is now on the premier's desk and I believe he will approve it," the president said.

Ma added that an overall review of blame of his government and the punishment of relevant officials will be carried out in early September, as it is more important at present to focus on the resettlement of the typhoon victims and the start of the reconstruction process.

Noting that the scale of destruction brought by Typhoon Morakot is unprecedented and describing it as a result of global warming, Ma said Taiwan needs to take more effective measures in the face of similar situations.
According to Ma, the government is drafting a Homeland Planning Act that will divide the country into different regions and identify those areas that are unsuitable for human habitation.

In addition to making arrangements and providing incentives for those living in dangerous zones to leave, the government will also work on public education on the importance of evacuation in the face of mudslides.
"We believe that disasters cannot be prevented but can only be mitigated," Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung magistrate inspects spots for prefabricated homes

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing on Tuesday inspects several spots for setting up prefabricated homes for victims hit hard by Typhoon Morakot which lashed Taiwan from Aug. 6-10.
Leading a group of public works and construction officials, Yang visited six spots selected to serve that purpose and listened to the opinions and demands of people displaced by the typhoon.
"We hope to make a decision soon and start erecting prefabricated houses on appropriate sites as soon as possible," Yang said.

Huang I-hsiung, director of the Economic Development Department, said officials have selected four sites, including a nine-hectare plot of land belonging to Taiwan Sugar Company near Shanlin Junior High School, and a 0.6-hectare plot of land in Wulipu, close to Siaolin Village.
The village, the worst-affected in the typhoon, is covered in 20 to 30 meters of mud following a mudslide, with more than 400 people believed buried. Some 50 villagers managed to escape.

Huang said, two other places, one in Dashu township and another in Cishan, were being considered for location of new dormitories to be constructed for students who have to study at schools in other neighborhoods after Typhoon Morakot damaged their schools.

Although the six spots are being viewed as suitable to erect prefabricated houses to accommodate typhoon victims and affected students, county officials said the victims' needs and concerns must first be addressed.
Later Monday, the Executive Yuan announced that the government and private sector will cooperate to help victims build new homes and return to normal lives as soon as possible.

According to Executive Yuan officials, the National Property Administration under the Ministry of Finance, within one week, will offer suitable state-owned land plots for the Ministry of the Interior or local governments to select and use.

The Executive Yuan has asked charitable organizations to adopt disaster areas in line with the rehoming project, the officials said, adding that welfare organizations will be allowed to first erect prefabricated homes or houses for victims on these land plots before conducting legal procedures required by the government.
Typhoon victims will be eligible to rent these houses from the property administration, but the rentals will be decided by the Executive Yuan, an administration official said.

The Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, Fo Guang Shan Monastery, Dharma Drum Mountain, Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation and World Vision Taiwan have agreed to take part in the plan, Executive Yuan officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait celebrities raise over US$6 million in aid for Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/09 20:50:50 (By Mandy Wong & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Around 300 celebrities and entertainers from Hong Kong, China and Taiwan have raised HK$50 million (US$6.37 million) in Hong Kong for aid to the victims of Typhoon Morakot.
They include Jackie Chan and Hong Kong media mogul Sir Run Run Shaw, as well as popular Hong Kong actors and singers Andy Lau, Aaron Kwok and Jackey Cheung.

They led a fund-raising show organized by the Hong Kong Performing Artistes Guild at the AsiaWorld-Expo Monday at which each audience member was asked to donate at least HK$20 as an entrance fee to help relief work in the aftermath of the typhoon that struck southern Taiwan last week.
The entertainers, well-known in the Taiwan Strait region and other areas with large Chinese societies, not only sang for the typhoon victims, but also donated their own money.

The funds raised in the four-hour show increased donations from Hong Kong to over NT$560 million, including a contribution of NT$212 million by the Hong Kong government, NT$100 million from Sir Li Ka-shing -- the richest person in Hong Kong -- and NT$42.5 million from the Hong Kong Jockey Club.
Typhoon Morakot dumped nearly 3,000 mm of rain in just four days in parts of southern Taiwan, washing away bridges and triggering landslides that buried entire villages.

As of 4 p.m. Tuesday, the storm had killed 128 people across Taiwan and had left 45 injured and 307 others unaccounted for, according to official statistics. The death toll did not include the inhabitants of a mountain village entirely buried in mud and debris.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Morakot rise to NT$13 billion

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Morakot had surged to NT$13 billion (US$394.4 million) as of Tuesday, an increase of NT$750 million from a day earlier, according to statistics released by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).

The COA said that Morakot, which pummeled Taiwan Aug. 7-9, caused serious damage to the agricultural sector in 11 counties, with Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties in southern Taiwan and Hualien and Taitung counties in the east the hardest hit.
The statistics show that damage to crops had amounted to NT$4.13 billion, with 27 percent of the crops on 72,345 hectares of farmland wiped out.
Banana crops suffered the heaviest damage, with 5,947 hectares ravaged by strong winds and flooding.
Over 140,000 pigs, nearly 6 million chickens and around 1.4 million ducks perished in floods caused by the storm, bringing the total livestock losses to NT$1.42 billion, the COA said.

Damage to the aquaculture sector had amounted to NT$4.13 billion, the heaviest loss in 19 years, according to the statistics, with stock in some 8,845 hectares of fishponds or coastal areas washed away, it said.

Forestry losses had reached over NT$112 million, while damage to agricultural infrastructure had amounted to NT$221.7 million, mostly facilities for the cultivation of vegetables and papayas in the areas of Yunlin, Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung.
Damage to the fishery sector had surpassed NT$261 million, with the worst damage reported in Pingtung County.
The tallies also show that a total of 2,967 hectares of farmland had been either washed away or inundated, mostly in Chiayi, Taitung, Pingtung and Kaohsiung counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: First shipment of Chinese prefab houses arrive in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The first 100 of a donation of 1,000 prefabricated houses from China for the displaced victims of Typhoon Morakot arrived at Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan Tuesday.
The prefab houses cleared Kaohsiung customs rapidly and were sent directly to Jiadong township in Pingtung County, one of the areas hardest hit by Typhoon Morakot.
Taiwan-based Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp. transported the houses free of charge from Guangdong Providence in southeastern China.
Yang Ming will also help transport the remaining 900 units that China has pledged to donate, according to a spokesman from the company.

Addressing misgivings about possible excessive levels of formaldehyde in the houses, Chen Hung-yi, a section chief of the Construction and Planning Agency (CPA) under the Ministry of the Interior, said that "all plastic products contain formaldehyde," and said that as long as the products are put in well- ventilated places, the toxic fumes will dissipate.
He added, however, that officials will conduct inspections to ensure that the units meet government safety requirements for temporary shelters.
The Environmental Protection Administration will also monitor the water drainage systems and hygiene situations of the locations for the prefab houses.

China offered to assist in Taiwan's rehabilitation operation last week after Typhoon Morakot wreaked havoc in parts of the country Aug. 7-9, particularly the southern counties of Pingtung and Kaohsiung, prompting the government to request the housing units.
In a related development, the Executive Yuan is planning to cooperate with five private groups to resettle typhoon-affected victims.

Among them, the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China said Taiwan is capable of assembling 2,000 prefab houses and expressed the hope that hard-hit cities and counties will make requests for the housing.

Red Cross Society Secretary-General Chen Shih-kuei said all five groups, which also include the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, World Vision Taiwan, Dharma Drum Mountain and the Fuokuangshan Foundation, support the government's efforts to resettle the displaced victims.
"But except for Taitung County, which has requested 153 prefab houses, no other cities or counties have made any requests, " Chen said.
According to the Red Cross, 2,000 prefab houses built in Taiwan, combined with the 1,000 houses donated by China, will meet the needs for initial resettlement.

Chen urged the affected city and county governments to select locations fit for resettlement quickly to allow assembly work to get started, adding that the victims would be able to move in two weeks after assembly begins.

Tzu Chi spokesman Ho Jih-sheng said the foundation supports the government's decision to resettle the flood victims, but noted that the government had yet to come up with any proposals as to how this should be achieved.
"Tzu Chi will wait for more details from the government before assessing how to cooperate," Ho added.

He said that members of the foundation -- the largest charity group in Taiwan -- have gone to every flood-affected area to carry out relief work, and that its plan is to resettle the victims, taking into account the views of the victims as to whether the resettlement areas will be temporary or more permanent shelters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water shortages in Kaohsiung to be resolved soon: MOEA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is working to resolve water shortages in the Kaohsiung area in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot and is expected to have overcome the situation in two days, Economic Minister Yiin Chii-ming said Tuesday.
Yiin said that although water supplies to Kaohsiung have resumed, some residents might still experience shortages because demand is higher than usual.
He said the MOEA was trying to purify the turbid water flowing into to the Nanhua reservoir in Tainan -- one of Kaohsiung's main water suppliers -- in an effort to increase the water supply.

According to a report published that day by the Economic Daily News, the water shortages have affected hundreds of factories in the Gangshan, Yanchao, Lujhu, Renwu and Dashe areas of Kaohsiung County, as well as the Nanzih district of Kaohsiung City, with some factories having been forced to suspend operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady visits children's center in typhoon-affected area

TEXT.P: First Lady Chow Mei-ching visited children at a Child Friendly Space (CFS) set up by the local chapter of the international Christian charity World Vision to shelter children affected by Typhoon Morakot.

Chow, who visited the center in the eastern county of Taitung, sang songs with the children and joined a drawing activity in which they used art to share their dreams, according to a World Vision Taiwan press release.
Its great that you all have a dream. I hope you will pursue your dream with much joy, Chow was quoted as saying in the press release.
With dreams in your heart, even when you are faced with difficulties or frustrations, you will not give up,she added.

Some of the children had to flee from the typhoon's destruction and had lost their home. Even those who may have been less affected may suffer from the trauma of enduring these stressful situations, the center's officials said.

World Vision Taiwan said that providing children with psychological and social support is one of its top priorities in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, as children are often the most vulnerable among disaster survivors.
Two centers have been set up in Taitung county, two in Pingtung county, and three in Kaohsiung county -- to shelter 280 children.
At these centers, these children engage in fun games and other creative activities, under the guidance of trained volunteers, to help them express their emotions and begin the process of healing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Expert urges single agency for nation's land, water management

TEXT.P: A single government agency should be made responsible for land restoration and river management, a scholar said Tuesday in the wake of the devastation in southern Taiwan caused by Typhoon Morakot.

Yao Nai-jia, director of the Center for Bridge Engineering Research of National Central University, noted that over 90 bridges were damaged in the flooding and mudslides triggered by the typhoon that battered Taiwan Aug. 6-10.
"The large number of damaged bridges shows that the government has done a poor job in land restoration and river management, " Yao said.

He noted that at present, the planning, use and restoration of land, as well as river management, are managed by different government agencies such as the Council of Agriculture and the Ministry of Economic Affairs, and suggested that "one agency should take full responsibility."

He explained that Taiwan has a unique climate and terrain, and is divided roughly into two parts by the Central Mountain Range, which means that torrential rain in mountainous regions quickly flows down to the sea.
"The nation also has more than 27,000 bridges, a density that is also rather rare," he added.

These bridges are most vulnerable during flooding, he said, pointing out that central and southern Taiwan recorded the equivalent of a whole year's-worth of precipitation in just two days during the typhoon.
The damage sustained by the bridges, he went on, was most likely caused by torrential rain over a very short period of time that triggered rockslides and mudslides.
He also said that the large amount of driftwood seen in flood-devastated areas is evidence of the abusive development of mountain areas.

Yao, who assisted in a survey of bridges after the earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999, said many bridges were only tilted or knocked askew during the big temblor, while the destructive power of the landslides caused by the typhoon was immediate.
If serious flooding washes away a bridge pier, the bridge will collapse immediately, Yao noted.
Another scholar agreed with Yao and said that "it is not fair" to compare the relief work after Typhoon Morakot with that which followed the 921 earthquake.
Wang Ya-nan, a professor of National Taiwan University, said that while many houses collapsed after the earthquake and there were numerous aftershocks, roads remained open.
After the typhoon left Taiwan Aug. 9, however, downpours continued that further disrupted road and bridge traffic, he said.
"With the changing weather patterns nowadays, extreme weather might become a norm, " Wang predicted.
"We also have to reflect upon the land overdevelopment that has caused this backlash of nature," she said.
"To solve the problem at its root, the government and the private sector must work together to conserve energy and cut carbon dioxide emissions," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Culinary Exhibition to contribute to typhoon disaster relief

TEXT.P: The organizer of the 2009 Taiwan Culinary Exhibition announced Tuesday that 10 percent of the revenues from sales of full-price tickets will be donated to disaster relief in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot.
A fundraising campaign will also be held at the exhibition venue in which visitors who donate to the fund will be presented with a cookbook or a book on food, the organizer said.
In addition, charity sales of food and hotel accommodation vouchers will take place on each day of the exhibition, the organizer said.
Now in its 20th year, the exhibition is scheduled for Aug. 20-23 at the Taiwan World Trade Center.
Among the highlights of this year's exhibition will be a giant grouper pavilion provided by the Aquaculture Development Association.

The Chinese cuisine pavilion, meanwhile, will feature Suzhou cuisine, one of China's eight main culinary schools. Soong He Lou, a 200-year old restaurant in Suzhou, will prepare a "riverboat banquet" and 60 famous Suzhou dishes at the show.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug. 19, 2009

TEXT.P: mud flow buried site of Siaolin Village in

DOC.HEADLINE: Township declines Chinese prefab houses due to toxin misgivings

TEXT.P: A township in southern Taiwan that was hit hard by Typhoon Morakot refused Tuesday to accept the first in a batch of 1,000 prefabricated houses that were donated by China, due to misgivings about levels of formaldehyde in the units.
The first 100 of the donation of 1,000 prefab houses from China arrived in Kaohsiung Harbor Tuesday and were immediately shipped to Jiadong township in Pingtung County.
However, the residents expressed concern after reports noted that the prefab houses might contain formaldehyde.

Jiadong township chief Lai Hsien-ho said he called the county government to convey the people's misgivings, upon which the county government decided to provide the township with 150 prefab houses donated by Rotary International.

The county government then called the Construction and Planning Agency (CPA) under the Ministry of the Interior and told the agency that there was no need to ship the Chinese houses to Jiadong. However, by that time, the prefabs were "already on the way, " Lai said.

CPA official Chen Hung-yi said Taitung County was the first to apply for the prefab houses, but as roads to Taitung were still not fully open after the serious flooding triggered by Morakot, Jiadong became the first stricken township to receive the temporary housing units from China.

Chen said that the Jiadong authorities should have made their objections known earlier. He pointed out that the houses had already arrived in the township, but added that if Jiadong is certain that it does not want them, they will be transferred elsewhere.

Addressing the misgivings about the possibility of formaldehyde in the houses, Chen had said earlier that a lot of plastic products contain formaldehyde and that as long as the products are situated in well-ventilated places, any toxic fumes will soon dissipate.
Another CPA official said that same day that the agency had not received any product certificate with the units and that certification was not included as part of the customs inspection.
But the official said that during the assembly process, the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection will dispatch staff to conduct tests on the materials.

The official said that each prefab house is about 15 pings (equivalent to around 50 square meters) , which is bigger than the 12-ping units provided for each homeless family after the magnitude 7.3 earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999 and also bigger than the 20-square-meter shelters used to house the victims of the major earthquake in China's Sichuan Province in 2008.
The larger size is because the Taiwanese authorities requested that each unit should include a kitchen and toilet, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 19, or the 29th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1662: Blaise Pascal, the French mathematician, physicist and religious philosopher, dies in Paris at the age of 39.
1871: Orville Wright, the American aviation pioneer, who, with his brother Wilbur, made the first powered and controlled flight, is born.
1878: Manuel Luis Quezon y Molina, first president of the Philippines Commonwealth established under U.S. tutelage in 1935, is born.
1901: Shang Tai, the last monarch of the Ryukyu Kingdom, dies in Tokyo at the age of 58.
1904: Japanese troops launch a disastrous attack on Russian-held Port Arthur (Lushun) in northeastern China during the Russo-Japanese War. Of the 51,000 troops involved, only about 35,000 survived.
1934: Nearly 90 percent of Germans vote to give Adolf Hitler the presidency in addition to his position as chancellor.
1936: Kwangsi rebels in China set up an independent regime in Kweilin.
1936: A total of 16 senior members of the Soviet Communist Party are executed after Josef Stalin orders a purge of the party to get rid of followers of Leon Trotsky, a leader of the Bolshevik Revolution.
1945: Forces led by Ho Chi Minh and the Viet Minh begin the August Revolution against French colonial rule in Vietnam.
1946: Chinese Communist Party leader Mao Tse-tung announces that communist forces will launch a full-scale war against the Chinese government.
1946: Bill Clinton, the 42nd president of the United States, is born. He served as governor of Arkansas from 1978 to 1980 and again from 1982 until he was elected U.S. president in November 1992.
1960: The Soviet Union sentences U-2 spy plane pilot Gary Powers to 10 years in detention.
1966: An earthquake rocks eastern Turkey, killing more than 2,000 people.
1979: Pol Pot, ex-dictator of Cambodia, is sentenced to death in absentia for genocide by the Cambodian government.
1989: Poland becomes the first country in Eastern Europe to end one-party rule, as Solidarity's Tadeuz Mazowiecki takes office as prime minister.
1990: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein offers to release all Western hostages in exchange for a U.S. withdrawal from the Gulf region and an end to the blockade.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader who gave a nervous world two words of hope -- "glasnost" and "perestroika" -- is toppled, just one day short of the scheduled signing of the Union Treaty, a document hated by the hardliners because it signals the beginning of the end of the Soviet empire they know and love.
1995: The Republic of China Foreign Ministry issues a position paper entitled "Why the U.N. Resolution No. 2758 Adopted in 1971 Should be Re-examined Today." The paper stresses that the resolution, which excluded the ROC from the United Nations, is obsolete and unjust.
1996: ROC Vice President and Premier Lien Chan visits the Ukraine.
1996: Niger switches diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.
1999: The Taiwan Independence Party nominates its chairman, Cheng Pang-chen, as its candidate for the ROC's next presidential election slated for March 2000.
2000: An agreement sending International Cooperation and Development volunteers from the ROC to Nicaragua is passed during a regular meeting of the Executive Yuan.
2001: A 36-hour course on conducting election campaigns launched by the newly- established Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), Taiwan's 95th political party, begins at the Grand Hotel Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to figure out, but once you try to figure out a thing, you must never give it up until you have got what you want."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Wednesday, moving up 53.92 points at 6,843.69 on a turnover of NT$2.28 billion (US$69.17 million).
The weighted price index lost 142.03 points, or 2.04 percent, to close at 6,789.77 Tuesday.

Another CPA official said that same day that the agency had not received any product certificate with the units and that certification was not included as part of the customs inspection.
But the official said that during the assembly process, the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection will dispatch staff to conduct tests on the materials.

The official said that each prefab house is about 15 pings (equivalent to around 50 square meters) , which is bigger than the 12-ping units provided for each homeless family after the magnitude 7.3 earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999 and also bigger than the 20-square-meter shelters used to house the victims of the major earthquake in China's Sichuan Province in 2008.
The larger size is because the Taiwanese authorities requested that each unit should include a kitchen and toilet, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Culinary Exhibition to contribute to typhoon disaster relief

TEXT.P: The organizer of the 2009 Taiwan Culinary Exhibition announced Tuesday that 10 percent of the revenues from sales of full-price tickets will be donated to disaster relief in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot.
A fundraising campaign will also be held at the exhibition venue in which visitors who donate to the fund will be presented with a cookbook or a book on food, the organizer said.
In addition, charity sales of food and hotel accommodation vouchers will take place on each day of the exhibition, the organizer said.
Now in its 20th year, the exhibition is scheduled for Aug. 20-23 at the Taiwan World Trade Center.
Among the highlights of this year's exhibition will be a giant grouper pavilion provided by the Aquaculture Development Association.

The Chinese cuisine pavilion, meanwhile, will feature Suzhou cuisine, one of China's eight main culinary schools. Soong He Lou, a 200-year old restaurant in Suzhou, will prepare a "riverboat banquet" and 60 famous Suzhou dishes at the show.

DOC.HEADLINE: Expert urges single agency for nation's land, water management

TEXT.P: A single government agency should be made responsible for land restoration and river management, a scholar said Tuesday in the wake of the devastation in southern Taiwan caused by Typhoon Morakot.

Yao Nai-jia, director of the Center for Bridge Engineering Research of National Central University, noted that over 90 bridges were damaged in the flooding and mudslides triggered by the typhoon that battered Taiwan Aug. 6-10.
"The large number of damaged bridges shows that the government has done a poor job in land restoration and river management, " Yao said.

He noted that at present, the planning, use and restoration of land, as well as river management, are managed by different government agencies such as the Council of Agriculture and the Ministry of Economic Affairs, and suggested that "one agency should take full responsibility."

He explained that Taiwan has a unique climate and terrain, and is divided roughly into two parts by the Central Mountain Range, which means that torrential rain in mountainous regions quickly flows down to the sea.
"The nation also has more than 27,000 bridges, a density that is also rather rare," he added.

These bridges are most vulnerable during flooding, he said, pointing out that central and southern Taiwan recorded the equivalent of a whole year's-worth of precipitation in just two days during the typhoon.
The damage sustained by the bridges, he went on, was most likely caused by torrential rain over a very short period of time that triggered rockslides and mudslides.
He also said that the large amount of driftwood seen in flood-devastated areas is evidence of the abusive development of mountain areas.

Yao, who assisted in a survey of bridges after the earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999, said many bridges were only tilted or knocked askew during the big temblor, while the destructive power of the landslides caused by the typhoon was immediate.
If serious flooding washes away a bridge pier, the bridge will collapse immediately, Yao noted.
Another scholar agreed with Yao and said that "it is not fair" to compare the relief work after Typhoon Morakot with that which followed the 921 earthquake.
Wang Ya-nan, a professor of National Taiwan University, said that while many houses collapsed after the earthquake and there were numerous aftershocks, roads remained open.
After the typhoon left Taiwan Aug. 9, however, downpours continued that further disrupted road and bridge traffic, she said.
"With the changing weather patterns nowadays, extreme weather might become a norm, " Wang predicted.
"We also have to reflect upon the land overdevelopment that has caused this backlash of nature," she said.
"To solve the problem at its root, the government and the private sector must work together to conserve energy and cut carbon dioxide emissions," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Wednesday:
LIBERTY TIMES:
Consoling victims becomes litany of complaints
Amid mounting criticism over failed flood relief operations, President Ma Ying-jeou's news conference Tuesday was a disappointment.
He stressed that he will not evade his responsibility, and that the road to resettlement is long and he will let the people know that he can carry out the task effectively.
When he previously failed to deliver on his campaign promises, he said that he will deliver it in 2016, and now he is employing the same gambit.

The more tangible measure he proposed during the news conference is to set up a disaster prevention and relief agency to replace the current National Fire Agency under the Ministry of the Interior, but we think that it is only a change of name and will not upgrade rescue and relief efficiency.
We can now be sure that the Ma administration, which missed the golden 72 hours period, has now proven itself powerless in relief operations.

Ma Ying-jeou's so-called consoling voice to ease the pain of those suffering has become a consoling voice full of excuses about why relief efforts were hampered, such as excessive amounts of rainfall, blocked roads and villagers who did not evacuate.
Can we turn over our nation to such a man? We have trouble sleeping or eating if we also think that he is insisting on pushing for an economic cooperation framework agreement with China.
APPLE DAILY:
Military in trouble if rescue mission like combat operation
The military rescue operation in Typhoon Morakot has been hampered by the procrastination of the president and the defense minister.
Intelligence agencies in other countries often use the speed, the deployment and efficiency a nation's military has displayed in a rescue operation to gauge its combat capability.
If our military were evaluated by the rescue mission this time, it would have been wiped out in the very beginning and the root of it can be traced to an inefficient commander-in-chief.

We also think the conspiracy theory circulating on the Internet that the U.S. sending heavy-lift helicopters to Taiwan to aid relief operations was a competition between Washington and Beijing over Taiwan is a smearing of goodwill assistance.
UNITED DAILY NEWS:
More than flood-affected areas need to be rebuilt

President Ma Ying-jeou's two news conferences Tuesday were mainly aimed at improving the seriously tarnished image his administration has suffered over the past 10 days due to a chaotic flood relief effort.
Every one knows that the focus of Ma's administration will now be on post- disaster reconstruction, but we think that Taiwan also needs reconstruction in three other major fronts:
First, public confidence in the administration should be rebuilt.

When the government's relief operations are seen as far less efficient than those of civilian groups and when officials are the targets of angry outbursts from flood victims when they inspect the affected areas, we think a crisis of confidence has formed.
If such a crisis cannot be reversed, we believe an effective reconstruction effort will be compromised.
Secondly, we think that the Cabinet should be rebuilt judging from its performance during the relief operation. All eyes are on Ma when he said that the Cabinet will be adjusted by September.
The third thing that needs reconstruction will be the nation's finances. The government has initially estimated that NT$110 billion will be needed for post- disaster reconstruction.

But we know that the nation's deficit has become more serious with this year's shortfall in tax revenues to the tune of several hundreds of billions of dollars. The nation's debt has almost risen to its legally mandated ceiling.

The Finance Ministry's tax-cutting measures over the past year, the free lunch promises on a whim of the premier and the Ministry of Economic Affairs subsidy for TMC in an unfavorable environment have all been "mudslides" created by government agencies.
We know that if we cannot rebuild on the above three fronts, then post-flood reconstruction tasks will flounder.
CHINA TIMES:
We're not just expecting an apology!
President Ma Ying-jeou offered an apology over the slow and chaotic rescue and relief operations in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot. But have you accepted it or felt his sincerity?
Disaster relief efforts are seldom satisfactory. The government was also panned soon after a magnitude 7.3 earthquake struck Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999.

When the people are in pain, a government should show its professionalism as well as empathy. President Ma said he has done his best, but when his good friend and policy adviser openly lash out at the Ma administration as cold blooded, he has been dealt a serious blow.
Ma was still "reasoning" during his news conference Tuesday when he explained why he did not issue an emergency decree after the most serious flooding in 50 years battered southern Taiwan.

We think that a president who abides by the law and will not randomly expand his power is to be appreciated in peacetime, but if a president still clings to the law during a major disaster, he could easily fall prey to triviality and overlook the big picture.
The president and all political appointees cannot avoid their responsibility, but we hope that they will not dwell on the administration's popularity but rather confront the nation's future plight.

DOC.HEADLINE: Reconstruction committee to set up office in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan has instructed the Cabinet committee promoting post- Typhoon Morakot reconstruction to set up an office in southern Taiwan to facilitate its work.
Liu issued the directive in a meeting with Minister without Portfolio Tsai Hsung-hsiung Tuesday, during which Tsai briefed the premier on the progress achieved by the committee.

According to Tsai, Liu also asked the Central Emergency Operation Center to gradually transfer some of its reconstruction-related projects to the new committee and make sure that the process is handled seamlessly.
On the government's effort to draft a special statute governing reconstruction efforts, the Cabinet said in a statement Tuesday that the legislation will address a number of key issues.

They include: budgeting related to reconstruction, financing bailout plans for businesses affected by the disaster, rebuilding or repairing public facilities, relaxing or simplifying procedures for emergency projects related to disaster prevention and rescue, and providing employment services for the jobless in disaster areas.
Hu Chung-ying, deputy minister of the Council of Economic Planning and Development, said earlier in the day that the budget for the reconstruction plan has been tentatively set at NT$100 billion.

Lin Yi-shih, head of the ruling Kuomintang's Policy Committee, said that as soon as the reconstruction bill is submitted to the Legislative Yuan, the party's legislative caucus will discuss with the opposition Democratic Progressive Party caucus whether to hold a special legislative session in late August to consider the bill.
Another option is for the legislature to convene early on Sept. 4 to deal with the bill, Lin said.
The legislature is currently in recess. While the new session starts in September, legislators are not expected to meet until the middle of the month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan secretary-general, defense minister offer to resign

TEXT.P: Executive Yuan Secretary-General Hsieh Hsiang-chuan and Defense Minister Chen Chao-min have offered to resign after they became magnets for criticism for the government's slow response to the destruction wrought by Typhoon Morakot last week, an official said Wednesday.
The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Executive Yuan will brief the press on their resignations later in the day.

Cable TV news reports said Premier Liu Chao-shiuan is not expected to immediately accept their offers to resign because of ongoing disaster relief efforts but will wait until early September to deal with the issue.

Hsieh has been heavily criticized for leaving the Central Emergency Operation Center Aug. 8 while southern Taiwan was being pummeled by torrential rains from Typhoon Morakot for a Father's Day dinner.
Chen was bashed for the military's lackluster deployment of troops and equipment to remote and flooded areas and its seeming lack of preparedness when faced with the natural disaster.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung on guard against epidemics in typhoon victim shelters

TEXT.P: Medical stations have been set up in each typhoon victim shelter in Kaohsiung County as part of an effort to prevent outbreaks of influenza A (H1N1) infections and dengue fever, the county's health authorities said Wednesday.
Other measures adopted are requiring the shelters to disinfect door handles every hour and sterilize their premises regularly, said Huang Chih-chung, head of the county's health bureau.
Nearly 3,000 people displaced by Typhoon Morakot are currently being sheltered at 20 locations in Kaohsiung County.
The results of monitoring conducted by the medical stations found that the number of residents infected with flu totaled 36 on Aug. 16, 87 on Aug. 17, and 67 on Aug. 18, Huang said.
While none has been diagnosed with the H1N1 flu strain, the stations will continue to monitor the situation to guard against any cluster infections of the new form of flu, he said.
Flu patients are being required to wear masks and have their temperature taken regularly to track their condition, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close marginally lower on local bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed marginally lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 1.19 points, or 0.01 percent, to close at 6,788.58.
The local bourse opened at 6,843.69 and fluctuated between 6,854.59 and 6,788.58 during the day's trading session.
A total of 2.66 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$70.56 billion (US$2.14 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 1.8 percent. Textile stocks dropped 1.3 percent, paper and pulp issues were down 1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares declined 0.8 percent, banking and financial shares dropped 0.2 percent, and construction issues decreased 0.1 percent.
The two other major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up 0.3 percent and foodstuff issues advancing 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,103 to 970, with 261 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$1.66 billion-worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU Hospital confirms H1N1 cluster infection, with 1 acute case

TEXT.P: A cluster infection of swine flu, officially known as influenza A(H1N1) , has been confirmed at National Taiwan University (NTU) Hospital in Taipei, involving four nurses and one patient, an NTU spokesman said Wednesday.

The patient had been confirmed as a severe H1N1 case, and was receiving emergency treatment in an intensive care unit after developing pneumonia, said Huang Li-min, director of the hospital's pediatric infectious disease department.

"The patient is a 45-year-old woman with underlying chronic disease," Huang said, adding that although the woman initially showed symptoms of respiratory failure, her vital signs stabilized after she was intubated.
She was the 26th A(H1N1) severe case confirmed in Taiwan, but the first recorded inside a hospital, according to official tallies.
The four infected nurses were all mild cases and were recuperating at home, Huang added.

More than 20 of their colleagues working at the same nursing station, as well as two other patients who shared a room with the severe case and their caregivers and family members, have been given preventive medication, Huang said.

Noting that all four nurses and the patient fell ill between Aug. 13 and Aug. 14, Huang said an initial investigation had ruled out the possibility of the patient and nurses coming down with the virus from the same source.

"It was most likely that the patient and the nurses contracted the virus from different sources, probably other patients, caregivers or family members and friends who had visited the patient, " Huang elaborated.
According to Huang, the cluster infection had been brought under control and had not shown any signs of spreading further.

In addition to disinfecting the patient's room, Huang said, the hospital had activated its in-hospital infection control mechanism and tightened monitoring of patients with fever and sore throat. Outpatients and emergency room patients with fevers had been separated from other patients to contain any spread of the virus, he added.
The Centers for Disease Control under the Cabinet-level Department of Health estimated that there were an additional 9,000 A(H1N1) flu cases through community infection over the past week.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon death toll climbs to 136

TEXT.P: The official death toll from Typhoon Morakot had climbed to 136 as of 1 p.m. Wednesday, with 386 people listed as missing and 45 injured, according to the Central Emergency Operation Center.
The death toll is likely to continue to rise, as an undetermined number of people in remote villages, especially Siaolin in Kaohsiung County, are thought to have died in massive landslides, it said.

In terms of water and electricity supplies, the center said over 11,600 households in the southern counties of Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung were still without running water as of 10 a.m. Wednesday and that 11,881 households were without power.
In addition, 2,129 telephone lines and 124 mobile stations were yet to be repaired, it said.
Meanwhile, 49 pumping systems have been sent to Pingtung County's Jiadong township for use in low-lying areas where floodwaters were about 25 to 70 centimeters high, the center said.

In the agricultural sector, damage from Typhoon Morakot was estimated at NT$13.06 billion as of Wednesday morning, with Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Tainan counties suffering the most, in that order, the center reported.
The aquaculture sector suffered NT$4.1 billion in losses, with Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Tainan counties also being the most heavily battered areas, according to the center.

About 24,281 victims have been evacuated since the flood, and the government has established 51 emergency shelters that are now accommodating 5,849 people. Disaster Response Centers in Chiayi, Taitung, Nantou, Kaohsiung, Pingtung and Tainan County remain on full alert, the central center said.

Some 550 airlift missions were carried out in the period Aug. 8-Aug. 19, transporting 308,031 kilos of relief commodities, carrying 1,622 rescue personnel to disaster areas and evacuating 9,033 victims and 17 bodies, according to the center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Abandoning Neihu Line to save Muzha system `not impossible'

TEXT.P: Every possible way to fix the problem-plagued Taipei Mass Rapid Transit Muzha- Neihu Line will be taken into account, the Taipei City Deputy Secretary-General Tan Gwa-guang said Wednesday.
Tan made the remarks in response to reporters' questions about a local tabloid weekly report saying Mayor Hau Lung-bin intends to abandon the unstable Neihu Line in order to save the Muzha Line.

Tan declined to comment directly on the allegation, but confirmed that work to transform the Matra-built Muzha Line trains so that they can be used on the Neihu Line system constructed by Bombardier Inc. have been suspended.

He also announced that to allow Bombardier -- a Canadian company -- to fix the broken system, the Muzha-Neihu Line will be closed from 10 p.m. Aug. 21 to 6 a.m. Aug. 24, adding that free shuttle bus services will operate along the line during the suspension of services.

According to Tan, the city government has outlined a variety plans to address the problem for good, including shortening the service hours and shutting down the entire line until it can run without any hitches.
No matter which plan is adopted, passenger convenience will be the top priority, according to Tan.
The Neihu Line has been plagued with problems since it began commercial services July 4 and has been shut down several times due to system failures since then.
The latest closures occurred a day earlier, with three breakdowns on that day alone setting a new record.
The latest failures were the result of the crashing of a network communication system at the Dahu Park Station on the Neihu Line, Tan said, adding that the failed device had already been replaced.

The Neihu Line is a medium capacity system and runs on an elevated corridor except near Taipei Songshan Airport. It spans 14.8 km and connects with the 13 -year-old Muzha Line, providing transport services to Taipei's suburban areas of Neihu, Nangang and Muzha.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dogs, devices used in search of victim remains

TEXT.P: Dogs and various hi-tech devices were employed Wednesday to help military personnel locate and excavate the bodies of residents who perished in landslides caused by Typhoon Morakot in two villages in Kaohsiung County.

The military had previously had soldiers lie on ground to sniff possible smell as a way to locate the remains of the victims, a method which reportedly had caused severe stress disorder in some of the soldiers.
The Ministry of National Defense decided Tuesday to forbid the use of such a method.
Hu Jui-chou, director of political warfare of the Army's Eight Regiment, said Wednesday that health examination and psychological counseling will be provided to the soldiers as soon as possible.

Joining the search effort Wednesday were three rescue and relief dogs provided by the National Police Agency, five combustible gas detectors provided by the Veterans Affairs Commission, three ground penetrating radars provided by Ching Yun University and three methane detectors provided by the state-owned oil refiner CPC Corp, Hu said.

The animals and devices were delivered by helicopters to Siaolin village, where hundreds of residents were believed buried alive by landslides, and Xinkai village, where 32 people reportedly also died from the disaster, he said.
A civic team equipped with gas detectors and a global positioning system (GPS) also went to Xinkai village to help with the search.
Among the members of the team was an executive from Taiwan Survey Corp., who identified by his surname as Chang.
Chang explained that decaying bodies release various gases that can be detected by devices.
If suspicious gases are discovered, the team will use the GPS and paint spray to mark the locations where the gases are released to facilitate the military's excavation work, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet reshuffle set for early September: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Wednesday that President Ma Ying-jeou and he had reached consensus on conducting a general Cabinet reshuffle in early September, but he declined to comment on whether he will remain in his post.

Speaking at a press conference after a meeting of the Reconstruction Advancement Committee, Liu reiterated that for the moment, all government efforts should be dedicated to the post-Typhoon Morakot relief and reconstruction.

Turning to resignation tenders by Executive Yuan Secretary-General Hsieh Hsiang-chuan and Defense Minister Chen chao-min, the premier said decisions on their futures will be made as part of the overall reshuffle arrangements.

The two Cabinet officials are among those who have come under the heaviest criticism in the wake of the Morakot-triggered disaster that has caused dozens of deaths, left hundreds of people missing or injured, destroyed bridges, and buried entire villages in mud and debris, in addition to causing agricultural losses estimated at more than NT$13 billion.
Asking the public to have faith in the administration, Liu apologized for giving the impression that the Cabinet was negligent in its rescue and relief response.

DOC.HEADLINE: President mourns Siaolin victims, promises aid

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou visited the typhoon wreckage of Siaolin village in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County Wednesday, 12 days after the mountain settlement was obliterated by landslides triggered by Typhoon Morakot that pummeled Taiwan Aug.7-9.

Ma burned incense at the site of the village to pay tribute to the hundreds of its residents believed to have been buried alive when torrential rains spawned by the typhoon loosened the foundations of two nearby mountain slopes and sent their topsoil tumbling down onto the approximately 200 dwellings.

The president later met with survivors and consoled those who lost their loved ones in the disaster, as well as promising the allocation of NT$1 billion (US$30.30 million) in special budget to the Kaohsiung county government to help finance various restoration projects.

Many of the survivors besieged the president upon his arrival at an emergency placement center at the Lungfeng Temple in neighboring Jiasian township, some of whom unleashed a flood of complaints about his administration's procrastination in post-disaster rescue and relief operations.
Several told the president that they still have family members believed to be stranded in the mountains awaiting rescue.
"Please, President Ma, do a bit more for our missing family members," exclaimed one woman.
In response, Ma immediately directed military officers accompanying him on the trip to help with search and rescue efforts.
At a follow-up colloquium with Siaolin survivors, Ma bowed in apology for his administration's flaws in the post-diaster relief.
"I indeed came a bit late, " Ma admitted as he promised to do a better job in the future and to shoulder full responsibility for the blame.

He pledged to complete the rehabilitation of Siaolin village, peopled mainly by members of the unofficially recognized Pingpu aboriginal tribe, during his term as president and to help the survivors pick up the traces of their shattered lives.

After a suitable location is selected, construction of temporary prefabricated houses will be completed within one month for the resettlement of all the displaced survivors, Ma announced at the seminar.

Until the prefabs are erected, Ma went on, displaced villagers can rent houses in neighboring Jiasian township, with the government offering NT$6,000 (US$181.82) to NT$10,000 in rental subsidies per month for each household for up to two years, as well as subsidies for living expenses.

Addressing allegations that the devastating landslides were caused by dynamiting to build a water intake opening at the Tsengwen Reservoir to draw water from the Laonong River, along which Siaolin village nestles, Ma said he will ask the Control Yuan, the government's supreme supervisory arm, to investigate the case.
He also noted that the Kaohsiung Prosecutor's Office is already probing the case.

"We will get to the bottom of the matter to determine the cause and if the speculation is substantiated, the government will definitely shoulder full responsibility and offer due compensation in accordance with the existing law," Ma assured the petitioners.
On the issue of certifying the missing people as officially deceased, Ma said the Ministry of Justice will send prosecutors to Jiasian township to speed up the issuance of death certificates.

Turning to a proposal that a Siaolin village reconstruction fund be established, Ma said that as the project is part of the government's work agenda, it will be financed from the government's regular budget.
The proposal of turning the wreckage of Siaolin village into a memorial park, Ma said, will be integrated into the overall reconstruction project.

DOC.HEADLINE: Township willing to move into Chinese prefab houses if proved safe

TEXT.P: A township chief in southern Taiwan said Wednesday that if a batch of prefabricated houses donated by China in the wake of Typhoon Morakot prove to be safe, the townspeople are willing to move into them.

Lai Hsien-ho, the township head of Jiadong in Pingtung County, which was hit hard by the typhoon Aug. 7-9, did a swift U-turn just one day after saying the townspeople had misgivings about the prefab houses from China in the wake of reports that the units contain high levels of formaldehyde, a known carcinogenic.
The houses arrived in Kaohsiung Harbor Tuesday and were transported directly to Jiadong to help those displaced by Morakot.
Lai said later that day that the townspeople were worried that the formaldehyde levels in the prefabs could be harmful and therefore refused to move into them.

Lai said Wednesday that the Pingtung county government has been put in charge of the temporary homes and that county officials had told him that the units, which were temporarily placed along roadsides, will be tested to make sure they are safe for habitation.
"I asked the people of my town, and they also said that if tests prove that the houses are safe, they are willing to move in, " he added.

Meanwhile, Maa Shaw-chang, deputy secretary-general of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, said Wednesday that his Chinese counterpart, Ma Xiaoguang of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), had notified him a day earlier that the first 100 of the houses contain 0.02ppm formaldehyde and therefore do not pose a health hazard.
Maa said that although in China the safety limit for prefab houses is 0.08 ppm formaldehyde per square meter, the houses shipped to Taiwan contain the far lower level of 0.02ppm, according to ARATS.
Asked when the remaining 900 units will arrive, Maa said that this will be decided based on the needs of the typhoon-affected cities and counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei on its way to becoming 'garden city'

TEXT.P: Walking the streets of Taipei City, many pedestrians may have noticed a refreshing change: a touch of green is being added to homes and public facilities.

Walls, roofs and balconies are being turned into kaleidoscopic galleries for living plants in the run-up to the 2010 Taipei International Gardening and Horticulture Exposition -- the first accredited world-class exhibition ever held by Taiwan.

The greenery that will soon radiate from the 91.8-hectare exhibition area -- comprised of four public parks near the Keelung River -- is gradually extending to schools, commercial areas, markets, office buildings, and communities around the city.
Forming the backbone of this ambitious beautification initiative are 50 neighborhood greening projects that were completed in 2008, the first year of the plan.

With the public's interest in the campaign increasing, the city government has received 300 more requests for green renovation projects since the start of this year, according to the city's Department of Economic Development.

"The news spread fast: spots that used to be the ugliest in each neighborhood have become the most beautiful. Now applications are flooding in from almost every borough, " said Chen Hsiung-wen, commissioner of the department.

Once an application is approved, specialized landscaping engineers contracted by the city are assigned to carry out the project at the selected site. Also, garden accessories and ornamental plants are offered to households for display on their balconies.
The city government foots the bill for these services on one condition: that the participating neighborhoods form a volunteer team to care for the plants.

Although part of the motivation of the greening campaign is to promote the horticulture exposition, its more far-reaching mission is to increase citizen involvement in environmental landscaping and eventually transform Taipei into a permanent "garden city, " Chen said.
He explained that through the campaign, the city government is trying to instill an appreciation for plants among residents, further encouraging them to grow and cherish flowers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to subsidize students affected by typhoon disaster

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) will spare no effort to help students in the typhoon disaster areas return to school, and will also cover all their educational expenses, Minister Cheng Jei-cheng said Wednesday.

Addressing the issue during a visit to Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan, Cheng said 31 schools in southern Taiwan were severely damaged by flooding and landslides triggered by Typhoon Morakot when it swept through Taiwan last week.
Eight of the schools were either leveled or partially buried under mud and debris from landslides, he said.

As it has been determined that most of the damaged schools will not be able to reopen in time for the new school year in September, Cheng said, arrangements have been made for the students to attend other schools.
Teachers from the damaged schools have been given a directive to locate all the students and thus ensure that the children can start classes soon, he added.

The central government will pay tuition and other expenses for students in the disaster-hit areas, and will also subsidize those who lost their parents or were rendered homeless by the storm, Cheng said.

According to MOE figures, more than 1,300 schools in central and southern Taiwan were demolished or damaged by Morakot, which presented a challenge to education authorities in the effort to resettle the students.

Meanwhile, in discussions being held by government officials, experts and scholars on the reconstruction of damaged schools and other educational facilities, it has been suggested that smaller schools with six or fewer classes be closed down or merged.

Maximum resources should be put into rebuilding destroyed campuses and renovating old schools so that they can better withstand natural disasters such as storms and earthquakes, some commentators have suggested.
