In Tainan County such schools account for 40 percent of the total number, in Pintung County 30.72 percent, and in Kaohsiung County 29.61 percent, the figures show.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier orders acceleration of relief subsidies distribution

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan on Wednesday ordered government agencies to accelerate the distribution of relief subsidies to people suffering losses of family members and properties in floodings and landslides triggered by Typhoon Morakot.

Premier Liu gave the order when he convened the first meeting of the Reconstruction Advancement Committee. He stressed the urgency of delivering the relief subsidies and arranging resettlement for those hit by the disaster.

The central government has already allocated a total of NT$2.7 billion to the local governments of Pingtung, Kaohsiung, Tainan and Chiayi and Taitung Counties. The premier expected that at least 80 percent of the subsidies will be delivered within a week.
For those waiting for government relief subsidies to pay rent, the money should be delivered within three days, said the premier.

In a survey among villagers stricken homeless, 70 percent said they preferred to rent a place to live and pay for it with subsidies, while 30 percent said they would like to live in government-provided prefabricated houses or to wait for the government to arrange other housing options for them, according to the premier.

He added that the government has found eight locations suitable for building prefabricated houses, and the government will work with the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation in building 70 to 80 housing units first in two locations in Taitung County.

Statistics compiled by the Ministry of Economic Affairs show that a total of 136,401 households in southern and southeastern Taiwan were flooded and each is entitled to NT$20,000 in relief payments from the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese procurement mission arrives in Taiwan with huge orders

TEXT.P: A Chinese procurement mission arrived in Taipei Wednesday with plans to purchase more than US$1.2 billion worth of machinery, petrochemical and textile goods.

The group, the fourth of its kind from China so far this year, came at a time when Taiwan is trying to dig itself out of the rubble left by Typhoon Morakot, which lashed Taiwan with strong winds and torrential rains Aug.7-9.

The mission, organized by the Association of Economy and Trade Across the Taiwan Straits (AETATS), is composed of more than 100 executives representing 55 major Chinese enterprises, including Chongqing Hybest Air Tools and Kingfa Sci & Tech Co.
The delegation is headed by AETATS Vice President Tang Wei who concurrently headed the Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau affairs Department under China's Ministry of Commerce.

The AETATS, an affiliate of China's Ministry of Commerce, is tasked with promoting commercial exchanges and economic cooperation with Taiwan. It has organized two previous procurement missions to Taiwan this year.

Lin Li-kai, a section chief at the Taiwan External Trade and Development Council (TAITRA), said the delegation will purchase a variety of products that Taiwanese manufacturers are competing keenly to supply.

The products will include machinery, electronics and chemical engineering equipment, garments and footwear. The buyers will also seek to purchase auto parts and components in line with China's "automobiles to the countryside" project that is part of its economic stimulus package.

As some companies in southern and central Taiwan are still recovering from serious flooding triggered by the storm, Lin said, they may not be able to send executives to Taipei to participate in the one-to-one sessions with prospective Chinese buyers.
Against this backdrop, Lin said, TAITRA has posted special application forms on its Web site to allow such companies to introduce their products and present their corporate profiles.
"The TAITRA will help disseminate relevant information in an effort to help those companies forge links with the companies represented on the Chinese procurement mission," Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Four initiatives unveiled for post-disaster reconstruction

TEXT.P: An ad hoc committee tasked with planning rehabilitation work in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot came up with four reconstruction packages Wednesday, focusing on land conservation, infrastructure construction, resettlement and industrial revival.
The four packages were finalized at the first working meeting of the ad hoc committee, which was chaired by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan.
Liu said at a news conference held after the meeting that the focus of the post- disaster rehabilitation work will now gradually shift from rescue and resettlement to reconstruction.
"The national land conservation package, drafted by the Council for Economic Planning and Development, will serve as the main guidelines for all reconstruction projects, " Liu said.
Protection of the natural environment is very important to the prevention of natural disasters, given Taiwan's unique climate and topography, he added.

The infrastructure construction package spells out guidelines for repair and restoration of broken highways and bridges and reinforcement of flood-control systems and management mechanisms, work that will be carried out by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Liu said.

The resettlement package will focus on helping displaced typhoon survivors rebuild their communities and establish permanent settlements, Liu said, adding that the Ministry of the Interior will be responsible for that task.

The industrial revival package will promote the development of industries and services suited to the hardest-hit disaster zones, including tourism, creative cultural industries and high-end agriculture.

It was also decided at the meeting that Minister-without-Portfolio Tsai Hsun-hsiung will serve as the committee's chief executive and Veterans Affairs Commission Minister Kao Hua-chu will head the committee's branch in southern Taiwan, which was the hardest hit area when Morakot lashed Taiwan with strong winds and heavy rains Aug.7-9, Liu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shenzhen Airlines donates funds to help restore Alishan area

TEXT.P: Shenzhen Airlines of China donated NT$10 million (US$302,000) to Taiwan Monday, saying that it hopes the money will be used to help restore the Alishan scenic area, one of the most popular tourist attractions among Chinese visitors to Taiwan.
Shenzhen Airlines President Li Kun presented the donation during a cocktail party held to celebrate the company's establishment of a branch in Taiwan.
Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai accepted the money and thanked the donor on behalf of the Taiwan government.

Lai said Taiwan is as beautiful as ever, despite the devastation wrought by Typhoon Morakot, which triggered massive flooding and landslides last week in southern Taiwan and caused devastation in many mountain villages that were popular among local sightseers.

However, most of the areas that foreign tourists find attractive were untouched by the storm, she said, noting that the Alishan forest recreation area, at an altitude of 2,200 meters to 2,500 meters in the greater Alishan National Scenic Area, was one such site.

Although the 1,400-hectare forest recreation site was spared by the typhoon, there was heavy damage to the roads, the popular alpine railway that serves the area, and some of the sightseeing spots along route.

According to the Directorate General of Highways, the heavily damaged Alishan Highway -- the main road to the forest recreation area -- will not be able to accommodate traffic again until late September.

Parts of the highway have caved in and the roadbed has been eroded in many spots. Also, sections of the Alishan Railway have been washed away by floods, some tunnels on the line have caved in, and some road beds have disappeared completely.
Yen Mao-sheng, the official in charge of railway construction at the Chiayi Forest District Office, has estimated that it would take at least a year to repair the railway.
Alishan is one of the must-see sites for visitors from China, and has attracted several thousand Chinese tourists a day since March.
Two other Chinese carriers -- China Southern Airlines and Air China -- have also made donations to help with Taiwan's relief work in the aftermath of the typhoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: President will not take up KMT chairmanship until Oct. 17

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang will postpone its 18th national party congress from Sept. 12 to Oct. 17, which means President Ma Ying-jeou will not take over as party chairman until October, KMT spokesman Lee Chien-jung said Wednesday.

According to Lee, Ma himself took the initiative to have the KMT national congress postponed to October so that he can focus his efforts on the rehabilitation work in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot.
"President Ma phoned outgoing KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung Tuesday to ask for Wu's consent on the matter," Lee said.

The telephone conversation took place shortly after Ma hosted Chinese- and English-language news conferences the same day to brief the local and international news media on his administration's post-typhoon response projects amid mounting criticism over flaws in the rescue and relief work.
Acting on Ma's request, Wu brought up the proposal for discussion Wednesday at the weekly meeting of the party's decision-making Central Standing Committee.

It was unanimously agreed at the meeting that the party's 18th national congress would be postponed until Oct.17, at which time Ma will take over from Wu as chairman, in accordance with the KMT charter.

In line with that decision, the party's election of Central Committee members will also be postponed from Aug.22 to Sept. 27 and the election of its Central Standing Committee members deferred from Sept. 6 to Oct. 11, Lee said.
Ma won the party's chairmanship in an unchallenged election July 26.

He was first elected KMT chairman July 17, 2005, but he resigned from the post Feb.13, 2007 after he was indicted on charges of misusing public funds during his tenure as Taipei mayor from 1998-2006. He was cleared of the charges before assuming the presidency in May 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. congressmen to visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: Howard Berman, chairman of the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Foreign Affairs, and four other members of the House will arrive in Taiwan Thursday for a three-day visit, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday in a press release.
Congressman Berman, along with his colleagues Eni F.H. Faleomavaega, Jack Kingston, Ruben Hinojosa and Diane Watson, will travel to the island on a U.S. military aircraft, the MOFA said.
Faleomavaega is also the chair of the Asia-Pacific caucus of the congressional committee.
The MOFA said the visit by the U.S. members of Congress in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot reflects the deep regard the U.S. Congress has for Taiwan.

During their stay from Aug. 20 to 22, they will call on President Ma Ying-jeou, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, National Security Council Secretary- General Su Chi, Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco Ou and other government officials to exchange views on issues of mutual concern, the MOFA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President mourns Siaolin victims, promises aid

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou visited the typhoon wreckage of Siaolin village in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County Wednesday, 12 days after the mountain settlement was obliterated by landslides triggered by Typhoon Morakot that pummeled Taiwan Aug.7-9.

Ma burned incense at the site of the village to pay tribute to the hundreds of its residents believed to have been buried alive when torrential rains spawned by the typhoon loosened the foundations of two nearby mountain slopes and sent their topsoil tumbling down onto the approximately 200 dwellings.

The president later met with survivors and consoled those who lost their loved ones in the disaster, as well as promising the allocation of NT$1 billion (US$30.30 million) in special budget to the Kaohsiung county government to help finance various restoration projects.

Many of the survivors besieged the president upon his arrival at an emergency placement center at the Lungfeng Temple in neighboring Jiasian township, some of whom unleashed a flood of complaints about his administration's procrastination in post-disaster rescue and relief operations.
Several told the president that they still have family members believed to be stranded in the mountains awaiting rescue.
"Please, President Ma, do a bit more for our missing family members," exclaimed one woman.
In response, Ma immediately directed military officers accompanying him on the trip to help with search and rescue efforts.
At a follow-up colloquium with Siaolin survivors, Ma bowed in apology for his administration's flaws in the post-diaster relief.
"I indeed came a bit late, " Ma admitted as he promised to do a better job in the future and to shoulder full responsibility for the blame.

He pledged to complete the rehabilitation of Siaolin village, peopled mainly by members of the unofficially recognized Pingpu aboriginal tribe, during his term as president and to help the survivors pick up the traces of their shattered lives.

After a suitable location is selected, construction of temporary prefabricated houses will be completed within one month for the resettlement of all the displaced survivors, Ma announced at the seminar.

Until the prefabs are erected, Ma went on, displaced villagers can rent houses in neighboring Jiasian township, with the government offering NT$6,000 (US$181.82) to NT$10,000 in rental subsidies per month for each household for up to two years, as well as subsidies for living expenses.

Addressing allegations that the devastating landslides were caused by dynamiting to build a water intake opening at the Tsengwen Reservoir to draw water from the Laonong River, along which Siaolin village nestles, Ma said he will ask the Control Yuan, the government's supreme supervisory arm, to investigate the case.
He also noted that the Kaohsiung Prosecutor's Office is already probing the case.

"We will get to the bottom of the matter to determine the cause and if the speculation is substantiated, the government will definitely shoulder full responsibility and offer due compensation in accordance with the existing law," Ma assured the petitioners.
On the issue of certifying the missing people as officially deceased, Ma said the Ministry of Justice will send prosecutors to Jiasian township to speed up the issuance of death certificates.

Turning to a proposal that a Siaolin village reconstruction fund be established, Ma said that as the project is part of the government's work agenda, it will be financed from the government's regular budget.
The proposal of turning the wreckage of Siaolin village into a memorial park, Ma said, will be integrated into the overall reconstruction project.

DOC.HEADLINE: Township willing to move into Chinese prefab houses if proved safe

TEXT.P: A township chief in southern Taiwan said Wednesday that if a batch of prefabricated houses donated by China in the wake of Typhoon Morakot prove to be safe, the townspeople are willing to move into them.

Lai Hsien-ho, the township head of Jiadong in Pingtung County, which was hit hard by the typhoon Aug. 7-9, did a swift U-turn just one day after saying the townspeople had misgivings about the prefab houses from China in the wake of reports that the units contain high levels of formaldehyde, a known carcinogenic.
The houses arrived in Kaohsiung Harbor Tuesday and were transported directly to Jiadong to help those displaced by Morakot.
Lai said later that day that the townspeople were worried that the formaldehyde levels in the prefabs could be harmful and therefore refused to move into them.

Lai said Wednesday that the Pingtung county government has been put in charge of the temporary homes and that county officials had told him that the units, which were temporarily placed along roadsides, will be tested to make sure they are safe for habitation.
"I asked the people of my town, and they also said that if tests prove that the houses are safe, they are willing to move in, " he added.

Meanwhile, Maa Shaw-chang, deputy secretary-general of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, said Wednesday that his Chinese counterpart, Ma Xiaoguang of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), had notified him a day earlier that the first 100 of the houses contain 0.02ppm formaldehyde and therefore do not pose a health hazard.
Maa said that although in China the safety limit for prefab houses is 0.08 ppm formaldehyde per square meter, the houses shipped to Taiwan contain the far lower level of 0.02ppm, according to ARATS.
Asked when the remaining 900 units will arrive, Maa said that this will be decided based on the needs of the typhoon-affected cities and counties.

Parts of the highway have caved in and the roadbed has been eroded in many spots. Also, sections of the Alishan Railway have been washed away by floods, some tunnels on the line have caved in, and some road beds have disappeared completely.
Yen Mao-sheng, the official in charge of railway construction at the Chiayi Forest District Office, has estimated that it would take at least a year to repair the railway.
Alishan is one of the must-see sites for visitors from China, and has attracted several thousand Chinese tourists a day since March.
Two other Chinese carriers -- China Southern Airlines and Air China -- have also made donations to help with Taiwan's relief work in the aftermath of the typhoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: President will not take up KMT chairmanship until Oct. 17

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang will postpone its 18th national party congress from Sept. 12 to Oct. 17, which means President Ma Ying-jeou will not take over as party chairman until October, KMT spokesman Lee Chien-jung said Wednesday.

According to Lee, Ma himself took the initiative to have the KMT national congress postponed to October so that he can focus his efforts on the rehabilitation work in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot.
"President Ma phoned outgoing KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung Tuesday to ask for Wu's consent on the matter," Lee said.

The telephone conversation took place shortly after Ma hosted Chinese- and English-language news conferences the same day to brief the local and international news media on his administration's post-typhoon response projects amid mounting criticism over flaws in the rescue and relief work.
Acting on Ma's request, Wu brought up the proposal for discussion Wednesday at the weekly meeting of the party's decision-making Central Standing Committee.

It was unanimously agreed at the meeting that the party's 18th national congress would be postponed until Oct.17, at which time Ma will take over from Wu as chairman, in accordance with the KMT charter.

In line with that decision, the party's election of Central Committee members will also be postponed from Aug.22 to Sept. 27 and the election of its Central Standing Committee members deferred from Sept. 6 to Oct. 11, Lee said.
Ma won the party's chairmanship in an unchallenged election July 26.

He was first elected KMT chairman July 17, 2005, but he resigned from the post Feb.13, 2007 after he was indicted on charges of misusing public funds during his tenure as Taipei mayor from 1998-2006. He was cleared of the charges before assuming the presidency in May 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. congressmen to visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: Howard Berman, chairman of the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Foreign Affairs, and four other members of the House will arrive in Taiwan Thursday for a three-day visit, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday in a press release.
Congressman Berman, along with his colleagues Eni F.H. Faleomavaega, Jack Kingston, Ruben Hinojosa and Diane Watson, will travel to the island on a U.S. military aircraft, the MOFA said.
Faleomavaega is also the chair of the Asia-Pacific caucus of the congressional committee.
The MOFA said the visit by the U.S. members of Congress in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot reflects the deep regard the U.S. Congress has for Taiwan.

During their stay from Aug. 20 to 22, they will call on President Ma Ying-jeou, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, National Security Council Secretary- General Su Chi, Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco Ou and other government officials to exchange views on issues of mutual concern, the MOFA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Four initiatives unveiled for post-disaster reconstruction

TEXT.P: An ad hoc committee tasked with planning rehabilitation work in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot came up with four reconstruction packages Wednesday, focusing on land conservation, infrastructure construction, resettlement and industrial revival.
The four packages were finalized at the first working meeting of the ad hoc committee, which was chaired by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan.
Liu said at a news conference held after the meeting that the focus of the post- disaster rehabilitation work will now gradually shift from rescue and resettlement to reconstruction.
"The national land conservation package, drafted by the Council for Economic Planning and Development, will serve as the main guidelines for all reconstruction projects, " Liu said.
Protection of the natural environment is very important to the prevention of natural disasters, given Taiwan's unique climate and topography, he added.

The infrastructure construction package spells out guidelines for repair and restoration of broken highways and bridges and reinforcement of flood-control systems and management mechanisms, work that will be carried out by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Liu said.

The resettlement package will focus on helping displaced typhoon survivors rebuild their communities and establish permanent settlements, Liu said, adding that the Ministry of the Interior will be responsible for that task.

The industrial revival package will promote the development of industries and services suited to the hardest-hit disaster zones, including tourism, creative cultural industries and high-end agriculture.

It was also decided at the meeting that Minister-without-Portfolio Tsai Hsun-hsiung will serve as the committee's chief executive and Veterans Affairs Commission Minister Kao Hua-chu will head the committee's branch in southern Taiwan, which was the hardest hit area when Morakot lashed Taiwan with strong winds and heavy rains Aug.7-9, Liu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shenzhen Airlines donates funds to help restore Alishan area

TEXT.P: Shenzhen Airlines of China donated NT$10 million (US$302,000) to Taiwan Monday, saying that it hopes the money will be used to help restore the Alishan scenic area, one of the most popular tourist attractions among Chinese visitors to Taiwan.
Shenzhen Airlines President Li Kun presented the donation during a cocktail party held to celebrate the company's establishment of a branch in Taiwan.
Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai accepted the money and thanked the donor on behalf of the Taiwan government.

Lai said Taiwan is as beautiful as ever, despite the devastation wrought by Typhoon Morakot, which triggered massive flooding and landslides last week in southern Taiwan and caused devastation in many mountain villages that were popular among local sightseers.

However, most of the areas that foreign tourists find attractive were untouched by the storm, she said, noting that the Alishan forest recreation area, at an altitude of 2,200 meters to 2,500 meters in the greater Alishan National Scenic Area, was one such site.

Although the 1,400-hectare forest recreation site was spared by the typhoon, there was heavy damage to the roads, the popular alpine railway that serves the area, and some of the sightseeing spots along route.

According to the Directorate General of Highways, the heavily damaged Alishan Highway -- the main road to the forest recreation area -- will not be able to accommodate traffic again until late September.

Parts of the highway have caved in and the roadbed has been eroded in many spots. Also, sections of the Alishan Railway have been washed away by floods, some tunnels on the line have caved in, and some road beds have disappeared completely.
Yen Mao-sheng, the official in charge of railway construction at the Chiayi Forest District Office, has estimated that it would take at least a year to repair the railway.
Alishan is one of the must-see sites for visitors from China, and has attracted several thousand Chinese tourists a day since March.
Two other Chinese carriers -- China Southern Airlines and Air China -- have also made donations to help with Taiwan's relief work in the aftermath of the typhoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 20, or the first day of the seventh month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1741: Danish explorer Vitus Bering discovers Alaska on a mission sponsored by Russia.
1833: Benjamin Harrison, the 23rd president of the United States, is born. The first Pan-American Conference took place (1889) during his administration, which passed the Sherman Anti-Trust Act in 1890.
1860: Raymond Poincare, French statesman and president from 1913 to 1920, is born.
1905: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who had been exiled for his involvement in the anti-Ching movement, organizes the Revolution Alliance in Tokyo. The organization, headed by Dr. Sun, sponsored an entire network of revolutionaries inside China.
1912: William Booth, British religious leader who founded the Salvation Army in 1878, dies at the age of 83.
1925: Liao Chung-kai, one of a 16-member steering committee that established a national government in July 1925, is assassinated in Canton, five months after the demise of Dr. Sun Yat-sen in Peking. Liao was 47.
1928: Both the Wen River and the Mi River in the province of Shantung overflow their banks, drowning 18,000 people and leaving some 30,000 others homeless.
1940: A total of 153 Japanese military aircraft carry out a heavy bombing raid on Chungking, the war-time capital of the Republic of China.
1940: Radar is used for the first time, with the British employing it during World War II.
1940: Leon Trotsky, one of the leaders of the Russian Revolution, is stabbed to death by a Spanish communist with an alpine ax in his home in Coyoacan, near Mexico City. He was 61.
1944: Representatives of China, the United States, the United Kingdom and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics meet in Washington, D.C., to discuss the establishment of a world organization after World War II.
1944: Rajiv Gandhi, former Indian prime minister, is born. The son of Indira Gandhi was assassinated on May 21, 1991.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek sends a second invitation to Mao Tse-tung after inviting him to come to Chungking for a conference on Aug. 14, 1945.
1955: Gen. Sun Li-jen, chief military aide to the president, submits a request for disciplinary action against himself as a gesture of self-reproach in regard to a communist espionage case involving Kuo Ting-liang.
1967: A total of 247 people, including Taipei City Councilor Lin Shui-chuan, are arrested for attempting to stage an armed rebellion for Taiwan independence.
1968: Soviet and Warsaw Pact troops begin the invasion of Czechoslovakia in an attempt to crush the "Prague Spring" reforms.
1972: The Republic of China Mei Ho baseball team defeats a U.S. team from California 9-0 to win the Senior League world title.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Richard Lugar, chairman of the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Lugar says that the U.S. government has not changed its basic support of the Republic of China and that he hopes the ROC will open its markets to reduce the ROC-US trade deficit.
1988: A U.N.-mediated cease-fire between Iran and Iraq takes effect, ending nearly eight years of war.
1995: An express train collides with another train in northern India, killing nearly 300 passengers and injuring more than 200 others.
1999: The Central Bank of China announces that Taiwan's second-quarter balance of international payments surplus amounted to US$5.47 billion, the highest single-quarter total in 12 years.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his delegation arrive in Gambia at the start of his one-week, three-nation African tour which will also take him to Burkina Faso and Chad.
2001: Taiwan's Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation makes its 300th bone marrow donation, with the recipient a college student in Hangzhou City, in mainland China's Zhejiang Province.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to sift out, but when you once try to sift out a thing, you must never give it up until you have sifted it out clearly and distinctly."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's semiconductor output expected to decline 13% in 2009

TEXT.P: The production value of Taiwan's semiconductor sector is expected to amount to NT$1.14 trillion (US$34.55 billion) for 2009, down 13 percent from last year, the Institute for Information Industry (III) forecast Thursday.

Supply and demand in the sector returned to normal in the second quarter of the year following rapid inventory adjustments in the first quarter when the sector bottomed out, according to the III's Market Intelligence and Consulting Institute (MIC).

The output of the contract chipmaking industry, which was estimated at NT$52.5 billion in the first quarter, is projected to reach NT$100 billion in the second quarter and increase further to NT$115.2 billion in the third quarter, the MIC said.
It said the industry's total production value is likely to reach NT$375.5 billion for the whole year.

The dynamic random access memory (DRAM) industry, which saw its production value plummet by 40 percent in the first half of 2009 from the previous six months, is expected to get a boost in the second half from seasonal demand, the MIC said, predicting that the industry's output will amount to NT$111.4 billion for the whole year.
Meanwhile, the IC design industry will continue to grow in the third quarter and is likely to see its output amount to NT$370.2 billion for the whole year, the MIC said.
The industry was already showing signs of recovery in the first quarter and posted a 30 percent quarter-on-quarter growth in the second quarter, according to the MIC.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three science parks' revenues fall more than 38% in 1st half of year

TEXT.P: The total revenues of companies in Taiwan's three science parks fell by more than 38 percent in the first half of 2009 as a result of the global recession, the National Science Council (NSC) reported Thursday.

Total turnover at the Hsinchu Science Park in northern Taiwan, the Central Taiwan Science Park and the Southern Taiwan Science Park amounted to NT$631.4 billion (US$19.13 billion) in the first six months of this year, representing a year-on-year decline of 38.2 percent, said NSC Vice Chairman Chen Li-chun at a news conference Wednesday.
A chart of the three science parks' total revenues between January 2008 and June 2009 shows that the revenues bottomed out in January 2009 and began a gradual rise, Chen said.
The chart showed that the parks' revenues amounted to NT$377.2 billion in the second quarter of this year, representing an increase of 48.3 percent from the first quarter, he noted.
"Judging from that trend, the revenues of the three science parks would continue to rise in July and August," he forecast.

IC companies were the mainstays of the three parks, contributing NT$316.3 billion, or 50.1 percent, to the total revenues in the first half of the year. This was a decline of 34.9 percent compared to the same period last year, according to NSC statistics.

Optoelectronic companies were the second largest contributors, generating NT$254.7 billion, or 40.3 percent of the three parks' revenues during the six- month period. The figure was a year-on-year drop of 43.7 percent.
The third largest group, computer and peripheral companies, contributed NT$27.7 billion in revenues to the total, a drop of 34.3 percent from the same period in 2008, the tallies showed.

Between January and June this year, Chen said, 20 new investment projects worth NT$6.6 billion were approved for the three parks, while 20 companies increased their investment capital by a total of NT$8.1 billion.
In July alone, 12 newly approved companies became operational in the three parks, while 10 companies increased their investment capital, Chen noted.

As of the end of June, 689 companies had been approved to operate in the three parks -- the backbone of Taiwan's industrial development -- with 446 to be located in the Hsinchu Science Park, 151 in the Southern Taiwan Science Park, and 92 in the Central Taiwan Science Park, according to NSC officials.
As of June 30, the three parks had a workforce of 194,096 people, down 5,353 from the figure posted at the end of 2008, mainly as a result of the global economic crunch, NSC officials said.
As of Aug. 1, the number of workers on unpaid leave at the three parks had dropped to 22,013, representing a sharp increase over the figure of 128,304 reported in January.
By Aug. 16, the number of workers on furlough had declined further to 14,697, according to the latest NSC tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of H1N1 clusters rises to 48

TEXT.P: Taiwan's health authorities have confirmed five more clusters of influenza A(H1N1) infection, bringing to 48 the total number on record.
Among the five latest clusters reported Wednesday by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC), two were at hospitals, two at junior high schools and one at an after-school care center.

In the cluster at National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) , flu-like symptoms were reported among 11 healthcare workers, four of whom were diagnosed with the new strain of influenza, CDC Deputy Director-General Lin Ting said.
The other cluster was discovered at a teaching hospital in southern Taiwan, where 18 healthcare workers came down with flu-like symptoms, Lin said.
Five of the 10 people who were tested for the A(H1N1) virus came up positive, he said.

Also on Wednesday, three cases of severe influenza A(H1N1) infection were reported. They were a 45-year-old female patient at NTUH, a six-year-old boy with acute lymphoid leukemia and a seven-year-old girl with ventricular septal defect.
The CDC is investigating whether there is a connection between the patient at NTUH and the cluster of infections there.
The three latest cases bring the number of severe infections recorded in Taiwan to 28, according to the CDC.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA checks safety of prefab houses donated by China

TEXT.P: Two prefabricated houses in a batch donated by China in the wake of Typhoon Morakot were erected in an open area in Pingtung County Thursday for the purpose of testing the materials for hazardous content.

A group of specialists from the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) went to Pingtung to check the indoor air quality of the two prefab houses that were erected in Pingtung County's Jiadong township, the EPA said.

Based on concerns that the first 100 prefabricated houses donated by China might contain high levels of formaldehyde, a known carcinogenic, EPA officials said that the materials will be tested and the results publicized on Aug. 22.

Ten containers of prefab housing materials arrived in Kaohsiung Harbor Tuesday and were transported directly to Jiadong as aid to people affected Typhoon Morakot, which triggered the worst flooding in Taiwan in half a century.

The death toll from the storm rose to 141 as of noon Thursday. Another 440 remained unaccounted for and 45 were reported injured. Jiadong was one of the areas in southern Taiwan hardest hit by the storm, which lashed Taiwan Aug.7-9.
"All 100 prefab houses will be erected if the first two prove safe for habitation," said township chief Lai Hsien-ho.

The comment was an about-face by Lai, who said two days ago that the townspeople were concerned about the safety of the units, in light of reports that the materials contained high levels of formaldehyde. He added that the townspeople had therefore said they would not occupy the houses.
Meanwhile, Lai said, his office has asked Rotary International Taiwan to donate another 150 prefab houses.
Even if the 100 units from China are all erected, Jiandong will still be 50 houses short, he said, noting that some 300 families in the township were rendered homeless by the storm.
He added that his office has been negotiating with Taiwan Sugar Corp. for about 7-8 hectares of land on which to erect the prefab houses for the flood victims.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's economy expected to grow 3 percent in 2010: gov't

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy will grow 3 percent or higher next year, following a gradual recovery in the global economy, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Thursday.

The growth of the domestic economy is likely to turn from negative to positive next year, thanks to the lower comparison basis of 2009 and a possible rebound in major global economies, the DGBAS said.
For this year, however, DGBAS officials forecasted that the growth rate would not be significant if there were any.

The officials said Typhoon Morakot, which pummeled Taiwan Aug. 7-9 with the worst flooding in Taiwan in 50 years, will drag down the domestic economy in the third quarter because of the massive destruction it wreaked.

However, they said, the outlook for Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) in the fourth quarter is not necessarily "pessimistic," given that huge governmental funds and resources expected to be channeled into post-disaster reconstruction efforts might rev up economic growth.

"There are chances that the GDP might register positive growth in Q4 as a result of the reconstruction work, which will generate new demand, investment and employment, and as a result of the recovery of the global economies," they forecasted.
"However, the growth range would not be significant," they noted.
Taiwan's government officials have said post-typhoon reconstruction could cost NT$100 billion (US$3 billion) and take as long as three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Undergrads to help clean up flooded schools in Chiayi

TEXT.P: Students from National Chiayi University (NCYU) will help clean up two of the local elementary schools in the county affected by Typhoon Morakot, the university said Thursday.

Data provided by Chiayi County's Education Department shows that nine elementary schools with a total of 409 students in the county's mountainous townships will not be able to reopen in time for the start of the new school year on Sept. 1, mainly because most of them are covered in mud in the wake of the storm.
The Ministry of Education has encouraged undergraduates to join the clean up efforts at the affected schools.
NCYU officials said more than 30 students from the university have registered to help clean up Taiho Elementary School in Meishan township and Chungho Elementary School in Jhuci township.

After mountain roads damaged by the typhoon have been repaired, the volunteer students will be divided into two teams and sent to the schools to undertake jobs such as tidying up and disinfecting the environment and repairing damaged computers and machines, the officials said.
The students will also provide tutoring and psychological counseling to the elementary school children during holidays and vacations, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2009 British Food Fair to open Saturday

TEXT.P: The 2009 British Food Fair, organized by the Taipei-based British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO), will open on Saturday, featuring over 100 kinds of food products imported from the United Kingdom, officials said.

Co-organized by the trade office and City' Super supermarket, the food fair will take place from Aug. 22 to Sept. 4 at three City' Super branch stores in Taipei with over 100 new products specially sourced from the UK, including drinks, sauces, tea, biscuits and chocolate.

Together with Tony Liu, CEO of CitySuper, BTCO Director David Campbell will attend the opening ceremony Saturday. Campbell will also act as a one-day shop supervisor to introduce the new products from Britain to customers.
Clare Lear, from the British Assistance and Services Section of the BTCO, will demonstrate how to use these products to make an elegant British afternoon tea and snacks.

There are many other exciting new food products from the UK, so you can spend your weekend at CitySuper, indulging in some British food shopping, the BTCO said on the event Web site, urging the public to participate.

In addition, visitors to the food fair will have the opportunity to try English afternoon tea with a special 10 percent discount at the Wedgwood Tearoom when they shop at CitySuper supermarket, according to the BTCO.

They will also have the opportunity to win prizes, including a Taipei-UK round- trip ticket, Brompton Baby Pink bicycle, Dyson vacuum cleaner and entrance tickets to the Pixar 20th anniversary exhibition, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Students who contracted H1N1 flu in South Korea return to Taiwan

TEXT.P: A total of 237 Taiwanese students, several of whom tested positive for the A (H1N1) influenza virus in South Korea, returned to Taiwan Thursday on two charter flights arranged by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

The 238-member group, which is composed of tour guides as well as students and teachers from National Taiwan Normal University, Kuang Hwa Junior High School in Hsinchu City, and Er Chong Junior High School in Hsinchu County were in South Korea to attend the 14th Jeju International Wind Ensemble Festival.

The group was quarantined in a resort on Jeju island after some members of the group developed high fevers on Aug. 17. Fifteen members of the group were later confirmed to have the H1N1 flu, also known as swine flu.
Apart from one tour guide who flew to Italy, the group returned to Taiwan Thursday morning on two TransAsia Airways charter flights.
The 15 confirmed H1N1 cases will receive necessary treatment while the rest will be quarantined and monitored.

James Chang, deputy spokesman for the Foreign Ministry, denied at a regular press briefing Thursday accusations made by some teachers that the ministry acted slowly in providing assistance to the group.

Chang said that officials from the Foreign Ministrys representative office in Seoul and Busan immediately went to Jeju on Aug. 18 and 19, respectively, upon learning that 15 of the students had H1N1 flu.
Chang said the officials reported the situation to the Centers for Disease Control in Taiwan, and asked it to send doctors.
At the same time, the ministry also contacted TransAsia Airways to arrange charter flights to transport the group back to Taiwan, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Thursday:
Liberty Times:
Ma Ying-jeou should step down, Liu Chao-shiuan should resign over their bungled rescue operation.
President Ma Ying-jeou's approval rate has plunged to 16 percent, while Premier Liu Chao-shiuan's has dived to 13 percent in the wake of Typhoon Morakot.
We are not surprised, because Ma has a record of incompetence in most of the political posts he has held.
As there are still two more years to go before Ma's term expires, we call on him to resign and spare the people the ordeal of his botched leadership.
As to Premier Liu, he should step down immediately if he still has a conscience.
United Daily News:
Let us remember the noble spirit of these people
The funerals of two of the three helicopter crew members who died in the line of duty were held yesterday.
The daughter of the deceased pilot Chang Shun-fa told journalists proudly that her father gave his life for his work.
In another case, a volunteer firefighter Chang Jui-hsiang drowned while searching for survivors in a car that had fallen into a river in a bridge collapse during the onslaught of Typhoon Morakot.

Chang, a survivor of the Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake, was still paying back loans that he had taken to rebuild his house after it was damaged in the earthquake. During the typhoon, he took leave from his job at a factory to join the rescue efforts.
The flooding brought about by Morakot revealed many facets of human character. Let us not forget the heroes we mentioned above, as their noble and courageous acts uplift the world.
China Times:
Ma's administration needs constructive purge
The shortcomings of President Ma's administration have been fully exposed by Typhoon Morakot.
Ma's aloofness toward the public could hardly be offset by Premier Liu Chao- shiuan because the two are similar in terms of educational background and character.

Natural disasters are not unusual in the world. Former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani earned a reputation as good leader because of his competence in the aftermath of the terror attack on the city Sept. 11, 2001.
President Ma, on the other hand, has become a lightning rod for criticism in the wake of Typhoon Morakot.
For this reason, a Cabinet reshuffle is an inevitable, though detrimental, decision for Ma, but we hope it will be conducive to better approval ratings for the president.
Apple Daily:
Incompetent officials, get off your posts quickly please
12 days after Typhoon Morakot cut a swathe through the island, only Deputy Foreign Ministry Andrew Hsia resigned. No others follow suit.

President Ma has vowed to keep the stability of his administration by refraining from replacing Cabinet members too often, but his pledge offered a shelter for the many incompetent officials in his administration.
With the popularity of Premier Liu Chao-shiuan's administration dipping to the nadir, the possibility of a Cabinet reshuffle is looming large.
We call on the president to replace these incompetent officials in one stroke.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese procurement group donates money for disaster relief

TEXT.P: A group Chinese buyers who arrived in Taipei Wednesday donated 3 million yuan (US$438,981) for disaster relief in Taiwan, and plans to purchase US$900 million worth of Taiwanese goods, the head of the delegation said at a news conference Thursday.

The group, the third of its kind to be organized by Beijing's Association of Economy and Trade Across the Taiwan Straits (AETATS) this year, arrived at a time when Taiwan is trying to dig itself out of the rubble left by Typhoon Morakot.
The mission is composed of more than 120 executives representing 55 major Chinese enterprises, including Lenovo Group Ltd, Chongqing Hybest Air Tools and Kingfa Sci & Tech Co.
The delegation is being led by AETATS Vice President Tang Wei who is also head of the Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Department under China's Ministry of Commerce.

Tang Wei stressed that the donation was a compassionate rather than a political gesture. It was also offered in return for Taiwan's kindness and generosity during China's Sichuan Earthquake last year, he said.

His comment was a reference to the fact that two days after a 7.8 magnitude temblor struck Sichuan Province in May last year killing more than 14,000 people, Taiwan's Red Cross Society mustered NT$70 million (US$2.27 million) in donations for disaster relief. The Taiwan government also donated a total of NT$2 billion (US$65.57 million) to the effort.

At the news conference Thursday, the Chinese delegation also presented Taiwan with a Chinese calligraphy piece bearing the words "Faith Is More Precious Than Gold," a biblical quote that is often used by Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao.
The group handed over the cash donation to the Taiwan External Trade Development Council, which will pass it on to the relevant agencies soon.
The delegation has begun one-on-one sessions with Taiwanese buyers, and plans to purchase US$900 million worth of machinery, petrochemical and textile goods.

The first Chinese procurement mission organized by the AETATS visited Taiwan in June and placed more than US$2.2 billion worth of orders for computers, television sets and other home appliances. The goods have already been shipped to China.
The second AETATS group was in Taiwan July 12-17 to buy US$700 million worth of specialty foods, giftware, daily necessities and handicrafts.

DOC.HEADLINE: National advisor offers to resign after making damaging remarks

TEXT.P: Lin Huo-wan, a national advisor to President Ma Ying-jeou, offered to resign Thursday after his blatant criticism of the Cabinet's slow response to Typhoon Morakot caused widespread criticism of the administration.
Lin, a professor of philosophy at National Taiwan University, said Thursday that he has submitted a letter of resignation to the Presidential Office.

Lin disclosed Monday on a cable TV political talk show that Premier Liu Chao- shiuan went to have his hair dyed on Aug. 11 and Executive Yuan Secretary- General Hsueh Hsiang-chuan had dinner at the five-star Howard Hotel on Aug. 9 when the Cabinet should have spared no effort in rescuing people and providing disaster relief after the typhoon caused severe flooding and massive landslides.
Lin's remarks led to Hsueh tendering his resignation this week. Premier Liu has yet to offer to resign or to accept Hsueh's resignation.
Despite admitting that he was rapped for tarnishing the Ma administration's image by making the remarks, Lin denied his resignation was offered under pressure from the Presidential Office.
Lin noted that he is a national advisor to the president, not an advisor to the ruling Kuomintang.
"If a government's behavior is not in the interest of the country's people, why should not the people make criticism? " asked Lin, when speaking to reporters Thursday.
In response, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi indicated Thursday that the Presidential Office has accepted Lin's resignation.
"We respect Lin Huo-wan's decision, and thank him for his assistance and suggestions during his term," said Wang.
The position of national advisor is unpaid.

DOC.HEADLINE: Broken bridges, broken calls, broken lives

TEXT.P: The distress call rang out at 0: 42 a.m. Aug. 9, a desperate cry for help from 31-year-old Tsai Ya-hsueh to her sister after her car plunged off the Shuangyuan Bridge over the Gaoping River and became caught at the abutment of the bridge.
"The bridge is out! I have fallen under... Come to save me! Hurry! "
But Tsai's mobile phone signal soon died in the rampaging waters fed by Typhoon Morakot, and she become one of the storm's early casualties.
Similar tragedies played out on roads around central and southern Taiwan, focusing the spotlight on the country's traditionally vulnerable bridges that have given out during natural disasters.

What was different this time was the scale and severity of the destruction, especially in the southern counties of Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Chiayi and in central Taiwan's Nantou County, and the questions it raised about how bridges in Taiwan will be built and managed in the future.

As of noon Aug. 19, a total of 90 bridges around Taiwan had collapsed, with another nine requiring repairs to their abutments, according to Yao Nai-jia, head of the National Central University's Center for Bridge Engineering Research, who has been monitoring the situation alongside government officials.
That number, he said, still does not include bridges on the Southern Cross Island Highway (No. 20) that may have collapsed in areas that remain inaccessible.
"Never before has a single typhoon caused bridge damage on such a massive scale," said Lin Chia-hsin, a Directorate General of Highways (DGH) official in charge of highway and bridge maintenance.

Particularly worrisome to officials is that only three of the 14 major bridges that collapsed on nationally administered roadways -- Tajin Bridge, Liouguei Bridge and Ciwei Bridge, all located in Kaohsiung County -- were listed as "dangerous" during a countrywide inspection last year.
Bridges such as the New Ciwei Bridge and the No. 1 Bridge that were pronounced "structurally sound with no serious problems" in the 2008 assessment also fell victim to Morakot's raging floodwaters.

Highway officials and bridge engineering experts generally agree that the staggering amount of rainfall dumped by Morakot over a very short period -- 2,500 mm of precipitation, or a year's-worth of rain, in three days from Aug. 7-9 -- was the main culprit behind the high frequency of bridge destruction.
But given more extreme weather patterns caused by global warming and climate change, massive storms like Morakot could become more common in the future.
Scholars said that with this in mind, the government should update bridge management procedures, including revising criteria for closing bridges in stormy weather.
Water levels have traditionally been the sole criteria for bridge closure amid flooding. This time around, many bridges were not closed off before they collapsed.
Take, for instance, the 2,083-meter Shuangyuan Bridge, which was actually two separate bridges, one for each direction of traffic.

The water level in the Gaoping River was still 4.5 meters lower than the riverbank when the northbound bridge's No. 1-15 piers and the southbound bridge's No. 1-16 piers were washed away by raging currents.
Under current guidelines, bridges do not need to be closed off until the water level rises to within 1.5 meters of the riverbank's upper level.

"The rules should be overhauled and should take into consideration the velocity of river flows, the geological condition of each bridge and the extent of abutment erosion, " said Tsai Chun-yi, a structural engineer and an assistant professor at National Central University.

Another key to improving bridge safety lies in design and construction, Tsai said. Most of Taiwan's 27,183 bridges are girder bridges, built of precast concrete and steel, which feature short spans and often require many piers -- the pillars supporting the individual spans.
"New thinking should be employed in designing Taiwan's river bridges, " Tsai said.

Two recent high-profile bridge collapses -- that of the 22-year-old Gaoping Bridge in Kaohsiung in 2000 and the 18-year-old Houfeng Bridge in Taichung in 2008 -- were both caused by bridge piers giving out after being battered by flash floods.

Noting that erosion, earthquakes and typhoons are three key elements that should be factored into the design of Taiwan's river bridges, Tsai said reducing the number of piers or eliminating them completely would be the most effective way to enhance the safety and durability of local bridges, a view echoed by his colleague.

"Riverbed bridge piers tend to disrupt water flow, increasing the hazard of piers being eroded or washed away. Therefore, the fewer the number of piers in a riverbed, the safer the bridge, " NCU's Yao said.
The Shuangyuan Bridge, for example, has more than 60 piers in the river, with no span longer than 31 meters.

"With so many piers sitting in the riverbed, the erosion of a single pier could lead to the collapse of other piers and the whole bridge, " Yao lamented, saddened by the thought that the two painstakingly built bridges stood for less than 30 years.

In light of Taiwan's unique climate and topography, Yao said bridges longer than 100 meters should use cable-stayed or extradosed bridges, which use cables suspended from single towers rather than a series of piers to support long bridge spans.
Most of Taiwan's river bridges stretch between 200 meters and over 1,000 meters are most suitable to these styles.
Whether the cable-stayed or extradosed model is chosen depends on the breadth of the rivers over which a bridge will be built.
According to Yao, the span of a cable-stayed bridge can stretch 400 to 500 meters, while that of an extradosed bridge can extend 200 to 300 meters.

However, high costs might deter the use of these bridge types. Construction of a cable-stayed bridge is three to four times more expensive than the cost of building a girder one, while an extradosed bridge costs around twice as much as a girder type.
Noting that the higher costs are mainly a result of higher technological thresholds, Yao said Taiwan is technologically capable of building such suspension-style bridges.

The 2,617-meter highway bridge on the Yancao-Jiuru section of Taiwan's Second Freeway that crosses the Gaoping River is a cable-stayed model that has become a landmark and is the longest such bridge in Asia.
With the technology available, the only problem is funding, but Yao said he does not think all Taiwan's bridges need to be changed to cable-stayed or extradose models.
"I think such models need to be introduced just for long river bridges that require longer spans to overcome abutment-scouring problems," Yao said.
As to the cost, while cable-stayed and extradosed bridges are more expensive than girder ones, they are easier to maintain, said Yao.

While girder bridges may cost less to construct, they tend to need more maintenance and to incur higher repair fees. In the event of collapse, huge compensation has to be paid to those who are affected, while reconstruction of such bridges costs even more, Yao went on.
Apart from bridge design, equally important is environmental protection.

Yao, who led a team on an investigation last week into why a large number of bridges in Chiayi County failed, said the main reason behind the collapse of so many bridges before water levels reached officially set alarm levels lay in the fact that the huge amounts of silt, soil, rocks and driftwood washed into the rivers by typhoon-triggered flash floods and landslides enormously increased the impact of the river flows.
"Silt, soil and driftwood from the mountains are testimony to illegal logging and excessive land development and residential construction on mountain slopes," Yao said.
"If rampant overuse of slopeland and riverside agriculture cannot be halted, bridges will be doomed to continue collapsing, no matter how advanced the technology used to build them."

In the face of Taiwan's unique natural environment, Yao went on, some areas should not be inhabited any longer to solve the problem at the root. "Land planning and river management should be addressed to resolve bridge safety problems once and for all," he stressed.

While Taiwan has one of the world's highest bridge densities, it is sadly lacking in manpower for bridge maintenance and management. Before the deadly earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999, only the DGH had a bridge supervisory system in charge of 4,564 provincial highway bridges.

After the 921 earthquake, Yao noted, the MOTC commissioned the NCT's bridge research center to conduct a nationwide survey, which found Taiwan has 20,000-plus bridges but only a limited number of staff to oversee them. For instance, Chiayi County has 993 bridges, but only one full-time engineering official and several contract workers to manage them.
Meanwhile, bridge experts suggested that the government should conduct a nationwide bridge examination and single out dangerous bridges.

Chen Ming-huang, president of the national federation of construction industry associations, said many bridges, particularly those in rural townships or villages, are situated on narrow rivers and are in a state of dilapidation.
"Environmental and climatic changes might have undermined their structures. Even though they remain standing after the typhoon, they might nonetheless require maintenance," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flags to fly at half-mast for Typhoon Morakot victims

TEXT.P: National flags around the country will be flown at half-mast Aug. 22-24 for those people who perished in the disaster caused by Typhoon Morakot, the Cabinet announced Thursday.

Statistics provided by the Central Emergency Operation Center show that as of 12 p.m. Thursday, confirmed fatalities from the disaster had totaled 141, with 440 people reported missing and 45 others injured.

In Kaohsiung County, the authorities were still verifying the number of residents who are believed buried under landslides in Siaolin village in Jiasian township and Xinkai community in Liouguei township.
Some 3,826 households remained without water supply, while 8,517 households were still being affected by power outages.
Also, 96 mobile base stations and telephone lines to 2,129 households had not yet been repaired.

Yenwen, Wenfeng and Jiangyuan villages in Jiadong township and Guanglin village in Linbian township -- all in Pintung County -- remained inundated by up to 70 centimeters of floodwater as of 6 a.m. Thursday.
Agricultural losses had increased to more than NT$13.45 billion, with Pingtung, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Chiayi counties hit the hardest.
The amount included NT$4.37 billion in crop losses and NT$4.14 billion in aquaculture losses.
A total of 24,775 people had been evacuated as of Thursday, 5,957 of whom were being given temporary shelter at 50 locations, while the rest were staying with friends and relatives.
From Aug. 8 to 12 p.m. Thursday, 2,777 flights had been provided to airlift a total of 340,475 kilograms of supplies, 1,890 rescuers, 9,274 evacuees, and 17 bodies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Stock prices drop on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices extended their losing streak into the fourth day Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 55.35 points, or 0.81 percent, to close at 6,733.23.
The local bourse opened at 6,784.91 and fluctuated between 6,784.91 and 6,647.32 during the trading session before closing above the index's three-month moving average of 6,700.
A total of 3.53 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$88.84 billion (US$2.69 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks dropping the most at 3.4 percent. Banking and financial stocks fell 2.1 percent, paper and pulp issues dipped 1.9 percent, foodstuff shares shed 1.2 percent, plastics and chemicals issues lost 1 percent, textile issues dropped 0.8 percent, cement issues lost 0.4 percent, and machinery and electronics stocks shed 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,807 to 544, with 131 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$450 million-worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign aid continues to flow in for typhoon relief: MOFA

TEXT.P: Donations and disaster relief supplies continue to flow in into Taiwan from the international community to help with the relief efforts in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

According to a MOFA press release, a donation from Japan, comprised of 200 waterproof ground sheets, 400 water buckets, 50 water tanks, 50 water purifiers, 30 generators and 900 sleeping pads, was scheduled to arrive in Taiwan later Thursday.

Japan's top representative to Taiwan Masaki Saito, on behalf of his government, will hand over the supplies to Vice Foreign Minister David Lin, the MOFA said, adding that the supplies will be sent to the Kaohsiung County government for distribution.

In addition, the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) sent a second disaster relief expert to Taiwan Aug. 19 to evaluate the country's needs in its reconstruction and rehabilitation efforts, the MOFA said.

Alan Dwyer, the principal East Asia-Pacific advisor with the USAID's Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance, arrived in Taiwan Wednesday after Ron Libby, a coordinator with the USAID in charge of disaster response assistance and support, concluded his assessment of the scale of the typhoon disaster and left the country.
Dwyer was scheduled to visit the Central Emergency Operation Center and storm- hit areas of southern Taiwan to assess what assistance the U.S. can provide. He will depart Taiwan Aug. 25.

Other aid from the international community included a donation of 30,000 euros (US$42,675) on Aug. 18 by France through its French Institute in Taipei to help shelter children affected by the natural disaster, according to MOFA.
Also, the South Korean government donated 500 emergency kits to the Presbyterian Church in Taiwan for relief work, the foreign ministry said.

In addition, Guy Ledoux, the top European Union representative to Taiwan, will hand over to the MOFA on Friday 4,600 bottles of water purification drops donated by the Swedish Civil Contingencies Agency, while a second batch of 6,900 bottles is scheduled to arrive in the country next week.

As of Aug. 19, at least 77 countries from around the world, the EU, as well as 20 international organizations, had donated a total of NT$137 million in relief aid to Taiwan, according to the latest tallies released by the MOFA.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, falling NT$0.044 to close at NT$32.966.
A total of US$781 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.010 and fluctuated between NT$32.945 and NT$33.021.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet approves special bill for post-typhoon reconstruction

TEXT.P: The government is scheduled to complete reconstruction in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot within three years at an estimated cost of NT$100 billion (US$3.03 billion) , Vice Minister of the Interior (MOI) Lin Chung-sen said Thursday after the Executive Yuan approved a bill on reconstruction.

If passed by the Legislature, the special MOI-drafted bill will authorize the executive branch to raise a special budget of NT$100 billion in three years to finance various post-typhoon rehabilitation and reconstruction projects.
"According to the special bill, the government will carry out reconstruction projects in line with three top principles -- leniency, promptness and minimal red-tape," Lin said.

Taking cues from the special statute governing reconstruction in the wake of the devastating Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake, the draft bill on post-Typhoon Morakot reconstruction outlines mechanisms regarding rehabilitation of public infrastructure and resettlement of displaced typhoon victims, Lin said.

Lin added that the bill will soon be referred to the Legislative Yuan for approval to facilitate rehabilitation of areas affected by Morakot which lashed southern Taiwan with strong winds and torrential rains from Aug. 7-9, causing severe flooding and landslides that killed an estimated 500 people.
One key element of the bill is to outlaw habitation in mountain hillsides and other areas that put residents at risk in typhoons or other natural disasters.
"With safety as the top concern, potentially dangerous regions will no longer be listed as inhabitable," Lin said.

One such area, Siaolin Village in Kaohsiung County, was hardest-hit in the typhoon. Nearly 400 people are believed buried alive when sides of nearby mountains came crashing down on the village after heavy rain loosened the soil. The village is located at the foothills of Alishan in a narrow valley.

Community relocation may be inevitable for some dangerous zones, Lin said, adding that the special reconstruction bill has outlined a mechanism for compensation and land acquisition for people who have to be relocated.
If land plots picked to accommodate resettlement projects are owned by government agencies or state-run enterprises, the use of such land will be free of charge, Lin said.

"So long as those land plots are professionally determined to be safe for habitation, regulations involving rezoning or land development will be relaxed, " Lin said, adding that the government will cooperate closely with the private sector to finalize resettlement and reconstruction as early as possible.
While preferential incentives will be offered, application procedures will also be simplified as much as possible to speed up reconstruction, Lin said.

As Morakot-triggered flooding and landslides which severely damaged or buried many roads and bridges, Lin said the central government will also work hand-in- hand with local governments to rebuild or repair roads and bridges in no more than three years.
According to Lin, the Executive Yuan has already paid NT$6.6 billion in reconstruction funds to various county governments whose districts were hit hardest by the disaster.

Meanwhile, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said he will call a meeting of caucus whips of ruling and oppsoition parties Friday to discuss whether an extraordinary session will be convened soon to screen the special bill for reconstruction projects or the next legislative session be opened ahead of the schedule to deal with this urgent bill.
"Anyway, the Legislature will scrutinize the bill and pass it as soon as possible to accelerate reconstruction and resettlement of displaced typhoon victims," Wang said.
The ruling Kuomintang contols an absolute majority in the Legislature. Both KMT and the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party have voiced support for the bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier announces beginning of reconstruction

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan announced Thursday that the government's post-typhoon response has now entered the resettlement and reconstruction phase, as rescues have more or less been completed.
Liu emphasized that the handover of tasks by government units of various levels must be a "seamless" process so that reconstruction in flood-affected areas can be launched smoothly.

Meanwhile, Liu said that although the Council for Economic Planning and Development already has a national homeland plan, it must come up with a new strategic plan on land conservation in flood-affected areas soon. The plan will serve as the main guidelines for all post-typhoon reconstruction projects.

"The new guidelines will enable post-typhoon reconstruction projects, including land conservation, infrastructure reconstruction, resettlement and industrial revival to be carried out efficiently," Liu said.

The premier gave the instructions after hearing briefings by Minister Without Portfolio Tsai Hsun-hsiung and the Central Emergency Operation Center chief Mao Chih-kuo on the latest situations in the hardest-hit areas, as well as the administration's post-disaster response plans.

Liu instructed the National Youth Commission Thursday to make plans for volunteers and volunteer work in flood-affected areas in the wake of the typhoon, which as of 4 p.m. Thursday had left 141 people dead, another 440 unaccounted for and 45 injured.
He also instructed relevant government agencies to speed up the delivery of relief subsidies and arrangement of resettlement for those hit by the disaster.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA to hold fundraising bazaar for disaster relief

TEXT.P: A fundraising bazaar will be held Aug. 22-23 in Taipei in the wake of Typhoon Morakot to help storm-stricken families in southern Taiwan, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.
"We are urging the public to take part in the charity event to show concern and love for the typhoon victims," the MOFA said.

The bazaar is being organized by the the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China and Huashan 1914 Creative Park, with the support of Taiwan's International Cooperation and Development Fund and diplomatic corps.

The bazaar, which will be held at the Huanshan Creative Park, will feature exotic souvenirs and arts and craft donated by Taiwan's diplomatic allies and other countries, as well as clothes, accessories, toys and home supplies.
Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou will officially open the event at 3 p.m. Aug. 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade pact expected to be concluded by year's end: Chinese official

TEXT.P: A visiting Chinese commerce official said Thursday he is confident that negotiations on an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China will be concluded by the end of this year.

Tang Wei, director general of the Department of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macao Affairs under China's Ministry of Commerce, told a news conference in Taipei that currently both sides are still at the stage of studying the feasibility of such an agreement on its own and will continue to strengthen communications with each other in order to develop a mutually beneficial and win-win cooperative mode.
Although it depends on the results of talks, Tang said that he "has great confidence" that the negotiations will be concluded by the end of this year.

Tang is on a visit in Taiwan as the head of a 100-member procurement delegation organized by China's Association of Economy and Trade Across the Taiwan Straits (AETATS). He is the AETATS' vice president.

Responding to concerns that the agreement will have a negative impact on Taiwan's various industries, such as the towel industry, Tang noted that the signing of the ECFA is to benefit both China and Taiwan and assure that China will take these concerns into account and will not allow the agreement to negatively impact Taiwan's domestic industries.

Touching on what kinds of industries will be included in the early-harvest list of the planned cross-Taiwan Strait ECFA, Tang said that those agreed upon by both sides, and those that can be implemented easily and quickly, will first be included on the list. These could be the financial and banking, petrochemicals and machinery industries proposed by Taiwan.
The AETATS, an affiliate of China's Ministry of Commerce, is tasked with promoting commercial exchanges and economic cooperation with Taiwan.
The procurement group, the fourth of its kind to come from China so far this year, plans to purchase more than US$1.2 billion worth of machinery, petrochemicals and textile goods.
President Ma Ying-jeou and his administration have said that negotiations on the ECFA agreement will begin in October and that they hope to sign such an agreement with China by next year.

While critics have expressed concerns that there could be a flood of Chinese products into Taiwan and local industries will be hurt, Ma and other proponents have argued that the agreement - similar to a free-trade agreement - is necessary for Taiwan to remain competitive, as China is signing similar pacts with other countries.
