DOC.HEADLINE: Government to borrow record sum in 2010

TEXT.P: The central government will float NT$466 billion (US$14.12 billion) in state bonds next year to help cover its spending, according to the 2010 draft budget bill approved by the Executive Yuan Thursday at a weekly Cabinet meeting.

The new budget bill projects the government's annual revenue and expenditure at NT$1.552 trillion and NT$1.7398 trillion, respectively, leaving the national coffers with a deficit of NT$187.8 billion.

As the government has to repay NT$66 billion in previous debts in 2010 and will need to spend an additional NT$212.2 billion on infrastructure construction, flood control and reservoir renovation, it will have to borrow the combined total of NT$466 billion in the coming year to make ends meet, a Cabinet official said.

The targeted 2010 government revenue marks a decrease of NT$121.2 billion from this year's level, while its projected expenditure represents a drop of NT$69.9 billion year on year, the official went on.

According to next year's budget bill, education, scientific research and cultural development will take the lion's share of government budget, at a combined 20.3 percent, followed by social welfare spending at 18.7 percent, defense expenditure at 16.6 percent and economic development spending at 12.1 percent.

The official pointed out that defense spending will account for roughly 3 percent of the country's gross domestic product, fulfilling a government promise to raise the defense budget to beef up the country's military muscle.

The key government work agenda listed in the budget bill includes research and development personnel cultivation, improvements in the transport network, improvements to the disaster prevention system, infrastructure construction, upgrading of living environments and increased cultural development.

DOC.HEADLINE: President, premier to review rehabilitation progress in Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan will meet at the army's Eighth Legion Command in Kaohsiung Friday to review the progress of post-Typhoon Morakot rehabilitation efforts, Government Information Office Minister Su Jun- pin said Thursday.

Determined to gain a full understanding of the situation and the coordination of the rehabilitation efforts in the aftermath of the typhoon's devastation, Ma and Liu are spending time close to the stricken areas, while the newly established Reconstruction Advancement Committee will set up a frontline office at the Eighth Legion Command, said Su.

Emphasizing that "there's nothing more important than the post-disaster rescue and rehabilitation," Su said that Liu, together with Minister of Transportation Mao Chih-kuo, Minister of the Interior Liao Liou-yi, Economics Minister Yiin Chii-ming and Minister without Portfolio Tsai Hsung-hsiung were heading south the following day to meet the president.

Meanwhile Thursday, Ma visited some of those who suffered from the devastation of the flooding and landslides triggered by Morakot, and earlier in the day, went to an orphanage in Liuguei township, Kaohsiung County.
He and the premier were scheduled to visit Saturday the site of Siaolin village in Pingtung County, which was completely buried by mudslides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tzu Chi Foundation to build `green' houses for typhoon victims

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation will build "green" houses in cooperation with the Kaohsiung county government for aboriginal people whose mountain homes were destroyed by Typhoon Morakot, officials said Thursday.

Lin Pi-yu, deputy chief executive of the Tzu Chi Foundation, Taiwan's largest charity, signed a letter of intent with Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsiung earlier in the day on cooperation in building a completely new village -- to be called Da Ai (Big Love) village -- in the southern county in which displaced typhoon victims can be resettled.

According to the preliminary agreement, the county government will provide a plot of land upon which the Buddhist charity will build up to 1,000 permanent houses to accommodate the displaced aboriginal people from several townships in mountainous areas of the county.
The Tzu Chi foundation, founded by Master Cheng Yen, will raise the funds needed to build the houses, Lin said.
Yang for his part said the county government had already selected a 22.8-hectare plot in Shanlin township to accommodate the planned Da Ai village.
The site, located near Shanlin Junior High School, is owned by state-run Taiwan Sugar Corp.
Yang said he will seek the central government's assistance in acquiring the land as soon as possible to speed up the resettlement project.
He further said the houses will be offered to the displaced typhoon victims free of charge, with the proviso that they cannot be sold for a specified period of time.

Tzu Chi has built many Da Ai villages in disaster zones in Taiwan and other countries around the world, and Lin said the housing units to be built in Kaohsiung County will be environmentally friendly "green" houses.

Several mountain townships in Kaohsiung County, including Jiasian, Siaolin, Liuguei and Taoyuan, were hit hard by torrential rain and landslides triggered by Typhoon Morakot that pummeled Taiwan Aug. 7-9, leaving hundreds of people dead or missing and rendering many others homeless.
Out of respect for aboriginal religious beliefs and customs, Lin went on, the roads in the planned Da Ai village will be unpaved, in keeping with the desires of the people who will live there.

The village will also feature a youth activity center and a handicraft display gallery to provide indigenous tribal people with a better living environment and a means of selling their traditional craftwork, Lin added.

As many of the aborigines are resistant to being resettled out of the mountains down onto the plains, Yang said the central government should help them relocate by offering incentives such as employment opportunities.

Years of excessive development, Taiwan's mountain slopes are vulnerable to landslides. Aboriginal communities have thus often fallen victim to typhoons whcih tend to bring with them heavy rains to trigger landslides and mudslides.

"Tzu Chi will reinforce communciations with aboriginal village chiefs to convince them the importance of land restoration and persuade them to relocate to safer places to establish new homes and return the mountains and forests to Mother Nature," Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DGBAS forecasts 4.04 percent negative economic growth

TEXT.P: The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) has revised its projections for Taiwan's economic situation for this year to 4.04 percent negative growth, slightly more optimistic than the 4.25 percent projected in May.

However, if a special budget for reconstruction projects in the wake of Typhoon Morakot is factored in, the economy for the whole of this year is expected to shrink even less, with 3.75 percent negative growth, DGBAS Minister Shih Su-mei said at a press conference Thursday to announce the projections.

Shih said a government plan to earmark NT$100 billion budget for post-typhoon reconstruction, of which NT$50 billion will be allocated for the 2009 fiscal year, is expected to increase the real gross domestic product (GDP) to NT$36.1 billion and lessen the contraction of the economy to 3.75 percent for the year.

The agency also revised upward its economic outlook, predicting that the economy will shrink 10.13 percent in Q1 and 7.54 percent in Q2, less than the previously projected 10.24 percent in Q1 and 8.5 percent in Q2.

According to DGBAS projections, Typhoon Morakot, which has battered the agriculture, tourism and manufacturing sectors, is estimated to have caused GDP losses of between NT$19 billion and NT$23 billion in Q3 and could lead to a further Q3 negative growth of 0.6 percent to 0.7 percent.

However, the negative impact of the typhoon on the Q4 GDP will be lessened after reconstruction projects begin, as they are expected to contribute 0.1 percent to 0.2 percent to the Q4 economic growth, Shih added.
The DGBAS also projected Taiwan a 3.92 percent economic growth for 2010 due to the low comparison base affected by the global economic downturn this year.
Taiwan, as an export-orientated country, is expected to benefit as a global recovery begins and to register positive year-on-year economic growth next year, according to Shih.
Meanwhile, the agency predicted that the Consumer Price Index will register a 0.87 percent year-on-year increase next year, compared with a projected 0.68 percent contraction this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's family income gap widens

TEXT.P: Taiwan's household income gap widened in 2008, with the average annual disposable incomes of the richest families reaching 6.05 times those of the poorest, according to the results of the latest survey released Thursday.

The trend marked a reversal from 2007, when the income gap between the richest and poorest 20 percent of local families narrowed slightly to 5.98-fold from 6.01-fold recorded in 2006, said an official of The Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Moreover, the official said, if social welfare subsidies and tax benefits are excluded, the income gap between the two groups hit an all-time high of 7.73-fold in 2008.
The DGBAS has conducted an annual survey of family incomes and expenditures around the country since 1964 to keep tabs on wealth distribution.

The survey divides families into five brackets in terms of annual disposable income, with the top 20 percent defined as the richest and the bottom 20 percent as the poorest. The largest income gap between these two brackets was 6.39-fold, recorded in 2001.
But if social welfare subsidies and tax benefits were excluded, the wealth gap in 2001 was 7.67 fold, lower than that recorded in 2008.

The latest survey found that the average annual disposable income in the richest group of families reached NT$1.84 million (US$55,757.5) in 2008, compared to NT$304,000 for those in the poorest bracket.
With government welfare subsidies and tax breaks excluded, the annual disposable family income of the richest group amounted to NT$1.9 million, compared to the poorest group's NT$245,000.
The DGBAS official attributed the widening wealth gap in part to structural changes in the job market as a result of economic globalization.
As to whether the global financial crisis had any impact on the local wealth distribution, the official said it requires a further survey and study.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA to hold fundraising bazaar for disaster relief

TEXT.P: A fundraising bazaar will be held Aug. 22-23 in Taipei in the wake of Typhoon Morakot to help storm-stricken families in southern Taiwan, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.
"We are urging the public to take part in the charity event to show concern and love for the typhoon victims," the MOFA said.

The bazaar is being organized by the the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China and Huashan 1914 Creative Park, with the support of Taiwan's International Cooperation and Development Fund and diplomatic corps.

The bazaar, which will be held at the Huanshan Creative Park, will feature exotic souvenirs and arts and craft donated by Taiwan's diplomatic allies and other countries, as well as clothes, accessories, toys and home supplies.
Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou will officially open the event at 3 p.m. Aug. 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade pact expected to be concluded by year's end: Chinese official

TEXT.P: A visiting Chinese commerce official said Thursday he is confident that negotiations on an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China will be concluded by the end of this year.

Tang Wei, director general of the Department of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macao Affairs under China's Ministry of Commerce, told a news conference in Taipei that currently both sides are still at the stage of studying the feasibility of such an agreement on its own and will continue to strengthen communications with each other in order to develop a mutually beneficial and win-win cooperative mode.
Although it depends on the results of talks, Tang said that he "has great confidence" that the negotiations will be concluded by the end of this year.

Tang is on a visit in Taiwan as the head of a 100-member procurement delegation organized by China's Association of Economy and Trade Across the Taiwan Straits (AETATS). He is the AETATS' vice president.

Responding to concerns that the agreement will have a negative impact on Taiwan's various industries, such as the towel industry, Tang noted that the signing of the ECFA is to benefit both China and Taiwan and assure that China will take these concerns into account and will not allow the agreement to negatively impact Taiwan's domestic industries.

Touching on what kinds of industries will be included in the early-harvest list of the planned cross-Taiwan Strait ECFA, Tang said that those agreed upon by both sides, and those that can be implemented easily and quickly, will first be included on the list. These could be the financial and banking, petrochemicals and machinery industries proposed by Taiwan.
The AETATS, an affiliate of China's Ministry of Commerce, is tasked with promoting commercial exchanges and economic cooperation with Taiwan.
The procurement group, the fourth of its kind to come from China so far this year, plans to purchase more than US$1.2 billion worth of machinery, petrochemicals and textile goods.
President Ma Ying-jeou and his administration have said that negotiations on the ECFA agreement will begin in October and that they hope to sign such an agreement with China by next year.

While critics have expressed concerns that there could be a flood of Chinese products into Taiwan and local industries will be hurt, Ma and other proponents have argued that the agreement - similar to a free-trade agreement - is necessary for Taiwan to remain competitive, as China is signing similar pacts with other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to borrow record sum in 2010

TEXT.P: The central government will float NT$466 billion (US$14.12 billion) in state bonds next year to help cover its spending, according to the 2010 draft budget bill approved by the Executive Yuan Thursday at a weekly Cabinet meeting.

The new budget bill projects the government's annual revenue and expenditure at NT$1.552 trillion and NT$1.7398 trillion, respectively, leaving the national coffers with a deficit of NT$187.8 billion.

As the government has to repay NT$66 billion in previous debts in 2010 and will need to spend an additional NT$212.2 billion on infrastructure construction, flood control and reservoir renovation, it will have to borrow the combined total of NT$466 billion in the coming year to make ends meet, a Cabinet official said.

The targeted 2010 government revenue marks a decrease of NT$121.2 billion from this year's level, while its projected expenditure represents a drop of NT$69.9 billion year on year, the official went on.

According to next year's budget bill, education, scientific research and cultural development will take the lion's share of government budget, at a combined 20.3 percent, followed by social welfare spending at 18.7 percent, defense expenditure at 16.6 percent and economic development spending at 12.1 percent.

The official pointed out that defense spending will account for roughly 3 percent of the country's gross domestic product, fulfilling a government promise to raise the defense budget to beef up the country's military muscle.

The key government work agenda listed in the budget bill includes research and development personnel cultivation, improvements in the transport network, improvements to the disaster prevention system, infrastructure construction, upgrading of living environments and increased cultural development.

DOC.HEADLINE: President, premier to review rehabilitation progress in Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan will meet at the army's Eighth Legion Command in Kaohsiung Friday to review the progress of post-Typhoon Morakot rehabilitation efforts, Government Information Office Minister Su Jun- pin said Thursday.

Determined to gain a full understanding of the situation and the coordination of the rehabilitation efforts in the aftermath of the typhoon's devastation, Ma and Liu are spending time close to the stricken areas, while the newly established Reconstruction Advancement Committee will set up a frontline office at the Eighth Legion Command, said Su.

Emphasizing that "there's nothing more important than the post-disaster rescue and rehabilitation," Su said that Liu, together with Minister of Transportation Mao Chih-kuo, Minister of the Interior Liao Liou-yi, Economics Minister Yiin Chii-ming and Minister without Portfolio Tsai Hsung-hsiung were heading south the following day to meet the president.

Meanwhile Thursday, Ma visited some of those who suffered from the devastation of the flooding and landslides triggered by Morakot, and earlier in the day, went to an orphanage in Liuguei township, Kaohsiung County.
He and the premier were scheduled to visit Saturday the site of Siaolin village in Pingtung County, which was completely buried by mudslides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tzu Chi Foundation to build `green' houses for typhoon victims

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation will build "green" houses in cooperation with the Kaohsiung county government for aboriginal people whose mountain homes were destroyed by Typhoon Morakot, officials said Thursday.

Lin Pi-yu, deputy chief executive of the Tzu Chi Foundation, Taiwan's largest charity, signed a letter of intent with Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsiung earlier in the day on cooperation in building a completely new village -- to be called Da Ai (Big Love) village -- in the southern county in which displaced typhoon victims can be resettled.

According to the preliminary agreement, the county government will provide a plot of land upon which the Buddhist charity will build up to 1,000 permanent houses to accommodate the displaced aboriginal people from several townships in mountainous areas of the county.
The Tzu Chi foundation, founded by Master Cheng Yen, will raise the funds needed to build the houses, Lin said.
Yang for his part said the county government had already selected a 22.8-hectare plot in Shanlin township to accommodate the planned Da Ai village.
The site, located near Shanlin Junior High School, is owned by state-run Taiwan Sugar Corp.
Yang said he will seek the central government's assistance in acquiring the land as soon as possible to speed up the resettlement project.
He further said the houses will be offered to the displaced typhoon victims free of charge, with the proviso that they cannot be sold for a specified period of time.

Tzu Chi has built many Da Ai villages in disaster zones in Taiwan and other countries around the world, and Lin said the housing units to be built in Kaohsiung County will be environmentally friendly "green" houses.

Several mountain townships in Kaohsiung County, including Jiasian, Siaolin, Liuguei and Taoyuan, were hit hard by torrential rain and landslides triggered by Typhoon Morakot that pummeled Taiwan Aug. 7-9, leaving hundreds of people dead or missing and rendering many others homeless.
Out of respect for aboriginal religious beliefs and customs, Lin went on, the roads in the planned Da Ai village will be unpaved, in keeping with the desires of the people who will live there.

The village will also feature a youth activity center and a handicraft display gallery to provide indigenous tribal people with a better living environment and a means of selling their traditional craftwork, Lin added.

As many of the aborigines are resistant to being resettled out of the mountains down onto the plains, Yang said the central government should help them relocate by offering incentives such as employment opportunities.

Years of excessive development, Taiwan's mountain slopes are vulnerable to landslides. Aboriginal communities have thus often fallen victim to typhoons whcih tend to bring with them heavy rains to trigger landslides and mudslides.

"Tzu Chi will reinforce communciations with aboriginal village chiefs to convince them the importance of land restoration and persuade them to relocate to safer places to establish new homes and return the mountains and forests to Mother Nature," Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DGBAS forecasts 4.04 percent negative economic growth

TEXT.P: The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) has revised its projections for Taiwan's economic situation for this year to 4.04 percent negative growth, slightly more optimistic than the 4.25 percent projected in May.

However, if a special budget for reconstruction projects in the wake of Typhoon Morakot is factored in, the economy for the whole of this year is expected to shrink even less, with 3.75 percent negative growth, DGBAS Minister Shih Su-mei said at a press conference Thursday to announce the projections.

Shih said a government plan to earmark NT$100 billion budget for post-typhoon reconstruction, of which NT$50 billion will be allocated for the 2009 fiscal year, is expected to increase the real gross domestic product (GDP) to NT$36.1 billion and lessen the contraction of the economy to 3.75 percent for the year.

The agency also revised upward its economic outlook, predicting that the economy will shrink 10.13 percent in Q1 and 7.54 percent in Q2, less than the previously projected 10.24 percent in Q1 and 8.5 percent in Q2.

According to DGBAS projections, Typhoon Morakot, which has battered the agriculture, tourism and manufacturing sectors, is estimated to have caused GDP losses of between NT$19 billion and NT$23 billion in Q3 and could lead to a further Q3 negative growth of 0.6 percent to 0.7 percent.

However, the negative impact of the typhoon on the Q4 GDP will be lessened after reconstruction projects begin, as they are expected to contribute 0.1 percent to 0.2 percent to the Q4 economic growth, Shih added.
The DGBAS also projected Taiwan a 3.92 percent economic growth for 2010 due to the low comparison base affected by the global economic downturn this year.
Taiwan, as an export-orientated country, is expected to benefit as a global recovery begins and to register positive year-on-year economic growth next year, according to Shih.
Meanwhile, the agency predicted that the Consumer Price Index will register a 0.87 percent year-on-year increase next year, compared with a projected 0.68 percent contraction this year.
The DGBAS also forecast that the country's gross national product will rise to NT$13.05 trillion next year from NT$12.56 trillion projected for this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 21, or the second day of the seventh month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1754: Scottish engineer William Murdoch is born. He pioneered the use of coal- gas for lighting in 1792 while working with James Watt and Matthew Bouton on their steam engines.
1902: Manufacturer Martin Leland starts his luxury car venture by naming his new automobile after Antoine de la Motte Cadillac, the French colonial administrator and Detroit's founding father.
1908: Orville Wright, American aviation pioneer, and his brother Wilbur make the first military aircraft for the United States.
1930: Princess Margaret, sister of British Queen Elizabeth II, is born.
1944: Representatives from China, Britain, Russia and the United States meet at Dumbarton Oaks near Washington, D.C. to plan for the formation of the United Nations.
1937: The Treaty of Non-Aggression between China and the Soviet Union is signed in Nanking.
1959: The Baghdad Pact is formally renamed the Central Treaty Organization (CENTO) following Iraq's withdrawal earlier in the year.
1959: Hawaii becomes the 50th state of the United States.
1963: South Vietnam declares martial law after raids on Buddhist pagodas and the arrest of hundreds of Buddhist monks.
1976: Prince Maphevu Harry Dlamini, prime minister of the Kingdom of Swaziland, accompanied by Madame Dlamini and a party of eight, arrives in the Republic of China for a seven-day visit.
1982: King Sobhuza II of Swaziland dies at the age of 83. He was one of the world's longest-reigning monarchs, having been on the throne sine 1921.
1982: Republic of China Economics Minister William Y.T. Chao announces the partial lifting of an import ban on 842 types of Japanese consumer goods.
1983: Benigno Aquino, leader of the anti-Marcos faction in the Philippines, is gunned down as he steps onto the asphalt at Manila Airport after returning from a three-year sojourn in the United States. He was 51.
1984: A massive demonstration is held in Manila to mark the first anniversary of the assassination of Benigno Aquino.
1985: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Robert C. Chien as the new finance minister, succeeding Loh Jen-kong who resigned on Aug. 15.
1986: A cloud of toxic gas is released from the volcanic Lake Nyos, near Wum in northwest Cameroon, killing more than 1,200 people.
1990: An ROC Air Force B-1900 air transport plane crashes in Tungshih Village in Yunlin County, killing all 16 people aboard, including three major-generals and nine colonels.
1990: The Indian Parliament approves presidential rule in Jammu and Kashmir and gives the armed forces special powers in the riot-torn state.
1991: President Mikhail Gorbachev arrives back in Moscow after the collapse of a coup attempt by hardliners.
1991: Latvia declares its independence from the Soviet Union.
1997: Abdur Rahim Gaffurzai, the newly appointed prime minister of Afghanistan, is killed along with 13 others in a plane crash.
1999: Over 96 percent of the Kuomintang's party delegates vote to support Vice President Lien Chan as the party's candidate in the following spring's presidential election.
2000: Former ROC President Lee Teng-hui proposes the establishment of an Asian monetary fund to promote economic cooperation in Asia.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his Gambian counterpart Yahya Jammeh sign a joint communique pledging to continue enhancing close cooperation between the two countries.
2001: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reiterates while meeting with visiting Paraguayan Foreign Minister Jose Antonio Moreno Ruffinelli that the ROC government will abide by the memorandum of trade and investment signed by the ROC and Paraguay to further cement the established ties between Taipei and Asuncion.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to carry out, but when you once try to carry out a thing you must never give it up until you have done it thoroughly and well."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
New Zealand donates money for typhoon relief

TEXT.P: The New Zealand government donated NZ$100,000 (US$67,635) to Taiwan's Red Cross Friday to help with the relief efforts in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot.

Felicity Bloor, acting director of the Taipei-based New Zealand Commerce and Industry Office, handed over the donation on behalf of her government to the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, which she said is a trustworthy charity group that she believed will make best use of the money.

"We hope that by giving it to the Red Cross, people that need to rebuild their houses and rebuild their lives will be able to benefit. Whoever these people are, we hope that they will be able to receive hope from my government to help rebuild their lives that have been shattered by this typhoon," Bloor said.
Noting that Asians constitute 9.8 percent of the New Zealand population, Bloor said her country is closely connected with Asian countries and communities in the region.
"We feel that we are a natural partner within the Asian region, so if something happens in your part of the world, we feel it. It concerns us," she said.
Steven Chen, secretary-general of the ROC chapter of the Red Cross Society, pledged to make the best use of the donation by caring for the emergency needs of the typhoon victims.

Typhoon Morakot dumped nearly 3,000 mm of rain in just four days on parts of Taiwan, mainly in the south, swelling rivers that washed away bridges and triggered landslides that buried entire villages.
As of 10 p.m. Thursday, the storm had killed at least 141 people across Taiwan, with 45 people injured and 440 others unaccounted for.

DOC.HEADLINE: China raises 310 million yuan for Taiwan storm victims
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/21/09 10:54:07 (By Chang Ming-kun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A large-scale television fundraiser took place in China Thursday that raised at least 310 million Chinese yuan (US$45 million) for the victims of Typhoon Morakot, the deadliest storm in Taiwan in 50 years.

The four-hour telethon involved leading television stations in six provinces, with over 100 movie and athletic stars, as well as celebrities from the political, cultural, business and entertainment sectors, serving as operators to receive phone calls from donors.
"The actual amount of donations is still being calculated, " said a spokesman for Shanghai Dragon TV, one of the sponsors of the drive.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan records third H1N1 fatality

TEXT.P: Taiwan's health authorities reported the country's third influenza A(H1N1) fatality Friday, a student from the eastern county of Taitung.

The 24-year-old man, who had not traveled overseas, came down with flu symptoms Aug. 11, a day after he returned home from a round-the-island tour that had been cut short because of Typhoon Morakot, said Lu Chiao-yang, head of Taitung County's Public Health Bureau.
He sought treatment at the Taitung Christian Hospital, where he tested negative for the new strain of influenza, Lu said.
Three days after he was hospitalized, the patient developed pneumonia and was transferred to the Mackay Memorial Hospital Taitung Branch, Lu went on.
The results of a second flu test on the patient released Thursday showed that he had been infected with A(H1N1), Lu said.
The patient's condition worsened and he died early the following morning.
The bureau examined his family and those who had traveled with him on the round- the-island tour, including a group of 51 children, all of whom were uninfected.

DOC.HEADLINE: 136,000 households to receive flood compensation

TEXT.P: Over 136,000 households in seven counties and one city in southern and eastern Taiwan are entitled to flood compensation because their homes were inundated by flooding or destroyed by mudslides triggered by Typhoon Morakot, a government-sponsored foundation said Friday.

Fan Liang-shiow, chairman of the non-profit Relieve Disaster Foundation, said NT$2.73 billion (US$82.91 million) was remitted the day before to local government offices in Pingtung, Kaohsiung, Tainan, Chiayi, Changhua, Nantou and Taitung counties, as well as Chiayi City, allowing each household to receive NT$20,000, said Fan, who is also chairman of the Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission.
It is expected that more than 80 percent of the eligible households will receive the NT$20,000 in cash within one week, Fan added.

The Relieve Disaster Foundation allocated NT$430 million and NT$660 million, respectively, to local governments of the hardest-hit counties several days ago as condolence money for households that have lost loved ones in the wake of Typhoon Morakot and as subsidies to help finance the rebuilding of their homes, he continued.

According to the foundation, families with members who have died or who have been reported missing because of the typhoon have already been earmarked for condolence money of NT$1 million (US$30,488) per casualty. Families whose members have suffered severe injury as a result of the typhoon are also to receive NT$250,000 per victim, the foundation said, adding that the money has already been remitted to the various local governments.

Fan said the foundation -- established in 2001 by the Ministry of the Interior to handle government relief funds and private donations in the wake of Typhoon Toraji, which killed 100 people and left 100 others unaccounted for -- presently has a balance of NT$2 billion after paying out the Morakot-related remittances.

The foundation is also offering flood victims a choice of either NT$10,000 per person in relocation funds for up to five people per household or NT$3,000 per person to rent a property for up to six months, up to three people per household.
As of Thursday, the official death toll of Typhoon Morakot was at 141, with 45 injured and 440 people remaining unaccounted for.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan politicians call for abolition of water channeling project

TEXT.P: Politicians in Tainan County launched a petition Friday calling for the abandonment of a local water channelling project that has been blamed for the terrible landslides that destroyed Siaolin village in Kaohsiung County during Typhoon Morakot.
Members of the Tainan County Council will encourage their constituents to sign the petition before submitting it to the Cabinet.

According to Wu Chien-pao, speaker of the council, residents in Tainan County have always opposed the project, believing that the required dynamiting damages the already fragile geological conditions and undermines the ecology of the area.
Wu warned that if the project continues, the Siaolin tragedy will likely be repeated.

The NT$21.2 billion project, which involves channeling water from Kaohsiung's Laonong River to Tainan's Zengwen Reservoir and delivering the treated water back to Kaohsiung, is intended to resolve water shortages in the Kaohsiung area.
The Water Resources Agency, which carries out the project, has already been fined NT$1.5 million for failing to obtain approval for part of the work.
It is expected to be completed in 2012.

Wu said that while the reservoir has seldom reached its full capacity in the past, the situation has changed in recent years as global climate change is increasing the frequency of extreme rainfall in southern Taiwan.

Under these circumstances, he argued, channeling water from the Laonong River will further increase the burden on the reservoir, and in the event of flood releases, areas located downstream from the reservoir may experience severe flooding.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA news budget for Aug. 21

TEXT.P: Typhoon Morakot victims 2. 136,000 households to receive flood compensation 3. Chinese manufacturers guarantee quality of prefabricated houses 4. skin diseases prevail among flood victims 5. Legislator accepts Chinese donation 6. Taiwan records third H1N1 fatality 7. Tainan politicians call for abolition of water channeling project 8.Movies shorten distance between Taiwan and Israel

DOC.HEADLINE: China raises 310 million yuan for Taiwan storm victims (update-1)
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/21/09 14:53:21 (By Chang Ming-kun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Houston Rockets center Yao Ming called for Chinese people around the world via a televised message Thursday to contribute to post-Typhoon Morakot relief efforts to help victims of the deadliest storm in Taiwan in 50 years.

Speaking during a star-studded fundraiser telethon that took place in Beijing Thursday to raise funds for Taiwanese storm victims, Yao expressed his deepest sympathy to families who lost their loved ones or their homes.

Yao, currently recovering from a foot injury at his U.S. home, said the damage wreaked by Morakot was beyond imagination and prediction, but said that "we people finally conquer each devastating disaster with empathy and compassion for each other."
At least 310 million Chinese yuan (US$45 million) were raised for the typhoon victims in the four-hour telethon co-sponsored by Shanghai Dragon TV and leading television stations in five provinces.
Over 100 movie and athletic stars, as well as notable figures from China's political, cultural, business and entertainment sectors, served as operators to receive phone calls from donors.

China's Red Cross Society and Beijing's intermediary body with Taiwan, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, also pitched in with the fundraiser, the largest of its kind for disaster victims on the other side of the Taiwan Strait.

The fundraiser linked six locations in Shanghai, Nanjing, Hangzhou, Changsha, Shenzhen and Chengdu during the direct broadcast, which also broadcast the donations committed by donors in the six cities.
"The actual amount of donations is still being calculated, " said a Shanghai Dragon TV spokesman.

Among the groups that performed during the fundraiser was a Taiwanese aboriginal group led by Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei. The group, wearing traditional tribal garb, danced and sang songs, including "We are One Family."
Speaking at the function, a visibly moved Kao Chin said that "we don't feel lonely any longer with your care."

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese manufacturers guarantee quality of prefabricated houses

TEXT.P: The Chinese manufacturer of 1,000 prefabricated houses sent to Taiwan to house victims of Typhoon Morakot reiterated Thursday that the units do not contain dangerous levels of formaldehyde, a known carcinogenic.

According to Beijing-based China News Agency, Di Da-hai, administrative manager of Yahgee Modular House Co., Ltd. -- the company that produced the houses -- said that all the company's products undergo strict quality control and none of the materials used for the prefabs contain excessive levels of formaldehyde.
"We had the houses inspected by Taiwanese quality inspection authorities," Di said.
"They knew the houses were safe at first glance, because usually wooden materials are the ones that have problems with formaldehyde, but we barely use any wood in our product."

Di also guaranteed that all aspects of the manufacturing processes conformed to standard operating procedures, rebutting speculation that workers had to rush to prepare the 1,000 houses, thus lowering the production quality.

However, some of the typhoon victims were initially doubtful as to the safety of the prefabs, with residents of one township initially refusing to accept them, although they later changed their minds.

Environmental Protection Administration officials assured the residents that a complete assessment of levels for all toxins, including formaldehyde, would be made before anyone had to move into the units, with an initial report due the following day.

DOC.HEADLINE: President visits more typhoon victims in Kaohsiung County

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou traveled by helicopter to two more mountainous townships in Kaohsiung County Friday to visit residents displaced by Typhoon Morakot.
The tour of Namasia and Taoyuan townships followed a similar one to Jiasian township on Wednesday and another to Liouguei township on Thursday.
Roads leading to the townships remained impassable up to Friday.
Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said Ma is visiting the disaster areas to extend his condolences to the victims and to gain a better understanding of their needs.
This face-to-face contact has allowed the victims to see the president's sincere intention to help them, Wang said.

The government's sluggish response to the disaster and its inefficient rescue efforts have led to widespread public resentment and the most serious leadership crisis the Ma administration has faced since it took office in May 2008.
In an apology to the public Tuesday for his administration's shortcomings, Ma promised to punish the responsible officials and give consideration to reshuffling the Cabinet.
Both Minister of National Defense Chen Chao-min and Executive Yuan Secretary- General Hsieh Hsiang-chuan verbally offered to resign Wednesday.
On reports that former Deputy Taipei Mayor Ou Chin-teh has been tipped as Hsieh's successor, Wang said all media reports regarding the upcoming Cabinet reshuffle are based on speculation.
President Ma has said that he and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan will not discuss the matter until early September, Wang reiterated.
Wang stressed that post-disaster rescue and reconstruction remain the government's top priority at present and that all personnel decisions will be made and announced in early September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Friday:
China Times:
Re-drafting 2010 government budget bill
The Executive Yuan has come up with a special budget bill of NT$100 billion for relief and reconstruction in the aftermath of the flooding caused by Typhoon Morakot.

We can understand why the Executive Yuan will have recourse to a special budget bill to deal with the disaster, because the government's general budget bill has already been formulated and is ready for presentation in September to the legislature for debate.

However, the easy way out is not necessarily the best way, because the government's general budget bill was worked out before the flooding and the government's agenda is sure to be revised in light of this new situation.
Therefore, we urge the Executive Yuan to overhaul its budget plan completely rather than simply tack a special bill onto it.
Liberty Times:
Ma should heed people's voice against him
Ma's popularity cannot be boosted by replacing the premier or reshuffling the Cabinet, which are being made scapegoats to protect him.
From the crisis triggered by Typhoon Morakot, Ma should take three lessons:
1. He should respect the Legislative Yuan and lawmakers, rather
than dictate to it; and lawmakers, especially those from the
ruling Kuomintang, should supervise the Executive Yuan
closely.
2. He should learn to exchange views with the opposition and
push policy only with the opposition's consent;
3. He should give the people the final voice in laying out
national policy, especially his pro-China policy.
United Daily News:
Is Hseh Hsiang-chuan at fault, or the person who picked him as a
Cabinet member?
Hseh Hsiang-chuan, secretary-general of the Cabinet, caused an uproar when he defended his dinning with his family at a restaurant while the island was being pounded by Typhoon Morakot.
He, as well as several other Cabinet members who have committed similar faux pas, have become a millstone around the neck of Ma's administration.
Is that their fault, or the fault of Ma who choose them for the posts ?
Apple Daily:
Debunking the myth of Ph.Ds value in Cabinet
President Ma's Cabinet is known for its many doctorate degree holders.
But the Cabinet is also known for its sluggish response to emergencies, ineptness in executing policy, inability to strategize on how to achieve goals, and ineffective communication with the people.
Cabinet members who do not have the necessary savoir faire and shrewdness cannot be expected to push the Cabinet's policies, far less cement the president's leadership.
This is because most of the Cabinet members are well-educated technocrats -- as are the president and the premier -- and they are out of touch with the people.
None of them have ever gone through the baptism of fire of an election.
We therefore suggest that the president replace his present Cabinet with a cast of veteran politicians, successful business executives and elected chiefs of local government.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close lower on local bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 78.43 points, or 1.16 percent, to close at 6,654.8.
The local bourse opened at 6,785.7 and fluctuated between 6,824.65 and 6,629.1 during the day's trading session.
A total of 3.87 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$102.95 billion (US$3.13 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 4.8 percent. Cement stocks declined 2.4 percent, paper and pulp issues were down 2.2 percent, banking and financial shares decreased 1.5 percent, textile stocks dropped 1.3 percent, machinery and electronics shares declined 1.2 percent and plastics and chemicals shares were down 0.2 percent.
Only one major stock category gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up 1.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,590 to 799, with 164 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$5.96 billion-worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Movies lessen distance between Taiwan, Israel

TEXT.P: The distance between Taiwan and Israel is being lessened by movies and performances, with Raphael Gamzou, the representative of the Israel Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei (ISECO) , meeting recently with locally renowned movie director and producer Lee Khan to discuss filmmaking ideas.

According to the ISECO, Gamzou and Lee talked about potential Taiwanese-Israeli co-productions in their meeting, in which art-lover Gamzou invited Lee to meet with Gila Almagor, an actress from Israel's Habimah National Theatre who is dubbed the "first lady" of Israeli cinema.

Almagor is scheduled to visit Taiwan in October to present an autobiographical one-woman stage play and to share with local audiences several of her films at the Performing Arts Festival organized by the Taipei National University of the Arts.

Gamzou and Lee were brought together not only because of their shared passion for cinema but also for good wine, as the top Israeli representative to Taiwan learnt that Lee had two bottles of Israeli wine he bought in Tel Aviv's Ben Gurion Airport confiscated at Bangkok Airport due to the restrictions on carrying liquids aboard aircraft.

Lee, who is the brother of world renowned director Ang Lee, went to Israel in May to attend the 2009 "Docaviv" international documentary film festival, as it featured a special tribute to Taiwan's documentary filmmaking.

Invited by the film festival to show his production Starts -- a documentary about young people pursuing their dreams of becoming singers -- Lee was among six Taiwanese filmmakers and directors who screened their work at the festival.

After returning from Israel, Lee wrote a letter to ISECO and recounted among other things his disappointment regarding the wine incident. Gamzou therefore decided to offer Lee two bottles of prestigious Israeli wine at their meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flooded areas see growing prevalence of skin disease

TEXT.P: Growing numbers of residents in areas of southern Taiwan where floodwaters from Typhoon Morakot have yet to fully recede are experiencing skin disease because of their exposure to contaminated water.
Many villages still remain blanketed by muddy water two weeks after the typhoon battered Taiwan, and some residents have lingered in it for more than 10 hours a day to clean up their homes.
Experts say the water is full of germs from garbage and animal corpses and can cause serious infections such as cellulitis if it comes into contact with the wounds.

Among the cases is a 70-year-old senior citizen in the coastal town of Linbian township in Pingtung County, who has not been able to sleep because his arms have itched constantly after being in the muddy water too long.
Also, a woman's feet started to blister after wearing rain boots for ten days in a row. Both patients contracted dermatitis, contracted after wading too long in dirty water.

They are just two of numerous villagers who have consulted doctors in the area for inflammatory rashes and itches, and physicians have warned that anybody with such symptoms should immediately get treatment so that the infections do not fester.
Also, young and elderly people who have more sensitive skin have been warned about contracting the fungal skin infection tinea, which leads to itchiness and pealing of the skin.
Doctors have also cautioned that residents in flooded areas should be careful about the water they drink.

There are fears that some may draw on groundwater or springwater for drinking water if their supply of potable water has been cut off because those sources are contaminated and might cause stomach diseases.
People who have also recently had their tap water restored should also be careful because changes in water pipe pressure could "back draw" dirty water into the household pipes.
Excessive fluoride residue is another concern, experts say, because if it is ingested, it may induce asthma or other respiratory ailments.
Flood victims are highly encouraged to boil their tap water before using it.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's China policy provides win-win solution: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/21/09 17:26:59 (By Y.F. Low) (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that his administration's "no unification, no independence, no use of force" approach has allowed Taiwan to simultaneously maintain relations with both China and the United States.
"This raises the possibility for the three sides to come to a win-win or win- win-win solution," Ma said.
Also, Ma said his administration's effort to improve cross-Taiwan Strait relations over the past year has made security ties between Taiwan and the United States less complicated.
The president made the remarks while receiving Howard Berman, chairman of the U.S. House of Representatives' Committee on Foreign Affairs.
Ma noted that he called Berman during transit stops in the United States last year and this year and was impressed with the attention paid by Berman to the implementation of the Taiwan Relations Act.
Congressman Berman, along with his colleagues Eni F.H. Faleomavaega, Jack Kingston, Ruben Hinojosa and Diane Watson, arrived in Taipei on Thursday for a three-day visit. ENDITEM/ls

DOC.HEADLINE: More international assistance flows to Taiwan

TEXT.P: The international community continues to express its condolences and offer assistance for victims in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday.

Mike Coleman, commander of the Salvation Army Taiwan Region, expressed the Christian group's willingness to participate in long-term reconstruction efforts in storm-stricken areas in southern Taiwan, including Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties, according to a MOFA press release.
The London headquarters of the Salvation Army will also send three disaster relief experts to assess what assistance it can provide, the press release added.

Meanwhile, Taiwan continues to receive condolences for typhoon victims from diplomatic allies and friendly countries around the world, including deep sympathies expressed by Gambian President Yahya A.J.J. Jammeh, Idaho Governor C.L."Butch" Otter, New York Governor David Paterson, and New York City Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

As of Aug. 20, at least 81 countries from around the world, the European Union, and 21 international organizations had donated a total of NT$160 million in relief aid to Taiwan, according to the latest figures released by the MOFA.

Typhoon Morakot lashed Taiwan two weeks ago, dumping massive amounts of rain on the southern parts of the country. As of 1 p.m. Friday, the storm had killed at least 153 people across Taiwan, with 45 people injured and 464 others unaccounted for.
Agricultural losses had surged to more than NT$13.4 billion (US$407 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: Obesity found associated with three genetic loci in ethnic Chinese

TEXT.P: After six years of research and genome comparisons, a Taiwanese research team has found recently that three genetic loci, or positions on a chromosome, are associated with severe obesity in ethnic Chinese.
Severe obesity is associated with novel single nucleotide polymorphisms of the ESR1 and PPAR loci in Han Chinese.

According to Pan Wen-harn, a researcher with the Institute of Biomedical Sciences, Academia Sinica, severe obesity is associated with novel single nucleotide polymorphisms, or DNA sequence variation, of the ESR1 and PPAR loci in ethnic Chinese.

Pan said many loci associated with obesity have been reported, with at least 18 genes having been replicated in five studies on obesity-related indicators and that 14 additional genes having been associated with obesity in Asians.

Pan and his associates examined these variants identified in medical periodicals in an attempt to find out how many are associated with severe obesity in Han Chinese and how they are combined to exert their effects.

In collaboration with Lee Wei-jei, vice president of Min-Sheng General Hospital in Taoyuan County, Pan and his group selected 304 severely obese patients with body mass index (BMI) exceeding 39 from the hospital and 304 control subjects with BMI smaller than 24 selected from Academia Sinica's Han Chinese Gene Data Bank to participate in a two-stage association study.

Subsequently, 220 additional severely obese patients (BMI 35) and 338 controls (BMI 24) were recruited to replicate the results, Pan said. All of the controls were age-, sex-, education- and residence-matched.
Finally, a pooled analysis was carried out based on all 514 cases and 606 controls with complete information, he added.
In the first stage, in tests on 94 cases and 94 controls, the researchers found 18 potentially associated single nucleotide polymorphisms, Pan said.
The significance of three novel common single nucleotide polymorphisms, one on ESR1 and two on PPAR, were confirmed in the second stage and replicated further, he said.
A combination of the three genes was stronger than that of any individual gene and resulted in a five-times greater risk of severe obesity than in those without the genetic variations.
"This information may contribute to the assessment of risk of severe obesity," he noted.
A summary of the study was carried in the August 2009 issue of the American Journal of Clinical Nutrition.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, falling NT$0.060 to close at NT$32.906.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.996 and reached a low of NT$32.888.

DOC.HEADLINE: Aboriginal legislator defends decision to accept donation from China

TEXT.P: Independent lawmaker Kao Chin Su-mei from the indigenous Atayal tribe said Friday that her acceptance of a disaster relief donation from China was not illegal and that anyone who wants to could monitor her distribution of the funds.

Kao, who is leading a group of 80 representatives of Taiwan aboriginal tribes on a visit to Beijing, accepted a donation of 20 million yuan (NT$96 million or US$2.9 million) from China's Taiwan Affairs Office Wednesday to aid victims of Typhoon Morakot.

However, Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has expressed reservations over the donation, saying that because of the way it was made, it will be difficult for the government to monitor its disbursement.

"That is not the way to make a contribution for relief aid, " MAC Deputy Chairman Liu Te-shun said Thursday, noting that the donation had not been routed through the Ministry of the Interior or the Red Cross Society of Taiwan.

In response, Kao on Friday promised that the fund will be used transparently and that proper records will be kept. The records will be made available the donor, to Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation and to anyone else, including the MAC, who wishes to see them, she said.
"The MAC is also welcome to help disburse the funds, if it has the time," she added.
She argued that there is no law to prevent her from accepting the donation on behalf of aboriginal typhoon victims.

In adherence to the donor's wishes, the money will be used to help rehabilitate families in minor aboriginal tribes in Taiwan who lost their homes in the massive flooding and landslides triggered by the storm, she said.

In addition to the funds from the Taiwan Affairs Office, donations of 1.5 million yuan each were received from China's state-run Sinosteel Corp. and a Guangdong-based business enterprise for the purpose of helping aboriginal students in the disaster areas return to school, the lawmaker said.

She promised to hold a presentation ceremony Saturday in Sandimen township, Pingtung County to inform the residents about the donation and solicit the opinions of typhoon victims there on how the money should be used.
Many of the mountain villages that suffered the worst flooding and landslides in the typhoon were home to Taiwan's aboriginal people.
The storm, which pummeled the island Aug. 7-9, has left hundreds of people dead or missing and many others homeless.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC adopts unprecedented gasoline pricing system

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-owned petroleum company, CPC Corp., announced Friday that it will use a three-tiered pricing system for gasoline across the country to ease the burden on areas hit hard by Typhoon Morakot.

Starting at midnight Friday, gasoline and diesel prices in certain remote mountainous townships hardest-hit by Morakot-triggered flooding and landslides will be lowered, while prices in eight affected city and counties will remain unchanged, and prices in unaffected localities will be raised.
It will mark the first time that CPC Corp. has ever adopted a multi-tiered pricing system.
"The strategy is part of the government's efforts to help reduce the financial burden of typhoon victims, " said Vice Minister of Economic Affairs John Chen- chung Deng at a news conference.

Under the new system, gasoline prices at 31 CPC-run or franchised gas stations in townships and villages that bore the brunt of the typhoon destruction will be lowered by NT$2.1 (US$0.0636) per liter and prices for diesel will be cut by NT$1.
"The preferential prices will remain valid for two months, " CPC Vice President Lin Mao-wen said. "After that, we will make a new decision depending on the progress in reconstruction."

Gasoline and diesel prices will remain unchanged in areas affected by the storm -- Tainan City and Kaohsiung, Tainan, Chiayi, Yunlin, and Pingtung counties in southern Taiwan, Nantou County in central Taiwan and Taitung County in eastern Taiwan.

In all other zones barely affected by the typhoon -- mainly northern Taiwan, eastern Taiwan's Yilan and Hualien counties, and Chiayi and Kaohsiung cities in southern Taiwan, gasoline and diesel prices will be raised by NT$0.4 and NT$0.5, respectively.
In those areas, the price per liter of 92, 95, and 98 octane gasoline will be NT$28.7, NT$29.4 and NT$30.9 respectively.
Given steady increases in crude oil prices in the international market, Lin said, the company should have raised its gasoline and diesel prices by NT$0.8 and NT$0.9 per liter.
But because of the significant surge in prices of vegetables, fruit, chicken eggs, and pork driven by the widespread destruction of the typhoon, the company decided to limit its price hike, Lin said.

The company actually should have adjusted prices higher two weeks ago to reflect rising crude oil costs according to a weekly pricing mechanism adopted last year, the executive said, but held off on making any adjustments for two weeks in the aftermath of the storm.

As a freeze in fuel price adjustments mainly benefits those unaffected by the typhoon rather than typhoon victims, Lin said, CPC decided to adjust its gasoline and diesel prices to let market mechanisms function normally.

DOC.HEADLINE: Formosa Plastics Group pledges more aid in aftermath of storm

TEXT.P: The Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) pledged Friday to increase its aid for post- typhoon recovery, saying that it will donate an additional NT$1 billion (US$30.4 million) to help rebuild schools in areas that were flooded in the storm.

FPG Chairman Wang Wen-yuan said that after its donation of NT$300 million last week, the FPG and its employees decided Friday to contribute another NT$1 billion for rehabilitation in southern Taiwan in the wake of the deadliest storm in Taiwan in half a century.
Wang said the FPG has its own construction and engineering teams that can quickly rebuild schools and infrastructure systems.

In 1999, after a 7.3 magnitude earthquake in Taiwan killed some 2,400 people and left 100,000 others homeless, the conglomerate donated at least NT$900 million to the disaster relief effort. The group has also funded the construction of 26 schools, at a total cost of NT$1.77 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County magistrate promises to help Pingtung with rehabilitation

TEXT.P: Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei visited Jiadong township in the southern county of Pingtung Friday to gain a better understanding of the situation there and to see how his local government could help.
He promised to assist with the clean up in areas that were devastated by flash floods during Typhoon Morakot and to help rebuild water conservation and irrigation systems.
The Taipei County government has also decided to give NT$5,000 to each household in Jiadong and the neighboring Gaoshu township, two of the hardest-hit areas in Pingtung County, Chou added.

Meanwhile, students from the Wu Feng Institute of Technology in Chiayi County will go to Alishan township, the hardest-hit area in Chiayi County, Aug. 24 to help clean up the campus of Shan Mei Elementary School, which was partially destroyed by flash floods and mudslides triggered by Typhoon Morakot.

The students will also clean and service the school's computers, said Wu Feng authorities, who last week launched a donation drive in Chiayi to collect books, toys and stationery for children in Alishan township.
National Chung Cheng University in Chiayi County has also launched a campaign aimed at providing subsidies to its students whose homes were destroyed or damaged in the storm.
A total of 1,403 students at the university are from the flood-affected areas in southern and eastern Taiwan, according to the school authorities.
The university's faculty and students have also decided to help with the post- disaster work to clean up and repair elementary and junior high schools, the authorities said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alishan Highway expected to reopen in one month

TEXT.P: The Alishan Highway, which was seriously damaged during Typhoon Morakot, is expected to reopen in one month, the Directorate General of Highways (DGH) said Friday.
DGH officials noted that rainfall on the famous, scenic mountain that is popular with domestic and international tourists reached nearly 3,000 mm when the typhoon pummeled Taiwan from Aug. 7-9.

As a result of the heavy rainfall, which weakened the soil, the 89-km highway suffered serious erosion of its foundation and six sections of the highway were broken or washed away by flood waters or mudslides.

An official from DGH's Fifth Maintenance Office said that workers have now repaired broken sections of the road up to the 59 km marker of the highway, and estimated that the highway can reopen by Sept. 20.
"But in the initial stage, only small cars will be allowed to travel on the road. Tourist buses or trucks will have to wait for some time later," he said.
That is because repairs up to that point will only enable the highway to have one lane in certain parts, so it will not be able to accommodate large vehicles.
Meanwhile, the hardest-hit 10 villages in Alishan township and Taiho village in nearby Meishan township are still inaccessible to the outside world, two weeks after Typhoon Morakot struck Taiwan.

Most of the communities in Alishan have relied on the Alishan Highway to travel to and from the mountain. Now that the mountain's major transportation route is disrupted, they have become isolated islands and have had to rely on food and supplies airlifted by military helicopters.
The DGH, which is under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, has estimated that restoration of the highway will cost as much as NT$1.75 billion.
In related news, 500 packages of relief goods from South Korea were carried by vehicles and workers to affected areas in Alishan.
Each package contains daily necessities and food, which will be enough for a four-member family to live on for four days.

Meanwhile, the Alishan National Scenic Area under the Tourism Bureau said that with Alishan now out of reach, they are planning to set up a signboard of Alishan at Wufeng Memorial Park, about 26 km into the highway, and another scenic spot nearby -- Tijiou Bridge -- for tourists to take pictures.
Starting Aug. 24, the Tourism Bureau will also offer dance performances by the Tsou indigenous people at Wufeng Memorial Park so that the tourism-dependent area can continue to attract tourists.
Before the typhoon, there used to be four such performances by Tsou people at the Alishan Railway Station, which had delighted of tourists, especially those from mainland China.
