DOC.HEADLINE: Q3 electronic component output growth forecast at 20% Q-on-Q

TEXT.P: The output of Taiwan's electronic components sector is expected to reach NT$174 billion (US$5.3 billion) in the third quarter this year, 20 percent higher than in Q2, the Industry and Technology Intelligence Services (ITIS) forecast Friday.

The technology intelligence provider, operated by the quasi-official Industrial Technology Research Institute, attributed the increase to surging demand for Chinese "bandit" phones and for CULV (consumer ultra low voltage) notebooks sold by major vendors such as Acer, Asustek, Lenovo Taiwan and Dell.
Bandit mobile phones, gray market handsets that closely approximate branded phones but are sold in China for a fraction of the price, depend heavily on components made in Taiwan.

Despite continuing quarter-on-quarter growth, the ITIS said the sector's estimated output for 2009 of NT$601.1 billion would still be 16 percent less than last year because of the global economic downturn.
Local manufacturers will also suffer declines in net earnings this year, because the economic slump has driven consumers toward cheaper low- and middle-end electronic products, the organization said.
The sector's output in Q2 grew 30 percent from Q1 to NT$145.5 billion, thanks to increasing demand from China, but the figure was still 17 percent lower than in the second quarter of 2008.
Semiconductors posted the highest Q-on-Q growth of any component in the sector, their output of NT$14 billion in Q2 43 percent higher than in the previous quarter.
The ITIS attributed the growth to the increasing popularity of light emitting diodes (LED) in the production of backlighting for LCD panels.

The ITIS predicted that LEDs will be used for the backlighting of at least 50 percent of notebooks produced this year for the first time ever, and said they are also being aggressively marketed for use in LCD flat panel TVs.

Meanwhile, the ITIS also reported that the Q3 output of printed circuit boards is expected to grow by 36 percent from the second quarter to NT$75.7 billion, while energy component output should rise 14 percent to NT$19.3 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan still needs U.S. to supply weapons: envoy
DOC.DATELINE: Chicago, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/21/09 20:40:57 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan needs the United States to continue supplying it defensive weapons to beef up its strength as it engages and negotiates with China, the country's top representative to the United States said here Thursday.

Speaking at a luncheon organized by the National Strategy Forum (NSF), a Chicago-based non-partisan think tank, Jason Yuan said U.S. President Barack Obama will follow the Taiwan policy adopted by his predecessor, George W. Bush, of providing Taiwan with necessary assistance.
According to the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), the United States is obligated to continue providing Taiwan with adequate military arsenals to safeguard its national security.

With President Ma Ying-jeou actively improving relations with China since taking office last year, Yuan said the Taiwan Strait is no longer a potential flashpoint, a development that is in the U.S. interest.

Nevertheless, Taiwan still needs to reinforce its military muscle to strengthen its position in negotiations with China, Yuan told an audience of nearly 50 elite members of political, economic and academic communities in the Chicago area.
Yuan said he is convinced that the United States will honor its commitment to furnish Taiwan with needed military hardware and services in accordance with the TRA, a U.S. law.

With cross-strait ties warming up, Yuan said Taiwan has managed to attend this year's World Health Assembly -- the decision-making arm of the World Health Organization -- as an observer and sign the World Trade Organization-affiliated Government Procurement Agreement to facilitate expansion of commercial exchanges with other countries.
Responding to questions raised by participants on the latest cross-strait situation, Yuan said cross-strait negotiations are now focusing on topics related to people's livelihood.
As political systems on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait remain far different, Yuan said, bilateral negotiations on political topics will be shelved for the time being.
Postponing solutions to those issues to the future is the view shared by a majority of Taiwan people, Yuan said.
He assured the audience that in its engagements with China, Taiwan will pursue a Taipei-Washington-Beijing "win-win-win" scenario on the basis of common interests.
Stressing that the United States is Taiwan's most important ally, Yuan said both countries share the same beliefs in a democratic and liberal political system.
Yuan said his office has often invited friends from many U.S. social circles to visit Taiwan to enhance their understanding of and support for Taiwan.

On the devastation Taiwan suffered from Typhoon Morakot, Yuan said Taiwan appreciated the assistance offered by the United States and some 70 other countries. Such aid indicated Taiwan is not alone in the international community, he added.

The luncheon meeting was chaired by NSF President Richard Friedman. Among the audience were Chicago Vice Mayor Bernard Stone and political science professors from the University of Chicago, Loyola University and DePaul University.

DOC.HEADLINE: Muzha-Neihu MRT line closed for repairs

TEXT.P: Service on the Taipei Muzha-Neihu Mass Transit (MRT) Line will be suspended from 10 p.m. Friday to 6 a.m. Monday for repairs on its electrical system, the director of the city's Department of Transportation said Friday.

The city government will provide free shuttle buses along the two sections of the line, Lou Hsiao-hsien said, adding that the bus service will begin at 9 p.m. Friday, and will run Saturday and Sunday from 5: 40 a.m. to midnight.

The shuttle buses will operate between Taipei Nangang Exhibition Center Station and Linguang Station along one section, and between Songshan Airport and Taipei Zoo along the other section of the MRT line.

With the approach of the 21st Summer Deaflympics in Taipei Sept. 5-15 and given that there are no guarantees that the problematic line will not have to be closed again, the city's Department of Transportation has preparations in place to deal with any glitches on the line, Lou said.
More shuttle buses will be put into service close to the Nanjing E. Road and Zhongxiao stations, both of which are in the area of the Deaflympics main venue, Lou said.

Mayor Hau Lung-bin said on Thursday that there was no question of eventually closing the Neihu section of the MRT Line, refuting rumors that the city government intended to abandon the Bambarier Inc.-built Neihu Line to save the Muzha section of the line.
Hau said the Canadian company has vowed to fix the unstable system at all costs and will conduct a final test of its repair work one week before the Deaflympics open on Sept. 5.
Hau reiterated that Bambarier has a responsibility to fulfill the terms of its contract.

The Neihu Line is a medium capacity system that runs on viaducts, except for the section near Taipei Songshan Airport. It covers 14.8 km and connects with the 13 -year-old Matra-constructed Muzha Line, providing transport services to Taipei's suburban areas of Neihu, Nangang and Muzha.
The Neihu Line, however, has been plagued with problems since it began commercial services July 4 and has since been shut down several times due to system failures.
The latest closure was on Thursday after there were a record three breakdowns that day alone on the line.

DOC.HEADLINE: President promises to settle typhoon victims in safe areas

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou promised Friday that the government's reconstruction and settlement measures targeting the Typhoon Morakot-affected people will be more complete in the future.

Ma made the promise during a visit to Namasia township in Kaohsiung County, which has yet to be connected to the outside world after the main road leading to the area was damaged by flooding and landslides triggered by the typhoon two weeks ago.

After arrived in the township by helicopter accompanied by other officials, Ma told local residents, "we are late " and bowed in apology for nearly 10 seconds, an acknowledgement of criticism that the government did not act quickly enough in dealing with the disaster as it unfolded.

Answering the local people's demands for help, Ma promised to fix the broken roads and electricity systems and vowed that before that time, the military would ensure that the village had enough food and drinking water.
Ma was accompanied by Council of Indigenous Peoples Minister Chang Jen-hsiang and Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing.
Namasia was among the townships in southern Taiwan most affected by the flooding, which was the worst in 50 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: First batch of prefab houses in south to be ready in three weeks

TEXT.P: The first lot of prefabricated houses to be built in Kaohsiung County for victims of Typhoon Morakot will be completed in about three weeks, the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China said Friday.
The nonprofit organization has pledged to donate 400 prefab houses to the county, and the first 100 will be erected in two locations -- next to a junior high school and close to a temple.
"Land clearing begins Friday and the houses are expected to be completed in three weeks," a spokesman for the organization said.
The first batch of prefab houses will have an area of about 15 pings (49.5 square meters), complete with a bathroom and a kitchen.

The prefab houses built beside Shanlin Junior High School will mainly accommodate disaster victims from Siaolin Village in Jiashien Township, while those located near Tiantai Temple will house people from Taoyuan Township.

Siaolin was buried by landslides early Aug. 9 after torrential rains from Typhoon Morakot had pummeled Taiwan's southern mountains for over two days. Shanlin lies well downriver from Siaolin and was less badly bruised by the storm.
Kaohsiung County has also asked the head of Liouguei to find a site where 100 prefab houses can be put up to shelter flood victims from the township's Sinkai and Sinfa villages.
In addition to the Red Cross Society, the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation and World Vision Taiwan will also donate prefab houses.

The Tzu Chi Foundation will build 300 permanent housing units for displaced flood victims. Those located near Shanlin Junior High School will accommodate residents from Taoyuan and Namasia townships, while units in Wulipu, one of the three major communities in Siaolin, will house survivors from the section of the village that was destroyed.
Kaohsiung County officials said that the number of short-term and long-term prefab houses to be built will depend on the needs of the flood victims.
The officials are surveying flood victims in 20 temporary shelters to discern their desire to move into the prefab houses.

Meanwhile, Pingtung County Magistrate Tsao Chi-hung said Friday that the Tzu Chi Foundation, the Red Cross Society and World Vision Taiwan will build mid-way housing units to help displaced victims in aboriginal communities.
The Tzu Chi Foundation will sponsor 586 units in the villages of Ali, Chilu, Haocha, Chiamu, Tawu and Kuchuan in the remote mountainous Wutai Township.
Among them are some 177 households that originally lived in Haocha, including 127 that agreed to be relocated to a military barrack two years ago due to landslides,
World Vision Taiwan says it will sponsor the resettlement of 317 households in three villages -- Taser, Talai and Derwen -- in two mountainous Pingtung County townships.

"A team of architects and villagers will work hand-in-hand to build the housing units," Tsao said, adding that Taser village has a number of famous artists, and the housing units will be given the flavor of the Paiwan indigenous peoples.

The Red Cross Society will sponsor 660 households from two villages further south in Laiyi township -- Laiyi and Yilin -- and Taiwu village in Taiwu township. All victims have been temporarily sheltered in a military barrack.
"The village people will be sheltered for the time being, and they can decide if they want to stay on for a longer time, " Tsao said.

The villagers will leave the mountainous region for the time being, but their lands in the mountain still belong to them, and they can still return for hunting to preserve the tradition of the indigenous people, Tsao said.

Meanwhile, China will send technicians to Taiwan to help with the construction of the prefab houses they have donated after local workers could not put together the parts because of a lack of structural and assembly instructions, and a confusion over technical terms in the information that China id provide.
China also announced that it will send 200 more prefab houses to Taiwan Aug. 22, which it said will meet international environmental standards, according to TV reports.

The first batch has proved controversial as some have charged the materials contain excessive levels of formaldehyde, a known carcinogenic. The Environmental Protection Administration is conducting tests on the quality of air in the houses both when they are and are not ventilated.
They expect the results to be available Aug. 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature to meet next week to screen reconstruction bill

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng announced Friday that the Legislature will convene a three-day extraordinary session starting Aug. 25 to deal with a special bill on reconstruction in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot.

Wang made the announcement after chairing a meeting of legislative caucus whips of the ruling and opposition parties to discuss whether to hold an extraordinary session or advance the opening of the next formal legislative session to screen the special reconstruction bill as early as possible.

"The caucus whips reached a consensus quickly on convening an extraordinary session next Tuesday through Thursday, " Wang said, adding that they are also determined to complete the third reading of the bill before the end of the session.
The bill will authorize the Executive Yuan to raise NT$100 billion (US$3.03 billion) over three years to finance various post-disaster reconstruction projects.
"We all agree that the bill should be passed as soon as possible to speed up rehabilitation work," Wang added.

During the meeting, ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator George Hsieh, who is also a party whip, said more money may be needed for reconstruction as Morakot- triggered flooding and landslides have left more than 600 people dead or missing, and caused an estimated NT$13.4 billion in agricultural losses and severe damage to a large number of roads and bridges in southern Taiwan.
If needed, Hsieh said, the Legislature will support an increase in the budget for reconstruction projects.
The Cabinet-drafted bill is expected to clear the legislative floor smoothly as the KMT controls an absolute majority in the Legislature.

Meanwhile, opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tsai Huang-liang said the government should exempt those whose homes were buried by landslides or washed away by flash floods from repaying outstanding loans on those homes or interest payments on new homes to be built in the aftermath of the disaster.
Such practices were implemented after a devastating magnitude-7.3 earthquake hit Taiwan Sept. 21, 1999 and killed some 2,500 people while leaving tens of thousands homeless, Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Reconstruction projects to face public scrutiny: President

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that every post-flood reconstruction project has a timetable, and he asked the public to help monitor their progress.

"The timetable of every project will be put on record and its progress monitored at least once a month. The results will be published for the scrutiny of the public," said Ma, who expects the first progress report to be issued on Sept. 8.
The pledge came after listening to a briefing by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan on post-flood reconstruction in Cishan, Kaohsiung.

The president noted there would be four stages -- rescue, shelter, resettlement and reconstruction -- in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot, which pummeled Taiwan with torrential rains Aug. 7-9, triggering the worst flooding in southern Taiwan in half a century,

"Currently, the rescue part has been largely completed, although we are still conducting the rescue mission in a few places. Some isolated communities still need outside support, but most areas have started resettlement and reconstruction," Ma said.
"More than 6,000 people are still in temporary shelters, and we hope that they can return to normal life soon," he said.
"The flooding was a tragic experience, " the president said, noting that over 100 people perished while more than 400 are missing and the agricultural and property losses are too big to calculate.

Before the meeting, Ma also led officials from the Cabinet and heads of the seven counties in southern and southeastern Taiwan hard hit by the flood to observe a minute of silence for those who perished in the flood and mudslides.

Meanwhile, the head of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said that a major blueprint for post-flood construction will be completed in two weeks and submitted to the Executive Yuan early next month.

CEPD Chairman Chen Tain-jy said that the principle for initial reconstruction includes "mitigation, " referring to reductions in populations and production activities, although the level of reduction still needs careful assessment.
After the major projects, then related government agencies will propose sub- projects related to homelands, living and schooling, industrial production and infrastructure.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water, power rate benefits for typhoon victims unveiled

TEXT.P: Those whose homes were hit by flooding during Typhoon Morakot will have their water and electricity bills waived or reduced for specified periods of time depending on the extent of damage their houses suffered.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs John Chen-chung Deng annoucned at a news conference that state-owned Taiwan Power Co. and Taiwan Water Corp. will offer exemptions or deductions to help ease the burden on typhoon victims.
According to the plan, those whose houses were submerged in floodwaters higher than 50 centimeters will be exempted from paying for up to 10 cubic meters of water for at least the next two months.

People who rebuild their houses at the original locations or reside in government-provided prefabricated houses will be exempted from water payments for two years if their water consumption falls below 20 cubic meters per month.
Meanwhile, those whose homes were waterlogged by floodwaters higher than 50 centimeters will not pay for electricity up to 110 kilowatt hours for at least two months.
They will not have to pay for electricity used under 330 kwh during the summer and 110 kwh per month during the other months for the next two years if they live in prefabicated houses.
Those whose houses were toppled and rendered uninhabitable will be exempted from paying water or electricity fees for the most recent payment period.

Typhoon Morakot dumped more than 2500 mm of precipitation or a year's worth of rains in southern Taiwan Aug. 7-9, swelling rivers that washed away bridges and spurring landslides that buried entire villages.

The storm, one of the worst natural disasters to batter Taiwan in half a century, had left more than 600 people dead or missing as of Friday as the military continued to dig up bodies buried deep under rocks and mud.

The Central Emergency Operation Center has confirmed 153 deaths since the typhoon hit as well as listed 464 people missing who were feared buried in landslides that wiped out parts of villages nestle on mountains in southern Taiwan.

According to the center, the exact number of people feared buried in landslides that obliterated Kaohsiung County's Siaolin Village and Sinkai tribal community in Liuguei township are still being investigated by the county's disaster response center.
As of 1 p.m. Friday, agricultural and fishing losses were estimated at NT$13.45 billion, with Pingtung, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Chiayi counties reported worst losses in that order.
The government had opened 47 emergency placement centers to shelter 5,678 evacuated typhoon victims as of Friday afternoon.
Several low-lying villages in Pingtung County were still submerged in 20 centimeter-high floodwaters. Military servicemen have been mobilized to help with cleanup.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet official says Taiwan's economy coming out of recession

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy has gradually come out of recession and will return to the pre- recession level of early last year by the fourth quarter at the earliest, according to a Cabinet official in charge of economic planning.
Minister Chen Tian-jy of the Council for Economic Planning and Development said that the economy bottomed out earlier than expected and the risk of a down-up- down pattern W-shaped recovery is slim.

A forecast released Thursday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics predicts Taiwan's economy to achieve an annual growth of 3.92 percent next year, with quarterly growth rates of 8.1 percent, 4.51 percent, 2.03 percent and 1.43 percent.
Chen said the nation's economy posting for consecutive quarter-on-quarter negative growth rates beginning in 2008 Q2 but began posting positive QoQ growth rates in the second quarter of this year.
In year-on-year terms, however, the economy contracted by 7.54 percent in the second quarter after declining 10.13 percent in the first quarter.
While many countries in the world have already begun to recover, Chen expects that Taiwan will not return to positive YoY growth until the fourth quarter of this year at the earliest.

The statistics bureau reported earlier that Taiwan's economy is expected to contract 4.40 percent, although the economy is expected to gain strength through the rest of the year despite the major economic disruption caused by Typhoon Morakot.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday Aug. 22, or the third day of the seventh month of the Year of the Ox, according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1834: Samuel Pierpoint Langley, American astronomer and aviation pioneer, is born. He built the first successful heavier-than-air flying machines in 1896.
1849: Amaral, the Portuguese governor of Macao, is assassinated for practicing anti-Chinese politics.
1910: Korea is formally annexed by Japan after five years as a Japanese protectorate.
1911: Leonardo da Vinci's Mona Lisa, one of the world's most famous paintings, is stolen from the Louvre in Paris. It was returned two years later.
1919: Some 5,000 Jews are massacred in the Ukraine.
1932: Japanese troops attack Jehol in northern China.
1937: The Chinese Communist Party issues a statement calling on the people to obey the National government and join the War of Resistance Against Japan, and changes its "Red Army" into the Eighth Army.
1941: German troops reach the outskirts of Leningrad.
1942: Madame Chiang Kai-shek leaves for the United States for a visit at the invitation of President Franklin D. Roosevelt. FDR announced on March 30 the establishment of the Pacific War Council in Washington, comprised of China, the United States, the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Australia, Canada and the Netherlands.
1968: Warsaw Pact tanks enter Prague, the Czech capital, to crush the first flowering of Alexander Dubcek's reforms.
1973: Henry Kissinger is named U.S. secretary of state, succeeding William Rogers.
1981: A Boeing 737 passenger plane owned by the Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes near Miaoli in central Taiwan, killing all 110 people aboard.
1983: China Airlines suspends its CI811 flight to Manila on orders of the Philippine civil aviation authorities. Manila had warned international airlines not to allow opposition leader Benigno Aquino to board their aircraft for a return to the Philippines on the grounds that he did not have legal travel papers.
Aquino was gunned down on Aug. 21 while soldiers were escorting him from his China Airlines flight from Taipei upon his return to Manila after three years of self-exile in the United States.
1985: The Executive Yuan approves the appointment by President Chiang Ching-kuo of Ronald H. C. Ho (Ho Hsien-chung) as the new finance political vice minister.
1985: A British Airtour Boeing 747 bound for Corfu catches fire at Manchester Airport shortly after engine failure had forced the pilot to abandon the takeoff. The fire killed 54 people aboard.
1986: Francisco Zepeda Andino, the new Honduran ambassador to the Republic of China, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1986: Wang Han successfully swims across the Strait of Gibraltar, becoming the first Chinese person to do so.
1986: Typhoon Wayne blasts across central and southern Taiwan and the Pescadores (Penghu), killing or injuring 256 people and causing property losses estimated at NT$11.5 billion. The typhoon damage is the heaviest in the past twenty years. The Executive Yuan allocates NT$1 billion to help victims.
1995: The KMT convenes its 14th National Congress and Lee Teng-hui, party chairman, announces he will seek the party's presidential nomination. Lin Yang- kang, a KMT vice chairman, declares his intention not to seek the party's nomination and to instead run as an independent.
1996: The 61-nation Conference on Disarmament in Geneva ends in failure after India blocked an agreement on a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.
1999: A China Airlines passenger plane with 315 on board crash-lands at Chek Lap Kok airport in Hong Kong during a typhoon, killing two and injuring 211.
2000: Opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong says that it is still too early to talk about overhauling the Guidelines for National Unification as the government has yet to demonstrate consistency regarding its cross-strait policies.
2000: Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore decorades visiting ROC President Chen Shui-bian with the Order of Grande Croix in recognition of his contribution to promoting bilateral ties.
2001: Republic of China Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya, along with a 20-strong delegation, attends the 2001 Women's Leaders Meeting under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Beijing.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If another man succeeds through one effort, use a hundred efforts. If another man succeeds though ten efforts, use a thousand efforts. Let a man really proceed in this manner, and, though dull, he will surely become intelligent; though weak, he will surely become strong."

DOC.HEADLINE: Magnitude-5.6 earthquake rocks southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 5.6 on the Richter scale struck southern Taiwan early Saturday morning, the Seismological Center under the Central Weather Bureau said.
No casulties or damage was reported.
The quake occurring at 4: 57 a.m. (Friday 2057 GMT) was centered 31.6 kilometers southwest of Fangliao, Pingtung County, at a depth of 50.5 kilometers below sea level, seismologists said.
Moderate shaking was felt in Kaohsiung City, Kaohsiung Port and the Pingtung- controlled island of Liouciouyu, and slight shaking was felt in Pingtung City and Tainan County's Cigu area, they said.
Feeble shaking was felt in Taitung County's Ansuo area, Tainan City, Chiayi County's Lioujiao area, and Yunlin County's Sihhu area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Veterans return to Kinmen for 51st anniversary of '823 Battle'

TEXT.P: A group of approximately 100 veterans of the "823 Battle" returned to Kinmen Saturday to take part in activities marking the 51st anniversary of artillery shelling of the island group by China.
The veterans toured various battle sites in Kinmen soon after their arrival and are expected to attend a ceremony to be held Sunday in memory of their deceased comrades.

Lu Fang-yen, leader of an association for "823 Battle" veterans, said the veterans came to Kinmen not to celebrate Taiwan's victory in the battle, but to tell their lost comrades that they have not been forgotten.
The battle left 439 Taiwanese soldiers dead or missing, with 1,870 others injured.
Lu reminded the public that the battle's victory was crucial to the prosperity and progress of Taiwan and urged the government to provide proper benefits for aging veterans.

The conflict, known internationally as the Battle of the Taiwan Strait, began on Aug. 23, 1958 with China launching heavy bombardment on Kinmen. More than 30,000 shells were fired by China in the first 85 minutes alone.
The Chinese military did not suspend the bombardment until Oct. 6, when the intensive action had continued for 44 days.

On Oct. 20, however, China resumed the shelling. This second action ran through Oct. 25 when Beijing announced it would shift to the strategy of bombing Kinmen on odd-numbered days and resting on even-numbered days.
When the battle finally came to an end on Jan. 7, 1959, the Chinese troops had fired approximately 480,000 shells, but still failed to pound Kinmen into submission.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan firm unveils world's thinnest fan for electronic goods

TEXT.P: A Kaohsiung-based company has earned a silver award at the 2009 National Invention and Creation contest for developing the world's thinnest fan to cool down electronic gadgets.
The fan, with a thickness of only 3 mm, is nearly half as thick as the 5 mm regular mini fans, and is one 1 mm thinner than the thinnest fan of 4 mm produced by a Japanese company.
Mini fans are in high demand as electronic gadgets, such as mobile phones and wrist watches, are competing with each other to be the smallest of their kind.
The Kaohsiung company Sunon has patented its invention, which can be installed in small spaces in electronic products and propel strong air currents through its blades.
Founded in 1980, Sunon owns 1,367 patents globally, including 187 obtained in the last four years, most of which involve the core technology of engines manufacturing.

An executive of Sunon said the company boasts a worldwide market share of 26 percent for slide-projectors, 19 percent for notebook computers, 8 percent for audio video systems in vehicles, and 6 percent for computer hard drives.

DOC.HEADLINE: President mourns Typhoon Morakot victims in Siaolin, Xinkai

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou again apologized Saturday over the disaster caused by Typhoon Morakot as he mourned people who perished in two of the hardest-hit locations in Kaohsiung County.

"The government is sorry to you. It failed to fulfill its responsibility of protecting you, " Ma said while attending a Buddhist prayer service held in Jiasian township to mourn residents who were killed by massive flooding and landslides that hit Siaolin Village on Aug. 9.
Around 400 people are believed buried alive when the entire village was destroyed in minutes. The authorities are still verifying the exact number of fatalities.

Ma renewed his promise to help the surviving villagers rebuild their homes during his term. The government will also help the affected families find temporary residence and provide them with all necessary schooling and employment assistance, he said.
A memorial park or monument may be set up in the village for the deceased depending on the desires of the bereaved families, he said.

At the scene of the service, however, some angry villagers were protesting against a water channelling project carried out by the government near Siaolin, which they believed were the main cause of the landslides. They demanded that Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, who also attended the ceremony, be replaced to assume responsibility for the disaster.
In response to the demand, Ma said although the project was not decided by his administration, he will investigate the matter to find out if any human errors were involved.
Ma later went to Liouguei Township to take part in another Buddhist prayer service held for those who were killed by mudslides in the indigenous community of Xinkai.
The president promised the surviving residents that related reconstruction work will be completed within his term. He assumed office in May 2008 and will serve a four-year term.
Ma later headed to a shelter in Pingtung County's Sandimen Township to visit people who were evacuated from Wutai township.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2009 British Food Fair opens in Taipei

TEXT.P: The 2009 British Food Fair opened Saturday, featuring over 100 kinds of food products imported from the United Kingdom.

The Taipei-based British Trade and Cultural Office's (BTCO) Director David Campbell said at an opening ceremony that the food fair, which is being organized with a high-end supermarket, provides a variety of sweet and savory products specially sourced from the United Kingdom to bring local customers the taste of traditional British culinary culture.

We are delighted to work with CitySuper, which has a reputation for quality and innovation. I wish you all a very enjoyable time looking at these products and I hope that you win one of the prizes,Campbell said.

Campbell also acted as a one-day shop supervisor to introduce the products from Britain to customers, while Clare Lear, from the British Assistance and Services Section of BTCO, demonstrated how to use some of the products to make an elegant British afternoon tea and snacks.
Co-organized by the trade office and CitySuper supermarket, the food fair will run through Sept. 4 at three CitySuper branch stores in Taipei.
Products specially sourced from the U.K., include drinks, sauces, tea, biscuits and chocolate.
Visitors to the food fair will have the opportunity to try English afternoon tea with a special 10 percent discount at the Wedgwood Tearoom when they shop at CitySuper supermarket, the BTCO said.
They can also try to win prizes, including a Taipei-U.K. round-trip ticket, Brompton Baby Pink bicycle, Dyson vacuum cleaner and entrance tickets to the Pixar 20th anniversary exhibition, it added.

According to the BTCO, the British food and drink industry is the largest of the countrys manufacturing sector, with one third of a total of 7,000 food and drinks companies exporting their products to the world.

The British food and drink industry has seen year-on-year growth over the past three years. Total export volume is worth 9.23 billion British pounds (US$ 15.2 billion), a record growth of 19.6 percent from the previous year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition DPP weighs no-confidence vote

TEXT.P: Although the popularity of President Ma Ying-jeou and his administration have dipped to their nadir in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is unsure how it can win support from people who are dissatisfied with the performance of Ma while it weights whether to push for a no-confidence vote, according to DPP members.

Cheng Li-chiun, executive-director of the Taiwan Thinktank which is friendly to the DPP, has called on the DPP lawmakers to oust Premier Liu Chao-shiuan by initiating a vote of no-confidence in the Legislative Yuan.

In light of the fact that Liu's approval rating has plunged to 20 percent because of his administration's bungled rescue operation, Cheng claimed there is a good chance that the premier will be forced to step down.
According to the Constitution, a no-confidence vote could be held at the request of one third of the lawmakers and approved by a majority of lawmakers.
However, a premier who is voted out of his post may ask the president to dismantle the legislature and call for a snap election before he leaves his post within ten days after a no-confidence vote.
Although the DPP controls only one third of the legislative seats, Cheng argued that some lawmakers of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), also upset with Ma's administration, may vote across party lines.

However, Cheng's suggestion was greeted with a cold shoulder from the DPP, with Tuan Yi-kang, a member of the party's Central Standing Committee, saying that the DPP would not necessarily win the backing of KMT lawmakers who are displeased with the KMT administration.
"The Democratic Progressive Party's popularity among the people do not rise because of the Kuomintang's losses," he said.
Furthermore, an attempt to drive out the Cabinet as the country was busy with post-disaster reconstruction could be considered a partisan political maneuver and backfire against the DPP, Tuan said.
"We have to do something to convert the Kuomintang's losses into our political gains rather than sit on our hands waiting for the Kuomintang to drive its supporters to us," Tuan said.
Former DPP lawmaker Lin Cho-shui agreed with his views, saying it would be better to initiate a motion for a no-confidence vote against the Cabinet when the reconstruction work was well underway.
"The no-confidence vote should be proposed as an examination of the premier's job performance rather than a political struggle leveled against the Kuomintang." he said.

In addition to being dissatisfied with the central government officials, Taiwan's public is also disappointed with local officials' handling of the typhoon disaster. The worst-hit areas are controlled by officials who are members of the DPP and in many of these areas residents were not evacuated, leading to the high death toll.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 14,000 flood victims join temporary employment program

TEXT.P: More than 14,000 people who became unemployed as a result of flooding caused by Typhoon Morakot have begun working in temporary jobs under an employment program targeting the flood victims, according to statistics released Saturday by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).
According to the program launched on Aug. 17, each worker will be paid an hourly wage of NT$100, or NT$800 a day, to help clean up and restore flooded buildings and communities.
Over the past five days, 11,207 such jobs, which run up to one month, have been provided in 43 townships around the country, CLA officials said.
As a job may be performed by different individuals on different days, the program has so far seen the participation of 14,232 people, the officials said.
They said the CLA will continue to provide more temporary job openings to help resolve the immediate financial needs of the flood victims.

Flood victims with further employment needs may join another program that offer temporary jobs that run for up to three months, the officials said, adding that the CLA will also cooperate with the private sector to create jobs that run up to three years for the flood victims.

DOC.HEADLINE: Control Yuan launching investigation into Typhoon Morakot response

TEXT.P: Two Control Yuan members, Yeh Yao-peng and Huang Huang-hsiung, will visit southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City on Monday to investigate whether there were negligence and mistakes in the administration's handling of the Typhoon Morakot disaster that took several hundred lives, officials said Saturday.

Huang announced the trip Saturday, which marks the first visit by Control Yuan members -- whose job is to supervise government ethics -- to the typhoon- affected areas since Morakot swept through Taiwan from Aug. 7-9, triggering the worst flooding the island has seen in 50 years.

The Control Yuan -- the highest government body with the power of impeachment, censure and audit -- has decided to have all its 25 members -- excluding its president and vice president -- take part in probes into the deadly flooding, which will be launched in several different fields.

The investigations will focus on weather forecasting, disaster control and rescue systems, anti-flooding construction, water and soil treatment, post- disaster personnel settlement and reconstruction, wastes management and disease control, fund-raising, supply of relief supplements, and maintenance of stable consumer prices, according to the Control Yuan.
Huang and Yeh were assigned to conduct their inspection in Kaohsiung City.
Yeh on Saturday invited people to submit petitions to him during his visit to the Kaohsiung City Hall on Monday.
Yeh promised to bring both their wishes and complaints back to the Control Yuan for review.
Huang revealed he and another colleague Chen Yung-hsiang have been assigned to investigate the tragedy of Siaolin Village in the Jiasian township of Kaohsiung County.
The mountain village was buried in mud and debris washed down by a powerful landslide caused by Morakot's heavy rainfall on Aug. 9, with nearly 400 of the residents believed to have perished.
Huang said he will try to determine how badly the aboriginal Pinpu tribal village and its culture was damaged, and whether or not the surviving residents have been properly resettled.
Chen is tasked with finding out what doomed the village, Huang said.

Villagers on Saturday complained to President Ma Ying-jeou, who was visiting the village, that construction of a water irrigation channel weakened the soil in the mountains and contributed to the mudslide. Ma said he will look into this claim.
The village was not evacuated despite its dangerous location in a narrow valley amidst mountains.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's international fund launches fundraiser for disaster relief

TEXT.P: A fundraising bazaar, which is organized by Taiwan International Cooperation and Development Fund (TaiwanICDF), opened Saturday in Taipei to raise money to help families stricken by Typhoon Morakot.
Sponsored by the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, Huashan 1914 Creative Park and diplomatic corps, the two-day bazaar officially opened Saturday afternoon at Huanshan Creative Park.

The bazaar features 20 booths selling hundreds of exotic souvenirs and arts and craft donated by Taiwans diplomatic allies and other countries, as well as clothes, accessories, toys and home supplies.
Chen Lien-gene, secretary-general of the TaiwanICDF, told the Central News Agency that his agency organized the fundraiser to show concern and love for the typhoon victims.
The charity event received great responses from members of the diplomatic corps, who provided a lot of support to the cause, he added.

Participating in the bazaar are people from Taiwan and from aboard, as well as a number of ambassadors from Taiwans diplomatic allies, including El Salvador, Dominican Republic, Gambia, Nauru, Nicaragua, Marshall Islands, Haiti, Belize, Burkina Faso, Honduras, Paraguay, Saint Kitts and Nevis.

Francisco Santana, El Salvadors ambassador to the Republic of China and head of the diplomatic corps, expressed deep sympathies for the typhoon victims and said that the diplomatic community wanted to contribute to the disaster relief efforts.

This is a demonstration of feelings that we are very willing to cooperate. No matter in what amount, we are with Taiwan. We are expressing our solidarity with your country and your people,Santana said.

Noting that the people of Nicaragua have gotten much help from Taiwan during their time of need and Taiwan was often the first country to come to the Central American countrys aid when it needed relief, Nicaragua Ambassador to the ROC William Tapia said now that a disaster has struck Taiwan, Nicaragua is here to help.
Even though our hearts are big, our wallets are small. But we still want to do something to show our solidarity,Tapia said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Grouper fish ponds in southern Taiwan almost wiped out by typhoon

TEXT.P: The fisheries industry in southern Taiwan suffered unprecedented losses in floods triggered by Typhoon Morakot this month and its grouper culture ponds, which turned out nearly 60 percent of the world's production in terms of value, have almost been completely wiped out, an industry source said Saturday.
A post-Morakot investigation conducted by the Council of Agriculture (COA) indicates that of the 1,500 hectares of grouper culture ponds in Taiwan, more than 90 percent have been damaged.

The COA reported that as of 3 p.m. Friday, Morakot's damage to the fishery industry amounted to NT$4.14 billion. In Chiatung and Linbian alone, the losses to the fish culture industry might reach NT$3 billion, according to the county magistrate.
Hsieh Chin-huei, president of the Aquaculture Development Association of the R.O.C., lamented that it might take the grouper culture industry more than a year to recover.

Groupers were among the high value fish products which earned the nation handsome foreign exchange every year. In 2008, the NT$3.88 billion (US$120 million) in Taiwan's grouper production value represented 58 percent of the world's overall production value for the popular fish.

As the coastal townships Chiatung and Linbian in Pingtung County are suffering the heaviest toll in terms of fishery losses, Pingtung County Magistrate Tsao Chi-Hung is looking into ways to help fish farmers there solve their financial difficulties.
"For those people affected by the typhoon who owe bank loans, we can adopt a special measure to cancel their debt," Tsao told reporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Charity groups to build permanent homes for typhoon victims

TEXT.P: Major charity organizations in the country have begun efforts in cooperation with the government to build permanent housing units for more than 6,000 people in southern Taiwan who have been made homeless by Typhoon Morakot.
According to the latest official statistics, there are 6,016 people still living at 51 shelters after their homes were washed away or destroyed by flooding and mudslides from Morakot.
The typhoon was the worst typhoon in Taiwan in 50 years in terms of death toll, which lashed the country with record rainfall from Aug. 7-9.

Almost every leading charity group on the island have launched aid and rescue efforts in the affected areas, including the Dharma Drum Mountain (DDM) Social Welfare and Charity Foundation, the Red Cross Society, the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, the Fo Guang Shan Monastery, and World Vision.

On Saturday -- two weeks after severe flooding began on Aug. 8 -- the Dharma Drum Mountain Foundation said that it has begun working with the Red Cross Society to build permanent housing units in Wulipu area, of Jiasian Township, Kaohsiung County, for 200 homeless households from nearby Siaolin Village.
The village, which is also located in the township, was entirely leveled by landslides during the typhoon on Aug. 9. Around 400 villagers are believed to have been buried in the mudslides.

Wulipu, located only 2 km away from Siaolin, is a good spot for the disaster survivors to rebuild their lives because they could still return to their old fruit gardens or farmland to make a living, the foundation said.

President Ma Ying-jeou promised Saturday during a religious mourning ceremony for Siaolin's deceased that he will complete post-typhoon reconstruction work at the village during his term in office, but he also said if the land in the village is found not fit for human habitation, the government will suggest relocation of the village.

The president said this week his administration was conducting an assessment of land in Taiwan to see which areas are too dangerous to live in, so as to prevent deaths in future typhoons and other natural disasters.
The Executive Yuan meanwhile announced a few days ago that it will provide state-owned land for the charity organizations to construct permanent houses for typhoon victims.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government closely monitoring two dams for landslide risks

TEXT.P: Two dams in southern Taiwan were being closely monitored after the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) released on Saturday a special report forecasting mountainous areas on the island may expect heavy rain during the day due to the influence of active cloud systems.

The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said it will warn local governments to evacuate residents living downstream from the dams once it detects that downpour in the area has reached 40 mm in an hour.
The dams are landslide dams, which were created by past landslides. The earth in the dams are not firm and heavy rainfall could caused the dams to collapse and cause severe flooding.

The barrier lakes are located in Baoshengshe of Jingfong Township, Taitung County and Majia Township in Kaohsiung County. The two counties were among the areas worst affected by the Aug. 8 flooding triggered by Typhoon Morakot.

As of 3 p.m. Saturday, a total of 18 landslide dams were recorded on the island. They are scattered in the central and southern counties of Nantou, Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung, Pingtung and Taitung, according to the COA.
Nine of the dammed lakes have collapsed while the other nine have been assessed to pose no immediate threat to the safety of people living in the lower reaches, the COA said.
But it noted that it was closely watching the Baoshengshe and Majia landslide dams even though there was no immediate risk of the dams collapsing.

The CWB's weather report said the mountain areas in Pingtung were observed to have had substantial rainfall Saturday afternoon. As of 5 p.m., the volume of downpour in Laiyi of the county's Wanluan Township has accumulated to 50 mm, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 23, or the fourth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1305: Sir William Wallace, Scottish patriot who demanded independence for his country, is hung, drawn and quartered in London.
1754: Louis XVI, king of France at the time of the outbreak of the French Revolution, is born.
1818: The first steamship service opens on the Great Lakes in North America.
1821: Mexico gains its independence.
1912: Gene Kelly, American dancer, choreographer, singer, actor and director, is born. He starred in Hollywood musicals, including "Anchors Aweigh," "Singin' in the Rain" and his "Invitation to Dance."
1914: Japan declares war on Germany.
1926: Screen actor Rudoph Valentino, the idol of millions, dies of peritonitis in New York's Polyclinic Hospital. He was 31. The Italian-born American actor was known for his romantic leading roles in silent films such as "The Sheik" and "Blood and Sand."
1927: In one of the most controversial cases in American legal history, Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti are sent to the electric chair. In July 1921, a jury found the two Italian political anarchists and immigrants guilty of the murder of a factory paymaster and a guard during a robbery in South Braintree, Massachusetts.

1940: German bombers begin night raids on London.

1945: Chiang Kai-shek sends a third invitation to Mao Tse-tung after inviting him Aug. 14 to come to Chungking for a conference and the again Aug. 20.
1958: The Battle of the Taiwan Strait begins with Communist China firing 57,000 rounds in 2 hours at the islands of Kinmen. Many defenders are killed, including Gen. Chi Sing-wen, deputy commander of the Kinmen Garrison Command.
1963: Ambassador to the United States Tsiang Ting-fu signs the nuclear test ban treaty on behalf of the Republic of China.
1981: One hundred and ten people die in the crash of a Far Eastern Air Transport plane. The incident represents Taiwan's worst air disaster.
1990: East and West Germany choose October 3 as the date for reunification.

Confucius' lesson of the day: "The Emperor Shun might perhaps be considered in the highest sense of the word a pious man. In moral qualities, he was a saint. In dignity of office, he was the ruler of the empire. In wealth, all that the wide world contained belonged to him."

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't urged to look for foreigners missing in disaster

TEXT.P: The Taiwan International Family Association (TIFA) and the Taiwan International Workers' Association (TIWA) on Sunday called on the government to set up an office in charge of finding foreign residents missing in the disaster triggered by Typhoon Morakot.

The two civic groups gave a press conference in Taipei to urge the authorities concerned to provide information about foreigners in the list of people who have died, are missing or are being provided with accommodations in temporary shelters.
Speaking at the press conference, Yuan Chin-feng, a Vietnamese woman married to a Taiwanese man, expressed worries about her compatriots living in the devastated regions.

Yuan told reporters that her friend Ah Hung, who was evacuated to a resettlement center in Kaohsiung with the family hiring her, told her that she had lost contact with a compatriot Ah Sheng, who married a native of Siaolin Village seven years ago.

Yuan said, with TIFA's assistance, they were able to speak with Ah Sheng's family in Vietnam and learned that Ah Sheng's last call on Aug. 8 was disrupted and there had been no information about her since.
TIFA executive officer Chang Yu-hua called on the government to help.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
'Underground ninja turtle' keeps Taiwan's effluence flowing

TEXT.P: CNA staff writer

For 32 years, Shen An-pao has been creeping through the stinking underworld of Taiwan's sewers, taking care of the island's underground "sweat glands" for over three decades, a job he has carried out with glamorous dignity and dogged perseverance.

Despite his advancing years -- Shen is nearly 70 -- he still spends a great deal of his time crawling through fetid, dark sewers with his company to open up, repair and maintain underground sewerage systems wherever his services are needed.

While city dwellers enjoy their cozy indoor life -- flushing their toilets, taking showers and washing their dishes in comfort -- most of them probably never give a thought that possibly under their very building, Shen and his crew could be sweating underground fixing their sewer system under high temperatures in darkness and stinking air.
Shen has been living his "ninja turtle" life from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. daily for the past 32 years without complaint, despite the fear and fatigue that his job entails.

Shen came to Taipei City from southern Taiwan with his wife at the age of 26 with a mere NT$800 in his pocket. After trying a variety of trades, including driving a taxi, a tour bus and working on construction sites, he became a sewer worker -- a trade he worked in as an employee for around a decade before deciding to open his own company.

Despite the physical demands and the potential dangers inherent in the job, Shen still takes great pride in his career, saying that the underground piping systems he has been taking care of transport domestic and industrial waste water for treatment before being flushed into the sea.

"We underground workers not only provide residents with a clean, sanitary environment, but also contribute to the country's environmental protection efforts, " Shen said proudly in an interview with CNA soon after emerging from a manhole wearing a safety helmet and with sweat covering his brow.

One of the major challenges of his work is to build new underground pipelines connected to sewer pipes from buildings and larger underground trunk mains that transport the sewage to treatment facilities.
In the past, he said, he and his co-workers built the sewers manually, without the assistance of machinery.
"The gravity and high pressure underground made us breathless and caused tinnitus. Some of us even suffered from the bends or caisson disease eventually," he recalled.

Geological variables also affect the speed of building new connecting pipes, he went on. In ground made up of ordinary gravel, he and his company can drill and lay down new connecting pipes at a rate of 20-25 meters a day. However, upon encountering bedrock, like that found in Xindian and other southern suburbs of Taipei, that rate can fall to just 5 meters per day.

Noting that the penetration rate of modern sewerage systems is one of the indices of whether a country is advanced or not, Shen said that most industrially advanced nations in the world have a penetration rate over 80 percent.

In Taiwan, however, only the capital city of Taipei has a penetration rate of over 80 percent, while many cities and counties in the rest of the country have a penetration rate of less than 30 percent, he lamented.
"Taiwan still has a long way to go," he pointed out.

Shen, who only has an elementary school education, said he has been running a business that provides jobs for members of his extended family, including younger brothers-in-law and his own children, as well as a number of unrelated workers who have stuck by him for years.
"Beating the global economic crunch, employees in my company have never been put on unpaid leave," Shen added proudly.

DOC.HEADLINE: President visits injured soldiers

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou traveled to the southern county of Kaohsiung Sunday to visit six soldiers hospitalized for injuries during rescue and relief work in the wake of the devastation wrought by Typhoon Morakot.

Ma, accompanied by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan and Defense Minister Chen Chao-min, visited the six soldiers at the Kaohsiung Armed Forces General Hospital to cheer the servicemen up and wish them a speedy recovery.
Two of the six -- an artilleryman and a marine, have been receiving treatment for cellulitis in wounds they incurred during the post-typhoon relief actions.
Another marine has a spinal fracture, while a private has bronchitis and two others are suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder, according to hospital authorities.

In related news, Ma visited the eastern county of Taitung later that day to visit once again the family of policeman Chiang Wen-hsiang, who remains unaccounted for since Aug. 8, when he went missing while guiding villagers near the Taimali river to evacuation points amid stormy weather and rising floodwater.
Chiang slipped and was washed away by turbulent floodwaters that inundated the entire area in the country's worst flooding in half a century.
Ma met with Chiang's mother, who has since been searching for her son every day at the mouth of the Taimali river, and offered her his deepest sympathies and condolences.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military barracks to be opened for typhoon victim resettlement

TEXT.P: The government will open disused military barracks that remain in a relatively good state of repair and are equipped with cooking facilities for the resettlement of displaced survivors in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Sunday.

Liu made the remarks while accompanying President Ma Ying-jeou on a visit to six soldiers injured during post-disaster rescue and relief operations who were receiving treatment at the Kaohsiung Military General Hospital in southern Taiwan.

Responding to media inquiries about the progress of post-typhoon rehabilitation, Liu said the government is stepping up its efforts to resettle thousands of displaced survivors who are still being accommodated at various emergency placement centers.
In addition to offering them condolence money and subsidies for day-to-day living, Liu said the government has accelerated its efforts to help them find new homes.

As part of the drive, Liu went on, the Executive Yuan will ask the military to open suitable disused army barracks for resettlement of those who have been displaced by Morakot-triggered flooding and landslides.

Several villages and townships in remote mountain areas of southern Kaohsiung, Pingtung and Chiayi counties, as well as in central Taiwan's Nantou County and the eastern county of Taitung, have borne the brunt of the devastation.
Hundreds of residents in villages in those areas are believed to have been buried alive when mudslides came crashing down on their homes after heavy rain loosened the soil.

The previous evening, Liu said he met with local government heads, including the chiefs of the hardest-hit villages and townships, to discuss measures for breaking bottlenecks in the rehabilitation work.

"We all agreed that survivor resettlement should get underway at full speed and that multiple measures should be employed simultaneously to meet the diverse demands of the different victims," Liu said.

Those whose homes were damaged can apply for housing subsidies from the government after their homes have been examined, Liu said, adding that each household will be entitled to an initial subsidy of NT$30,000.
He also promised that examination of houses located in places accesible by vehicle will be completed within three days.

For survivors from villages that were obliterated entirely by landslides and mudslides, such as Siaolin, located in the foothills of Alishan in a narrow valley in Kaohsiung County, they can apply for compensation directly without the need for prior examination, Liu said.

Moreover, Liu continued, local governments in disaster zones will set up joint service stations in cooperation with private real estate or property brokerages to provide displaced victims with updated information about resettlement and counseling on leasing or purchasing houses.

Typhoon Morakot, one of the worst natural disasters to batter Taiwan in half a century, had left more than 600 people dead or missing as of Friday, as the military continued to dig up bodies buried deep under rocks and mud.
As of 1 p.m. that day, the Central Emergency Operation Center had confirmed 153 deaths since the typhoon hit, as well as listing 464 people missing and feared buried under landslides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei hosts cultural festival to honor Vietnamese workers

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government sponsored a Vietnamese cultural festival Sunday to honor the thousands of migrant workers and new immigrants from the Southeast Asian country.
The festival, offering a variety of entertainment, attracted more than 1,000 migrant workers to the Daan Forest Park in downtown Taipei.
Addressing the opening ceremony, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin greeted the participants with a "How are you" in Vietnamese, winning thunderous applause.
He then expressed his condolences and sympathies for the victims of recent typhoons in southern Taiwan and in northern Vietnam.

Typhoon Morakot dumped heavy rainfall in southern Taiwan Aug. 7-9 that triggered serious flooding and landslides in remote mountain regions, leaving more than 600 people dead or missing and rendering thousands of others homeless.
At almost the same period, northern Vietnam was also battered by a typhoon that led to heavy human casualties and property losses.
"Let's come together on this occasion to express our condolences and concern for all the surviving victims and pray for their well-being," Hau said.

The festival was part of a series of cultural activities being held by the Taipei city government this year to promote cultural exchanges with Southeast Asian countries, many of which are major sources of Taiwan's migrant workers and new immigrants.
"The festival is also designed to celebrate Vietnam's Sept. 2 National Day," Hua said.
According to Hau, Taiwan's capital city now has more than 1,300 Vietnamese spouses of local citizens, as well as more than 5,000 workers and caregivers from the Southeast Asian country.

"We appreciate the contributions and dedication the Vietnamese workers and new immigrants have made to our city and country, " Hau said, adding that all those who have encountered problems in work and daily life are welcome to contact the city's Bureau of Labor Affairs, where city officials will offer them counseling services or other forms of assistance in resolving their issues.
Nguyen Ba Cu, director of the Vietnamese Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei, and many Taipei city officials attended the festival and offered their best wishes for the migrant workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health agency plans expanded use of Tamiflu

TEXT.P: As nearly 10,000 new cases of influenza A(H1N1) have been reported per week in Taiwan over the past few weeks, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) is planning to allow for the expanded use of the antiviral drug Tamiflu, a DOH official said Sunday.

From Aug. 15, anyone testing positive for the virus using a preliminary testing kit has been able to receive a course of Tamiflu treatment covered by National Health Insurance, according to Kuo Hsu-sung, director-general of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the DOH.
The testing kits are being paid for by the CDC, but there is a shortage of the kits, Kuo said.

Those who test negative for A(H1N1) virus but who have been diagnosed with flu and have experienced exacerbations or pneumonia can obtain a prescription for Tamiflu but have to pay for the drug themselves, Kuo said, adding that these cases will also soon be covered by insurance in the near future.

Tamiflu should not be given to all patients with flu-like symptoms without the initial screening test because that could cause drug misuse and abuse, while about 30 percent of Tamiflu users experience harmful side effects that are worse than the symptoms caused by the virus, Kuo noted.

At present, hospitals and medical centers equipped with both Tamiflu and quick- test kits are mostly larger facilities, requiring patients with flu-like symptoms attending smaller hospitals or clinics to be referred to bigger institutions to receive testing and treatment.

The preliminary test kits, which cost NT$250-NT$300 (US$7.6-US$9.1) each, are in short supply due to insufficient production and high production costs, Kuo noted, adding that the DOH will coordinate biomedical companies to speed up production of the test kits to meet an anticipated increase in demand during the peak of the seasonal flu period in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ceremony marking 51st anniversary of `823 Battle' held on Kinmen

TEXT.P: Some 800 participants, including veterans, local officials and military servicemen, took part in a public memorial ceremony Sunday at the Martyr's Shrine in Taiwushan on the outlying island of Kinmen to pay tribute to those who died in the "823 Battle" of Kinmen.

The ceremony, part of a series of activities marking the 51st anniversary of the battle that involved mainly artillery shelling of the island group by China, was presided over by Maj. Gen. Lu Hsiao-jung, commander of the Kinmen Defense Command, and Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng.
The dead were paid tribute with three ceremonial bows followed by the placing of a wreath at the foot of a memorial dedicated to those who fell in the battle.
A group of approximately 100 veterans of the battle headed by Lu Fang-yen, leader of an association of battle veterans, also attended the ceremony.
Lu Hsiao-jung said the fruits of democracy, freedom and prosperity that Taiwan people enjoy should be attributed to those who gave their lives in defense of the country.

He added that despite improved relations between Taiwan and China, the people should still uphold the spirit of adventure and sacrifice possessed by the veterans, enhance their combat preparedness and ensure national security.

Lu Fang-yen for his part said Taiwan's victory in the battle laid a solid foundation for accelerating the country's democratic and economic development and that the veterans should be given credit for their contributions.
He further said the government should attach more importance to the rights and interests of the aging veterans and should provide them with proper benefits.
The conflict began Aug. 23, 1958 when China launched a heavy bombardment on the Kinmen archipelago, which has a total surface area of just 150 square kilometers.
Over the course of the next 44 days of non-stop barrages, Chinese troops fired approximately 470,000 shells, but failed to pound Kinmen into submission.

DOC.HEADLINE: No formaldehyde problems with prefab houses donated by China

TEXT.P: There have been no excess levels of the carcinogenic formaldehyde recorded in prefabricated houses donated by China to house victims of Typhoon Morakot who have been evacuated or who have lost their homes, the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Sunday.

Wang Pi, director-general of the National Institute of Environmental Analysis under the EPA, said that indoor air samples collected from two Chinese prefab houses that were erected in Pingtung County's Jiadong township Aug. 20 were tested and were found to contain no formaldehyde, dashing rumors that the materials used to construct the dwellings contained high levels of the toxic substance.
Wang also confirmed that total volatile organic compounds (TVOC) concentrations in indoor air samples collected from the two Chinese prefabs were under allowable levels of less than 3ppm.

Wang said the TVOC concentrations averaged 11.3 ppm in the air collected from the two prefabs within the first hour of erection, although the concentrations dropped to below 3 ppm in one day. "The TVOCs we found in our tests actually pose no harm to humans," he added.

Hsieh Yen-ju, director-general of the EPA Bureau of Air Quality Protection and Noise Control, suggested nevertheless that anyone moving into the units should keep doors and windows open for one day before moving in.
Wang, Hsieh and other EPA specialists were called in by the Consumers Foundation Aug. 20 to check the safety of the first batch of 100 prefabs that arrived in Taiwan in the wake of Typhoon Morakot.
The units arrived Aug. 18 and were transported directly to Jiadong township to house people there affected by Typhoon Morakot, which triggered the worst flooding in Taiwan in half a century.
The death toll from the storm had risen to 160 as of Saturday, with another 490 remaining unaccounted for and 45 people reported injured.
Jiadong was one of the areas in southern Taiwan hardest hit by the storm that lashed Taiwan Aug. 7-9.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1st 100 prefab houses in Kaohsiung to be completed in 2 weeks

TEXT.P: Assembly of 100 units of a second batch of prefabricated houses for temporary resettlement of survivors of Typhoon Morakot got underway Sunday in Shanlin township in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County.
The prefab houses were donated by China's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) and were delivered to Kaohsiung Harbor the previous day.

Three Chinese technicians, who also arrived in Kaohsiung the previous day to offer technical counseling and manpower training, visited the construction site near Shanlin Junior High School to oversee the assembly of the units.
They said their company has exported prefab houses to the Middle East and Africa, all of which have been of satisfactory quality.

The Chinese technicians were accompanied by executives of Taiwan's Red Cross Society, which is joining with several other charities, including World Vision Taiwan, Dharma Drum Mountain and the Fo Guang Shan Monastery, to provide the prefabs for displaced typhoon victims.
Seven other Chinese technicians were also scheduled to arrive in Kaohsiung the following day to assist in assembly of the houses.

China has donated 1,000 prefab houses to help with Taiwan's post-disaster resettlement drive. A total of 300 had arrived in Taiwan in two shipments as of Saturday, with a third batch of 300 due to be delivered Monday.

Yeh Shih-wen, director of the Construction and Planning Agency under the Ministry of the Interior, said at a ceremony marking the start of assembly that the project is part of efforts to deliver on President Ma Ying-jeou's promise to build prefab houses within one month for displaced victims in several of the hardest-hit disaster zones.

During an inspection tour of the three hardest-hit villages and townships in Kaohsiung County -- Siaolin, Liouguei and Taoyuan -- Aug. 19, Ma promised to complete within a month temporary resettlement of residents who were still being accommodated in emergency placement centers.
Yeh said the current site, which is owned by the state-run Taiwan Sugar Co., will be able to accommodate 200 to 400 of the prefabs. "The first 100 will be ready in two weeks," he added.
Each 15-ping prefab house has two bed rooms, one living area and a bathroom.

"The houses can be used for more than 10 years," Yeh said, adding that the new 100-house community will have an activity center, a parking lot and other public facilities, with major roads 8 meters wide.
According to Yeh, the plot can also be used to accommodate permanent houses for the survivors.

Hsu Pao-yen, an executive of the Siaolin Village Self-Help Association, said 247 houses in the remote mountain village were buried when mudslides came crashing down after torrential rain spawned by Morakot loosened the topsoil in the hills above the village.

Hundreds of Siaolin villagers are believed to have been buried alive in the tragic landslides, and Hsu said the survivors have expressed preference to have their new permanent houses built at the nearby village of Wulipu.

DOC.HEADLINE: HTC Corp. to develop new phones with China Mobile

TEXT.P: Taiwan's HTC Corp. will sign an agreement Monday with China Mobile, the world's largest mobile carrier, for joint development of 3G phones in China, an HTC executive said Sunday.

China Mobile Chairman Wang Jianzhou arrived in Taiwan Aug. 21 for a nine-day visit during which he will meet with HTC Chairwoman Cher Wang to discuss mobile phone procurement and cooperation in development and research of China's TD- SCDMA standards, according to the executive.

The planned strategic alliance between the two companies is expected to help HTC Corp.'s Ophone to compete with Apple's iPhone in China's vast market, despite a lackluster performance by the company in China this year, the HTC executive said.

To attain its goal of gaining 85 million households using 3G services in three years, China Mobile has been investing heavily in TD-SCDMA network expansion, according to the executive, who said that during Wang's stay, he will also visit a number of local companies, including Mediatek and Chunghwa Telecom, to seek cooperation with them.

China Mobile and HTC will develop at least one new type of mobile phone this year and at least five types next year. The two companies will develop new smartphones based on China Mobile's Open Mobile System (OMS), the executive added.
The day before his arrival, Wang Jianzhou said in Hong Kong that China Mobile will launch its Ophone running on the OMS platform in collaboration with HTC, Lenovo and Dell.

DOC.HEADLINE: No remains of typhoon victims recovered Sunday

TEXT.P: Operations to retrieve the bodies of residents who perished in landslides caused by Typhoon Morakot in Liouguei township's Xinkao tribal settlement in Kaohsiung County did not yield any results Sunday.
A total of 24 diggers and bulldozers were employed to help military personnel locate and excavate the bodies of the victims, but the efforts were in vain.
As of Sunday, the corpses of just four of the 28 people believed to be buried alive in the settlement had been retrieved.
President Ma Ying-jeou has promised that all search work will be completed by Aug. 27 and military servicemen have been working hard to carry out the excavation work according to Ma's deadline.
"We will do our utmost to complete the task and are not worried that we will fall behind schedule, " said Chou Li-shuan, head of the military excavation operations.

Pan Hin-pei, a representative of the township, said local residents will not demand to much of the military as long as it is seen to have done its best, because the area requiring excavation is so large.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier vows to improve disaster prevention, relief mechanism

TEXT.P: The government will overview the existing public infrastructure specifications with regard to natural disaster prevention out of safety concerns in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Sunday.
Liu made the statement after presiding over a meeting of an ad hoc post-typhoon reconstruction committee held at an army base in Cishan township in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County.

Liu said the country's natural disaster prevention and response mechanism, as well as the present standard operating procedure (SOP) for evacuating people from potentially dangerous areas in the event of an imminent natural disaster, should also be overhauled and reinforced.

Liu's pledge came after scathing criticism over the government's flawed post- disaster rescue and relief operation after Morakot wreaked havoc in southern Taiwan, particularly in several remote mountainous regions.

Liu said he has directed the Construction and Planning Agency under the Ministry of the Interior and the National Science and Technology Center for Disaster Reduction to come up with improvement and reinforcement measures.
"The central government will also discuss relevant reform measures with local governments before putting them into force, " Liu said.

President Ma Ying-jeou also said last week that the existing Disaster Prevention and Response Act should be updated to establish criteria that would allow or a compulsory evacuation to prevent a repeat of the loss of human life and suffering caused by Typhoon Morakot that pummeled Taiwan Aug.7-9.

Morakot, which dumped a staggering amount of rainfall in some parts of Taiwan, had its deadliest impact on some remote villages that nestle mountains in Pingtung and Kaohsiung counties. One such village, Siaolin, was obliterated when Morakot-triggered torrential rains sent the faces of the nearby mountains tumbling down on the village's 240 or so houses. Hundreds of Siaolin residents are believed to have been buried alive in the killer landslides.
On post-disaster rehabilitation, Liu said the government will enlist local enterprises that have promised to donate funds to take part in various reconstruction projects.

Noting that reconstruction involves not only building prefab houses or permanent houses but also employment, schooling, cultural preservation and other issues, Liu said the government plans to mobilize local enterprises to sponsor various hardest-hit villages.

"The funds donated by business groups should be better used by mobilizing donor companies to sponsor various hardest-hit villages or townships, " Liu said, adding that the proposal has received warmer-than-expected response from the business community.
A large number of local enterprises have chipped in to help finance post- disaster relief and rehabilitation projects.

"We should not waste even a penny of those funds and the central and local governments as well as public-interest groups and private corporations should work hand-in-hand to accelerate rehabilitation on various fronts," Liu said.
In the process, Liu went on, surviving victims certainly will have a say so that all reconstruction projects will better meet their future demand.
Meanwhile, the Interior Ministry had interviewed 3,927 survivors from 1,388 households as of Aug.18 to explore their opinions about resettlement.
Among them, 553 households want government-arranged resettlements; 264 want to rent houses on their own; 74 want to buy new houses; and 497 remain undecided.
