DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't urged to look for foreigners missing in disaster

TEXT.P: The Taiwan International Family Association (TIFA) and the Taiwan International Workers' Association (TIWA) on Sunday called on the government to set up an office in charge of finding foreign residents missing in the disaster triggered by Typhoon Morakot.

The two civic groups gave a press conference in Taipei to urge the authorities concerned to provide information about foreigners in the list of people who have died, are missing or are being provided with accommodations in temporary shelters.
Speaking at the press conference, Yuan Chin-feng, a Vietnamese woman married to a Taiwanese man, expressed worries about her compatriots living in the devastated regions.

Yuan told reporters that her friend Ah Hung, who was evacuated to a resettlement center in Kaohsiung with the family hiring her, told her that she had lost contact with a compatriot Ah Sheng, who married a native of Siaolin Village seven years ago.

Yuan said, with TIFA's assistance, they were able to speak with Ah Sheng's family in Vietnam and learned that Ah Sheng's last call on Aug. 8 was disrupted and there had been no information about her since.
TIFA executive officer Chang Yu-hua called on the government to help.

TEXT.P: CNA staff writer

For 32 years, Shen An-pao has been creeping through the stinking underworld of Taiwan's sewers, taking care of the island's underground "sweat glands" for over three decades, a job he has carried out with glamorous dignity and dogged perseverance.

Despite his advancing years -- Shen is nearly 70 -- he still spends a great deal of his time crawling through fetid, dark sewers with his company to open up, repair and maintain underground sewerage systems wherever his services are needed.

While city dwellers enjoy their cozy indoor life -- flushing their toilets, taking showers and washing their dishes in comfort -- most of them probably never give a thought that possibly under their very building, Shen and his crew could be sweating underground fixing their sewer system under high temperatures in darkness and stinking air.
Shen has been living his "ninja turtle" life from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. daily for the past 32 years without complaint, despite the fear and fatigue that his job entails.

Shen came to Taipei City from southern Taiwan with his wife at the age of 26 with a mere NT$800 in his pocket. After trying a variety of trades, including driving a taxi, a tour bus and working on construction sites, he became a sewer worker -- a trade he worked in as an employee for around a decade before deciding to open his own company.

Despite the physical demands and the potential dangers inherent in the job, Shen still takes great pride in his career, saying that the underground piping systems he has been taking care of transport domestic and industrial waste water for treatment before being flushed into the sea.

"We underground workers not only provide residents with a clean, sanitary environment, but also contribute to the country's environmental protection efforts, " Shen said proudly in an interview with CNA soon after emerging from a manhole wearing a safety helmet and with sweat covering his brow.

One of the major challenges of his work is to build new underground pipelines connected to sewer pipes from buildings and larger underground trunk mains that transport the sewage to treatment facilities.
In the past, he said, he and his co-workers built the sewers manually, without the assistance of machinery.
"The gravity and high pressure underground made us breathless and caused tinnitus. Some of us even suffered from the bends or caisson disease eventually," he recalled.

Geological variables also affect the speed of building new connecting pipes, he went on. In ground made up of ordinary gravel, he and his company can drill and lay down new connecting pipes at a rate of 20-25 meters a day. However, upon encountering bedrock, like that found in Xindian and other southern suburbs of Taipei, that rate can fall to just 5 meters per day.

Noting that the penetration rate of modern sewerage systems is one of the indices of whether a country is advanced or not, Shen said that most industrially advanced nations in the world have a penetration rate over 80 percent.

In Taiwan, however, only the capital city of Taipei has a penetration rate of over 80 percent, while many cities and counties in the rest of the country have a penetration rate of less than 30 percent, he lamented.
"Taiwan still has a long way to go," he pointed out.

Shen, who only has an elementary school education, said he has been running a business that provides jobs for members of his extended family, including younger brothers-in-law and his own children, as well as a number of unrelated workers who have stuck by him for years.
"Beating the global economic crunch, employees in my company have never been put on unpaid leave," Shen added proudly.

DOC.HEADLINE: President visits injured soldiers

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou traveled to the southern county of Kaohsiung Sunday to visit six soldiers hospitalized for injuries during rescue and relief work in the wake of the devastation wrought by Typhoon Morakot.

Ma, accompanied by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan and Defense Minister Chen Chao-min, visited the six soldiers at the Kaohsiung Armed Forces General Hospital to cheer the servicemen up and wish them a speedy recovery.
Two of the six -- an artilleryman and a marine, have been receiving treatment for cellulitis in wounds they incurred during the post-typhoon relief actions.
Another marine has a spinal fracture, while a private has bronchitis and two others are suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder, according to hospital authorities.

In related news, Ma visited the eastern county of Taitung later that day to visit once again the family of policeman Chiang Wen-hsiang, who remains unaccounted for since Aug. 8, when he went missing while guiding villagers near the Taimali river to evacuation points amid stormy weather and rising floodwater.
Chiang slipped and was washed away by turbulent floodwaters that inundated the entire area in the country's worst flooding in half a century.
Ma met with Chiang's mother, who has since been searching for her son every day at the mouth of the Taimali river, and offered her his deepest sympathies and condolences.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military barracks to be opened for typhoon victim resettlement

TEXT.P: The government will open disused military barracks that remain in a relatively good state of repair and are equipped with cooking facilities for the resettlement of displaced survivors in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Sunday.

Liu made the remarks while accompanying President Ma Ying-jeou on a visit to six soldiers injured during post-disaster rescue and relief operations who were receiving treatment at the Kaohsiung Military General Hospital in southern Taiwan.

Responding to media inquiries about the progress of post-typhoon rehabilitation, Liu said the government is stepping up its efforts to resettle thousands of displaced survivors who are still being accommodated at various emergency placement centers.
In addition to offering them condolence money and subsidies for day-to-day living, Liu said the government has accelerated its efforts to help them find new homes.

As part of the drive, Liu went on, the Executive Yuan will ask the military to open suitable disused army barracks for resettlement of those who have been displaced by Morakot-triggered flooding and landslides.

Several villages and townships in remote mountain areas of southern Kaohsiung, Pingtung and Chiayi counties, as well as in central Taiwan's Nantou County and the eastern county of Taitung, have borne the brunt of the devastation.
Hundreds of residents in villages in those areas are believed to have been buried alive when mudslides came crashing down on their homes after heavy rain loosened the soil.

The previous evening, Liu said he met with local government heads, including the chiefs of the hardest-hit villages and townships, to discuss measures for breaking bottlenecks in the rehabilitation work.

"We all agreed that survivor resettlement should get underway at full speed and that multiple measures should be employed simultaneously to meet the diverse demands of the different victims," Liu said.

Those whose homes were damaged can apply for housing subsidies from the government after their homes have been examined, Liu said, adding that each household will be entitled to an initial subsidy of NT$30,000.
He also promised that examination of houses located in places accesible by vehicle will be completed within three days.

For survivors from villages that were obliterated entirely by landslides and mudslides, such as Siaolin, located in the foothills of Alishan in a narrow valley in Kaohsiung County, they can apply for compensation directly without the need for prior examination, Liu said.

Moreover, Liu continued, local governments in disaster zones will set up joint service stations in cooperation with private real estate or property brokerages to provide displaced victims with updated information about resettlement and counseling on leasing or purchasing houses.

Typhoon Morakot, one of the worst natural disasters to batter Taiwan in half a century, had left more than 600 people dead or missing as of Friday, as the military continued to dig up bodies buried deep under rocks and mud.
As of 1 p.m. that day, the Central Emergency Operation Center had confirmed 153 deaths since the typhoon hit, as well as listing 464 people missing and feared buried under landslides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei hosts cultural festival to honor Vietnamese workers

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government sponsored a Vietnamese cultural festival Sunday to honor the thousands of migrant workers and new immigrants from the Southeast Asian country.
The festival, offering a variety of entertainment, attracted more than 1,000 migrant workers to the Daan Forest Park in downtown Taipei.
Addressing the opening ceremony, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin greeted the participants with a "How are you" in Vietnamese, winning thunderous applause.
He then expressed his condolences and sympathies for the victims of recent typhoons in southern Taiwan and in northern Vietnam.

Typhoon Morakot dumped heavy rainfall in southern Taiwan Aug. 7-9 that triggered serious flooding and landslides in remote mountain regions, leaving more than 600 people dead or missing and rendering thousands of others homeless.
At almost the same period, northern Vietnam was also battered by a typhoon that led to heavy human casualties and property losses.
"Let's come together on this occasion to express our condolences and concern for all the surviving victims and pray for their well-being," Hau said.

The festival was part of a series of cultural activities being held by the Taipei city government this year to promote cultural exchanges with Southeast Asian countries, many of which are major sources of Taiwan's migrant workers and new immigrants.
"The festival is also designed to celebrate Vietnam's Sept. 2 National Day," Hua said.
According to Hau, Taiwan's capital city now has more than 1,300 Vietnamese spouses of local citizens, as well as more than 5,000 workers and caregivers from the Southeast Asian country.

"We appreciate the contributions and dedication the Vietnamese workers and new immigrants have made to our city and country, " Hau said, adding that all those who have encountered problems in work and daily life are welcome to contact the city's Bureau of Labor Affairs, where city officials will offer them counseling services or other forms of assistance in resolving their issues.
Nguyen Ba Cu, director of the Vietnamese Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei, and many Taipei city officials attended the festival and offered their best wishes for the migrant workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health agency plans expanded use of Tamiflu

TEXT.P: As nearly 10,000 new cases of influenza A(H1N1) have been reported per week in Taiwan over the past few weeks, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) is planning to allow for the expanded use of the antiviral drug Tamiflu, a DOH official said Sunday.

From Aug. 15, anyone testing positive for the virus using a preliminary testing kit has been able to receive a course of Tamiflu treatment covered by National Health Insurance, according to Kuo Hsu-sung, director-general of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the DOH.
The testing kits are being paid for by the CDC, but there is a shortage of the kits, Kuo said.

Those who test negative for A(H1N1) virus but who have been diagnosed with flu and have experienced exacerbations or pneumonia can obtain a prescription for Tamiflu but have to pay for the drug themselves, Kuo said, adding that these cases will also soon be covered by insurance in the near future.

Tamiflu should not be given to all patients with flu-like symptoms without the initial screening test because that could cause drug misuse and abuse, while about 30 percent of Tamiflu users experience harmful side effects that are worse than the symptoms caused by the virus, Kuo noted.

At present, hospitals and medical centers equipped with both Tamiflu and quick- test kits are mostly larger facilities, requiring patients with flu-like symptoms attending smaller hospitals or clinics to be referred to bigger institutions to receive testing and treatment.

The preliminary test kits, which cost NT$250-NT$300 (US$7.6-US$9.1) each, are in short supply due to insufficient production and high production costs, Kuo noted, adding that the DOH will coordinate biomedical companies to speed up production of the test kits to meet an anticipated increase in demand during the peak of the seasonal flu period in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ceremony marking 51st anniversary of `823 Battle' held on Kinmen

TEXT.P: Some 800 participants, including veterans, local officials and military servicemen, took part in a public memorial ceremony Sunday at the Martyr's Shrine in Taiwushan on the outlying island of Kinmen to pay tribute to those who died in the "823 Battle" of Kinmen.

The ceremony, part of a series of activities marking the 51st anniversary of the battle that involved mainly artillery shelling of the island group by China, was presided over by Maj. Gen. Lu Hsiao-jung, commander of the Kinmen Defense Command, and Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng.
The dead were paid tribute with three ceremonial bows followed by the placing of a wreath at the foot of a memorial dedicated to those who fell in the battle.
A group of approximately 100 veterans of the battle headed by Lu Fang-yen, leader of an association of battle veterans, also attended the ceremony.
Lu Hsiao-jung said the fruits of democracy, freedom and prosperity that Taiwan people enjoy should be attributed to those who gave their lives in defense of the country.

He added that despite improved relations between Taiwan and China, the people should still uphold the spirit of adventure and sacrifice possessed by the veterans, enhance their combat preparedness and ensure national security.

Lu Fang-yen for his part said Taiwan's victory in the battle laid a solid foundation for accelerating the country's democratic and economic development and that the veterans should be given credit for their contributions.
He further said the government should attach more importance to the rights and interests of the aging veterans and should provide them with proper benefits.
The conflict began Aug. 23, 1958 when China launched a heavy bombardment on the Kinmen archipelago, which has a total surface area of just 150 square kilometers.
Over the course of the next 44 days of non-stop barrages, Chinese troops fired approximately 470,000 shells, but failed to pound Kinmen into submission.

DOC.HEADLINE: No formaldehyde problems with prefab houses donated by China

TEXT.P: There have been no excess levels of the carcinogenic formaldehyde recorded in prefabricated houses donated by China to house victims of Typhoon Morakot who have been evacuated or who have lost their homes, the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Sunday.

Wang Pi, director-general of the National Institute of Environmental Analysis under the EPA, said that indoor air samples collected from two Chinese prefab houses that were erected in Pingtung County's Jiadong township Aug. 20 were tested and were found to contain no formaldehyde, dashing rumors that the materials used to construct the dwellings contained high levels of the toxic substance.
Wang also confirmed that total volatile organic compounds (TVOC) concentrations in indoor air samples collected from the two Chinese prefabs were under allowable levels of less than 3ppm.

Wang said the TVOC concentrations averaged 11.3 ppm in the air collected from the two prefabs within the first hour of erection, although the concentrations dropped to below 3 ppm in one day. "The TVOCs we found in our tests actually pose no harm to humans," he added.

Hsieh Yen-ju, director-general of the EPA Bureau of Air Quality Protection and Noise Control, suggested nevertheless that anyone moving into the units should keep doors and windows open for one day before moving in.
Wang, Hsieh and other EPA specialists were called in by the Consumers Foundation Aug. 20 to check the safety of the first batch of 100 prefabs that arrived in Taiwan in the wake of Typhoon Morakot.
The units arrived Aug. 18 and were transported directly to Jiadong township to house people there affected by Typhoon Morakot, which triggered the worst flooding in Taiwan in half a century.
The death toll from the storm had risen to 160 as of Saturday, with another 490 remaining unaccounted for and 45 people reported injured.
Jiadong was one of the areas in southern Taiwan hardest hit by the storm that lashed Taiwan Aug. 7-9.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1st 100 prefab houses in Kaohsiung to be completed in 2 weeks

TEXT.P: Assembly of 100 units of a second batch of prefabricated houses for temporary resettlement of survivors of Typhoon Morakot got underway Sunday in Shanlin township in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County.
The prefab houses were donated by China's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) and were delivered to Kaohsiung Harbor the previous day.

Three Chinese technicians, who also arrived in Kaohsiung the previous day to offer technical counseling and manpower training, visited the construction site near Shanlin Junior High School to oversee the assembly of the units.
They said their company has exported prefab houses to the Middle East and Africa, all of which have been of satisfactory quality.

The Chinese technicians were accompanied by executives of Taiwan's Red Cross Society, which is joining with several other charities, including World Vision Taiwan, Dharma Drum Mountain and the Fo Guang Shan Monastery, to provide the prefabs for displaced typhoon victims.
Seven other Chinese technicians were also scheduled to arrive in Kaohsiung the following day to assist in assembly of the houses.

China has donated 1,000 prefab houses to help with Taiwan's post-disaster resettlement drive. A total of 300 had arrived in Taiwan in two shipments as of Saturday, with a third batch of 300 due to be delivered Monday.

Yeh Shih-wen, director of the Construction and Planning Agency under the Ministry of the Interior, said at a ceremony marking the start of assembly that the project is part of efforts to deliver on President Ma Ying-jeou's promise to build prefab houses within one month for displaced victims in several of the hardest-hit disaster zones.

During an inspection tour of the three hardest-hit villages and townships in Kaohsiung County -- Siaolin, Liouguei and Taoyuan -- Aug. 19, Ma promised to complete within a month temporary resettlement of residents who were still being accommodated in emergency placement centers.
Yeh said the current site, which is owned by the state-run Taiwan Sugar Co., will be able to accommodate 200 to 400 of the prefabs. "The first 100 will be ready in two weeks," he added.
Each 15-ping prefab house has two bed rooms, one living area and a bathroom.

"The houses can be used for more than 10 years," Yeh said, adding that the new 100-house community will have an activity center, a parking lot and other public facilities, with major roads 8 meters wide.
According to Yeh, the plot can also be used to accommodate permanent houses for the survivors.

Hsu Pao-yen, an executive of the Siaolin Village Self-Help Association, said 247 houses in the remote mountain village were buried when mudslides came crashing down after torrential rain spawned by Morakot loosened the topsoil in the hills above the village.

Hundreds of Siaolin villagers are believed to have been buried alive in the tragic landslides, and Hsu said the survivors have expressed preference to have their new permanent houses built at the nearby village of Wulipu.

DOC.HEADLINE: HTC Corp. to develop new phones with China Mobile

TEXT.P: Taiwan's HTC Corp. will sign an agreement Monday with China Mobile, the world's largest mobile carrier, for joint development of 3G phones in China, an HTC executive said Sunday.

China Mobile Chairman Wang Jianzhou arrived in Taiwan Aug. 21 for a nine-day visit during which he will meet with HTC Chairwoman Cher Wang to discuss mobile phone procurement and cooperation in development and research of China's TD- SCDMA standards, according to the executive.

The planned strategic alliance between the two companies is expected to help HTC Corp.'s Ophone to compete with Apple's iPhone in China's vast market, despite a lackluster performance by the company in China this year, the HTC executive said.

To attain its goal of gaining 85 million households using 3G services in three years, China Mobile has been investing heavily in TD-SCDMA network expansion, according to the executive, who said that during Wang's stay, he will also visit a number of local companies, including Mediatek and Chunghwa Telecom, to seek cooperation with them.

China Mobile and HTC will develop at least one new type of mobile phone this year and at least five types next year. The two companies will develop new smartphones based on China Mobile's Open Mobile System (OMS), the executive added.
The day before his arrival, Wang Jianzhou said in Hong Kong that China Mobile will launch its Ophone running on the OMS platform in collaboration with HTC, Lenovo and Dell.

DOC.HEADLINE: No remains of typhoon victims recovered Sunday

TEXT.P: Operations to retrieve the bodies of residents who perished in landslides caused by Typhoon Morakot in Liouguei township's Xinkao tribal settlement in Kaohsiung County did not yield any results Sunday.
A total of 24 diggers and bulldozers were employed to help military personnel locate and excavate the bodies of the victims, but the efforts were in vain.
As of Sunday, the corpses of just four of the 28 people believed to be buried alive in the settlement had been retrieved.
President Ma Ying-jeou has promised that all search work will be completed by Aug. 27 and military servicemen have been working hard to carry out the excavation work according to Ma's deadline.
"We will do our utmost to complete the task and are not worried that we will fall behind schedule, " said Chou Li-shuan, head of the military excavation operations.

Pan Hin-pei, a representative of the township, said local residents will not demand to much of the military as long as it is seen to have done its best, because the area requiring excavation is so large.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier vows to improve disaster prevention, relief mechanism

TEXT.P: The government will overview the existing public infrastructure specifications with regard to natural disaster prevention out of safety concerns in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Sunday.
Liu made the statement after presiding over a meeting of an ad hoc post-typhoon reconstruction committee held at an army base in Cishan township in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County.

Liu said the country's natural disaster prevention and response mechanism, as well as the present standard operating procedure (SOP) for evacuating people from potentially dangerous areas in the event of an imminent natural disaster, should also be overhauled and reinforced.

Liu's pledge came after scathing criticism over the government's flawed post- disaster rescue and relief operation after Morakot wreaked havoc in southern Taiwan, particularly in several remote mountainous regions.

Liu said he has directed the Construction and Planning Agency under the Ministry of the Interior and the National Science and Technology Center for Disaster Reduction to come up with improvement and reinforcement measures.
"The central government will also discuss relevant reform measures with local governments before putting them into force, " Liu said.

President Ma Ying-jeou also said last week that the existing Disaster Prevention and Response Act should be updated to establish criteria that would allow or a compulsory evacuation to prevent a repeat of the loss of human life and suffering caused by Typhoon Morakot that pummeled Taiwan Aug.7-9.

Morakot, which dumped a staggering amount of rainfall in some parts of Taiwan, had its deadliest impact on some remote villages that nestle mountains in Pingtung and Kaohsiung counties. One such village, Siaolin, was obliterated when Morakot-triggered torrential rains sent the faces of the nearby mountains tumbling down on the village's 240 or so houses. Hundreds of Siaolin residents are believed to have been buried alive in the killer landslides.
On post-disaster rehabilitation, Liu said the government will enlist local enterprises that have promised to donate funds to take part in various reconstruction projects.

Noting that reconstruction involves not only building prefab houses or permanent houses but also employment, schooling, cultural preservation and other issues, Liu said the government plans to mobilize local enterprises to sponsor various hardest-hit villages.

"The funds donated by business groups should be better used by mobilizing donor companies to sponsor various hardest-hit villages or townships, " Liu said, adding that the proposal has received warmer-than-expected response from the business community.
A large number of local enterprises have chipped in to help finance post- disaster relief and rehabilitation projects.

"We should not waste even a penny of those funds and the central and local governments as well as public-interest groups and private corporations should work hand-in-hand to accelerate rehabilitation on various fronts," Liu said.
In the process, Liu went on, surviving victims certainly will have a say so that all reconstruction projects will better meet their future demand.
Meanwhile, the Interior Ministry had interviewed 3,927 survivors from 1,388 households as of Aug.18 to explore their opinions about resettlement.
Among them, 553 households want government-arranged resettlements; 264 want to rent houses on their own; 74 want to buy new houses; and 497 remain undecided.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 24, or the fifth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1814: The small but very bitter war being fought between Britain and the United States continues, with British forces razing many Washington, D.C. landmarks, including the White House.
1923: A "Dr. Sun Yat-sen mission" led by Chiang Kai-shek leaves Harbin for Moscow on a fact-finding tour.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's Nationalist government, signs the ratification instrument of the U.N. Charter.
1945: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China ratifies the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1950: Communist China sends troops into Tibet.
1954: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs into law the Communist Control Act, outlawing the Communist Party.
1954: Brazilian President Getulio Vargas shoots himself to avoid scandal as well as demands that he relinquish power. He was 71.
1968: Taichung's Golden Dragons baseball team defeats the U.S. West team 5A-0 to win the 23rd Little League World Championship.
1981: A Manhattan Supreme Court judge jails Mark David Chapman for 20 years to life for shooting dead John Lennon the previous December.
1983: The auditorium of Fengyuan High School in Taichung County collapses, killing 27 students and injuring 83 others.
1983: Communist Chinese pilot Lt. Col. Sun Tien-chin, who flew to South Korea from mainland China in a MiG-21 jet fighter Aug. 7, arrives in Taiwan.
1985: Communist Chinese pilot Hsiao Tien-jun, 33, flies an H-5 torpedo attack bomber to South Korea and requests political asylum in the ROC.
1986: The ROC Little League baseball team "Kungyuan" defeats Tucson, Arizona, and recaptures the Little League World Series title after four years.
1991: The Ukraine declares independence from Moscow.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as head of the Soviet Communist Party and urges its leadership to disband the party.
1992: Communist China and South Korea establish diplomatic relations.
1995: President Juan Carlos Wasmosy of Paraguay leads a delegation to Taipei for a four-day visit.
1995: Beijing expels Chinese-American human rights activist Harry Wu shortly after he was sentenced to a 15-year prison term for spying and leaking state secrets.
1996: The ROC wins the 1996 Little League World Series in the U.S. city of Williamsport, Pennsylvania.
1999: A UNI Air plane from Taipei crash-lands at Hualien Airport in flames, injuring 28 passengers.
1999: Ever Decent, a Panamanian-flagged container ship owned by Taiwan's Evergreen Marine Corp., is hit by Norwegian Dream, a Bahamas-registered cruise ship, injuring three people aboard the cruise ship.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian wraps up his visit to Chad ahead of schedule after issuing a joint communique with Chadian President Idriss Deby.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian officiates at the opening of the plenary session of the much-anticipated Economic Development Advisory Conference Friday, a series of meetings and discussions designed to invigorate Taiwan's floundering economy.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who possesses great moral qualities will certainly attain a corresponding high position, a corresponding great prosperity, a corresponding great name, and a corresponding great age."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei schools urged to assist students affected by storm

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin on Monday urged principals of 150 elementary schools in the city to help accommodate school children displaced by Typhoon Morakot.

At a meeting with the principals, Hau exhorted them to make greater efforts to help school children from southern Taiwan, as many students would be unable to attend school in their own areas when the new semester begins because they lost their homes or were evacuated from their residences.
Hau also asked the principals to help rebuild schools that were destroyed or damaged by landslides and flooding during Typhoon Morakot.
Also speaking at the meeting, Wu Ching-shan, director of the Taipei City Education Department, detailed a plan for Taipei City schools to help those in the disaster areas.
Wu said public elementary schools in Taipei City will offer a total of 3,000 openings to students from the affected areas.

Meanwhile, he said, the Education Department last week offered aid to five elementary schools and one junior high school in Linbian township in the southernmost county of Pingtung, one of the hardest-hit areas.
"Our aid will be arriving there before the new semester begins on Sept. 1," Wu said.

According to official tallies, a total of 1,282 schools in central and southern Taiwan were demolished or damaged by Typhoon Morakot, which wreaked havoc on Taiwan Aug. 7-9 with landslides and the worst flooding in Taiwan in half a century.
Of the total, 31 elementary schools in remote mountain villages were leveled or covered in mud and debris, putting paid to any hopes of children returning for the new semester.
More than 10,000 university and college students have volunteered to help clean up and restore damaged elementary and junior high schools, according to the Ministry of Education.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wandan residents do not have swine flu, preliminary checks find

TEXT.P: The many villagers in southern Taiwan who developed fevers in the wake of Typhoon Morakot were preliminarily cleared of suspicion of A(H1N1) infection, health authorities said Monday.

Lin Ting, director-general of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC), said that more than 30 residents in the flood-affected Wandan township in Pingtung County, southern Taiwan, have developed fevers since Aug. 17, and 13 of them have been hospitalized.
However, in all cases, the symptoms were different from those of swine flu, Lin said, adding that the CDC is carrying out tests to determine the cause of the patients' illness.
Those who developed fevers and sore muscles might have contracted other types of viruses while they were cleaning up their flooded homes in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, CDC officials suggested.
Meanwhile, officials from the Pingtung County Public Health Bureau said Monday that all the Wandan residents who had reported having fevers were lucid and in stable condition.
The health authorities called for Pingtung residents to wear waterproof gear, including rubber boots, when cleaning up areas flooded by the storm.
The authorities warned that in flood affected areas there is risk of outbreaks of diseases such dysentery, exogenous febrile disease, cholera, amoebic dysentery, leptospirosis and dengue fever.

DOC.HEADLINE: Regional balance of power not affected by economic crisis: scholars

TEXT.P: Several scholars said Monday at an international economic forum in Taipei that the economic downturn has had limited impact on security in the Asia Pacific region, and that China will likely emerge as a "quasi-superpower" because of its economic resilience and military clout.

Park Kie-duck, a senior fellow and former president of the South Korea's Seiong Institute, said that although the recession has only been in effect for about one year and its impact might not be fully reflected in area of security, "there is no tangible sign of change in status quo in the security sector."

He and other prominent figures from academia, government institutions and the private sector at home and abroad are discussing key issues surrounding "Asia- Pacific Security in the Context of the Global Economic Crisis," at the 2009 Asia-Pacific Security Forum (APSF) Aug. 24-25.
Park forecast that if there is reasonable recovery from the recession, the United States will maintain its economic hegemony for the foreseeable future and military supremacy for an even longer time.
However, the South-Korean scholar said, China will emerge as a military and economic "quasi-superpower" in the near future.
Meanwhile, Japan, with relatively declining economic and military power vis-a-vis China, will strive to maintain its alliance with the U.S. and to modernize its warfare capabilities, Park said.
Japan will also be more frequently and strongly tempted into going nuclear, he added.

Carolina Hernandez, president of the Philippines' Institute for Strategic and Development Studies, expressed a similar view as Parks, saying that military spending by most countries in the Asia-Pacific region may not be overly affected by the global economic crisis, and therefore the balance of power in the region is unlikely to change soon.

For countries that have ongoing military modernization programs, those that have ongoing overseas commitments including for peacekeeping operations, and those preparing for an uncertain and fluid strategic environment to some extent shaped by the crisis, a dramatic decrease in military spending may not be in the cards, Hernandez said.
It is also likely that defense assistance and military cooperation activities in the Asia Pacific will continue, according to Hernandez.

Regional joint exercise between and among the U.S. and its allies and friends, for example, are long-standing commitments not likely to decline in the foreseeable future, especially due to the continuing uncertainty of the region's strategic environment, she added.

"In the case of China, it is safe to say that the resilience of its economy as shown by its continuing growth will enable it to pursue its military modernization program beyond the present crisis," she said.

Brad Glosserman, executive director of the U.S. think tank Center for Strategic and International Studies' (CSIS) Pacific Forum, said that in Asia, the primary beneficiary of the global economic crisis is China.
According to Glosserman, if China is seen to weather the crisis better than the U.S. or emerges from the downturn more quickly, this will impact on the U.S.' leadership.

However, that does not foretell a shift in the balance of power within the region because such a development may spur other countries to cling more tightly to the U.S. to ensure its continuing engagement, though this will alter regional dynamics, he added.
"Of course, if the U.S. emerges from this crisis faster and stronger that any of its 'competitors,' then its credibility will be re-enhanced," Glosserman said.

Now in its 13th year, the forum is being held by Taiwan's Institute for National Policy Research in collaboration with the Pacific Forum from the United States, the Institute for Strategic and Development Studies and the Asia Center of France.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lite-On Tech Corp. invests in China's solar industry

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Lite-On Technology Corp. will cooperate with China's Yingtan city government to develop thin film solar power generating systems for agricultural use, Lite-on General Manager Chuang Mei-chen said Monday.

Although the details of the agreement between Lite-On and the Chinese city in Jianxi Province have not been finalized, the Taiwanese company has already agreed to provide five solar power generating systems for agricultural use to China's Shangrao City, also in Jianxi Province, with each system generating 20 kilowatts for a total estimated price of 5 million yuan (US$732,055).

Chuang noted that investing in thin film solar power generating systems will not only boost the development of green energy but will also speed up modern hi-tech agricultural development, which will in turn increase output value and increase farmers' incomes.
Lite-On products include computers, semiconductor components, projector power supplies and phone camera modules.

The Taiwanese government is supporting the growth of the solar energy industry and has designated solar energy as a strategic industry for the country. It forecasts that the total value of the sector will hit $12.5 billion in 2015, compared to $652 million in 2006, accounting for 7 percent of the global solar- power generation equipment sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon damage forces indigenous performance group to move

TEXT.P: The flagship indigenous performance group of the Tsou tribespeople has been forced to relocate from the Alishan National Scenic Area in the Alishan mountain to a flat area in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan, in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot.
The Tsou aboriginal group performed its traditional dances and songs for a group of tourists from mainland China Monday, in its first public appearance since its members were forced to relocate.
The group moved from Alishan earlier this month after the highway that leads to the mountain was damaged during the typhoon, which wreaked havoc in southern Taiwan Aug. 7-9.
The group's first performance since then was staged at Wufeng Park in Chiayi County's Jhongpu township.

Most of the group members escaped down the mountain on foot after the highway was deluged by floodwaters and damaged in some sections by landslides. Some of the members remained on the mountain to repair their ravaged homes, said Yang Chia-yu, a dancer whose home in Laichi Village was also destroyed by the storm.
"We're down and out, feeling listless and depressed as our homes and performance venue have all gone," Yang said.
"However, we are strong enough to hang in there and wait for the highway to reopen to traffic," she stressed.

The National Alishan Scenic Area -- one of the attractions in Taiwan that Chinese tourists consider as a "must see" -- has been cut off from the rest of the island since the typhoon slammed into Taiwan. Sections of the Alishan Highway have been destroyed and the Alishan Forest Railway permanently damaged.
According to the Chiayi County government, the highway might be rebuilt and reopened to public traffic by later September, but there is no timetable for the repair of the railway.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education ministry organizes therapy for children in disaster areas

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) is taking steps to provide counseling for the many traumatized children in areas that were devastated by Typhoon Morakot earlier this month, Administrative Deputy Minister Lin Tsong-ming Monday.

According to Lin, some 277 volunteer counselors and 100 professionals are already in place in these areas and they will be offering therapy to the numerous children in emergency shelters who lost their relatives and their homes in the storm.
Many of these children have been displaying symptoms of post-disaster psychological trauma that include insomnia, nightmares, poor appetite, and inability to focus, he said.

In an effort to address this problem, Lin said, the MOE has devised a two-phase plan, under which individual one-on-one counseling will be provided in the first stage. In the second phase, universities will "adopt" elementary and junior high schools to offer professional therapy to affected children, he added.
The plan calls for an integrated effort by the MOE, local governments and the participating universities and will involve students, parents and teachers in the disaster areas, he said.
The aim is to provide a professional, systematic, localized and deeply caring service, he added.
The first stage of the plan will commence before school opens for the new semester and will focus on soothing the victims and easing their stress.
Currently there are 13 psychological therapy centers at the emergency shelters. The counselors will identify children in need of therapy and send them to these centers.

In the second phase, which will begin after school opens and run until next February, professional counselors will be placed at schools to help the children recover in the long term and adapt to new lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: July jobless rate hits 6.07 percent

TEXT.P: The nation's unemployment rate rose to 6.07 percent in July, up 0.13 percentage points from the previous month, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) announced Monday.
The number of jobless in July totaled 663,000, up 16,000 from the figure recorded in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, falling NT$0.043 to close at NT$32.863.
A total of US$494 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.906 and reached a low of NT$32.829.

DOC.HEADLINE: More Chinese technicians arrive to help assemble prefab houses

TEXT.P: Seven Chinese technicians arrived Monday in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan, to help assemble prefabricated houses donated by China to house people made homeless by Typhoon Morakot.
The technicians joined three others who have been in Taiwan since Aug. 22 to assist with the work of erecting the houses in Shanlin Township in Kaohsiung County.
They are expected to assemble 200 prefab houses within three weeks.
China had donated 1,000 of the prefabs, 300 of which have already been shipped to Taiwan, with another 300 scheduled to be delivered later Monday.
As local workers have had difficulty assembling the structures, they have turned to the Chinese manufacturers of the houses for help.
The Chinese manufacturers sent three technicians to Taiwan Saturday but they were unable to handle the heavy schedule required to assemble the houses within a short space of time.

To allow the typhoon victims to have their own temporary homes as soon as possible, China's cross-Taiwan Strait intermediary body, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, asked for Taiwan's consent to allow seven more technicians to enter Taiwan to help with the work.
The remaining 400 prefabs will be shipped to Taiwan Aug. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. organization aid workers arrive to help with disaster relief

TEXT.P: Three members of a U.N.-affiliated disaster relief organization arrived in Taiwan Monday and were expected to immediately enter and evaluate disaster areas battered by Typhoon Morakot earlier this month.
The three workers of the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) were greeted by members of the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China upon their arrival.

OCHA staffer Stephen Tull said he and his two colleagues represent the U.N.'s concern for the disaster in Taiwan and would evaluate the damage so that the OCHA can provide necessary support with post-disaster resettlement and disaster avoidance.
The OCHA last sent people to Taiwan following the earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999.

At that time, then-U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan had to ask permission from China before sending people to Taiwan. However, the current secretary-general, Ban Ki-moon, did not contact China this time before dispatching the aid workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: July export orders decline 8.77 percent

TEXT.P: Export orders received in July reached US$28.614 billion, registering a year-on- year decline of 8.77 percent and marking the biggest drop in nine months, according to statistics released Monday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
The accumulated export orders totaled US$168.577 billion in the first seven months of the year, representing a drop of 21.15 percent from the same period of 2008, according to the tallies.

However, July exports of precision instruments and electronic products grew, with precision instruments recording a year-on-year growth of 17.39 percent and electronic products increasing by 12.74 percent, the MOEA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices surge on local bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices, snapping a five-day losing streak, opened high and closed 2.75 percent higher Monday, following the announcement of two collaborative projects between companies in Taiwan and China.

The weighted index, the market's key barometer, surged 183.45 points to close at 6,838.25, on hopes that the signing Monday of an agreement between Taiwan's HTC Corp. and China Mobile for joint development of 3G phones in China, and Formosa Plastics' plan to expand its factory in Ningbo in eastern China would help boost Taiwan's economy.
Following Wall Street's rise last Friday to an eight-month closing high and the rally of regional stock markets, the local bourse opened high at 6,766.76.
The Taiex later reached the day's high of 6,859.79 then retreated to the day's low of 6,762.68.
The local market lost 414 points last week as Taiwan scrambled to recover from Typhoon Morakot, which triggered the most severe flooding in the country in 50 years.
A total of 3.08 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$90.10 billion (US$2.74 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 4.2 percent. Plastics and chemicals shares advanced 4.1 percent, textile stocks gained 3.7 percent, construction stocks rose 3 percent, machinery and electronics shares surged 2.4 percent, paper and pulp issues advanced 2.1 percent, cement stocks rose 1.6 percent, and foodstuff issues advanced 1.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,752 to 684, with 128 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$6.79 billion worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flood victim children invited to visit Mongolia

TEXT.P: A visiting Mongolian delegation Monday invited children from the southern Taiwan areas that were badly hit by flooding in the wake of Typhoon Morakot to visit their country to share their experience of rebuilding their homes and lives.

The nine-strong delegation, comprising representatives of the city government of Ulan Bator, the capital of Mongolia, as well as representatives of some of the city's civic groups, arrived in Taiwan Aug. 15 for a 10-day visit to study the country's waste management policies.

Delgerbayar Badam, chief of the Ulan Bator bureau of environmental pollution and waste management, said his delegation "wanted to do something" to help the victims of Taiwan's worst flooding for 50 years.

Badam noted that his country invited 40 children from devastated areas of Sichuan Province, southwestern China, following the 7.9-magnitude earthquake of May. 12, 2008 to visit Mongolia to share their restoration experience with Mongolian people.
This promoted him to do the same for some of the flood-affected children in Taiwan, he said.
Badam added that a formal invitation will be extended in the coming year and that the best time for the children to visit Mongolia would be June or later.

Since its arrival, the delegation has visited the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration, the Taipei City Department of Environment Protection and several local civic organizations advocating recycling.
Badam said he has been deeply impressed by the Taiwanese people's willingness to conduct resource recycling. "Many people here are willing to do things to help the environment," he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Driftwood did not come from Forestry Bureau land: official

TEXT.P: Officials from the Forestry Bureau under the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Monday that most of the driftwood that has built up on the coast near Jiangjyun fishing port in Tainan County, southern Taiwan, did not originate from state- owned forests overseen by the COA.

Yang Hung-chih, a Forestry Bureau division head in Chiayi, southern Taiwan, said after a fact-finding tour of the port area that a majority of the driftwood, extending over an area of about 1.3 hectares, did not come from state-owned forests.
At a meeting with Jiangjyun-based fishermen, the bureau officials said the question of who should clear the driftwood will be referred to the central government.

The fishermen were complaining that they have incurred huge losses as the driftwood -- washed from the mountains downriver into the sea in the wake of Typhoon Morakot -- has clogged the port area, scraping their boats and damaging their propellers.
One fisherman said his fishing boat was speared by a huge trunk all the way through the hull, while others said their fishing gear had been destroyed.
"We are suffering from dual losses, with our equipment damaged, and our fishing operations have ground to complete halt, " they lamented.

Almost all the fishing ports and estuaries along Taiwan's central, southern, eastern and southwestern coasts have been clogged with thousands of tons of driftwood washed down from the mountains after the typhoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH to expand anti-viral drug inventory to ward off H1N1 outbreak

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan ordered an increase in Taiwan's anti-viral drug supply on Monday in anticipation of a possible outbreak of influenza A(H1N1), more commonly known as swine flu, after schools reopen in September.
His instruction came amid reports of the fourth and fifth A(H1N1) fatalities in Taiwan the same day.

Addressing a meeting of public health officials, Liu said the Department of Health (DOH) should collaborate with educational authorities to avert the spread of the disease as local schools will open soon after the summer break.
For one thing, the premier said, procurement and inventory of anti-viral drugs, such as Tamiflu and Relenza, should be expanded to meet the demand in case of an emergency.
As of Monday, Taiwan had confirmed five swine flu fatalities. CDC tallies also show that the number of severe cases has exceeded 40, with some patients still receiving treatment at hospitals.
The number of cluster H1N1 infections is also believed to have hit 100, and more than 10,000 Taiwanese people are coming down with the virus each week, according to CDC estimates.
Given the trend, the government's epidemic-fighting capability could be put to a test after local schools reopen next week, health experts said.
In response to the situation, the Cabinet's epidemic control advisory task force convened an emergency meeting Sunday.

It was decided during the meeting that the inventory of Tamiflu and Relenza will be raised to an amount sufficient for use by 30 percent of Taiwan's total population - or at least 7 million people - up from the original 18 percent.

After consulting with epidemic specialists, the CDC has also decided to ease regulations for anti-viral drug prescriptions. Under the relaxed rules, physicians will be authorized to prescribe Tamiflu or Relenza to certain categories of flu-like patients without the need of passing speedy screenings for the patients.

Those patients will include people with underlying chronic diseases, pregnant women, children under the age of 5, people who have come into contact with confirmed H1N1 patients, and those who have developed pneumonia or severe flu symptoms.

The DOH has also unveiled guidelines for school closures. The criteria stipulates that if two or more students in the same class are confirmed to have contracted the flu, either the seasonal or swine flu, the whole class should stay home for five days.

At present, some city and county governments have ordered elementary and secondary schools as well as kindergartens and day care centers in their districts to monitor the temperatures of their students every day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Monday:
Apple Daily:
Foreign ministry officials can't be bothered to socialize.
The foreign minister and his deputy were both absent Saturday from a disaster relief fundraiser organized by diplomats stationed in Taipei, for disaster relief.

It was really impolite of the host country not to have an official at the ministerial level at the fundraising event, which was attended by diplomats, including six ambassadors, from 13 of Taiwan's allies.
We would like to know what could have been important enough to prevent the foreign minister from attending the fundraiser.
As a Cabinet reshuffle appears to be imminent, we are calling for the foreign minister to be replaced.
Liberty Times:
Beware of China's beguiling offense

We have to warn the public that while the country is preoccupied with relief operations in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot, Beijing has gone on a beguiling offense against Taiwan with generous offers of aid.

The flooding caused by Morakot was the worst in five decades, and President Ma Ying-jeou's administration is the most incompetent in five decades -- two factors that combined to produce an unprecedented disaster.
Out of sympathy, Taiwanese donated more than NT$6 billion to China after the 2008 Sichuan Earthquake, but China donations to Taiwan in the wake of Typhoon Morakot are for its own political gains.

Beijing's donation of 20 million yuan to Taiwan lawmaker Kao-chin Su-mei to help provide relief to aboriginals in Taiwan was obviously intended to woo Taiwan's aboriginals, in China's aim to take over Taiwan.
If China achieves its goals with regard to Taiwan, it will be a policial disaster of a magnitude greater than the devastation caused by Typhoon Morakot.
China Times:
Reconstruction should not be carried out in haste
Taiwan's mountainous areas were hardest-hit in the flooding caused by Typhoon Morakot.
As the government gears up to begin post-diaster reconstruction, the guideline should be to coexist with nature rather than to fight for land that has rivers or mountains.

There are many problems in Taiwan's mountains that make them prone to mudslides. We cannot agree with the government's promise to rebuild on the original sites those villages that were leveled by mudslides. This will only set the stage for more tragedy.

Past experience shows that it also won't work to relocate people in the disaster areas to safer places far away. Usually, when these people cannot adapt to their new lives they sneak back to their homes in the mountains.

We therefore suggest the authorities rebuild these mountain villages at carefully chosen safe sites near the original locations and improve the flood- warning systems to alert people in mountainous areas to impending disasters.
United Daily News:
Ma's administration has been criticised for its approach toward the disaster caused by Typhoon Morakot and its attempts to deal with the flooding.
Ma should take lessons from the ancient Chinese Emperor Yu in both these respects.
Legend has it that Yu was so immersed in his work trying to quell floodwater that he did not enter his home, even though he passed by it three times.

Members of Ma's Cabinet have been lambasted for having haircuts or dining out with their families during the onslaught of Typhoon Morakot, which, while perhaps not inexcusable behavior, is considered a sign of negligence by a public that has scant confidence in officialdom.
As for ways to control flooding, Emperor Yu used dredging instead of containment, which is still the principle followed by experts today.
Yu's achievement in controlling flooding earned him the throne and thereby sent a message to his descendants that people, like water, can oust an unpopular ruler or sweep a popular leader to power.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fourth, fifth H1N1 fatalities reported in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Taiwan's health authorities reported the country's fourth and fifth influenza A(H1N1) fatalities Monday, bringing the number of local residents who died of swine flu-related illnesses from three to five in just three days.

The fifth fatality, a 44-year-old woman from Pingtung County, southern Taiwan, had not traveled overseas in recent months, but came down with flu symptoms on Aug. 17 and developed a fever of 39 degrees Celsius on Aug. 20, according to the Centers for Disease Control (CDC).
The woman, who was not a victim of flooding triggered by Typhoon Morakot, sought treatment on Aug. 20 at a Pingtung hospital and later tested positive for the A(H1N1) virus the next day.
Although doctors administered Tamiflu to her immediately on Aug. 21, she died of multiple organ failure early Monday -- less than a week after showing flu symptoms.
Confounded by the woman's abrupt death, CDC officials said they will probe whether it was a result of the occurrence of resistance to Tamiflu or mutation by the A(H1N1) virus.

The fourth fatality was a 6-year-old boy who lived in the central Taiwanese county of Changhua and had not traveled overseas in recent months. The boy developed flu symptoms in mid-July and was treated as a normal flu patient until July 27 when he developed a high fever and his condition deteriorated.

He was referred to a medical center on July 27 where he tested positive for influenza A(H1N1) strain. After one month of treatment, the boy died on Aug. 21, soon after he was taken home by his parents.
Both the fourth and fifth cases were considered victims of community infections of A(H1N1) strain.
As of Monday, Taiwan has reported five A(H1N1) fatalities, with one each in Taipei City, Taitung County, Pingtung County, Kaohsiung City and Changhua County.
Five other severe cases were under close medical monitoring at intensive care units, according to the CDC.
The Central Epidemics Command will soon convene an emergency meeting aimed at heightening Taiwan's epidemic-defensive capabilities, CDC officials said.

In related news, Cheng Jen-hung, an ombudsman of the Control Yuan, Taiwan's top watchdog, said Monday that he will not rule out the possibility of initiating an investigation into the fifth A(H1NI) fatality case to learn why the patient died even after having been treated with Tamiflu.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA news budget for Aug. 24

TEXT.P: to move 5. More Chinese technicians arrive to help assemble prefab houses 6. Fourth, fifth H1N1 fatality reported in Taiwan 7. Lite-On Tech Corp. invests in solar energy in China 8. DOH to expand drug inventory to prevent H1N1 outbreak 9. Forestry Bureau would not foot the bill for drifted lumber

cleaning 10. Flood-affected children invited to visit Mongolia 11. Export orders decline 8.77% in July 12.Jobless rate surges to all-time high 13. Premier announces five measures on H1N1 prevention 14. China Mobile cooperates with HTC in making new 3G mobile phones 15. Singapore sends APEC invitation to Ma 16. Over 1,300 flood-affected schools to open as scheduled

DOC.HEADLINE: China incapable of launching financial warfare against U.S.: scholars

TEXT.P: Two renowned scholars said Monday in Taipei that it is impossible for China to launch "financial warfare" against the United States despite China's apparent greater resilience in the face of the global financial crisis from which the U.S. is still struggling to recover.

"I believe U.S. status depends on what it does, no what China does. China cannot undermine U.S. power," said Brad Glosserman, executive director of the Hawaii- based U.S. think tank Center for Strategic and International Studies' (CSIS) Pacific Forum.
"In the context of financial warfare, no, it won't happen; the two economies are too much intertwined," he added.

Glosserman and Carolina Hernandez, president of the Philippines' Institute for Strategic and Development Studies, expressed their views on the issue of whether China has the ability to take over the U.S. as the leader in the global economic arena, at the 13th Asia-Pacific Security Forum (APSF) being held in Taipei from Aug. 24-25.

Their responses came as one of the forum panelists Park Kie-duck, a senior fellow and former president of South Korea's Seiong Institute, argued at the forum that China's economic strength poses potential threats to the U.S. in two ways -- China could launch a kind of financial warfare against the U.S. with the massive amount of U.S. debt owed to China, including treasury bonds and other securities, and could also utilize its continually expanding, diversified, and sophisticated military capabilities against U.S. interests.

However, Glosserman argued that he does not believe China will become the world's leader any time soon because China is a nation that is in the process of building its power and status, and is not prepared to take on any responsibility in the international system beyond protecting its national interests.

Hernandez expressed similar views as Glosserman, saying that at present, the size of the U.S. economy is much bigger than China's, which would make it difficult for China to initiate financial warfare.
"Let's think about those figures before we go crazy thinking about other things that someone is on the way out and somebody else is on the way in," she said.

Entering its 13th year, the APSF forum is being held from Aug. 24-25 in Taipei by Taiwan's Institute for National Policy Research in collaboration with the Pacific Forum from the United States, the Institute for Strategic and Development Studies and the Asia Center from France.

It features prominent figures from academia, government institutions and the private sector who gather from home and abroad to discuss key issues surrounding the topic: "Asia-Pacific Security in the Context of the Global Economic Crisis."

DOC.HEADLINE: Unemployment rate hits all-time high

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate has risen above 6 percent for the first time since the government began compiling jobless statistics in 1978, reaching 6.07 percent in July as new college graduates entered the labor market.

The number of jobless also hit a record high of 663,000, up 16,000 from the level recorded in June, according to figures released by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The number of people affected by unemployment (including dependents of unemployed individuals) was estimated at 1.399 million in July, up 10,000 from the June level, also a historical high.
July's jobless rate marked an increase of 0.13 percentage points from the previous month and a 2.01 percent rise year-on-year.
The seasonally adjusted jobless rate for July also broke the 6 percent threshold at 6.01 percent, according to DGBAS statistics.
Heavily dependent on exports, Taiwan's economy has been battered by the global economic crisis as traditional export markets in the West have dramatically cut purchases.

That has led to continuing layoffs in the export sector as local factories closed or cut production. The total of jobless increased 117,000 between November 2008 and February 2009 and then stabilized for the next three months before rising by 30,000 in the past two months.
Liu Tien-si, a DGBAS deputy department chief, said the swelling jobless ranks could be attributed in part to the entry of new university graduates into the job market in July.
There were 115,000 new job seekers in July, 7,000 more than in the same month a year earlier.

In the particularly sensitive 45-64 age bracket, employment levels continued to stabilize. Some 34.34 million people in the age group were employed, up 8,000 from the June level. The 143,000 people unemployed in the age group was the same as in June, the first time in 11 months that the total had not increased.
The number of jobless in the age bracket, however, was also 67,000 higher than in July 2008, a jobless growth rate of 87.86 percent that was the highest for any age group.

Noting that few middle-age and elderly people would quit their jobs voluntarily, Liu said the swelling of jobless numbers among middle-aged and older workers could have the greatest negative impact on families and society.
Commenting on the further weakening of the job market, Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin said the government will continue taking active steps to stem a further rise in unemployment.

"Given an influx of new school graduates into the job market, we have foreseen a possible rise in the unemployment rate in July and August and have taken many measures to alleviate the situation, " Su said.
He added that the unemployment rate is expected to drop gradually beginning in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan intensifies fight against H1N1 outbreak

TEXT.P: Taiwan has intensified epidemic prevention efforts as it confirmed on Monday the fourth and fifth fatalities from swine flu, officially known as influenza A (H1N1).

As part of the reinforced campaign, more flu patients will be treated with the anti-viral drug Tamiflu, with the government rather than the National Health Insurance system footing the bill, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said.

In response to a steady rise in the number of swine flu infections in Taiwan, Liu said the government has decided to ease guidelines for Tamiflu prescriptions, which will be paid for with aspecial government budget.

Under the relaxed rules, physicians will be authorized to prescribe Tamiflu or Relenza to certain categories of flu patients without the need for them to undergo rapid screening tests for the H1N1 flu strain, which are not totally reliable.

Those patients will include people with underlying chronic diseases, pregnant women, children under the age of 5, people who have come into contact with confirmed H1N1 patients, and those who have developed pneumonia or severe flu symptoms.
Moreover, the premier said the procurement and inventory of anti-viral flu drugs, such as Tamiflu and Relenza, should be expanded to meet the demand in case of an emergency.

After consulting with health specialists, Liu said the inventory of Tamiflu and Relenza will be raised to an amount sufficient to treat 30 percent of Taiwan's total population -- or at least 7 million people -- up from the original 18 percent.

As Taiwan is still recovering from the destruction wrought by Typhoon Morakot, Liu said priority should be given to epidemic control measures at emergency shelters for people left homeless by the natural disaster.
As of Monday, more than 6,000 survivors remain in shelters in the hardest-hit zones in southern Taiwan's Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Chiayi counties.
Morakot dumped a staggering amount of rainfall in southern Taiwan Aug. 7-9, swelling rivers that washed away bridges and triggering landslides that buried entire remote mountainous villages.

As many military servicemen and volunteers have been mobilized to help clean up the huge amounts of mud and debris left by the storm, Liu said those working in the disaster zones should wear facial masks to protect themselves from coming down with the H1N1 virus.
As of Monday, Taiwan had confirmed five swine flu fatalities. CDC tallies also show that the number of severe cases has exceeded 40, with some patients still receiving treatment at hospitals.
The number of cluster H1N1 infections is also believed to have hit 100, and more than 10,000 Taiwanese people are coming down with the virus each week, according to CDC estimates.

DOC.HEADLINE: H1N1 cluster infections confirmed among soldiers in disaster zones

TEXT.P: Two cluster infections of swine flu, officially known as influenza A(H1N1) , were confirmed Monday among soldiers who are helping with post-typhoon relief and cleanup work in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County.

Lin Ting, deputy director-general of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health (DOH), said two samples collected from officers and enlisted men working at Tatan Elementary School in Donggang township tested positive for the H1N1 flu strain and a third one tested positive for the H3N2 seasonal flu strain.
Meanwhile, two samples collected from the Wanjin army barrack in Wandan township both tested positive for the A(H1N1) virus.
"It marks the first time that swine flu cluster infections have been confirmed among military servicemen taking part in the post-disaster rescue and cleanup work," Lin said.

As to reports that one naval serviceman and one army soldier working in the disaster zone had succumbed to swine flu, Lin said the DOH had not received such information and described the reports as sheer speculation.
According to CDC estimates, Taiwan should have 60 to 70 cluster H1N1 infections.
On Monday, Taiwan also confirmed its fourth and fifth H1N1 fatalities.

DOC.HEADLINE: HTC, China Mobile sign pact to develop new smartphones
