DOC.HEADLINE: 19 supermarkets and shopping malls in Taiwan vow to save energy

TEXT.P: Representatives of 19 major shopping malls and supermarkets in Taiwan took a vow on Tuesday to cut their store's electricity use by 5 percent in the next three years and reduce carbon dioxide emissions.
Among the 19 enterprises, 12 were shopping malls and seven were supermarkets. Altogether they have 868 franchise stores under them.
According to Yiin Chii-ming, Minister of Ministry of Economic Affairs, an enormous amount of energy and money will be saved if the businesses keep their promise.
If the companies stick to their agreement, 40.72 million kwh of electricity will be saved, which in turn will prevent 26,000 tons of CO2 from being released into the air, Yiin said.

That's 70 times the yearly carbon absorption for Daan Park, Taipei City's largest park, which is 259,293-square meters in size. The energy savings can also create NT$300 million worth of profit for energy-saving businesses, Yiin added.
Yiin was at a ceremony held by the Bureau of Energy at the International Convention Center in National Taiwan University Hospital.
The energy-saving campaign was launched in 2006. Back then, the energy consumption growth rate of the service industry was 4.2 percent, higher than the 3.7 percent in industrial businesses.

Over the past few years, the campaign persuaded different trades to sign an agreement to reduce energy consumption. In the first year, convenience stores signed up, the second year warehouse stores, and the third hospitals, hotels and department stores. This year it was supermarkets and shopping malls.

Previous participants have already reduced energy consumption by a total of 473 million kwh per year, preventing the release of 301,000 tons of CO2, which equals to one year's worth of carbon absorption by Taiwan's Kenting National Park, which is 18,084 hectares in size, Yiin said.

Statistics showed that investments made on energy-saving equipment by participants reached NT$1.8 billion, Yiin said, but the electricity bills they saved in a year amounted to NT$1 billion, which means that within two years, the participants get their money back, proving that energy-saving businesses can be both meaningful and profitable.

The results also show that convenience stores, the first type of business to enter the campaign in 2006, have already reduced 22 percent of their total energy consumption rate, saving 2.9 million kwh of energy and reducing 18,400 tons of CO2 per year, which equals to the yearly carbon absorption of the 28,400-hectare Yangmingshan National Park, an astonishing accomplishment, said Yiin.
The four most energy-efficient convenience stores are Uni-President, FamilyMart, Hi-Life and OK Mart, according to the Bureau of Energy.
The seven supermarkets that participated in the campaign were Pxmart, Wellcome, Matsusei, Taiwan Fresh Supermarket, Tung Kuan, Ken & Kuma and Civil Community Market.
The 12 shopping malls were The Mall, TaiMall, Metro Walk, the Breeze Center, Living Mall, Taichung Central Mall, Tiger City, Taipei 101, SugarMall, Miramar, Global Mall and Dream Mall.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon victims to take part in reconstruction panels

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that representatives of victims of Typhoon Morakot are welcome to take part in reconstruction committees organized by the central government or local authorities, so as to help speed up the process of resettlement and rebuilding.

The president made the remarks during a visit to a reception center temporarily set up by Shunshien Temple in Kaohsiung County's Neimen Village for victims from neighboring Namasia Village, which was devastated by the typhoon earlier this month.
Victims erected banners expressing their demands, such as "We want to participate in reconstruction panels."

Ma had flown to Namasia Village on a helicopter to gain a better understanding of the damage caused by Morakot there. Two out of three towns in Namasia are seriously damaged by mudslide stirred up by the typhoon and are no longer suitable for people to live in.
"Three townships have to be relocated and the complex task must be thoroughly assessed by experts. Residents' willingness and decision must be fully respected," said the president.
Ma urged the victims to swiftly make a decision on which government auxiliary measures they would accept so as to help the government launch all necessary measures as soon as possible.

"The government has put short-term, medium-term and long-term subsidy and housing plans in place to re-settle victims made homeless by Morakot, and it hopes that the victims can quickly choose one option that best serves their interest so as to allow the government to start ensuing projects swiftly," Ma said.

Ma stressed that the government will verify the deceased victims' identities in a looser way and that their affected family members are not obliged to take on any rehabilitation or rehoming projects put forward by the government.
At the reception center, survivors and victims also held up signs saying: "Stop the cross-region water channeling project to the Tsengwen Reservoir."

Many typhoon victims blame the water project for destabilizing the mountains near their villages and causing the deadly mudslides that killed many of their villagers during Typhoon Morakot, the worst typhoon Taiwan has suffered in 50 years.
Ma has promised to investigate their claim.

Minister of National Defense Chen Chao-min, Council of Indigenous Peoples Chairwoman Chang Jen-shiang and Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing were also present. Along with Ma, They bowed to the victims and apologized for the government's much criticized slow response in carrying out rescue and relief operations in the wake of the typhoon.

A bill seeking NT$100 billion for reconstruction is currently being screened by lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan, and the Executive Yuan is set to launch many rehabilitation projects once the bill clears the legislature, Ma added.

According to Yang, 2,000 prefabricated houses are being built in Kaohsiung County to house typhoon victims on a temporary basis, while the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation has promised to construct 1,000 permanent homes for the victims.
Kaohsiung, Taitung, Pingtung and Tainan counties are worst damaged by Typhoon Morakot, which lashed Taiwan from Aug. 7-10. Most of the victims are indigenous residents in mountain townships.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei on guard against swine flu for Deaflympics

TEXT.P: Taipei city government officials said Tuesday that they have made every possible preparation to guard against influenza A(H1N1) next month, when schools open for the new semester and the city will host the international Deaflympics 2009.
Amid reports that the new flu is spreading, city health officials said they have explained the situation to staff of hotels, restaurants, games volunteers and medical stations.
They said the city authorities have also purchased forehead thermometers and will distribute them to hotels to take the temperatures of guests and maintain daily notification with health officials.
Alcohol and antiseptic wipes will also be available at hotels and restaurants, according to the officials.
Sign-language publicity ads will also be aired at public places such as hotels, restaurants and MRT stations to spread the message of H1N1 prevention and control.

"Currently, available resources to fight the disease are abundant, " one health official said, adding that if tests conducted by medical facilities confirm anyone of having contracted A(H1N1) , they will be given Tamiflu, which is covered by national health insurance.
If athletes taking part in the Deaflympics are infected with the H1N1 virus, they will also be given Tamiflu despite not being covered by national insurance, the official added.

All competition venues will have medical stations and will provide assessments to athletes who show flu symptoms. The athletes will be sent to hospitals if necessary and doctors accompanying each team will decide whether they will suspend events as a result.
On the issue of class suspensions after schools open, the officials said they will follow the advice provided by the Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC).

The CECC advises that all schools, kindergartens, cram schools and day care institutions with two or more students in one class who have been diagnosed with A(H1N1) within three days will be closed for five days. Flu victims will only be allowed to return to school 24 hours after the symptoms disappear.
According to statistics provided by the CECC, Taiwan had recorded 70 cases of serious swine flu as of Monday -- 10 in Taipei -- with five fatalities.
The city government will make policy adjustments by keeping tabs on the swine flu situation at home and abroad, following the central government's guidelines.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fitch Ratings gives more optimistic forecast for Taiwan banks

TEXT.P: Fitch Ratings has lowered its forecast of losses by Taiwanese banks for the year, from NT$100 billion to NT$30 billion, citing better-than-expected asset quality maintenance during the global credit crisis.

In a report released Tuesday, the company stated that the banks were able to maintain good asset quality because of multi-year deleveraging by Taiwanese households and corporations before the financial crisis hit in 2008.

Nevertheless, the rating agency warned that the banking sector's large credit exposure to the troubled dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chip makers remains a significant threat to their asset quality over the short and medium term.
Local DRAM chip makers have all been losing money for most of the past year because of oversupply, while demand for chips have declined in the face of the global economic crisis.

Although local banks have done a good job in maintaining their asset quality in the first half of this year, other factors, including Taiwan's persistent economic slump, weak profit margins and high credit costs, could drive down their profits, said Jonathan Lee, senior director of the financial institutions group at Fitch Ratings Taiwan.

Taiwan's banking and financial reform plan may have been postponed because of the sharp economic recession from the fourth quarter of last year and the recent damage caused by Typhoon Morakot, according to Lee.
Over the next two to three years, Taiwan would not likely see mergers of large state-owned banks, Lee predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud Gate announces winners of 2010 Wanderer program

TEXT.P: Cloud Gate Dance Theater, a renowned Taiwanese dance company, announced Tuesday winners of its 2010 Wanderer program, which provides subsidies for budding or experienced artists to travel abroad or to take time off to gain artistic inspiration.
Twelve people from a total of 220 applicants have been selected to participate in the program next year, according to a press release from Cloud Gate Dance Theater.
"Although these wanderers have different backgrounds, they share the same fervent passion to travel to foreign countries and to explore inspirations,the press release said.

The 12 wanderers include Taiwanese opera actress Lee Pei-ying, stage actor Kao Ming-chien, art designer Wu Sheng-lin, theater stage and costume designer Li Huei-lin, social worker Chen Yu-ching and others.

Lee will go to Shaanxi, China to learnQinqiang, one of the oldest Chinese operas. Wu, who owns a free publication called the Lantern, will visit Hong Kong, Shanghai and Tibet to exchange ideas with local youth on independent publishing.
Li will go to Okinawa, Japan to learnbingata, which is a kind traditional resist dyed cloth, made using stencils and other methods, while Chen will study human rights development in Burma.

The 2010 Wanderer program is geared toward budding and professional artists under the age of 35, as well as people under the age of 45 who are involved in social service and have an enthusiasm for literature, music, performance arts, image art or public service.
Winners will be awarded a grant of NT$80,000 to NT$150,000 (US$2,428 to US$4,553), plus return tickets, visa fees and insurance fees for a 60-day trip to China, Japan, Turkey, India or Burma in 2010.
The Wanderer program was initiated in 2004 by Cloud Gate Theater founder Lin Hwai-min and has been sponsored since 2006 by Stan Shih, founder of the laptop- manufacturing giant, the Acer group.
Since then, a total of 53 Taiwanese artists, including this year s 12 winners, have obtained grants under the program.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier to work at reconstruction office in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan will work at a post-Typhoon Morakot reconstruction office in southern Taiwan for one week from Wednesday to coordinate relief and rehabilitation efforts, Government Information Office Minister Su Jun-pin said Tuesday.

Liu will help chiefs and deputy chiefs of government agencies in charge of post- disaster reconstruction work at the office to facilitate the distribution of relief subsidies, resettlement and reconstruction work, according to Su.

The initiative is aimed at providing a platform for Cabinet chiefs and officials to exchange views with residents of areas in southern Taiwan affected by the typhoon on reconstruction-related issues, he added.
The government also hopes to strengthen communication and coordination with displaced victims of the typhoon in terms of resettlement operations, he went on.
The premier will ask relevant agencies to map out plans pertaining to future typhoons and torrential rain in Morakot-affected areas during this year's typhoon season.
He will also preside over an Aug. 27 Cabinet meeting in Taipei as scheduled and will attend other important meetings in Taipei, such as those in relation to A(H1N1) influenza, according to Su.
"In principle, Liu will stay in southern Taiwan but will return to Taipei for important meetings," Su added.

In a related development, Control Yuan President Wang Chien-hsuan said the country's highest watchdog body will release a report in six months on its investigation into who should be held responsible for the administration's flawed response to the typhoon, which killed an estimated 500 people and left hundreds more homeless.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly 40,000 patients infected with swine flu: CDC

TEXT.P: Close to 40,000 people in Taiwan have contracted influenza A(H1N1) since early June, with a majority of them developing only mild symptoms, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yang Chi-liang, who serves as chief of the Central Epidemic Command Center, said Tuesday.

Citing estimates by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the DOH, Yang said about 38,000 people have been infected over the past three months around the country, with some 12,000 getting the virus last week alone.
Yang admitted that the epidemic, widely known as swine flu, is gradually spreading as had been previously forecast, but he added that "it will be OK if patients take medicine early enough."
"Around 70 percent of the people infected with the influenza A(HINI) virus will recover without taking anti-virals, " he noted.
The DOH's top concern at present, Yang went on, is to stave off a massive outbreak of A(H1N1), as it had initially succeeded in stemming the spread of the disease.

According to CDC Director-General Kuo Hsu-sung, there have been only 44 pneumonia cases induced by swine flu in Taiwan. Twenty-two of them have recovered, five have died, five are still in intensive care units and five are in normal wards.

"Swine flu does not necessarily lead to death from pneumonia, " Kuo said, pointing out that last year, Taiwan recorded 8,000 deaths caused by pneumonia, while for last week alone, there were 183 such cases, only two of which were induced by swine flu.

"Compared to the same period of last year, the number of pneumonia deaths linked to swine flu has not markedly increased, but the possibility of further deaths cannot be ruled out for the whole of this year," he added.

Kuo forecast that the first wave of swine flu will hit hard after schools begin the new semester in early September. However, he went on, the impact will be minimized as long as schools follow due procedure to stop classes for five days if "two cases are confirmed in three days in the same class."

Meanwhile, Adimmune Corp., Taiwan's only producer of swine flu vaccine, said it had begun mass production of vaccine and that the first batch of 5 million doses will be ready by the middle of September.
A vaccination program is expected to kick off in mid-November, once the drug's safety can be proven by the authorities, a company manager said.

Meanwhile that day, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said President Ma Ying-jeou had decided not to call a national security meeting for the time being to address the swine flu issue, despite grave public concern that the situation might spiral out of control.

The president made the decision upon the advice of Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, who had discussed the matter with epidemic experts, who assessed that the situation did not merit such a meeting, according to Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: President thanks U.S. for assistance in wake of typhoon

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou thanked the United States Tuesday for its assistance to Taiwan after Typhoon Morakot lashed the country Aug. 7-10.

"The Republic of China government and people wholeheartedly appreciate the United States for its provision of large helicopters which helped transport heavy machinery to disaster areas, " Ma said during a meeting with visiting Oklahoma Governor Brad Henry at the Presidential Office.

Ma also thanked Henry for the support that his state extended to Taiwan, such as favoring Taiwan's participation in world bodies and the idea of Taiwan signing a free trade agreement with the United States.
It was Henry's first visit to Taiwan since he assumed office in 2003. Taiwan Province and the state of Oklahoma will celebrate their 30th anniversary of sisterhood ties next year.
Typhoon Morakot had killed 292 people, with another 385 missing, mostly residents buried by a landslide in Siaolin village, Kaohsiung County, according to official estimates.
The typhoon also caused tens of billions of dollars-worth of losses in the agricultural, livestock and fish farming sectors, sending local prices of vegetables, fruit, fish and meat soaring.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Morakot rise to NT$15.8 billion

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Morakot had surged to NT$15.81 billion (US$540.55 million) as of Tuesday, according to statistics released that day by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).

The COA said that Morakot, which pummeled Taiwan Aug. 7-9, caused serious damage to the agricultural sector in 11 counties, with Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties in southern Taiwan and Hualien and Taitung counties in the east the hardest hit.
The statistics show that damage to crops had amounted to NT$4.47 billion, with 27 percent of the crops on 74,997 hectares of farmland wiped out.

Bananas suffered the heaviest damage, with 6,307 hectares ravaged by strong winds and flooding, followed by papayas, guavas, rice, bamboo shoots, orchids, custard apples and leafy vegetables. Bee losses amounted to NT$6.9 million.
Over 148,273 pigs, nearly 6.11 million chickens and around 1.54 million ducks perished in floods caused by the storm, bringing the total livestock losses to NT$1.48 billion, the COA said.

Damage to the aquaculture sector had amounted to NT$4.17 billion, the heaviest loss in 19 years, according to the statistics, with stock in some 9,162 hectares of fishponds or coastal areas washed away, it said.
Over 2,512 hectares of forestry was destroyed, while damage to all agricultural and fishery facilities amounted to NT$5.44 billion.
Damage to the fishery sector had surpassed NT$488 million, with the worst damage reported in Tainan City and Pingtung County.

The tallies also show that a total of 5,140 hectares of farmland had been either washed away or inundated, mostly in Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Chiayi counties, bringing the total losses in this respect to NT$4.58 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Future of Muzha-Neihu MRT line under evaluation: mayor

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Tuesday that the city government will decide whether to shut down the problematic Muzha-Neihu MRT line indefinitely after an inspection and repair program over the weekend.
The new line, which began commercial services July 4, has been a source of embarrassment to the Taipei city government, with constant shutdowns due to system failures.

A 56-hour suspension of operations last weekend for inspection and repair apparently failed to guarantee a smooth return to service, when a southbound train ground to a complete halt during rush hour Tuesday morning.
Replying to press inquiries regarding the latest half-hour shutdown, Hau said that problems with the brake and propulsion systems on one section caused the breakdown.

The Muzha-Neihu MRT line has been suspended twice over previous weekends for inspection and repair following numerous breakdowns. The contractor, Canada's Bombardier, will conduct another thorough inspection this coming weekend.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Vision announces rehabilitation plans for typhoon victims

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese chapter of the Christian charity World Vision said Tuesday that it will invest over NT$1.2 billion (US$36.5 million) in emergency relief and rehabilitation programs in the wake of Typhoon Morakot.

Hank Du, executive director of World Vision Taiwan, made the announcement at a news conference that same day in which he gave an update on the organization's relief operations in the storm-stricken areas and announced long-term rehabilitation plans to help the affected people return to normal life as soon as possible.

Noting that World Vision Taiwan plans to build 1,200 temporary homes for the storm victims in Taitung, Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Chiayi counties, Du said the temporary homes can be easily assembled by untrained personnel with simple hand tools and that once the land is ready, these homes can be completed in two or three weeks.
The homes will be made of different local materials such as bamboo and slate, Du went on, adding that the construction materials are light, environmentally friendly and reusable.
"We have worked with aboriginal people for a long time. We understand their cultures and needs. World Vision's housing plan is particularly suitable for them," Du went on.
"The housing project will be implemented with a cash-for-work mechanism, so the beneficiaries can participate in the construction of their own homes," he added.
The organization will provide educational aid as well as living subsidies for children affected by the typhoon and will continue to set up "Child Friendly Spaces" for children.

Since the disaster caused by Morakot, World Vision Taiwan has received NT$57.4 million from both individuals and corporations, as well as receiving support from other countries such as the United States, Canada, Hong Kong and Singapore.
Shelter Box, a British charity organization, has donated 324 tents to World Vision through Rotary International to provide additional temporary housing for affected families.
Hsieh Yen-Shen, Rotary International D3480 district governor, said the tents can provide shelter until more stable and permanent houses are constructed.

Moreover, the Swedish government, which currently holds the EU presidency, had also donated 4,600 bottles of water purification drops as a temporary solution to provide storm victims with clean water, Hernes said. A second batch of the drops is scheduled to arrive in the country on Aug. 27, he added.

Roger Valberg, head of the EU team, said that in addition to its daily situation reports, the team will deliver a final report to the EU when it returns to Brussels at the end of the week. On the basis of these reports and briefings, the EU will decide what to do next, he said.

Typhoon Morakot lashed Taiwan Aug.7-9, dumping massive amounts of rain on the southern parts of the country. The storm killed over 160 people, and left 45 injured and nearly 500 unaccounted for. Agricultural losses are estimated at more than NT$ 14.6 billion (US$444 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: Muzha-Neihu MRT line shut down again

TEXT.P: The problematic Muzha-Neihu MRT Line was shut down again Tuesday due to system failure, after a few hours of service following a 56-hour suspension of operations to allow the contractor -- Canadian Bombardier -- to carry out repairs.
A south-bound train ground to a complete halt at 9: 12 a.m. Tuesday as it reached Dazhi Station and did not pull out again until 10 a.m.
Preliminary investigations suggested that the train was stalled because of problems with its brake and propulsion systems, said Taipei City Deputy Secretary-General Tan Gwa-guang.
More than 200 passengers were inconvenienced by the breakdown.
Realizing that the problem could not be fixed right away, the control center announced at 9: 27 a.m. that service on the entire Muzha-Neihu MRT Line will be suspended, according to Tan.
The technicians released the train's automatic driving system, activated its manual system and drove it to the Songshan Airport depot for repairs, he said. Service on the line resumed at 10 a.m.

During the 33-minute suspension, more than 700 people asked for refunds, 429 tickets for free bus rides were distributed and 191 tickets for free MRT rides were given out, according to Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC), the system's operator.
The Neihu Line, built by Canadian Bombardier, has been plagued with problems since it began commercial services July 4 and has been shut down more than 10 times due to system failures.

The new Neihu Line was integrated with the Muzha Line that was built in the 1990s mainly by a French contractor, Matra. Critics have suggested that the project to merge the two lines and integrate the control systems was too ambitious.

The Neihu Line is a medium capacity system that runs on viaducts, except for the section near Taipei Songshan Airport. The 14.8-km line, which cost NT$63.7 billion and took nearly seven years to complete, provides transport services to Taipei's suburban areas of Neihu, Nangang and Muzha.

DOC.HEADLINE: 19 supermarkets and shopping malls in Taiwan vow to save energy

TEXT.P: Representatives of 19 major shopping malls and supermarkets in Taiwan took a vow on Tuesday to cut their store's electricity use by 5 percent in the next three years and reduce carbon dioxide emissions.
Among the 19 enterprises, 12 were shopping malls and seven were supermarkets. Altogether they have 868 franchise stores under them.
According to Yiin Chii-ming, Minister of Ministry of Economic Affairs, an enormous amount of energy and money will be saved if the businesses keep their promise.
If the companies stick to their agreement, 40.72 million kwh of electricity will be saved, which in turn will prevent 26,000 tons of CO2 from being released into the air, Yiin said.

That's 70 times the yearly carbon absorption for Daan Park, Taipei City's largest park, which is 259,293-square meters in size. The energy savings can also create NT$300 million worth of profit for energy-saving businesses, Yiin added.
Yiin was at a ceremony held by the Bureau of Energy at the International Convention Center in National Taiwan University Hospital.
The energy-saving campaign was launched in 2006. Back then, the energy consumption growth rate of the service industry was 4.2 percent, higher than the 3.7 percent in industrial businesses.

Over the past few years, the campaign persuaded different trades to sign an agreement to reduce energy consumption. In the first year, convenience stores signed up, the second year warehouse stores, and the third hospitals, hotels and department stores. This year it was supermarkets and shopping malls.

Previous participants have already reduced energy consumption by a total of 473 million kwh per year, preventing the release of 301,000 tons of CO2, which equals to one year's worth of carbon absorption by Taiwan's Kenting National Park, which is 18,084 hectares in size, Yiin said.

Statistics showed that investments made on energy-saving equipment by participants reached NT$1.8 billion, Yiin said, but the electricity bills they saved in a year amounted to NT$1 billion, which means that within two years, the participants get their money back, proving that energy-saving businesses can be both meaningful and profitable.

The results also show that convenience stores, the first type of business to enter the campaign in 2006, have already reduced 22 percent of their total energy consumption rate, saving 2.9 million kwh of energy and reducing 18,400 tons of CO2 per year, which equals to the yearly carbon absorption of the 28,400-hectare Yangmingshan National Park, an astonishing accomplishment, said Yiin.
The four most energy-efficient convenience stores are Uni-President, FamilyMart, Hi-Life and OK Mart, according to the Bureau of Energy.
The seven supermarkets that participated in the campaign were Pxmart, Wellcome, Matsusei, Taiwan Fresh Supermarket, Tung Kuan, Ken & Kuma and Civil Community Market.
The 12 shopping malls were The Mall, TaiMall, Metro Walk, the Breeze Center, Living Mall, Taichung Central Mall, Tiger City, Taipei 101, SugarMall, Miramar, Global Mall and Dream Mall.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon victims to take part in reconstruction panels

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that representatives of victims of Typhoon Morakot are welcome to take part in reconstruction committees organized by the central government or local authorities, so as to help speed up the process of resettlement and rebuilding.

The president made the remarks during a visit to a reception center temporarily set up by Shunshien Temple in Kaohsiung County's Neimen Village for victims from neighboring Namasia Village, which was devastated by the typhoon earlier this month.
Victims erected banners expressing their demands, such as "We want to participate in reconstruction panels."

Ma had flown to Namasia Village on a helicopter to gain a better understanding of the damage caused by Morakot there. Two out of three towns in Namasia are seriously damaged by mudslide stirred up by the typhoon and are no longer suitable for people to live in.
"Three townships have to be relocated and the complex task must be thoroughly assessed by experts. Residents' willingness and decision must be fully respected," said the president.
Ma urged the victims to swiftly make a decision on which government auxiliary measures they would accept so as to help the government launch all necessary measures as soon as possible.

"The government has put short-term, medium-term and long-term subsidy and housing plans in place to re-settle victims made homeless by Morakot, and it hopes that the victims can quickly choose one option that best serves their interest so as to allow the government to start ensuing projects swiftly," Ma said.

Ma stressed that the government will verify the deceased victims' identities in a looser way and that their affected family members are not obliged to take on any rehabilitation or rehoming projects put forward by the government.
At the reception center, survivors and victims also held up signs saying: "Stop the cross-region water channeling project to the Tsengwen Reservoir."

Many typhoon victims blame the water project for destabilizing the mountains near their villages and causing the deadly mudslides that killed many of their villagers during Typhoon Morakot, the worst typhoon Taiwan has suffered in 50 years.
Ma has promised to investigate their claim.

Minister of National Defense Chen Chao-min, Council of Indigenous Peoples Chairwoman Chang Jen-shiang and Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing were also present. Along with Ma, They bowed to the victims and apologized for the government's much criticized slow response in carrying out rescue and relief operations in the wake of the typhoon.

A bill seeking NT$100 billion for reconstruction is currently being screened by lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan, and the Executive Yuan is set to launch many rehabilitation projects once the bill clears the legislature, Ma added.

According to Yang, 2,000 prefabricated houses are being built in Kaohsiung County to house typhoon victims on a temporary basis, while the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation has promised to construct 1,000 permanent homes for the victims.
Kaohsiung, Taitung, Pingtung and Tainan counties are worst damaged by Typhoon Morakot, which lashed Taiwan from Aug. 7-10. Most of the victims are indigenous residents in mountain townships.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei on guard against swine flu for Deaflympics

TEXT.P: Taipei city government officials said Tuesday that they have made every possible preparation to guard against influenza A(H1N1) next month, when schools open for the new semester and the city will host the international Deaflympics 2009.
Amid reports that the new flu is spreading, city health officials said they have explained the situation to staff of hotels, restaurants, games volunteers and medical stations.
They said the city authorities have also purchased forehead thermometers and will distribute them to hotels to take the temperatures of guests and maintain daily notification with health officials.
Alcohol and antiseptic wipes will also be available at hotels and restaurants, according to the officials.
Sign-language publicity ads will also be aired at public places such as hotels, restaurants and MRT stations to spread the message of H1N1 prevention and control.

"Currently, available resources to fight the disease are abundant, " one health official said, adding that if tests conducted by medical facilities confirm anyone of having contracted A(H1N1) , they will be given Tamiflu, which is covered by national health insurance.
If athletes taking part in the Deaflympics are infected with the H1N1 virus, they will also be given Tamiflu despite not being covered by national insurance, the official added.

All competition venues will have medical stations and will provide assessments to athletes who show flu symptoms. The athletes will be sent to hospitals if necessary and doctors accompanying each team will decide whether they will suspend events as a result.
On the issue of class suspensions after schools open, the officials said they will follow the advice provided by the Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC).

The CECC advises that all schools, kindergartens, cram schools and day care institutions with two or more students in one class who have been diagnosed with A(H1N1) within three days will be closed for five days. Flu victims will only be allowed to return to school 24 hours after the symptoms disappear.
According to statistics provided by the CECC, Taiwan had recorded 70 cases of serious swine flu as of Monday -- 10 in Taipei -- with five fatalities.
The city government will make policy adjustments by keeping tabs on the swine flu situation at home and abroad, following the central government's guidelines.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fitch Ratings gives more optimistic forecast for Taiwan banks

TEXT.P: Fitch Ratings has lowered its forecast of losses by Taiwanese banks for the year, from NT$100 billion to NT$30 billion, citing better-than-expected asset quality maintenance during the global credit crisis.

In a report released Tuesday, the company stated that the banks were able to maintain good asset quality because of multi-year deleveraging by Taiwanese households and corporations before the financial crisis hit in 2008.

Nevertheless, the rating agency warned that the banking sector's large credit exposure to the troubled dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chip makers remains a significant threat to their asset quality over the short and medium term.
Local DRAM chip makers have all been losing money for most of the past year because of oversupply, while demand for chips have declined in the face of the global economic crisis.

Although local banks have done a good job in maintaining their asset quality in the first half of this year, other factors, including Taiwan's persistent economic slump, weak profit margins and high credit costs, could drive down their profits, said Jonathan Lee, senior director of the financial institutions group at Fitch Ratings Taiwan.

Taiwan's banking and financial reform plan may have been postponed because of the sharp economic recession from the fourth quarter of last year and the recent damage caused by Typhoon Morakot, according to Lee.
Over the next two to three years, Taiwan would not likely see mergers of large state-owned banks, Lee predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud Gate announces winners of 2010 Wanderer program

TEXT.P: Cloud Gate Dance Theater, a renowned Taiwanese dance company, announced Tuesday winners of its 2010 Wanderer program, which provides subsidies for budding or experienced artists to travel abroad or to take time off to gain artistic inspiration.
Twelve people from a total of 220 applicants have been selected to participate in the program next year, according to a press release from Cloud Gate Dance Theater.
"Although these wanderers have different backgrounds, they share the same fervent passion to travel to foreign countries and to explore inspirations,the press release said.

The 12 wanderers include Taiwanese opera actress Lee Pei-ying, stage actor Kao Ming-chien, art designer Wu Sheng-lin, theater stage and costume designer Li Huei-lin, social worker Chen Yu-ching and others.

Lee will go to Shaanxi, China to learnQinqiang, one of the oldest Chinese operas. Wu, who owns a free publication called the Lantern, will visit Hong Kong, Shanghai and Tibet to exchange ideas with local youth on independent publishing.
Li will go to Okinawa, Japan to learnbingata, which is a kind traditional resist dyed cloth, made using stencils and other methods, while Chen will study human rights development in Burma.

The 2010 Wanderer program is geared toward budding and professional artists under the age of 35, as well as people under the age of 45 who are involved in social service and have an enthusiasm for literature, music, performance arts, image art or public service.
Winners will be awarded a grant of NT$80,000 to NT$150,000 (US$2,428 to US$4,553), plus return tickets, visa fees and insurance fees for a 60-day trip to China, Japan, Turkey, India or Burma in 2010.
The Wanderer program was initiated in 2004 by Cloud Gate Theater founder Lin Hwai-min and has been sponsored since 2006 by Stan Shih, founder of the laptop- manufacturing giant, the Acer group.
Since then, a total of 53 Taiwanese artists, including this year s 12 winners, have obtained grants under the program.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier to work at reconstruction office in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan will work at a post-Typhoon Morakot reconstruction office in southern Taiwan for one week from Wednesday to coordinate relief and rehabilitation efforts, Government Information Office Minister Su Jun-pin said Tuesday.

Liu will help chiefs and deputy chiefs of government agencies in charge of post- disaster reconstruction work at the office to facilitate the distribution of relief subsidies, resettlement and reconstruction work, according to Su.

The initiative is aimed at providing a platform for Cabinet chiefs and officials to exchange views with residents of areas in southern Taiwan affected by the typhoon on reconstruction-related issues, he added.
The government also hopes to strengthen communication and coordination with displaced victims of the typhoon in terms of resettlement operations, he went on.
The premier will ask relevant agencies to map out plans pertaining to future typhoons and torrential rain in Morakot-affected areas during this year's typhoon season.
He will also preside over an Aug. 27 Cabinet meeting in Taipei as scheduled and will attend other important meetings in Taipei, such as those in relation to A(H1N1) influenza, according to Su.
"In principle, Liu will stay in southern Taiwan but will return to Taipei for important meetings," Su added.

In a related development, Control Yuan President Wang Chien-hsuan said the country's highest watchdog body will release a report in six months on its investigation into who should be held responsible for the administration's flawed response to the typhoon, which killed an estimated 500 people and left hundreds more homeless.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly 40,000 patients infected with swine flu: CDC

TEXT.P: Close to 40,000 people in Taiwan have contracted influenza A(H1N1) since early June, with a majority of them developing only mild symptoms, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yang Chi-liang, who serves as chief of the Central Epidemic Command Center, said Tuesday.

Citing estimates by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the DOH, Yang said about 38,000 people have been infected over the past three months around the country, with some 12,000 getting the virus last week alone.
Yang admitted that the epidemic, widely known as swine flu, is gradually spreading as had been previously forecast, but he added that "it will be OK if patients take medicine early enough."
"Around 70 percent of the people infected with the influenza A(HINI) virus will recover without taking anti-virals, " he noted.
The DOH's top concern at present, Yang went on, is to stave off a massive outbreak of A(H1N1), as it had initially succeeded in stemming the spread of the disease.

According to CDC Director-General Kuo Hsu-sung, there have been only 44 pneumonia cases induced by swine flu in Taiwan. Twenty-two of them have recovered, five have died, five are still in intensive care units and five are in normal wards.

"Swine flu does not necessarily lead to death from pneumonia, " Kuo said, pointing out that last year, Taiwan recorded 8,000 deaths caused by pneumonia, while for last week alone, there were 183 such cases, only two of which were induced by swine flu.

"Compared to the same period of last year, the number of pneumonia deaths linked to swine flu has not markedly increased, but the possibility of further deaths cannot be ruled out for the whole of this year," he added.

Kuo forecast that the first wave of swine flu will hit hard after schools begin the new semester in early September. However, he went on, the impact will be minimized as long as schools follow due procedure to stop classes for five days if "two cases are confirmed in three days in the same class."

Meanwhile, Adimmune Corp., Taiwan's only producer of swine flu vaccine, said it had begun mass production of vaccine and that the first batch of 5 million doses will be ready by the middle of September.
A vaccination program is expected to kick off in mid-November, once the drug's safety can be proven by the authorities, a company manager said.

Meanwhile that day, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said President Ma Ying-jeou had decided not to call a national security meeting for the time being to address the swine flu issue, despite grave public concern that the situation might spiral out of control.

The president made the decision upon the advice of Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, who had discussed the matter with epidemic experts, who assessed that the situation did not merit such a meeting, according to Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: President thanks U.S. for assistance in wake of typhoon

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou thanked the United States Tuesday for its assistance to Taiwan after Typhoon Morakot lashed the country Aug. 7-10.

"The Republic of China government and people wholeheartedly appreciate the United States for its provision of large helicopters which helped transport heavy machinery to disaster areas, " Ma said during a meeting with visiting Oklahoma Governor Brad Henry at the Presidential Office.

Ma also thanked Henry for the support that his state extended to Taiwan, such as favoring Taiwan's participation in world bodies and the idea of Taiwan signing a free trade agreement with the United States.
It was Henry's first visit to Taiwan since he assumed office in 2003. Taiwan Province and the state of Oklahoma will celebrate their 30th anniversary of sisterhood ties next year.
Typhoon Morakot had killed 292 people, with another 385 missing, mostly residents buried by a landslide in Siaolin village, Kaohsiung County, according to official estimates.
The typhoon also caused tens of billions of dollars-worth of losses in the agricultural, livestock and fish farming sectors, sending local prices of vegetables, fruit, fish and meat soaring.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Morakot rise to NT$15.8 billion

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Morakot had surged to NT$15.81 billion (US$540.55 million) as of Tuesday, according to statistics released that day by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).

The COA said that Morakot, which pummeled Taiwan Aug. 7-9, caused serious damage to the agricultural sector in 11 counties, with Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties in southern Taiwan and Hualien and Taitung counties in the east the hardest hit.
The statistics show that damage to crops had amounted to NT$4.47 billion, with 27 percent of the crops on 74,997 hectares of farmland wiped out.

Bananas suffered the heaviest damage, with 6,307 hectares ravaged by strong winds and flooding, followed by papayas, guavas, rice, bamboo shoots, orchids, custard apples and leafy vegetables. Bee losses amounted to NT$6.9 million.
Over 148,273 pigs, nearly 6.11 million chickens and around 1.54 million ducks perished in floods caused by the storm, bringing the total livestock losses to NT$1.48 billion, the COA said.

Damage to the aquaculture sector had amounted to NT$4.17 billion, the heaviest loss in 19 years, according to the statistics, with stock in some 9,162 hectares of fishponds or coastal areas washed away, it said.
Over 2,512 hectares of forestry was destroyed, while damage to all agricultural and fishery facilities amounted to NT$5.44 billion.
Damage to the fishery sector had surpassed NT$488 million, with the worst damage reported in Tainan City and Pingtung County.

The tallies also show that a total of 5,140 hectares of farmland had been either washed away or inundated, mostly in Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Chiayi counties, bringing the total losses in this respect to NT$4.58 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Future of Muzha-Neihu MRT line under evaluation: mayor

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Tuesday that the city government will decide whether to shut down the problematic Muzha-Neihu MRT line indefinitely after an inspection and repair program over the weekend.
The new line, which began commercial services July 4, has been a source of embarrassment to the Taipei city government, with constant shutdowns due to system failures.

A 56-hour suspension of operations last weekend for inspection and repair apparently failed to guarantee a smooth return to service, when a southbound train ground to a complete halt during rush hour Tuesday morning.
Replying to press inquiries regarding the latest half-hour shutdown, Hau said that problems with the brake and propulsion systems on one section caused the breakdown.

The Muzha-Neihu MRT line has been suspended twice over previous weekends for inspection and repair following numerous breakdowns. The contractor, Canada's Bombardier, will conduct another thorough inspection this coming weekend.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Vision announces rehabilitation plans for typhoon victims

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese chapter of the Christian charity World Vision said Tuesday that it will invest over NT$1.2 billion (US$36.5 million) in emergency relief and rehabilitation programs in the wake of Typhoon Morakot.

Hank Du, executive director of World Vision Taiwan, made the announcement at a news conference that same day in which he gave an update on the organization's relief operations in the storm-stricken areas and announced long-term rehabilitation plans to help the affected people return to normal life as soon as possible.

Noting that World Vision Taiwan plans to build 1,200 temporary homes for the storm victims in Taitung, Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Chiayi counties, Du said the temporary homes can be easily assembled by untrained personnel with simple hand tools and that once the land is ready, these homes can be completed in two or three weeks.
The homes will be made of different local materials such as bamboo and slate, Du went on, adding that the construction materials are light, environmentally friendly and reusable.
"We have worked with aboriginal people for a long time. We understand their cultures and needs. World Vision's housing plan is particularly suitable for them," Du went on.
"The housing project will be implemented with a cash-for-work mechanism, so the beneficiaries can participate in the construction of their own homes," he added.
The organization will provide educational aid as well as living subsidies for children affected by the typhoon and will continue to set up "Child Friendly Spaces" for children.

Since the disaster caused by Morakot, World Vision Taiwan has received NT$57.4 million from both individuals and corporations, as well as receiving support from other countries such as the United States, Canada, Hong Kong and Singapore.
Shelter Box, a British charity organization, has donated 324 tents to World Vision through Rotary International to provide additional temporary housing for affected families.
Hsieh Yen-Shen, Rotary International D3480 district governor, said the tents can provide shelter until more stable and permanent houses are constructed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 26, or the seventh day of the seventh month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1789: The French Assembly adopts the Declaration of the Rights of Man.
1850: Louis Philippe, the "Citizen King" of France who abdicated rather than face a middle-class revolt, dies.
1858: Britain and Japan sign the Treaty of Edo (Tokyo), opening up Japan to British trade.
1873: Lee De Forest, American radio and television pioneer and inventor of the Audion vacuum tube, which made broadcasting possible, is born.
1906: Albert Bruce Sabin, American microbiologist and physician, is born in Poland. He developed a live-virus vaccine against polio in 1957, replacing the killed-virus vaccine invented by Jonas Salk.
1910: American physicians verify that the X-ray, discovered in 1895 by German physicist Wilhelm C. Roentgen, can help detect lung disease.
1920: The US legislature ratifies the 19th Amendment, giving American women the right to vote.
1926: Warner Brothers, an American movie company, is successful with its premiere sound picture.
1936: Egypt and Great Britain agree to a treaty that reaffirms Egypt's independence. This treaty also reduces the number of British troops stationed in Egypt and restricts them to the Suez Canal region.
1952: The Soviet Unions announces that the first successful Intercontinental Ballistic Missile (ICBM) tests have taken place.
1961: Burma becomes the world's first Buddhist republic.
1972: Sir Francis Chichester, English yachtsman who was the first senior citizen to sail around the world alone in his 53-foot yacht in 1966, dies at the age of 71.
1974: Charles Lindbergh, American aviator who made the first solo non-stop flight across Atlantic in 1927, dies at the age of 72.
1977: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo receives Richard Holbrooke, US assistant secretary of state for Asian and Pacific affairs, at the Executive Yuan for a briefing on Secretary of State Cyrus Vance's trip to Peking.
1978: Cardinal Albino Luciani of Venice is elected as Pope John Paul I. He died of a heart attack on Sept. 28.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo decorates visiting vice president of the Republic of Costa Rica Jose Miguel Alfaro Rodriguez with the Order of the Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon.
1987: A sex-crazed elephant "urgently in search of a mate" runs amuck in Bangkok, killing two people and flattening a radio center.
1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin signs a friendship treaty with the Czech Republic after condemning the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.
1996: Prince Charles, the heir to the British throne, formally divorces Princess Diana Frances Spencer, ending 15 years of marriage.
1996: A court in Seoul sentences former President Chun Doo Hwan to death on charges of masterminding a 1979 coup and his successor, Roh Tae Woo, is sentenced to 22 years and six months in prison for playing a supporting role. Their prison terms were reduced later.
2001: Seven Democratic members of the U.S. House of Representatives write a letter to State Secretary Madeleine Albright, requesting that the State Department "take the necessary steps to end the inappropriate ban on high-level visits between elected Taiwanese officials and U.S. officials, including the democratically-elected president of Taiwan."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who possesses exceedingly great moral qualities will certainly receive the divine call to the Imperial throne."
