DOC.HEADLINE: Will Taiwan's defense outpost become casino hub?

TEXT.P: Residents on Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen may soon go to the polls to decide whether the defense outpost could turn into a casino hub.

That prospect became more likely Thursday, with an activist filing a petition with the Kinmen county government to hold a referendum on whether to legalize gaming on the island and allow the establishment of tourist casinos.

Kinmen, composed of 12 islets, lies closer to China's southeastern province of Fujian than to Taiwan proper. It used to be Taiwan's froneline island against China and in the late 50s and early 60s was the target of intense shelling by Communist China.
With cross-strait ties improving, the number of troops stationed there has significantly decreased and tourism has become the backbone of its economic activities.

Chen Chang-chiang, head of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) Kinmen chapter, filed the petition in his capacity as convener of the organizing committee of a Kinmen County tourism industry promotion association.
To back his petition, Chen also produced 460 signatures endorsing the proposal.

"According to the Referendum Act, the casino referendum petition needs formal endorsement by at least 0.5 percent of eligible voters in the county's last magistrate election, namely at least 354 signatures, " Chen said, adding that the number of signatures collected by the association is well over that threshold.
A county government official received the petition along with signatures from Chen and promised to pass them to the Kinmen County Election Commission for processing.
If the petition passes the screening, Chen's association will then launch the second stage of signature campaign to qualify for putting the proposal to a referendum.

Stressing that he is petitioning for the referendum in his private capacity, Chen said the move has nothing to do with his party's position. The DPP is known to oppose legalizing casinos on outlying islands.
Chen also argued that his petition does not necessarily imply his personal support for the proposal.

"My move just signifies my belief that the issue should be determined by the majority of local residents instead by a few politicians' personal stance or ideology, " Chen said, claiming that the county government and the county council have been reluctant to address the issue.
Gambling has long been banned in Taiwan, but the Legislative Yuan passed legislation on Jan. 12 to legalize casino gambling on outlying islands.
The offshore county of Penghu is scheduled to hold a referendum on whether to allow casinos to be built there on Sept. 26.
Chen said that although Kinmen lagged behind Penghu in launching the drive, his association managed to collect the more-than-required-number of endorsements in just three days.
"The promptness indicates that local residents do not reject the proposal to permit the establishment of tourist casinos, " Chen contended.

According to Chen, Lawrence Ho, the son of Macau gaming business tycoon Stanley Ho, toured Kinmen on Aug. 7 to get a sense of the county's business environment and expressed keen interest in tapping the market.

"It is generally believed that Kinmen residents will approve the casino business if a referendum is held, " Chen argued. "Given a fast thawing in relations across the Taiwan Strait, it seems to me that Kinmen stands a better chance than Penghu to operate tourist casino businesses."

DOC.HEADLINE: Dalai Lama to visit Siaolin, Linbian villages

TEXT.P: Tibet's spiritual leader the Dalai Lama will arrive in Taiwan for a six-day visit Aug. 30 and will travel to two villages hit hard by Typhoon Morakot to comfort the victims, the Kaohsiung city government confirmed Thursday.

City officials have begun arranging the Dalai Lama's itinerary while he is in Taiwan, and he is expected to head for some of the worst-hit disaster areas in southern Taiwan, including Siaolin village in Kaohsiung County and Linbian Township in neighboring Pingtung County, Sept. 1 and Sept. 2.

The two villages, particularly Siaolin village, were devastated by Morakok, which lashed southern Taiwan Aug. 7-10. Chiayi, Kaohsiung, Pingtung and Taitung counties suffered the most damage from the storm.

According to the Central Emergency Operation Center, the death toll from the disaster had reached 461, with 192 others reported missing and 46 injured, as of Tuesday. Many of the dead and missing are residents believed to have been buried under mudslides in Siaolin village.
The Kaohsiung city government is also hoping that the Dalai Lama will give a speech at the Kaohsiung Arena and hold an international news conference in the city during his three-day stay.

In bid to give moral support to the typhoon victims, the Dalai Lama agreed to travel to Taiwan and pray for them, responding to an invitation jointly issued by seven city majors and county magistrates in southern Taiwan, all of whom are members of Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Citing "humanitarian" and "religious" considerations, the central government in Taipei approved the Dalai Lama's proposed visit to Taiwan earlier that same day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourism industry suffers from Morakot aftermath

TEXT.P: While Typhoon Morakot triggered flooding and landslides had demolished a small percentage of Taiwan's scenic spots, the tourism industry is anticipating an even worse scenario of a sharp decline of tourist arrivals from abroad and a slumping market for domestic travel, a tourism official said Thursday.

Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai said international tourist arrivals from August to October could drop by 10 percent from the level of the same period of last year, leading to industry losses of up to NT$2.7 billion (US$84.4 million).

As many tour groups from China have canceled trips to Taiwan in the wake of the worst flooding in 50 years in some southern areas of the country, only an average of 700 Chinese tourists are expected each day in the coming weeks, a drastic decline from the daily average of 2,000 at the end of July.
Lai said the bureau has contacted travel businesses in China, suggesting that they can still design impressive tour packages, since most of the tourist attractions remain intact.
Although the iconic mountain resort of Alishan was seriously damaged by floods and mudslides, there are many other mountainous scenic spots in central Taiwan worth seeing, she added.
As the nation mourns the dead and works on rehabilitation and reconstruction, people's interest in domestic travel has also declined.
The bureau said that with the number of domestic tourists down by 15 percent in August compared with the same month of the previous year, the tourism industry will lose another NT$5.9 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Youth from Taiwan, China search for love on Kinmen

TEXT.P: To love and be loved. That is the common wish of more than 300 single young men and women from Taiwan and China who together marked the inauguration of the statue of a traditional Chinese matchmaker Thursday on Taiwan's outlying county of Kinmen.

The young people jointly witnessed the inauguration of the statue of Yueh Lau -- an elderly and kind male matchmaker of Chinese folklore with a white beard -- in one of a series of romantic activities to mark Chinese Lover's Day, which fell on Aug. 26 this year.
Over 200 Chinese youths from the city of Xiamen in Fujian Province sailed to Kinmen a day earlier to take part in the activities sponsored by the authorities on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng and a variety of Chinese guests, including Ma Zhenlin, chief of the Hai Xia Dao Bao -- a Xiamen-based newspaper -- expressed hope that the young lovers will soon find eternal love with their Mr. or Miss Right.

On Kinmen Island's Shiapu beach, where the statue has been erected, the lovers competed to snatch a piece of red thread from Yueh Lau as a gesture of being blessed by the matchmaker. They also hung cards inscribed with their most sincerest hopes from surrounding trees in a gesture designed to fulfill their sweetest dreams.

Lee and Ma also planted symbolic trees and flowers to represent their county and city on the seashore as testimony to the pursuit of everlasting love by the young people who took part in the festivities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government takes steps to prevent H1N1 epidemic

TEXT.P: The Taipei County Public Health Bureau held a drill Thursday in an effort to perfect the process of quickly identifying, testing and treating students with flu-like symptoms, as part of a campaign to prevent an outbreak of influenza A (H1N1) after schools reopen on Friday.
The drill, held at Wende Elementary School, simulated a situation in which the school nurse confirmed that a student had a fever and had to be taken immediately to Taipei County Public Health Center.

After the student arrived at the health center, nose and throat swabs were immediately taken and a doctor was able to determine within five minutes whether or not the student was infected with the H1N1 virus.
In an actual situation, if a student tests positive for the H1N1 virus, he or she will be given medication and sent home to rest for five days, or hospitalized if the symptoms are serious.

In order to effectively monitor the spread of the virus, the Taipei City Government's Department of Education will supply all public schools with ear thermometers -- one for every three classes -- and students will be required to have their temperatures taken every day.

According to Lin Guo-ning, an official at the Centers for Disease Control, these measures are being introduced to make good use of the precious time before a massive A(H1N1) outbreak occurs, as has been predicted.

The Centers for Disease Control has also stipulated that if two students in a class are diagnosed with H1N1 within three days, the whole class must be suspended for five days in order to prevent cluster infections, Lin said.

However, according to the head of the Kaohsiung County Government Health Bureau, five days of suspension might not be enough to alleviate the risk. Other countries tend to stipulate seven days in such situations, he noted.
He also pointed out that it would be difficult to isolate students who are housed in emergency shelters in areas devastated by Typhoon Morakot, if they contract the H1N1 virus.

For example, the 120 students of Baolai Junior High School in Liugui Township -- one of the 18 schools completely destroyed by Typhoon Morakot earlier this month -- are now housed at an Iguan Dao Temple where they all eat, sleep and take classes, he said.

The Department of Health has given priority to typhoon victims, medical workers, pregnant women and children below high school level for H1N1 inoculation when 10,000,000 doses of the new vaccine become available in mid-November.
However, experts have predicted that the vaccination campaign will come too late to prevent an H1N1 epidemic.
The Centers for Disease Control has estimated that there are 15,000 new cases of H1N1 influenza cases every week, and the number is predicted to increase when the new school semester starts.
The predictions put the number of H1N1 infections at a peak of 7,000,000, with a conservative death count of 7,000.
H1N1 symptoms include cough, nasal congestion, nausea or vomiting, diarrhea, body aches, joint pains, fever, sore throat, headache, fatigue and loss of energy.
Antiviral drugs such as Tamiflu, if taken within 48 hours of the onset of H1N1 symptoms, can give some relief and reduce the period of illness by about a day.
Tamiflu prescriptions for those who have been diagnosed with the H1N1 virus are now covered by National Health Insurance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Post-disaster reconstruction bill clears Legislature

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an urgent special statute Thursday authorizing the executive branch to raise a special budget of up to NT$120 billion (US$3.64 billion) for reconstruction in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot.
The statute also calls for the establishment of a reconstruction commission to lead and guide relevant work, with the premier and vice premier serving as its head and deputy head.
It further stipulates that the number of those who represent affected residents and aboriginal tribesmen should not be less than one-fifth of the commission's complete roster.

Morakot pummeled Taiwan Aug. 7-9, triggering the worst flooding in 50 years in certain places in southern Taiwan and leading to landslides that buried remote mountainous villages and tribal settlements.
The special statute authorizes governments at all levels to impose compulsory relocation of villages or tribal settlements from areas vulnerable to floods and landslides to safer areas.
The ruling Kuomintang-controlled Legislature completed a third reading of the bill at the conclusion of a three-day extraordinary screening session.

The Executive Yuan originally planned to raise a special budget of NT$100 billion to finance various reconstruction projects, but the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) proposed that the fund be increased to NT$200 billion. The KMT also came up with a proposal that funding should be capped at NT$120 billion.

The KMT proposal prevailed. The method of fundraising was also changed to the floating of state bonds or borrowing instead of selling government stakes in state-run banks as had been proposed by the Cabinet.
As the outstanding government debts are approaching the legal ceiling, the statute exempts the government from restrictions set forth in the Public Debt Law in this respect.
Regarding mortgage balances on houses rendered uninhabitable or washed away during the storm's onslaught, the statute stipulates that lending banks should absorb all such losses.

Financial institutions should also exempt borrowers from having to repay outstanding mortgages on farmland and aquaculture ponds destroyed or washed away during the storm, with the government offering them subsidies equivalent to a maximum 80 percent of the total amount.

On relocation of the hardest-hit villages and tribal settlements, the statute prescribes that central and local governments should consult with residents to reach a consensus on resettlement or relocation. No flood- and landslide-prone areas should be available for habitation any longer.

The statute also stipulates that land development and rezoning in selected sites that have passed environmental impact assessments will not be subject to restrictions imposed by existing urban planning laws or regulations.

During the legislative screening process, some representatives from Namasia township in Kaohsiung County -- one of the hardest-hit disaster zones -- voiced strong opposition to the compulsory relocation regulation, but were bundled out of the conference hall by policemen and security guards.

The legislature also passed a resolution demanding that the Executive Yuan submit a draft package within one month on national land protection and restoration, as years of rampant overdevelopment of mountain slopelands and river catchment areas have made many parts of Taiwan vulnerable to landslides and mudslides.
The resolution also demands that the central government set up service centers in various typhoon-affected areas to offer mental health counseling as well as employment and education services.

In terms of driftwood cleanup, the resolution stipulates that a week after the implementation of the special statute, typhoon victims should be allowed to pick up driftwood that the Council of Agriculture has not already marked.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet screening committee rejects DPP initiated ECFA referendum

"The ratio is still below the 40 percent ceiling set forth in the Public Debt Law," Tseng noted.

He also discounted a media report that the government's debts have exceeded NT$10 trillion. "The report is misleading and erroneous," he said, adding that the report used a calculation method far different from the ones usually adopted in the international community.
Compared with many other countries, he said, the government's debts remain within a normal range.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC welcomes Dalai Lama's upcoming visit

TEXT.P: The Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, is welcome to visit Taiwan, as his visit will provide spiritual support for survivors of the devastating Typhoon Morakot, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Thursday.
"Religious belief can help disaster survivors to get back on track and the Dalai Lama's visit will help rest the soul of the dead and comfort the survivors," said MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun.
Stressing that the government has approved the Dalai Lama's visit on humanitarian and religious stances, Liu said the event is not expected to adversely affect relations across the Taiwan Strait.
The exiled Tibetan spiritual leader is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Aug.30 for a six-day visit at the invitation of seven southern Taiwan local government heads.
He will head for some of the worst-hit disaster areas in southern Taiwan, including Siaolin village in Kaohsiung County and Linbian Township in neighboring Pingtung County, Sept. 1 and Sept. 2.
The storm claimed more than 600 lives when it lashed Taiwan Aug.7-9.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government takes steps to prevent H1N1 epidemic

TEXT.P: The Taipei County Public Health Bureau held a drill Thursday in an effort to perfect the process of quickly identifying, testing and treating students with flu-like symptoms, as part of a campaign to prevent an outbreak of influenza A (H1N1) after schools reopen on Friday.
The drill, held at Wende Elementary School, simulated a situation in which the school nurse confirmed that a student had a fever and had to be taken immediately to Taipei County Public Health Center.

After the student arrived at the health center, nose and throat swabs were immediately taken and a doctor was able to determine within five minutes whether or not the student was infected with the H1N1 virus.
In an actual situation, if a student tests positive for the H1N1 virus, he or she will be given medication and sent home to rest for five days, or hospitalized if the symptoms are serious.

In order to effectively monitor the spread of the virus, the Taipei City Government's Department of Education will supply all public schools with ear thermometers -- one for every three classes -- and students will be required to have their temperatures taken every day.

According to Lin Guo-ning, an official at the Centers for Disease Control, these measures are being introduced to make good use of the precious time before a massive A(H1N1) outbreak occurs, as has been predicted.

The Centers for Disease Control has also stipulated that if two students in a class are diagnosed with H1N1 within three days, the whole class must be suspended for five days in order to prevent cluster infections, Lin said.

However, according to the head of the Kaohsiung County Government Health Bureau, five days of suspension might not be enough to alleviate the risk. Other countries tend to stipulate seven days in such situations, he noted.
He also pointed out that it would be difficult to isolate students who are housed in emergency shelters in areas devastated by Typhoon Morakot, if they contract the H1N1 virus.

For example, the 120 students of Baolai Junior High School in Liugui Township -- one of the 18 schools completely destroyed by Typhoon Morakot earlier this month -- are now housed at an Iguan Dao Temple where they all eat, sleep and take classes, he said.

The Department of Health has given priority to typhoon victims, medical workers, pregnant women and children below high school level for H1N1 inoculation when 10,000,000 doses of the new vaccine become available in mid-November.
However, experts have predicted that the vaccination campaign will come too late to prevent an H1N1 epidemic.
The Centers for Disease Control has estimated that there are 15,000 new cases of H1N1 influenza cases every week, and the number is predicted to increase when the new school semester starts.
The predictions put the number of H1N1 infections at a peak of 7,000,000, with a conservative death count of 7,000.
H1N1 symptoms include cough, nasal congestion, nausea or vomiting, diarrhea, body aches, joint pains, fever, sore throat, headache, fatigue and loss of energy.
Antiviral drugs such as Tamiflu, if taken within 48 hours of the onset of H1N1 symptoms, can give some relief and reduce the period of illness by about a day.
Tamiflu prescriptions for those who have been diagnosed with the H1N1 virus are now covered by National Health Insurance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Post-disaster reconstruction bill clears Legislature

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an urgent special statute Thursday authorizing the executive branch to raise a special budget of up to NT$120 billion (US$3.64 billion) for reconstruction in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot.
The statute also calls for the establishment of a reconstruction commission to lead and guide relevant work, with the premier and vice premier serving as its head and deputy head.
It further stipulates that the number of those who represent affected residents and aboriginal tribesmen should not be less than one-fifth of the commission's complete roster.

Morakot pummeled Taiwan Aug. 7-9, triggering the worst flooding in 50 years in certain places in southern Taiwan and leading to landslides that buried remote mountainous villages and tribal settlements.
The special statute authorizes governments at all levels to impose compulsory relocation of villages or tribal settlements from areas vulnerable to floods and landslides to safer areas.
The ruling Kuomintang-controlled Legislature completed a third reading of the bill at the conclusion of a three-day extraordinary screening session.

The Executive Yuan originally planned to raise a special budget of NT$100 billion to finance various reconstruction projects, but the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) proposed that the fund be increased to NT$200 billion. The KMT also came up with a proposal that funding should be capped at NT$120 billion.

The KMT proposal prevailed. The method of fundraising was also changed to the floating of state bonds or borrowing instead of selling government stakes in state-run banks as had been proposed by the Cabinet.
As the outstanding government debts are approaching the legal ceiling, the statute exempts the government from restrictions set forth in the Public Debt Law in this respect.
Regarding mortgage balances on houses rendered uninhabitable or washed away during the storm's onslaught, the statute stipulates that lending banks should absorb all such losses.

Financial institutions should also exempt borrowers from having to repay outstanding mortgages on farmland and aquaculture ponds destroyed or washed away during the storm, with the government offering them subsidies equivalent to a maximum 80 percent of the total amount.

On relocation of the hardest-hit villages and tribal settlements, the statute prescribes that central and local governments should consult with residents to reach a consensus on resettlement or relocation. No flood- and landslide-prone areas should be available for habitation any longer.

The statute also stipulates that land development and rezoning in selected sites that have passed environmental impact assessments will not be subject to restrictions imposed by existing urban planning laws or regulations.

During the legislative screening process, some representatives from Namasia township in Kaohsiung County -- one of the hardest-hit disaster zones -- voiced strong opposition to the compulsory relocation regulation, but were bundled out of the conference hall by policemen and security guards.

The legislature also passed a resolution demanding that the Executive Yuan submit a draft package within one month on national land protection and restoration, as years of rampant overdevelopment of mountain slopelands and river catchment areas have made many parts of Taiwan vulnerable to landslides and mudslides.
The resolution also demands that the central government set up service centers in various typhoon-affected areas to offer mental health counseling as well as employment and education services.

In terms of driftwood cleanup, the resolution stipulates that a week after the implementation of the special statute, typhoon victims should be allowed to pick up driftwood that the Council of Agriculture has not already marked.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet screening committee rejects DPP initiated ECFA referendum

TEXT.P: The Referendum Screening Committee under the Executive Yuan rejected an opposition Democratic Progressive Party-initiated proposal to hold a referendum on the signing of a Taiwan-China economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

Only 19 of the 21-member committee were present, and a majority 13 members voted to reject the proposal on the grounds that it is based on a hypothetical situation that does not meet the criteria of the Referendum Law. Four voted in favor and two abstained.
The DPP had hoped to have the nation's voters answer the question: "Do you agree that the government should hold a referendum to allow the people to decide on the signing of a Taiwan-China ECFA?"
Committee Chairman Chao Yung-mao commented that the referendum proposal was ambiguous and based on something that has not actually happened.

The proposed ECFA advocated by President Ma Ying-jeou is aimed at protecting Taiwan from being marginalized as countries in the Asia-Pacific region, including China, Japan, South Korea and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, are in the process of economic integration through the signing of free trade agreements.
So far, the ECFA proposal has not been put on the table for negotiation, although the administration is expected to start cross-strait negotiations on the issue by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese procurement mission places US$3.87 billion in orders

TEXT.P: A Chinese procurement mission placed US$3.87 billion worth of orders with Taiwanese companies Monday, part of China's attempt to help stimulate Taiwan's battered economy.

The biggest share of the orders were placed by China's biggest personal computer maker Lenovo Group, which intends to buy US$3.255 billion worth of information technology products from Taiwan, including notebooks and electronic items.

A joint contract signing ceremony took place at the Taipei International Convention Center, with Wang Chih-kang, chairman of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) and Tang Wei, vice president of the Association of Economy and Trade Across the Taiwan Straits (AETATS), in attendance.

The group, which arrived in Taiwan Aug. 19, was the third AETATS-organized procurement mission to Taiwan so far this year. It is composed of some 100 senior executives representating 47 Chinese business groups.
According to Wang, the three AETATS-organized missions have so far placed a total of US$5.476 billion worth of orders with local suppliers.
The AETATS, an affiliate of China's Ministry of Commerce, is tasked with promoting commercial exchanges and economic cooperation with Taiwan.

The three groups are expected to place an additional US$3.144 billion worth of orders with Taiwanese manufacturers in the coming year, bringing the total to US$8.62 billion, which Wang said would exceed the original target without being more specific.
He denied that the total order value of the three buying missions had "shrunk," as has been speculated.

In addition to Lenovo Group's purchase of information technology products, other goods purchased by the third AETATS group also included machinery, chemical engineering equipment, garments, footwear and auto parts and components in line with China's "automobiles to the countryside" project that is part of its economic stimulus package.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 28, or the ninth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1640: The Scots defeat royalist English forces at the Battle of Newburn, near Newcastle.
1774: Elizabeth Ann Seton, American educator and religious leader who founded the Sisters of St. Joseph, is born. She was canonized as the first US-born saint in 1975.
1828: Lev Nikolayevich Tolstoy, also known as Count Leo Tolstoi, Russian writer and philosopher, is born. His great novels "War and Peace" and "Anna Karenina" offer extraordinary detail and profound psychological insights. His later theories of ethics and morality recommended non-participation in and passive resistance to evil.
1830: Peter Cooper, American inventor who built the first American locomotive, displays his latest creation, a steam-driven locomotive called Tom Thumb.
1849: Venice surrenders to the Australians, having been under siege since July 20 after proclaiming independence from Austrian rule.
1884: Peter Fraser, prime minister of New Zealand from 1940 to 1949 , is born in Scotland.
1910: Montenegro proclaims independence from the Ottoman empire.
1916: Germany declares war on Romania.
1919, Sir Godfrey Hounsfield, British inventor of the EMI medical scanner, is born. He was winner of the Nobel Prize for Psychology in 1979.
1927: The Eighth Far East Games is held in Shanghai.
1929: The Kuomintang (KMT) branch in Shanghai asks the Nanking government to punish Professor Hu Shih, a former student of John Dewey, for publishing an article criticizing Dr. Sun Yat-sen and the KMT.
1931: The Mexican government orders all ethnic Chinese to leave Mexico before Sept. 2.
1945: Mao Tse-tung, accompanied by US Ambassador Patrick Hurley, arrives in Chungking from Yenan to hold a meeting with the KMT to discuss such issues as national unity.
1963: US civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. delivers his "I have a dream" speech to some 200,000 people after an interracial march on Washington, a peaceful demonstration in favor of furthering the cause of civil rights.
1973: Princess Anne arrives in Kiev for an equestrian event, becoming the first member of the British royal family to visit the Soviet Union.
1974: The Republic of China and Thailand conclude a maize trade agreement.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Bolivian Vice Foreign Minister Hernando Garcia Vespa and his wife.
1980: Premier Y.S. Sun leaves for Costa Rica, Panama and the Dominican Republic for official visits.
1983: Menachem Begin resigns as prime minister of Israel.
1988: Three jet planes belonging to an Italian Air Force aeronautics display team collide during an exhibition in front of a crowd of 300,000 at the US Air Force base at Ramstein in West Germany, killing 47 people and injuring some 500 others.
1990: Iraq declares Kuwait the 19th province of Iraq.
1993: Ong Teng Cheong, chairman of the ruling People's Action Party, is elected president of Singapore.
1996: El Salvador President Armando Calderon Sol visits the Republic of China.
1999: The ruling Kuomintang convenes the second plenary session of its 15th National Congress to formally approve Lien Chan and Vincent Siew as the party's nominees for the 2000 presidential election of the Republic of China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Like the rush of mighty waters, the presence of unseen powers is felt -- sometimes above us, sometimes around us. Such is the evidence of things invisible that it is impossible to doubt the spiritual nature of man."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Chiang Kai-shek's diaries to be published in Taiwan in 2010
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/28/09 15:05:31 (By Chiao Hsing-hua and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The diaries of the late Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek are expected to be published, almost in their entirety, in Taiwan in 2010, a relative of the Chiang family has revealed in a recent interview with a Chinese newspaper.

Soong Tsao Li-hsuan, wife of a nephew of the late Madame Chiang Kai-shek, told the Shanghai Morning Post Thursday that the diary collection comprises 55 volumes that cover a 55-year period from 1917 to 1972.
The full content of the diaries will go to print, with the exception of a small number of passages that the family has decided will remain private, Soong said.

Soong, who has been helping to screen the diaries at Stanford University's Hoover Institution, where the original copies are deposited, was in Shanghai to attend a symposium held by Fudan University on the life of T.V. Soong, a brother of Madame Chiang who served as finance minister and as foreign affairs minister of the ROC.
Soong said Chiang, who died in 1975, left his diaries to his son, the late ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo, who in turn passed them to his third son Chiang Hsiao-yung before his death in 1988.
Chiang Hsiao-yung kept the diaries until his own death in 1996, after which his widow, Elizabeth Chiang, took over the job of looking after them, she went on.
In 2004, however, she decided to send the documents to the Hoover Institution for preservation, Soong said.

The diaries, which were written using a calligraphy pen, were in poor condition when they arrived at the institution, with many pages stuck together, according to Soong, who added that the institution spent around two years and approximately US$3 million handling the papers.

Copies of the originals, with some redacted passages, have been made available at the Hoover Archives in various batches since 2006, attracting a large number of scholars from different countries seeking to conduct research into their contents.
However, as readers are forbidden from making copies and can only take notes, some of the scholars have made mistakes in reference to the diaries, causing confusion of historical facts, Soong noted.
In light of this situation, the Chiang family agreed to publish the diaries to ensure a truthful presentation of history, she explained.
According to Soong, some passages of the diaries were redacted mainly out of privacy concerns and will also not appear in the published versions.
The family, however, has authorized that the redacted passages can be published in 2035, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Friday:
Apple Daily:
Political parties on both sides of the strait, please be merciful

The chiefs of local governments controlled by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) extended an invitation to Tibet's spiritual leader the Dalai Lama to visit Taiwan to console local flood victims, and President Ma Ying-jeou approved, but with the string attached that the Dalai Lama should not engage in any political activities while here.
Ma deserves applause for his decision, as it demonstrates that humanitarianism and mercy are beyond politics.
Ma has disaffected voters by botching the relief operation after Typhoon Morakot and would be sure to plunge into an abyss by denying the Dalai Lama's visit.
Beijing has put Ma's administration in a hot spot by opposing the decision, and the DPP is gleeful at the sale of its trick to alienate Taipei and Beijing.
We urge all political parties involved to put aside their political designs and to be sympathetic with the flood victims.
Liberty Times:
Give the Dalai Lama freedom to act in Taiwan
President Ma Ying-jeou has approved a visit to Taiwan by Tibet's spiritual leader the Dalai Lama but has limited him to engage in only humanitarian or religious acts.
Taiwan is a state with full sovereignty and Ma has no reason to attach any strings to the Dalai Lama's visit.
As a pacifist, the Dalai Lama should be given full freedom to act, and as leader of the exiled Tibetan government, he should be allowed to promote whatever political beliefs he fosters.
On the other hand, if Ma wants to underline his capacity as head of state, he should meet the Dalai Lama officially at his office rather than at religious prayer gatherings or any other occasions.
China Times:
Our opinion on Dalai Lama's visit -- Treasuring the thawing ties with China, praying for the flood victims
The chiefs of seven DPP-controlled counties and cities huddled the day before yesterday over the handling of the aftermath of the Typhoon Morakot.
To our surprise, their resolution was to invite Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama to visit Taiwan rather than finding ways to deal with the mudslides and mountains of dirt left by the flooding.

They should know that among the victims, the aboriginals are mainly Christian, while the Taiwanese are mainly followers of Taoism, only a few of them are Buddhists, and still fewer are followers of Tibetan Buddhism.

Who will believe these local leaders' claims that their request is not political maneuvering aimed to cause more trouble for President Ma Ying-jeou when he is occupied with the task of reconstruction.
We are surprised by the DPP's decision to kick up a political controversy at this time.

Everybody know this will damage the country's hard-earned closer ties with China, and that Ma, with his popularity having dipped to a nadir at home, has had to agree to the DPP chiefs' request to prevent voters from deserting him.

Beijing has gone out of its way to help Taiwan ever since the disaster caused by Typhoon Morakot, but its attempts have failed to draw a response as favorable as that received by Taiwan when it went to the aid of Chinese victims after the Sichuan earthquake in 2008.
Now that Taiwan has requited Beijing's bona fide overtures with an invitation to the Dalai Lama, Beijing's anger can be understood.
So we have to urge China to refrain from a drastic response to the Taiwan's decision, and we urge Ma's administration to go out of its way to mend fences with China.
We also urge the DPP and the ruling Kuomintang to play down the issue of whether Ma should meet with the Dalai Lama during his visit.
United Daily News:
Inappropriate time for Dalai Lama's visit
Only a fool would buy the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) claims that its invitation to Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama to visit Taiwan has nothing to do with politics.
The country's pro-independence forces have always used the Tibetan leader as a lever against China.
When former President Lee Teng-hui invited the Dalai Lama to visit Taiwan to show his contempt for Beijing, it was a clever political gambit.
When former President Chen Shui-bian invited him to visit Taiwan, it was a poor imitation.
And when Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu followed their lead recently by inviting the Dalai Lama, it was a dirty trick.
Beijing showed its friendship toward Chen Chu by not blocking President Ma's opening of the Kaohsiung World Games 2009.

In rewarding Beijing by inviting the Dalai Lama to visit Taiwan, what does the DPP expect to earn? People's respect? Their appreciation? Or an understanding of its evil intention to use the flood victims for its political gains?
Ma should not have contradicted his own policy of a diplomatic truce with China by approving the Dalai Lama's visit.
If Beijing refuses to defer to Taipei's decision, Ma's efforts in the past year to reconcile with China will all go down the drain.

Taiwan and Tibet each has its own issue to settle with China, and it is better for the two to seek their own separate relations with China on their own. That strategy will likely be in the best interest of both sides.
The Dalai Lama has been unable to resolve the Tibet problem. Does the DPP really want to use him as a lever in creating friction between Taiwan and China?

DOC.HEADLINE: New U.S. envoy vows to boost bilateral ties

TEXT.P: The new U.S. representative to Taiwan pledged Friday to continue the work of his predecessors in further strengthening bilateral relations and supporting the maintenance of peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

William A. Stanton, the new director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , made the remarks at a news conference held upon his arrival at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in northern Taiwan.

At the beginning of the news conference, Stanton greeted the local public with a "How Are You" in Mandarin Chinese and said he felt honored to return to Taiwan to head the AIT Taipei office, which represents U.S. interests in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

"Although I last lived in Taiwan 22 years ago, I have many fond memories, including the birth of my older daughter Kate who was therefore -- as I said in Washington recently -- 'made in Taiwan, '" Stanton said.
The new envoy lauded the enormous progress Taiwan has made in the past two decades.
"Taiwan is of course an economic miracle. With virtually no natural resources other than intelligence and hard work of its people, it is now the 26th largest economy in the world," he said.
The career diplomat also praised Taiwan's progress in democratic development.

"Just after I left Taiwan, martial law was lifted, and now Taiwan is a vibrant democracy built on the foundation of a civil society of the people of tawain and NGOs. This is an impressive achievement that the people of Taiwan can all be proud of," he added.

Acknowledging that the United States is proud of the support it has given Taiwan in achieving those goals, Stanton said the success of U.S. policy toward Taiwan has been built on the Taiwan Relations Act, which was enacted 30 years ago.
"Our commitment to that policy is firm, and on that basis we will continue to improve our relations," he promised.

Noting that relations between America and Taiwan are fundamentally based on shared values as well as common interests, Stanton said thiose values will continue to guide the development of bilateral ties.
Stanton said that in the coming weeks and months, he will listen carefully to the people of Taiwan on how the two countries may best continue to make progress.
"I also look forward to working with you, members of the Taiwan media, and plan to hold a press conference after I have a chance to reacquaint myself with Taiwan," he added.

Stanton's most recent assignment was as deputy chief of the U.S. Embassy in South Korea. He also had served as Charge d'Affaires ad interim and as deputy chief of mission at the U.S. Embassy in Canberra, Australia. With his experience of studying Chinese in Taipei between 1986 and 1987, he has a fair understanding of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dalai Lama wants to console flood-affected victims
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/28/09 17:20:54 (By Paul Kuo and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Dalai Lama hopes to console people in southern Taiwan who have suffered a great deal during Typhoon Morakot, an official of the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader's office said Friday.

Tsegyam, secretary of the Dalai Lama Office who once served as Tibetan exile government's representative to Taipei, made the remarks during a telephone interview with the Central News Agency prior to his trip to Taiwan to arrange the Dalai Lama's visit to Taiwan.
Tsegyam stressed that the Dalai Lama's visit is based on the "responsibility and obligation of a Buddhist leader."

He said that when the Dalai Lama heard chiefs from the seven cities and counties had invited him to visit Taiwan to comfort the flood-affected victims, his immediate response was if his visit to Taiwan could help release the dead from their suffering and comfort those who were affected by the typhoon-triggered flooding, then he "felt he had the responsibility to go."
Amid speculation that the Dalai Lama's visit could touch a raw nerve in China, Tsegyam also said that the Dalai Lama would only go "if the visit will not cause any troubles."

The 75-year-old Dalai Lama only recently returned to his base in Dharamsala in northwestern India after concluding a three-week visit and religious activities in Ladakh in the northern part of that country.
The Dalai Lama is expected to lead a nine-member team, including his three body guards, to Taiwan Sunday afternoon for a week-long "humanitarian" visit.
This will be his third trip to Taiwan, following his first visit in March 1997 and his second in March 2001,

Kaohsiung City officials said the Dalai Lama is expected to head for some of the worst-hit disaster areas in southern Taiwan, including Siaolin village in Kaohsiung County and Linbian Township in neighboring Pingtung County, Sept. 1 and Sept. 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan team edges closer to Little League World Series title
DOC.DATELINE: Washington D.C./Taipei, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/28/09 17:33:10 (By Hu Li-chung and Luke Sabatier)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Kuei-Shan Little League moved a step closer to a Little League World Series crown Friday morning Taiwan time by taking advantage of some timely chocolate snacks and three errors by the opponent to defeat Caribbean champion Curacao 5-2.

The win sent the Taoyuan County team, representing the Asia-Pacific region, into the tournament's International Championship Game against the Mexican representative from Reynosa on Saturday at midnight Taiwan time.
The winner will move on to vie for the World Series crown against the American champion.

Kuei-Shan Little League is hoping to become the first Taiwanese team to capture a World Series crown since 1996. Local teams once dominated the annual tournament, taking 17 titles between 1969 and 1996, but no team representing Taiwan has even made it to the World Series championship game since then.

Though defeating the unbeaten Caribbean champion was not easy, overcoming a strong Mexican pitching staff that has given up only three runs in four consecutive victories, including a 6-0 whitewash of Japan a day earlier, will be even more challenging.

The Mexicans beat Kuei-Shan 3-2 in a Pool D game earlier in the tourney, and the Taiwanese team will likely again face starter Marcelo Martinez, who no-hit the Asia-Pacific champion over 4 2/3 innings and struck out 12 in that game.
Against Curacao, however, Taiwan showed it could figure out a tough pitcher.

Curacao starter Claycandy Hariquez kept Kuei-Shan's hitters off balance with fastballs of up to 74 miles per hour (the equivalent of a 97-mph fastball at the Major League level) and 50-mph change-ups, allowing only two hits and striking out seven over the first three innings of the regulation six-inning game.
But then Taiwan manager Lee Cheng-ta said he told his team to concentrate on hitting fastballs and lay off Hariquez's off-speed stuff.

The strategy paid off in the fourth inning, as two singles sandwiched around a hit batsman scored a run, and catcher Kao Yu-chieh added to the tally by scoring on an errant throw after his RBI single.

Taiwan added a run in the fifth, when Lin Hung-yuan reached on an error, went to second on a wild pitch and scored on a base hit by Sung Wen-hua. The team then knocked out Hariquez in the sixth with a solo home run by Cheng Tang-fu and an RBI single by Lin.
Meanwhile, Kuei-Shan starter Ou Chin baffled his Caribbean opponents with an excellent curve ball, and pitched a no-hitter over the first five innings.

The key, Lee said, was M&M chocolates, which coaches fed to Ou whenever he appeared to tire or get nervous. As Ou mowed down opposing batters, his teammates started to think the chocolates were lucky and had some themselves.

With Kuei-shan ahead 5-0 in the bottom of the sixth and final inning, the chocolates lost their potency, and Ou was roughed up for two runs, but Sung came on in relief to strike out Richendly Bicentini to clinch the victory.
Lee expects to start Sung against Mexico. The pitcher has appeared in all four of Taiwan's games, never throwing more than an inning.
In his three innings on the mound at Williamsport, Pennsylvania, where the World Series is being held, he has struck out seven and allowed only one hit.

With Mexico eliminating the Japanese champion and Taiwan eliminating Curacao, it will be the first time since 1996 that the International final will not feature a team from either Japan or the Caribbean.
Kuei-Shan is now hoping to set another first since 1996 and become the first Taiwanese Little League World Series champion in 18 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP denies political plot involved in inviting Dalai Lama to Taiwan

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) denied Friday there was any political plot behind the move by some of the party's politicians to invite the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama to visit Taiwan.

DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen stressed that the Dalai Lama will come to Taiwan to console and pray for the victims of Typhoon Morakot and she urged critics not to overstate the visit's political implications.
Tsai said with the Dalai Lama's prestige around the world, his visit will help cast global attention on Taiwan's post-disaster reconstruction needs.
"It's exciting that the Dalai Lama will take part in such an important process," Tsai said.
By accusing the DPP of political maneuvering, it is the critics who are politicizing the matter rather than the DPP, Tsai contended.
She said if the Dalai Lama has the desire to meet with Taiwan's opposition leaders, she will be very happy to meet him.
The invitation to the exiled Tibetan leader to visit Taiwan was issued by the chiefs of seven DPP-controlled localities in southern Taiwan that were hit hard by the storm.
The visit is tentatively scheduled for Aug. 30 to Sept. 4.

President Ma Ying-jeou, who had turned down a proposal by the Dalai Lama to visit in 2008 out of concern that it could hurt Taiwan's warming ties with China, announced Thursday that the Tibetan leader will be allowed to come for religious activities related to the typhoon's aftermath.

Chang Jung-kung, deputy secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang, accused the pro-independence DPP later Friday of attempting to use the Dalai Lama to create domestic political conflict and cross-Taiwan Strait tensions.

According to Chang, by making public the Dalai Lama's planned visit before he officially filed an application with Taiwan, the DPP was "launching a surprise political attack" at a time when the country was busy dealing with the disaster aftermath.
Tsai Huang-liang, a senior DPP legislator, called on both the KMT and Beijing Friday to take the Dalai Lama's visit in stride.
Tsai suggested that President Ma arrange a meeting with the Tibetan leader to demonstrate to the world that Taiwan is a country practicing democracy, human rights and humanitarianism.
"As a sovereign country, Taiwan can decide on its own who to invite to visit. It is none of the business of other countries," Tsai said.
Also, Tsai said, the government should not restrict the Dalai Lama's activities and speeches in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIG closes bid for Nan Shan Life, declining

TEXT.P: The American International Group (AIG) closed the bid for its Taiwanese unit, the Nan Shan Life Insurance Co., on Friday. However, the financially-hit US insurance giant declined to reveal information about the bidders or give a timetable as to when it would decide on a buyer.

According to industry sources, Primus Financial Holdings Limited, a Hong Kong- based financial services company, was one of the parties that made a bid for Nan Shan. Other parties that are known to have been highly interested in bidding for the Taiwanese arm of AIG are the Fubon Financial Holding Company, Cathay Financial Holding Company and Chinatrust Financial Holding Company, all of which are based in Taiwan.
Established in July 1963, Nan Shan currently has 10 percent to 12 percent of Taiwan's insurance market, and is one of the biggest insurance companies here.

Statistics released by Nan Shan recently indicate that as of May 2009, the company's total assets amounted to NT$1.5 trillion. Total policies in force reached 7.94 million, with 4 million policy holders.

Since the New York based AIG was hit by a financial crisis last October, there has been considerable speculation about Nan Shan's fate. However, AIG only announced in early August that it would sell 97.57 percent of its Taiwanese unit's shares.

Since AIG announced the sale, the company workers' union has been trying to negotiate with the management regarding the job security of the nearly 40,000 employees at Nan Shan and the handling of the company's NT$14 billion pension fund.
Nan Shan requires employees who have worked for the company for over seven years to contribute 2 percent of their salaries to the pension fund.

Unsatisfied with the company's decision to return only 27 percent of the pension fund's assets to the contributors, some 400 employees brought a suit against the company at the Taipei District Court Friday, demanding a full refund.
The dispute over the pension fund may pose difficulties to AIG in selling Nan Shan, said an industry source.

DOC.HEADLINE: Web site created to ensure transparency of disaster relief donations

TEXT.P: A Web site was created Friday by an alliance of public interest groups to ensure transparency of the use of donations for relief and reconstruction in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot.

"We hope all government and private fundraising units can join us so that every penny donated can be used to its fullest through self-discipline and public supervision, " said Cheng Hsin-chen, president of the Taiwan NPO Self-Regulation Alliance.
The alliance joined forces with the Consumers Foundation and lawyer and accountant associations in creating and operating the Web site "88.npoalliance.org.tw," Cheng said.

Noting that the new Web site will serve as a platform for public scrutiny of the disposal or use of all donations, Cheng said more than 10 member groups of the alliance that have launched fundraising drives to help those affected by the storm have agreed to post all relevant information on the Web site.

The groups include the United Way Taiwan, the Red Cross Society, the Eden Social Welfare Foundation, the Child Welfare League Foundation, the Red Heart Association, the Children Are Us Foundation and the Chinese Christian Relief Association.

Cheng said he hopes non-alliance member organizations, such as World Vision Taiwan, the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation -- Taiwan's largest charity -- and all government agencies that have opened bank accounts to receive donations will also post information related to Morakot donations on the site.

Citing statistics released by the Ministry of the Interior, Cheng said 21 local and central government units and 43 private groups have registered with the ministry to raise funds for post-disaster relief projects.
"We will write letters to all those organizations to join the new platform or at least publish relevant information in line with the principle of self- discipline," he said.

As government agencies tend to open accounts to receive public donations before even deciding what post-disaster relief or rehabilitation programs will be launched, Cheng said the 21 government units should be subject to stringent supervision.

Feng Yen, an adviser to the alliance, said that because Morakot-related donations have totaled an estimated NT$10 billion (US$303 million) , public supervision is very important to prevent abuses of the money.

DOC.HEADLINE: Program to nurture indigenous students to kick off in Pingtung

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education and National Tsing Hua University jointly announced on Friday a program to nurture indigenous students so that they can one day return to their communities to help restore them.
The program will be held at National Pinbei Senior High School in Pingtung in southern Taiwan, one of the counties hardest hit during Typhoon Morakot.

National Tsing Hua University professors broached the idea to the Ministry of Education after participating in flood relief efforts. Flood relief is a short- term job, they said, but only through education and the cultivation of talent can long-term problems be solved.

The faculty of the university's Tsing Hua College, a new educational concept launched last year, formed a disaster relief team Aug. 10 after Typhoon Morakot pummeled southern Taiwan and triggered the most serious flooding and mudslides in half a century.

They mobilized around 350 college students to help with flood relief efforts in the coastal towns of Jiadong and Linbian in Pingtung between Aug. 13-25, becoming the first college students to enter the affected areas.
The pilot program was supported by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, who attended a seminar on the school's education policy for indigenous students.

Liu said he was glad to have Tsing Hua professors forming the backbone of the project and said it will be "the beginning of better education, which will allow the integration of the ecological concepts of aboriginal peoples and mainstream education."

The premier said he hoped the program will be expanded to the whole island and lure more indigenous peoples to return to their community so as to "increase their employment opportunities and let them become the guardians of nature."
The premier also announced that indigenous students in flood-affected senior high and vocational schools and colleges will not have to pay tuition or miscellaneous fees this year.

Starting next year, the tuition and miscellaneous fees of indigenous students in senior high and vocational schools will be exempted. The measure is expected to benefit 18,000 aboriginal students and cost the government about NT$620 million (US$18.78 million).
Under Tsing Hua's pilot program, Pinbei Senior High School will recruit two additional classes of indigenous students from flood-affected areas starting September 2010 with 30 students in each class.
Tsing Hua university professors and leading figures from various sectors will deliver lectures to broaden the students' horizons.

In addition to their regular high school classes, they will also take courses on ecology. Students will also return to their communities for service during winter and summer vacations, as well as receive psychological counseling in the wake of the flooding.

Professor Juju Chin-shou Wang, the CEO of Tsing Hua College and one of the architects of the program, noted that mainstream society has not made good use of the ecological wisdom of indigenous peoples.
"If it had, then the disasters of the land could have possibly been avoided, " Wang said. "The protagonists of ecological conservation will be indigenous peoples."
Their ecological wisdom will be taught in the program, so that the students will return to their communities for "restoration" instead of "reconstruction," according to Wang.
The program in the Pingtung high school will be patterned after that at Tsing Hua College, where students from different departments are selected based on their passion for the future.

They live together in the school dormitory to learn the values of tolerance and appreciation, and program insists that students first learn human values and then civic values, before focusing on gaining knowledge in a particular field.
Also, additional lectures will be given at night after regular classes and during the summer and winter vacations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition parties will try to reverse decision on referendum

TEXT.P: Opposition party leaders said Friday that the rejection of a petition to hold a referendum on the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement with China is not acceptable, and they vowed to use all possible measures to reverse the decision.

Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , and Huang Kun-huei, chairman of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , contended in a press conference Friday that the Cabinet Referendum Screening Committee's decision is against the law.
They said they will try all possible options, including administrative petitions, administrative litigation or a constitutional interpretation, to reverse the committee's decision.

Accusing the committee of either being much too conservative or having preconceptions while screening the referendum proposal, Tsai said it is only fair to hold a referendum allowing people to decide the issue since they will be affected when such an agreement is signed.

The DPP proposed to have the nation's voters answer the question: "Do you agree that the government should hold a referendum to allow the people to decide on the signing of a Taiwan-China economic cooperation framework agreement?"

A majority 13 members of the committee on Thursday voted to reject the proposal on the grounds that it is based on a hypothetical situation that does not meet criteria for referendum questions stipulated in the Referendum Law.
Four other members of the committee voted in favor and two members abstained.

Tsai contended that the existing referendum mechanism failed to serve its purpose and pledged to apply all check and balance measures to ensure that the welfare of the people will not be violated in the the process of realizing such an agreement.

DOC.HEADLINE: Less than 10% aware of swine flu transmission modes: survey

TEXT.P: Less than 10 percent of respondents to a recent survey are fully aware how swine flu, officially known as influenza A(H1N1), spreadescan occur, according to the results of the survey released Friday.

The telephone survey, conducted by Common Health Magazine July 9-11, found that only 6.84 percent of those interviewed correctly identified the two ways through which the H1N1 virus can be transmitted -- through contact with infected pigs or environments contaminated with the swine flu virus and through contact with a person with H1N1.
In human-to-human transmission, the virus is spread by breathing in infectious droplets from the coughing or sneezing of infected people rather than through airborne transmission.
The survey collected 1,112 valid samples, with a 95 percent confidence level and a margin of error of plus or minus 2.9 percent.
Up to 32.81 percent mistakenly thought that the H1N1 virus could be spread through airborne transmission as well as through coughing or sneezing of infected people.
Another 20 percent erroneously thought that the virus could be transmitted through airborne transmission, contact with infected people and coughing or sneezing of infected people.

The survey also found that only one-third of the respondents would stay at home if they came down with the swine flu, while the remaining respondents said they would still go to school or to the office.

Men are more likely than women to continue their work schedule if they contract the disease and the higher the education level, the more likely the respondents were to go to school or to work, according to the survey.
It also found that 90 percent of the respondents would go to see doctor if they contracted the H1N1 virus.
If their children come down with the virus, 60 percent of the respondents said they would not let them go to school, but 20 percent said it would depend on the actual situation.

Speaking at a news conference at which the survey results were unveiled, Chen Chien-jen, a former Department of Health (DOH) minister who is also an Academia Sinica academinician, said the ratio of people with correct knowledge about the swine flu was lower than he had expected.
"This trend is worrisome because wrong perceptions of the disease could lead to public health risks, " Chen said.
He urged the government to step up publicity to provide members of the public correct information about the swine flu to facilitate prevention of the disease.

DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang, who also attended the news conference, said those who develop flu-like symptoms, such as a fever, sore throat, runny nose, body aches and headaches, should go to see a doctor immediately and should stay at home to avoid transmitting the virus to others.
Yaung also reminded swine flu patients to take the anti-viral drug Tamiflu in accordance with their attending doctors' instructions to avoid developing a resistance to the medication.
He further said that hoarding Tamiflu and facial masks is meaningless.
Yaung said the DOH will formulate guidelines for physicians at private clinics to follow in prescribing Tamiflu.

Meanwhile, Ho Mei-hsiang, R&D chief at Adimmune Corp. -- Taiwan's only human vaccine manufacturer who is producing swine flu vaccines for domestic use -- said about 3,000 people die from seasonal flu and that the mortality of swine flu is expected to be higher.
According to Ho, seasonal flu mainly affects elderly people while swine flu tends to infect young people, particularly those with underlying chronic diseases.

DOC.HEADLINE: President is not expected to meet Dalai Lama

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou is not expected to meet with the Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of Tibet, during his stay in Taiwan, the Presidential Office spokesman said Friday.
The exiled Tibetan leader, who was invited by local chiefs from flood-affected areas in southern Taiwan, is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Sunday for a six-day visit before leaving Sept. 4.

During his visit, the Dalai Lama is expected to preside over a series of dharma services to console people who suffered from Typhoon Morakot, which devastated southern Taiwan with the most serious flooding and mudslides in half a century.

Asked whether Ma will attend one of the services, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said that, "our understanding is that the president has only planned to attend a national mourning ceremony Sept. 7 for those killed during the storm.
"There are no plans for other activities," Wang said.
Wang also dismissed the possibility of the president meeting the Dalai Lama in private.
"That probably won't happen, " Wang said. "As far as we know, the Dalai Lama is here for activities related to religious and humanitarian aspects."

Some believe the Ma administration's approval of the Dalai Lama's visit could damage Taiwan's warming relations with Beijing, and a meeting between Ma and the Tibetan leader could cause even greater friction.

DOC.HEADLINE: Insurance companies have paid NT$121.88 million for typhoon victims

TEXT.P: The Life Insurance Association of the Republic of China said that as of 5 p.m, Friday, local insurers have paid NT$121.88 million (US$3.69 million) in claims on life and injury insurance policies in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot.
The typhoon devastated southern Taiwan Aug. 7-9, triggering the most serious flooding and mudslides in half a century. Agricultural losses have surged to NT$16.4 billion.

The association said that among those killed or unaccounted for, 277 bought NT$558.13 million in personal insurance policies, including NT$254.71 million in life insurance policies and NT$303.42 million in accidental injury insurance.
Meanwhile, local insurance companies and their staffs have donated NT$325.62 million to disaster relief efforts.
According to official figures, 461 people died in the storm and 192 have gone unaccounted for.

DOC.HEADLINE: Weather bureau to invest NT$1.9b in improving forecasting tools

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau announced Friday that a total of NT$1.9 billion (US$59 million) will be invested over the next six years to strengthen forecasting technologies, enabling meteorologists to provide rainfall projections two to three hours before torrential rains arrive.

Many criticized the bureau for inaccurate rainfall predictions prior to the arrival of Typhoon Morakot and its torrential rains, which devastated southern Taiwan by triggering floods and mudslides in the second week of August.

The government was blamed for failing to respond more promptly and efficiently to the disaster, but officials felt weathermen could have provided more timely rainfall forecasts instead of predicting rainfall only one hour in advance.
A weather bureau spokesman said Friday that there are 400 weather monitoring stations around the island, and the bureau plans to build 90 to 100 more.

Currently, the weather bureau forecasts the path of tropical storms approaching Taiwan five days in advance, but after it upgrades its equipment, it hopes to forecast storm routes seven days in advance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Morakot hit NT$16.4 billion

TEXT.P: Estimates of agricultural losses from Typhoon Morakot rose to NT$16.4 billion (US$497 million) as of Thursday, nearing the record amount for losses from a storm set in 1996.

The Council of Agriculture, which released the latest loss estimates Friday, said the typhoon, which pummeled Taiwan Aug. 7-9, caused serious damage to the agricultural sector in 11 counties, with Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Chiayi counties in southern Taiwan the hardest hit.
The losses from Typhoon Morakot rank second only to the NT$18 billion in agricultural losses caused by Typhoon Herb that struck Taiwan in 1996.
The COA put damage to crops at NT$4.93 billion, with 28 percent of the crops on 82,408 hectares of farmland wiped out or washed away.

Bananas suffered the heaviest damage, with 6,396 hectares ravaged by strong winds and flooding, followed by papayas, guavas, rice, bamboo shoots, orchids, custard apples and leafy vegetables. Bee losses amounted to NT$7.49 million.
The storm also took a heavy toll on animal farms, killing 148,273 pigs, nearly 6.11 million chickens and around 1.54 million ducks and causing losses of NT$1.48 billion, the COA said.
Damage to the aquaculture sector totaled NT$4.17 billion, the highest in 19 years, with stock in some 6,942 hectares of fishponds in coastal areas washed away, it said.

The tallies also show that a total of 5,405 hectares of farmland had been either washed away or inundated, mostly in Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Chiayi counties, bringing the total farmland losses to NT$4.77 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet fund to earmark NT$24 billion for biotech investment

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan's National Development Fund will earmark NT$24 billion (US$727.27 million) as venture capital for the biotech sector, according to investment guidelines for the sector approved by the fund's management committee Friday.
Biotech companies can apply for the financing immediately, according to the guidelines.
The committee said the fund will invest NT$24 billion in the biotech sector over several stages based on a risk diversification approach to upgrade the output of the industry.

To be eligible for the cash injections, companies must be engaged in pharmaceutical development, medical equipment development and production and other related sectors and have paid-in capital of at least NT$5 billion.
The development fund will provide up to 40 percent of biotech companies' paid-in capital and require the recipient to invest over 50 percent of its capital in Taiwan.

Applicants must also have a qualified management team. Their executives must have science and engineering, biomedical, investment, or legal backgrounds, and the team must have a total of at least 60 years of related experience.

DOC.HEADLINE: Muzha-Neihu MRT line experiences eighth emergency shutdown

TEXT.P: The controversial Muzha-Neihu MRT Line sustained yet another emergency shutdown Friday after the signal room at its Jiannan station blacked out at 9:25 p.m.
It marked the eighth time that the integrated metro line had to suspend services due to system failure since the 14.8-km Neihu line built by Canadian contractor Bombadier was inaugurated July 4.
A Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC) spokesman said that because the power outage affected network communications, the entire line had to be shut down.
At the time, 22 trains were in operation. Three trains were caught between stations and had to be manually driven into the stations. All passengers were evacuated by 9:39 p.m.

Traffic services on the Taipei Zoo-Zhongshan Junior High School section -- the Muzha Line built by France's Matra Co. in the 1990s -- resumed at 9:45 p.m. and the entire line resumed normal operations at 10:05 p.m.
According to the TRTC spokesman, the power outage happened after workers inadvertently hit a power line while installing a second UPS backup system.
"The outage had nothing to do with the main control system provided by the Canadian contractor Bombardier," said the spokesman.
