DOC.HEADLINE: Four financial holding companies bid for Nan Shan

TEXT.P: Three financial holding companies in Taiwan and the Hong Kong-based Primus Financial Holdings Limited submitted bids for the American International Group's (AIG) Taiwanese unit, the Nan Shan Life Insurance Co., before the closing of the bid Friday.

According to industry sources, among the four bidders, Primus Financial Holdings Ltd. and Chinatrust Financial Holding Company are most keen to acquire Nan Shan Life, and may bid between US$1.5 billion and US$$2 billion, while the Fubon Financial Holding Co. and Cathay Financial Holding Co.'s offers are estimated at between US$1 billion and US$1.5 billion.

Earlier this month there were speculations that Chinatrust might not submit a bid, but the company has since demonstrated its ambition to expand its insurance business, announcing that it will sell 2.5 billion new shares to fund its expansion.

An analysis by Deutsche Securities suggests that a merger of Chinatrust and Nan Shan would have the least impact on the Taiwan insurance market, while acquisition of Nan Shan by either Cathay Financial or Fubon Financial would mean the emergence of a dominant power in the market.

Cathay Financial is Taiwan's largest life insurance company in terms of market share, but Fubon Financial can overtake Cathay if Fubon succeeds in acquiring Nan Shan, analysts have said. Fubon is a major player in the life insurance market with 10 percent to 12 percent of the market share, the analysts have noted.

Established in July 1963, Nan Shan is one of the biggest insurance companies in Taiwan. Statistics released by Nan Shan recently indicate that as of the end of June, the company's total assets exceeded NT$1.5 trillion. The total number of policies in force were 7.97 million, with 4 million policy holders.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei hopes to impress with 2010 Taipei International Flora Expo

TEXT.P: CNA Staff Writer

Taipei, Aug. 29 (CNA) The venue of the 2010 Taipei International Gardening and Horticulture Expo will reflect the diversity of the host city, stretching from the scenic Yuanshan hill and Xinsheng Park along the Keelung River to the commercially active Neihu hi-tech park and Zhongshan North Rd.
But the Taipei City government is not simply counting on the exposition's setting to draw visitors.

From Nov. 6, 2010 to April 25, 2011, the modern city hopes to impress the world with colorful touches that showcase Taiwan's bountiful flora, gardening creativity, and unique fusion of horticulture and technology.

Chen Hsiung-wen, commissioner of the city's Department of Economic Development, said the 91.8 hectare expo site is divided into four areas, with 14 exhibition pavilions featuring Taiwan's flora and landscape, gardening and horticulture, and stages for artistic programs.

With the recognition and support of the international community, Taipei won the right to host the event at the spring meeting of the International Association of Horticultural Producers (AIPH) in April 2006, three years after the Taiwan Floriculture Development Association was admitted as a member.
The Netherlands-headquartered organization represents flower and plant growers and landscape service providers around the world.

Since 1960, the Netherlands, Germany, Austria, and France have each hosted flora expos more than once, and the Asian cities of Osaka, Japan, Kunming, China, and Chiang Mai, Thailand, have held the event since 1990.

Chen said that the 1990 International Gardens and Greenery Exposition in Osaka, Japan was an acclaimed success, and Taipei hopes its presentation next year will win similar recognition among flower admirers.
Since creativity and technology have helped Taiwan's horticulture sector achieve breakthroughs, Chen said that he believed the flora industry in Taiwan can make impressive presentation.

As the leading planner of the first internationally accredited exposition in Taiwan, Chen has attended AIPH meetings in Europe and Asia over the past few years to learn from the experiences of other countries and find sources of inspiration to make the expo a success.

Construction of the exhibition halls and neighborhood beautification projects began early this year, and the city government has cooperated with Taiwan's floraculture producers to arrange the most attractive presentation of Taiwan's flowers, plants, and horticulture research and development.
One of the designers' strategies will be to cover the expo's grounds with more than 40 million of Taiwan's indigenous flowers, plants and trees.

Chen said that by hosting the exposition, Taipei City is trying to build its image as a garden city with an emphasis on a balanced ecosystem, but he also indicated it could have a strong stimulative effect on a number of sectors.

The NT$3.53 billion investment in the exposition, for instance, is expected to help Taiwan's horticulture sector boost its production value by 23 percent, according to a Council of Agriculture estimate.
The tourism sector is also expected to benefit, as the exposition could draw 6 million visitors from home and abroad and sell NT$2.6 billion in tickets.

Chen also estimated that the show will inject an additional NT$8.8 billion into the local economy indirectly during its six-month run, as tourists spend money on local accommodation, food, and other purchases.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. praises Taiwan's post-disaster operations
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 29 (CNA) 08/29/09 13:42:03 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) has given a positive evaluation of Taiwan's response operations in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot, after OCHA sent a mission to Taiwan to assess the country's humanitarian needs.

The OCHA disaster assessment and coordination mission, which was in Taiwan Aug. 24-28, reported that there is "a large and seemingly well coordinated capacity of government as well as civilian actors on the ground."

The team visited the seven most severely affected villages in Kaohsiung County and also the southern coastal areas of Pingtung County where a massive clean-up operation involving 13,000 people was in progress, the report stated.

Another disaster relief team dispatched by the Japanese International Cooperation Agency during the same period has not come across any serious health problems in the shelters, according to the OCHA report.
The Japanese team focused its support on displaced individuals housed in temporary shelters in Kaohsiung County.

Meanwhile, the United States Pacific Command has concluded its humanitarian operations in Taiwan, with cargo planes and helicopters conducting a total of 55 missions to deliver relief supplies and 20 pieces of excavation equipment to affected areas, according to the report.
Japan continues to provide relief supplies to Kaohsiung County, while 600 of the 1,000 pre-fabricated houses donated by China have reached Taiwan, it said.
"The international community continues to express concern and send donations to assist authorities in Taipei to conduct residual relief and reconstruction activities," the report stated.
To date, 77 countries, the European Union and 20 international organizations have donated funds to Taiwan worth a total of NT$137 million (US$4.2 million), the report said.

Official figures released by Taiwan authorities show that as of Aug. 26, the disaster caused by Typhoon Morakot had left 461 people dead and 254 others missing, with 769,159 households directly affected and 6,000 displaced individuals housed in temporary shelters.

DOC.HEADLINE: President confident H1N1 outbreak will be brought under control

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou expressed confidence Saturday that the current outbreak of influenza A(H1N1) in Taiwan will be brought under control with the measures being taken by health authorities.
Addressing the issue in the latest issue of his weekly online video journal, Ma said greater public awareness of the new flu strain is needed but people should not panic over the situation.

According to Ma, the epidemic prevention measures adopted by Taiwan since April are not inferior to those of other countries, and thanks to efforts made by the Central Epidemics Command Center (CECC), an H1N1 epidemic was delayed by more than one month.

On his decision not to activate the national security mechanism for the time being to deal with the situation, Ma explained that he reached the decision after reading three different opinions by various segments of analysts in the country.

Those who support activating the national security mechanism immediately believe that it will facilitate widespread use of medication by the authorities to control the epidemic before a vaccine against the virus becomes available in mid November, Ma noted.
However, some are concerned that activating the national security mechanism too early can cause unnecessary public panic, he said.

Meanwhile, there are others who think the National Security Council should set up a task force that would maintain close contact with the CECC in preparation for national mobilization at an appropriate time, according to Ma.
Likening epidemic prevention and control to a battle, the president stressed that it involves a "very crucial decision" as to when to issue a command to "open fire."
"This must be handled properly. Too much is as bad as not enough," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Reconstruction of quake-toppled building in Taipei completed

TEXT.P: A project to reconstruct a Taipei City building that was toppled in the 921 earthquake was completed Saturday, weeks ahead of the 10th anniversary of the disaster.
Former residents of the Tunghsing Building gathered in the lobby of the reconstructed complex for a cocktail party Saturday, in anticipation of their return to the homes.
However, the residents will have to wait another three months before they can move in, as the related paperwork is still being processed.

Lin Chung-huan, director of the Urban Redevelopment Office under the Taipei City government, said despite the many twists and turns in the reconstruction process, the city took many steps to facilitate the project.

The 12-story Tunghsing Building crumpled when a 7.6 magnitude earthquake struck central Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999. Some 87 residents of the building were killed when it collapsed. It was the only building in Taipei City that was completely destroyed by the earthquake, which was centered about 200 kilometers away from the city.
The reconstruction project, which did not start until 2004, was suspended in October 2006 as a result of a financial crisis faced by the contractor.
The project was taken over in August 2008 by another contractor, but it came to standstill again two months later because of a similar problem.
The building was completed by a third contractor that took over the project in December 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local companies invited to clear, keep driftwood

TEXT.P: Local companies will be allowed to keep any driftwood that they clear from specified areas in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, the Council of Agriculture's Forestry Bureau said Saturday.
Driftwood that is clogging rivers and fishing ports and cluttering farmland will be free of charge to those companies that clear it, the bureau said.

Under Taiwan law, unauthorized removal of driftwood from state property is not permitted. However, the immense volume of rainfall brought by the typhoon Aug-7-9 caused flooding and landslides that left some 400,000 tons of driftwood in areas of central and southern Taiwan, according to Forestry Bureau statistics.
Farmers and fishermen in the affected areas have been complaining about clogged fishing ports, irrigation channels and cluttered farmlands, the bureau said.

With the help of local governments, the bureau said, it has so far managed to clear only about of fourth of the driftwood, even though it has mobilized 1,593 people from its local offices and 709 pieces of heavy-duty machinery and vehicles.
The bureau is therefore inviting private enterprises to clear the driftwood and is offering them the incentive of keeping whatever amount they move.

The companies are required to apply for permission to clear as much driftwood as they want from the specified areas, the bureau said, adding that the wood may used as fuel or compost, or for art and craft or paper pulp.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prefab houses will be erected based on demand: premier

TEXT.P: The government will evaluate the demand among Typhoon Morakot victims for temporary pre-fabricated houses before erecting such structures, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Saturday.

Liu made the remarks during a visit to a military barracks in Kaohsiung County where some of the victims are being sheltered. He was responding to reports that the government had decided to halt the pre-fabricated housing project.
Liu explained that the government is committed to providing permanent housing for people dislocated or rendered homeless by the storm.
Under these circumstance, unless there is a demand among the storm victims for temporary housing, the government will avoid wasting resources by building too many pre-fabricated houses, he said.

Expressing his support for the central government's position on the issue, Kaohsiung magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing said many people find it hard to adjust to the conditions in pre-fabricated houses and prefer to remain temporarily in military barracks, which offer a better living environment.
Another option is for the victims to rent homes and claim rental allowances from the government, Yang said.

Also during the trip, Liu told residents at the shelter that the Government Information Office will publish a weekly "reconstruction newsletter" that will be circulated among the typhoon victims starting Sept. 1 to allow them to keep track of the progress of the government's reconstruction efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Public satisfaction with social order drops: poll

TEXT.P: Although the number of crime victims in Taiwan appears to be dropping, an increasing number of people are not satisfied with the government's performance in maintaining social order, according to the results of a survey released Saturday.

The survey, conducted by the Crime Research Center of National Chung Cheng University in Chaiyi, found that 76 percent of the Taiwan public was dissatisfied with the government's efforts in the first half of the year to improve social order.
This was an increase of 5.3 percentage points compared with the results of a similar survey in 2008, said Yang Shi-lung, director of the center, at press conference Saturday.
In addition, public satisfaction with the police's ability to maintain social order also dropped in this year's poll to 39.5 percent compared with 47 percent last year, he said.
This suggests that the government is losing the people's trust, he added.

However, the survey also found that the percentage of fraud crime victims fell from 7.7 percent to 4.1 percent, theft crime victims from 16 percent to 11 percent, and violent crime victims from 5 percent to 3 percent.

On the question of public safety, 57.6 percent of the respondents said they were worried that they or their family members would become victims of crime, and nearly 40 percent said they did not feel safe going out at night.
These two figures were close to the results of the 2008 poll, Yang said.

When asked about the death penalty, 42.2 percent of the respondents said they were firmly opposed to the idea of its abolition, while 5.5 percent said it should be dropped from the law books. However, 50 percent said they would support the abolition of capital punishment if substitute measures are introduced.
Again, these results were close to those in the 2008 survey, Yang said.
The survey was conducted islandwide by telephone July 1-7 on residents age 20 or above. A total of 2004 valid samples were collected, and the poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 2.19 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dalai Lama to begin public activities in Taiwan Aug. 31

TEXT.P: The Dalai Lama will arrive in Taiwan Aug. 30 and will begin his visit the next day to areas of the country devastated by Typhoon Morakot, the Kaohsiung City government said Saturday.
Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu said that she will be at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport to welcome the Tibetan spiritual leader on behalf of her city.
If possible, she will accompany the Dalai Lama on his trip to Kaohsiung City by high-speed rail, she added.
The Dalai Lama was invited by local government chiefs in southern Taiwan to comfort and pray for the typhoon victims in areas that were hardest hit by the storm Aug.7-9.

According to the Kaohsiung City government, the Dalai Lama's public activities will be scheduled between Aug. 31 and Sept. 2. He will first hold a news conference Aug. 31 before setting off that same day for the typhoon-affected areas, the city government said.

On Sept. 1, the exiled Tibetan Buddhist leader will deliver a speech and preside over a prayer ceremony at Kaohsiung Arena for typhoon victims. He will meet with Cardinal Shan Kuo-hsi of the Roman Catholic Church the following day at a hotel in the city.
The Dalai Lama first visited Taiwan in 1997 and again in 2001.
When Typhoon Morakot struck earlier this month, it brought torrential rains which triggered the worst flooding in the country in 50 years, devastating much of southern Taiwan.
As of Saturday, confirmed fatalities from the disaster had reached 571, with 106 others reported missing and 33 injured, according to the Central Emergency Operation Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Visit by China Mobile chief spurs interest among 3G suppliers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 29 (CNA) 08/29/09 20:10:25 (By Yeh Tai-chi and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Wang Jianzhou, chairman of the world's largest mobile carrier China Mobile Ltd., concluded a weeklong visit in Taiwan Saturday that spurred telecommunications service providers and hi-tech firms to join hands to explore China's third generation mobile business.
China Mobile already has 500 million customers and is undertaking the infrastructure development of the 3G system TD-SCDMA that is being promoted by the Chinese authorities.
During his meetings with executives of Taiwan's information and communications companies, Wang disclosed that investments in TD-SCDMA infrastructure could reach 400 billion yuan (US$52 billion).
The construction cost of base stations alone is estimated at 120 billion yuan, and expenses to purchase terminal facilities and other equipment will be even higher, he said.
This explained why executives of Taiwan's 3G devices suppliers were very eager to meet Wang, although he made it clear that he had no plans to make any purchases at this time.
A research report by China Mobile indicates that China expects the number of its users of 3G devices to reach 85 million by 2011, and a pivotal element to that goal is device suppliers.

Since Taiwan's information industry -- from upstream IC designers and manufactures to downstream production of handsets, netbooks and e-readers -- can offer a streamlined supply chain, one of Wang's top missions during his visit was to look for partners who can help China Mobile secure its supply chain, local industry sources suggested.

In addition to visiting the Hsinchu-based Industrial Technology Research Institute, Wang has signed a memorandum of understanding with Taiwan's handset maker HTC Corp. to jointly develop smartphones and has met with executives of other leading hi-tech firms to explore possibilities for strategic alliances.

Before his departure, Wang told Taiwan's media he is convinced that the expansion of the telecommunications market on the Chinese mainland can offer opportunities to business and industry on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan WorldSkills team departs for Canada

TEXT.P: A Taiwan national team that will take part in the 40th WorldSkills Competition in Calgary, Canada, next month departed Saturday with the hope of winning medals in 45 skills categories that range from cabinetmaking to web design.
Wang Ju-hsuan, minister of the Council of Labor Affairs, met in Taipei with the 42 members of the under-23 national team and gave them some encouragement before their departure.

She expressed the hope that the team will bring home gold medals, especially as Taiwan missed out on golds in the last competition in Shizuoka, Japan. The Taiwan team took five silvers, three bronzes and 19 awards of excellence in the 2007 competition.

The WorldSkills Competition has been held every two years since it was launched in 1950 as a global "skills olympics." It is a world-class competition for youth between 17 and 22 years to demonstrate their excellence in skilled professions.

Some 51 countries will compete in Calgary this year in six broad sub-categories of skills, trades and technologies. The six areas are social and personal services, creative arts and fashion, information and communication technology, manufacturing and engineering technology, construction and building technology, and transportation and logistics.
The competition will be held at Stampede Park, Calgary Sept.1-7.

DOC.HEADLINE: A(H1N1) flu hospitalized cases increase to 65

TEXT.P: The Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) alerted the public Saturday that in the past 24 hours an additional 11 hospitalized A(H1N1) flu cases were reported, bringing the total of severe cases to 65.

Steve Kuo, director-general of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC), said more A(H1N1) patients were hospitalized probably because the public health system has become more cautious in its epidemic prevention and protection measures.
While a further increase in the number of hospitalized cases can be expected, no fatalities have been reported in the past two days, he added.

With a new school semester about to begin in early September, Kuo urged schools and parents take precautionary measures, such as checking the temperatures of school children, to ensure that no infected students will be at school.

To prevent cluster infections in schools, public health and education authorities have ruled that any class with two identified infections within a period of three days should be suspended for five days.
This 3-2-5 prevention system applies to all kindergartens, elementary and secondary schools.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 30, or the 11th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
30 B.C.: Mark Antony, the ruler of the eastern part of the Roman Empire, commits suicide at the court of his lover, Cleopatra, queen of Egypt, who later commits suicide by allowing an asp to bite her breast.
1483: Louis XI, king of France who was responsible for the unification of his country after the Hundred Years War, dies and is succeeded by his son, Charles VIII.
1862: Thomas Jonathan Jackson, known as "Stonewall," American Confederate general, leads his forces to victory against the Union Army at the Second Battle of Bull Run in Virginia. He was accidentally killed by his own troops at Chancellorvile in 1863.
1901: The vacuum cleaner is patented by Scotsman Hubert Cecil Booth.
1916: Turkey declares war on Romania.
1918: Vladimir Ilich Lenin, known as "Nikolai Lenin," first head of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, is shot and wounded by Fanya Kaplan and her sister Dora in Moscow.
1928: Jawaharlal Nehru founds the Independence of India League.
1932: Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Nazi politician and military leader, is elected president of the German Reichstag. He was responsible for the buildup of the German air force, directed Germany's wartime economy and was designated Hitler's successor in 1939.
1937: American boxer Joe Louis flattens Britain's Tommy Farr to win the heavyweight title at Madison Square Garden in New York.
1940: Sir Joseph John Thomson, British physicist, dies at the age of 84. He won a Nobel Prize in 1906 for investigating the electrical conductivity of gases.
1945: Hong Kong is liberated when the British Navy under Rear Adm. Cecil Harcourt sails into Victoria harbor to accept the Japanese surrender.
1949: The Southeast China Governor's Office, which was established in Taipei on Aug. 15, appoints Gen. Sun Li-jen as commander-in-chief of the Taiwan Garrison Command.
1958: Mainland China's Resolution Concerning the Establishment of People's Communes in the Rural Areas is promulgated. In a period of less then three months, 26,578 people's communes involving 127 million peasant household were established all over the mainland.
1963: The "hot line," a direct telephone line between the White House and the Kremlin linking the US president with the Soviet leader, becomes operational.
1974: A bomb planted by leftist guerrillas explodes in the main office of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries at Marunouchi in Tokyo, killing eight people and injuring 376 others.
1979: Ding Mou-shih, former vice minister of Foreign Affairs, leaves for Seoul to assume his post as ROC ambassador to the Republic of Korea.
1981: Muhammad Ali Rajai, president of Iran, and his prime minister, Mohammed Javad Bahonar, become victims of a bomb planted in the premier's office in Teheran.
1981: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives US Senator John Glenn.
1988: Republic of China-US talks on finance and banking open in Washington. The ROC negotiators agree to open the Taiwan market to credit card companies and to expand credit for foreign banks.
1989: Guatemalan President Marco Vincicio Cerezo Arevalo arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1990: Chien Mu, a great master in the study of Chinese classics, dies in Taipei at the age of 96.
1991: Azerbaijan declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1999: New Salvadoran Ambassador Francisco Ricardo Santana Berrios presents his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew leaves Taipei for Los Angeles en route to Panama to attend the inauguration of President-elect Mireya Moscoso on Sept. 1 as the special envoy of President Lee Teng-hui.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian receives Brisbane Mayor Jim Soorley, and welcomes his visit aimed at strenthening exchanges between the ROC and Australia.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is truth, there is intelligence; where there is intelligence, there is truth."

DOC.HEADLINE: Expertise of Taipei City rescue team on full display

TEXT.P: One day after Typhoon Morakot slashed through Taiwan cutting a swathe of destruction, President Ma Ying-jeou went on a fact-finding tour of southern Taiwan.

When he saw that the massive flooding along a raging creek that had breached the levee on the boundary of Chiayi County and Chiayi City, he asked an aide to contact Hsiung Kuang-hua, chief of the Taipei City Fire Department.
The TV cameras following the president were rolling as he asked Hsiung by phone to send the Taipei City Urban Search and Rescue Team to help evacuate people stranded by floods in the area.
For the rescue team, it was an endorsement by the head of state of its expertise, especially as the scene of the president making the request was televised live across the country.

But even before the president asked for the team's assistance on Aug. 9, 32 of its members had already been dispatched late the previous day to Pingtung County's Linbian township which was swamped by flood waters one-story high.
One hour after the team received an 11.00 p.m. call from the National Emergency Operation Centre, its members hit the road, and by 6 a.m. on Aug. 9 they were in action in Linbian.

On its first day of operation in the township, the team succeeded in rescuing 130 people stranded by floods, although five of its rubber rafts were punctured by unidentifiable sharp objects in the flood waters.
When it received the request from President Ma, the Taipei City Fire Department sent a team of 37 members to Minhsiung township in Chiayi County.
By Aug. 16, the department had dispatched seven other rescue teams, or 585 person/times, to help with the relief operations in southern Taiwan.

Morakot had dumped nearly 3,000 mm of rain -- nearly a year's volume -- on the island over a period of three days, causing the worst catastrophe in Taiwan history since a magnitude 7.6 earthquake killed more than 2,400 people on Sept. 21, 1999.

As the government scrambled to deal with the aftermath of the storm, the country's press lashed out in criticism, claiming that the authorities had not learned anything from the earthquake disaster a decade ago.
But Hsiung took issue with this view, pointing that since then Taiwan has assembled highly trained rescue teams that have worked in disaster zones in other countries.
The Taipei City Urban Search and Rescue Team, for example, has conducted many overseas missions in the decade since the 921 earthquake, he said.

At the time of the earthquake, Hsiung was serving as chairman of the Fire Science Department at Central Police University in Guishan, Taoyuan County and was given a directive by the Executive Yuan to request help from overseas.
Twenty-seven rescue missions from a dozen countries came to Taiwan's aid and they competed against each other for the distinction of saving the most people, Hsiung recalled.
Among them, Hsiung said, he was most impressed by the two teams from the United Sates, which were well organized and boasted state-of-the-art equipment.

"They flew in the day after the earthquake aboard a C-5B freight carrier and touched down at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport because the air force was hesitant about giving them access to the Chingchuankang air force base in Taichung -- the nearest airport to the center of the disaster," he recalled.

"As soon as the plane came to a halt on the tarmac, the two rescue teams emerged from the belly in their trucks. All their leaders asked was: 'Where should we start? And with whom should we be in contact?'" said Hsiung.

The two teams asked for no support whatsoever from the Taiwanese authorities because they had brought with them everything they needed -- from medicine, food and satellite communication equipment to long wave infrared locators, he said.
In such circumstances, the job of search and rescue teams is to rescue people trapped under debris, not to unearth bodies, Huang said.
One year after the 921 earthquake, the Taipei City Fire Department set up a search and rescue team, using money from the city's budget and funds donated by people in the wake of the temblor.
The team, patterned on the structure of the similar team under the U.S. Federal Emergency Management Agency, has 56 firefighters, four ER doctors and four structural engineers.

It has since been expanded to 123 members and has joined rescue operations in El Salvador in the wake of an earthquake in 2001, in Iran after its historic city of Bam was leveled by an earthquake in 2003, in Java in 2004 in the wake of a tsunami there, and in Wenchuan, western China in 2008 after a devastating earthquake.
The city's rescue team has also carried out many disaster rescue operations at home and is now considered one of the country's most experienced teams.
"The team can go into action within one hour of receiving a call for help, it can arrive anywhere in Taiwan within six hours, and anywhere around the world in 24 hours," Hsiung said.
Its performance in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot has fully showed its mettle and calibre.
However, "there is no room for complacency, as there is always scope for the team to upgrade its skills and training in order to prepare for any future challenges," Hsiung stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Inmates to join post-flood recovery work

TEXT.P: A number of convicts who were sentenced to six months or less in prison are expected to be put to work in communities hardest-hit by Typhoon Morakot, sources from the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) said Sunday.
The assignment will be part of a community service sentencing program introduced under an amendment to Article 41 of the Criminal Code in January this year.
The program is slated to begin Sept. 1.
Under the amendment, convicts sentenced to prison terms of six months or less for petty crimes could be released on probation and allowed to do community service in lieu of fines or time behind bars.

According to MOJ statistics, 1,802 prison inmates are eligible to apply for early release by paying fines. If they cannot afford the fines, they could apply for community service sentencing instead, the amendment stipulates.
It is expected that the amendment will benefit mainly convicted felons sentenced to six months or less in prison.

This category of convicts could include former President Chen Shui-bian's son Chen Chih-chung, daughter Chen Hsing-yu, and son-in-law Chao Chien-ming, who have been indicted for crimes related to corruption and money laundering, according to Tsai Jui-tsung, director of the MOJ Department of Prosecutorial Affairs.

The MOJ estimates that about 1,000 inmates on probation will work for free in social service organizations each year, which will translate into more than NT$800 million (US$24.39 million) worth of labor.
The community service program will also help alleviate problems related to overcrowding in prisons, said Wu Hsien-chang, director of the MOJ Department of Corrections.
The total population of prisons islandwide is 63,994 inmates, which is 16.51 percent, or 9,070 inmates, over capacity, Wu said.
Overcrowding is most serious in prisons in the northern cities of Taipei, Keelung and Taoyuan, he added.
Meanwhile, social service organizations have had mixed reactions to the implementation of community service sentencing.
Wang Yu-min, CEO of the nonprofit Child Welfare League Foundation, said they would welcome male convicts to do the more laborious work at the foundation, such as moving cartons of toys and cleaning.
Wang said the foundation would be willing to take on the inmates, as long as they were not convicted of violent crimes or sexual assault.
The Genesis Social Welfare Foundation, however, said it would pass.
"We have enough resources to recruit volunteers, so we would be pleased to let other charity organizations have the convicts," said a foundation spokesman.

Meanwhile, a spokesman for the Shihlin District Prosecutors Office said Sunday that the convict community service program will not have an adverse impact on public order, given that these people will be assessed and screened by prosecutors before they are released on probation.

"The program is not expected to exacerbate the unemployment problem either," said Yen Nai-wei, pointing out that more than 1,000 public organizations and schools islandwide have asked for a total of 1,900 inmate workers.
Nevertheless, Yen said, the Shihlin District Prosecutors Office will send only 200 inmates into community service in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: President says he respects indigenous villagers' wish to relocate

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that he fully respects the wish of residents of Minzu Village in Kaohsiung County's mountainous Namaxia township to relocate further downhill as their homes have been destroyed by Typhoon Morakot.

During a talk with residents of Namaxia -- a town in northern Kaohsiung County near the Central Mountain Range and home to the indigenous Bunun people -- Ma said that he respects the villagers' wish to settle in Shanlin township, also in Kaohsiung County.
However, the president said, he will instruct the Executive Yuan to assess whether the villagers should return to their mountain lands to farm after they have been resettled.

The Minzu Village residents have decided to move permanently to a tract of land near Shanlin Junior High School, said Lin Ching-chang, a member of the Minzu Village Self-Save Committee, during the meeting with President Ma and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan.

Lin said the villagers will ask for the right to own the land, which currently belongs to Taiwan Sugar Corp. The villagers will also seek permission to return to Minzu to farm their lands there, he said. They remain owners of the Minzu land, even though their residences were damaged or buried by mudslides caused by Typhoon Morakot, he added.
Ma said he will ask the Executive Yuan and Ministry of Finance to study the feasibility of allowing the villagers to own the land on which they will be resettled in Shanlin township.
However, it is debatable whether it would be safe for the villagers to return to their mountain village to farm, he added.

Since the typhoon wreaked havoc on southern Taiwan Aug. 7-9 causing the worst flooding in the country in 50 years, more than 3,500 villagers in Kaohsiung County have been placed in temporary shelters at military barracks.
Of the total, about half were from Namaxia, one of the hardest-hit areas in Kaohisung.
As of Saturday, confirmed fatalities from the typhoon disaster had reached 571, with 106 others reported missing and 33 injured, according to the Central Emergency Operation Center.

In related news, the president reiterated in another meeting in the southernmost county of Pingtung that the government will assist major public-interest organizations, including the ROC Red Cross Society, to disburse cash relief aid to the flood victims with flexibility and minimal red-tape.
"I promise you that rehabilitation will not be too hard to achieve," Ma said to representatives of the typhoon victims.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.K. office urges Taiwan companies to participate in technology fair

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) is urging Taiwanese companies to participate in the TechnologyWorld09 slated for Nov. 23-24 in Coventry, United Kingdom, saying that it will boost their business potential.

The exhibition, which is the U.K.'s biggest international "meet-the-buyer" event, is the right place for technology companies looking for more business, more innovation and more business partners, the BTCO said in a recent press release. U.K. Trade and Investment Chief Executive Andrew Cahn was quoted as
saying in the press release that each year TechnologyWorld gets
better and better.
"The U.K. attracts top buyers because of its track record in innovation and excellence in technology," Cahn said.

Building on last year's success, which generated an estimated 30 million pounds (US$48.8 million), this year's event will be held Nov. 23-24 at Richo Arena in Coventry. It will host global giants such as Panasonic, Hitachi, Nokia, Orange, PTT and Kayagura Health Solutions, according to the BTCO.

Some 200 companies from around the world have registered to participate in this year's show in search of technology innovation, the BTCO said, adding that evidence from TechnologyWorld08 suggests they will find it. Some 93 percent of the businesses from 38 countries that attended the 2008 show said they were likely to increase trade with U.K. businesses, the BTCO said.
This year's show has been considerably enhanced as part of the British government's strategic vision for the country's economic recovery, according to the BTCO.
Participating companies can arrange one-to-one meetings through the online meeting facility and sign up for relevant sessions of the conference program, it added.

Companies interested in attending the event can download the TechnologyWorld09 flyer at http: //www.technologyworld09.com or contact Julia Chang, commercial officer at BTCO, at telephone 02 8758 2045 or email: julia.chang@fco.gov.uk.

DOC.HEADLINE: Israel representative sends Ramadan greetings to Muslims in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Raphael Gamzou, the head of the Israel Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei (ISECO) , recently sent greetings to the Muslim community in Taiwan at the start of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan.

According to an ISECO press release, Gamzou, Israel's de facto representative to Taiwan, sent a letter to the head of the Muslim community in Taiwan, conveying "warm greetings of health, prosperity and peace."

In addition to his greetings of "Ramadan Karim" to the A-Hung Ma Hsiao and his family, "Gamzou would like to greet the entire Muslim community of Taiwan, in the name of the citizens of Israel-- Jews and Muslims alike," the letter stated.
The letter was meant as a goodwill gesture aimed at bridging cultural and religious barriers and easing longstanding tensions between Muslims and Jews.

Ramadan is a Muslim religious observance that takes place during the ninth month of the Islamic calendar. It is believed to be the month in which the Quran was revealed to the Angel Gabriel, who later revealed it to the Prophet Muhammad.
During Ramadan, participating Muslims do not eat or drink anything from dawn until sunset. Fasting is meant to teach patience, sacrifice and humility.
Ramadan 2009 started on Aug. 21 and will run through Sept. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military retains plan to procure 60 Blackhawk choppers

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Sunday it will go ahead with its original plan to procure 60 U.S.-built Blackhawk helicopters, but will allocate 15 of them to the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) for disaster relief work.
"We reached that decision after consulting with the Interior Ministry," the MND said in a news statement.

The MND's decision was a departure from President Ma Ying-jeou's announcement at a news conference Aug.18 that the military will buy 45 instead of the 60 Blackhawks originally planned and will reassign NT$10 billion of its procurement budget for the purchase of disaster relief choppers and relevant equipment.

Ma's announcement came after an aging UH-1H helicopter from the MOI's National Airborne Service Corps crashed into a mountainside and slid into a valley near the aboriginal settlement of Sandimen in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County Aug. 11 while on a mission to help victims of Typhoon Morakot. The three crew members aboard the helicopter were killed in the crash.
The tragedy reawakened calls for the government to modernize and invigorate the country's emergency relief capacity and facilities.

The MND said in its statement that it has decided to stick to the original number of Blackhawks because this will allow it to acquire the new helicopters in the shortest possible time at the cheapest possible price.
Noting that it has finalized all the preparatory work for the procurement deal, the ministry said any change in the quantity could lead to delivery delays and price adjustments.
The MND further said it will give the first 15 Blackhawks delivered by the U.S. contractor to the National Airborne Service Corps for rescue and relief operations.

"In peacetime, the 15 Blackhawks will mainly operate rescue or disaster relief missions, but in wartime, they will be drafted for combat missions, " according to the MND. "This way, our combat preparedness will not be affected while our national resources can be used to the fullest."
The MND said it will work out further technical details regarding the use of the 15 helicopters, in collaboration with the Interior Ministry.
The UH-60 Blackhawk is a four-bladed, twin-engine, medium-lift utility helicopter manufactured by Sikorsky Aircraft.

Stressing that the Blackhawk is a multi-functional utility chopper, the MND said acquisition of the new choppers will help upgrade both the country's disaster relief operations and military logistics support.

The National Airborne Service Corps has long used aging, single-engine UH-1H choppers provided by the military for post-disaster rescue and relief operations. The aircraft are not suitable for operations at sea or in high mountains. The corps has been pushing for the purchase of new helicopters.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Vision, Red Cross to join forces in storm-recovery work

TEXT.P: The Taiwan chapter of the Christian charity World Vision has decided to partner with the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China to help with the reconstruction of indigenous communities affected by Typhoon Morakot.

"These two leading relief agencies in Taiwan will soon be determining how to coordinate and share resources to build sustainable communities that will maintain the integrity of indigenous cultures," World Vision Taiwan said in a press release.

Hank Du, executive director of World Vision Taiwan, has reached an agreement with Taiwan Red Cross Secretary-General Steven Chen to collaborate on several fronts to help people in storm-stricken indigenous communities rebuild their homes and livelihoods, according to the press release.
The two agencies will openly share information to avoid duplication of work or waste of resources, it added.

World Vision Taiwan, which has over 40 years of experience working with indigenous communities, will be responsible for coordinating with the affected communities to rebuild infrastructure, and the voices and cultural values of the people will be fully respected, the release stated.

World Vision Taiwan said that flexibility will be required to rebuild infrastructure that incorporates sustainability, cultural and religious values, livelihood, child education and development, environment, disaster risk reduction, and social customs.
Community participation will also be part of the process, it added.

The two agencies will cooperate on rehabilitation, based on identified needs, and local church resources will be sought to deliver service and care, World Vision said. Other partners of the Typhoon Morakot Service Alliance will also be invited to help restore livelihoods in affected indigenous communities, it added.
Noting that World Vision has partnered with different entities in the past in post-disaster work, Du said such alliances contribute to greater effectiveness and efficiency.

Typhoon Morakot lashed Taiwan Aug.7-9, dumping massive amounts of rain on the southern parts of the country. The storm killed at least 571 people, and left 33 injured and hundreds unaccounted for. Agricultural losses are estimated at more than NT$ 16.5 billion (US$501 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: Dalai Lama's international news conference may be canceled: official

TEXT.P: An international news conference by the Dalai Lama that was scheduled for Monday morning in Kaohsiung City may be canceled, a Kaohsiung city government source said Sunday.

The city government was informed Sunday by the Tibet Religious Foundation of His Holiness the Dalai Lama, the de facto representative office of the Tibetan government in exile in Taiwan, that the Dalai Lama will proceed to the Typhoon Morakot disaster areas earlier than originally scheduled on Monday, the source said.
"The arrangements for the news conference have been halted, " the city government official said.

However, as of press time, the Kaohsiung city government had not notified the 130-odd media outlets from home and abroad that had registered to attend the news conference of any cancellation of the press conference, the official said.
The Tibetan spiritual leader was scheduled to arrive in Taiwan late Sunday for a six-day visit -- his third to Taiwan. He first visited Taiwan in 1997 and again in 2001.
The Dalai Lama was invited by local government chiefs in southern Taiwan to comfort and pray for the typhoon victims in areas that were hardest hit by Morakot Aug.7-9.

His itinerary includes delivering a speech and presiding over a prayer ceremony at Kaohsiung Arena for typhoon victims on Sept. 1 and meeting with Cardinal Shan Kuo-hsi of the Roman Catholic Church at a Kaohsiung hotel on Sept. 2, the official said.

A local media outlet reported Sunday that a ranking official from the ruling Kuomintang made a telephone call to the Kaohsiung city government Saturday, suggesting that Mayor Chen Chu cancel the Dalai Lama's international news conference and make the "religious visit as simple as possible."
The Kaoshiung city government declined to confirm the report.

China has strongly denounced the trip but has avoided laying the blame on President Ma Ying-jeou, who gave the final approval for the Dalai Lama's visit. Instead, Beijing has accused the opposition Democratic Progressive Party of sabotaging warming cross-Taiwan Strait ties by inviting someone China brands as a "separatist."

DOC.HEADLINE: Dalai Lama distances himself from politics before trip to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/09 18:32:54 (By Paul Kuo and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, issued a three-point statement Sunday prior to his departure for Taiwan for a six-day visit, reiterating that his trip has nothing to do with politics or any political group.
The 1989 Nobel Peace Prize winner said at New Delhi Indira Gandhi International Airport that he is traveling to Taiwan at the invitation of the Taiwanese people, not any political group.

Stressing that the main purpose of his visit is console surviving victims of Typhoon Morakot and release the souls of those killed in the disaster from their suffering, the Dalai Lama said he has not considered any elements other than praying for blessings on and the wellbeing of the Taiwanese people.
His three-point statement was seen as part of his efforts to minimize the sensitivity of his Taiwan trip which has touched a raw nerve in China.

Analysts said his visit could hinder the Tibetan government-in-exile's negotiations with China and may even derail nascent detente between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait which began after President Ma Ying-jeou assumed office in May 2008.
The 75-year-old Tibetan spiritual leader is scheduled to arrive at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport at around 10:30 p.m. Sunday.
This will be his third trip to Taiwan, following his first visit in March 1997 and his second in March 2001.

The Dalai Lama was invited by the heads of seven southern Taiwan cities and counties -- known as strongholds of the pro-independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party -- to host Dharma sermons for typhoon-affected victims.

During his stay, the Dalai Lama is expected to head for some of the worst-hit disaster zones, including Siaolin village where some 400 residents were believed to have been buried alive under a massive landslide triggered by Morakot's torrential rains.
He is scheduled to wrap up his Taiwan visit Sept. 4

DOC.HEADLINE: Regularly scheduled cross-strait flights to begin Monday

TEXT.P: Regularly scheduled cross-Taiwan Strait flights are slated to be launched Monday, but Taiwan is keeping it a low-key affair amid the somber mood that has prevailed islandwide in the wake of the Typhoon Morakot disaster.

"There will be no celebrations to mark the launch of the service, which will increase the number of direct cross-strait flights from 108 to 270 per week, " the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said.

CAA officials noted that the government and Taiwanese air carriers had already celebrated a few months ago the expansion of a special direct charter flight service that was launched to accommodate cross-strait travel during three major national festivals.
On Monday, a total of 44 round-trip direct flights across the strait will be available, the CAA said, adding that nine of them will be between Taiwan and Shanghai.
The first China-bound regular flight from Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport will be a Uni Airways flight, departing at 7:30 a.m. and arriving in Qingdao around 10 a.m.
The first China-bound regular flight from Taipei's Songshan Airport will be a Trans Asia Airways flight, also departing at 7:30 a.m., but arriving in Shanghai around 8:55 a.m., according to the CAA.
The first regular flight from China to Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport will be a China Eastern flight, departing from Ningbo at 9 a.m. and arriving at 10:25 a.m.

The first regular flight from China to Songshan Airport will be a Shanghai Airlines flight, departing from Shanghai's Hongqiao International Airport at 9: 20 a.m. and arriving at 11 a.m., according to the CAA.
With the launch of the regularly scheduled cross-strait flights, the number of mainland China destinations has also been increased from 21 to 27.

Addressing widespread public complaints about high ticket prices, CAA officials said they had urged the air carriers to make some price adjustments. Unconfirmed reports stated that the CAA and the Taiwanese carriers have reached a decision that ticket prices for regular cross-strait flights will be cut by about 15 percent.
Taiwan and China reached an agreement in April, in their third round of negotiations, to increase the number of cross-strait flights from 108 to 270 per week.
Direct air links between Taiwan and China were opened in July last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of H1N1 hospitalized cases rises to 75

TEXT.P: Ten new hospitalized cases of influenza A(H1N1) were confirmed in Taiwan Sunday, bringing the total of such cases to 75, according to the latest tallies released by the Central Epidemic Command Center.

"The rate of increase is not beyond what was expected, " said Steve Kuo, director-general of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health (DOH) . "Generally speaking, the symptoms of all the hospitalized H1N1 patients are mild."
As the number of new infections each week now exceeds 12,000, the number of hospitalized cases can also be expected to rise, Kuo said.
Most notable among the new hospitalized cases is a 1-year-old girl in central Taiwan, who is the youngest such patient in Taiwan.
The nine other new hospitalized cases include four males -- aged 3, 7, 13, and 27 -- and five females -- aged 12, 18, and 45, and two 6-year-olds.
The 75 hospitalized cases included five fatalities, 39 patients who have recovered, and 31 others who are still receiving treatment at hospitals, Kuo said.

With local elementary and junior high schools about to reopen Monday after the summer break, the epidemic command center announced Sunday that the CDC will release 2 million face masks next week in an effort to meet a possible increase in demand and to stabilize prices.
DOH Deputy Minister Chang Shan-chwen said there is no shortage of masks in the local market right now.

"What is lacking are cheap face masks. Therefore, the CDC will release 2 million into the market, priced at NT$6 each," Chang said. The NT$6 masks will be available at franchised outlets of four major convenience store chains around Taiwan in seven days time, he added.
Cheap masks will also be available later at drug stores, he said, adding that the move is aimed at driving down the price of face masks.
Cases of sellers hoarding masks can be reported to county and city consumer rights protection offices, Chang said.
Meanwhile, he denied a newspaper report which claimed he had suggested that the N1H1 vaccine, to be available soon, will not be safe for pregnant women in their first trimester.

"The report is not true. I have never made such a recommendation, " Chang said, adding that pregnant women in their first trimester will be free to decide whether or not they want to be inoculated against the H1N1 virus.

According to Chang, the World Health Organization and the United States have suggested that pregnant women be vaccinated against both seasonal and swine flu strains because they are likely to become severe cases if they are infected.
"Neither the WHO nor the United States has especially recommended that the H1N1 vaccine will not be safe for pregnant women in their first trimester," he said.
In Taiwan, the DOH has put pregnant women on the priority list for swine flu inoculation, but they will not be forced to have the vaccine, Chang stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Will Muzha-Neihu MRT line be shut down during Deaflympics?

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Sunday the city government will decide by Sept. 1 whether to shut down the problematic Muzha-Neihu MRT Line during the Deaflympics.

The metro line, which integrates the Muzha segment that was built by French contractor Matra Co. in the 1990s and the Neihu segment built by Canadian contractor Bombadier, has experienced eight emergency shutdowns since its inauguration July 4.
Critics have suggested that the MRT line be closed during the 21st Summer Deaflympics in Taipei Sept.5-15 to spare the city the embarrassment of a breakdown during that period.
Hau said Bombadier has been working on a project to fine tune the Muzha-Neihu line's network system.
The line has suspended operations over the past two weekends (Aug.22-23 and Aug.29-30) to enable the contractor to fine tune the computer software project and conduct dynamic and static testing.

According to electric engineering experts with Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC), the ATM network program will protect the whole system from a complete breakdown if a single facility fails or malfunctions, as it will keep the problem confined to a single station or segment of the line.
Moreover, the experts said all of the line's 24 stations have been equipped with a second uninterrupted power system (UPS) to enhance operational stability.

"After all these upgrades are completed, we will conduct an overall review to decide whether the entire line should remain operational or be shut down during the Deaflympics," Hau said, adding that an announcement will be made no later than Sept. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese Deaflympics team to arrive Saturday

TEXT.P: The Chinese team that will compete in the upcoming Deaflympics is expected to arrive in Taipei on Sept. 5 at the earliest, Taipei City government officials said Sunday.
The officials said that the team will be comprised of 70-odd athletes and about 50 team officials.
With the Deaflympics poised to open at 7:30 p.m. Saturday, teams from various participating countries have been arriving in Taiwan over the past week.
Emile C. J. Sheng, chief executive officer of the organizing committee for the Taipei Deaflympics, will give a news conference on Chinese team's activities in Taiwan Monday.
Chinese team was absent at the World Games opening in Kaohsiung in July.
The Deaflympics is one of four games regulated by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) . Its events are similar to those of the Olympic Games and are governed by the same rules.
The 21st Summer Deaflympics in Taipei is expected to bring together about 4,000 athletes and sports officials from 101 countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dalai Lama arrives in Taiwan for religious visit

TEXT.P: The Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, arrived in Taiwan late Sunday for a six-day visit aimed at consoling victims of Typhoon Morakot, one of the worst natural disasters ever to hit Taiwan.

The 1989 Nobel Peace Prize winner traveled to the southern port city of Kaohsiung via a bullet train shortly after his arrival at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, some 40 kilometers south of Taipei.
During his stay, the 75-year-old Dalai Lama will spend most of time visiting areas hit hard by Typhoon Morakot, which pummeled Taiwan Aug.7-9 and left more than 600 people dead or missing.

He originally planned to host an international news conference Monday morning, but has canceled that event and will instead visit Siaolin village in Kaohsiung County. Some 400 Siaolin residents were believed to have been buried alive under a massive landslide triggered by Morakot's torrential rains.

The Dalai Lama said at New Delhi Indira Gandhi International Airport before flying to Taiwan that his visit was strictly non-political and a "moral responsibility" after a massive storm devastated the island.
"I'm very, very strict, (the trip is of a) non-political nature," he said in television footage shown by TVBS cable news channel.
He further said he believes his visit will not affect relations across the Taiwan Strait.
His statement was seen as part of his efforts to minimize the sensitivity of his Taiwan trip which has touched a raw nerve in China.

Analysts said his visit could hinder the Tibetan government-in-exile's negotiations with China and may even derail nascent detente between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait which began after President Ma Ying-jeou assumed office in May 2008.

The Dalai Lama was invited by the heads of seven southern Taiwan cities and counties -- known as strongholds of the pro-independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party -- to host Dharma sermons for typhoon-affected victims.
He is scheduled to wrap up his visit Sept.4.
