DOC.HEADLINE: Number of hospitalized H1N1 patients rises to 80

TEXT.P: Five more patients with influenza A (H1N1) were hospitalized in Taiwan Monday, bringing the total to 80 since the outbreak began, according to the latest tallies released by the Central Epidemics Command Center.
Steve Kuo, director-general of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health (DOH), said the rate of increase was not beyond expectations.
Kuo said the new patients include three males and two females ranging in age from 8 to 49 who come from northern and central Taiwan.
Of the 80 patients hospitalized to date, five have died and 36 have recovered. The youngest hospitalized case involves a 23-month-old girl whose condition is mild, Kuo said.
Meanwhile, Kuo said the CDC will release enough of the anti-viral drug Tamiflu to treat 250,000 people to health offices in cities and counties around Taiwan Tuesday to meet the demand.
That will leave the government with a Tamiflu capsule inventory large enough to treat another 260,000 people, Kuo said.

"There has been no pressure yet at grassroots medical institutions to obtain Tamiflu, " Kuo said, but he explained that if the capsules in stock are not sufficient to meet demand, the CDC will release the powdered form of Tamiflu it has in inventory so that hospitals can produce the liquid form of the drug.

Kuo outlined the Tamiflu situation after Chen Chien-jen, a DOH minister under the previous administation, said in a letter published in a local newspaper Monday that all of Taiwan's Tamiflu inventory was purchased when the Democratic Progressive Party was in power.
The Academia Sinica academician argued that the current Kuomintang government has an insufficient supply of anti-viral medication to cope with the ongoing fight againt swine flu.

According to Kuo, the CDC's inventory of Tamiflu and another anti-viral drug Relenza is sufficient for use by 18 percent of Taiwan's population, and he said the epidemic command center has decided to raise the inventory to cover 30 percent of the population.
Kuo said the command center will publish a report Tuesday on its procurement of anti-viral drugs.

At present, aside from the powdered form of Tamiflu, which can cover more than 2 million patients, and the Tamiflu capsules, the government has also inventoried enough Relenza to treat 970,000 patients.
It has also stocked four tons of shikimic acid, the base material to produce Tamiflu, which could quickly be used to manufacture enough of the drug for another 1 million patients.

In the future, for every three doses of anti-viral drugs the government intends to buy, two will be Tamiflu and one will be Relenza to be able to treat the H1N1 patients who develop a resistance to Tamiflu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local entrepreneurs supporting reconstruction programs

TEXT.P: More than 100 business tycoons lent their support Monday to an Executive Yuan- initiated home and industry reconstruction program in the areas badly damaged by Typhoon Morakot earlier in the month.

They included Hon Hai Precision Industry Chairman Terry Gou, Far Eastern Group Chairman Douglas Hsu, Kinpo Group Chairman Rock Hsu, Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries Chairman Chen Wu-hsiung, and ASUSTek Computer Chairman Johnny Shih.
The entrepreneurs attended a ceremony hosted by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan at the Executive Yuan to launch the government's move to seek the business sector's help with the post-disaster reconstruction.
In his address, Liu expressed hope that the sector can use its special skills and resources to help build not just "houses" but "homes" for the typhoon victims.

Introducing the government's plans to invite enterprises to get involved in the home reconstruction, Liu stated that the projects will be carried out according to a "green concept" and that the new buildings will be equipped with "smart living" systems including safety- and environment-monitoring networks, as well as Wi-Max connections.

In terms of the restoration of industrial and commercial activities in typhoon- battered areas, Liu said the government has mapped out plans to develop niche- market agriculture and tourism in the affected areas to help create employment opportunities.

Gou suggested that the government could impose a special tax on stock market deals in an effort to raise funds to deal with flood problems and he also advised the government stop increasing its debts.

The typhoon swept through Taiwan Aug. 7-9, triggering the worst flooding in 50 years in southern Taiwan and causing serious casualties and losses. As of 5: 30 p.m. Monday, the death toll had reached 602 with 81 people still reported missing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mobile image system developed to help shoppers make wise decisions

TEXT.P: A local research team has developed a mobile image query with pseudo-object system that can help shoppers learn more about prices for similar products.

"The new system allows a mobile phone user to get information about the appearances, styles, and prices of items similar to the product a consumer plans to buy, " said Winston H. Hsu, an associate professor at NTU's Graduate Institute of Computer Science and Information Engineering, who led the research team to develop the new system.
According to Hsu, the shopper needs only to photograph the product with a mobile phone to get related information almost instantly.
"By so doing, the shopper will get a sense of prevailing market prices," Hsu said.
"I got the idea to develop the system after I went shopping with my wife one time at a local department store," he recalled.
His wife intended to buy a handbag for NT$50,000.
"She asked me whether it was too expensive. I had no idea about handbag prices then and could not give her any advice, " Hsu said, prompting him to develop the multimedia system.
Hsu said the system has been patented and that he is discussing cooperative projects with local system developers and online shopping companies.
The system will also be applied in the future to identify local landmarks, Hsu said.
"For instance, if you reach a location and have no idea about a certain building, you can photograph it and then get information on it online," he explained.

The system was one of the 23 multimedia products developed under a cooperative project between NTU and the National Science Council, all of which were introduced at a news conference held earlier in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dalai Lama visits storm-affected areas in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Dalai Lama drew welcoming crowds in southern Taiwan Monday as he began his tour of areas hard-hit by Typhoon Morakot and prayed for those who lost their families and homes in flooding and mudslides caused by the storm.

In Siaolin village, which had hundreds of its residents buried alive by a landslide in the storm, the exiled Tibetan leader put his palms together in prayer while a monk next to him recited a Buddhist sutra.

Braving the sweltering heat, many typhoon-affected victims took the belongings of their loved ones who perished in the storm to the site, hoping that their souls could rest in peace following the Dalai Lama's prayer.
After the ceremony, which lasted 10 minutes, the Dalai Lama greeted the typhoon- affected victims surrounding him.
He said that although many survived the typhoon, some people lost their family members and good friends, and he wanted to share their sorrow and sadness, which is the main purpose of his visit.
Facing the dogged media throng around him, he was articulate and did not shun from sensitive political questions.
He stressed that his visit has "no political agenda" and that he has nothing to discuss with the leader of this country, saying he doesn't "want to create any inconvenience (for) anybody."

Asked about his views on cross-strait relations, he said that Taiwanese politicians, including those from the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , do not seek "separation" from China.
"Taiwan should have really close unique links with mainland China," the Dalai Lama said.
He later traveled to Jiadong, a town on the southwestern coast of Pingtung County that was heavily flooded during the typhoon, to pray for the quick recovery of the town and its people.
In a pouring rain that began when he arrived in the coastal town, the Dalai Lama said people were traumatized because of the disaster, but urged them not to lose faith but start a new life.
Shortly after he left, the pouring rain stopped and the sun came out, and many of his followers interpreted the temporary rain as a good omen for the affected area and its victims.

Before heading to disaster areas Monday morning, the Dalai Lama was greeted outside his hotel in Kaohsiung by about 20 aboriginal protesters from Paiwan and Rukai tribal villages in Pingtung County that were also battered by the typhoon.
They were unhappy that the Dalai Lama did not plan to visit aboriginal villages during his time in Taiwan and that he had only come with prayers but no substantial relief resources.
They displayed white banners displaying the words, "We don't want the Dalai Lama politics, we want his food and shelter," and "We need relief resources, not verbal prayers."
They said, however, that they would be happy if the Dalai Lama consented to stay in Taiwan for a longer period of time to help the victims.
There were also several supporters and members of the U.N. For Taiwan Association who welcomed the Tibetan spiritual leader's visit.
About 40 policemen were dispatched to maintain order around the hotel where the Dalai Lama was staying.

Beijing has said it "resolutely opposes" the Dalai Lama's visit, and a Chinese official involved in Taiwan affairs warned Sunday night that his trip "is bound to have a negative influence on the relations between the mainland and Taiwan."

Unflustered by the commotion, the Dalai Lama said the diversity of responses was a wonderful sign of democracy and freedom of speech, and he emphasized that he did not plan any political statements but came here solely for humanitarian purposes.

"We are not seeking separation for Taiwan, but the fate of Taiwan depends on the more than 20 million people, " he said. "You are enjoying democracy and that you must preserve. I myself am totally dedicated to the promotion of democracy."
Despite the Dalai Lama's insistence that his trip is strictly for humanitarian and religious purposes, some of his itinerary has been changed.

A press conference scheduled for Monday and a speech scheduled in the Taoyuan Arena for later in the week were canceled and an event in the 15,000-seat Kaohsiung Arena has been moved to the Garden Villa, which can only accommodate an audience of 700 people.
Chow Mei-li, the president of the "Taiwan Friends of Tibet, " accused China of putting pressure on Taiwan's authorities to cancel or downsize the events.

However, Dawa Tsering, chairman of the Tibet Religious Foundation of H.H. The Dalai Lama, explained that the Tibetan leader changed the venue of the Kaohsiung speech because it would have required 5,000 policemen to maintain order at Kaohsiung Arena, which in the Dalai Lama's opinion was too much.
Dawa Tsering also said the Taoyuan Arena speech was canceled because the site had already been booked.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former health minister fails in Hualien magistrate race bid

TEXT.P: Former Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan has lost a primary held by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) to determine its nominee in the year-end race for magistrate in eastern Taiwan's Hualien County.
Yeh, known as a hero in the war on SARS in 2003, was defeated by Tu Li-hua, the county's former Agricultural Development Office chief, in a three-day telephone poll.
Tu won the support of 54.5 percent of the interviewed voters in the county to secure the KMT's nomination as its candidate in the county chief election.
Yeh, who resigned from the post of health minister earlier this month to run in the primary, said he had too little time to prepare for the race.
He also said he will be glad to stump for Tu if she asks for his assistance in her campaign activities.
Despite the failure, Yeh will remain in Hualien until the end of the year to offer services to his supporters.

Fu Kun-chi, a KMT legislator who was excluded from the primary by the party's Organization and Development Committee because of a conviction on illegal stock speculation that he is currently appealing, has still not decided whether to run in the county magistrate election as an independent.
Hualien County is one of the most strongly pro-KMT districts in Taiwan, and Tu is almost a sure winner of the race if the popular Fu does not enter the race.

DOC.HEADLINE: Last batch of China-donated prefab houses arrives in Taiwan

TEXT.P: A shipment of 400 prefabricated houses -- the last batch of a total of 1,000 prefabs donated by China for people rendered homeless by Typhoon Morakot -- arrived in Taiwan Monday, unaffected by the Dalai Lama's visit to the country.

The quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said in a statement said it had taken control of the cargo after it arrived at the No. 70 pier in Kaohsiung Harbor and handed it over to the Ministry of the Interior.

In the statement, the SEF said the shipment completed delivery of the houses donated by China, and it thanked Beijing for the assistance it had provided to thousands of typhoon victims in southern Taiwan.
The Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of Tibet, arrived in Taiwan Sunday for a six-day visit aimed at consoling and praying for typhoon victims.
The visit, however, has displeased Beijing, which warned that the Dalai Lama's visit would affect improved cross-strait ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: People's Bank of China deputy head defers Taiwan visit

TEXT.P: People's Bank of China (PBC) Deputy Governor Su Ning, who was originally scheduled to lead a high-level banking delegation to Taiwan Monday to attend a seminar, has postponed his visit for a week.

The postponement of Su's trip, which came after the Dalai Lama arrived in Taiwan late Sunday for a six-day visit, was seen as a Chinese gesture to show its anger at Taiwan's approval of the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader's visit.
China has branded the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize winner as a "separatist" and has never hesitated to retaliate against any country that has hosted him.

The co-organizer of the seminar that the Su-led delegation was expected to attend -- the Taipei Foundation of Finance -- received a message Sunday from its Chinese counterpart -- The China Society for Finance and Banking -- saying that because of "technical reasons, "the Su-led delegation could not travel to Taipei Monday as scheduled.

The Chinese association, which will co-organize the seminar, further said in its message that if the Taipei foundation agrees to reschedule the seminar, the Su- led delegation will fly to Taiwan a week later on Sept. 7.
As a result, the Taipei foundation said the planned seminar on the development of bill financing markets on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will be rescheduled for Sept. 8.
In addition to attending the seminar, the Chinese delegation will also visit relevant financial and banking institutions and travel to central and southern Taiwan during its stay.
The Chinese delegation will be composed of senior officials of major Chinese banks in charge of bills financing business.

DOC.HEADLINE: Record number of snake-eating turtles seized at Kaohsiung Airport

TEXT.P: A total of 1,255 protected Chinese yellow margined box turtles have been seized at Kaohsiung International Airport, a customs official said Monday.

The snake-eating turtles, known by the scientific name Cuora flavomarginata, were uncovered last weekend when customs officers inspected an export shipment that was listed as green-headed turtles, or Ocadia sinensis, on the customs declaration form, the official said.
It marked the first time that the Kaohsiung customs office has ever seized such a large number of protected animal species to be sent abroad, the official said.

The turtles were placed in 50 well-packed cases, each containing three plastic containers separated by dividers. Unfastening the screws securing the dividers proved difficult and time-consuming, but customs officers discovered the protected turtles in the containers below those packed at the top of each carton.
A close examination by experts from National Pingtung University of Science and Technology confirmed that the animals were a protected species barred from being exported, the official said.

Noting that the would-be exporter has violated the Wildlife Protection Act and smuggling regulations, the official said the customs office has referred the case to relevant authorities for processing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gambia donates US$700,000 to help Taiwan's typhoon victims

TEXT.P: The West African country of The Gambia has donated US$700,000 to help with relief projects in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot, which wreaked havoc in Taiwan Aug. 7-9, diplomatic officials said Monday.
Gambian Vice President Isatou Njie-Saidy presented the donation to Republic of China Ambassador Richard Shih in a ceremony held at the Gambian Presidential Office last Friday, the officials said.
Njie-Saidy also expressed condolences and sympathy for typhoon-affected Taiwanese citizens on behalf of The Gambian government and people.
Morakot-triggered flooding and landslides have left more than 600 people dead or missing and rendered thousands of people homeless.

As of Monday, 85 countries, international organizations, non-government organizations and charities have extended condolences, provided relief supplies or made cash donations to help Taiwanese typhoon victims, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Foreign donations for post-Morakot relief projects had amounted to NT$380 million (US$11.52 million) as of Aug. 31.

DOC.HEADLINE: Live broadcast for Dalai Lama's speech Tuesday

TEXT.P: A speech to be made by the Dalai Lama on Tuesday will be broadcast live, the Tibet Religious Foundation of His Holiness the Dalai Lama said Monday.
The foundation, in a press release, said the Dalai Lama had originally planned to give a speech on "One World, Common Responsibility" Sept. 1 at Kaohsiung Arena, which has more than 10,000 seats.

But the organizer, out of concern for the personal safety of the Tibetan spiritual leader and a wish to mitigate the inconvenience brought to others, has changed the speech venue to Garden Villa, the hotel and conference center where he is currently staying.
Only 1,200 people will be able to attend the speech in person, but Public Television Service will broadcast it live from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m. and televise it again at midnight.
The Dalai Lama's prayer service for the typhoon-affected victims is scheduled for between 9: 30 a.m and 11: 30 a.m. and will still take place at Kaohsiung Arena.

The Dalai Lama, who arrived in Taiwan Sunday for a six-day visit to console typhoon-affected victims in southern Taiwan, will meet with Cardinal Paul Shan Kuo-hsi Wednesday between 9:30 a.m. and noon.
